It is a record of several years of\r\nvariegated vagabondizing, and its object is rather to help the resting\r\nreader while away an idle hour than afflict him with metaphysics, or\r\ngoad him with science. Still, there is information in the volume;\r\ninformation concerning an interesting episode in the history of the Far\r\nWest, about which no books have been written by persons who were on the\r\nground in person, and saw the happenings of the time with their own\r\neyes. I allude to the rise, growth and culmination of the silver-mining\r\nfever in Nevada\xe2\x80\x94a curious episode, in some respects; the only one, of\r\nits peculiar kind, that has occurred in the land; and the only one,\r\nindeed, that is likely to occur in it.\r\n\r\nYes, take it all around, there is quite a good deal of information in\r\nthe book. I regret this very much; but really it could not be helped:\r\ninformation appears to stew out of me naturally, like the precious ottar\r\nof roses out of the otter. Sometimes it has seemed to me that I would\r\ngive worlds if I could retain my facts; but it cannot be. The more I\r\ncalk up the sources, and the tighter I get, the more I leak wisdom.\r\nTherefore, I can only claim indulgence at the hands of the reader, not\r\njustification.\r\n\r\nTHE AUTHOR.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCONTENTS.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I. THE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I.\r\n\r\n\r\nMy brother had just been appointed Secretary of Nevada Territory\xe2\x80\x94an\r\noffice of such majesty that it concentrated in itself the duties and\r\ndignities of Treasurer, Comptroller, Secretary of State, and Acting\r\nGovernor in the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s absence. A salary of eighteen hundred dollars\r\na year and the title of \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Secretary,\xe2\x80\x9d gave to the great position an\r\nair of wild and imposing grandeur. I was young and ignorant, and I\r\nenvied my brother. I coveted his distinction and his financial splendor,\r\nbut particularly and especially the long, strange journey he was going\r\nto make, and the curious new world he was going to explore. He was going\r\nto travel! I never had been away from home, and that word \xe2\x80\x9ctravel\xe2\x80\x9d had a\r\nseductive charm for me. Pretty soon he would be hundreds and hundreds of\r\nmiles away on the great plains and deserts, and among the mountains of\r\nthe Far West, and would see buffaloes and Indians, and prairie dogs, and\r\nantelopes, and have all kinds of adventures, and may be get hanged or\r\nscalped, and have ever such a fine time, and write home and tell us all\r\nabout it, and be a hero. And he would see the gold mines and the silver\r\nmines, and maybe go about of an afternoon when his work was done, and\r\npick up two or three pailfuls of shining slugs, and nuggets of gold and\r\nsilver on the hillside. And by and by he would become very rich, and\r\nreturn home by sea, and be able to talk as calmly about San Francisco\r\nand the ocean, and \xe2\x80\x9cthe isthmus\xe2\x80\x9d as if it was nothing of any consequence\r\nto have seen those marvels face to face.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n020.jpg (69K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat I suffered in contemplating his happiness, pen cannot describe. And\r\nso, when he offered me, in cold blood, the sublime position of private\r\nsecretary under him, it appeared to me that the heavens and the earth\r\npassed away, and the firmament was rolled together as a scroll! I had\r\nnothing more to desire. My contentment was complete.\r\n\r\nAt the end of an hour or two I was ready for the journey. Not much\r\npacking up was necessary, because we were going in the overland stage\r\nfrom the Missouri frontier to Nevada, and passengers were only allowed a\r\nsmall quantity of baggage apiece. There was no Pacific railroad in those\r\nfine times of ten or twelve years ago\xe2\x80\x94not a single rail of it. I only\r\nproposed to stay in Nevada three months\xe2\x80\x94I had no thought of staying\r\nlonger than that. I meant to see all I could that was new and strange,\r\nand then hurry home to business. I little thought that I would not see\r\nthe end of that three-month pleasure excursion for six or seven\r\nuncommonly long years!\r\n\r\nI dreamed all night about Indians, deserts, and silver bars, and in due\r\ntime, next day, we took shipping at the St. Louis wharf on board a\r\nsteamboat bound up the Missouri River.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n021.jpg (82K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe were six days going from St. Louis to \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Jo.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a trip that was so\r\ndull, and sleepy, and eventless that it has left no more impression on\r\nmy memory than if its duration had been six minutes instead of that many\r\ndays. No record is left in my mind, now, concerning it, but a confused\r\njumble of savage-looking snags, which we deliberately walked over with\r\none wheel or the other; and of reefs which we butted and butted, and\r\nthen retired from and climbed over in some softer place; and of sand-\r\nbars which we roosted on occasionally, and rested, and then got out our\r\ncrutches and sparred over.\r\n\r\nIn fact, the boat might almost as well have gone to St. Jo. by land, for\r\nshe was walking most of the time, anyhow\xe2\x80\x94climbing over reefs and\r\nclambering over snags patiently and laboriously all day long. The\r\ncaptain said she was a \xe2\x80\x9cbully\xe2\x80\x9d boat, and all she wanted was more \xe2\x80\x9cshear\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand a bigger wheel. I thought she wanted a pair of stilts, but I had the\r\ndeep sagacity not to say so.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHaPTER II.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe first thing we did on that glad evening that landed us at St. Joseph\r\nwas to hunt up the stage-office, and pay a hundred and fifty dollars\r\napiece for tickets per overland coach to Carson City, Nevada.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n023a.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next morning, bright and early, we took a hasty breakfast, and\r\nhurried to the starting-place. Then an inconvenience presented itself\r\nwhich we had not properly appreciated before, namely, that one cannot\r\nmake a heavy traveling trunk stand for twenty-five pounds of\r\nbaggage\xe2\x80\x94because it weighs a good deal more. But that was all we could\r\ntake\xe2\x80\x94twenty-five pounds each. So we had to snatch our trunks open, and\r\nmake a selection in a good deal of a hurry. We put our lawful twenty-\r\nfive pounds apiece all in one valise, and shipped the trunks back to St.\r\nLouis again. It was a sad parting, for now we had no swallow-tail coats\r\nand white kid gloves to wear at Pawnee receptions in the Rocky\r\nMountains, and no stove-pipe hats nor patent-leather boots, nor anything\r\nelse necessary to make life calm and peaceful. We were reduced to a war-\r\nfooting. Each of us put on a rough, heavy suit of clothing, woolen army\r\nshirt and \xe2\x80\x9cstogy\xe2\x80\x9d boots included; and into the valise we crowded a few\r\nwhite shirts, some under-clothing and such things. My brother, the\r\nSecretary, took along about four pounds of United States statutes and\r\nsix pounds of Unabridged Dictionary; for we did not know\xe2\x80\x94poor\r\ninnocents\xe2\x80\x94that such things could be bought in San Francisco on one day\r\nand received in Carson City the next. I was armed to the teeth with a\r\npitiful little Smith & Wesson\xe2\x80\x99s seven-shooter, which carried a ball like\r\na homoeopathic pill, and it took the whole seven to make a dose for an\r\nadult. But I thought it was grand. It appeared to me to be a dangerous\r\nweapon. It only had one fault\xe2\x80\x94you could not hit anything with it. One of\r\nour \xe2\x80\x9cconductors\xe2\x80\x9d practiced awhile on a cow with it, and as long as she\r\nstood still and behaved herself she was safe; but as soon as she went to\r\nmoving about, and he got to shooting at other things, she came to grief.\r\nThe Secretary had a small-sized Colt\xe2\x80\x99s revolver strapped around him for\r\nprotection against the Indians, and to guard against accidents he\r\ncarried it uncapped. Mr. George Bemis was dismally formidable. George\r\nBemis was our fellow-traveler.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n023b.jpg (11K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe had never seen him before. He wore in his belt an old original\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllen\xe2\x80\x9d revolver, such as irreverent people called a \xe2\x80\x9cpepper-box.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSimply drawing the trigger back, cocked and fired the pistol. As the\r\ntrigger came back, the hammer would begin to rise and the barrel to turn\r\nover, and presently down would drop the hammer, and away would speed the\r\nball. To aim along the turning barrel and hit the thing aimed at was a\r\nfeat which was probably never done with an \xe2\x80\x9cAllen\xe2\x80\x9d in the world. But\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x99s was a reliable weapon, nevertheless, because, as one of the\r\nstage-drivers afterward said, \xe2\x80\x9cIf she didn\xe2\x80\x99t get what she went after,\r\nshe would fetch something else.\xe2\x80\x9d And so she did. She went after a deuce\r\nof spades nailed against a tree, once, and fetched a mule standing about\r\nthirty yards to the left of it. Bemis did not want the mule; but the\r\nowner came out with a double-barreled shotgun and persuaded him to buy\r\nit, anyhow. It was a cheerful weapon\xe2\x80\x94the \xe2\x80\x9cAllen.\xe2\x80\x9d Sometimes all its six\r\nbarrels would go off at once, and then there was no safe place in all\r\nthe region round about, but behind it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n024.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe took two or three blankets for protection against frosty weather in\r\nthe mountains. In the matter of luxuries we were modest\xe2\x80\x94we took none\r\nalong but some pipes and five pounds of smoking tobacco. We had two\r\nlarge canteens to carry water in, between stations on the Plains, and we\r\nalso took with us a little shot-bag of silver coin for daily expenses in\r\nthe way of breakfasts and dinners.\r\n\r\nBy eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock everything was ready, and we were on the other side of\r\nthe river. We jumped into the stage, the driver cracked his whip, and we\r\nbowled away and left \xe2\x80\x9cthe States\xe2\x80\x9d behind us. It was a superb summer\r\nmorning, and all the landscape was brilliant with sunshine. There was a\r\nfreshness and breeziness, too, and an exhilarating sense of emancipation\r\nfrom all sorts of cares and responsibilities, that almost made us feel\r\nthat the years we had spent in the close, hot city, toiling and slaving,\r\nhad been wasted and thrown away. We were spinning along through Kansas,\r\nand in the course of an hour and a half we were fairly abroad on the\r\ngreat Plains. Just here the land was rolling\xe2\x80\x94a grand sweep of regular\r\nelevations and depressions as far as the eye could reach\xe2\x80\x94like the\r\nstately heave and swell of the ocean\xe2\x80\x99s bosom after a storm. And\r\neverywhere were cornfields, accenting with squares of deeper green, this\r\nlimitless expanse of grassy land. But presently this sea upon dry ground\r\nwas to lose its \xe2\x80\x9crolling\xe2\x80\x9d character and stretch away for seven hundred\r\nmiles as level as a floor!\r\n\r\nOur coach was a great swinging and swaying stage, of the most sumptuous\r\ndescription\xe2\x80\x94an imposing cradle on wheels. It was drawn by six handsome\r\nhorses, and by the side of the driver sat the \xe2\x80\x9cconductor,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nlegitimate captain of the craft; for it was his business to take charge\r\nand care of the mails, baggage, express matter, and passengers. We three\r\nwere the only passengers, this trip. We sat on the back seat, inside.\r\nAbout all the rest of the coach was full of mail bags\xe2\x80\x94for we had three\r\ndays\xe2\x80\x99 delayed mails with us. Almost touching our knees, a perpendicular\r\nwall of mail matter rose up to the roof. There was a great pile of it\r\nstrapped on top of the stage, and both the fore and hind boots were\r\nfull. We had twenty-seven hundred pounds of it aboard, the driver\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca little for Brigham, and Carson, and \xe2\x80\x99Frisco, but the heft of it\r\nfor the Injuns, which is powerful troublesome \xe2\x80\x99thout they get plenty of\r\ntruck to read.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n026.jpg (65K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut as he just then got up a fearful convulsion of his countenance which\r\nwas suggestive of a wink being swallowed by an earthquake, we guessed\r\nthat his remark was intended to be facetious, and to mean that we would\r\nunload the most of our mail matter somewhere on the Plains and leave it\r\nto the Indians, or whosoever wanted it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n025.jpg (32K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe changed horses every ten miles, all day long, and fairly flew over\r\nthe hard, level road. We jumped out and stretched our legs every time\r\nthe coach stopped, and so the night found us still vivacious and\r\nunfatigued.\r\n\r\nAfter supper a woman got in, who lived about fifty miles further on, and\r\nwe three had to take turns at sitting outside with the driver and\r\nconductor. Apparently she was not a talkative woman. She would sit there\r\nin the gathering twilight and fasten her steadfast eyes on a mosquito\r\nrooting into her arm, and slowly she would raise her other hand till she\r\nhad got his range, and then she would launch a slap at him that would\r\nhave jolted a cow; and after that she would sit and contemplate the\r\ncorpse with tranquil satisfaction\xe2\x80\x94for she never missed her mosquito; she\r\nwas a dead shot at short range. She never removed a carcase, but left\r\nthem there for bait. I sat by this grim Sphynx and watched her kill\r\nthirty or forty mosquitoes\xe2\x80\x94watched her, and waited for her to say\r\nsomething, but she never did. So I finally opened the conversation\r\nmyself. I said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mosquitoes are pretty bad, about here, madam.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou bet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I understand you to say, madam?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou BET!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n027.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen she cheered up, and faced around and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDanged if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t begin to think you fellers was deef and dumb. I did,\r\nb\xe2\x80\x99gosh. Here I\xe2\x80\x99ve sot, and sot, and sot, a-bust\xe2\x80\x99n muskeeters and\r\nwonderin\xe2\x80\x99 what was ailin\xe2\x80\x99 ye. Fust I thot you was deef and dumb, then I\r\nthot you was sick or crazy, or suthin\xe2\x80\x99, and then by and by I begin to\r\nreckon you was a passel of sickly fools that couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of nothing\r\nto say. Wher\xe2\x80\x99d ye come from?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Sphynx was a Sphynx no more! The fountains of her great deep were\r\nbroken up, and she rained the nine parts of speech forty days and forty\r\nnights, metaphorically speaking, and buried us under a desolating deluge\r\nof trivial gossip that left not a crag or pinnacle of rejoinder\r\nprojecting above the tossing waste of dislocated grammar and decomposed\r\npronunciation!\r\n\r\nHow we suffered, suffered, suffered! She went on, hour after hour, till\r\nI was sorry I ever opened the mosquito question and gave her a start.\r\nShe never did stop again until she got to her journey\xe2\x80\x99s end toward\r\ndaylight; and then she stirred us up as she was leaving the stage (for\r\nwe were nodding, by that time), and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you git out at Cottonwood, you fellers, and lay over a couple o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndays, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll be along some time to-night, and if I can do ye any good\r\nby edgin\xe2\x80\x99 in a word now and then, I\xe2\x80\x99m right thar. Folks\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve always ben kind o\xe2\x80\x99 offish and partic\xe2\x80\x99lar for a gal that\xe2\x80\x99s raised in\r\nthe woods, and I am, with the rag-tag and bob-tail, and a gal _has_ to\r\nbe, if she wants to _be_ anything, but when people comes along which is\r\nmy equals, I reckon I\xe2\x80\x99m a pretty sociable heifer after all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe resolved not to \xe2\x80\x9clay by at Cottonwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III.\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout an hour and a half before daylight we were bowling along smoothly\r\nover the road\xe2\x80\x94so smoothly that our cradle only rocked in a gentle,\r\nlulling way, that was gradually soothing us to sleep, and dulling our\r\nconsciousness\xe2\x80\x94when something gave away under us! We were dimly aware of\r\nit, but indifferent to it. The coach stopped. We heard the driver and\r\nconductor talking together outside, and rummaging for a lantern, and\r\nswearing because they could not find it\xe2\x80\x94but we had no interest in\r\nwhatever had happened, and it only added to our comfort to think of\r\nthose people out there at work in the murky night, and we snug in our\r\nnest with the curtains drawn. But presently, by the sounds, there seemed\r\nto be an examination going on, and then the driver\xe2\x80\x99s voice said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy George, the thoroughbrace is broke!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis startled me broad awake\xe2\x80\x94as an undefined sense of calamity is always\r\napt to do. I said to myself: \xe2\x80\x9cNow, a thoroughbrace is probably part of a\r\nhorse; and doubtless a vital part, too, from the dismay in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvoice. Leg, maybe\xe2\x80\x94and yet how could he break his leg waltzing along such\r\na road as this? No, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be his leg. That is impossible, unless he\r\nwas reaching for the driver. Now, what can be the thoroughbrace of a\r\nhorse, I wonder? Well, whatever comes, I shall not air my ignorance in\r\nthis crowd, anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then the conductor\xe2\x80\x99s face appeared at a lifted curtain, and his\r\nlantern glared in on us and our wall of mail matter. He said: \xe2\x80\x9cGents,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll have to turn out a spell. Thoroughbrace is broke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe climbed out into a chill drizzle, and felt ever so homeless and\r\ndreary. When I found that the thing they called a \xe2\x80\x9cthoroughbrace\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\nthe massive combination of belts and springs which the coach rocks\r\nitself in, I said to the driver:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never saw a thoroughbrace used up like that, before, that I can\r\nremember. How did it happen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it happened by trying to make one coach carry three days\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmail\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s how it happened,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd right here is the very\r\ndirection which is wrote on all the newspaper-bags which was to be put\r\nout for the Injuns for to keep \xe2\x80\x99em quiet. It\xe2\x80\x99s most uncommon lucky,\r\nbecuz it\xe2\x80\x99s so nation dark I should \xe2\x80\x99a\xe2\x80\x99 gone by unbeknowns if that air\r\nthoroughbrace hadn\xe2\x80\x99t broke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI knew that he was in labor with another of those winks of his, though I\r\ncould not see his face, because he was bent down at work; and wishing\r\nhim a safe delivery, I turned to and helped the rest get out the mail-\r\nsacks. It made a great pyramid by the roadside when it was all out. When\r\nthey had mended the thoroughbrace we filled the two boots again, but put\r\nno mail on top, and only half as much inside as there was before. The\r\nconductor bent all the seat-backs down, and then filled the coach just\r\nhalf full of mail-bags from end to end. We objected loudly to this, for\r\nit left us no seats. But the conductor was wiser than we, and said a bed\r\nwas better than seats, and moreover, this plan would protect his\r\nthoroughbraces. We never wanted any seats after that. The lazy bed was\r\ninfinitely preferable. I had many an exciting day, subsequently, lying\r\non it reading the statutes and the dictionary, and wondering how the\r\ncharacters would turn out.\r\n\r\nThe conductor said he would send back a guard from the next station to\r\ntake charge of the abandoned mail-bags, and we drove on.\r\n\r\nIt was now just dawn; and as we stretched our cramped legs full length\r\non the mail sacks, and gazed out through the windows across the wide\r\nwastes of greensward clad in cool, powdery mist, to where there was an\r\nexpectant look in the eastern horizon, our perfect enjoyment took the\r\nform of a tranquil and contented ecstasy. The stage whirled along at a\r\nspanking gait, the breeze flapping curtains and suspended coats in a\r\nmost exhilarating way; the cradle swayed and swung luxuriously, the\r\npattering of the horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs, the cracking of the driver\xe2\x80\x99s whip, and\r\nhis \xe2\x80\x9cHi-yi! g\xe2\x80\x99lang!\xe2\x80\x9d were music; the spinning ground and the waltzing\r\ntrees appeared to give us a mute hurrah as we went by, and then slack up\r\nand look after us with interest, or envy, or something; and as we lay\r\nand smoked the pipe of peace and compared all this luxury with the years\r\nof tiresome city life that had gone before it, we felt that there was\r\nonly one complete and satisfying happiness in the world, and we had\r\nfound it.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, at some station whose name I have forgotten, we three\r\nclimbed up on the seat behind the driver, and let the conductor have our\r\nbed for a nap. And by and by, when the sun made me drowsy, I lay down on\r\nmy face on top of the coach, grasping the slender iron railing, and\r\nslept for an hour or more. That will give one an appreciable idea of\r\nthose matchless roads. Instinct will make a sleeping man grip a fast\r\nhold of the railing when the stage jolts, but when it only swings and\r\nsways, no grip is necessary. Overland drivers and conductors used to sit\r\nin their places and sleep thirty or forty minutes at a time, on good\r\nroads, while spinning along at the rate of eight or ten miles an hour. I\r\nsaw them do it, often. There was no danger about it; a sleeping man\r\n_will_ seize the irons in time when the coach jolts. These men were hard\r\nworked, and it _was_ not possible for them to stay awake all the time.\r\n\r\nBy and by we passed through Marysville, and over the Big Blue and Little\r\nSandy; thence about a mile, and entered Nebraska. About a mile further\r\non, we came to the Big Sandy\xe2\x80\x94one hundred and eighty miles from St.\r\nJoseph.\r\n\r\nAs the sun was going down, we saw the first specimen of an animal known\r\nfamiliarly over two thousand miles of mountain and desert\xe2\x80\x94from Kansas\r\nclear to the Pacific Ocean\xe2\x80\x94as the \xe2\x80\x9cjackass rabbit.\xe2\x80\x9d He is well named. He\r\nis just like any other rabbit, except that he is from one third to twice\r\nas large, has longer legs in proportion to his size, and has the most\r\npreposterous ears that ever were mounted on any creature _but_ a\r\njackass.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n032.jpg (27K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen he is sitting quiet, thinking about his sins, or is absent-minded\r\nor unapprehensive of danger, his majestic ears project above him\r\nconspicuously; but the breaking of a twig will scare him nearly to\r\ndeath, and then he tilts his ears back gently and starts for home. All\r\nyou can see, then, for the next minute, is his long gray form stretched\r\nout straight and \xe2\x80\x9cstreaking it\xe2\x80\x9d through the low sage-brush, head erect,\r\neyes right, and ears just canted a little to the rear, but showing you\r\nwhere the animal is, all the time, the same as if he carried a jib. Now\r\nand then he makes a marvelous spring with his long legs, high over the\r\nstunted sage-brush, and scores a leap that would make a horse envious.\r\nPresently he comes down to a long, graceful \xe2\x80\x9clope,\xe2\x80\x9d and shortly he\r\nmysteriously disappears. He has crouched behind a sage-bush, and will\r\nsit there and listen and tremble until you get within six feet of him,\r\nwhen he will get under way again. But one must shoot at this creature\r\nonce, if he wishes to see him throw his heart into his heels, and do the\r\nbest he knows how. He is frightened clear through, now, and he lays his\r\nlong ears down on his back, straightens himself out like a yard-stick\r\nevery spring he makes, and scatters miles behind him with an easy\r\nindifference that is enchanting.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n033a.jpg (35K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOur party made this specimen \xe2\x80\x9chump himself,\xe2\x80\x9d as the conductor said. The\r\nsecretary started him with a shot from the Colt; I commenced spitting at\r\nhim with my weapon; and all in the same instant the old \xe2\x80\x9cAllen\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d whole\r\nbroadside let go with a rattling crash, and it is not putting it too\r\nstrong to say that the rabbit was frantic! He dropped his ears, set up\r\nhis tail, and left for San Francisco at a speed which can only be\r\ndescribed as a flash and a vanish! Long after he was out of sight we\r\ncould hear him whiz.\r\n\r\nI do not remember where we first came across \xe2\x80\x9csage-brush,\xe2\x80\x9d but as I have\r\nbeen speaking of it I may as well describe it.\r\n\r\nThis is easily done, for if the reader can imagine a gnarled and\r\nvenerable live oak-tree reduced to a little shrub two feet-high, with\r\nits rough bark, its foliage, its twisted boughs, all complete, he can\r\npicture the \xe2\x80\x9csage-brush\xe2\x80\x9d exactly. Often, on lazy afternoons in the\r\nmountains, I have lain on the ground with my face under a sage-bush, and\r\nentertained myself with fancying that the gnats among its foliage were\r\nliliputian birds, and that the ants marching and countermarching about\r\nits base were liliputian flocks and herds, and myself some vast loafer\r\nfrom Brobdignag waiting to catch a little citizen and eat him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n033b.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is an imposing monarch of the forest in exquisite miniature, is the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csage-brush.\xe2\x80\x9d Its foliage is a grayish green, and gives that tint to\r\ndesert and mountain. It smells like our domestic sage, and \xe2\x80\x9csage-tea\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nmade from it taste like the sage-tea which all boys are so well\r\nacquainted with. The sage-brush is a singularly hardy plant, and grows\r\nright in the midst of deep sand, and among barren rocks, where nothing\r\nelse in the vegetable world would try to grow, except \xe2\x80\x9cbunch-\r\ngrass.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94[\xe2\x80\x9cBunch-grass\xe2\x80\x9d grows on the bleak mountain-sides of Nevada and\r\nneighboring territories, and offers excellent feed for stock, even in\r\nthe dead of winter, wherever the snow is blown aside and exposes it;\r\nnotwithstanding its unpromising home, bunch-grass is a better and more\r\nnutritious diet for cattle and horses than almost any other hay or grass\r\nthat is known\xe2\x80\x94so stock-men say.]\xe2\x80\x94The sage-bushes grow from three to six\r\nor seven feet apart, all over the mountains and deserts of the Far West,\r\nclear to the borders of California. There is not a tree of any kind in\r\nthe deserts, for hundreds of miles\xe2\x80\x94there is no vegetation at all in a\r\nregular desert, except the sage-brush and its cousin the \xe2\x80\x9cgreasewood,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwhich is so much like the sage-brush that the difference amounts to\r\nlittle. Camp-fires and hot suppers in the deserts would be impossible\r\nbut for the friendly sage-brush. Its trunk is as large as a boy\xe2\x80\x99s wrist\r\n(and from that up to a man\xe2\x80\x99s arm), and its crooked branches are half as\r\nlarge as its trunk\xe2\x80\x94all good, sound, hard wood, very like oak.\r\n\r\nWhen a party camps, the first thing to be done is to cut sage-brush; and\r\nin a few minutes there is an opulent pile of it ready for use. A hole a\r\nfoot wide, two feet deep, and two feet long, is dug, and sage-brush\r\nchopped up and burned in it till it is full to the brim with glowing\r\ncoals. Then the cooking begins, and there is no smoke, and consequently\r\nno swearing. Such a fire will keep all night, with very little\r\nreplenishing; and it makes a very sociable camp-fire, and one around\r\nwhich the most impossible reminiscences sound plausible, instructive,\r\nand profoundly entertaining.\r\n\r\nSage-brush is very fair fuel, but as a vegetable it is a distinguished\r\nfailure. Nothing can abide the taste of it but the jackass and his\r\nillegitimate child the mule. But their testimony to its nutritiousness\r\nis worth nothing, for they will eat pine knots, or anthracite coal, or\r\nbrass filings, or lead pipe, or old bottles, or anything that comes\r\nhandy, and then go off looking as grateful as if they had had oysters\r\nfor dinner. Mules and donkeys and camels have appetites that anything\r\nwill relieve temporarily, but nothing satisfy.\r\n\r\nIn Syria, once, at the head-waters of the Jordan, a camel took charge of\r\nmy overcoat while the tents were being pitched, and examined it with a\r\ncritical eye, all over, with as much interest as if he had an idea of\r\ngetting one made like it; and then, after he was done figuring on it as\r\nan article of apparel, he began to contemplate it as an article of diet.\r\nHe put his foot on it, and lifted one of the sleeves out with his teeth,\r\nand chewed and chewed at it, gradually taking it in, and all the while\r\nopening and closing his eyes in a kind of religious ecstasy, as if he\r\nhad never tasted anything as good as an overcoat before, in his life.\r\nThen he smacked his lips once or twice, and reached after the other\r\nsleeve. Next he tried the velvet collar, and smiled a smile of such\r\ncontentment that it was plain to see that he regarded that as the\r\ndaintiest thing about an overcoat. The tails went next, along with some\r\npercussion caps and cough candy, and some fig-paste from Constantinople.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n035.jpg (95K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd then my newspaper correspondence dropped out, and he took a chance\r\nin that\xe2\x80\x94manuscript letters written for the home papers. But he was\r\ntreading on dangerous ground, now. He began to come across solid wisdom\r\nin those documents that was rather weighty on his stomach; and\r\noccasionally he would take a joke that would shake him up till it\r\nloosened his teeth; it was getting to be perilous times with him, but he\r\nheld his grip with good courage and hopefully, till at last he began to\r\nstumble on statements that not even a camel could swallow with impunity.\r\nHe began to gag and gasp, and his eyes to stand out, and his forelegs to\r\nspread, and in about a quarter of a minute he fell over as stiff as a\r\ncarpenter\xe2\x80\x99s work-bench, and died a death of indescribable agony. I went\r\nand pulled the manuscript out of his mouth, and found that the sensitive\r\ncreature had choked to death on one of the mildest and gentlest\r\nstatements of fact that I ever laid before a trusting public.\r\n\r\nI was about to say, when diverted from my subject, that occasionally one\r\nfinds sage-bushes five or six feet high, and with a spread of branch and\r\nfoliage in proportion, but two or two and a half feet is the usual\r\nheight.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV.\r\n\r\n\r\nAs the sun went down and the evening chill came on, we made preparation\r\nfor bed. We stirred up the hard leather letter-sacks, and the knotty\r\ncanvas bags of printed matter (knotty and uneven because of projecting\r\nends and corners of magazines, boxes and books). We stirred them up and\r\nredisposed them in such a way as to make our bed as level as possible.\r\nAnd we _did_ improve it, too, though after all our work it had an\r\nupheaved and billowy look about it, like a little piece of a stormy sea.\r\nNext we hunted up our boots from odd nooks among the mail-bags where\r\nthey had settled, and put them on. Then we got down our coats, vests,\r\npantaloons and heavy woolen shirts, from the arm-loops where they had\r\nbeen swinging all day, and clothed ourselves in them\xe2\x80\x94for, there being no\r\nladies either at the stations or in the coach, and the weather being\r\nhot, we had looked to our comfort by stripping to our underclothing, at\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning. All things being now ready, we stowed the\r\nuneasy Dictionary where it would lie as quiet as possible, and placed\r\nthe water-canteens and pistols where we could find them in the dark.\r\nThen we smoked a final pipe, and swapped a final yarn; after which, we\r\nput the pipes, tobacco and bag of coin in snug holes and caves among the\r\nmail-bags, and then fastened down the coach curtains all around, and\r\nmade the place as \xe2\x80\x9cdark as the inside of a cow,\xe2\x80\x9d as the conductor\r\nphrased it in his picturesque way. It was certainly as dark as any place\r\ncould be\xe2\x80\x94nothing was even dimly visible in it. And finally, we rolled\r\nourselves up like silk-worms, each person in his own blanket, and sank\r\npeacefully to sleep.\r\n\r\nWhenever the stage stopped to change horses, we would wake up, and try\r\nto recollect where we were\xe2\x80\x94and succeed\xe2\x80\x94and in a minute or two the stage\r\nwould be off again, and we likewise. We began to get into country, now,\r\nthreaded here and there with little streams. These had high, steep banks\r\non each side, and every time we flew down one bank and scrambled up the\r\nother, our party inside got mixed somewhat. First we would all be down\r\nin a pile at the forward end of the stage, nearly in a sitting posture,\r\nand in a second we would shoot to the other end, and stand on our heads.\r\nAnd we would sprawl and kick, too, and ward off ends and corners of\r\nmail- bags that came lumbering over us and about us; and as the dust\r\nrose from the tumult, we would all sneeze in chorus, and the majority of\r\nus would grumble, and probably say some hasty thing, like: \xe2\x80\x9cTake your\r\nelbow out of my ribs!\xe2\x80\x94can\xe2\x80\x99t you quit crowding?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvery time we avalanched from one end of the stage to the other, the\r\nUnabridged Dictionary would come too; and every time it came it damaged\r\nsomebody. One trip it \xe2\x80\x9cbarked\xe2\x80\x9d the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s elbow; the next trip it\r\nhurt me in the stomach, and the third it tilted Bemis\xe2\x80\x99s nose up till he\r\ncould look down his nostrils\xe2\x80\x94he said. The pistols and coin soon settled\r\nto the bottom, but the pipes, pipe-stems, tobacco and canteens clattered\r\nand floundered after the Dictionary every time it made an assault on us,\r\nand aided and abetted the book by spilling tobacco in our eyes, and\r\nwater down our backs.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n038.jpg (54K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nStill, all things considered, it was a very comfortable night. It wore\r\ngradually away, and when at last a cold gray light was visible through\r\nthe puckers and chinks in the curtains, we yawned and stretched with\r\nsatisfaction, shed our cocoons, and felt that we had slept as much as\r\nwas necessary. By and by, as the sun rose up and warmed the world, we\r\npulled off our clothes and got ready for breakfast. We were just\r\npleasantly in time, for five minutes afterward the driver sent the weird\r\nmusic of his bugle winding over the grassy solitudes, and presently we\r\ndetected a low hut or two in the distance. Then the rattling of the\r\ncoach, the clatter of our six horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs, and the driver\xe2\x80\x99s crisp\r\ncommands, awoke to a louder and stronger emphasis, and we went sweeping\r\ndown on the station at our smartest speed. It was fascinating\xe2\x80\x94that old\r\noverland stagecoaching.\r\n\r\nWe jumped out in undress uniform. The driver tossed his gathered reins\r\nout on the ground, gaped and stretched complacently, drew off his heavy\r\nbuckskin gloves with great deliberation and insufferable dignity\xe2\x80\x94taking\r\nnot the slightest notice of a dozen solicitous inquires after his\r\nhealth, and humbly facetious and flattering accostings, and obsequious\r\ntenders of service, from five or six hairy and half-civilized station-\r\nkeepers and hostlers who were nimbly unhitching our steeds and bringing\r\nthe fresh team out of the stables\xe2\x80\x94for in the eyes of the stage-driver of\r\nthat day, station-keepers and hostlers were a sort of good enough low\r\ncreatures, useful in their place, and helping to make up a world, but\r\nnot the kind of beings which a person of distinction could afford to\r\nconcern himself with; while, on the contrary, in the eyes of the\r\nstation-keeper and the hostler, the stage-driver was a hero\xe2\x80\x94a great and\r\nshining dignitary, the world\xe2\x80\x99s favorite son, the envy of the people, the\r\nobserved of the nations. When they spoke to him they received his\r\ninsolent silence meekly, and as being the natural and proper conduct of\r\nso great a man; when he opened his lips they all hung on his words with\r\nadmiration (he never honored a particular individual with a remark, but\r\naddressed it with a broad generality to the horses, the stables, the\r\nsurrounding country _and_ the human underlings); when he discharged a\r\nfacetious insulting personality at a hostler, that hostler was happy for\r\nthe day; when he uttered his one jest\xe2\x80\x94old as the hills, coarse, profane,\r\nwitless, and inflicted on the same audience, in the same language, every\r\ntime his coach drove up there\xe2\x80\x94the varlets roared, and slapped their\r\nthighs, and swore it was the best thing they\xe2\x80\x99d ever heard in all their\r\nlives. And how they would fly around when he wanted a basin of water, a\r\ngourd of the same, or a light for his pipe!\xe2\x80\x94but they would instantly\r\ninsult a passenger if he so far forgot himself as to crave a favor at\r\ntheir hands. They could do that sort of insolence as well as the driver\r\nthey copied it from\xe2\x80\x94for, let it be borne in mind, the overland driver\r\nhad but little less contempt for his passengers than he had for his\r\nhostlers.\r\n\r\nThe hostlers and station-keepers treated the really powerful _conductor_\r\nof the coach merely with the best of what was their idea of civility,\r\nbut the _driver_ was the only being they bowed down to and worshipped.\r\nHow admiringly they would gaze up at him in his high seat as he gloved\r\nhimself with lingering deliberation, while some happy hostler held the\r\nbunch of reins aloft, and waited patiently for him to take it! And how\r\nthey would bombard him with glorifying ejaculations as he cracked his\r\nlong whip and went careering away.\r\n\r\nThe station buildings were long, low huts, made of sundried, mud-colored\r\nbricks, laid up without mortar (_adobes_, the Spaniards call these\r\nbricks, and Americans shorten it to \xe2\x80\x99_dobies_). The roofs, which had no\r\nslant to them worth speaking of, were thatched and then sodded or\r\ncovered with a thick layer of earth, and from this sprung a pretty rank\r\ngrowth of weeds and grass. It was the first time we had ever seen a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s front yard on top of his house. The building consisted of barns,\r\nstable-room for twelve or fifteen horses, and a hut for an eating-room\r\nfor passengers. This latter had bunks in it for the station-keeper and a\r\nhostler or two. You could rest your elbow on its eaves, and you had to\r\nbend in order to get in at the door. In place of a window there was a\r\nsquare hole about large enough for a man to crawl through, but this had\r\nno glass in it. There was no flooring, but the ground was packed hard.\r\nThere was no stove, but the fire-place served all needful purposes.\r\nThere were no shelves, no cupboards, no closets. In a corner stood an\r\nopen sack of flour, and nestling against its base were a couple of black\r\nand venerable tin coffee-pots, a tin teapot, a little bag of salt, and a\r\nside of bacon.\r\n\r\nBy the door of the station-keeper\xe2\x80\x99s den, outside, was a tin wash-basin,\r\non the ground. Near it was a pail of water and a piece of yellow bar\r\nsoap, and from the eaves hung a hoary blue woolen shirt,\r\nsignificantly\xe2\x80\x94but this latter was the station-keeper\xe2\x80\x99s private towel,\r\nand only two persons in all the party might venture to use it\xe2\x80\x94the stage-\r\ndriver and the conductor. The latter would not, from a sense of decency;\r\nthe former would not, because he did not choose to encourage the\r\nadvances of a station-keeper. We had towels\xe2\x80\x94in the valise; they might as\r\nwell have been in Sodom and Gomorrah. We (and the conductor) used our\r\nhandkerchiefs, and the driver his pantaloons and sleeves. By the door,\r\ninside, was fastened a small old-fashioned looking-glass frame, with two\r\nlittle fragments of the original mirror lodged down in one corner of it.\r\nThis arrangement afforded a pleasant double-barreled portrait of you\r\nwhen you looked into it, with one half of your head set up a couple of\r\ninches above the other half. From the glass frame hung the half of a\r\ncomb by a string\xe2\x80\x94but if I had to describe that patriarch or die, I\r\nbelieve I would order some sample coffins.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n041.jpg (47K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n042a.jpg (11K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt had come down from Esau and Samson, and had been accumulating hair\r\never since\xe2\x80\x94along with certain impurities. In one corner of the room\r\nstood three or four rifles and muskets, together with horns and pouches\r\nof ammunition. The station-men wore pantaloons of coarse, country-woven\r\nstuff, and into the seat and the inside of the legs were sewed ample\r\nadditions of buckskin, to do duty in place of leggings, when the man\r\nrode horseback\xe2\x80\x94so the pants were half dull blue and half yellow, and\r\nunspeakably picturesque. The pants were stuffed into the tops of high\r\nboots, the heels whereof were armed with great Spanish spurs, whose\r\nlittle iron clogs and chains jingled with every step. The man wore a\r\nhuge beard and mustachios, an old slouch hat, a blue woolen shirt, no\r\nsuspenders, no vest, no coat\xe2\x80\x94in a leathern sheath in his belt, a great\r\nlong \xe2\x80\x9cnavy\xe2\x80\x9d revolver (slung on right side, hammer to the front), and\r\nprojecting from his boot a horn-handled bowie-knife.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n042b.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe furniture of the hut was neither gorgeous nor much in the way. The\r\nrocking-chairs and sofas were not present, and never had been, but they\r\nwere represented by two three-legged stools, a pine-board bench four\r\nfeet long, and two empty candle-boxes. The table was a greasy board on\r\nstilts, and the table-cloth and napkins had not come\xe2\x80\x94and they were not\r\nlooking for them, either. A battered tin platter, a knife and fork, and\r\na tin pint cup, were at each man\xe2\x80\x99s place, and the driver had a queens-\r\nware saucer that had seen better days. Of course this duke sat at the\r\nhead of the table. There was one isolated piece of table furniture that\r\nbore about it a touching air of grandeur in misfortune. This was the\r\ncaster. It was German silver, and crippled and rusty, but it was so\r\npreposterously out of place there that it was suggestive of a tattered\r\nexiled king among barbarians, and the majesty of its native position\r\ncompelled respect even in its degradation.\r\n\r\nThere was only one cruet left, and that was a stopperless, fly-specked,\r\nbroken-necked thing, with two inches of vinegar in it, and a dozen\r\npreserved flies with their heels up and looking sorry they had invested\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n043.jpg (23K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe station-keeper upended a disk of last week\xe2\x80\x99s bread, of the shape and\r\nsize of an old-time cheese, and carved some slabs from it which were as\r\ngood as Nicholson pavement, and tenderer.\r\n\r\nHe sliced off a piece of bacon for each man, but only the experienced\r\nold hands made out to eat it, for it was condemned army bacon which the\r\nUnited States would not feed to its soldiers in the forts, and the stage\r\ncompany had bought it cheap for the sustenance of their passengers and\r\nemployees. We may have found this condemned army bacon further out on\r\nthe plains than the section I am locating it in, but we _found_ it\xe2\x80\x94there\r\nis no gainsaying that.\r\n\r\nThen he poured for us a beverage which he called \xe2\x80\x9cSlumgullion,\xe2\x80\x9d and it\r\nis hard to think he was not inspired when he named it. It really\r\npretended to be tea, but there was too much dish-rag, and sand, and old\r\nbacon-rind in it to deceive the intelligent traveler.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n044.jpg (64K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe had no sugar and no milk\xe2\x80\x94not even a spoon to stir the ingredients\r\nwith.\r\n\r\nWe could not eat the bread or the meat, nor drink the \xe2\x80\x9cslumgullion.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nwhen I looked at that melancholy vinegar-cruet, I thought of the\r\nanecdote (a very, very old one, even at that day) of the traveler who\r\nsat down to a table which had nothing on it but a mackerel and a pot of\r\nmustard. He asked the landlord if this was all. The landlord said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_All_! Why, thunder and lightning, I should think there was mackerel\r\nenough there for six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t like mackerel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh\xe2\x80\x94then help yourself to the mustard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn other days I had considered it a good, a very good, anecdote, but\r\nthere was a dismal plausibility about it, here, that took all the humor\r\nout of it.\r\n\r\nOur breakfast was before us, but our teeth were idle.\r\n\r\nI tasted and smelt, and said I would take coffee, I believed. The\r\nstation-boss stopped dead still, and glared at me speechless. At last,\r\nwhen he came to, he turned away and said, as one who communes with\r\nhimself upon a matter too vast to grasp:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Coffee_! Well, if that don\xe2\x80\x99t go clean ahead of me, I\xe2\x80\x99m d\xe2\x80\x94-d!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n045.jpg (40K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe could not eat, and there was no conversation among the hostlers and\r\nherdsmen\xe2\x80\x94we all sat at the same board. At least there was no\r\nconversation further than a single hurried request, now and then, from\r\none employee to another. It was always in the same form, and always\r\ngruffly friendly. Its western freshness and novelty startled me, at\r\nfirst, and interested me; but it presently grew monotonous, and lost its\r\ncharm. It was:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPass the bread, you son of a skunk!\xe2\x80\x9d No, I forget\xe2\x80\x94skunk was not the\r\nword; it seems to me it was still stronger than that; I know it was, in\r\nfact, but it is gone from my memory, apparently. However, it is no\r\nmatter\xe2\x80\x94probably it was too strong for print, anyway. It is the landmark\r\nin my memory which tells me where I first encountered the vigorous new\r\nvernacular of the occidental plains and mountains.\r\n\r\nWe gave up the breakfast, and paid our dollar apiece and went back to\r\nour mail-bag bed in the coach, and found comfort in our pipes. Right\r\nhere we suffered the first diminution of our princely state. We left our\r\nsix fine horses and took six mules in their place. But they were wild\r\nMexican fellows, and a man had to stand at the head of each of them and\r\nhold him fast while the driver gloved and got himself ready. And when at\r\nlast he grasped the reins and gave the word, the men sprung suddenly\r\naway from the mules\xe2\x80\x99 heads and the coach shot from the station as if it\r\nhad issued from a cannon. How the frantic animals did scamper! It was a\r\nfierce and furious gallop\xe2\x80\x94and the gait never altered for a moment till\r\nwe reeled off ten or twelve miles and swept up to the next collection of\r\nlittle station-huts and stables.\r\n\r\nSo we flew along all day. At 2 P.M. the belt of timber that fringes the\r\nNorth Platte and marks its windings through the vast level floor of the\r\nPlains came in sight. At 4 P.M. we crossed a branch of the river, and at\r\n5 P.M. we crossed the Platte itself, and landed at Fort Kearney, fifty-\r\nsix hours out from _St. Joe_\xe2\x80\x94THREE HUNDRED MILES!\r\n\r\nNow that was stage-coaching on the great overland, ten or twelve years\r\nago, when perhaps not more than ten men in America, all told, expected\r\nto live to see a railroad follow that route to the Pacific. But the\r\nrailroad is there, now, and it pictures a thousand odd comparisons and\r\ncontrasts in my mind to read the following sketch, in the New York\r\nTimes, of a recent trip over almost the very ground I have been\r\ndescribing. I can scarcely comprehend the new state of things:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cACROSS THE CONTINENT.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt 4.20 P.M., Sunday, we rolled out of the station at Omaha, and\r\nstarted westward on our long jaunt. A couple of hours out, dinner was\r\nannounced\xe2\x80\x94an \xe2\x80\x9cevent\xe2\x80\x9d to those of us who had yet to experience what it is\r\nto eat in one of Pullman\xe2\x80\x99s hotels on wheels; so, stepping into the car\r\nnext forward of our sleeping palace, we found ourselves in the dining-\r\ncar. It was a revelation to us, that first dinner on Sunday. And though\r\nwe continued to dine for four days, and had as many breakfasts and\r\nsuppers, our whole party never ceased to admire the perfection of the\r\narrangements, and the marvelous results achieved. Upon tables covered\r\nwith snowy linen, and garnished with services of solid silver, Ethiop\r\nwaiters, flitting about in spotless white, placed as by magic a repast\r\nat which Delmonico himself could have had no occasion to blush; and,\r\nindeed, in some respects it would be hard for that distinguished chef to\r\nmatch our menu; for, in addition to all that ordinarily makes up a\r\nfirst-chop dinner, had we not our antelope steak (the gormand who has\r\nnot experienced this\xe2\x80\x94bah! what does he know of the feast of fat things?)\r\nour delicious mountain-brook trout, and choice fruits and berries, and\r\n(sauce piquant and unpurchasable!) our sweet-scented, appetite-\r\ncompelling air of the prairies?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n047.jpg (88K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may depend upon it, we all did justice to the good things, and as\r\nwe washed them down with bumpers of sparkling Krug, whilst we sped along\r\nat the rate of thirty miles an hour, agreed it was the fastest living we\r\nhad ever experienced. (We beat that, however, two days afterward when we\r\nmade twenty-seven miles in twenty-seven minutes, while our Champagne\r\nglasses filled to the brim spilled not a drop!) After dinner we repaired\r\nto our drawing-room car, and, as it was Sabbath eve, intoned some of the\r\ngrand old hymns\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPraise God from whom,\xe2\x80\x9d etc.; \xe2\x80\x9cShining Shore,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCoronation,\xe2\x80\x9d etc.\xe2\x80\x94the voices of the men singers and of the women\r\nsingers blending sweetly in the evening air, while our train, with its\r\ngreat, glaring Polyphemus eye, lighting up long vistas of prairie,\r\nrushed into the night and the Wild. Then to bed in luxurious couches,\r\nwhere we slept the sleep of the just and only awoke the next morning\r\n(Monday) at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, to find ourselves at the crossing of the\r\nNorth Platte, three hundred miles from Omaha\xe2\x80\x94fifteen hours and forty\r\nminutes out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V.\r\n\r\n\r\nAnother night of alternate tranquillity and turmoil. But morning came,\r\nby and by. It was another glad awakening to fresh breezes, vast expanses\r\nof level greensward, bright sunlight, an impressive solitude utterly\r\nwithout visible human beings or human habitations, and an atmosphere of\r\nsuch amazing magnifying properties that trees that seemed close at hand\r\nwere more than three mile away. We resumed undress uniform, climbed a-\r\ntop of the flying coach, dangled our legs over the side, shouted\r\noccasionally at our frantic mules, merely to see them lay their ears\r\nback and scamper faster, tied our hats on to keep our hair from blowing\r\naway, and leveled an outlook over the world-wide carpet about us for\r\nthings new and strange to gaze at. Even at this day it thrills me\r\nthrough and through to think of the life, the gladness and the wild\r\nsense of freedom that used to make the blood dance in my veins on those\r\nfine overland mornings!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n049.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n050.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlong about an hour after breakfast we saw the first prairie-dog\r\nvillages, the first antelope, and the first wolf. If I remember rightly,\r\nthis latter was the regular _cayote_ (pronounced ky-_o_-te) of the\r\nfarther deserts. And if it _was_, he was not a pretty creature or\r\nrespectable either, for I got well acquainted with his race afterward,\r\nand can speak with confidence. The cayote is a long, slim, sick and\r\nsorry-looking skeleton, with a gray wolf-skin stretched over it, a\r\ntolerably bushy tail that forever sags down with a despairing expression\r\nof forsakenness and misery, a furtive and evil eye, and a long, sharp\r\nface, with slightly lifted lip and exposed teeth. He has a general\r\nslinking expression all over. The cayote is a living, breathing allegory\r\nof Want. He is _always_ hungry.\r\n\r\nHe is always poor, out of luck and friendless. The meanest creatures\r\ndespise him, and even the fleas would desert him for a velocipede. He is\r\nso spiritless and cowardly that even while his exposed teeth are\r\npretending a threat, the rest of his face is apologizing for it. And he\r\nis so _homely_!\xe2\x80\x94so scrawny, and ribby, and coarse-haired, and pitiful.\r\nWhen he sees you he lifts his lip and lets a flash of his teeth out, and\r\nthen turns a little out of the course he was pursuing, depresses his\r\nhead a bit, and strikes a long, soft-footed trot through the sage-brush,\r\nglancing over his shoulder at you, from time to time, till he is about\r\nout of easy pistol range, and then he stops and takes a deliberate\r\nsurvey of you; he will trot fifty yards and stop again\xe2\x80\x94another fifty and\r\nstop again; and finally the gray of his gliding body blends with the\r\ngray of the sage-brush, and he disappears. All this is when you make no\r\ndemonstration against him; but if you do, he develops a livelier\r\ninterest in his journey, and instantly electrifies his heels and puts\r\nsuch a deal of real estate between himself and your weapon, that by the\r\ntime you have raised the hammer you see that you need a minie rifle, and\r\nby the time you have got him in line you need a rifled cannon, and by\r\nthe time you have \xe2\x80\x9cdrawn a bead\xe2\x80\x9d on him you see well enough that nothing\r\nbut an unusually long-winded streak of lightning could reach him where\r\nhe is now. But if you start a swift-footed dog after him, you will enjoy\r\nit ever so much\xe2\x80\x94especially if it is a dog that has a good opinion of\r\nhimself, and has been brought up to think he knows something about\r\nspeed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n051.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe cayote will go swinging gently off on that deceitful trot of his,\r\nand every little while he will smile a fraudful smile over his shoulder\r\nthat will fill that dog entirely full of encouragement and worldly\r\nambition, and make him lay his head still lower to the ground, and\r\nstretch his neck further to the front, and pant more fiercely, and stick\r\nhis tail out straighter behind, and move his furious legs with a yet\r\nwilder frenzy, and leave a broader and broader, and higher and denser\r\ncloud of desert sand smoking behind, and marking his long wake across\r\nthe level plain! And all this time the dog is only a short twenty feet\r\nbehind the cayote, and to save the soul of him he cannot understand why\r\nit is that he cannot get perceptibly closer; and he begins to get\r\naggravated, and it makes him madder and madder to see how gently the\r\ncayote glides along and never pants or sweats or ceases to smile; and he\r\ngrows still more and more incensed to see how shamefully he has been\r\ntaken in by an entire stranger, and what an ignoble swindle that long,\r\ncalm, soft-footed trot is; and next he notices that he is getting\r\nfagged, and that the cayote actually has to slacken speed a little to\r\nkeep from running away from him\xe2\x80\x94and _then_ that town-dog is mad in\r\nearnest, and he begins to strain and weep and swear, and paw the sand\r\nhigher than ever, and reach for the cayote with concentrated and\r\ndesperate energy. This \xe2\x80\x9cspurt\xe2\x80\x9d finds him six feet behind the gliding\r\nenemy, and two miles from his friends. And then, in the instant that a\r\nwild new hope is lighting up his face, the cayote turns and smiles\r\nblandly upon him once more, and with a something about it which seems to\r\nsay: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I shall have to tear myself away from you, bub\xe2\x80\x94business is\r\nbusiness, and it will not do for me to be fooling along this way all\r\nday\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and forthwith there is a rushing sound, and the sudden splitting of\r\na long crack through the atmosphere, and behold that dog is solitary and\r\nalone in the midst of a vast solitude!\r\n\r\nIt makes his head swim. He stops, and looks all around; climbs the\r\nnearest sand-mound, and gazes into the distance; shakes his head\r\nreflectively, and then, without a word, he turns and jogs along back to\r\nhis train, and takes up a humble position under the hindmost wagon, and\r\nfeels unspeakably mean, and looks ashamed, and hangs his tail at half-\r\nmast for a week. And for as much as a year after that, whenever there is\r\na great hue and cry after a cayote, that dog will merely glance in that\r\ndirection without emotion, and apparently observe to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe\r\nI do not wish any of the pie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n052.jpg (145K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe cayote lives chiefly in the most desolate and forbidding desert,\r\nalong with the lizard, the jackass-rabbit and the raven, and gets an\r\nuncertain and precarious living, and earns it. He seems to subsist\r\nalmost wholly on the carcases of oxen, mules and horses that have\r\ndropped out of emigrant trains and died, and upon windfalls of carrion,\r\nand occasional legacies of offal bequeathed to him by white men who have\r\nbeen opulent enough to have something better to butcher than condemned\r\narmy bacon.\r\n\r\nHe will eat anything in the world that his first cousins, the desert-\r\nfrequenting tribes of Indians will, and they will eat anything they can\r\nbite. It is a curious fact that these latter are the only creatures\r\nknown to history who will eat nitro-glycerine and ask for more if they\r\nsurvive.\r\n\r\nThe cayote of the deserts beyond the Rocky Mountains has a peculiarly\r\nhard time of it, owing to the fact that his relations, the Indians, are\r\njust as apt to be the first to detect a seductive scent on the desert\r\nbreeze, and follow the fragrance to the late ox it emanated from, as he\r\nis himself; and when this occurs he has to content himself with sitting\r\noff at a little distance watching those people strip off and dig out\r\neverything edible, and walk off with it. Then he and the waiting ravens\r\nexplore the skeleton and polish the bones. It is considered that the\r\ncayote, and the obscene bird, and the Indian of the desert, testify\r\ntheir blood kinship with each other in that they live together in the\r\nwaste places of the earth on terms of perfect confidence and friendship,\r\nwhile hating all other creature and yearning to assist at their\r\nfunerals. He does not mind going a hundred miles to breakfast, and a\r\nhundred and fifty to dinner, because he is sure to have three or four\r\ndays between meals, and he can just as well be traveling and looking at\r\nthe scenery as lying around doing nothing and adding to the burdens of\r\nhis parents.\r\n\r\nWe soon learned to recognize the sharp, vicious bark of the cayote as it\r\ncame across the murky plain at night to disturb our dreams among the\r\nmail-sacks; and remembering his forlorn aspect and his hard fortune,\r\nmade shift to wish him the blessed novelty of a long day\xe2\x80\x99s good luck and\r\na limitless larder the morrow.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI.\r\n\r\n\r\nOur new conductor (just shipped) had been without sleep for twenty\r\nhours. Such a thing was very frequent. From St. Joseph, Missouri, to\r\nSacramento, California, by stage-coach, was nearly nineteen hundred\r\nmiles, and the trip was often made in fifteen days (the cars do it in\r\nfour and a half, now), but the time specified in the mail contracts, and\r\nrequired by the schedule, was eighteen or nineteen days, if I remember\r\nrightly. This was to make fair allowance for winter storms and snows,\r\nand other unavoidable causes of detention. The stage company had\r\neverything under strict discipline and good system. Over each two\r\nhundred and fifty miles of road they placed an agent or superintendent,\r\nand invested him with great authority. His beat or jurisdiction of two\r\nhundred and fifty miles was called a \xe2\x80\x9cdivision.\xe2\x80\x9d He purchased horses,\r\nmules harness, and food for men and beasts, and distributed these things\r\namong his stage stations, from time to time, according to his judgment\r\nof what each station needed. He erected station buildings and dug wells.\r\nHe attended to the paying of the station-keepers, hostlers, drivers and\r\nblacksmiths, and discharged them whenever he chose. He was a very, very\r\ngreat man in his \xe2\x80\x9cdivision\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a kind of Grand Mogul, a Sultan of the\r\nIndies, in whose presence common men were modest of speech and manner,\r\nand in the glare of whose greatness even the dazzling stage-driver\r\ndwindled to a penny dip. There were about eight of these kings, all\r\ntold, on the overland route.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n055.jpg (39K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNext in rank and importance to the division-agent came the \xe2\x80\x9cconductor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHis beat was the same length as the agent\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94two hundred and fifty miles.\r\nHe sat with the driver, and (when necessary) rode that fearful distance,\r\nnight and day, without other rest or sleep than what he could get\r\nperched thus on top of the flying vehicle. Think of it! He had absolute\r\ncharge of the mails, express matter, passengers and stage-coach, until\r\nhe delivered them to the next conductor, and got his receipt for them.\r\n\r\nConsequently he had to be a man of intelligence, decision and\r\nconsiderable executive ability. He was usually a quiet, pleasant man,\r\nwho attended closely to his duties, and was a good deal of a gentleman.\r\nIt was not absolutely necessary that the division-agent should be a\r\ngentleman, and occasionally he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t. But he was always a general in\r\nadministrative ability, and a bull-dog in courage and\r\ndetermination\xe2\x80\x94otherwise the chieftainship over the lawless underlings of\r\nthe overland service would never in any instance have been to him\r\nanything but an equivalent for a month of insolence and distress and a\r\nbullet and a coffin at the end of it. There were about sixteen or\r\neighteen conductors on the overland, for there was a daily stage each\r\nway, and a conductor on every stage.\r\n\r\nNext in _real_ and official rank and importance, _after_ the conductor,\r\ncame my delight, the driver\xe2\x80\x94next in real but not in _apparent_\r\nimportance\xe2\x80\x94for we have seen that in the eyes of the common herd the\r\ndriver was to the conductor as an admiral is to the captain of the flag-\r\nship. The driver\xe2\x80\x99s beat was pretty long, and his sleeping-time at the\r\nstations pretty short, sometimes; and so, but for the grandeur of his\r\nposition his would have been a sorry life, as well as a hard and a\r\nwearing one. We took a new driver every day or every night (for they\r\ndrove backward and forward over the same piece of road all the time),\r\nand therefore we never got as well acquainted with them as we did with\r\nthe conductors; and besides, they would have been above being familiar\r\nwith such rubbish as passengers, anyhow, as a general thing. Still, we\r\nwere always eager to get a sight of each and every new driver as soon as\r\nthe watch changed, for each and every day we were either anxious to get\r\nrid of an unpleasant one, or loath to part with a driver we had learned\r\nto like and had come to be sociable and friendly with. And so the first\r\nquestion we asked the conductor whenever we got to where we were to\r\nexchange drivers, was always, \xe2\x80\x9cWhich is him?\xe2\x80\x9d The grammar was faulty,\r\nmaybe, but we could not know, then, that it would go into a book some\r\nday. As long as everything went smoothly, the overland driver was well\r\nenough situated, but if a fellow driver got sick suddenly it made\r\ntrouble, for the coach _must_ go on, and so the potentate who was about\r\nto climb down and take a luxurious rest after his long night\xe2\x80\x99s siege in\r\nthe midst of wind and rain and darkness, had to stay where he was and do\r\nthe sick man\xe2\x80\x99s work. Once, in the Rocky Mountains, when I found a driver\r\nsound asleep on the box, and the mules going at the usual break-neck\r\npace, the conductor said never mind him, there was no danger, and he was\r\ndoing double duty\xe2\x80\x94had driven seventy-five miles on one coach, and was\r\nnow going back over it on this without rest or sleep. A hundred and\r\nfifty miles of holding back of six vindictive mules and keeping them\r\nfrom climbing the trees! It sounds incredible, but I remember the\r\nstatement well enough.\r\n\r\nThe station-keepers, hostlers, etc., were low, rough characters, as\r\nalready described; and from western Nebraska to Nevada a considerable\r\nsprinkling of them might be fairly set down as outlaws\xe2\x80\x94fugitives from\r\njustice, criminals whose best security was a section of country which\r\nwas without law and without even the pretence of it. When the \xe2\x80\x9cdivision-\r\nagent\xe2\x80\x9d issued an order to one of these parties he did it with the full\r\nunderstanding that he might have to enforce it with a navy six-shooter,\r\nand so he always went \xe2\x80\x9cfixed\xe2\x80\x9d to make things go along smoothly.\r\n\r\nNow and then a division-agent was really obliged to shoot a hostler\r\nthrough the head to teach him some simple matter that he could have\r\ntaught him with a club if his circumstances and surroundings had been\r\ndifferent. But they were snappy, able men, those division-agents, and\r\nwhen they tried to teach a subordinate anything, that subordinate\r\ngenerally \xe2\x80\x9cgot it through his head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n057.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA great portion of this vast machinery\xe2\x80\x94these hundreds of men and\r\ncoaches, and thousands of mules and horses\xe2\x80\x94was in the hands of Mr. Ben\r\nHolliday. All the western half of the business was in his hands. This\r\nreminds me of an incident of Palestine travel which is pertinent here,\r\nso I will transfer it just in the language in which I find it set down\r\nin my Holy Land note-book:\r\n\r\nNo doubt everybody has heard of Ben Holliday\xe2\x80\x94a man of prodigious energy,\r\nwho used to send mails and passengers flying across the continent in his\r\noverland stage-coaches like a very whirlwind\xe2\x80\x94two thousand long miles in\r\nfifteen days and a half, by the watch! But this fragment of history is\r\nnot about Ben Holliday, but about a young New York boy by the name of\r\nJack, who traveled with our small party of pilgrims in the Holy Land\r\n(and who had traveled to California in Mr. Holliday\xe2\x80\x99s overland coaches\r\nthree years before, and had by no means forgotten it or lost his gushing\r\nadmiration of Mr. H.) Aged nineteen. Jack was a good boy\xe2\x80\x94a good-hearted\r\nand always well-meaning boy, who had been reared in the city of New\r\nYork, and although he was bright and knew a great many useful things,\r\nhis Scriptural education had been a good deal neglected\xe2\x80\x94to such a\r\ndegree, indeed, that all Holy Land history was fresh and new to him, and\r\nall Bible names mysteries that had never disturbed his virgin ear.\r\n\r\nAlso in our party was an elderly pilgrim who was the reverse of Jack, in\r\nthat he was learned in the Scriptures and an enthusiast concerning them.\r\nHe was our encyclopedia, and we were never tired of listening to his\r\nspeeches, nor he of making them. He never passed a celebrated locality,\r\nfrom Bashan to Bethlehem, without illuminating it with an oration. One\r\nday, when camped near the ruins of Jericho, he burst forth with\r\nsomething like this:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJack, do you see that range of mountains over yonder that bounds the\r\nJordan valley? The mountains of Moab, Jack! Think of it, my boy\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nactual mountains of Moab\xe2\x80\x94renowned in Scripture history! We are actually\r\nstanding face to face with those illustrious crags and peaks\xe2\x80\x94and for all\r\nwe know\xe2\x80\x9d [dropping his voice impressively], \xe2\x80\x9cour eyes may be resting at\r\nthis very moment upon the spot WHERE LIES THE MYSTERIOUS GRAVE OF MOSES!\r\nThink of it, Jack!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoses who?\xe2\x80\x9d (falling inflection).\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n058.jpg (62K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoses who! Jack, you ought to be ashamed of yourself\xe2\x80\x94you ought to be\r\nashamed of such criminal ignorance. Why, Moses, the great guide,\r\nsoldier, poet, lawgiver of ancient Israel! Jack, from this spot where we\r\nstand, to Egypt, stretches a fearful desert three hundred miles in\r\nextent\xe2\x80\x94and across that desert that wonderful man brought the children of\r\nIsrael!\xe2\x80\x94guiding them with unfailing sagacity for forty years over the\r\nsandy desolation and among the obstructing rocks and hills, and landed\r\nthem at last, safe and sound, within sight of this very spot; and where\r\nwe now stand they entered the Promised Land with anthems of rejoicing!\r\nIt was a wonderful, wonderful thing to do, Jack! Think of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForty years? Only three hundred miles? Humph! Ben Holliday would have\r\nfetched them through in thirty-six hours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boy meant no harm. He did not know that he had said anything that\r\nwas wrong or irreverent. And so no one scolded him or felt offended with\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94and nobody could but some ungenerous spirit incapable of excusing\r\nthe heedless blunders of a boy.\r\n\r\nAt noon on the fifth day out, we arrived at the \xe2\x80\x9cCrossing of the South\r\nPlatte,\xe2\x80\x9d _alias_ \xe2\x80\x9cJulesburg,\xe2\x80\x9d _alias_ \xe2\x80\x9cOverland City,\xe2\x80\x9d four hundred and\r\nseventy miles from St. Joseph\xe2\x80\x94the strangest, quaintest, funniest\r\nfrontier town that our untraveled eyes had ever stared at and been\r\nastonished with.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt did seem strange enough to see a town again after what appeared to us\r\nsuch a long acquaintance with deep, still, almost lifeless and houseless\r\nsolitude! We tumbled out into the busy street feeling like meteoric\r\npeople crumbled off the corner of some other world, and wakened up\r\nsuddenly in this. For an hour we took as much interest in Overland City\r\nas if we had never seen a town before. The reason we had an hour to\r\nspare was because we had to change our stage (for a less sumptuous\r\naffair, called a \xe2\x80\x9cmud-wagon\xe2\x80\x9d) and transfer our freight of mails.\r\n\r\nPresently we got under way again. We came to the shallow, yellow, muddy\r\nSouth Platte, with its low banks and its scattering flat sand-bars and\r\npigmy islands\xe2\x80\x94a melancholy stream straggling through the centre of the\r\nenormous flat plain, and only saved from being impossible to find with\r\nthe naked eye by its sentinel rank of scattering trees standing on\r\neither bank. The Platte was \xe2\x80\x9cup,\xe2\x80\x9d they said\xe2\x80\x94which made me wish I could\r\nsee it when it was down, if it could look any sicker and sorrier. They\r\nsaid it was a dangerous stream to cross, now, because its quicksands\r\nwere liable to swallow up horses, coach and passengers if an attempt was\r\nmade to ford it. But the mails had to go, and we made the attempt. Once\r\nor twice in midstream the wheels sunk into the yielding sands so\r\nthreateningly that we half believed we had dreaded and avoided the sea\r\nall our lives to be shipwrecked in a \xe2\x80\x9cmud-wagon\xe2\x80\x9d in the middle of a\r\ndesert at last. But we dragged through and sped away toward the setting\r\nsun.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n061.jpg (69K)\r\n\r\nNext morning, just before dawn, when about five hundred and fifty miles\r\nfrom St. Joseph, our mud-wagon broke down. We were to be delayed five or\r\nsix hours, and therefore we took horses, by invitation, and joined a\r\nparty who were just starting on a buffalo hunt. It was noble sport\r\ngalloping over the plain in the dewy freshness of the morning, but our\r\npart of the hunt ended in disaster and disgrace, for a wounded buffalo\r\nbull chased the passenger Bemis nearly two miles, and then he forsook\r\nhis horse and took to a lone tree. He was very sullen about the matter\r\nfor some twenty-four hours, but at last he began to soften little by\r\nlittle, and finally he said:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n062.jpg (81K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it was not funny, and there was no sense in those gawks making\r\nthemselves so facetious over it. I tell you I was angry in earnest for\r\nawhile. I should have shot that long gangly lubber they called Hank, if\r\nI could have done it without crippling six or seven other people\xe2\x80\x94but of\r\ncourse I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t, the old \xe2\x80\x98Allen\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x99 so confounded comprehensive. I wish\r\nthose loafers had been up in the tree; they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have wanted to\r\nlaugh so. If I had had a horse worth a cent\xe2\x80\x94but no, the minute he saw\r\nthat buffalo bull wheel on him and give a bellow, he raised straight up\r\nin the air and stood on his heels. The saddle began to slip, and I took\r\nhim round the neck and laid close to him, and began to pray. Then he\r\ncame down and stood up on the other end awhile, and the bull actually\r\nstopped pawing sand and bellowing to contemplate the inhuman spectacle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the bull made a pass at him and uttered a bellow that sounded\r\nperfectly frightful, it was so close to me, and that seemed to literally\r\nprostrate my horse\xe2\x80\x99s reason, and make a raving distracted maniac of him,\r\nand I wish I may die if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t stand on his head for a quarter of a\r\nminute and shed tears. He was absolutely out of his mind\xe2\x80\x94he was, as sure\r\nas truth itself, and he really didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what he was doing. Then the\r\nbull came charging at us, and my horse dropped down on all fours and\r\ntook a fresh start\xe2\x80\x94and then for the next ten minutes he would actually\r\nthrow one hand-spring after another so fast that the bull began to get\r\nunsettled, too, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t know where to start in\xe2\x80\x94and so he stood there\r\nsneezing, and shovelling dust over his back, and bellowing every now and\r\nthen, and thinking he had got a fifteen-hundred dollar circus horse for\r\nbreakfast, certain. Well, I was first out on his neck\xe2\x80\x94the horse\xe2\x80\x99s, not\r\nthe bull\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94and then underneath, and next on his rump, and sometimes head\r\nup, and sometimes heels\xe2\x80\x94but I tell you it seemed solemn and awful to be\r\nripping and tearing and carrying on so in the presence of death, as you\r\nmight say. Pretty soon the bull made a snatch for us and brought away\r\nsome of my horse\xe2\x80\x99s tail (I suppose, but do not know, being pretty busy\r\nat the time), but _something_ made him hungry for solitude and suggested\r\nto him to get up and hunt for it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n063.jpg (63K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then you ought to have seen that spider legged old skeleton go! and\r\nyou ought to have seen the bull cut out after him, too\xe2\x80\x94head down, tongue\r\nout, tail up, bellowing like everything, and actually mowing down the\r\nweeds, and tearing up the earth, and boosting up the sand like a\r\nwhirlwind! By George, it was a hot race! I and the saddle were back on\r\nthe rump, and I had the bridle in my teeth and holding on to the pommel\r\nwith both hands. First we left the dogs behind; then we passed a jackass\r\nrabbit; then we overtook a cayote, and were gaining on an antelope when\r\nthe rotten girth let go and threw me about thirty yards off to the left,\r\nand as the saddle went down over the horse\xe2\x80\x99s rump he gave it a lift with\r\nhis heels that sent it more than four hundred yards up in the air, I\r\nwish I may die in a minute if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t. I fell at the foot of the only\r\nsolitary tree there was in nine counties adjacent (as any creature could\r\nsee with the naked eye), and the next second I had hold of the bark with\r\nfour sets of nails and my teeth, and the next second after that I was\r\nastraddle of the main limb and blaspheming my luck in a way that made my\r\nbreath smell of brimstone. I _had_ the bull, now, if he did not think of\r\none thing. But that one thing I dreaded. I dreaded it very seriously.\r\nThere was a possibility that the bull might not think of it, but there\r\nwere greater chances that he would. I made up my mind what I would do in\r\ncase he did. It was a little over forty feet to the ground from where I\r\nsat. I cautiously unwound the lariat from the pommel of my saddle\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour _saddle_? Did you take your saddle up in the tree with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it up in the tree with me? Why, how you talk. Of course I didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\nNo man could do that. It _fell_ in the tree when it came down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh\xe2\x80\x94exactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. I unwound the lariat, and fastened one end of it to the\r\nlimb. It was the very best green raw-hide, and capable of sustaining\r\ntons. I made a slip-noose in the other end, and then hung it down to see\r\nthe length. It reached down twenty-two feet\xe2\x80\x94half way to the ground. I\r\nthen loaded every barrel of the Allen with a double charge. I felt\r\nsatisfied. I said to myself, if he never thinks of that _one_ thing that\r\nI dread, all right\xe2\x80\x94but if he does, all right anyhow\xe2\x80\x94I am fixed for him.\r\nBut don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that the very thing a man dreads is the thing that\r\nalways happens? Indeed it is so. I watched the bull, now, with\r\nanxiety\xe2\x80\x94anxiety which no one can conceive of who has not been in such a\r\nsituation and felt that at any moment death might come. Presently a\r\nthought came into the bull\xe2\x80\x99s eye. I knew it! said I\xe2\x80\x94if my nerve fails\r\nnow, I am lost. Sure enough, it was just as I had dreaded, he started in\r\nto climb the tree\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, the bull?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course\xe2\x80\x94who else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut a bull can\xe2\x80\x99t climb a tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n065.jpg (75K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe can\xe2\x80\x99t, can\xe2\x80\x99t he? Since you know so much about it, did you ever see a\r\nbull try?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I never dreamt of such a thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, what is the use of your talking that way, then? Because you\r\nnever saw a thing done, is that any reason why it can\xe2\x80\x99t be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all right\xe2\x80\x94go on.
