What did you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bull started up, and got along well for about ten feet, then\r\nslipped and slid back. I breathed easier. He tried it again\xe2\x80\x94got up a\r\nlittle higher\xe2\x80\x94slipped again. But he came at it once more, and this time\r\nhe was careful. He got gradually higher and higher, and my spirits went\r\ndown more and more. Up he came\xe2\x80\x94an inch at a time\xe2\x80\x94with his eyes hot, and\r\nhis tongue hanging out. Higher and higher\xe2\x80\x94hitched his foot over the\r\nstump of a limb, and looked up, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x98You are my meat,\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x99 Up again\xe2\x80\x94higher and higher, and getting more excited the closer\r\nhe got. He was within ten feet of me! I took a long breath,\xe2\x80\x94and then\r\nsaid I, \xe2\x80\x98It is now or never.\xe2\x80\x99 I had the coil of the lariat all ready; I\r\npaid it out slowly, till it hung right over his head; all of a sudden I\r\nlet go of the slack, and the slipnoose fell fairly round his neck!\r\nQuicker than lightning I out with the Allen and let him have it in the\r\nface. It was an awful roar, and must have scared the bull out of his\r\nsenses. When the smoke cleared away, there he was, dangling in the air,\r\ntwenty foot from the ground, and going out of one convulsion into\r\nanother faster than you could count! I didn\xe2\x80\x99t stop to count, anyhow\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nshinned down the tree and shot for home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBemis, is all that true, just as you have stated it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I may rot in my tracks and die the death of a dog if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we can\xe2\x80\x99t refuse to believe it, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t. But if there were\r\nsome proofs\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProofs! Did I bring back my lariat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I bring back my horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see the bull again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, what more do you want? I never saw anybody as particular as\r\nyou are about a little thing like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI made up my mind that if this man was not a liar he only missed it by\r\nthe skin of his teeth. This episode reminds me of an incident of my\r\nbrief sojourn in Siam, years afterward. The European citizens of a town\r\nin the neighborhood of Bangkok had a prodigy among them by the name of\r\nEckert, an Englishman\xe2\x80\x94a person famous for the number, ingenuity and\r\nimposing magnitude of his lies. They were always repeating his most\r\ncelebrated falsehoods, and always trying to \xe2\x80\x9cdraw him out\xe2\x80\x9d before\r\nstrangers; but they seldom succeeded. Twice he was invited to the house\r\nwhere I was visiting, but nothing could seduce him into a specimen lie.\r\nOne day a planter named Bascom, an influential man, and a proud and\r\nsometimes irascible one, invited me to ride over with him and call on\r\nEckert. As we jogged along, said he:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, do you know where the fault lies? It lies in putting Eckert on his\r\nguard. The minute the boys go to pumping at Eckert he knows perfectly\r\nwell what they are after, and of course he shuts up his shell. Anybody\r\nmight know he would. But when we get there, we must play him finer than\r\nthat. Let him shape the conversation to suit himself\xe2\x80\x94let him drop it or\r\nchange it whenever he wants to. Let him see that nobody is trying to\r\ndraw him out. Just let him have his own way. He will soon forget himself\r\nand begin to grind out lies like a mill. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get impatient\xe2\x80\x94just keep\r\nquiet, and let me play him. I will make him lie. It does seem to me that\r\nthe boys must be blind to overlook such an obvious and simple trick as\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEckert received us heartily\xe2\x80\x94a pleasant-spoken, gentle-mannered creature.\r\nWe sat in the veranda an hour, sipping English ale, and talking about\r\nthe king, and the sacred white elephant, the Sleeping Idol, and all\r\nmanner of things; and I noticed that my comrade never led the\r\nconversation himself or shaped it, but simply followed Eckert\xe2\x80\x99s lead,\r\nand betrayed no solicitude and no anxiety about anything. The effect was\r\nshortly perceptible. Eckert began to grow communicative; he grew more\r\nand more at his ease, and more and more talkative and sociable. Another\r\nhour passed in the same way, and then all of a sudden Eckert said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, by the way! I came near forgetting. I have got a thing here to\r\nastonish you. Such a thing as neither you nor any other man ever heard\r\nof\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a cat that will eat cocoanut! Common green cocoanut\xe2\x80\x94and not\r\nonly eat the meat, but drink the milk. It is so\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll swear to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA quick glance from Bascom\xe2\x80\x94a glance that I understood\xe2\x80\x94then:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, bless my soul, I never heard of such a thing. Man, it is\r\nimpossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew you would say it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll fetch the cat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went in the house. Bascom said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x94what did I tell you? Now, that is the way to handle Eckert. You\r\nsee, I have petted him along patiently, and put his suspicions to sleep.\r\nI am glad we came. You tell the boys about it when you go back. Cat eat\r\na cocoanut\xe2\x80\x94oh, my! Now, that is just his way, exactly\xe2\x80\x94he will tell the\r\nabsurdest lie, and trust to luck to get out of it again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCat eat a cocoanut\xe2\x80\x94the innocent fool!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n068.jpg (84K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEckert approached with his cat, sure enough.\r\n\r\nBascom smiled. Said he:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll hold the cat\xe2\x80\x94you bring a cocoanut.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEckert split one open, and chopped up some pieces. Bascom smuggled a\r\nwink to me, and proffered a slice of the fruit to puss. She snatched it,\r\nswallowed it ravenously, and asked for more!\r\n\r\nWe rode our two miles in silence, and wide apart. At least I was silent,\r\nthough Bascom cuffed his horse and cursed him a good deal,\r\nnotwithstanding the horse was behaving well enough. When I branched off\r\nhomeward, Bascom said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep the horse till morning. And\xe2\x80\x94you need not speak of this\xe2\x80\x94foolishness\r\nto the boys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n069.jpg (50K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn a little while all interest was taken up in stretching our necks and\r\nwatching for the \xe2\x80\x9cpony-rider\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the fleet messenger who sped across the\r\ncontinent from St. Joe to Sacramento, carrying letters nineteen hundred\r\nmiles in eight days! Think of that for perishable horse and human flesh\r\nand blood to do! The pony-rider was usually a little bit of a man,\r\nbrimful of spirit and endurance. No matter what time of the day or night\r\nhis watch came on, and no matter whether it was winter or summer,\r\nraining, snowing, hailing, or sleeting, or whether his \xe2\x80\x9cbeat\xe2\x80\x9d was a\r\nlevel straight road or a crazy trail over mountain crags and precipices,\r\nor whether it led through peaceful regions or regions that swarmed with\r\nhostile Indians, he must be always ready to leap into the saddle and be\r\noff like the wind! There was no idling-time for a pony-rider on duty. He\r\nrode fifty miles without stopping, by daylight, moonlight, starlight, or\r\nthrough the blackness of darkness\xe2\x80\x94just as it happened. He rode a\r\nsplendid horse that was born for a racer and fed and lodged like a\r\ngentleman; kept him at his utmost speed for ten miles, and then, as he\r\ncame crashing up to the station where stood two men holding fast a\r\nfresh, impatient steed, the transfer of rider and mail-bag was made in\r\nthe twinkling of an eye, and away flew the eager pair and were out of\r\nsight before the spectator could get hardly the ghost of a look. Both\r\nrider and horse went \xe2\x80\x9cflying light.\xe2\x80\x9d The rider\xe2\x80\x99s dress was thin, and\r\nfitted close; he wore a \xe2\x80\x9cround-about,\xe2\x80\x9d and a skull-cap, and tucked his\r\npantaloons into his boot-tops like a race-rider. He carried no arms\xe2\x80\x94he\r\ncarried nothing that was not absolutely necessary, for even the postage\r\non his literary freight was worth _five dollars a letter_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n071.jpg (120K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe got but little frivolous correspondence to carry\xe2\x80\x94his bag had business\r\nletters in it, mostly. His horse was stripped of all unnecessary weight,\r\ntoo. He wore a little wafer of a racing-saddle, and no visible blanket.\r\nHe wore light shoes, or none at all. The little flat mail-pockets\r\nstrapped under the rider\xe2\x80\x99s thighs would each hold about the bulk of a\r\nchild\xe2\x80\x99s primer. They held many and many an important business chapter\r\nand newspaper letter, but these were written on paper as airy and thin\r\nas gold-leaf, nearly, and thus bulk and weight were economized. The\r\nstage-coach traveled about a hundred to a hundred and twenty-five miles\r\na day (twenty-four hours), the pony-rider about two hundred and fifty.\r\nThere were about eighty pony-riders in the saddle all the time, night\r\nand day, stretching in a long, scattering procession from Missouri to\r\nCalifornia, forty flying eastward, and forty toward the west, and among\r\nthem making four hundred gallant horses earn a stirring livelihood and\r\nsee a deal of scenery every single day in the year.\r\n\r\nWe had had a consuming desire, from the beginning, to see a pony-rider,\r\nbut somehow or other all that passed us and all that met us managed to\r\nstreak by in the night, and so we heard only a whiz and a hail, and the\r\nswift phantom of the desert was gone before we could get our heads out\r\nof the windows. But now we were expecting one along every moment, and\r\nwould see him in broad daylight. Presently the driver exclaims:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHERE HE COMES!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvery neck is stretched further, and every eye strained wider. Away\r\nacross the endless dead level of the prairie a black speck appears\r\nagainst the sky, and it is plain that it moves. Well, I should think so!\r\n\r\nIn a second or two it becomes a horse and rider, rising and falling,\r\nrising and falling\xe2\x80\x94sweeping toward us nearer and nearer\xe2\x80\x94growing more and\r\nmore distinct, more and more sharply defined\xe2\x80\x94nearer and still nearer,\r\nand the flutter of the hoofs comes faintly to the ear\xe2\x80\x94another instant a\r\nwhoop and a hurrah from our upper deck, a wave of the rider\xe2\x80\x99s hand, but\r\nno reply, and man and horse burst past our excited faces, and go winging\r\naway like a belated fragment of a storm!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n072.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSo sudden is it all, and so like a flash of unreal fancy, that but for\r\nthe flake of white foam left quivering and perishing on a mail-sack\r\nafter the vision had flashed by and disappeared, we might have doubted\r\nwhether we had seen any actual horse and man at all, maybe.\r\n\r\nWe rattled through Scott\xe2\x80\x99s Bluffs Pass, by and by. It was along here\r\nsomewhere that we first came across genuine and unmistakable alkali\r\nwater in the road, and we cordially hailed it as a first-class\r\ncuriosity, and a thing to be mentioned with eclat in letters to the\r\nignorant at home. This water gave the road a soapy appearance, and in\r\nmany places the ground looked as if it had been whitewashed. I think the\r\nstrange alkali water excited us as much as any wonder we had come upon\r\nyet, and I know we felt very complacent and conceited, and better\r\nsatisfied with life after we had added it to our list of things which\r\n_we_ had seen and some other people had not. In a small way we were the\r\nsame sort of simpletons as those who climb unnecessarily the perilous\r\npeaks of Mont Blanc and the Matterhorn, and derive no pleasure from it\r\nexcept the reflection that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t a common experience. But once in a\r\nwhile one of those parties trips and comes darting down the long\r\nmountain-crags in a sitting posture, making the crusted snow smoke\r\nbehind him, flitting from bench to bench, and from terrace to terrace,\r\njarring the earth where he strikes, and still glancing and flitting on\r\nagain, sticking an iceberg into himself every now and then, and tearing\r\nhis clothes, snatching at things to save himself, taking hold of trees\r\nand fetching them along with him, roots and all, starting little rocks\r\nnow and then, then big boulders, then acres of ice and snow and patches\r\nof forest, gathering and still gathering as he goes, adding and still\r\nadding to his massed and sweeping grandeur as he nears a three thousand-\r\nfoot precipice, till at last he waves his hat magnificently and rides\r\ninto eternity on the back of a raging and tossing avalanche!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n073.jpg (48K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThis is all very fine, but let us not be carried away by excitement, but\r\nask calmly, how does this person feel about it in his cooler moments\r\nnext day, with six or seven thousand feet of snow and stuff on top of\r\nhim?\r\n\r\nWe crossed the sand hills near the scene of the Indian mail robbery and\r\nmassacre of 1856, wherein the driver and conductor perished, and also\r\nall the passengers but one, it was supposed; but this must have been a\r\nmistake, for at different times afterward on the Pacific coast I was\r\npersonally acquainted with a hundred and thirty-three or four people who\r\nwere wounded during that massacre, and barely escaped with their lives.\r\nThere was no doubt of the truth of it\xe2\x80\x94I had it from their own lips. One\r\nof these parties told me that he kept coming across arrow-heads in his\r\nsystem for nearly seven years after the massacre; and another of them\r\ntold me that he was struck so literally full of arrows that after the\r\nIndians were gone and he could raise up and examine himself, he could\r\nnot restrain his tears, for his clothes were completely ruined.\r\n\r\nThe most trustworthy tradition avers, however, that only one man, a\r\nperson named Babbitt, survived the massacre, and he was desperately\r\nwounded. He dragged himself on his hands and knee (for one leg was\r\nbroken) to a station several miles away. He did it during portions of\r\ntwo nights, lying concealed one day and part of another, and for more\r\nthan forty hours suffering unimaginable anguish from hunger, thirst and\r\nbodily pain. The Indians robbed the coach of everything it contained,\r\nincluding quite an amount of treasure.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe passed Fort Laramie in the night, and on the seventh morning out we\r\nfound ourselves in the Black Hills, with Laramie Peak at our elbow\r\n(apparently) looming vast and solitary\xe2\x80\x94a deep, dark, rich indigo blue in\r\nhue, so portentously did the old colossus frown under his beetling brows\r\nof storm-cloud. He was thirty or forty miles away, in reality, but he\r\nonly seemed removed a little beyond the low ridge at our right. We\r\nbreakfasted at Horse-Shoe Station, six hundred and seventy-six miles out\r\nfrom St. Joseph. We had now reached a hostile Indian country, and during\r\nthe afternoon we passed Laparelle Station, and enjoyed great discomfort\r\nall the time we were in the neighborhood, being aware that many of the\r\ntrees we dashed by at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length concealed a lurking Indian or two.\r\nDuring the preceding night an ambushed savage had sent a bullet through\r\nthe pony-rider\xe2\x80\x99s jacket, but he had ridden on, just the same, because\r\npony-riders were not allowed to stop and inquire into such things except\r\nwhen killed. As long as they had life enough left in them they had to\r\nstick to the horse and ride, even if the Indians had been waiting for\r\nthem a week, and were entirely out of patience. About two hours and a\r\nhalf before we arrived at Laparelle Station, the keeper in charge of it\r\nhad fired four times at an Indian, but he said with an injured air that\r\nthe Indian had \xe2\x80\x9cskipped around so\xe2\x80\x99s to spile everything\xe2\x80\x94and ammunition\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nblamed skurse, too.\xe2\x80\x9d The most natural inference conveyed by his manner\r\nof speaking was, that in \xe2\x80\x9cskipping around,\xe2\x80\x9d the Indian had taken an\r\nunfair advantage.\r\n\r\nThe coach we were in had a neat hole through its front\xe2\x80\x94a reminiscence of\r\nits last trip through this region. The bullet that made it wounded the\r\ndriver slightly, but he did not mind it much. He said the place to keep\r\na man \xe2\x80\x9chuffy\xe2\x80\x9d was down on the Southern Overland, among the Apaches,\r\nbefore the company moved the stage line up on the northern route. He\r\nsaid the Apaches used to annoy him all the time down there, and that he\r\ncame as near as anything to starving to death in the midst of abundance,\r\nbecause they kept him so leaky with bullet holes that he \xe2\x80\x9ccouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hold\r\nhis vittles.\xe2\x80\x9d This person\xe2\x80\x99s statements were not generally believed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n076.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe shut the blinds down very tightly that first night in the hostile\r\nIndian country, and lay on our arms. We slept on them some, but most of\r\nthe time we only lay on them. We did not talk much, but kept quiet and\r\nlistened. It was an inky-black night, and occasionally rainy. We were\r\namong woods and rocks, hills and gorges\xe2\x80\x94so shut in, in fact, that when\r\nwe peeped through a chink in a curtain, we could discern nothing. The\r\ndriver and conductor on top were still, too, or only spoke at long\r\nintervals, in low tones, as is the way of men in the midst of invisible\r\ndangers. We listened to rain-drops pattering on the roof; and the\r\ngrinding of the wheels through the muddy gravel; and the low wailing of\r\nthe wind; and all the time we had that absurd sense upon us, inseparable\r\nfrom travel at night in a close-curtained vehicle, the sense of\r\nremaining perfectly still in one place, notwithstanding the jolting and\r\nswaying of the vehicle, the trampling of the horses, and the grinding of\r\nthe wheels. We listened a long time, with intent faculties and bated\r\nbreath; every time one of us would relax, and draw a long sigh of relief\r\nand start to say something, a comrade would be sure to utter a sudden\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark!\xe2\x80\x9d and instantly the experimenter was rigid and listening again. So\r\nthe tiresome minutes and decades of minutes dragged away, until at last\r\nour tense forms filmed over with a dulled consciousness, and we slept,\r\nif one might call such a condition by so strong a name\xe2\x80\x94for it was a\r\nsleep set with a hair-trigger. It was a sleep seething and teeming with\r\na weird and distressful confusion of shreds and fag-ends of dreams\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nsleep that was a chaos. Presently, dreams and sleep and the sullen hush\r\nof the night were startled by a ringing report, and cloven by _such_ a\r\nlong, wild, agonizing shriek! Then we heard\xe2\x80\x94ten steps from the stage\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp! help! help!\xe2\x80\x9d [It was our driver\xe2\x80\x99s voice.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKill him! Kill him like a dog!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m being murdered! Will no man lend me a pistol?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook out! head him off! head him off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Two pistol shots; a confusion of voices and the trampling of many feet,\r\nas if a crowd were closing and surging together around some object;\r\nseveral heavy, dull blows, as with a club; a voice that said\r\nappealingly, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, gentlemen, please don\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m a dead man!\xe2\x80\x9d Then a\r\nfainter groan, and another blow, and away sped the stage into the\r\ndarkness, and left the grisly mystery behind us.]\r\n\r\nWhat a startle it was! Eight seconds would amply cover the time it\r\noccupied\xe2\x80\x94maybe even five would do it. We only had time to plunge at a\r\ncurtain and unbuckle and unbutton part of it in an awkward and hindering\r\nflurry, when our whip cracked sharply overhead, and we went rumbling and\r\nthundering away, down a mountain \xe2\x80\x9cgrade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe fed on that mystery the rest of the night\xe2\x80\x94what was left of it, for it\r\nwas waning fast. It had to remain a present mystery, for all we could\r\nget from the conductor in answer to our hails was something that\r\nsounded, through the clatter of the wheels, like \xe2\x80\x9cTell you in the\r\nmorning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo we lit our pipes and opened the corner of a curtain for a chimney,\r\nand lay there in the dark, listening to each other\xe2\x80\x99s story of how he\r\nfirst felt and how many thousand Indians he first thought had hurled\r\nthemselves upon us, and what his remembrance of the subsequent sounds\r\nwas, and the order of their occurrence. And we theorized, too, but there\r\nwas never a theory that would account for our driver\xe2\x80\x99s voice being out\r\nthere, nor yet account for his Indian murderers talking such good\r\nEnglish, if they _were_ Indians.\r\n\r\nSo we chatted and smoked the rest of the night comfortably away, our\r\nboding anxiety being somehow marvelously dissipated by the real presence\r\nof something to be anxious _about_.\r\n\r\nWe never did get much satisfaction about that dark occurrence. All that\r\nwe could make out of the odds and ends of the information we gathered in\r\nthe morning, was that the disturbance occurred at a station; that we\r\nchanged drivers there, and that the driver that got off there had been\r\ntalking roughly about some of the outlaws that infested the region (\xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nthere wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a man around there but had a price on his head and didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndare show himself in the settlements,\xe2\x80\x9d the conductor said); he had\r\ntalked roughly about these characters, and ought to have \xe2\x80\x9cdrove up there\r\nwith his pistol cocked and ready on the seat alongside of him, and begun\r\nbusiness himself, because any softy would know they would be laying for\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat was all we could gather, and we could see that neither the\r\nconductor nor the new driver were much concerned about the matter. They\r\nplainly had little respect for a man who would deliver offensive\r\nopinions of people and then be so simple as to come into their presence\r\nunprepared to \xe2\x80\x9cback his judgment,\xe2\x80\x9d as they pleasantly phrased the\r\nkilling of any fellow-being who did not like said opinions. And likewise\r\nthey plainly had a contempt for the man\xe2\x80\x99s poor discretion in venturing\r\nto rouse the wrath of such utterly reckless wild beasts as those\r\noutlaws\xe2\x80\x94and the conductor added:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you it\xe2\x80\x99s as much as Slade himself wants to do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis remark created an entire revolution in my curiosity. I cared\r\nnothing now about the Indians, and even lost interest in the murdered\r\ndriver. There was such magic in that name, SLADE! Day or night, now, I\r\nstood always ready to drop any subject in hand, to listen to something\r\nnew about Slade and his ghastly exploits. Even before we got to Overland\r\nCity, we had begun to hear about Slade and his \xe2\x80\x9cdivision\xe2\x80\x9d (for he was a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdivision-agent\xe2\x80\x9d) on the Overland; and from the hour we had left\r\nOverland City we had heard drivers and conductors talk about only three\r\nthings\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCaliforny,\xe2\x80\x9d the Nevada silver mines, and this desperado Slade.\r\nAnd a deal the most of the talk was about Slade. We had gradually come\r\nto have a realizing sense of the fact that Slade was a man whose heart\r\nand hands and soul were steeped in the blood of offenders against his\r\ndignity; a man who awfully avenged all injuries, affront, insults or\r\nslights, of whatever kind\xe2\x80\x94on the spot if he could, years afterward if\r\nlack of earlier opportunity compelled it; a man whose hate tortured him\r\nday and night till vengeance appeased it\xe2\x80\x94and not an ordinary vengeance\r\neither, but his enemy\xe2\x80\x99s absolute death\xe2\x80\x94nothing less; a man whose face\r\nwould light up with a terrible joy when he surprised a foe and had him\r\nat a disadvantage. A high and efficient servant of the Overland, an\r\noutlaw among outlaws and yet their relentless scourge, Slade was at once\r\nthe most bloody, the most dangerous and the most valuable citizen that\r\ninhabited the savage fastnesses of the mountains.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X.\r\n\r\n\r\nReally and truly, two thirds of the talk of drivers and conductors had\r\nbeen about this man Slade, ever since the day before we reached\r\nJulesburg. In order that the eastern reader may have a clear conception\r\nof what a Rocky Mountain desperado is, in his highest state of\r\ndevelopment, I will reduce all this mass of overland gossip to one\r\nstraightforward narrative, and present it in the following shape:\r\n\r\nSlade was born in Illinois, of good parentage. At about twenty-six years\r\nof age he killed a man in a quarrel and fled the country. At St. Joseph,\r\nMissouri, he joined one of the early California-bound emigrant trains,\r\nand was given the post of train-master. One day on the plains he had an\r\nangry dispute with one of his wagon-drivers, and both drew their\r\nrevolvers. But the driver was the quicker artist, and had his weapon\r\ncocked first. So Slade said it was a pity to waste life on so small a\r\nmatter, and proposed that the pistols be thrown on the ground and the\r\nquarrel settled by a fist-fight. The unsuspecting driver agreed, and\r\nthrew down his pistol\xe2\x80\x94whereupon Slade laughed at his simplicity, and\r\nshot him dead!\r\n\r\nHe made his escape, and lived a wild life for awhile, dividing his time\r\nbetween fighting Indians and avoiding an Illinois sheriff, who had been\r\nsent to arrest him for his first murder. It is said that in one Indian\r\nbattle he killed three savages with his own hand, and afterward cut\r\ntheir ears off and sent them, with his compliments, to the chief of the\r\ntribe.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n081.jpg (55K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSlade soon gained a name for fearless resolution, and this was\r\nsufficient merit to procure for him the important post of overland\r\ndivision-agent at Julesburg, in place of Mr. Jules, removed. For some\r\ntime previously, the company\xe2\x80\x99s horses had been frequently stolen, and\r\nthe coaches delayed, by gangs of outlaws, who were wont to laugh at the\r\nidea of any man\xe2\x80\x99s having the temerity to resent such outrages. Slade\r\nresented them promptly.\r\n\r\nThe outlaws soon found that the new agent was a man who did not fear\r\nanything that breathed the breath of life. He made short work of all\r\noffenders. The result was that delays ceased, the company\xe2\x80\x99s property was\r\nlet alone, and no matter what happened or who suffered, Slade\xe2\x80\x99s coaches\r\nwent through, every time! True, in order to bring about this wholesome\r\nchange, Slade had to kill several men\xe2\x80\x94some say three, others say four,\r\nand others six\xe2\x80\x94but the world was the richer for their loss. The first\r\nprominent difficulty he had was with the ex-agent Jules, who bore the\r\nreputation of being a reckless and desperate man himself. Jules hated\r\nSlade for supplanting him, and a good fair occasion for a fight was all\r\nhe was waiting for. By and by Slade dared to employ a man whom Jules had\r\nonce discharged. Next, Slade seized a team of stage-horses which he\r\naccused Jules of having driven off and hidden somewhere for his own use.\r\nWar was declared, and for a day or two the two men walked warily about\r\nthe streets, seeking each other, Jules armed with a double-barreled shot\r\ngun, and Slade with his history-creating revolver. Finally, as Slade\r\nstepped into a store Jules poured the contents of his gun into him from\r\nbehind the door. Slade was pluck, and Jules got several bad pistol\r\nwounds in return.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n082.jpg (157K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen both men fell, and were carried to their respective lodgings, both\r\nswearing that better aim should do deadlier work next time. Both were\r\nbedridden a long time, but Jules got to his feet first, and gathering\r\nhis possessions together, packed them on a couple of mules, and fled to\r\nthe Rocky Mountains to gather strength in safety against the day of\r\nreckoning. For many months he was not seen or heard of, and was\r\ngradually dropped out of the remembrance of all save Slade himself. But\r\nSlade was not the man to forget him. On the contrary, common report said\r\nthat Slade kept a reward standing for his capture, dead or alive!\r\n\r\nAfter awhile, seeing that Slade\xe2\x80\x99s energetic administration had restored\r\npeace and order to one of the worst divisions of the road, the overland\r\nstage company transferred him to the Rocky Ridge division in the Rocky\r\nMountains, to see if he could perform a like miracle there. It was the\r\nvery paradise of outlaws and desperadoes. There was absolutely no\r\nsemblance of law there. Violence was the rule. Force was the only\r\nrecognized authority. The commonest misunderstandings were settled on\r\nthe spot with the revolver or the knife. Murders were done in open day,\r\nand with sparkling frequency, and nobody thought of inquiring into them.\r\nIt was considered that the parties who did the killing had their private\r\nreasons for it; for other people to meddle would have been looked upon\r\nas indelicate. After a murder, all that Rocky Mountain etiquette\r\nrequired of a spectator was, that he should help the gentleman bury his\r\ngame\xe2\x80\x94otherwise his churlishness would surely be remembered against him\r\nthe first time he killed a man himself and needed a neighborly turn in\r\ninterring him.\r\n\r\nSlade took up his residence sweetly and peacefully in the midst of this\r\nhive of horse-thieves and assassins, and the very first time one of them\r\naired his insolent swaggerings in his presence he shot him dead! He\r\nbegan a raid on the outlaws, and in a singularly short space of time he\r\nhad completely stopped their depredations on the stage stock, recovered\r\na large number of stolen horses, killed several of the worst desperadoes\r\nof the district, and gained such a dread ascendancy over the rest that\r\nthey respected him, admired him, feared him, obeyed him! He wrought the\r\nsame marvelous change in the ways of the community that had marked his\r\nadministration at Overland City. He captured two men who had stolen\r\noverland stock, and with his own hands he hanged them. He was supreme\r\njudge in his district, and he was jury and executioner likewise\xe2\x80\x94and not\r\nonly in the case of offences against his employers, but against passing\r\nemigrants as well. On one occasion some emigrants had their stock lost\r\nor stolen, and told Slade, who chanced to visit their camp. With a\r\nsingle companion he rode to a ranch, the owners of which he suspected,\r\nand opening the door, commenced firing, killing three, and wounding the\r\nfourth.\r\n\r\nFrom a bloodthirstily interesting little Montana book.\xe2\x80\x94[\xe2\x80\x9cThe Vigilantes\r\nof Montana,\xe2\x80\x9d by Prof. Thos. J. Dimsdale.]\xe2\x80\x94I take this paragraph:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile on the road, Slade held absolute sway. He would ride down to a\r\nstation, get into a quarrel, turn the house out of windows, and maltreat\r\nthe occupants most cruelly. The unfortunates had no means of redress,\r\nand were compelled to recuperate as best they could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n084.jpg (67K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOn one of these occasions, it is said he killed the father of the fine\r\nlittle half-breed boy Jemmy, whom he adopted, and who lived with his\r\nwidow after his execution. Stories of Slade\xe2\x80\x99s hanging men, and of\r\ninnumerable assaults, shootings, stabbings and beatings, in which he was\r\na principal actor, form part of the legends of the stage line. As for\r\nminor quarrels and shootings, it is absolutely certain that a minute\r\nhistory of Slade\xe2\x80\x99s life would be one long record of such practices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Vigilantes of Montana\xe2\x80\x9d by Prof. Thomas J. Dimsdale\r\n\r\nSlade was a matchless marksman with a navy revolver. The legends say\r\nthat one morning at Rocky Ridge, when he was feeling comfortable, he saw\r\na man approaching who had offended him some days before\xe2\x80\x94observe the fine\r\nmemory he had for matters like that\xe2\x80\x94and, \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Slade,\r\ndrawing, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a good twenty-yard shot\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll clip the third button on\r\nhis coat!\xe2\x80\x9d Which he did. The bystanders all admired it. And they all\r\nattended the funeral, too.\r\n\r\nOn one occasion a man who kept a little whisky-shelf at the station did\r\nsomething which angered Slade\xe2\x80\x94and went and made his will. A day or two\r\nafterward Slade came in and called for some brandy. The man reached\r\nunder the counter (ostensibly to get a bottle\xe2\x80\x94possibly to get something\r\nelse), but Slade smiled upon him that peculiarly bland and satisfied\r\nsmile of his which the neighbors had long ago learned to recognize as a\r\ndeath-warrant in disguise, and told him to \xe2\x80\x9cnone of that!\xe2\x80\x94pass out the\r\nhigh-priced article.\xe2\x80\x9d So the poor bar-keeper had to turn his back and\r\nget the high-priced brandy from the shelf; and when he faced around\r\nagain he was looking into the muzzle of Slade\xe2\x80\x99s pistol. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the next\r\ninstant,\xe2\x80\x9d added my informant, impressively, \xe2\x80\x9che was one of the deadest\r\nmen that ever lived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n085.jpg (94K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe stage-drivers and conductors told us that sometimes Slade would\r\nleave a hated enemy wholly unmolested, unnoticed and unmentioned, for\r\nweeks together\xe2\x80\x94had done it once or twice at any rate. And some said they\r\nbelieved he did it in order to lull the victims into unwatchfulness, so\r\nthat he could get the advantage of them, and others said they believed\r\nhe saved up an enemy that way, just as a schoolboy saves up a cake, and\r\nmade the pleasure go as far as it would by gloating over the\r\nanticipation. One of these cases was that of a Frenchman who had\r\noffended Slade. To the surprise of everybody Slade did not kill him on\r\nthe spot, but let him alone for a considerable time. Finally, however,\r\nhe went to the Frenchman\xe2\x80\x99s house very late one night, knocked, and when\r\nhis enemy opened the door, shot him dead\xe2\x80\x94pushed the corpse inside the\r\ndoor with his foot, set the house on fire and burned up the dead man,\r\nhis widow and three children! I heard this story from several different\r\npeople, and they evidently believed what they were saying. It may be\r\ntrue, and it may not. \xe2\x80\x9cGive a dog a bad name,\xe2\x80\x9d etc.\r\n\r\nSlade was captured, once, by a party of men who intended to lynch him.\r\nThey disarmed him, and shut him up in a strong log-house, and placed a\r\nguard over him. He prevailed on his captors to send for his wife, so\r\nthat he might have a last interview with her. She was a brave, loving,\r\nspirited woman. She jumped on a horse and rode for life and death. When\r\nshe arrived they let her in without searching her, and before the door\r\ncould be closed she whipped out a couple of revolvers, and she and her\r\nlord marched forth defying the party. And then, under a brisk fire, they\r\nmounted double and galloped away unharmed!\r\n\r\nIn the fulness of time Slade\xe2\x80\x99s myrmidons captured his ancient enemy\r\nJules, whom they found in a well-chosen hiding-place in the remote\r\nfastnesses of the mountains, gaining a precarious livelihood with his\r\nrifle. They brought him to Rocky Ridge, bound hand and foot, and\r\ndeposited him in the middle of the cattle-yard with his back against a\r\npost. It is said that the pleasure that lit Slade\xe2\x80\x99s face when he heard\r\nof it was something fearful to contemplate. He examined his enemy to see\r\nthat he was securely tied, and then went to bed, content to wait till\r\nmorning before enjoying the luxury of killing him. Jules spent the night\r\nin the cattle-yard, and it is a region where warm nights are never\r\nknown. In the morning Slade practised on him with his revolver, nipping\r\nthe flesh here and there, and occasionally clipping off a finger, while\r\nJules begged him to kill him outright and put him out of his misery.\r\nFinally Slade reloaded, and walking up close to his victim, made some\r\ncharacteristic remarks and then dispatched him. The body lay there half\r\na day, nobody venturing to touch it without orders, and then Slade\r\ndetailed a party and assisted at the burial himself. But he first cut\r\noff the dead man\xe2\x80\x99s ears and put them in his vest pocket, where he\r\ncarried them for some time with great satisfaction. That is the story as\r\nI have frequently heard it told and seen it in print in California\r\nnewspapers. It is doubtless correct in all essential particulars.\r\n\r\nIn due time we rattled up to a stage-station, and sat down to breakfast\r\nwith a half-savage, half-civilized company of armed and bearded\r\nmountaineers, ranchmen and station employees. The most gentlemanly-\r\nappearing, quiet and affable officer we had yet found along the road in\r\nthe Overland Company\xe2\x80\x99s service was the person who sat at the head of the\r\ntable, at my elbow. Never youth stared and shivered as I did when I\r\nheard them call him SLADE!\r\n\r\nHere was romance, and I sitting face to face with it!\xe2\x80\x94looking upon\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94touching it\xe2\x80\x94hobnobbing with it, as it were! Here, right by my side,\r\nwas the actual ogre who, in fights and brawls and various ways, _had\r\ntaken the lives of twenty-six human beings_, or all men lied about him!\r\nI suppose I was the proudest stripling that ever traveled to see strange\r\nlands and wonderful people.\r\n\r\nHe was so friendly and so gentle-spoken that I warmed to him in spite of\r\nhis awful history. It was hardly possible to realize that this pleasant\r\nperson was the pitiless scourge of the outlaws, the raw-head-and-bloody-\r\nbones the nursing mothers of the mountains terrified their children\r\nwith. And to this day I can remember nothing remarkable about Slade\r\nexcept that his face was rather broad across the cheek bones, and that\r\nthe cheek bones were low and the lips peculiarly thin and straight. But\r\nthat was enough to leave something of an effect upon me, for since then\r\nI seldom see a face possessing those characteristics without fancying\r\nthat the owner of it is a dangerous man.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n088.jpg (57K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe coffee ran out. At least it was reduced to one tin-cupful, and Slade\r\nwas about to take it when he saw that my cup was empty.\r\n\r\nHe politely offered to fill it, but although I wanted it, I politely\r\ndeclined. I was afraid he had not killed anybody that morning, and might\r\nbe needing diversion. But still with firm politeness he insisted on\r\nfilling my cup, and said I had traveled all night and better deserved it\r\nthan he\xe2\x80\x94and while he talked he placidly poured the fluid, to the last\r\ndrop. I thanked him and drank it, but it gave me no comfort, for I could\r\nnot feel sure that he would not be sorry, presently, that he had given\r\nit away, and proceed to kill me to distract his thoughts from the loss.\r\nBut nothing of the kind occurred. We left him with only twenty-six dead\r\npeople to account for, and I felt a tranquil satisfaction in the thought\r\nthat in so judiciously taking care of No. 1 at that breakfast-table I\r\nhad pleasantly escaped being No. 27. Slade came out to the coach and saw\r\nus off, first ordering certain rearrangements of the mail-bags for our\r\ncomfort, and then we took leave of him, satisfied that we should hear of\r\nhim again, some day, and wondering in what connection.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n089.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI.\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd sure enough, two or three years afterward, we did hear him again.\r\nNews came to the Pacific coast that the Vigilance Committee in Montana\r\n(whither Slade had removed from Rocky Ridge) had hanged him. I find an\r\naccount of the affair in the thrilling little book I quoted a paragraph\r\nfrom in the last chapter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Vigilantes of Montana; being a Reliable\r\nAccount of the Capture, Trial and Execution of Henry Plummer\xe2\x80\x99s Notorious\r\nRoad Agent Band: By Prof. Thos. J. Dimsdale, Virginia City, M.T.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nDimsdale\xe2\x80\x99s chapter is well worth reading, as a specimen of how the\r\npeople of the frontier deal with criminals when the courts of law prove\r\ninefficient. Mr. Dimsdale makes two remarks about Slade, both of which\r\nare accurately descriptive, and one of which is exceedingly picturesque:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose who saw him in his natural state only, would pronounce him to be\r\na kind husband, a most hospitable host and a courteous gentleman; on the\r\ncontrary, those who met him when maddened with liquor and surrounded by\r\na gang of armed roughs, would pronounce him a fiend incarnate.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nthis: \xe2\x80\x9cFrom Fort Kearney, west, _he was feared A GREAT DEAL MORE THAN\r\nTHE ALMIGHTY_.\xe2\x80\x9d For compactness, simplicity and vigor of expression, I\r\nwill \xe2\x80\x9cback\xe2\x80\x9d that sentence against anything in literature. Mr. Dimsdale\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnarrative is as follows. In all places where italics occur, they are\r\nmine:\r\n\r\nAfter the execution of the five men on the 14th of January, the\r\nVigilantes considered that their work was nearly ended. They had freed\r\nthe country of highwaymen and murderers to a great extent, and they\r\ndetermined that in the absence of the regular civil authority they would\r\nestablish a People\xe2\x80\x99s Court where all offenders should be tried by judge\r\nand jury. This was the nearest approach to social order that the\r\ncircumstances permitted, and, though strict legal authority was wanting,\r\nyet the people were firmly determined to maintain its efficiency, and to\r\nenforce its decrees. It may here be mentioned that the overt act which\r\nwas the last round on the fatal ladder leading to the scaffold on which\r\nSlade perished, was the tearing in pieces and stamping upon a writ of\r\nthis court, followed by his arrest of the Judge Alex. Davis, by\r\nauthority of a presented Derringer, and with his own hands.\r\n\r\nJ. A. Slade was himself, we have been informed, a Vigilante; he openly\r\nboasted of it, and said he knew all that they knew. He was never\r\naccused, or even suspected, of either murder or robbery, committed in\r\nthis Territory (the latter crime was never laid to his charge, in any\r\nplace); but that he had killed several men in other localities was\r\nnotorious, and his bad reputation in this respect was a most powerful\r\nargument in determining his fate, when he was finally arrested for the\r\noffence above mentioned. On returning from Milk River he became more and\r\nmore addicted to drinking, until at last it was a common feat for him\r\nand his friends to \xe2\x80\x9ctake the town.\xe2\x80\x9d He and a couple of his dependents\r\nmight often be seen on one horse, galloping through the streets,\r\nshouting and yelling, firing revolvers, etc. On many occasions he would\r\nride his horse into stores, break up bars, toss the scales out of doors\r\nand use most insulting language to parties present. Just previous to the\r\nday of his arrest, he had given a fearful beating to one of his\r\nfollowers; but such was his influence over them that the man wept\r\nbitterly at the gallows, and begged for his life with all his power. It\r\nhad become quite common, when Slade was on a spree, for the shop-keepers\r\nand citizens to close the stores and put out all the lights; being\r\nfearful of some outrage at his hands. For his wanton destruction of\r\ngoods and furniture, he was always ready to pay, when sober, if he had\r\nmoney; but there were not a few who regarded payment as small\r\nsatisfaction for the outrage, and these men were his personal enemies.\r\n\r\nFrom time to time Slade received warnings from men that he well knew\r\nwould not deceive him, of the certain end of his conduct. There was not\r\na moment, for weeks previous to his arrest, in which the public did not\r\nexpect to hear of some bloody outrage. The dread of his very name, and\r\nthe presence of the armed band of hangers-on who followed him alone\r\nprevented a resistance which must certainly have ended in the instant\r\nmurder or mutilation of the opposing party.\r\n\r\nSlade was frequently arrested by order of the court whose organization\r\nwe have described, and had treated it with respect by paying one or two\r\nfines and promising to pay the rest when he had money; but in the\r\ntransaction that occurred at this crisis, he forgot even this caution,\r\nand goaded by passion and the hatred of restraint, he sprang into the\r\nembrace of death.\r\n\r\nSlade had been drunk and \xe2\x80\x9ccutting up\xe2\x80\x9d all night. He and his companions\r\nhad made the town a perfect hell. In the morning, J. M. Fox, the\r\nsheriff, met him, arrested him, took him into court and commenced\r\nreading a warrant that he had for his arrest, by way of arraignment. He\r\nbecame uncontrollably furious, and seizing the writ, he tore it up,\r\nthrew it on the ground and stamped upon it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n092.jpg (121K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe clicking of the locks of his companions\xe2\x80\x99 revolvers was instantly\r\nheard, and a crisis was expected. The sheriff did not attempt his\r\nretention; but being at least as prudent as he was valiant, he\r\nsuccumbed, leaving Slade the master of the situation and the conqueror\r\nand ruler of the courts, law and law-makers. This was a declaration of\r\nwar, and was so accepted. The Vigilance Committee now felt that the\r\nquestion of social order and the preponderance of the law-abiding\r\ncitizens had then and there to be decided. They knew the character of\r\nSlade, and they were well aware that they must submit to his rule\r\nwithout murmur, or else that he must be dealt with in such fashion as\r\nwould prevent his being able to wreak his vengeance on the committee,\r\nwho could never have hoped to live in the Territory secure from outrage\r\nor death, and who could never leave it without encountering his friends,\r\nwhom his victory would have emboldened and stimulated to a pitch that\r\nwould have rendered them reckless of consequences. The day previous he\r\nhad ridden into Dorris\xe2\x80\x99s store, and on being requested to leave, he drew\r\nhis revolver and threatened to kill the gentleman who spoke to him.\r\nAnother saloon he had led his horse into, and buying a bottle of wine,\r\nhe tried to make the animal drink it. This was not considered an\r\nuncommon performance, as he had often entered saloons and commenced\r\nfiring at the lamps, causing a wild stampede.\r\n\r\nA leading member of the committee met Slade, and informed him in the\r\nquiet, earnest manner of one who feels the importance of what he is\r\nsaying: \xe2\x80\x9cSlade, get your horse at once, and go home, or there will\r\nbe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94to pay.\xe2\x80\x9d Slade started and took a long look, with his dark and\r\npiercing eyes, at the gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have\r\nno right to ask me what I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d was the quiet reply, \xe2\x80\x9cget your horse at\r\nonce, and remember what I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d After a short pause he promised to\r\ndo so, and actually got into the saddle; but, being still intoxicated,\r\nhe began calling aloud to one after another of his friends, and at last\r\nseemed to have forgotten the warning he had received and became again\r\nuproarious, shouting the name of a well-known courtezan in company with\r\nthose of two men whom he considered heads of the committee, as a sort of\r\nchallenge; perhaps, however, as a simple act of bravado. It seems\r\nprobable that the intimation of personal danger he had received had not\r\nbeen forgotten entirely; though fatally for him, he took a foolish way\r\nof showing his remembrance of it. He sought out Alexander Davis, the\r\nJudge of the Court, and drawing a cocked Derringer, he presented it at\r\nhis head, and told him that he should hold him as a hostage for his own\r\nsafety. As the judge stood perfectly quiet, and offered no resistance to\r\nhis captor, no further outrage followed on this score. Previous to this,\r\non account of the critical state of affairs, the committee had met, and\r\nat last resolved to arrest him. His execution had not been agreed upon,\r\nand, at that time, would have been negatived, most assuredly. A\r\nmessenger rode down to Nevada to inform the leading men of what was on\r\nhand, as it was desirable to show that there was a feeling of unanimity\r\non the subject, all along the gulch.\r\n\r\nThe miners turned out almost en masse, leaving their work and forming in\r\nsolid column about six hundred strong, armed to the teeth, they marched\r\nup to Virginia. The leader of the body well knew the temper of his men\r\non the subject. He spurred on ahead of them, and hastily calling a\r\nmeeting of the executive, he told them plainly that the miners meant\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness,\xe2\x80\x9d and that, if they came up, they would not stand in the\r\nstreet to be shot down by Slade\xe2\x80\x99s friends; but that they would take him\r\nand hang him. The meeting was small, as the Virginia men were loath to\r\nact at all. This momentous announcement of the feeling of the Lower Town\r\nwas made to a cluster of men, who were deliberating behind a wagon, at\r\nthe rear of a store on Main street.\r\n\r\nThe committee were most unwilling to proceed to extremities. All the\r\nduty they had ever performed seemed as nothing to the task before them;\r\nbut they had to decide, and that quickly. It was finally agreed that if\r\nthe whole body of the miners were of the opinion that he should be\r\nhanged, that the committee left it in their hands to deal with him. Off,\r\nat hot speed, rode the leader of the Nevada men to join his command.\r\n\r\nSlade had found out what was intended, and the news sobered him\r\ninstantly. He went into P. S. Pfouts\xe2\x80\x99 store, where Davis was, and\r\napologized for his conduct, saying that he would take it all back.\r\n\r\nThe head of the column now wheeled into Wallace street and marched up at\r\nquick time. Halting in front of the store, the executive officer of the\r\ncommittee stepped forward and arrested Slade, who was at once informed\r\nof his doom, and inquiry was made as to whether he had any business to\r\nsettle. Several parties spoke to him on the subject; but to all such\r\ninquiries he turned a deaf ear, being entirely absorbed in the\r\nterrifying reflections on his own awful position. He never ceased his\r\nentreaties for life, and to see his dear wife. The unfortunate lady\r\nreferred to, between whom and Slade there existed a warm affection, was\r\nat this time living at their ranch on the Madison. She was possessed of\r\nconsiderable personal attractions; tall, well-formed, of graceful\r\ncarriage, pleasing manners, and was, withal, an accomplished horsewoman.\r\n\r\nA messenger from Slade rode at full speed to inform her of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narrest. In an instant she was in the saddle, and with all the energy\r\nthat love and despair could lend to an ardent temperament and a strong\r\nphysique, she urged her fleet charger over the twelve miles of rough and\r\nrocky ground that intervened between her and the object of her\r\npassionate devotion.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile a party of volunteers had made the necessary preparations for\r\nthe execution, in the valley traversed by the branch. Beneath the site\r\nof Pfouts and Russell\xe2\x80\x99s stone building there was a corral, the gate-\r\nposts of which were strong and high. Across the top was laid a beam, to\r\nwhich the rope was fastened, and a dry-goods box served for the\r\nplatform. To this place Slade was marched, surrounded by a guard,\r\ncomposing the best armed and most numerous force that has ever appeared\r\nin Montana Territory.\r\n\r\nThe doomed man had so exhausted himself by tears, prayers and\r\nlamentations, that he had scarcely strength left to stand under the\r\nfatal beam. He repeatedly exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cMy God! my God! must I die? Oh, my\r\ndear wife!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the return of the fatigue party, they encountered some friends of\r\nSlade, staunch and reliable citizens and members of the committee, but\r\nwho were personally attached to the condemned. On hearing of his\r\nsentence, one of them, a stout-hearted man, pulled out his handkerchief\r\nand walked away, weeping like a child. Slade still begged to see his\r\nwife, most piteously, and it seemed hard to deny his request; but the\r\nbloody consequences that were sure to follow the inevitable attempt at a\r\nrescue, that her presence and entreaties would have certainly incited,\r\nforbade the granting of his request. Several gentlemen were sent for to\r\nsee him, in his last moments, one of whom (Judge Davis) made a short\r\naddress to the people; but in such low tones as to be inaudible, save to\r\na few in his immediate vicinity. One of his friends, after exhausting\r\nhis powers of entreaty, threw off his coat and declared that the\r\nprisoner could not be hanged until he himself was killed. A hundred guns\r\nwere instantly leveled at him; whereupon he turned and fled; but, being\r\nbrought back, he was compelled to resume his coat, and to give a promise\r\nof future peaceable demeanor.\r\n\r\nScarcely a leading man in Virginia could be found, though numbers of the\r\ncitizens joined the ranks of the guard when the arrest was made. All\r\nlamented the stern necessity which dictated the execution.\r\n\r\nEverything being ready, the command was given, \xe2\x80\x9cMen, do your duty,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nthe box being instantly slipped from beneath his feet, he died almost\r\ninstantaneously.\r\n\r\nThe body was cut down and carried to the Virginia Hotel, where, in a\r\ndarkened room, it was scarcely laid out, when the unfortunate and\r\nbereaved companion of the deceased arrived, at headlong speed, to find\r\nthat all was over, and that she was a widow. Her grief and heart-\r\npiercing cries were terrible evidences of the depth of her attachment\r\nfor her lost husband, and a considerable period elapsed before she could\r\nregain the command of her excited feelings.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n095.jpg (48K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThere is something about the desperado-nature that is wholly\r\nunaccountable\xe2\x80\x94at least it looks unaccountable. It is this. The true\r\ndesperado is gifted with splendid courage, and yet he will take the most\r\ninfamous advantage of his enemy; armed and free, he will stand up before\r\na host and fight until he is shot all to pieces, and yet when he is\r\nunder the gallows and helpless he will cry and plead like a child. Words\r\nare cheap, and it is easy to call Slade a coward (all executed men who\r\ndo not \xe2\x80\x9cdie game\xe2\x80\x9d are promptly called cowards by unreflecting people),\r\nand when we read of Slade that he \xe2\x80\x9chad so exhausted himself by tears,\r\nprayers and lamentations, that he had scarcely strength left to stand\r\nunder the fatal beam,\xe2\x80\x9d the disgraceful word suggests itself in a\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94yet in frequently defying and inviting the vengeance of banded\r\nRocky Mountain cut-throats by shooting down their comrades and leaders,\r\nand never offering to hide or fly, Slade showed that he was a man of\r\npeerless bravery. No coward would dare that. Many a notorious coward,\r\nmany a chicken-livered poltroon, coarse, brutal, degraded, has made his\r\ndying speech without a quaver in his voice and been swung into eternity\r\nwith what looked liked the calmest fortitude, and so we are justified in\r\nbelieving, from the low intellect of such a creature, that it was not\r\n_moral_ courage that enabled him to do it. Then, if moral courage is not\r\nthe requisite quality, what could it have been that this stout-hearted\r\nSlade lacked?\xe2\x80\x94this bloody, desperate, kindly-mannered, urbane gentleman,\r\nwho never hesitated to warn his most ruffianly enemies that he would\r\nkill them whenever or wherever he came across them next! I think it is a\r\nconundrum worth investigating.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII.\r\n\r\n\r\nJust beyond the breakfast-station we overtook a Mormon emigrant train of\r\nthirty-three wagons; and tramping wearily along and driving their herd\r\nof loose cows, were dozens of coarse-clad and sad-looking men, women and\r\nchildren, who had walked as they were walking now, day after day for\r\neight lingering weeks, and in that time had compassed the distance our\r\nstage had come in _eight days and three hours_\xe2\x80\x94seven hundred and ninety-\r\neight miles! They were dusty and uncombed, hatless, bonnetless and\r\nragged, and they did look so tired!\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, we bathed in Horse Creek, a (previously) limpid,\r\nsparkling stream\xe2\x80\x94an appreciated luxury, for it was very seldom that our\r\nfurious coach halted long enough for an indulgence of that kind. We\r\nchanged horses ten or twelve times in every twenty-four hours\xe2\x80\x94changed\r\nmules, rather\xe2\x80\x94six mules\xe2\x80\x94and did it nearly every time in _four minutes_.\r\nIt was lively work. As our coach rattled up to each station six\r\nharnessed mules stepped gayly from the stable; and in the twinkling of\r\nan eye, almost, the old team was out, and the new one in and we off and\r\naway again.\r\n\r\nDuring the afternoon we passed Sweetwater Creek, Independence Rock,\r\nDevil\xe2\x80\x99s Gate and the Devil\xe2\x80\x99s Gap. The latter were wild specimens of\r\nrugged scenery, and full of interest\xe2\x80\x94_we were in the heart of the Rocky\r\nMountains, now_. And we also passed by \xe2\x80\x9cAlkali\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cSoda Lake,\xe2\x80\x9d and we\r\nwoke up to the fact that our journey had stretched a long way across the\r\nworld when the driver said that the Mormons often came there from Great\r\nSalt Lake City to haul away saleratus. He said that a few days gone by\r\nthey had shoveled up enough pure saleratus from the ground (it was a\r\n_dry_ lake) to load two wagons, and that when they got these two wagons-\r\nloads of a drug that cost them nothing, to Salt Lake, they could sell it\r\nfor twenty-five cents a pound.\r\n\r\nIn the night we sailed by a most notable curiosity, and one we had been\r\nhearing a good deal about for a day or two, and were suffering to see.\r\nThis was what might be called a natural ice-house. It was August, now,\r\nand sweltering weather in the daytime, yet at one of the stations the\r\nmen could scape the soil on the hill-side under the lee of a range of\r\nboulders, and at a depth of six inches cut out pure blocks of ice\xe2\x80\x94hard,\r\ncompactly frozen, and clear as crystal!\r\n\r\nToward dawn we got under way again, and presently as we sat with raised\r\ncurtains enjoying our early-morning smoke and contemplating the first\r\nsplendor of the rising sun as it swept down the long array of mountain\r\npeaks, flushing and gilding crag after crag and summit after summit, as\r\nif the invisible Creator reviewed his gray veterans and they saluted\r\nwith a smile, we hove in sight of South Pass City. The hotel-keeper, the\r\npostmaster, the blacksmith, the mayor, the constable, the city marshal\r\nand the principal citizen and property holder, all came out and greeted\r\nus cheerily, and we gave him good day. He gave us a little Indian news,\r\nand a little Rocky Mountain news, and we gave him some Plains\r\ninformation in return. He then retired to his lonely grandeur and we\r\nclimbed on up among the bristling peaks and the ragged clouds. South\r\nPass City consisted of four log cabins, one if which was unfinished, and\r\nthe gentleman with all those offices and titles was the chiefest of the\r\nten citizens of the place. Think of hotel-keeper, postmaster,\r\nblacksmith, mayor, constable, city marshal and principal citizen all\r\ncondensed into one person and crammed into one skin. Bemis said he was\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ca perfect Allen\xe2\x80\x99s revolver of dignities.\xe2\x80\x9d And he said that if he were\r\nto die as postmaster, or as blacksmith, or as postmaster and blacksmith\r\nboth, the people might stand it; but if he were to die all over, it\r\nwould be a frightful loss to the community.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n099.jpg (57K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTwo miles beyond South Pass City we saw for the first time that\r\nmysterious marvel which all Western untraveled boys have heard of and\r\nfully believe in, but are sure to be astounded at when they see it with\r\ntheir own eyes, nevertheless\xe2\x80\x94banks of snow in dead summer time. We were\r\nnow far up toward the sky, and knew all the time that we must presently\r\nencounter lofty summits clad in the \xe2\x80\x9ceternal snow\xe2\x80\x9d which was so common\r\nplace a matter of mention in books, and yet when I did see it glittering\r\nin the sun on stately domes in the distance and knew the month was\r\nAugust and that my coat was hanging up because it was too warm to wear\r\nit, I was full as much amazed as if I never had heard of snow in August\r\nbefore. Truly, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing is believing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and many a man lives a long life\r\nthrough, thinking he believes certain universally received and well\r\nestablished things, and yet never suspects that if he were confronted by\r\nthose things once, he would discover that he did not really believe them\r\nbefore, but only thought he believed them.\r\n\r\nIn a little while quite a number of peaks swung into view with long\r\nclaws of glittering snow clasping them; and with here and there, in the\r\nshade, down the mountain side, a little solitary patch of snow looking\r\nno larger than a lady\xe2\x80\x99s pocket-handkerchief but being in reality as\r\nlarge as a \xe2\x80\x9cpublic square.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd now, at last, we were fairly in the renowned SOUTH PASS, and\r\nwhirling gayly along high above the common world. We were perched upon\r\nthe extreme summit of the great range of the Rocky Mountains, toward\r\nwhich we had been climbing, patiently climbing, ceaselessly climbing,\r\nfor days and nights together\xe2\x80\x94and about us was gathered a convention of\r\nNature\xe2\x80\x99s kings that stood ten, twelve, and even thirteen thousand feet\r\nhigh\xe2\x80\x94grand old fellows who would have to stoop to see Mount Washington,\r\nin the twilight. We were in such an airy elevation above the creeping\r\npopulations of the earth, that now and then when the obstructing crags\r\nstood out of the way it seemed that we could look around and abroad and\r\ncontemplate the whole great globe, with its dissolving views of\r\nmountains, seas and continents stretching away through the mystery of\r\nthe summer haze.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n100.jpg (164K)\r\n\r\n\r\nAs a general thing the Pass was more suggestive of a valley than a\r\nsuspension bridge in the clouds\xe2\x80\x94but it strongly suggested the latter at\r\none spot. At that place the upper third of one or two majestic purple\r\ndomes projected above our level on either hand and gave us a sense of a\r\nhidden great deep of mountains and plains and valleys down about their\r\nbases which we fancied we might see if we could step to the edge and\r\nlook over. These Sultans of the fastnesses were turbaned with tumbled\r\nvolumes of cloud, which shredded away from time to time and drifted off\r\nfringed and torn, trailing their continents of shadow after them; and\r\ncatching presently on an intercepting peak, wrapped it about and brooded\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x94then shredded away again and left the purple peak, as they had\r\nleft the purple domes, downy and white with new-laid snow. In passing,\r\nthese monstrous rags of cloud hung low and swept along right over the\r\nspectator\xe2\x80\x99s head, swinging their tatters so nearly in his face that his\r\nimpulse was to shrink when they came closest. In the one place I speak\r\nof, one could look below him upon a world of diminishing crags and\r\ncanyons leading down, down, and away to a vague plain with a thread in\r\nit which was a road, and bunches of feathers in it which were trees,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\npretty picture sleeping in the sunlight\xe2\x80\x94but with a darkness stealing\r\nover it and glooming its features deeper and deeper under the frown of a\r\ncoming storm; and then, while no film or shadow marred the noon\r\nbrightness of his high perch, he could watch the tempest break forth\r\ndown there and see the lightnings leap from crag to crag and the sheeted\r\nrain drive along the canyon-sides, and hear the thunders peal and crash\r\nand roar. We had this spectacle; a familiar one to many, but to us a\r\nnovelty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n101.jpg (164K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe bowled along cheerily, and presently, at the very summit (though it\r\nhad been all summit to us, and all equally level, for half an hour or\r\nmore), we came to a spring which spent its water through two outlets and\r\nsent it in opposite directions. The conductor said that one of those\r\nstreams which we were looking at, was just starting on a journey\r\nwestward to the Gulf of California and the Pacific Ocean, through\r\nhundreds and even thousands of miles of desert solitudes. He said that\r\nthe other was just leaving its home among the snow-peaks on a similar\r\njourney eastward\xe2\x80\x94and we knew that long after we should have forgotten\r\nthe simple rivulet it would still be plodding its patient way down the\r\nmountain sides, and canyon-beds, and between the banks of the\r\nYellowstone; and by and by would join the broad Missouri and flow\r\nthrough unknown plains and deserts and unvisited wildernesses; and add a\r\nlong and troubled pilgrimage among snags and wrecks and sandbars; and\r\nenter the Mississippi, touch the wharves of St. Louis and still drift\r\non, traversing shoals and rocky channels, then endless chains of\r\nbottomless and ample bends, walled with unbroken forests, then\r\nmysterious byways and secret passages among woody islands, then the\r\nchained bends again, bordered with wide levels of shining sugar-cane in\r\nplace of the sombre forests; then by New Orleans and still other chains\r\nof bends\xe2\x80\x94and finally, after two long months of daily and nightly\r\nharassment, excitement, enjoyment, adventure, and awful peril of parched\r\nthroats, pumps and evaporation, pass the Gulf and enter into its rest\r\nupon the bosom of the tropic sea, never to look upon its snow-peaks\r\nagain or regret them.\r\n\r\nI freighted a leaf with a mental message for the friends at home, and\r\ndropped it in the stream. But I put no stamp on it and it was held for\r\npostage somewhere.\r\n\r\nOn the summit we overtook an emigrant train of many wagons, many tired\r\nmen and women, and many a disgusted sheep and cow.\r\n\r\nIn the wofully dusty horseman in charge of the expedition I recognized\r\nJohn \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Of all persons in the world to meet on top of the Rocky\r\nMountains thousands of miles from home, he was the last one I should\r\nhave looked for. We were school-boys together and warm friends for\r\nyears. But a boyish prank of mine had disruptured this friendship and it\r\nhad never been renewed. The act of which I speak was this. I had been\r\naccustomed to visit occasionally an editor whose room was in the third\r\nstory of a building and overlooked the street. One day this editor gave\r\nme a watermelon which I made preparations to devour on the spot, but\r\nchancing to look out of the window, I saw John standing directly under\r\nit and an irresistible desire came upon me to drop the melon on his\r\nhead, which I immediately did. I was the loser, for it spoiled the\r\nmelon, and John never forgave me and we dropped all intercourse and\r\nparted, but now met again under these circumstances.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n102.jpg (41K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe recognized each other simultaneously, and hands were grasped as\r\nwarmly as if no coldness had ever existed between us, and no allusion\r\nwas made to any. All animosities were buried and the simple fact of\r\nmeeting a familiar face in that isolated spot so far from home, was\r\nsufficient to make us forget all things but pleasant ones, and we parted\r\nagain with sincere \xe2\x80\x9cgood-bye\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you\xe2\x80\x9d from both.\r\n\r\nWe had been climbing up the long shoulders of the Rocky Mountains for\r\nmany tedious hours\xe2\x80\x94we started _down_ them, now. And we went spinning\r\naway at a round rate too.\r\n\r\nWe left the snowy Wind River Mountains and Uinta Mountains behind, and\r\nsped away, always through splendid scenery but occasionally through long\r\nranks of white skeletons of mules and oxen\xe2\x80\x94monuments of the huge\r\nemigration of other days\xe2\x80\x94and here and there were up-ended boards or\r\nsmall piles of stones which the driver said marked the resting-place of\r\nmore precious remains.\r\n\r\nIt was the loneliest land for a grave! A land given over to the cayote\r\nand the raven\xe2\x80\x94which is but another name for desolation and utter\r\nsolitude. On damp, murky nights, these scattered skeletons gave forth a\r\nsoft, hideous glow, like very faint spots of moonlight starring the\r\nvague desert. It was because of the phosphorus in the bones. But no\r\nscientific explanation could keep a body from shivering when he drifted\r\nby one of those ghostly lights and knew that a skull held it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n103.jpg (35K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt midnight it began to rain, and I never saw anything like it\xe2\x80\x94indeed, I\r\ndid not even see this, for it was too dark. We fastened down the\r\ncurtains and even caulked them with clothing, but the rain streamed in\r\nin twenty places, nothwithstanding. There was no escape. If one moved\r\nhis feet out of a stream, he brought his body under one; and if he moved\r\nhis body he caught one somewhere else. If he struggled out of the\r\ndrenched blankets and sat up, he was bound to get one down the back of\r\nhis neck. Meantime the stage was wandering about a plain with gaping\r\ngullies in it, for the driver could not see an inch before his face nor\r\nkeep the road, and the storm pelted so pitilessly that there was no\r\nkeeping the horses still. With the first abatement the conductor turned\r\nout with lanterns to look for the road, and the first dash he made was\r\ninto a chasm about fourteen feet deep, his lantern following like a\r\nmeteor. As soon as he touched bottom he sang out frantically:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n104.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t come here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo which the driver, who was looking over the precipice where he had\r\ndisappeared, replied, with an injured air: \xe2\x80\x9cThink I\xe2\x80\x99m a dam fool?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n105.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe conductor was more than an hour finding the road\xe2\x80\x94a matter which\r\nshowed us how far we had wandered and what chances we had been taking.\r\nHe traced our wheel-tracks to the imminent verge of danger, in two\r\nplaces. I have always been glad that we were not killed that night. I do\r\nnot know any particular reason, but I have always been glad. In the\r\nmorning, the tenth day out, we crossed Green River, a fine, large,\r\nlimpid stream\xe2\x80\x94stuck in it with the water just up to the top of our mail-\r\nbed, and waited till extra teams were put on to haul us up the steep\r\nbank. But it was nice cool water, and besides it could not find any\r\nfresh place on us to wet.\r\n\r\nAt the Green River station we had breakfast\xe2\x80\x94hot biscuits, fresh antelope\r\nsteaks, and coffee\xe2\x80\x94the only decent meal we tasted between the United\r\nStates and Great Salt Lake City, and the only one we were ever really\r\nthankful for.\r\n\r\nThink of the monotonous execrableness of the thirty that went before it,\r\nto leave this one simple breakfast looming up in my memory like a shot-\r\ntower after all these years have gone by!\r\n\r\nAt five P.M. we reached Fort Bridger, one hundred and seventeen miles\r\nfrom the South Pass, and one thousand and twenty-five miles from St.\r\nJoseph. Fifty-two miles further on, near the head of Echo Canyon, we met\r\nsixty United States soldiers from Camp Floyd. The day before, they had\r\nfired upon three hundred or four hundred Indians, whom they supposed\r\ngathered together for no good purpose. In the fight that had ensued,\r\nfour Indians were captured, and the main body chased four miles, but\r\nnobody killed. This looked like business. We had a notion to get out and\r\njoin the sixty soldiers, but upon reflecting that there were four\r\nhundred of the Indians, we concluded to go on and join the Indians.\r\n\r\nEcho Canyon is twenty miles long. It was like a long, smooth, narrow\r\nstreet, with a gradual descending grade, and shut in by enormous\r\nperpendicular walls of coarse conglomerate, four hundred feet high in\r\nmany places, and turreted like mediaeval castles. This was the most\r\nfaultless piece of road in the mountains, and the driver said he would\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clet his team out.\xe2\x80\x9d He did, and if the Pacific express trains whiz\r\nthrough there now any faster than we did then in the stage-coach, I envy\r\nthe passengers the exhilaration of it. We fairly seemed to pick up our\r\nwheels and fly\xe2\x80\x94and the mail matter was lifted up free from everything\r\nand held in solution! I am not given to exaggeration, and when I say a\r\nthing I mean it.\r\n\r\nHowever, time presses. At four in the afternoon we arrived on the summit\r\nof Big Mountain, fifteen miles from Salt Lake City, when all the world\r\nwas glorified with the setting sun, and the most stupendous panorama of\r\nmountain peaks yet encountered burst on our sight. We looked out upon\r\nthis sublime spectacle from under the arch of a brilliant rainbow! Even\r\nthe overland stage-driver stopped his horses and gazed!\r\n\r\nHalf an hour or an hour later, we changed horses, and took supper with a\r\nMormon \xe2\x80\x9cDestroying Angel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDestroying Angels,\xe2\x80\x9d as I understand it, are Latter-Day Saints who are\r\nset apart by the Church to conduct permanent disappearances of obnoxious\r\ncitizens. I had heard a deal about these Mormon Destroying Angels and\r\nthe dark and bloody deeds they had done, and when I entered this one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse I had my shudder all ready. But alas for all our romances, he was\r\nnothing but a loud, profane, offensive, old blackguard! He was murderous\r\nenough, possibly, to fill the bill of a Destroyer, but would you have\r\n_any_ kind of an Angel devoid of dignity? Could you abide an Angel in an\r\nunclean shirt and no suspenders? Could you respect an Angel with a\r\nhorse-laugh and a swagger like a buccaneer?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n106.jpg (47K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were other blackguards present\xe2\x80\x94comrades of this one. And there was\r\none person that looked like a gentleman\xe2\x80\x94Heber C. Kimball\xe2\x80\x99s son, tall and\r\nwell made, and thirty years old, perhaps. A lot of slatternly women\r\nflitted hither and thither in a hurry, with coffee-pots, plates of\r\nbread, and other appurtenances to supper, and these were said to be the\r\nwives of the Angel\xe2\x80\x94or some of them, at least. And of course they were;\r\nfor if they had been hired \xe2\x80\x9chelp\xe2\x80\x9d they would not have let an angel from\r\nabove storm and swear at them as he did, let alone one from the place\r\nthis one hailed from.\r\n\r\nThis was our first experience of the western \xe2\x80\x9cpeculiar institution,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nit was not very prepossessing. We did not tarry long to observe it, but\r\nhurried on to the home of the Latter-Day Saints, the stronghold of the\r\nprophets, the capital of the only absolute monarch in America\xe2\x80\x94Great Salt\r\nLake City. As the night closed in we took sanctuary in the Salt Lake\r\nHouse and unpacked our baggage.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe had a fine supper, of the freshest meats and fowls and vegetables\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngreat variety and as great abundance. We walked about the streets some,\r\nafterward, and glanced in at shops and stores; and there was fascination\r\nin surreptitiously staring at every creature we took to be a Mormon.\r\nThis was fairy-land to us, to all intents and purposes\xe2\x80\x94a land of\r\nenchantment, and goblins, and awful mystery. We felt a curiosity to ask\r\nevery child how many mothers it had, and if it could tell them apart;\r\nand we experienced a thrill every time a dwelling-house door opened and\r\nshut as we passed, disclosing a glimpse of human heads and backs and\r\nshoulders\xe2\x80\x94for we so longed to have a good satisfying look at a Mormon\r\nfamily in all its comprehensive ampleness, disposed in the customary\r\nconcentric rings of its home circle.\r\n\r\nBy and by the Acting Governor of the Territory introduced us to other\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentiles,\xe2\x80\x9d and we spent a sociable hour with them. \xe2\x80\x9cGentiles\xe2\x80\x9d are\r\npeople who are not Mormons. Our fellow-passenger, Bemis, took care of\r\nhimself, during this part of the evening, and did not make an\r\noverpowering success of it, either, for he came into our room in the\r\nhotel about eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, full of cheerfulness, and talking loosely,\r\ndisjointedly and indiscriminately, and every now and then tugging out a\r\nragged word by the roots that had more hiccups than syllables in it.\r\nThis, together with his hanging his coat on the floor on one side of a\r\nchair, and his vest on the floor on the other side, and piling his pants\r\non the floor just in front of the same chair, and then comtemplating the\r\ngeneral result with superstitious awe, and finally pronouncing it \xe2\x80\x9ctoo\r\nmany for _him_\xe2\x80\x9d and going to bed with his boots on, led us to fear that\r\nsomething he had eaten had not agreed with him.\r\n\r\nBut we knew afterward that it was something he had been drinking. It was\r\nthe exclusively Mormon refresher, \xe2\x80\x9cvalley tan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValley tan (or, at least, one form of valley tan) is a kind of whisky,\r\nor first cousin to it; is of Mormon invention and manufactured only in\r\nUtah. Tradition says it is made of (imported) fire and brimstone.
