If I\r\nremember rightly no public drinking saloons were allowed in the kingdom\r\nby Brigham Young, and no private drinking permitted among the faithful,\r\nexcept they confined themselves to \xe2\x80\x9cvalley tan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n109.jpg (55K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNext day we strolled about everywhere through the broad, straight, level\r\nstreets, and enjoyed the pleasant strangeness of a city of fifteen\r\nthousand inhabitants with no loafers perceptible in it; and no visible\r\ndrunkards or noisy people; a limpid stream rippling and dancing through\r\nevery street in place of a filthy gutter; block after block of trim\r\ndwellings, built of \xe2\x80\x9cframe\xe2\x80\x9d and sunburned brick\xe2\x80\x94a great thriving orchard\r\nand garden behind every one of them, apparently\xe2\x80\x94branches from the street\r\nstream winding and sparkling among the garden beds and fruit trees\xe2\x80\x94and a\r\ngrand general air of neatness, repair, thrift and comfort, around and\r\nabout and over the whole. And everywhere were workshops, factories, and\r\nall manner of industries; and intent faces and busy hands were to be\r\nseen wherever one looked; and in one\xe2\x80\x99s ears was the ceaseless clink of\r\nhammers, the buzz of trade and the contented hum of drums and fly-\r\nwheels.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n110a.jpg (25K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe armorial crest of my own State consisted of two dissolute bears\r\nholding up the head of a dead and gone cask between them and making the\r\npertinent remark, \xe2\x80\x9cUNITED, WE STAND\xe2\x80\x94(hic!)\xe2\x80\x94DIVIDED, WE FALL.\xe2\x80\x9d It was\r\nalways too figurative for the author of this book. But the Mormon crest\r\nwas easy. And it was simple, unostentatious, and fitted like a glove. It\r\nwas a representation of a GOLDEN BEEHIVE, with the bees all at work!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n110b.jpg (23K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe city lies in the edge of a level plain as broad as the State of\r\nConnecticut, and crouches close down to the ground under a curving wall\r\nof mighty mountains whose heads are hidden in the clouds, and whose\r\nshoulders bear relics of the snows of winter all the summer long.\r\n\r\nSeen from one of these dizzy heights, twelve or fifteen miles off, Great\r\nSalt Lake City is toned down and diminished till it is suggestive of a\r\nchild\xe2\x80\x99s toy-village reposing under the majestic protection of the\r\nChinese wall.\r\n\r\nOn some of those mountains, to the southwest, it had been raining every\r\nday for two weeks, but not a drop had fallen in the city. And on hot\r\ndays in late spring and early autumn the citizens could quit fanning and\r\ngrowling and go out and cool off by looking at the luxury of a glorious\r\nsnow-storm going on in the mountains. They could enjoy it at a distance,\r\nat those seasons, every day, though no snow would fall in their streets,\r\nor anywhere near them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n111.jpg (83K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSalt Lake City was healthy\xe2\x80\x94an extremely healthy city. They declared\r\nthere was only one physician in the place and he was arrested every week\r\nregularly and held to answer under the vagrant act for having \xe2\x80\x9cno\r\nvisible means of support.\xe2\x80\x9d They always give you a good substantial\r\narticle of truth in Salt Lake, and good measure and good weight, too.\r\n[Very often, if you wished to weigh one of their airiest little\r\ncommonplace statements you would want the hay scales.]\r\n\r\nWe desired to visit the famous inland sea, the American \xe2\x80\x9cDead Sea,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\ngreat Salt Lake\xe2\x80\x94seventeen miles, horseback, from the city\xe2\x80\x94for we had\r\ndreamed about it, and thought about it, and talked about it, and yearned\r\nto see it, all the first part of our trip; but now when it was only\r\narm\xe2\x80\x99s length away it had suddenly lost nearly every bit of its interest.\r\nAnd so we put it off, in a sort of general way, till next day\xe2\x80\x94and that\r\nwas the last we ever thought of it. We dined with some hospitable\r\nGentiles; and visited the foundation of the prodigious temple; and\r\ntalked long with that shrewd Connecticut Yankee, Heber C. Kimball (since\r\ndeceased), a saint of high degree and a mighty man of commerce.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n112.jpg (21K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe saw the \xe2\x80\x9cTithing-House,\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cLion House,\xe2\x80\x9d and I do not know or\r\nremember how many more church and government buildings of various kinds\r\nand curious names. We flitted hither and thither and enjoyed every hour,\r\nand picked up a great deal of useful information and entertaining\r\nnonsense, and went to bed at night satisfied.\r\n\r\nThe second day, we made the acquaintance of Mr. Street (since deceased)\r\nand put on white shirts and went and paid a state visit to the king. He\r\nseemed a quiet, kindly, easy-mannered, dignified, self-possessed old\r\ngentleman of fifty-five or sixty, and had a gentle craft in his eye that\r\nprobably belonged there. He was very simply dressed and was just taking\r\noff a straw hat as we entered. He talked about Utah, and the Indians,\r\nand Nevada, and general American matters and questions, with our\r\nsecretary and certain government officials who came with us. But he\r\nnever paid any attention to me, notwithstanding I made several attempts\r\nto \xe2\x80\x9cdraw him out\xe2\x80\x9d on federal politics and his high handed attitude\r\ntoward Congress. I thought some of the things I said were rather fine.\r\nBut he merely looked around at me, at distant intervals, something as I\r\nhave seen a benignant old cat look around to see which kitten was\r\nmeddling with her tail.\r\n\r\nBy and by I subsided into an indignant silence, and so sat until the\r\nend, hot and flushed, and execrating him in my heart for an ignorant\r\nsavage. But he was calm. His conversation with those gentlemen flowed on\r\nas sweetly and peacefully and musically as any summer brook. When the\r\naudience was ended and we were retiring from the presence, he put his\r\nhand on my head, beamed down on me in an admiring way and said to my\r\nbrother:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh\xe2\x80\x94your child, I presume? Boy, or girl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n113.jpg (49K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Street was very busy with his telegraphic matters\xe2\x80\x94and considering\r\nthat he had eight or nine hundred miles of rugged, snowy, uninhabited\r\nmountains, and waterless, treeless, melancholy deserts to traverse with\r\nhis wire, it was natural and needful that he should be as busy as\r\npossible. He could not go comfortably along and cut his poles by the\r\nroad-side, either, but they had to be hauled by ox teams across those\r\nexhausting deserts\xe2\x80\x94and it was two days\xe2\x80\x99 journey from water to water, in\r\none or two of them. Mr. Street\xe2\x80\x99s contract was a vast work, every way one\r\nlooked at it; and yet to comprehend what the vague words \xe2\x80\x9ceight hundred\r\nmiles of rugged mountains and dismal deserts\xe2\x80\x9d mean, one must go over the\r\nground in person\xe2\x80\x94pen and ink descriptions cannot convey the dreary\r\nreality to the reader. And after all, Mr. S.\xe2\x80\x99s mightiest difficulty\r\nturned out to be one which he had never taken into the account at all.\r\nUnto Mormons he had sub-let the hardest and heaviest half of his great\r\nundertaking, and all of a sudden they concluded that they were going to\r\nmake little or nothing, and so they tranquilly threw their poles\r\noverboard in mountain or desert, just as it happened when they took the\r\nnotion, and drove home and went about their customary business! They\r\nwere under written contract to Mr. Street, but they did not care\r\nanything for that. They said they would \xe2\x80\x9cadmire\xe2\x80\x9d to see a \xe2\x80\x9cGentile\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nforce a Mormon to fulfil a losing contract in Utah! And they made\r\nthemselves very merry over the matter. Street said\xe2\x80\x94for it was he that\r\ntold us these things:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was in dismay. I was under heavy bonds to complete my contract in a\r\ngiven time, and this disaster looked very much like ruin. It was an\r\nastounding thing; it was such a wholly unlooked-for difficulty, that I\r\nwas entirely nonplussed. I am a business man\xe2\x80\x94have always been a business\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94do not know anything _but_ business\xe2\x80\x94and so you can imagine how like\r\nbeing struck by lightning it was to find myself in a country _where\r\nwritten contracts were worthless!_\xe2\x80\x94that main security, that sheet-\r\nanchor, that absolute necessity, of business. My confidence left me.\r\nThere was no use in making new contracts\xe2\x80\x94that was plain. I talked with\r\nfirst one prominent citizen and then another. They all sympathized with\r\nme, first rate, but they did not know how to help me. But at last a\r\nGentile said, \xe2\x80\x98Go to Brigham Young!\xe2\x80\x94these small fry cannot do you any\r\ngood.\xe2\x80\x99 I did not think much of the idea, for if the _law_ could not help\r\nme, what could an individual do who had not even anything to do with\r\neither making the laws or executing them? He might be a very good\r\npatriarch of a church and preacher in its tabernacle, but something\r\nsterner than religion and moral suasion was needed to handle a hundred\r\nrefractory, half-civilized sub-contractors. But what was a man to do? I\r\nthought if Mr. Young could not do anything else, he might probably be\r\nable to give me some advice and a valuable hint or two, and so I went\r\nstraight to him and laid the whole case before him. He said very little,\r\nbut he showed strong interest all the way through. He examined all the\r\npapers in detail, and whenever there seemed anything like a hitch,\r\neither in the papers or my statement, he would go back and take up the\r\nthread and follow it patiently out to an intelligent and satisfactory\r\nresult. Then he made a list of the contractors\xe2\x80\x99 names. Finally he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Street, this is all perfectly plain. These contracts are strictly\r\nand legally drawn, and are duly signed and certified. These men\r\nmanifestly entered into them with their eyes open. I see no fault or\r\nflaw anywhere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Mr. Young turned to a man waiting at the other end of the room and\r\nsaid: \xe2\x80\x98Take this list of names to So-and-so, and tell him to have these\r\nmen here at such-and-such an hour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were there, to the minute. So was I. Mr. Young asked them a number\r\nof questions, and their answers made my statement good. Then he said to\r\nthem:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You signed these contracts and assumed these obligations of your own\r\nfree will and accord?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Then carry them out to the letter, if it makes paupers of you! Go!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n116.jpg (101K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they _did_ go, too! They are strung across the deserts now, working\r\nlike bees. And I never hear a word out of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a batch of governors, and judges, and other officials here,\r\nshipped from Washington, and they maintain the semblance of a republican\r\nform of government\xe2\x80\x94but the petrified truth is that Utah is an absolute\r\nmonarchy and Brigham Young is king!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Street was a fine man, and I believe his story. I knew him well\r\nduring several years afterward in San Francisco.\r\n\r\nOur stay in Salt Lake City amounted to only two days, and therefore we\r\nhad no time to make the customary inquisition into the workings of\r\npolygamy and get up the usual statistics and deductions preparatory to\r\ncalling the attention of the nation at large once more to the matter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n117.jpg (104K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI had the will to do it. With the gushing self-sufficiency of youth I\r\nwas feverish to plunge in headlong and achieve a great reform here\xe2\x80\x94until\r\nI saw the Mormon women. Then I was touched. My heart was wiser than my\r\nhead. It warmed toward these poor, ungainly and pathetically \xe2\x80\x9chomely\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncreatures, and as I turned to hide the generous moisture in my eyes, I\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94the man that marries one of them has done an act of Christian\r\ncharity which entitles him to the kindly applause of mankind, not their\r\nharsh censure\xe2\x80\x94and the man that marries sixty of them has done a deed of\r\nopen-handed generosity so sublime that the nations should stand\r\nuncovered in his presence and worship in silence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[For a brief sketch of Mormon history, and the noted Mountain Meadow\r\nmassacre, see Appendices A and B. ]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n118.jpg (82K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is a luscious country for thrilling evening stories about\r\nassassinations of intractable Gentiles. I cannot easily conceive of\r\nanything more cosy than the night in Salt Lake which we spent in a\r\nGentile den, smoking pipes and listening to tales of how Burton galloped\r\nin among the pleading and defenceless \xe2\x80\x9cMorisites\xe2\x80\x9d and shot them down,\r\nmen and women, like so many dogs. And how Bill Hickman, a Destroying\r\nAngel, shot Drown and Arnold dead for bringing suit against him for a\r\ndebt. And how Porter Rockwell did this and that dreadful thing. And how\r\nheedless people often come to Utah and make remarks about Brigham, or\r\npolygamy, or some other sacred matter, and the very next morning at\r\ndaylight such parties are sure to be found lying up some back alley,\r\ncontentedly waiting for the hearse.\r\n\r\nAnd the next most interesting thing is to sit and listen to these\r\nGentiles talk about polygamy; and how some portly old frog of an elder,\r\nor a bishop, marries a girl\xe2\x80\x94likes her, marries her sister\xe2\x80\x94likes her,\r\nmarries another sister\xe2\x80\x94likes her, takes another\xe2\x80\x94likes her, marries her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x94likes her, marries her father, grandfather, great grandfather,\r\nand then comes back hungry and asks for more. And how the pert young\r\nthing of eleven will chance to be the favorite wife and her own\r\nvenerable grandmother have to rank away down toward D 4 in their mutual\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s esteem, and have to sleep in the kitchen, as like as not. And\r\nhow this dreadful sort of thing, this hiving together in one foul nest\r\nof mother and daughters, and the making a young daughter superior to her\r\nown mother in rank and authority, are things which Mormon women submit\r\nto because their religion teaches them that the more wives a man has on\r\nearth, and the more children he rears, the higher the place they will\r\nall have in the world to come\xe2\x80\x94and the warmer, maybe, though they do not\r\nseem to say anything about that.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n120.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAccording to these Gentile friends of ours, Brigham Young\xe2\x80\x99s harem\r\ncontains twenty or thirty wives. They said that some of them had grown\r\nold and gone out of active service, but were comfortably housed and\r\ncared for in the henery\xe2\x80\x94or the Lion House, as it is strangely named.\r\nAlong with each wife were her children\xe2\x80\x94fifty altogether. The house was\r\nperfectly quiet and orderly, when the children were still. They all took\r\ntheir meals in one room, and a happy and home-like sight it was\r\npronounced to be. None of our party got an opportunity to take dinner\r\nwith Mr. Young, but a Gentile by the name of Johnson professed to have\r\nenjoyed a sociable breakfast in the Lion House. He gave a preposterous\r\naccount of the \xe2\x80\x9ccalling of the roll,\xe2\x80\x9d and other preliminaries, and the\r\ncarnage that ensued when the buckwheat cakes came in. But he embellished\r\nrather too much. He said that Mr. Young told him several smart sayings\r\nof certain of his \xe2\x80\x9ctwo-year-olds,\xe2\x80\x9d observing with some pride that for\r\nmany years he had been the heaviest contributor in that line to one of\r\nthe Eastern magazines; and then he wanted to show Mr. Johnson one of the\r\npets that had said the last good thing, but he could not find the child.\r\n\r\nHe searched the faces of the children in detail, but could not decide\r\nwhich one it was. Finally he gave it up with a sigh and said:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n121.jpg (86K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I would know the little cub again but I don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Johnson\r\nsaid further, that Mr. Young observed that life was a sad, sad\r\nthing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbecause the joy of every new marriage a man contracted was so apt\r\nto be blighted by the inopportune funeral of a less recent bride.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nMr. Johnson said that while he and Mr. Young were pleasantly conversing\r\nin private, one of the Mrs. Youngs came in and demanded a breast-pin,\r\nremarking that she had found out that he had been giving a breast-pin to\r\nNo. 6, and _she_, for one, did not propose to let this partiality go on\r\nwithout making a satisfactory amount of trouble about it. Mr. Young\r\nreminded her that there was a stranger present. Mrs. Young said that if\r\nthe state of things inside the house was not agreeable to the stranger,\r\nhe could find room outside. Mr. Young promised the breast-pin, and she\r\nwent away. But in a minute or two another Mrs. Young came in and\r\ndemanded a breast-pin. Mr. Young began a remonstrance, but Mrs. Young\r\ncut him short. She said No. 6 had got one, and No. 11 was promised one,\r\nand it was \xe2\x80\x9cno use for him to try to impose on her\xe2\x80\x94she hoped she knew\r\nher rights.\xe2\x80\x9d He gave his promise, and she went. And presently three Mrs.\r\nYoungs entered in a body and opened on their husband a tempest of tears,\r\nabuse, and entreaty. They had heard all about No. 6, No. 11, and No. 14.\r\nThree more breast-pins were promised. They were hardly gone when nine\r\nmore Mrs. Youngs filed into the presence, and a new tempest burst forth\r\nand raged round about the prophet and his guest. Nine breast-pins were\r\npromised, and the weird sisters filed out again. And in came eleven\r\nmore, weeping and wailing and gnashing their teeth. Eleven promised\r\nbreast-pins purchased peace once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a specimen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Young. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see how it is. You see what a\r\nlife I lead. A man _can\xe2\x80\x99t_ be wise all the time. In a heedless moment I\r\ngave my darling No. 6\xe2\x80\x94excuse my calling her thus, as her other name has\r\nescaped me for the moment\xe2\x80\x94a breast-pin. It was only worth twenty-five\r\ndollars\xe2\x80\x94that is, _apparently_ that was its _whole_ cost\xe2\x80\x94but its ultimate\r\ncost was inevitably bound to be a good deal more. You yourself have seen\r\nit climb up to six hundred and fifty dollars\xe2\x80\x94and alas, even that is not\r\nthe end! For I have wives all over this Territory of Utah. I have dozens\r\nof wives whose _numbers_, even, I do not know without looking in the\r\nfamily Bible. They are scattered far and wide among the mountains and\r\nvalleys of my realm. And mark you, every solitary one of them will hear\r\nof this wretched breast pin, and every last one of them will have one or\r\ndie. No. 6\xe2\x80\x99s breast pin will cost me twenty-five hundred dollars before\r\nI see the end of it. And these creatures will compare these pins\r\ntogether, and if one is a shade finer than the rest, they will all be\r\nthrown on my hands, and I will have to order a new lot to keep peace in\r\nthe family. Sir, you probably did not know it, but all the time you were\r\npresent with my children your every movement was watched by vigilant\r\nservitors of mine. If you had offered to give a child a dime, or a stick\r\nof candy, or any trifle of the kind, you would have been snatched out of\r\nthe house instantly, provided it could be done before your gift left\r\nyour hand. Otherwise it would be absolutely necessary for you to make an\r\nexactly similar gift to all my children\xe2\x80\x94and knowing by experience the\r\nimportance of the thing, I would have stood by and seen to it myself\r\nthat you did it, and did it thoroughly. Once a gentleman gave one of my\r\nchildren a tin whistle\xe2\x80\x94a veritable invention of Satan, sir, and one\r\nwhich I have an unspeakable horror of, and so would you if you had\r\neighty or ninety children in your house. But the deed was done\xe2\x80\x94the man\r\nescaped. I knew what the result was going to be, and I thirsted for\r\nvengeance. I ordered out a flock of Destroying Angels, and they hunted\r\nthe man far into the fastnesses of the Nevada mountains. But they never\r\ncaught him. I am not cruel, sir\xe2\x80\x94I am not vindictive except when sorely\r\noutraged\xe2\x80\x94but if I had caught him, sir, so help me Joseph Smith, I would\r\nhave locked him into the nursery till the brats whistled him to death.\r\nBy the slaughtered body of St. Parley Pratt (whom God assoil!) there was\r\nnever anything on this earth like it! _I_ knew who gave the whistle to\r\nthe child, but I could, not make those jealous mothers believe me. They\r\nbelieved _I_ did it, and the result was just what any man of reflection\r\ncould have foreseen: I had to order a hundred and ten whistles\xe2\x80\x94I think\r\nwe had a hundred and ten children in the house then, but some of them\r\nare off at college now\xe2\x80\x94I had to order a hundred and ten of those\r\nshrieking things, and I wish I may never speak another word if we didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave to talk on our fingers entirely, from that time forth until the\r\nchildren got tired of the whistles. And if ever another man gives a\r\nwhistle to a child of mine and I get my hands on him, I will hang him\r\nhigher than Haman! That is the word with the bark on it! Shade of Nephi!\r\n_You_ don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about married life. I am rich, and everybody\r\nknows it. I am benevolent, and everybody takes advantage of it. I have a\r\nstrong fatherly instinct and all the foundlings are foisted on me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery time a woman wants to do well by her darling, she puzzles her\r\nbrain to cipher out some scheme for getting it into my hands. Why, sir,\r\na woman came here once with a child of a curious lifeless sort of\r\ncomplexion (and so had the woman), and swore that the child was mine and\r\nshe my wife\xe2\x80\x94that I had married her at such-and-such a time in such-and-\r\nsuch a place, but she had forgotten her number, and of course I could\r\nnot remember her name. Well, sir, she called my attention to the fact\r\nthat the child looked like me, and really it did seem to resemble me\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ncommon thing in the Territory\xe2\x80\x94and, to cut the story short, I put it in\r\nmy nursery, and she left.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n124.jpg (68K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by the ghost of Orson Hyde, when they came to wash the paint off\r\nthat child it was an Injun! Bless my soul, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about\r\nmarried life. It is a perfect dog\xe2\x80\x99s life, sir\xe2\x80\x94a perfect dog\xe2\x80\x99s life. You\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t economize. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t possible. I have tried keeping one set of\r\nbridal attire for all occasions. But it is of no use. First you\xe2\x80\x99ll marry\r\na combination of calico and consumption that\xe2\x80\x99s as thin as a rail, and\r\nnext you\xe2\x80\x99ll get a creature that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing more than the dropsy in\r\ndisguise, and then you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to eke out that bridal dress with an old\r\nballoon. That is the way it goes. And think of the wash-bill\xe2\x80\x94(excuse\r\nthese tears)\xe2\x80\x94nine hundred and eighty-four pieces a week! No, sir, there\r\nis no such a thing as economy in a family like mine. Why, just the one\r\nitem of cradles\xe2\x80\x94think of it! And vermifuge! Soothing syrup! Teething\r\nrings! And \xe2\x80\x98papa\xe2\x80\x99s watches\xe2\x80\x99 for the babies to play with! And things to\r\nscratch the furniture with! And lucifer matches for them to eat, and\r\npieces of glass to cut themselves with! The item of glass alone would\r\nsupport _your_ family, I venture to say, sir. Let me scrimp and squeeze\r\nall I can, I still can\xe2\x80\x99t get ahead as fast as I feel I ought to, with my\r\nopportunities. Bless you, sir, at a time when I had seventy-two wives in\r\nthis house, I groaned under the pressure of keeping thousands of dollars\r\ntied up in seventy-two bedsteads when the money ought to have been out\r\nat interest; and I just sold out the whole stock, sir, at a sacrifice,\r\nand built a bedstead seven feet long and ninety-six feet wide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n126.jpg (99K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was a failure, sir. I could _not_ sleep. It appeared to me that\r\nthe whole seventy-two women snored at once. The roar was deafening. And\r\nthen the danger of it! That was what I was looking at. They would all\r\ndraw in their breath at once, and you could actually see the walls of\r\nthe house suck in\xe2\x80\x94and then they would all exhale their breath at once,\r\nand you could see the walls swell out, and strain, and hear the rafters\r\ncrack, and the shingles grind together. My friend, take an old man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nadvice, and _don\xe2\x80\x99t_ encumber yourself with a large family\xe2\x80\x94mind, I tell\r\nyou, don\xe2\x80\x99t do it. In a small family, and in a small family only, you\r\nwill find that comfort and that peace of mind which are the best at last\r\nof the blessings this world is able to afford us, and for the lack of\r\nwhich no accumulation of wealth, and no acquisition of fame, power, and\r\ngreatness can ever compensate us. Take my word for it, ten or eleven\r\nwives is all you need\xe2\x80\x94never go over it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome instinct or other made me set this Johnson down as being\r\nunreliable. And yet he was a very entertaining person, and I doubt if\r\nsome of the information he gave us could have been acquired from any\r\nother source. He was a pleasant contrast to those reticent Mormons.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nAll men have heard of the Mormon Bible, but few except the \xe2\x80\x9celect\xe2\x80\x9d have\r\nseen it, or, at least, taken the trouble to read it. I brought away a\r\ncopy from Salt Lake. The book is a curiosity to me, it is such a\r\npretentious affair, and yet so \xe2\x80\x9cslow,\xe2\x80\x9d so sleepy; such an insipid mess\r\nof inspiration. It is chloroform in print. If Joseph Smith composed this\r\nbook, the act was a miracle\xe2\x80\x94keeping awake while he did it was, at any\r\nrate. If he, according to tradition, merely translated it from certain\r\nancient and mysteriously-engraved plates of copper, which he declares he\r\nfound under a stone, in an out-of-the-way locality, the work of\r\ntranslating was equally a miracle, for the same reason.\r\n\r\nThe book seems to be merely a prosy detail of imaginary history, with\r\nthe Old Testament for a model; followed by a tedious plagiarism of the\r\nNew Testament. The author labored to give his words and phrases the\r\nquaint, old-fashioned sound and structure of our King James\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntranslation of the Scriptures; and the result is a mongrel\xe2\x80\x94half modern\r\nglibness, and half ancient simplicity and gravity. The latter is awkward\r\nand constrained; the former natural, but grotesque by the contrast.\r\nWhenever he found his speech growing too modern\xe2\x80\x94which was about every\r\nsentence or two\xe2\x80\x94he ladled in a few such Scriptural phrases as \xe2\x80\x9cexceeding\r\nsore,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cand it came to pass,\xe2\x80\x9d etc., and made things satisfactory again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it came to pass\xe2\x80\x9d was his pet. If he had left that out, his Bible\r\nwould have been only a pamphlet.\r\n\r\nThe title-page reads as follows:\r\n\r\nTHE BOOK OF MORMON: AN ACCOUNT WRITTEN BY THE HAND OF MORMON, UPON\r\nPLATES TAKEN FROM THE PLATES OF NEPHI.\r\n\r\nWherefore it is an abridgment of the record of the people of Nephi, and\r\nalso of the Lamanites; written to the Lamanites, who are a remnant of\r\nthe House of Israel; and also to Jew and Gentile; written by way of\r\ncommandment, and also by the spirit of prophecy and of revelation.\r\nWritten and sealed up, and hid up unto the Lord, that they might not be\r\ndestroyed; to come forth by the gift and power of God unto the\r\ninterpretation thereof; sealed by the hand of Moroni, and hid up unto\r\nthe Lord, to come forth in due time by the way of Gentile; the\r\ninterpretation thereof by the gift of God. An abridgment taken from the\r\nBook of Ether also; which is a record of the people of Jared; who were\r\nscattered at the time the Lord confounded the language of the people\r\nwhen they were building a tower to get to Heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHid up\xe2\x80\x9d is good. And so is \xe2\x80\x9cwherefore\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94though why \xe2\x80\x9cwherefore\xe2\x80\x9d? Any\r\nother word would have answered as well\xe2\x80\x94though\xe2\x80\x94in truth it would not have\r\nsounded so Scriptural.\r\n\r\nNext comes:\r\n\r\nTHE TESTIMONY OF THREE WITNESSES. Be it known unto all nations,\r\nkindreds, tongues, and people unto whom this work shall come, that we,\r\nthrough the grace of God the Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ, have\r\nseen the plates which contain this record, which is a record of the\r\npeople of Nephi, and also of the Lamanites, their brethren, and also of\r\nthe people of Jared, who came from the tower of which hath been spoken;\r\nand we also know that they have been translated by the gift and power of\r\nGod, for His voice hath declared it unto us; wherefore we know of a\r\nsurety that the work is true. And we also testify that we have seen the\r\nengravings which are upon the plates; and they have been shown unto us\r\nby the power of God, and not of man. And we declare with words of\r\nsoberness, that an angel of God came down from heaven, and he brought\r\nand laid before our eyes, that we beheld and saw the plates, and the\r\nengravings thereon; and we know that it is by the grace of God the\r\nFather, and our Lord Jesus Christ, that we beheld and bear record that\r\nthese things are true; and it is marvellous in our eyes; nevertheless\r\nthe voice of the Lord commanded us that we should bear record of it;\r\nwherefore, to be obedient unto the commandments of God, we bear\r\ntestimony of these things. And we know that if we are faithful in\r\nChrist, we shall rid our garments of the blood of all men, and be found\r\nspotless before the judgment-seat of Christ, and shall dwell with Him\r\neternally in the heavens. And the honor be to the Father, and to the\r\nSon, and to the Holy Ghost, which is one God. Amen. OLIVER COWDERY,\r\nDAVID WHITMER, MARTIN HARRIS.\r\n\r\nSome people have to have a world of evidence before they can come\r\nanywhere in the neighborhood of believing anything; but for me, when a\r\nman tells me that he has \xe2\x80\x9cseen the engravings which are upon the\r\nplates,\xe2\x80\x9d and not only that, but an angel was there at the time, and saw\r\nhim see them, and probably took his receipt for it, I am very far on the\r\nroad to conviction, no matter whether I ever heard of that man before or\r\nnot, and even if I do not know the name of the angel, or his nationality\r\neither.\r\n\r\nNext is this:\r\n\r\nAND ALSO THE TESTIMONY OF EIGHT WITNESSES. Be it known unto all nations,\r\nkindreds, tongues, and people unto whom this work shall come, that\r\nJoseph Smith, Jr., the translator of this work, has shown unto us the\r\nplates of which hath been spoken, which have the appearance of gold; and\r\nas many of the leaves as the said Smith has translated, we did handle\r\nwith our hands; and we also saw the engravings thereon, all of which has\r\nthe appearance of ancient work, and of curious workmanship. And this we\r\nbear record with words of soberness, that the said Smith has shown unto\r\nus, for we have seen and hefted, and know of a surety that the said\r\nSmith has got the plates of which we have spoken. And we give our names\r\nunto the world, to witness unto the world that which we have seen; and\r\nwe lie not, God bearing witness of it. CHRISTIAN WHITMER, JACOB WHITMER,\r\nPETER WHITMER, JR., JOHN WHITMER, HIRAM PAGE, JOSEPH SMITH, SR., HYRUM\r\nSMITH, SAMUEL H. SMITH.\r\n\r\nAnd when I am far on the road to conviction, and eight men, be they\r\ngrammatical or otherwise, come forward and tell me that they have seen\r\nthe plates too; and not only seen those plates but \xe2\x80\x9chefted\xe2\x80\x9d them, I am\r\nconvinced. I could not feel more satisfied and at rest if the entire\r\nWhitmer family had testified.\r\n\r\nThe Mormon Bible consists of fifteen \xe2\x80\x9cbooks\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94being the books of Jacob,\r\nEnos, Jarom, Omni, Mosiah, Zeniff, Alma, Helaman, Ether, Moroni, two\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbooks\xe2\x80\x9d of Mormon, and three of Nephi.\r\n\r\nIn the first book of Nephi is a plagiarism of the Old Testament, which\r\ngives an account of the exodus from Jerusalem of the \xe2\x80\x9cchildren of Lehi\xe2\x80\x9d;\r\nand it goes on to tell of their wanderings in the wilderness, during\r\neight years, and their supernatural protection by one of their number, a\r\nparty by the name of Nephi. They finally reached the land of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBountiful,\xe2\x80\x9d and camped by the sea. After they had remained there \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nthe space of many days\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which is more Scriptural than definite\xe2\x80\x94Nephi was\r\ncommanded from on high to build a ship wherein to \xe2\x80\x9ccarry the people\r\nacross the waters.\xe2\x80\x9d He travestied Noah\xe2\x80\x99s ark\xe2\x80\x94but he obeyed orders in the\r\nmatter of the plan. He finished the ship _in a single day_, while his\r\nbrethren stood by and made fun of it\xe2\x80\x94and of him, too\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csaying, our\r\nbrother is a fool, for he thinketh that he can build a ship.\xe2\x80\x9d They did\r\nnot wait for the timbers to dry, but the whole tribe or nation sailed\r\nthe next day. Then a bit of genuine nature cropped out, and is revealed\r\nby outspoken Nephi with Scriptural frankness\xe2\x80\x94they all got on a spree!\r\nThey, \xe2\x80\x9cand also their wives, began to make themselves merry, insomuch\r\nthat they began to dance, and to sing, and to speak with much rudeness;\r\nyea, they were lifted up unto exceeding rudeness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNephi tried to stop these scandalous proceedings; but they tied him neck\r\nand heels, and went on with their lark. But observe how Nephi the\r\nprophet circumvented them by the aid of the invisible powers:\r\n\r\nAnd it came to pass that after they had bound me, insomuch that I could\r\nnot move, the compass, which had been prepared of the Lord, did cease to\r\nwork; wherefore, they knew not whither they should steer the ship,\r\ninsomuch that there arose a great storm, yea, a great and terrible\r\ntempest, and we were driven back upon the waters for the space of three\r\ndays; and they began to be frightened exceedingly, lest they should be\r\ndrowned in the sea; nevertheless they did not loose me. And on the\r\nfourth day, which we had been driven back, the tempest began to be\r\nexceeding sore. And it came to pass that we were about to be swallowed\r\nup in the depths of the sea.\r\n\r\nThen they untied him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n131.jpg (77K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd it came to pass after they had loosed me, behold, I took the\r\ncompass, and it did work whither I desired it. And it came to pass that\r\nI prayed unto the Lord; and after I had prayed, the winds did cease, and\r\nthe storm did cease, and there was a great calm.\r\n\r\nEquipped with their compass, these ancients appear to have had the\r\nadvantage of Noah.\r\n\r\nTheir voyage was toward a \xe2\x80\x9cpromised land\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the only name they give it.\r\nThey reached it in safety.\r\n\r\nPolygamy is a recent feature in the Mormon religion, and was added by\r\nBrigham Young after Joseph Smith\xe2\x80\x99s death. Before that, it was regarded\r\nas an \xe2\x80\x9cabomination.\xe2\x80\x9d This verse from the Mormon Bible occurs in Chapter\r\nII. of the book of Jacob:\r\n\r\nFor behold, thus saith the Lord, this people begin to wax in iniquity;\r\nthey understand not the Scriptures; for they seek to excuse themselves\r\nin committing whoredoms, because of the things which were written\r\nconcerning David, and Solomon his son. Behold, David and Solomon truly\r\nhad many wives and concubines, which thing was abominable before me,\r\nsaith the Lord; wherefore, thus saith the Lord, I have led this people\r\nforth out of the land of Jerusalem, by the power of mine arm, that I\r\nmight raise up unto me a righteous branch from the fruit of the loins of\r\nJoseph. Wherefore, I the Lord God, will no suffer that this people shall\r\ndo like unto them of old.\r\n\r\nHowever, the project failed\xe2\x80\x94or at least the modern Mormon end of it\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nBrigham \xe2\x80\x9csuffers\xe2\x80\x9d it. This verse is from the same chapter:\r\n\r\nBehold, the Lamanites your brethren, whom ye hate, because of their\r\nfilthiness and the cursings which hath come upon their skins, are more\r\nrighteous than you; for they have not forgotten the commandment of the\r\nLord, which was given unto our fathers, that they should have, save it\r\nwere one wife; and concubines they should have none.\r\n\r\nThe following verse (from Chapter IX. of the Book of Nephi) appears to\r\ncontain information not familiar to everybody:\r\n\r\nAnd now it came to pass that when Jesus had ascended into heaven, the\r\nmultitude did disperse, and every man did take his wife and his\r\nchildren, and did return to his own home.\r\n\r\nAnd it came to pass that on the morrow, when the multitude was gathered\r\ntogether, behold, Nephi and his brother whom he had raised from the\r\ndead, whose name was Timothy, and also his son, whose name was Jonas,\r\nand also Mathoni, and Mathonihah, his brother, and Kumen, and Kumenenhi,\r\nand Jeremiah, and Shemnon, and Jonas, and Zedekiah, and Isaiah; now\r\nthese were the names of the disciples whom Jesus had chosen.\r\n\r\nIn order that the reader may observe how much more grandeur and\r\npicturesqueness (as seen by these Mormon twelve) accompanied on of the\r\ntenderest episodes in the life of our Saviour than other eyes seem to\r\nhave been aware of, I quote the following from the same \xe2\x80\x9cbook\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Nephi:\r\n\r\nAnd it came to pass that Jesus spake unto them, and bade them arise. And\r\nthey arose from the earth, and He said unto them, Blessed are ye because\r\nof your faith. And now behold, My joy is full. And when He had said\r\nthese words, He wept, and the multitude bear record of it, and He took\r\ntheir little children, one by one, and blessed them, and prayed unto the\r\nFather for them. And when He had done this He wept again, and He spake\r\nunto the multitude, and saith unto them, Behold your little ones. And as\r\nthey looked to behold, they cast their eyes toward heaven, and they saw\r\nthe heavens open, and they saw angels descending out of heaven as it\r\nwere, in the midst of fire; and they came down and encircled those\r\nlittle ones about, and they were encircled about with fire; and the\r\nangels did minister unto them, and the multitude did see and hear and\r\nbear record; and they know that their record is true, for they all of\r\nthem did see and hear, every man for himself; and they were in number\r\nabout two thousand and five hundred souls; and they did consist of men,\r\nwomen, and children.\r\n\r\nAnd what else would they be likely to consist of?\r\n\r\nThe Book of Ether is an incomprehensible medley of \xe2\x80\x9chistory,\xe2\x80\x9d much of it\r\nrelating to battles and sieges among peoples whom the reader has\r\npossibly never heard of; and who inhabited a country which is not set\r\ndown in the geography. There was a King with the remarkable name of\r\nCoriantumr, and he warred with Shared, and Lib, and Shiz, and others, in\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cplains of Heshlon\xe2\x80\x9d; and the \xe2\x80\x9cvalley of Gilgal\xe2\x80\x9d; and the \xe2\x80\x9cwilderness\r\nof Akish\xe2\x80\x9d; and the \xe2\x80\x9cland of Moran\xe2\x80\x9d; and the \xe2\x80\x9cplains of Agosh\xe2\x80\x9d; and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOgath,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRamah,\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cland of Corihor,\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9chill Comnor,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nby \xe2\x80\x9cthe waters of Ripliancum,\xe2\x80\x9d etc., etc., etc. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it came to pass,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nafter a deal of fighting, that Coriantumr, upon making calculation of\r\nhis losses, found that \xe2\x80\x9cthere had been slain two millions of mighty men,\r\nand also their wives and their children\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94say 5,000,000 or 6,000,000 in\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand he began to sorrow in his heart.\xe2\x80\x9d Unquestionably it was time.\r\nSo he wrote to Shiz, asking a cessation of hostilities, and offering to\r\ngive up his kingdom to save his people. Shiz declined, except upon\r\ncondition that Coriantumr would come and let him cut his head off\r\nfirst\xe2\x80\x94a thing which Coriantumr would not do. Then there was more\r\nfighting for a season; then _four years_ were devoted to gathering the\r\nforces for a final struggle\xe2\x80\x94after which ensued a battle, which, I take\r\nit, is the most remarkable set forth in history,\xe2\x80\x94except, perhaps, that\r\nof the Kilkenny cats, which it resembles in some respects. This is the\r\naccount of the gathering and the battle:\r\n\r\n7. And it came to pass that they did gather together all the people,\r\nupon all the face of the land, who had not been slain, save it was\r\nEther. And it came to pass that Ether did behold all the doings of the\r\npeople; and he beheld that the people who were for Coriantumr, were\r\ngathered together to the army of Coriantumr; and the people who were for\r\nShiz, were gathered together to the army of Shiz; wherefore they were\r\nfor the space of four years gathering together the people, that they\r\nmight get all who were upon the face of the land, and that they might\r\nreceive all the strength which it was possible that they could receive.\r\nAnd it came to pass that when they were all gathered together, every one\r\nto the army which he would, with their wives and their children; both\r\nmen, women, and children being armed with weapons of war, having\r\nshields, and breast-plates, and head-plates, and being clothed after the\r\nmanner of war, they did march forth one against another, to battle; and\r\nthey fought all that day, and conquered not. And it came to pass that\r\nwhen it was night they were weary, and retired to their camps; and after\r\nthey had retired to their camps, they took up a howling and a\r\nlamentation for the loss of the slain of their people; and so great were\r\ntheir cries, their howlings and lamentations, that it did rend the air\r\nexceedingly. And it came to pass that on the morrow they did go again to\r\nbattle, and great and terrible was that day; nevertheless they conquered\r\nnot, and when the night came again, they did rend the air with their\r\ncries, and their howlings, and their mournings, for the loss of the\r\nslain of their people.\r\n\r\n8. And it came to pass that Coriantumr wrote again an epistle unto Shiz,\r\ndesiring that he would not come again to battle, but that he would take\r\nthe kingdom, and spare the lives of the people. But behold, the Spirit\r\nof the Lord had ceased striving with them, and Satan had full power over\r\nthe hearts of the people, for they were given up unto the hardness of\r\ntheir hearts, and the blindness of their minds that they might be\r\ndestroyed; wherefore they went again to battle. And it came to pass that\r\nthey fought all that day, and when the night came they slept upon their\r\nswords; and on the morrow they fought even until the night came; and\r\nwhen the night came they were drunken with anger, even as a man who is\r\ndrunken with wine; and they slept again upon their swords; and on the\r\nmorrow they fought again; and when the night came they had all fallen by\r\nthe sword save it were fifty and two of the people of Coriantumr, and\r\nsixty and nine of the people of Shiz. And it came to pass that they\r\nslept upon their swords that night, and on the morrow they fought again,\r\nand they contended in their mights with their swords, and with their\r\nshields, all that day; and when the night came there were thirty and two\r\nof the people of Shiz, and twenty and seven of the people of Coriantumr.\r\n\r\n9. And it came to pass that they ate and slept, and prepared for death\r\non the morrow. And they were large and mighty men, as to the strength of\r\nmen. And it came to pass that they fought for the space of three hours,\r\nand they fainted with the loss of blood. And it came to pass that when\r\nthe men of Coriantumr had received sufficient strength, that they could\r\nwalk, they were about to flee for their lives, but behold, Shiz arose,\r\nand also his men, and he swore in his wrath that he would slay\r\nCoriantumr, or he would perish by the sword: wherefore he did pursue\r\nthem, and on the morrow he did overtake them; and they fought again with\r\nthe sword. And it came to pass that when they had all fallen by the\r\nsword, save it were Coriantumr and Shiz, behold Shiz had fainted with\r\nloss of blood. And it came to pass that when Coriantumr had leaned upon\r\nhis sword, that he rested a little, he smote off the head of Shiz. And\r\nit came to pass that after he had smote off the head of Shiz, that Shiz\r\nraised upon his hands and fell; and after that he had struggled for\r\nbreath, he died. And it came to pass that Coriantumr fell to the earth,\r\nand became as if he had no life. And the Lord spake unto Ether, and said\r\nunto him, go forth. And he went forth, and beheld that the words of the\r\nLord had all been fulfilled; and he finished his record; and the\r\nhundredth part I have not written.\r\n\r\nIt seems a pity he did not finish, for after all his dreary former\r\nchapters of commonplace, he stopped just as he was in danger of becoming\r\ninteresting.\r\n\r\nThe Mormon Bible is rather stupid and tiresome to read, but there is\r\nnothing vicious in its teachings. Its code of morals is\r\nunobjectionable\xe2\x80\x94it is \xe2\x80\x9csmouched\xe2\x80\x9d [Milton] from the New Testament and no\r\ncredit given.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the end of our two days\xe2\x80\x99 sojourn, we left Great Salt Lake City hearty\r\nand well fed and happy\xe2\x80\x94physically superb but not so very much wiser, as\r\nregards the \xe2\x80\x9cMormon question,\xe2\x80\x9d than we were when we arrived, perhaps. We\r\nhad a deal more \xe2\x80\x9cinformation\xe2\x80\x9d than we had before, of course, but we did\r\nnot know what portion of it was reliable and what was not\xe2\x80\x94for it all\r\ncame from acquaintances of a day\xe2\x80\x94strangers, strictly speaking. We were\r\ntold, for instance, that the dreadful \xe2\x80\x9cMountain Meadows Massacre\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\nthe work of the Indians entirely, and that the Gentiles had meanly tried\r\nto fasten it upon the Mormons; we were told, likewise, that the Indians\r\nwere to blame, partly, and partly the Mormons; and we were told,\r\nlikewise, and just as positively, that the Mormons were almost if not\r\nwholly and completely responsible for that most treacherous and pitiless\r\nbutchery. We got the story in all these different shapes, but it was not\r\ntill several years afterward that Mrs. Waite\xe2\x80\x99s book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mormon\r\nProphet,\xe2\x80\x9d came out with Judge Cradlebaugh\xe2\x80\x99s trial of the accused parties\r\nin it and revealed the truth that the latter version was the correct one\r\nand that the Mormons _were_ the assassins. All our \xe2\x80\x9cinformation\xe2\x80\x9d had\r\nthree sides to it, and so I gave up the idea that I could settle the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMormon question\xe2\x80\x9d in two days. Still I have seen newspaper\r\ncorrespondents do it in one.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n137.jpg (62K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI left Great Salt Lake a good deal confused as to what state of things\r\nexisted there\xe2\x80\x94and sometimes even questioning in my own mind whether a\r\nstate of things existed there at all or not. But presently I remembered\r\nwith a lightening sense of relief that we had learned two or three\r\ntrivial things there which we could be certain of; and so the two days\r\nwere not wholly lost. For instance, we had learned that we were at last\r\nin a pioneer land, in absolute and tangible reality.\r\n\r\nThe high prices charged for trifles were eloquent of high freights and\r\nbewildering distances of freightage. In the east, in those days, the\r\nsmallest moneyed denomination was a penny and it represented the\r\nsmallest purchasable quantity of any commodity. West of Cincinnati the\r\nsmallest coin in use was the silver five-cent piece and no smaller\r\nquantity of an article could be bought than \xe2\x80\x9cfive cents\xe2\x80\x99 worth.\xe2\x80\x9d In\r\nOverland City the lowest coin appeared to be the ten-cent piece; but in\r\nSalt Lake there did not seem to be any money in circulation smaller than\r\na quarter, or any smaller quantity purchasable of any commodity than\r\ntwenty-five cents\xe2\x80\x99 worth. We had always been used to half dimes and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfive cents\xe2\x80\x99 worth\xe2\x80\x9d as the minimum of financial negotiations; but in\r\nSalt Lake if one wanted a cigar, it was a quarter; if he wanted a chalk\r\npipe, it was a quarter; if he wanted a peach, or a candle, or a\r\nnewspaper, or a shave, or a little Gentile whiskey to rub on his corns\r\nto arrest indigestion and keep him from having the toothache, twenty-\r\nfive cents was the price, every time. When we looked at the shot-bag of\r\nsilver, now and then, we seemed to be wasting our substance in riotous\r\nliving, but if we referred to the expense account we could see that we\r\nhad not been doing anything of the kind.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n138.jpg (21K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut people easily get reconciled to big money and big prices, and fond\r\nand vain of both\xe2\x80\x94it is a descent to little coins and cheap prices that\r\nis hardest to bear and slowest to take hold upon one\xe2\x80\x99s toleration. After\r\na month\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance with the twenty-five cent minimum, the average\r\nhuman being is ready to blush every time he thinks of his despicable\r\nfive-cent days. How sunburnt with blushes I used to get in gaudy Nevada,\r\nevery time I thought of my first financial experience in Salt Lake. It\r\nwas on this wise (which is a favorite expression of great authors, and a\r\nvery neat one, too, but I never hear anybody _say_ on this wise when\r\nthey are talking). A young half-breed with a complexion like a yellow-\r\njacket asked me if I would have my boots blacked. It was at the Salt\r\nLake House the morning after we arrived. I said yes, and he blacked\r\nthem. Then I handed him a silver five-cent piece, with the benevolent\r\nair of a person who is conferring wealth and blessedness upon poverty\r\nand suffering. The yellow-jacket took it with what I judged to be\r\nsuppressed emotion, and laid it reverently down in the middle of his\r\nbroad hand. Then he began to contemplate it, much as a philosopher\r\ncontemplates a gnat\xe2\x80\x99s ear in the ample field of his microscope. Several\r\nmountaineers, teamsters, stage-drivers, etc., drew near and dropped into\r\nthe tableau and fell to surveying the money with that attractive\r\nindifference to formality which is noticeable in the hardy pioneer.\r\nPresently the yellow-jacket handed the half dime back to me and told me\r\nI ought to keep my money in my pocket-book instead of in my soul, and\r\nthen I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get it cramped and shriveled up so!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n139.jpg (61K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat a roar of vulgar laughter there was! I destroyed the mongrel\r\nreptile on the spot, but I smiled and smiled all the time I was\r\ndetaching his scalp, for the remark he made _was_ good for an \xe2\x80\x9cInjun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYes, we had learned in Salt Lake to be charged great prices without\r\nletting the inward shudder appear on the surface\xe2\x80\x94for even already we had\r\noverheard and noted the tenor of conversations among drivers,\r\nconductors, and hostlers, and finally among citizens of Salt Lake, until\r\nwe were well aware that these superior beings despised \xe2\x80\x9cemigrants.\xe2\x80\x9d We\r\npermitted no tell-tale shudders and winces in our countenances, for we\r\nwanted to seem pioneers, or Mormons, half-breeds, teamsters, stage-\r\ndrivers, Mountain Meadow assassins\xe2\x80\x94anything in the world that the plains\r\nand Utah respected and admired\xe2\x80\x94but we were wretchedly ashamed of being\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cemigrants,\xe2\x80\x9d and sorry enough that we had white shirts and could not\r\nswear in the presence of ladies without looking the other way.\r\n\r\nAnd many a time in Nevada, afterwards, we had occasion to remember with\r\nhumiliation that we were \xe2\x80\x9cemigrants,\xe2\x80\x9d and consequently a low and\r\ninferior sort of creatures. Perhaps the reader has visited Utah, Nevada,\r\nor California, even in these latter days, and while communing with\r\nhimself upon the sorrowful banishment of these countries from what he\r\nconsiders \xe2\x80\x9cthe world,\xe2\x80\x9d has had his wings clipped by finding that _he_ is\r\nthe one to be pitied, and that there are entire populations around him\r\nready and willing to do it for him\xe2\x80\x94yea, who are complacently doing it\r\nfor him already, wherever he steps his foot.\r\n\r\nPoor thing, they are making fun of his hat; and the cut of his New York\r\ncoat; and his conscientiousness about his grammar; and his feeble\r\nprofanity; and his consumingly ludicrous ignorance of ores, shafts,\r\ntunnels, and other things which he never saw before, and never felt\r\nenough interest in to read about. And all the time that he is thinking\r\nwhat a sad fate it is to be exiled to that far country, that lonely\r\nland, the citizens around him are looking down on him with a blighting\r\ncompassion because he is an \xe2\x80\x9cemigrant\xe2\x80\x9d instead of that proudest and\r\nblessedest creature that exists on all the earth, a \xe2\x80\x9cFORTY-NINER.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n140.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe accustomed coach life began again, now, and by midnight it almost\r\nseemed as if we never had been out of our snuggery among the mail sacks\r\nat all. We had made one alteration, however. We had provided enough\r\nbread, boiled ham and hard boiled eggs to last double the six hundred\r\nmiles of staging we had still to do.\r\n\r\nAnd it was comfort in those succeeding days to sit up and contemplate\r\nthe majestic panorama of mountains and valleys spread out below us and\r\neat ham and hard boiled eggs while our spiritual natures revelled\r\nalternately in rainbows, thunderstorms, and peerless sunsets. Nothing\r\nhelps scenery like ham and eggs. Ham and eggs, and after these a pipe\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nold, rank, delicious pipe\xe2\x80\x94ham and eggs and scenery, a \xe2\x80\x9cdown grade,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nflying coach, a fragrant pipe and a contented heart\xe2\x80\x94these make\r\nhappiness. It is what all the ages have struggled for.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n141.jpg (29K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt eight in the morning we reached the remnant and ruin of what had been\r\nthe important military station of \xe2\x80\x9cCamp Floyd,\xe2\x80\x9d some forty-five or fifty\r\nmiles from Salt Lake City. At four P.M. we had doubled our distance and\r\nwere ninety or a hundred miles from Salt Lake. And now we entered upon\r\none of that species of deserts whose concentrated hideousness shames the\r\ndiffused and diluted horrors of Sahara\xe2\x80\x94an \xe2\x80\x9c_alkali_\xe2\x80\x9d desert. For sixty-\r\neight miles there was but one break in it. I do not remember that this\r\nwas really a break; indeed it seems to me that it was nothing but a\r\nwatering depot _in the midst_ of the stretch of sixty-eight miles. If my\r\nmemory serves me, there was no well or spring at this place, but the\r\nwater was hauled there by mule and ox teams from the further side of the\r\ndesert. There was a stage station there. It was forty-five miles from\r\nthe beginning of the desert, and twenty-three from the end of it.\r\n\r\nWe plowed and dragged and groped along, the whole live-long night, and\r\nat the end of this uncomfortable twelve hours we finished the forty-five\r\nmile part of the desert and got to the stage station where the imported\r\nwater was. The sun was just rising. It was easy enough to cross a desert\r\nin the night while we were asleep; and it was pleasant to reflect, in\r\nthe morning, that we in actual person _had_ encountered an absolute\r\ndesert and could always speak knowingly of deserts in presence of the\r\nignorant thenceforward. And it was pleasant also to reflect that this\r\nwas not an obscure, back country desert, but a very celebrated one, the\r\nmetropolis itself, as you may say. All this was very well and very\r\ncomfortable and satisfactory\xe2\x80\x94but now we were to cross a desert in\r\n_daylight_. This was fine\xe2\x80\x94novel\xe2\x80\x94romantic\xe2\x80\x94dramatically\r\nadventurous\xe2\x80\x94_this_, indeed, was worth living for, worth traveling for!\r\nWe would write home all about it.\r\n\r\nThis enthusiasm, this stern thirst for adventure, wilted under the\r\nsultry August sun and did not last above one hour. One poor little\r\nhour\xe2\x80\x94and then we were ashamed that we had \xe2\x80\x9cgushed\xe2\x80\x9d so. The poetry was\r\nall in the anticipation\xe2\x80\x94there is none in the reality. Imagine a vast,\r\nwaveless ocean stricken dead and turned to ashes; imagine this solemn\r\nwaste tufted with ash-dusted sage-bushes; imagine the lifeless silence\r\nand solitude that belong to such a place; imagine a coach, creeping like\r\na bug through the midst of this shoreless level, and sending up tumbled\r\nvolumes of dust as if it were a bug that went by steam; imagine this\r\naching monotony of toiling and plowing kept up hour after hour, and the\r\nshore still as far away as ever, apparently; imagine team, driver, coach\r\nand passengers so deeply coated with ashes that they are all one\r\ncolorless color; imagine ash-drifts roosting above moustaches and\r\neyebrows like snow accumulations on boughs and bushes. This is the\r\nreality of it.\r\n\r\nThe sun beats down with dead, blistering, relentless malignity; the\r\nperspiration is welling from every pore in man and beast, but scarcely a\r\nsign of it finds its way to the surface\xe2\x80\x94it is absorbed before it gets\r\nthere; there is not the faintest breath of air stirring; there is not a\r\nmerciful shred of cloud in all the brilliant firmament; there is not a\r\nliving creature visible in _any_ direction whither one searches the\r\nblank level that stretches its monotonous miles on every hand; there is\r\nnot a sound\xe2\x80\x94not a sigh\xe2\x80\x94not a whisper\xe2\x80\x94not a buzz, or a whir of wings, or\r\ndistant pipe of bird\xe2\x80\x94not even a sob from the lost souls that doubtless\r\npeople that dead air. And so the occasional sneezing of the resting\r\nmules, and the champing of the bits, grate harshly on the grim\r\nstillness, not dissipating the spell but accenting it and making one\r\nfeel more lonesome and forsaken than before.\r\n\r\nThe mules, under violent swearing, coaxing and whip-cracking, would make\r\nat stated intervals a \xe2\x80\x9cspurt,\xe2\x80\x9d and drag the coach a hundred or may be\r\ntwo hundred yards, stirring up a billowy cloud of dust that rolled back,\r\nenveloping the vehicle to the wheel-tops or higher, and making it seem\r\nafloat in a fog. Then a rest followed, with the usual sneezing and bit-\r\nchamping. Then another \xe2\x80\x9cspurt\xe2\x80\x9d of a hundred yards and another rest at\r\nthe end of it. All day long we kept this up, without water for the mules\r\nand without ever changing the team. At least we kept it up ten hours,\r\nwhich, I take it, is a day, and a pretty honest one, in an alkali\r\ndesert. It was from four in the morning till two in the afternoon. And\r\nit was so hot! and so close! and our water canteens went dry in the\r\nmiddle of the day and we got so thirsty! It was so stupid and tiresome\r\nand dull! and the tedious hours did lag and drag and limp along with\r\nsuch a cruel deliberation! It was so trying to give one\xe2\x80\x99s watch a good\r\nlong undisturbed spell and then take it out and find that it had been\r\nfooling away the time and not trying to get ahead any! The alkali dust\r\ncut through our lips, it persecuted our eyes, it ate through the\r\ndelicate membranes and made our noses bleed and _kept_ them bleeding\xe2\x80\x94and\r\ntruly and seriously the romance all faded far away and disappeared, and\r\nleft the desert trip nothing but a harsh reality\xe2\x80\x94a thirsty, sweltering,\r\nlonging, hateful reality!\r\n\r\nTwo miles and a quarter an hour for ten hours\xe2\x80\x94that was what we\r\naccomplished. It was hard to bring the comprehension away down to such a\r\nsnail-pace as that, when we had been used to making eight and ten miles\r\nan hour. When we reached the station on the farther verge of the desert,\r\nwe were glad, for the first time, that the dictionary was along, because\r\nwe never could have found language to tell how glad we were, in any sort\r\nof dictionary but an unabridged one with pictures in it. But there could\r\nnot have been found in a whole library of dictionaries language\r\nsufficient to tell how tired those mules were after their twenty-three\r\nmile pull. To try to give the reader an idea of how _thirsty_ they were,\r\nwould be to \xe2\x80\x9cgild refined gold or paint the lily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomehow, now that it is there, the quotation does not seem to fit\xe2\x80\x94but no\r\nmatter, let it stay, anyhow. I think it is a graceful and attractive\r\nthing, and therefore have tried time and time again to work it in where\r\nit _would_ fit, but could not succeed. These efforts have kept my mind\r\ndistracted and ill at ease, and made my narrative seem broken and\r\ndisjointed, in places. Under these circumstances it seems to me best to\r\nleave it in, as above, since this will afford at least a temporary\r\nrespite from the wear and tear of trying to \xe2\x80\x9clead up\xe2\x80\x9d to this really apt\r\nand beautiful quotation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n145.jpg (32K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the morning of the sixteenth day out from St. Joseph we arrived at\r\nthe entrance of Rocky Canyon, two hundred and fifty miles from Salt\r\nLake. It was along in this wild country somewhere, and far from any\r\nhabitation of white men, except the stage stations, that we came across\r\nthe wretchedest type of mankind I have ever seen, up to this writing. I\r\nrefer to the Goshoot Indians. From what we could see and all we could\r\nlearn, they are very considerably inferior to even the despised Digger\r\nIndians of California; inferior to all races of savages on our\r\ncontinent; inferior to even the Terra del Fuegans; inferior to the\r\nHottentots, and actually inferior in some respects to the Kytches of\r\nAfrica. Indeed, I have been obliged to look the bulky volumes of Wood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncivilized Races of Men\xe2\x80\x9d clear through in order to find a savage tribe\r\ndegraded enough to take rank with the Goshoots. I find but one people\r\nfairly open to that shameful verdict. It is the Bosjesmans (Bushmen) of\r\nSouth Africa. Such of the Goshoots as we saw, along the road and hanging\r\nabout the stations, were small, lean, \xe2\x80\x9cscrawny\xe2\x80\x9d creatures; in complexion\r\na dull black like the ordinary American negro; their faces and hands\r\nbearing dirt which they had been hoarding and accumulating for months,\r\nyears, and even generations, according to the age of the proprietor; a\r\nsilent, sneaking, treacherous looking race; taking note of everything,\r\ncovertly, like all the other \xe2\x80\x9cNoble Red Men\xe2\x80\x9d that we (do not) read\r\nabout, and betraying no sign in their countenances; indolent,\r\neverlastingly patient and tireless, like all other Indians; prideless\r\nbeggars\xe2\x80\x94for if the beggar instinct were left out of an Indian he would\r\nnot \xe2\x80\x9cgo,\xe2\x80\x9d any more than a clock without a pendulum; hungry, always\r\nhungry, and yet never refusing anything that a hog would eat, though\r\noften eating what a hog would decline; hunters, but having no higher\r\nambition than to kill and eat jack-ass rabbits, crickets and\r\ngrasshoppers, and embezzle carrion from the buzzards and cayotes;\r\nsavages who, when asked if they have the common Indian belief in a Great\r\nSpirit show a something which almost amounts to emotion, thinking\r\nwhiskey is referred to; a thin, scattering race of almost naked black\r\nchildren, these Goshoots are, who produce nothing at all, and have no\r\nvillages, and no gatherings together into strictly defined tribal\r\ncommunities\xe2\x80\x94a people whose only shelter is a rag cast on a bush to keep\r\noff a portion of the snow, and yet who inhabit one of the most rocky,\r\nwintry, repulsive wastes that our country or any other can exhibit.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n147.jpg (86K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Bushmen and our Goshoots are manifestly descended from the self-same\r\ngorilla, or kangaroo, or Norway rat, whichever animal-Adam the\r\nDarwinians trace them to.\r\n\r\nOne would as soon expect the rabbits to fight as the Goshoots, and yet\r\nthey used to live off the offal and refuse of the stations a few months\r\nand then come some dark night when no mischief was expected, and burn\r\ndown the buildings and kill the men from ambush as they rushed out. And\r\nonce, in the night, they attacked the stage-coach when a District Judge,\r\nof Nevada Territory, was the only passenger, and with their first volley\r\nof arrows (and a bullet or two) they riddled the stage curtains, wounded\r\na horse or two and mortally wounded the driver. The latter was full of\r\npluck, and so was his passenger. At the driver\xe2\x80\x99s call Judge Mott swung\r\nhimself out, clambered to the box and seized the reins of the team, and\r\naway they plunged, through the racing mob of skeletons and under a\r\nhurtling storm of missiles. The stricken driver had sunk down on the\r\nboot as soon as he was wounded, but had held on to the reins and said he\r\nwould manage to keep hold of them until relieved.\r\n\r\nAnd after they were taken from his relaxing grasp, he lay with his head\r\nbetween Judge Mott\xe2\x80\x99s feet, and tranquilly gave directions about the\r\nroad; he said he believed he could live till the miscreants were outrun\r\nand left behind, and that if he managed that, the main difficulty would\r\nbe at an end, and then if the Judge drove so and so (giving directions\r\nabout bad places in the road, and general course) he would reach the\r\nnext station without trouble. The Judge distanced the enemy and at last\r\nrattled up to the station and knew that the night\xe2\x80\x99s perils were done;\r\nbut there was no comrade-in-arms for him to rejoice with, for the\r\nsoldierly driver was dead.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n148.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nLet us forget that we have been saying harsh things about the Overland\r\ndrivers, now. The disgust which the Goshoots gave me, a disciple of\r\nCooper and a worshipper of the Red Man\xe2\x80\x94even of the scholarly savages in\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cLast of the Mohicans\xe2\x80\x9d who are fittingly associated with\r\nbackwoodsmen who divide each sentence into two equal parts: one part\r\ncritically grammatical, refined and choice of language, and the other\r\npart just such an attempt to talk like a hunter or a mountaineer, as a\r\nBroadway clerk might make after eating an edition of Emerson Bennett\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nworks and studying frontier life at the Bowery Theatre a couple of\r\nweeks\xe2\x80\x94I say that the nausea which the Goshoots gave me, an Indian\r\nworshipper, set me to examining authorities, to see if perchance I had\r\nbeen over-estimating the Red Man while viewing him through the mellow\r\nmoonshine of romance. The revelations that came were disenchanting. It\r\nwas curious to see how quickly the paint and tinsel fell away from him\r\nand left him treacherous, filthy and repulsive\xe2\x80\x94and how quickly the\r\nevidences accumulated that wherever one finds an Indian tribe he has\r\nonly found Goshoots more or less modified by circumstances and\r\nsurroundings\xe2\x80\x94but Goshoots, after all. They deserve pity, poor creatures;\r\nand they can have mine\xe2\x80\x94at this distance. Nearer by, they never get\r\nanybody\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nThere is an impression abroad that the Baltimore and Washington Railroad\r\nCompany and many of its employees are Goshoots; but it is an error.\r\nThere is only a plausible resemblance, which, while it is apt enough to\r\nmislead the ignorant, cannot deceive parties who have contemplated both\r\ntribes. But seriously, it was not only poor wit, but very wrong to start\r\nthe report referred to above; for however innocent the motive may have\r\nbeen, the necessary effect was to injure the reputation of a class who\r\nhave a hard enough time of it in the pitiless deserts of the Rocky\r\nMountains, Heaven knows! If we cannot find it in our hearts to give\r\nthose poor naked creatures our Christian sympathy and compassion, in\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s name let us at least not throw mud at them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the seventeenth day we passed the highest mountain peaks we had yet\r\nseen, and although the day was very warm the night that followed upon\r\nits heels was wintry cold and blankets were next to useless.\r\n\r\nOn the eighteenth day we encountered the eastward-bound telegraph-\r\nconstructors at Reese River station and sent a message to his Excellency\r\nGov. Nye at Carson City (distant one hundred and fifty-six miles).\r\n\r\nOn the nineteenth day we crossed the Great American Desert\xe2\x80\x94forty\r\nmemorable miles of bottomless sand, into which the coach wheels sunk\r\nfrom six inches to a foot. We worked our passage most of the way across.\r\nThat is to say, we got out and walked. It was a dreary pull and a long\r\nand thirsty one, for we had no water. From one extremity of this desert\r\nto the other, the road was white with the bones of oxen and horses. It\r\nwould hardly be an exaggeration to say that we could have walked the\r\nforty miles and set our feet on a bone at every step! The desert was one\r\nprodigious graveyard. And the log-chains, wagon tyres, and rotting\r\nwrecks of vehicles were almost as thick as the bones. I think we saw\r\nlog-chains enough rusting there in the desert, to reach across any State\r\nin the Union. Do not these relics suggest something of an idea of the\r\nfearful suffering and privation the early emigrants to California\r\nendured?\r\n\r\nAt the border of the Desert lies Carson Lake, or The \xe2\x80\x9cSink\xe2\x80\x9d of the\r\nCarson, a shallow, melancholy sheet of water some eighty or a hundred\r\nmiles in circumference. Carson River empties into it and is lost\xe2\x80\x94sinks\r\nmysteriously into the earth and never appears in the light of the sun\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94for the lake has no outlet whatever.\r\n\r\nThere are several rivers in Nevada, and they all have this mysterious\r\nfate. They end in various lakes or \xe2\x80\x9csinks,\xe2\x80\x9d and that is the last of\r\nthem. Carson Lake, Humboldt Lake, Walker Lake, Mono Lake, are all great\r\nsheets of water without any visible outlet. Water is always flowing into\r\nthem; none is ever seen to flow out of them, and yet they remain always\r\nlevel full, neither receding nor overflowing. What they do with their\r\nsurplus is only known to the Creator.\r\n\r\nOn the western verge of the Desert we halted a moment at Ragtown. It\r\nconsisted of one log house and is not set down on the map.\r\n\r\nThis reminds me of a circumstance. Just after we left Julesburg, on the\r\nPlatte, I was sitting with the driver, and he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you a most laughable thing indeed, if you would like to\r\nlisten to it. Horace Greeley went over this road once. When he was\r\nleaving Carson City he told the driver, Hank Monk, that he had an\r\nengagement to lecture at Placerville and was very anxious to go through\r\nquick. Hank Monk cracked his whip and started off at an awful pace. The\r\ncoach bounced up and down in such a terrific way that it jolted the\r\nbuttons all off of Horace\xe2\x80\x99s coat, and finally shot his head clean\r\nthrough the roof of the stage, and then he yelled at Hank Monk and\r\nbegged him to go easier\xe2\x80\x94said he warn\xe2\x80\x99t in as much of a hurry as he was\r\nawhile ago. But Hank Monk said, \xe2\x80\x98Keep your seat, Horace, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nyou there on time\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and you bet you he did, too, what was left of him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n151.jpg (54K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA day or two after that we picked up a Denver man at the cross roads,\r\nand he told us a good deal about the country and the Gregory Diggings.\r\nHe seemed a very entertaining person and a man well posted in the\r\naffairs of Colorado. By and by he remarked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you a most laughable thing indeed, if you would like to\r\nlisten to it. Horace Greeley went over this road once. When he was\r\nleaving Carson City he told the driver, Hank Monk, that he had an\r\nengagement to lecture at Placerville and was very anxious to go through\r\nquick. Hank Monk cracked his whip and started off at an awful pace. The\r\ncoach bounced up and down in such a terrific way that it jolted the\r\nbuttons all off of Horace\xe2\x80\x99s coat, and finally shot his head clean\r\nthrough the roof of the stage, and then he yelled at Hank Monk and\r\nbegged him to go easier\xe2\x80\x94said he warn\xe2\x80\x99t in as much of a hurry as he was\r\nawhile ago. But Hank Monk said, \xe2\x80\x98Keep your seat, Horace, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nyou there on time!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and you bet you he did, too, what was left of him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt Fort Bridger, some days after this, we took on board a cavalry\r\nsergeant, a very proper and soldierly person indeed. From no other man\r\nduring the whole journey, did we gather such a store of concise and\r\nwell- arranged military information. It was surprising to find in the\r\ndesolate wilds of our country a man so thoroughly acquainted with\r\neverything useful to know in his line of life, and yet of such inferior\r\nrank and unpretentious bearing. For as much as three hours we listened\r\nto him with unabated interest. Finally he got upon the subject of trans-\r\ncontinental travel, and presently said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you a very laughable thing indeed, if you would like to\r\nlisten to it. Horace Greeley went over this road once. When he was\r\nleaving Carson City he told the driver, Hank Monk, that he had an\r\nengagement to lecture at Placerville and was very anxious to go through\r\nquick. Hank Monk cracked his whip and started off at an awful pace. The\r\ncoach bounced up and down in such a terrific way that it jolted the\r\nbuttons all off of Horace\xe2\x80\x99s coat, and finally shot his head clean\r\nthrough the roof of the stage, and then he yelled at Hank Monk and\r\nbegged him to go easier\xe2\x80\x94said he warn\xe2\x80\x99t in as much of a hurry as he was\r\nawhile ago. But Hank Monk said, \xe2\x80\x98Keep your seat, Horace, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nyou there on time!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and you bet you he did, too, what was left of him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen we were eight hours out from Salt Lake City a Mormon preacher got\r\nin with us at a way station\xe2\x80\x94a gentle, soft-spoken, kindly man, and one\r\nwhom any stranger would warm to at first sight. I can never forget the\r\npathos that was in his voice as he told, in simple language, the story\r\nof his people\xe2\x80\x99s wanderings and unpitied sufferings. No pulpit eloquence\r\nwas ever so moving and so beautiful as this outcast\xe2\x80\x99s picture of the\r\nfirst Mormon pilgrimage across the plains, struggling sorrowfully onward\r\nto the land of its banishment and marking its desolate way with graves\r\nand watering it with tears. His words so wrought upon us that it was a\r\nrelief to us all when the conversation drifted into a more cheerful\r\nchannel and the natural features of the curious country we were in came\r\nunder treatment. One matter after another was pleasantly discussed, and\r\nat length the stranger said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you a most laughable thing indeed, if you would like to\r\nlisten to it. Horace Greeley went over this road once. When he was\r\nleaving Carson City he told the driver, Hank Monk, that he had an\r\nengagement to lecture in Placerville, and was very anxious to go through\r\nquick. Hank Monk cracked his whip and started off at an awful pace. The\r\ncoach bounced up and down in such a terrific way that it jolted the\r\nbuttons all off of Horace\xe2\x80\x99s coat, and finally shot his head clean\r\nthrough the roof of the stage, and then he yelled at Hank Monk and\r\nbegged him to go easier\xe2\x80\x94said he warn\xe2\x80\x99t in as much of a hurry as he was\r\nawhile ago. But Hank Monk said, \xe2\x80\x98Keep your seat, Horace, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nyou there on time!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and you bet you bet you he did, too, what was left\r\nof him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTen miles out of Ragtown we found a poor wanderer who had lain down to\r\ndie. He had walked as long as he could, but his limbs had failed him at\r\nlast. Hunger and fatigue had conquered him. It would have been inhuman\r\nto leave him there. We paid his fare to Carson and lifted him into the\r\ncoach. It was some little time before he showed any very decided signs\r\nof life; but by dint of chafing him and pouring brandy between his lips\r\nwe finally brought him to a languid consciousness. Then we fed him a\r\nlittle, and by and by he seemed to comprehend the situation and a\r\ngrateful light softened his eye. We made his mail-sack bed as\r\ncomfortable as possible, and constructed a pillow for him with our\r\ncoats. He seemed very thankful. Then he looked up in our faces, and said\r\nin a feeble voice that had a tremble of honest emotion in it:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I know not who you are, but you have saved my life; and\r\nalthough I can never be able to repay you for it, I feel that I can at\r\nleast make one hour of your long journey lighter. I take it you are\r\nstrangers to this great thorough fare, but I am entirely familiar with\r\nit. In this connection I can tell you a most laughable thing indeed, if\r\nyou would like to listen to it. Horace Greeley\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n154.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI said, impressively:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuffering stranger, proceed at your peril. You see in me the melancholy\r\nwreck of a once stalwart and magnificent manhood. What has brought me to\r\nthis? That thing which you are about to tell.
