Gradually but surely, that\r\ntiresome old anecdote has sapped my strength, undermined my\r\nconstitution, withered my life. Pity my helplessness. Spare me only just\r\nthis once, and tell me about young George Washington and his little\r\nhatchet for a change.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe were saved. But not so the invalid. In trying to retain the anecdote\r\nin his system he strained himself and died in our arms.\r\n\r\nI am aware, now, that I ought not to have asked of the sturdiest citizen\r\nof all that region, what I asked of that mere shadow of a man; for,\r\nafter seven years\xe2\x80\x99 residence on the Pacific coast, I know that no\r\npassenger or driver on the Overland ever corked that anecdote in, when a\r\nstranger was by, and survived. Within a period of six years I crossed\r\nand recrossed the Sierras between Nevada and California thirteen times\r\nby stage and listened to that deathless incident four hundred and\r\neighty-one or eighty-two times. I have the list somewhere. Drivers\r\nalways told it, conductors told it, landlords told it, chance passengers\r\ntold it, the very Chinamen and vagrant Indians recounted it. I have had\r\nthe same driver tell it to me two or three times in the same afternoon.\r\nIt has come to me in all the multitude of tongues that Babel bequeathed\r\nto earth, and flavored with whiskey, brandy, beer, cologne, sozodont,\r\ntobacco, garlic, onions, grasshoppers\xe2\x80\x94everything that has a fragrance to\r\nit through all the long list of things that are gorged or guzzled by the\r\nsons of men. I never have smelt any anecdote as often as I have smelt\r\nthat one; never have smelt any anecdote that smelt so variegated as that\r\none. And you never could learn to know it by its smell, because every\r\ntime you thought you had learned the smell of it, it would turn up with\r\na different smell. Bayard Taylor has written about this hoary anecdote,\r\nRichardson has published it; so have Jones, Smith, Johnson, Ross Browne,\r\nand every other correspondence-inditing being that ever set his foot\r\nupon the great overland road anywhere between Julesburg and San\r\nFrancisco; and I have heard that it is in the Talmud. I have seen it in\r\nprint in nine different foreign languages; I have been told that it is\r\nemployed in the inquisition in Rome; and I now learn with regret that it\r\nis going to be set to music. I do not think that such things are right.\r\n\r\nStage-coaching on the Overland is no more, and stage drivers are a race\r\ndefunct. I wonder if they bequeathed that bald-headed anecdote to their\r\nsuccessors, the railroad brakemen and conductors, and if these latter\r\nstill persecute the helpless passenger with it until he concludes, as\r\ndid many a tourist of other days, that the real grandeurs of the Pacific\r\ncoast are not Yo Semite and the Big Trees, but Hank Monk and his\r\nadventure with Horace Greeley.\r\n\r\n[And what makes that worn anecdote the more aggravating, is, that the\r\nadventure it celebrates never occurred. If it were a good anecdote, that\r\nseeming demerit would be its chiefest virtue, for creative power belongs\r\nto greatness; but what ought to be done to a man who would wantonly\r\ncontrive so flat a one as this? If I were to suggest what ought to be\r\ndone to him, I should be called extravagant\xe2\x80\x94but what does the sixteenth\r\nchapter of Daniel say? Aha!]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n156.jpg (17K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe were approaching the end of our long journey. It was the morning of\r\nthe twentieth day. At noon we would reach Carson City, the capital of\r\nNevada Territory. We were not glad, but sorry. It had been a fine\r\npleasure trip; we had fed fat on wonders every day; we were now well\r\naccustomed to stage life, and very fond of it; so the idea of coming to\r\na stand-still and settling down to a humdrum existence in a village was\r\nnot agreeable, but on the contrary depressing.\r\n\r\nVisibly our new home was a desert, walled in by barren, snow-clad\r\nmountains. There was not a tree in sight. There was no vegetation but\r\nthe endless sage-brush and greasewood. All nature was gray with it. We\r\nwere plowing through great deeps of powdery alkali dust that rose in\r\nthick clouds and floated across the plain like smoke from a burning\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nWe were coated with it like millers; so were the coach, the mules, the\r\nmail-bags, the driver\xe2\x80\x94we and the sage-brush and the other scenery were\r\nall one monotonous color. Long trains of freight wagons in the distance\r\nenveloped in ascending masses of dust suggested pictures of prairies on\r\nfire. These teams and their masters were the only life we saw. Otherwise\r\nwe moved in the midst of solitude, silence and desolation. Every twenty\r\nsteps we passed the skeleton of some dead beast of burthen, with its\r\ndust-coated skin stretched tightly over its empty ribs. Frequently a\r\nsolemn raven sat upon the skull or the hips and contemplated the passing\r\ncoach with meditative serenity.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n158.jpg (17K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBy and by Carson City was pointed out to us. It nestled in the edge of a\r\ngreat plain and was a sufficient number of miles away to look like an\r\nassemblage of mere white spots in the shadow of a grim range of\r\nmountains overlooking it, whose summits seemed lifted clear out of\r\ncompanionship and consciousness of earthly things.\r\n\r\nWe arrived, disembarked, and the stage went on. It was a \xe2\x80\x9cwooden\xe2\x80\x9d town;\r\nits population two thousand souls. The main street consisted of four or\r\nfive blocks of little white frame stores which were too high to sit down\r\non, but not too high for various other purposes; in fact, hardly high\r\nenough. They were packed close together, side by side, as if room were\r\nscarce in that mighty plain.\r\n\r\nThe sidewalk was of boards that were more or less loose and inclined to\r\nrattle when walked upon. In the middle of the town, opposite the stores,\r\nwas the \xe2\x80\x9cplaza\xe2\x80\x9d which is native to all towns beyond the Rocky\r\nMountains\xe2\x80\x94a large, unfenced, level vacancy, with a liberty pole in it,\r\nand very useful as a place for public auctions, horse trades, and mass\r\nmeetings, and likewise for teamsters to camp in. Two other sides of the\r\nplaza were faced by stores, offices and stables.\r\n\r\nThe rest of Carson City was pretty scattering.\r\n\r\nWe were introduced to several citizens, at the stage-office and on the\r\nway up to the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s from the hotel\xe2\x80\x94among others, to a Mr. Harris,\r\nwho was on horseback; he began to say something, but interrupted himself\r\nwith the remark:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have to get you to excuse me a minute; yonder is the witness that\r\nswore I helped to rob the California coach\xe2\x80\x94a piece of impertinent\r\nintermeddling, sir, for I am not even acquainted with the man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he rode over and began to rebuke the stranger with a six-shooter,\r\nand the stranger began to explain with another. When the pistols were\r\nemptied, the stranger resumed his work (mending a whip-lash), and Mr.\r\nHarris rode by with a polite nod, homeward bound, with a bullet through\r\none of his lungs, and several in his hips; and from them issued little\r\nrivulets of blood that coursed down the horse\xe2\x80\x99s sides and made the\r\nanimal look quite picturesque. I never saw Harris shoot a man after that\r\nbut it recalled to mind that first day in Carson.\r\n\r\nThis was all we saw that day, for it was two o\xe2\x80\x99clock, now, and according\r\nto custom the daily \xe2\x80\x9cWashoe Zephyr\xe2\x80\x9d set in; a soaring dust-drift about\r\nthe size of the United States set up edgewise came with it, and the\r\ncapital of Nevada Territory disappeared from view.\r\n\r\nStill, there were sights to be seen which were not wholly uninteresting\r\nto new comers; for the vast dust cloud was thickly freckled with things\r\nstrange to the upper air\xe2\x80\x94things living and dead, that flitted hither and\r\nthither, going and coming, appearing and disappearing among the rolling\r\nbillows of dust\xe2\x80\x94hats, chickens and parasols sailing in the remote\r\nheavens; blankets, tin signs, sage-brush and shingles a shade lower;\r\ndoor-mats and buffalo robes lower still; shovels and coal scuttles on\r\nthe next grade; glass doors, cats and little children on the next;\r\ndisrupted lumber yards, light buggies and wheelbarrows on the next; and\r\ndown only thirty or forty feet above ground was a scurrying storm of\r\nemigrating roofs and vacant lots.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n159.jpg (92K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was something to see that much. I could have seen more, if I could\r\nhave kept the dust out of my eyes.\r\n\r\nBut seriously a Washoe wind is by no means a trifling matter. It blows\r\nflimsy houses down, lifts shingle roofs occasionally, rolls up tin ones\r\nlike sheet music, now and then blows a stage coach over and spills the\r\npassengers; and tradition says the reason there are so many bald people\r\nthere, is, that the wind blows the hair off their heads while they are\r\nlooking skyward after their hats. Carson streets seldom look inactive on\r\nSummer afternoons, because there are so many citizens skipping around\r\ntheir escaping hats, like chambermaids trying to head off a spider.\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cWashoe Zephyr\xe2\x80\x9d (Washoe is a pet nickname for Nevada) is a peculiar\r\nScriptural wind, in that no man knoweth \xe2\x80\x9cwhence it cometh.\xe2\x80\x9d That is to\r\nsay, where it _originates_. It comes right over the mountains from the\r\nWest, but when one crosses the ridge he does not find any of it on the\r\nother side! It probably is manufactured on the mountain-top for the\r\noccasion, and starts from there. It is a pretty regular wind, in the\r\nsummer time. Its office hours are from two in the afternoon till two the\r\nnext morning; and anybody venturing abroad during those twelve hours\r\nneeds to allow for the wind or he will bring up a mile or two to leeward\r\nof the point he is aiming at. And yet the first complaint a Washoe\r\nvisitor to San Francisco makes, is that the sea winds blow so, there!\r\nThere is a good deal of human nature in that.\r\n\r\nWe found the state palace of the Governor of Nevada Territory to consist\r\nof a white frame one-story house with two small rooms in it and a\r\nstanchion supported shed in front\xe2\x80\x94for grandeur\xe2\x80\x94it compelled the respect\r\nof the citizen and inspired the Indians with awe. The newly arrived\r\nChief and Associate Justices of the Territory, and other machinery of\r\nthe government, were domiciled with less splendor. They were boarding\r\naround privately, and had their offices in their bedrooms.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n161.jpg (63K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Secretary and I took quarters in the \xe2\x80\x9cranch\xe2\x80\x9d of a worthy French lady\r\nby the name of Bridget O\xe2\x80\x99Flannigan, a camp follower of his Excellency\r\nthe Governor. She had known him in his prosperity as commander-in-chief\r\nof the Metropolitan Police of New York, and she would not desert him in\r\nhis adversity as Governor of Nevada.\r\n\r\nOur room was on the lower floor, facing the plaza, and when we had got\r\nour bed, a small table, two chairs, the government fire-proof safe, and\r\nthe Unabridged Dictionary into it, there was still room enough left for\r\na visitor\xe2\x80\x94may be two, but not without straining the walls. But the walls\r\ncould stand it\xe2\x80\x94at least the partitions could, for they consisted simply\r\nof one thickness of white \xe2\x80\x9ccotton domestic\xe2\x80\x9d stretched from corner to\r\ncorner of the room. This was the rule in Carson\xe2\x80\x94any other kind of\r\npartition was the rare exception. And if you stood in a dark room and\r\nyour neighbors in the next had lights, the shadows on your canvas told\r\nqueer secrets sometimes! Very often these partitions were made of old\r\nflour sacks basted together; and then the difference between the common\r\nherd and the aristocracy was, that the common herd had unornamented\r\nsacks, while the walls of the aristocrat were overpowering with\r\nrudimental fresco\xe2\x80\x94_i.e._, red and blue mill brands on the flour sacks.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n162.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOccasionally, also, the better classes embellished their canvas by\r\npasting pictures from _Harper\xe2\x80\x99s Weekly_ on them. In many cases, too, the\r\nwealthy and the cultured rose to spittoons and other evidences of a\r\nsumptuous and luxurious taste. [Washoe people take a joke so hard that I\r\nmust explain that the above description was only the rule; there were\r\nmany honorable exceptions in Carson\xe2\x80\x94plastered ceilings and houses that\r\nhad considerable furniture in them.\xe2\x80\x94M. T.]\r\n\r\nWe had a carpet and a genuine queen\xe2\x80\x99s-ware washbowl. Consequently we\r\nwere hated without reserve by the other tenants of the O\xe2\x80\x99Flannigan\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cranch.\xe2\x80\x9d When we added a painted oilcloth window curtain, we simply took\r\nour lives into our own hands. To prevent bloodshed I removed up stairs\r\nand took up quarters with the untitled plebeians in one of the fourteen\r\nwhite pine cot-bedsteads that stood in two long ranks in the one sole\r\nroom of which the second story consisted.\r\n\r\nIt was a jolly company, the fourteen. They were principally voluntary\r\ncamp-followers of the Governor, who had joined his retinue by their own\r\nelection at New York and San Francisco and came along, feeling that in\r\nthe scuffle for little territorial crumbs and offices they could not\r\nmake their condition more precarious than it was, and might reasonably\r\nexpect to make it better. They were popularly known as the \xe2\x80\x9cIrish\r\nBrigade,\xe2\x80\x9d though there were only four or five Irishmen among all the\r\nGovernor\xe2\x80\x99s retainers.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n163.jpg (95K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHis good-natured Excellency was much annoyed at the gossip his henchmen\r\ncreated\xe2\x80\x94especially when there arose a rumor that they were paid\r\nassassins of his, brought along to quietly reduce the democratic vote\r\nwhen desirable!\r\n\r\nMrs. O\xe2\x80\x99Flannigan was boarding and lodging them at ten dollars a week\r\napiece, and they were cheerfully giving their notes for it. They were\r\nperfectly satisfied, but Bridget presently found that notes that could\r\nnot be discounted were but a feeble constitution for a Carson boarding-\r\nhouse. So she began to harry the Governor to find employment for the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrigade.\xe2\x80\x9d Her importunities and theirs together drove him to a gentle\r\ndesperation at last, and he finally summoned the Brigade to the\r\npresence. Then, said he:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I have planned a lucrative and useful service for you\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nservice which will provide you with recreation amid noble landscapes,\r\nand afford you never ceasing opportunities for enriching your minds by\r\nobservation and study. I want you to survey a railroad from Carson City\r\nwestward to a certain point! When the legislature meets I will have the\r\nnecessary bill passed and the remuneration arranged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, a railroad over the Sierra Nevada Mountains?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, survey it eastward to a certain point!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe converted them into surveyors, chain-bearers and so on, and turned\r\nthem loose in the desert. It was \xe2\x80\x9crecreation\xe2\x80\x9d with a vengeance!\r\nRecreation on foot, lugging chains through sand and sage-brush, under a\r\nsultry sun and among cattle bones, cayotes and tarantulas.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n164.jpg (15K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRomantic adventure\xe2\x80\x9d could go no further. They surveyed very slowly,\r\nvery deliberately, very carefully. They returned every night during the\r\nfirst week, dusty, footsore, tired, and hungry, but very jolly. They\r\nbrought in great store of prodigious hairy spiders\xe2\x80\x94tarantulas\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nimprisoned them in covered tumblers up stairs in the \xe2\x80\x9cranch.\xe2\x80\x9d After the\r\nfirst week, they had to camp on the field, for they were getting well\r\neastward. They made a good many inquiries as to the location of that\r\nindefinite \xe2\x80\x9ccertain point,\xe2\x80\x9d but got no information. At last, to a\r\npeculiarly urgent inquiry of \xe2\x80\x9cHow far eastward?\xe2\x80\x9d Governor Nye\r\ntelegraphed back:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Atlantic Ocean, blast you!\xe2\x80\x94and then bridge it and go on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis brought back the dusty toilers, who sent in a report and ceased\r\nfrom their labors. The Governor was always comfortable about it; he said\r\nMrs. O\xe2\x80\x99Flannigan would hold him for the Brigade\xe2\x80\x99s board anyhow, and he\r\nintended to get what entertainment he could out of the boys; he said,\r\nwith his old-time pleasant twinkle, that he meant to survey them into\r\nUtah and then telegraph Brigham to hang them for trespass!\r\n\r\nThe surveyors brought back more tarantulas with them, and so we had\r\nquite a menagerie arranged along the shelves of the room. Some of these\r\nspiders could straddle over a common saucer with their hairy, muscular\r\nlegs, and when their feelings were hurt, or their dignity offended, they\r\nwere the wickedest-looking desperadoes the animal world can furnish. If\r\ntheir glass prison-houses were touched ever so lightly they were up and\r\nspoiling for a fight in a minute. Starchy?\xe2\x80\x94proud? Indeed, they would\r\ntake up a straw and pick their teeth like a member of Congress. There\r\nwas as usual a furious \xe2\x80\x9czephyr\xe2\x80\x9d blowing the first night of the brigade\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreturn, and about midnight the roof of an adjoining stable blew off, and\r\na corner of it came crashing through the side of our ranch. There was a\r\nsimultaneous awakening, and a tumultuous muster of the brigade in the\r\ndark, and a general tumbling and sprawling over each other in the narrow\r\naisle between the bedrows. In the midst of the turmoil, Bob H\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94sprung up\r\nout of a sound sleep, and knocked down a shelf with his head. Instantly\r\nhe shouted:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTurn out, boys\xe2\x80\x94the tarantulas is loose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n165.jpg (15K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNo warning ever sounded so dreadful. Nobody tried, any longer, to leave\r\nthe room, lest he might step on a tarantula. Every man groped for a\r\ntrunk or a bed, and jumped on it. Then followed the strangest silence\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nsilence of grisly suspense it was, too\xe2\x80\x94waiting, expectancy, fear. It was\r\nas dark as pitch, and one had to imagine the spectacle of those fourteen\r\nscant-clad men roosting gingerly on trunks and beds, for not a thing\r\ncould be seen. Then came occasional little interruptions of the silence,\r\nand one could recognize a man and tell his locality by his voice, or\r\nlocate any other sound a sufferer made by his gropings or changes of\r\nposition. The occasional voices were not given to much speaking\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nsimply heard a gentle ejaculation of \xe2\x80\x9cOw!\xe2\x80\x9d followed by a solid thump,\r\nand you knew the gentleman had felt a hairy blanket or something touch\r\nhis bare skin and had skipped from a bed to the floor. Another silence.\r\nPresently you would hear a gasping voice say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSu-su-something\xe2\x80\x99s crawling up the back of my neck!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvery now and then you could hear a little subdued scramble and a\r\nsorrowful \xe2\x80\x9cO Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d and then you knew that somebody was getting away\r\nfrom something he took for a tarantula, and not losing any time about\r\nit, either. Directly a voice in the corner rang out wild and clear:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got him! I\xe2\x80\x99ve got him!\xe2\x80\x9d [Pause, and probable change of\r\ncircumstances.] \xe2\x80\x9cNo, he\xe2\x80\x99s got me! Oh, ain\xe2\x80\x99t they never going to fetch a\r\nlantern!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n166.jpg (89K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe lantern came at that moment, in the hands of Mrs. O\xe2\x80\x99Flannigan, whose\r\nanxiety to know the amount of damage done by the assaulting roof had not\r\nprevented her waiting a judicious interval, after getting out of bed and\r\nlighting up, to see if the wind was done, now, up stairs, or had a\r\nlarger contract.\r\n\r\nThe landscape presented when the lantern flashed into the room was\r\npicturesque, and might have been funny to some people, but was not to\r\nus. Although we were perched so strangely upon boxes, trunks and beds,\r\nand so strangely attired, too, we were too earnestly distressed and too\r\ngenuinely miserable to see any fun about it, and there was not the\r\nsemblance of a smile anywhere visible. I know I am not capable of\r\nsuffering more than I did during those few minutes of suspense in the\r\ndark, surrounded by those creeping, bloody-minded tarantulas. I had\r\nskipped from bed to bed and from box to box in a cold agony, and every\r\ntime I touched anything that was furzy I fancied I felt the fangs. I had\r\nrather go to war than live that episode over again. Nobody was hurt. The\r\nman who thought a tarantula had \xe2\x80\x9cgot him\xe2\x80\x9d was mistaken\xe2\x80\x94only a crack in a\r\nbox had caught his finger. Not one of those escaped tarantulas was ever\r\nseen again. There were ten or twelve of them. We took candles and hunted\r\nthe place high and low for them, but with no success. Did we go back to\r\nbed then? We did nothing of the kind. Money could not have persuaded us\r\nto do it. We sat up the rest of the night playing cribbage and keeping a\r\nsharp lookout for the enemy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was the end of August, and the skies were cloudless and the weather\r\nsuperb. In two or three weeks I had grown wonderfully fascinated with\r\nthe curious new country and concluded to put off my return to \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nStates\xe2\x80\x9d awhile. I had grown well accustomed to wearing a damaged slouch\r\nhat, blue woolen shirt, and pants crammed into boot-tops, and gloried in\r\nthe absence of coat, vest and braces. I felt rowdyish and \xe2\x80\x9cbully,\xe2\x80\x9d (as\r\nthe historian Josephus phrases it, in his fine chapter upon the\r\ndestruction of the Temple). It seemed to me that nothing could be so\r\nfine and so romantic. I had become an officer of the government, but\r\nthat was for mere sublimity. The office was an unique sinecure. I had\r\nnothing to do and no salary. I was private Secretary to his majesty the\r\nSecretary and there was not yet writing enough for two of us. So Johnny\r\nK\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94and I devoted our time to amusement. He was the young son of an Ohio\r\nnabob and was out there for recreation. He got it. We had heard a world\r\nof talk about the marvellous beauty of Lake Tahoe, and finally curiosity\r\ndrove us thither to see it. Three or four members of the Brigade had\r\nbeen there and located some timber lands on its shores and stored up a\r\nquantity of provisions in their camp. We strapped a couple of blankets\r\non our shoulders and took an axe apiece and started\xe2\x80\x94for we intended to\r\ntake up a wood ranch or so ourselves and become wealthy. We were on\r\nfoot. The reader will find it advantageous to go horseback. We were told\r\nthat the distance was eleven miles. We tramped a long time on level\r\nground, and then toiled laboriously up a mountain about a thousand miles\r\nhigh and looked over. No lake there. We descended on the other side,\r\ncrossed the valley and toiled up another mountain three or four thousand\r\nmiles high, apparently, and looked over again. No lake yet. We sat down\r\ntired and perspiring, and hired a couple of Chinamen to curse those\r\npeople who had beguiled us. Thus refreshed, we presently resumed the\r\nmarch with renewed vigor and determination. We plodded on, two or three\r\nhours longer, and at last the Lake burst upon us\xe2\x80\x94a noble sheet of blue\r\nwater lifted six thousand three hundred feet above the level of the sea,\r\nand walled in by a rim of snow-clad mountain peaks that towered aloft\r\nfull three thousand feet higher still! It was a vast oval, and one would\r\nhave to use up eighty or a hundred good miles in traveling around it. As\r\nit lay there with the shadows of the mountains brilliantly photographed\r\nupon its still surface I thought it must surely be the fairest picture\r\nthe whole earth affords.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n169.jpg (80K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe found the small skiff belonging to the Brigade boys, and without loss\r\nof time set out across a deep bend of the lake toward the landmarks that\r\nsignified the locality of the camp. I got Johnny to row\xe2\x80\x94not because I\r\nmind exertion myself, but because it makes me sick to ride backwards\r\nwhen I am at work. But I steered. A three-mile pull brought us to the\r\ncamp just as the night fell, and we stepped ashore very tired and\r\nwolfishly hungry. In a \xe2\x80\x9ccache\xe2\x80\x9d among the rocks we found the provisions\r\nand the cooking utensils, and then, all fatigued as I was, I sat down on\r\na boulder and superintended while Johnny gathered wood and cooked\r\nsupper. Many a man who had gone through what I had, would have wanted to\r\nrest.\r\n\r\nIt was a delicious supper\xe2\x80\x94hot bread, fried bacon, and black coffee. It\r\nwas a delicious solitude we were in, too. Three miles away was a saw-\r\nmill and some workmen, but there were not fifteen other human beings\r\nthroughout the wide circumference of the lake. As the darkness closed\r\ndown and the stars came out and spangled the great mirror with jewels,\r\nwe smoked meditatively in the solemn hush and forgot our troubles and\r\nour pains. In due time we spread our blankets in the warm sand between\r\ntwo large boulders and soon feel asleep, careless of the procession of\r\nants that passed in through rents in our clothing and explored our\r\npersons. Nothing could disturb the sleep that fettered us, for it had\r\nbeen fairly earned, and if our consciences had any sins on them they had\r\nto adjourn court for that night, any way. The wind rose just as we were\r\nlosing consciousness, and we were lulled to sleep by the beating of the\r\nsurf upon the shore.\r\n\r\nIt is always very cold on that lake shore in the night, but we had\r\nplenty of blankets and were warm enough. We never moved a muscle all\r\nnight, but waked at early dawn in the original positions, and got up at\r\nonce, thoroughly refreshed, free from soreness, and brim full of\r\nfriskiness. There is no end of wholesome medicine in such an experience.\r\nThat morning we could have whipped ten such people as we were the day\r\nbefore\xe2\x80\x94sick ones at any rate. But the world is slow, and people will go\r\nto \xe2\x80\x9cwater cures\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmovement cures\xe2\x80\x9d and to foreign lands for health.\r\nThree months of camp life on Lake Tahoe would restore an Egyptian mummy\r\nto his pristine vigor, and give him an appetite like an alligator. I do\r\nnot mean the oldest and driest mummies, of course, but the fresher ones.\r\nThe air up there in the clouds is very pure and fine, bracing and\r\ndelicious. And why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be?\xe2\x80\x94it is the same the angels breathe. I\r\nthink that hardly any amount of fatigue can be gathered together that a\r\nman cannot sleep off in one night on the sand by its side. Not under a\r\nroof, but under the sky; it seldom or never rains there in the summer\r\ntime. I know a man who went there to die. But he made a failure of it.\r\nHe was a skeleton when he came, and could barely stand. He had no\r\nappetite, and did nothing but read tracts and reflect on the future.\r\nThree months later he was sleeping out of doors regularly, eating all he\r\ncould hold, three times a day, and chasing game over mountains three\r\nthousand feet high for recreation. And he was a skeleton no longer, but\r\nweighed part of a ton. This is no fancy sketch, but the truth. His\r\ndisease was consumption. I confidently commend his experience to other\r\nskeletons.\r\n\r\n\r\n170.jpg (19K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n171.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\nI superintended again, and as soon as we had eaten breakfast we got in\r\nthe boat and skirted along the lake shore about three miles and\r\ndisembarked. We liked the appearance of the place, and so we claimed\r\nsome three hundred acres of it and stuck our \xe2\x80\x9cnotices\xe2\x80\x9d on a tree. It was\r\nyellow pine timber land\xe2\x80\x94a dense forest of trees a hundred feet high and\r\nfrom one to five feet through at the butt. It was necessary to fence our\r\nproperty or we could not hold it. That is to say, it was necessary to\r\ncut down trees here and there and make them fall in such a way as to\r\nform a sort of enclosure (with pretty wide gaps in it). We cut down\r\nthree trees apiece, and found it such heart-breaking work that we\r\ndecided to \xe2\x80\x9crest our case\xe2\x80\x9d on those; if they held the property, well and\r\ngood; if they didn\xe2\x80\x99t, let the property spill out through the gaps and\r\ngo; it was no use to work ourselves to death merely to save a few acres\r\nof land. Next day we came back to build a house\xe2\x80\x94for a house was also\r\nnecessary, in order to hold the property.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n172.jpg (142K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe decided to build a substantial log-house and excite the envy of the\r\nBrigade boys; but by the time we had cut and trimmed the first log it\r\nseemed unnecessary to be so elaborate, and so we concluded to build it\r\nof saplings. However, two saplings, duly cut and trimmed, compelled\r\nrecognition of the fact that a still modester architecture would satisfy\r\nthe law, and so we concluded to build a \xe2\x80\x9cbrush\xe2\x80\x9d house. We devoted the\r\nnext day to this work, but we did so much \xe2\x80\x9csitting around\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\ndiscussing, that by the middle of the afternoon we had achieved only a\r\nhalf-way sort of affair which one of us had to watch while the other cut\r\nbrush, lest if both turned our backs we might not be able to find it\r\nagain, it had such a strong family resemblance to the surrounding\r\nvegetation. But we were satisfied with it.\r\n\r\nWe were land owners now, duly seized and possessed, and within the\r\nprotection of the law. Therefore we decided to take up our residence on\r\nour own domain and enjoy that large sense of independence which only\r\nsuch an experience can bring. Late the next afternoon, after a good long\r\nrest, we sailed away from the Brigade camp with all the provisions and\r\ncooking utensils we could carry off\xe2\x80\x94borrow is the more accurate word\xe2\x80\x94and\r\njust as the night was falling we beached the boat at our own landing.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIf there is any life that is happier than the life we led on our timber\r\nranch for the next two or three weeks, it must be a sort of life which I\r\nhave not read of in books or experienced in person. We did not see a\r\nhuman being but ourselves during the time, or hear any sounds but those\r\nthat were made by the wind and the waves, the sighing of the pines, and\r\nnow and then the far-off thunder of an avalanche. The forest about us\r\nwas dense and cool, the sky above us was cloudless and brilliant with\r\nsunshine, the broad lake before us was glassy and clear, or rippled and\r\nbreezy, or black and storm-tossed, according to Nature\xe2\x80\x99s mood; and its\r\ncircling border of mountain domes, clothed with forests, scarred with\r\nland-slides, cloven by ca\xc3\xb1ons and valleys, and helmeted with glittering\r\nsnow, fitly framed and finished the noble picture. The view was always\r\nfascinating, bewitching, entrancing. The eye was never tired of gazing,\r\nnight or day, in calm or storm; it suffered but one grief, and that was\r\nthat it could not look always, but must close sometimes in sleep.\r\n\r\nWe slept in the sand close to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge, between two protecting\r\nboulders, which took care of the stormy night-winds for us. We never\r\ntook any paregoric to make us sleep. At the first break of dawn we were\r\nalways up and running foot-races to tone down excess of physical vigor\r\nand exuberance of spirits. That is, Johnny was\xe2\x80\x94but I held his hat. While\r\nsmoking the pipe of peace after breakfast we watched the sentinel peaks\r\nput on the glory of the sun, and followed the conquering light as it\r\nswept down among the shadows, and set the captive crags and forests\r\nfree. We watched the tinted pictures grow and brighten upon the water\r\ntill every little detail of forest, precipice and pinnacle was wrought\r\nin and finished, and the miracle of the enchanter complete. Then to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n174.jpg (84K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThat is, drifting around in the boat. We were on the north shore. There,\r\nthe rocks on the bottom are sometimes gray, sometimes white. This gives\r\nthe marvelous transparency of the water a fuller advantage than it has\r\nelsewhere on the lake. We usually pushed out a hundred yards or so from\r\nshore, and then lay down on the thwarts, in the sun, and let the boat\r\ndrift by the hour whither it would. We seldom talked. It interrupted the\r\nSabbath stillness, and marred the dreams the luxurious rest and\r\nindolence brought. The shore all along was indented with deep, curved\r\nbays and coves, bordered by narrow sand-beaches; and where the sand\r\nended, the steep mountain-sides rose right up aloft into space\xe2\x80\x94rose up\r\nlike a vast wall a little out of the perpendicular, and thickly wooded\r\nwith tall pines.\r\n\r\nSo singularly clear was the water, that where it was only twenty or\r\nthirty feet deep the bottom was so perfectly distinct that the boat\r\nseemed floating in the air! Yes, where it was even _eighty_ feet deep.\r\nEvery little pebble was distinct, every speckled trout, every hand\xe2\x80\x99s-\r\nbreadth of sand. Often, as we lay on our faces, a granite boulder, as\r\nlarge as a village church, would start out of the bottom apparently, and\r\nseem climbing up rapidly to the surface, till presently it threatened to\r\ntouch our faces, and we could not resist the impulse to seize an oar and\r\navert the danger. But the boat would float on, and the boulder descend\r\nagain, and then we could see that when we had been exactly above it, it\r\nmust still have been twenty or thirty feet below the surface. Down\r\nthrough the transparency of these great depths, the water was not\r\n_merely_ transparent, but dazzlingly, brilliantly so. All objects seen\r\nthrough it had a bright, strong vividness, not only of outline, but of\r\nevery minute detail, which they would not have had when seen simply\r\nthrough the same depth of atmosphere. So empty and airy did all spaces\r\nseem below us, and so strong was the sense of floating high aloft in\r\nmid-nothingness, that we called these boat-excursions \xe2\x80\x9cballoon-voyages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe fished a good deal, but we did not average one fish a week. We could\r\nsee trout by the thousand winging about in the emptiness under us, or\r\nsleeping in shoals on the bottom, but they would not bite\xe2\x80\x94they could see\r\nthe line too plainly, perhaps. We frequently selected the trout we\r\nwanted, and rested the bait patiently and persistently on the end of his\r\nnose at a depth of eighty feet, but he would only shake it off with an\r\nannoyed manner, and shift his position.\r\n\r\nWe bathed occasionally, but the water was rather chilly, for all it\r\nlooked so sunny. Sometimes we rowed out to the \xe2\x80\x9cblue water,\xe2\x80\x9d a mile or\r\ntwo from shore. It was as dead blue as indigo there, because of the\r\nimmense depth. By official measurement the lake in its centre is one\r\nthousand five hundred and twenty-five feet deep!\r\n\r\nSometimes, on lazy afternoons, we lolled on the sand in camp, and smoked\r\npipes and read some old well-worn novels. At night, by the camp-fire, we\r\nplayed euchre and seven-up to strengthen the mind\xe2\x80\x94and played them with\r\ncards so greasy and defaced that only a whole summer\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance with\r\nthem could enable the student to tell the ace of clubs from the jack of\r\ndiamonds.\r\n\r\nWe never slept in our \xe2\x80\x9chouse.\xe2\x80\x9d It never recurred to us, for one thing;\r\nand besides, it was built to hold the ground, and that was enough. We\r\ndid not wish to strain it.\r\n\r\nBy and by our provisions began to run short, and we went back to the old\r\ncamp and laid in a new supply. We were gone all day, and reached home\r\nagain about night-fall, pretty tired and hungry. While Johnny was\r\ncarrying the main bulk of the provisions up to our \xe2\x80\x9chouse\xe2\x80\x9d for future\r\nuse, I took the loaf of bread, some slices of bacon, and the coffee-pot,\r\nashore, set them down by a tree, lit a fire, and went back to the boat\r\nto get the frying-pan. While I was at this, I heard a shout from Johnny,\r\nand looking up I saw that my fire was galloping all over the premises!\r\nJohnny was on the other side of it. He had to run through the flames to\r\nget to the lake shore, and then we stood helpless and watched the\r\ndevastation.\r\n\r\nThe ground was deeply carpeted with dry pine-needles, and the fire\r\ntouched them off as if they were gunpowder. It was wonderful to see with\r\nwhat fierce speed the tall sheet of flame traveled! My coffee-pot was\r\ngone, and everything with it. In a minute and a half the fire seized\r\nupon a dense growth of dry manzanita chapparal six or eight feet high,\r\nand then the roaring and popping and crackling was something terrific.\r\nWe were driven to the boat by the intense heat, and there we remained,\r\nspell-bound.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n176.jpg (161K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWithin half an hour all before us was a tossing, blinding tempest of\r\nflame! It went surging up adjacent ridges\xe2\x80\x94surmounted them and\r\ndisappeared in the ca\xc3\xb1ons beyond\xe2\x80\x94burst into view upon higher and farther\r\nridges, presently\xe2\x80\x94shed a grander illumination abroad, and dove\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94flamed out again, directly, higher and still higher up the\r\nmountain-side threw out skirmishing parties of fire here and there, and\r\nsent them trailing their crimson spirals away among remote ramparts and\r\nribs and gorges, till as far as the eye could reach the lofty mountain-\r\nfronts were webbed as it were with a tangled network of red lava\r\nstreams. Away across the water the crags and domes were lit with a ruddy\r\nglare, and the firmament above was a reflected hell!\r\n\r\nEvery feature of the spectacle was repeated in the glowing mirror of the\r\nlake! Both pictures were sublime, both were beautiful; but that in the\r\nlake had a bewildering richness about it that enchanted the eye and held\r\nit with the stronger fascination.\r\n\r\nWe sat absorbed and motionless through four long hours. We never thought\r\nof supper, and never felt fatigue. But at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the\r\nconflagration had traveled beyond our range of vision, and then darkness\r\nstole down upon the landscape again.\r\n\r\nHunger asserted itself now, but there was nothing to eat. The provisions\r\nwere all cooked, no doubt, but we did not go to see. We were homeless\r\nwanderers again, without any property. Our fence was gone, our house\r\nburned down; no insurance. Our pine forest was well scorched, the dead\r\ntrees all burned up, and our broad acres of manzanita swept away. Our\r\nblankets were on our usual sand-bed, however, and so we lay down and\r\nwent to sleep. The next morning we started back to the old camp, but\r\nwhile out a long way from shore, so great a storm came up that we dared\r\nnot try to land. So I baled out the seas we shipped, and Johnny pulled\r\nheavily through the billows till we had reached a point three or four\r\nmiles beyond the camp. The storm was increasing, and it became evident\r\nthat it was better to take the hazard of beaching the boat than go down\r\nin a hundred fathoms of water; so we ran in, with tall white-caps\r\nfollowing, and I sat down in the stern-sheets and pointed her head-on to\r\nthe shore. The instant the bow struck, a wave came over the stern that\r\nwashed crew and cargo ashore, and saved a deal of trouble. We shivered\r\nin the lee of a boulder all the rest of the day, and froze all the night\r\nthrough. In the morning the tempest had gone down, and we paddled down\r\nto the camp without any unnecessary delay. We were so starved that we\r\nate up the rest of the Brigade\xe2\x80\x99s provisions, and then set out to Carson\r\nto tell them about it and ask their forgiveness. It was accorded, upon\r\npayment of damages.\r\n\r\nWe made many trips to the lake after that, and had many a hair-breadth\r\nescape and blood-curdling adventure which will never be recorded in any\r\nhistory.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nI resolved to have a horse to ride. I had never seen such wild, free,\r\nmagnificent horsemanship outside of a circus as these picturesquely-clad\r\nMexicans, Californians and Mexicanized Americans displayed in Carson\r\nstreets every day. How they rode! Leaning just gently forward out of the\r\nperpendicular, easy and nonchalant, with broad slouch-hat brim blown\r\nsquare up in front, and long _riata_ swinging above the head as they\r\nswept through the town like the wind! The next minute they were only a\r\nsailing puff of dust on the far desert. If they trotted, they sat up\r\ngallantly and gracefully, and seemed part of the horse; did not go\r\njiggering up and down after the silly Miss-Nancy fashion of the riding-\r\nschools. I had quickly learned to tell a horse from a cow, and was full\r\nof anxiety to learn more. I was resolved to buy a horse.\r\n\r\nWhile the thought was rankling in my mind, the auctioneer came skurrying\r\nthrough the plaza on a black beast that had as many humps and corners on\r\nhim as a dromedary, and was necessarily uncomely; but he was \xe2\x80\x9cgoing,\r\ngoing, at twenty-two!\xe2\x80\x94horse, saddle and bridle at twenty-two dollars,\r\ngentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d and I could hardly resist.\r\n\r\nA man whom I did not know (he turned out to be the auctioneer\xe2\x80\x99s brother)\r\nnoticed the wistful look in my eye, and observed that that was a very\r\nremarkable horse to be going at such a price; and added that the saddle\r\nalone was worth the money. It was a Spanish saddle, with ponderous\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_tapidaros_\xe2\x80\x99, and furnished with the ungainly sole-leather covering\r\nwith the unspellable name. I said I had half a notion to bid. Then this\r\nkeen-eyed person appeared to me to be \xe2\x80\x9ctaking my measure\xe2\x80\x9d; but I\r\ndismissed the suspicion when he spoke, for his manner was full of\r\nguileless candor and truthfulness. Said he:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that horse\xe2\x80\x94know him well. You are a stranger, I take it, and so\r\nyou might think he was an American horse, maybe, but I assure you he is\r\nnot. He is nothing of the kind; but\xe2\x80\x94excuse my speaking in a low voice,\r\nother people being near\xe2\x80\x94he is, without the shadow of a doubt, a Genuine\r\nMexican Plug!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n179.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI did not know what a Genuine Mexican Plug was, but there was something\r\nabout this man\xe2\x80\x99s way of saying it, that made me swear inwardly that I\r\nwould own a Genuine Mexican Plug, or die.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he any other\xe2\x80\x94er\xe2\x80\x94advantages?\xe2\x80\x9d I inquired, suppressing what eagerness\r\nI could.\r\n\r\nHe hooked his forefinger in the pocket of my army-shirt, led me to one\r\nside, and breathed in my ear impressively these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe can out-buck anything in America!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing, going, going\xe2\x80\x94at twent\xe2\x80\x94ty\xe2\x80\x94four dollars and a half, gen\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-seven!\xe2\x80\x9d I shouted, in a frenzy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd sold!\xe2\x80\x9d said the auctioneer, and passed over the Genuine Mexican\r\nPlug to me.\r\n\r\nI could scarcely contain my exultation. I paid the money, and put the\r\nanimal in a neighboring livery-stable to dine and rest himself.\r\n\r\nIn the afternoon I brought the creature into the plaza, and certain\r\ncitizens held him by the head, and others by the tail, while I mounted\r\nhim. As soon as they let go, he placed all his feet in a bunch together,\r\nlowered his back, and then suddenly arched it upward, and shot me\r\nstraight into the air a matter of three or four feet! I came as straight\r\ndown again, lit in the saddle, went instantly up again, came down almost\r\non the high pommel, shot up again, and came down on the horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck\xe2\x80\x94all\r\nin the space of three or four seconds. Then he rose and stood almost\r\nstraight up on his hind feet, and I, clasping his lean neck desperately,\r\nslid back into the saddle and held on. He came down, and immediately\r\nhoisted his heels into the air, delivering a vicious kick at the sky,\r\nand stood on his forefeet. And then down he came once more, and began\r\nthe original exercise of shooting me straight up again. The third time I\r\nwent up I heard a stranger say:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n180.jpg (50K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t he _buck,_ though!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile I was up, somebody struck the horse a sounding thwack with a\r\nleathern strap, and when I arrived again the Genuine Mexican Plug was\r\nnot there. A California youth chased him up and caught him, and asked if\r\nhe might have a ride. I granted him that luxury. He mounted the Genuine,\r\ngot lifted into the air once, but sent his spurs home as he descended,\r\nand the horse darted away like a telegram. He soared over three fences\r\nlike a bird, and disappeared down the road toward the Washoe Valley.\r\n\r\nI sat down on a stone, with a sigh, and by a natural impulse one of my\r\nhands sought my forehead, and the other the base of my stomach. I\r\nbelieve I never appreciated, till then, the poverty of the human\r\nmachinery\xe2\x80\x94for I still needed a hand or two to place elsewhere. Pen\r\ncannot describe how I was jolted up. Imagination cannot conceive how\r\ndisjointed I was\xe2\x80\x94how internally, externally and universally I was\r\nunsettled, mixed up and ruptured. There was a sympathetic crowd around\r\nme, though.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n181.jpg (38K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOne elderly-looking comforter said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStranger, you\xe2\x80\x99ve been taken in. Everybody in this camp knows that\r\nhorse. Any child, any Injun, could have told you that he\xe2\x80\x99d buck; he is\r\nthe very worst devil to buck on the continent of America. You hear _me_.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m Curry. _Old_ Curry. Old _Abe_ Curry. And moreover, he is a simon-\r\npure, out-and-out, genuine d\xe2\x80\x94d Mexican plug, and an uncommon mean one at\r\nthat, too. Why, you turnip, if you had laid low and kept dark, there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchances to buy an _American_ horse for mighty little more than you paid\r\nfor that bloody old foreign relic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI gave no sign; but I made up my mind that if the auctioneer\xe2\x80\x99s brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfuneral took place while I was in the Territory I would postpone all\r\nother recreations and attend it.\r\n\r\nAfter a gallop of sixteen miles the Californian youth and the Genuine\r\nMexican Plug came tearing into town again, shedding foam-flakes like the\r\nspume-spray that drives before a typhoon, and, with one final skip over\r\na wheelbarrow and a Chinaman, cast anchor in front of the \xe2\x80\x9cranch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n182.jpg (45K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch panting and blowing! Such spreading and contracting of the red\r\nequine nostrils, and glaring of the wild equine eye! But was the\r\nimperial beast subjugated? Indeed he was not.\r\n\r\nHis lordship the Speaker of the House thought he was, and mounted him to\r\ngo down to the Capitol; but the first dash the creature made was over a\r\npile of telegraph poles half as high as a church; and his time to the\r\nCapitol\xe2\x80\x94one mile and three quarters\xe2\x80\x94remains unbeaten to this day. But\r\nthen he took an advantage\xe2\x80\x94he left out the mile, and only did the three\r\nquarters. That is to say, he made a straight cut across lots, preferring\r\nfences and ditches to a crooked road; and when the Speaker got to the\r\nCapitol he said he had been in the air so much he felt as if he had made\r\nthe trip on a comet.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n183.jpg (50K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the evening the Speaker came home afoot for exercise, and got the\r\nGenuine towed back behind a quartz wagon. The next day I loaned the\r\nanimal to the Clerk of the House to go down to the Dana silver mine, six\r\nmiles, and _he_ walked back for exercise, and got the horse towed.\r\nEverybody I loaned him to always walked back; they never could get\r\nenough exercise any other way.\r\n\r\nStill, I continued to loan him to anybody who was willing to borrow him,\r\nmy idea being to get him crippled, and throw him on the borrower\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhands, or killed, and make the borrower pay for him. But somehow nothing\r\never happened to him. He took chances that no other horse ever took and\r\nsurvived, but he always came out safe. It was his daily habit to try\r\nexperiments that had always before been considered impossible, but he\r\nalways got through. Sometimes he miscalculated a little, and did not get\r\nhis rider through intact, but _he_ always got through himself. Of course\r\nI had tried to sell him; but that was a stretch of simplicity which met\r\nwith little sympathy. The auctioneer stormed up and down the streets on\r\nhim for four days, dispersing the populace, interrupting business, and\r\ndestroying children, and never got a bid\xe2\x80\x94at least never any but the\r\neighteen-dollar one he hired a notoriously substanceless bummer to make.\r\nThe people only smiled pleasantly, and restrained their desire to buy,\r\nif they had any. Then the auctioneer brought in his bill, and I withdrew\r\nthe horse from the market. We tried to trade him off at private vendue\r\nnext, offering him at a sacrifice for second-hand tombstones, old iron,\r\ntemperance tracts\xe2\x80\x94any kind of property. But holders were stiff, and we\r\nretired from the market again. I never tried to ride the horse any more.\r\nWalking was good enough exercise for a man like me, that had nothing the\r\nmatter with him except ruptures, internal injuries, and such things.\r\nFinally I tried to _give_ him away. But it was a failure. Parties said\r\nearthquakes were handy enough on the Pacific coast\xe2\x80\x94they did not wish to\r\nown one. As a last resort I offered him to the Governor for the use of\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cBrigade.\xe2\x80\x9d His face lit up eagerly at first, but toned down again,\r\nand he said the thing would be too palpable.\r\n\r\nJust then the livery stable man brought in his bill for six weeks\xe2\x80\x99\r\nkeeping\xe2\x80\x94stall-room for the horse, fifteen dollars; hay for the horse,\r\ntwo hundred and fifty! The Genuine Mexican Plug had eaten a ton of the\r\narticle, and the man said he would have eaten a hundred if he had let\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nI will remark here, in all seriousness, that the regular price of hay\r\nduring that year and a part of the next was really two hundred and fifty\r\ndollars a ton. During a part of the previous year it had sold at five\r\nhundred a ton, in _gold_, and during the winter before that there was\r\nsuch scarcity of the article that in several instances small quantities\r\nhad brought eight hundred dollars a ton in coin! The consequence might\r\nbe guessed without my telling it: peopled turned their stock loose to\r\nstarve, and before the spring arrived Carson and Eagle valleys were\r\nalmost literally carpeted with their carcases! Any old settler there\r\nwill verify these statements.\r\n\r\nI managed to pay the livery bill, and that same day I gave the Genuine\r\nMexican Plug to a passing Arkansas emigrant whom fortune delivered into\r\nmy hand. If this ever meets his eye, he will doubtless remember the\r\ndonation.\r\n\r\nNow whoever has had the luck to ride a real Mexican plug will recognize\r\nthe animal depicted in this chapter, and hardly consider him\r\nexaggerated\xe2\x80\x94but the uninitiated will feel justified in regarding his\r\nportrait as a fancy sketch, perhaps.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV.\r\n\r\n\r\nOriginally, Nevada was a part of Utah and was called Carson county; and\r\na pretty large county it was, too. Certain of its valleys produced no\r\nend of hay, and this attracted small colonies of Mormon stock-raisers\r\nand farmers to them. A few orthodox Americans straggled in from\r\nCalifornia, but no love was lost between the two classes of colonists.\r\nThere was little or no friendly intercourse; each party staid to itself.\r\nThe Mormons were largely in the majority, and had the additional\r\nadvantage of being peculiarly under the protection of the Mormon\r\ngovernment of the Territory. Therefore they could afford to be distant,\r\nand even peremptory toward their neighbors. One of the traditions of\r\nCarson Valley illustrates the condition of things that prevailed at the\r\ntime I speak of. The hired girl of one of the American families was\r\nIrish, and a Catholic; yet it was noted with surprise that she was the\r\nonly person outside of the Mormon ring who could get favors from the\r\nMormons. She asked kindnesses of them often, and always got them. It was\r\na mystery to everybody. But one day as she was passing out at the door,\r\na large bowie knife dropped from under her apron, and when her mistress\r\nasked for an explanation she observed that she was going out to \xe2\x80\x9cborry a\r\nwash-tub from the Mormons!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n186.jpg (88K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn 1858 silver lodes were discovered in \xe2\x80\x9cCarson County,\xe2\x80\x9d and then the\r\naspect of things changed. Californians began to flock in, and the\r\nAmerican element was soon in the majority. Allegiance to Brigham Young\r\nand Utah was renounced, and a temporary territorial government for\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWashoe\xe2\x80\x9d was instituted by the citizens. Governor Roop was the first and\r\nonly chief magistrate of it. In due course of time Congress passed a\r\nbill to organize \xe2\x80\x9cNevada Territory,\xe2\x80\x9d and President Lincoln sent out\r\nGovernor Nye to supplant Roop.\r\n\r\nAt this time the population of the Territory was about twelve or fifteen\r\nthousand, and rapidly increasing. Silver mines were being vigorously\r\ndeveloped and silver mills erected. Business of all kinds was active and\r\nprosperous and growing more so day by day.\r\n\r\nThe people were glad to have a legitimately constituted government, but\r\ndid not particularly enjoy having strangers from distant States put in\r\nauthority over them\xe2\x80\x94a sentiment that was natural enough. They thought\r\nthe officials should have been chosen from among themselves from among\r\nprominent citizens who had earned a right to such promotion, and who\r\nwould be in sympathy with the populace and likewise thoroughly\r\nacquainted with the needs of the Territory. They were right in viewing\r\nthe matter thus, without doubt. The new officers were \xe2\x80\x9cemigrants,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nthat was no title to anybody\xe2\x80\x99s affection or admiration either.\r\n\r\nThe new government was received with considerable coolness. It was not\r\nonly a foreign intruder, but a poor one. It was not even worth\r\nplucking\xe2\x80\x94except by the smallest of small fry office-seekers and such.\r\nEverybody knew that Congress had appropriated only twenty thousand\r\ndollars a year in greenbacks for its support\xe2\x80\x94about money enough to run a\r\nquartz mill a month. And everybody knew, also, that the first year\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmoney was still in Washington, and that the getting hold of it would be\r\na tedious and difficult process. Carson City was too wary and too wise\r\nto open up a credit account with the imported bantling with anything\r\nlike indecent haste.\r\n\r\nThere is something solemnly funny about the struggles of a new-born\r\nTerritorial government to get a start in this world. Ours had a trying\r\ntime of it. The Organic Act and the \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d from the State\r\nDepartment commanded that a legislature should be elected at such-and-\r\nsuch a time, and its sittings inaugurated at such-and-such a date. It\r\nwas easy to get legislators, even at three dollars a day, although board\r\nwas four dollars and fifty cents, for distinction has its charm in\r\nNevada as well as elsewhere, and there were plenty of patriotic souls\r\nout of employment; but to get a legislative hall for them to meet in was\r\nanother matter altogether. Carson blandly declined to give a room rent-\r\nfree, or let one to the government on credit.\r\n\r\nBut when Curry heard of the difficulty, he came forward, solitary and\r\nalone, and shouldered the Ship of State over the bar and got her afloat\r\nagain. I refer to \xe2\x80\x9cCurry\xe2\x80\x94_Old_ Curry\xe2\x80\x94Old _Abe_ Curry.\xe2\x80\x9d But for him the\r\nlegislature would have been obliged to sit in the desert. He offered his\r\nlarge stone building just outside the capital limits, rent-free, and it\r\nwas gladly accepted. Then he built a horse-railroad from town to the\r\ncapitol, and carried the legislators gratis.\r\n\r\nHe also furnished pine benches and chairs for the legislature, and\r\ncovered the floors with clean saw-dust by way of carpet and spittoon\r\ncombined. But for Curry the government would have died in its tender\r\ninfancy. A canvas partition to separate the Senate from the House of\r\nRepresentatives was put up by the Secretary, at a cost of three dollars\r\nand forty cents, but the United States declined to pay for it. Upon\r\nbeing reminded that the \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d permitted the payment of a\r\nliberal rent for a legislative hall, and that that money was saved to\r\nthe country by Mr. Curry\xe2\x80\x99s generosity, the United States said that did\r\nnot alter the matter, and the three dollars and forty cents would be\r\nsubtracted from the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s eighteen hundred dollar salary\xe2\x80\x94and it\r\nwas!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n188.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe matter of printing was from the beginning an interesting feature of\r\nthe new government\xe2\x80\x99s difficulties. The Secretary was sworn to obey his\r\nvolume of written \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions,\xe2\x80\x9d and these commanded him to do two\r\ncertain things without fail, viz.:\r\n\r\n1. Get the House and Senate journals printed; and, 2. For this work, pay\r\none dollar and fifty cents per \xe2\x80\x9cthousand\xe2\x80\x9d for composition, and one\r\ndollar and fifty cents per \xe2\x80\x9ctoken\xe2\x80\x9d for press-work, in greenbacks.\r\n\r\nIt was easy to swear to do these two things, but it was entirely\r\nimpossible to do more than one of them. When greenbacks had gone down to\r\nforty cents on the dollar, the prices regularly charged everybody by\r\nprinting establishments were one dollar and fifty cents per \xe2\x80\x9cthousand\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand one dollar and fifty cents per \xe2\x80\x9ctoken,\xe2\x80\x9d in _gold_. The\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d commanded that the Secretary regard a paper dollar issued\r\nby the government as equal to any other dollar issued by the government.\r\nHence the printing of the journals was discontinued. Then the United\r\nStates sternly rebuked the Secretary for disregarding the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cinstructions,\xe2\x80\x9d and warned him to correct his ways. Wherefore he got\r\nsome printing done, forwarded the bill to Washington with full exhibits\r\nof the high prices of things in the Territory, and called attention to a\r\nprinted market report wherein it would be observed that even hay was two\r\nhundred and fifty dollars a ton. The United States responded by\r\nsubtracting the printing- bill from the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s suffering salary\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nmoreover remarked with dense gravity that he would find nothing in his\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d requiring him to purchase hay!\r\n\r\nNothing in this world is palled in such impenetrable obscurity as a U.S.\r\nTreasury Comptroller\xe2\x80\x99s understanding. The very fires of the hereafter\r\ncould get up nothing more than a fitful glimmer in it. In the days I\r\nspeak of he never could be made to comprehend why it was that twenty\r\nthousand dollars would not go as far in Nevada, where all commodities\r\nranged at an enormous figure, as it would in the other Territories,\r\nwhere exceeding cheapness was the rule. He was an officer who looked out\r\nfor the little expenses all the time. The Secretary of the Territory\r\nkept his office in his bedroom, as I before remarked; and he charged the\r\nUnited States no rent, although his \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d provided for that\r\nitem and he could have justly taken advantage of it (a thing which I\r\nwould have done with more than lightning promptness if I had been\r\nSecretary myself). But the United States never applauded this devotion.\r\nIndeed, I think my country was ashamed to have so improvident a person\r\nin its employ.\r\n\r\nThose \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d (we used to read a chapter from them every morning,\r\nas intellectual gymnastics, and a couple of chapters in Sunday school\r\nevery Sabbath, for they treated of all subjects under the sun and had\r\nmuch valuable religious matter in them along with the other statistics)\r\nthose \xe2\x80\x9cinstructions\xe2\x80\x9d commanded that pen-knives, envelopes, pens and\r\nwriting-paper be furnished the members of the legislature. So the\r\nSecretary made the purchase and the distribution. The knives cost three\r\ndollars apiece. There was one too many, and the Secretary gave it to the\r\nClerk of the House of Representatives. The United States said the Clerk\r\nof the House was not a \xe2\x80\x9cmember\xe2\x80\x9d of the legislature, and took that three\r\ndollars out of the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s salary, as usual.\r\n\r\nWhite men charged three or four dollars a \xe2\x80\x9cload\xe2\x80\x9d for sawing up stove-\r\nwood. The Secretary was sagacious enough to know that the United States\r\nwould never pay any such price as that; so he got an Indian to saw up a\r\nload of office wood at one dollar and a half. He made out the usual\r\nvoucher, but signed no name to it\xe2\x80\x94simply appended a note explaining that\r\nan Indian had done the work, and had done it in a very capable and\r\nsatisfactory way, but could not sign the voucher owing to lack of\r\nability in the necessary direction. The Secretary had to pay that dollar\r\nand a half. He thought the United States would admire both his economy\r\nand his honesty in getting the work done at half price and not putting a\r\npretended Indian\xe2\x80\x99s signature to the voucher, but the United States did\r\nnot see it in that light.\r\n\r\nThe United States was too much accustomed to employing dollar-and-a-half\r\nthieves in all manner of official capacities to regard his explanation\r\nof the voucher as having any foundation in fact.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n190.jpg (22K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut the next time the Indian sawed wood for us I taught him to make a\r\ncross at the bottom of the voucher\xe2\x80\x94it looked like a cross that had been\r\ndrunk a year\xe2\x80\x94and then I \xe2\x80\x9cwitnessed\xe2\x80\x9d it and it went through all right.\r\nThe United States never said a word. I was sorry I had not made the\r\nvoucher for a thousand loads of wood instead of one.\r\n\r\nThe government of my country snubs honest simplicity but fondles\r\nartistic villainy, and I think I might have developed into a very\r\ncapable pickpocket if I had remained in the public service a year or\r\ntwo.\r\n\r\nThat was a fine collection of sovereigns, that first Nevada legislature.\r\nThey levied taxes to the amount of thirty or forty thousand dollars and\r\nordered expenditures to the extent of about a million. Yet they had\r\ntheir little periodical explosions of economy like all other bodies of\r\nthe kind. A member proposed to save three dollars a day to the nation by\r\ndispensing with the Chaplain. And yet that short-sighted man needed the\r\nChaplain more than any other member, perhaps, for he generally sat with\r\nhis feet on his desk, eating raw turnips, during the morning prayer.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n191.jpg (99K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe legislature sat sixty days, and passed private tollroad franchises\r\nall the time. When they adjourned it was estimated that every citizen\r\nowned about three franchises, and it was believed that unless Congress\r\ngave the Territory another degree of longitude there would not be room\r\nenough to accommodate the toll-roads. The ends of them were hanging over\r\nthe boundary line everywhere like a fringe.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n192.jpg (29K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe fact is, the freighting business had grown to such important\r\nproportions that there was nearly as much excitement over suddenly\r\nacquired toll-road fortunes as over the wonderful silver mines.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nBy and by I was smitten with the silver fever. \xe2\x80\x9cProspecting parties\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwere leaving for the mountains every day, and discovering and taking\r\npossession of rich silver-bearing lodes and ledges of quartz. Plainly\r\nthis was the road to fortune. The great \xe2\x80\x9cGould and Curry\xe2\x80\x9d mine was held\r\nat three or four hundred dollars a foot when we arrived; but in two\r\nmonths it had sprung up to eight hundred. The \xe2\x80\x9cOphir\xe2\x80\x9d had been worth\r\nonly a mere trifle, a year gone by, and now it was selling at nearly\r\n_four thousand dollars a foot_! Not a mine could be named that had not\r\nexperienced an astonishing advance in value within a short time.\r\nEverybody was talking about these marvels. Go where you would, you heard\r\nnothing else, from morning till far into the night. Tom So-and-So had\r\nsold out of the \xe2\x80\x9cAmanda Smith\xe2\x80\x9d for $40,000\xe2\x80\x94hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a cent when he \xe2\x80\x9ctook\r\nup\xe2\x80\x9d the ledge six months ago. John Jones had sold half his interest in\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cBald Eagle and Mary Ann\xe2\x80\x9d for $65,000, gold coin, and gone to the\r\nStates for his family. The widow Brewster had \xe2\x80\x9cstruck it rich\xe2\x80\x9d in the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGolden Fleece\xe2\x80\x9d and sold ten feet for $18,000\xe2\x80\x94hadn\xe2\x80\x99t money enough to buy\r\na crape bonnet when Sing-Sing Tommy killed her husband at Baldy\r\nJohnson\xe2\x80\x99s wake last spring. The \xe2\x80\x9cLast Chance\xe2\x80\x9d had found a \xe2\x80\x9cclay casing\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand knew they were \xe2\x80\x9cright on the ledge\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94consequence, \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d that went\r\nbegging yesterday were worth a brick house apiece to-day, and seedy\r\nowners who could not get trusted for a drink at any bar in the country\r\nyesterday were roaring drunk on champagne to-day and had hosts of warm\r\npersonal friends in a town where they had forgotten how to bow or shake\r\nhands from long-continued want of practice. Johnny Morgan, a common\r\nloafer, had gone to sleep in the gutter and waked up worth a hundred\r\nthousand dollars, in consequence of the decision in the \xe2\x80\x9cLady Franklin\r\nand Rough and Ready\xe2\x80\x9d lawsuit. And so on\xe2\x80\x94day in and day out the talk\r\npelted our ears and the excitement waxed hotter and hotter around us.\r\n\r\nI would have been more or less than human if I had not gone mad like the\r\nrest. Cart-loads of solid silver bricks, as large as pigs of lead, were\r\narriving from the mills every day, and such sights as that gave\r\nsubstance to the wild talk about me. I succumbed and grew as frenzied as\r\nthe craziest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n194.jpg (65K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEvery few days news would come of the discovery of a bran-new mining\r\nregion; immediately the papers would teem with accounts of its richness,\r\nand away the surplus population would scamper to take possession. By the\r\ntime I was fairly inoculated with the disease, \xe2\x80\x9cEsmeralda\xe2\x80\x9d had just had\r\na run and \xe2\x80\x9cHumboldt\xe2\x80\x9d was beginning to shriek for attention. \xe2\x80\x9cHumboldt!\r\nHumboldt!\xe2\x80\x9d was the new cry, and straightway Humboldt, the newest of the\r\nnew, the richest of the rich, the most marvellous of the marvellous\r\ndiscoveries in silver-land was occupying two columns of the public\r\nprints to \xe2\x80\x9cEsmeralda\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d one. I was just on the point of starting to\r\nEsmeralda, but turned with the tide and got ready for Humboldt. That the\r\nreader may see what moved me, and what would as surely have moved him\r\nhad he been there, I insert here one of the newspaper letters of the\r\nday. It and several other letters from the same calm hand were the main\r\nmeans of converting me. I shall not garble the extract, but put it in\r\njust as it appeared in the _Daily Territorial Enterprise_:\r\n\r\nBut what about our mines? I shall be candid with you. I shall express an\r\nhonest opinion, based upon a thorough examination. Humboldt county is\r\nthe richest mineral region upon God\xe2\x80\x99s footstool. Each mountain range is\r\ngorged with the precious ores. Humboldt is the true Golconda.\r\n\r\nThe other day an assay of mere croppings yielded exceeding four thousand\r\ndollars to the ton. A week or two ago an assay of just such surface\r\ndevelopments made returns of seven thousand dollars to the ton. Our\r\nmountains are full of rambling prospectors. Each day and almost every\r\nhour reveals new and more startling evidences of the profuse and\r\nintensified wealth of our favored county. The metal is not silver alone.\r\nThere are distinct ledges of auriferous ore. A late discovery plainly\r\nevinces cinnabar. The coarser metals are in gross abundance. Lately\r\nevidences of bituminous coal have been detected. My theory has ever been\r\nthat coal is a ligneous formation. I told Col. Whitman, in times past,\r\nthat the neighborhood of Dayton (Nevada) betrayed no present or previous\r\nmanifestations of a ligneous foundation, and that hence I had no\r\nconfidence in his lauded coal mines. I repeated the same doctrine to the\r\nexultant coal discoverers of Humboldt. I talked with my friend Captain\r\nBurch on the subject. My pyrhanism vanished upon his statement that in\r\nthe very region referred to he had seen petrified trees of the length of\r\ntwo hundred feet. Then is the fact established that huge forests once\r\ncast their grim shadows over this remote section. I am firm in the coal\r\nfaith. Have no fears of the mineral resources of Humboldt county. They\r\nare immense\xe2\x80\x94incalculable.\r\n\r\nLet me state one or two things which will help the reader to better\r\ncomprehend certain items in the above. At this time, our near neighbor,\r\nGold Hill, was the most successful silver mining locality in Nevada. It\r\nwas from there that more than half the daily shipments of silver bricks\r\ncame. \xe2\x80\x9cVery rich\xe2\x80\x9d (and scarce) Gold Hill ore yielded from $100 to $400\r\nto the ton; but the usual yield was only $20 to $40 per ton\xe2\x80\x94that is to\r\nsay, each hundred pounds of ore yielded from one dollar to two dollars.\r\nBut the reader will perceive by the above extract, that in Humboldt from\r\none fourth to nearly half the mass was silver! That is to say, every one\r\nhundred pounds of the ore had from two hundred dollars up to about three\r\nhundred and fifty in it. Some days later this same correspondent wrote:\r\n\r\nI have spoken of the vast and almost fabulous wealth of this region\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nis incredible. The intestines of our mountains are gorged with precious\r\nore to plethora. I have said that nature has so shaped our mountains as\r\nto furnish most excellent facilities for the working of our mines. I\r\nhave also told you that the country about here is pregnant with the\r\nfinest mill sites in the world. But what is the mining history of\r\nHumboldt? The Sheba mine is in the hands of energetic San Francisco\r\ncapitalists. It would seem that the ore is combined with metals that\r\nrender it difficult of reduction with our imperfect mountain machinery.\r\nThe proprietors have combined the capital and labor hinted at in my\r\nexordium. They are toiling and probing. Their tunnel has reached the\r\nlength of one hundred feet. From primal assays alone, coupled with the\r\ndevelopment of the mine and public confidence in the continuance of\r\neffort, the stock had reared itself to eight hundred dollars market\r\nvalue. I do not know that one ton of the ore has been converted into\r\ncurrent metal. I do know that there are many lodes in this section that\r\nsurpass the Sheba in primal assay value. Listen a moment to the\r\ncalculations of the Sheba operators. They purpose transporting the ore\r\nconcentrated to Europe. The conveyance from Star City (its locality) to\r\nVirginia City will cost seventy dollars per ton; from Virginia to San\r\nFrancisco, forty dollars per ton; from thence to Liverpool, its\r\ndestination, ten dollars per ton. Their idea is that its conglomerate\r\nmetals will reimburse them their cost of original extraction, the price\r\nof transportation, and the expense of reduction, and that then a ton of\r\nthe raw ore will net them twelve hundred dollars. The estimate may be\r\nextravagant. Cut it in twain, and the product is enormous, far\r\ntranscending any previous developments of our racy Territory.\r\n\r\nA very common calculation is that many of our mines will yield five\r\nhundred dollars to the ton. Such fecundity throws the Gould & Curry, the\r\nOphir and the Mexican, of your neighborhood, in the darkest shadow. I\r\nhave given you the estimate of the value of a single developed mine. Its\r\nrichness is indexed by its market valuation. The people of Humboldt\r\ncounty are feet crazy. As I write, our towns are near deserted. They\r\nlook as languid as a consumptive girl. What has become of our sinewy and\r\nathletic fellow-citizens? They are coursing through ravines and over\r\nmountain tops. Their tracks are visible in every direction. Occasionally\r\na horseman will dash among us. His steed betrays hard usage. He alights\r\nbefore his adobe dwelling, hastily exchanges courtesies with his\r\ntownsmen, hurries to an assay office and from thence to the District\r\nRecorder\xe2\x80\x99s. In the morning, having renewed his provisional supplies, he\r\nis off again on his wild and unbeaten route. Why, the fellow numbers\r\nalready his feet by the thousands. He is the horse-leech. He has the\r\ncraving stomach of the shark or anaconda. He would conquer metallic\r\nworlds.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n196.jpg (187K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThis was enough. The instant we had finished reading the above article,\r\nfour of us decided to go to Humboldt. We commenced getting ready at\r\nonce. And we also commenced upbraiding ourselves for not deciding\r\nsooner\xe2\x80\x94for we were in terror lest all the rich mines would be found and\r\nsecured before we got there, and we might have to put up with ledges\r\nthat would not yield more than two or three hundred dollars a ton,\r\nmaybe. An hour before, I would have felt opulent if I had owned ten feet\r\nin a Gold Hill mine whose ore produced twenty-five dollars to the ton;\r\nnow I was already annoyed at the prospect of having to put up with mines\r\nthe poorest of which would be a marvel in Gold Hill.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nHurry, was the word! We wasted no time. Our party consisted of four\r\npersons\xe2\x80\x94a blacksmith sixty years of age, two young lawyers, and myself.\r\nWe bought a wagon and two miserable old horses. We put eighteen hundred\r\npounds of provisions and mining tools in the wagon and drove out of\r\nCarson on a chilly December afternoon. The horses were so weak and old\r\nthat we soon found that it would be better if one or two of us got out\r\nand walked. It was an improvement. Next, we found that it would be\r\nbetter if a third man got out. That was an improvement also. It was at\r\nthis time that I volunteered to drive, although I had never driven a\r\nharnessed horse before and many a man in such a position would have felt\r\nfairly excused from such a responsibility. But in a little while it was\r\nfound that it would be a fine thing if the drive got out and walked\r\nalso. It was at this time that I resigned the position of driver, and\r\nnever resumed it again. Within the hour, we found that it would not only\r\nbe better, but was absolutely necessary, that we four, taking turns, two\r\nat a time, should put our hands against the end of the wagon and push it\r\nthrough the sand, leaving the feeble horses little to do but keep out of\r\nthe way and hold up the tongue. Perhaps it is well for one to know his\r\nfate at first, and get reconciled to it. We had learned ours in one\r\nafternoon. It was plain that we had to walk through the sand and shove\r\nthat wagon and those horses two hundred miles. So we accepted the\r\nsituation, and from that time forth we never rode. More than that, we\r\nstood regular and nearly constant watches pushing up behind.\r\n\r\nWe made seven miles, and camped in the desert. Young Clagett (now member\r\nof Congress from Montana) unharnessed and fed and watered the horses;\r\nOliphant and I cut sagebrush, built the fire and brought water to cook\r\nwith; and old Mr. Ballou the blacksmith did the cooking. This division\r\nof labor, and this appointment, was adhered to throughout the journey.\r\nWe had no tent, and so we slept under our blankets in the open plain. We\r\nwere so tired that we slept soundly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n199.jpg (54K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe were fifteen days making the trip\xe2\x80\x94two hundred miles; thirteen,\r\nrather, for we lay by a couple of days, in one place, to let the horses\r\nrest.\r\n\r\nWe could really have accomplished the journey in ten days if we had\r\ntowed the horses behind the wagon, but we did not think of that until it\r\nwas too late, and so went on shoving the horses and the wagon too when\r\nwe might have saved half the labor. Parties who met us, occasionally,\r\nadvised us to put the _horses_ in the wagon, but Mr. Ballou, through\r\nwhose iron-clad earnestness no sarcasm could pierce, said that that\r\nwould not do, because the provisions were exposed and would suffer, the\r\nhorses being \xe2\x80\x9cbituminous from long deprivation.\xe2\x80\x9d The reader will excuse\r\nme from translating. What Mr. Ballou customarily meant, when he used a\r\nlong word, was a secret between himself and his Maker. He was one of the\r\nbest and kindest hearted men that ever graced a humble sphere of life.\r\nHe was gentleness and simplicity itself\xe2\x80\x94and unselfishness, too. Although\r\nhe was more than twice as old as the eldest of us, he never gave himself\r\nany airs, privileges, or exemptions on that account.
