He did a _young_\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s share of the work; and did his share of conversing and\r\nentertaining from the general stand-point of any age\xe2\x80\x94not from the\r\narrogant, overawing summit-height of sixty years. His one striking\r\npeculiarity was his Partingtonian fashion of loving and using big words\r\n_for their own sakes_, and independent of any bearing they might have\r\nupon the thought he was purposing to convey. He always let his ponderous\r\nsyllables fall with an easy unconsciousness that left them wholly\r\nwithout offensiveness. In truth his air was so natural and so simple\r\nthat one was always catching himself accepting his stately sentences as\r\nmeaning something, when they really meant nothing in the world. If a\r\nword was long and grand and resonant, that was sufficient to win the old\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s love, and he would drop that word into the most out-of-the-way\r\nplace in a sentence or a subject, and be as pleased with it as if it\r\nwere perfectly luminous with meaning.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n201.jpg (62K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe four always spread our common stock of blankets together on the\r\nfrozen ground, and slept side by side; and finding that our foolish,\r\nlong-legged hound pup had a deal of animal heat in him, Oliphant got to\r\nadmitting him to the bed, between himself and Mr. Ballou, hugging the\r\ndog\xe2\x80\x99s warm back to his breast and finding great comfort in it. But in\r\nthe night the pup would get stretchy and brace his feet against the old\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s back and shove, grunting complacently the while; and now and then,\r\nbeing warm and snug, grateful and happy, he would paw the old man\xe2\x80\x99s back\r\nsimply in excess of comfort; and at yet other times he would dream of\r\nthe chase and in his sleep tug at the old man\xe2\x80\x99s back hair and bark in\r\nhis ear. The old gentleman complained mildly about these familiarities,\r\nat last, and when he got through with his statement he said that such a\r\ndog as that was not a proper animal to admit to bed with tired men,\r\nbecause he was \xe2\x80\x9cso meretricious in his movements and so organic in his\r\nemotions.\xe2\x80\x9d We turned the dog out.\r\n\r\nIt was a hard, wearing, toilsome journey, but it had its bright side;\r\nfor after each day was done and our wolfish hunger appeased with a hot\r\nsupper of fried bacon, bread, molasses and black coffee, the pipe-\r\nsmoking, song- singing and yarn-spinning around the evening camp-fire in\r\nthe still solitudes of the desert was a happy, care-free sort of\r\nrecreation that seemed the very summit and culmination of earthly\r\nluxury.\r\n\r\nIt is a kind of life that has a potent charm for all men, whether city\r\nor country-bred. We are descended from desert-lounging Arabs, and\r\ncountless ages of growth toward perfect civilization have failed to root\r\nout of us the nomadic instinct. We all confess to a gratified thrill at\r\nthe thought of \xe2\x80\x9ccamping out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnce we made twenty-five miles in a day, and once we made forty miles\r\n(through the Great American Desert), and ten miles beyond\xe2\x80\x94fifty in\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94in twenty-three hours, without halting to eat, drink or rest. To\r\nstretch out and go to sleep, even on stony and frozen ground, after\r\npushing a wagon and two horses fifty miles, is a delight so supreme that\r\nfor the moment it almost seems cheap at the price.\r\n\r\nWe camped two days in the neighborhood of the \xe2\x80\x9cSink of the Humboldt.\xe2\x80\x9d We\r\ntried to use the strong alkaline water of the Sink, but it would not\r\nanswer. It was like drinking lye, and not weak lye, either. It left a\r\ntaste in the mouth, bitter and every way execrable, and a burning in the\r\nstomach that was very uncomfortable. We put molasses in it, but that\r\nhelped it very little; we added a pickle, yet the alkali was the\r\nprominent taste and so it was unfit for drinking.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n202.jpg (58K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe coffee we made of this water was the meanest compound man has yet\r\ninvented. It was really viler to the taste than the unameliorated water\r\nitself. Mr. Ballou, being the architect and builder of the beverage felt\r\nconstrained to endorse and uphold it, and so drank half a cup, by little\r\nsips, making shift to praise it faintly the while, but finally threw out\r\nthe remainder, and said frankly it was \xe2\x80\x9ctoo technical for _him_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut presently we found a spring of fresh water, convenient, and then,\r\nwith nothing to mar our enjoyment, and no stragglers to interrupt it, we\r\nentered into our rest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter leaving the Sink, we traveled along the Humboldt river a little\r\nway. People accustomed to the monster mile-wide Mississippi, grow\r\naccustomed to associating the term \xe2\x80\x9criver\xe2\x80\x9d with a high degree of watery\r\ngrandeur. Consequently, such people feel rather disappointed when they\r\nstand on the shores of the Humboldt or the Carson and find that a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9criver\xe2\x80\x9d in Nevada is a sickly rivulet which is just the counterpart of\r\nthe Erie canal in all respects save that the canal is twice as long and\r\nfour times as deep. One of the pleasantest and most invigorating\r\nexercises one can contrive is to run and jump across the Humboldt river\r\ntill he is overheated, and then drink it dry.\r\n\r\nOn the fifteenth day we completed our march of two hundred miles and\r\nentered Unionville, Humboldt county, in the midst of a driving snow-\r\nstorm. Unionville consisted of eleven cabins and a liberty-pole. Six of\r\nthe cabins were strung along one side of a deep canyon, and the other\r\nfive faced them. The rest of the landscape was made up of bleak mountain\r\nwalls that rose so high into the sky from both sides of the canyon that\r\nthe village was left, as it were, far down in the bottom of a crevice.\r\nIt was always daylight on the mountain tops a long time before the\r\ndarkness lifted and revealed Unionville.\r\n\r\nWe built a small, rude cabin in the side of the crevice and roofed it\r\nwith canvas, leaving a corner open to serve as a chimney, through which\r\nthe cattle used to tumble occasionally, at night, and mash our furniture\r\nand interrupt our sleep. It was very cold weather and fuel was scarce.\r\nIndians brought brush and bushes several miles on their backs; and when\r\nwe could catch a laden Indian it was well\xe2\x80\x94and when we could not (which\r\nwas the rule, not the exception), we shivered and bore it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n205.jpg (58K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI confess, without shame, that I expected to find masses of silver lying\r\nall about the ground. I expected to see it glittering in the sun on the\r\nmountain summits. I said nothing about this, for some instinct told me\r\nthat I might possibly have an exaggerated idea about it, and so if I\r\nbetrayed my thought I might bring derision upon myself. Yet I was as\r\nperfectly satisfied in my own mind as I could be of anything, that I was\r\ngoing to gather up, in a day or two, or at furthest a week or two,\r\nsilver enough to make me satisfactorily wealthy\xe2\x80\x94and so my fancy was\r\nalready busy with plans for spending this money. The first opportunity\r\nthat offered, I sauntered carelessly away from the cabin, keeping an eye\r\non the other boys, and stopping and contemplating the sky when they\r\nseemed to be observing me; but as soon as the coast was manifestly\r\nclear, I fled away as guiltily as a thief might have done and never\r\nhalted till I was far beyond sight and call. Then I began my search with\r\na feverish excitement that was brimful of expectation\xe2\x80\x94almost of\r\ncertainty. I crawled about the ground, seizing and examining bits of\r\nstone, blowing the dust from them or rubbing them on my clothes, and\r\nthen peering at them with anxious hope. Presently I found a bright\r\nfragment and my heart bounded! I hid behind a boulder and polished it\r\nand scrutinized it with a nervous eagerness and a delight that was more\r\npronounced than absolute certainty itself could have afforded. The more\r\nI examined the fragment the more I was convinced that I had found the\r\ndoor to fortune. I marked the spot and carried away my specimen. Up and\r\ndown the rugged mountain side I searched, with always increasing\r\ninterest and always augmenting gratitude that I had come to Humboldt and\r\ncome in time. Of all the experiences of my life, this secret search\r\namong the hidden treasures of silver-land was the nearest to unmarred\r\necstasy. It was a delirious revel.\r\n\r\nBy and by, in the bed of a shallow rivulet, I found a deposit of shining\r\nyellow scales, and my breath almost forsook me! A gold mine, and in my\r\nsimplicity I had been content with vulgar silver! I was so excited that\r\nI half believed my overwrought imagination was deceiving me. Then a fear\r\ncame upon me that people might be observing me and would guess my\r\nsecret. Moved by this thought, I made a circuit of the place, and\r\nascended a knoll to reconnoiter. Solitude. No creature was near. Then I\r\nreturned to my mine, fortifying myself against possible disappointment,\r\nbut my fears were groundless\xe2\x80\x94the shining scales were still there. I set\r\nabout scooping them out, and for an hour I toiled down the windings of\r\nthe stream and robbed its bed. But at last the descending sun warned me\r\nto give up the quest, and I turned homeward laden with wealth. As I\r\nwalked along I could not help smiling at the thought of my being so\r\nexcited over my fragment of silver when a nobler metal was almost under\r\nmy nose. In this little time the former had so fallen in my estimation\r\nthat once or twice I was on the point of throwing it away.\r\n\r\nThe boys were as hungry as usual, but I could eat nothing. Neither could\r\nI talk. I was full of dreams and far away. Their conversation\r\ninterrupted the flow of my fancy somewhat, and annoyed me a little, too.\r\nI despised the sordid and commonplace things they talked about. But as\r\nthey proceeded, it began to amuse me. It grew to be rare fun to hear\r\nthem planning their poor little economies and sighing over possible\r\nprivations and distresses when a gold mine, all our own, lay within\r\nsight of the cabin and I could point it out at any moment. Smothered\r\nhilarity began to oppress me, presently. It was hard to resist the\r\nimpulse to burst out with exultation and reveal everything; but I did\r\nresist. I said within myself that I would filter the great news through\r\nmy lips calmly and be serene as a summer morning while I watched its\r\neffect in their faces. I said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere have you all been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProspecting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you find?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing? What do you think of the country?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t tell, yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Ballou, who was an old gold miner, and had\r\nlikewise had considerable experience among the silver mines.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you formed any sort of opinion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a sort of a one. It\xe2\x80\x99s fair enough here, may be, but overrated.\r\nSeven thousand dollar ledges are scarce, though.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat Sheba may be rich enough, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t own it; and besides, the\r\nrock is so full of base metals that all the science in the world can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwork it. We\xe2\x80\x99ll not starve, here, but we\xe2\x80\x99ll not get rich, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you think the prospect is pretty poor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo name for it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99d better go back, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, not yet\xe2\x80\x94of course not. We\xe2\x80\x99ll try it a riffle, first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose, now\xe2\x80\x94this is merely a supposition, you know\xe2\x80\x94suppose you could\r\nfind a ledge that would yield, say, a hundred and fifty dollars a\r\nton\xe2\x80\x94would _that_ satisfy you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry us once!\xe2\x80\x9d from the whole party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr suppose\xe2\x80\x94merely a supposition, of course\xe2\x80\x94suppose you were to find a\r\nledge that would yield two thousand dollars a ton\xe2\x80\x94would that satisfy\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x94what do you mean? What are you coming at? Is there some mystery\r\nbehind all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind. I am not saying anything. You know perfectly well there are\r\nno rich mines here\xe2\x80\x94of course you do. Because you have been around and\r\nexamined for yourselves. Anybody would know that, that had been around.\r\nBut just for the sake of argument, suppose\xe2\x80\x94in a kind of general\r\nway\xe2\x80\x94suppose some person were to tell you that two-thousand-dollar ledges\r\nwere simply contemptible\xe2\x80\x94contemptible, understand\xe2\x80\x94and that right yonder\r\nin sight of this very cabin there were piles of pure gold and pure\r\nsilver\xe2\x80\x94oceans of it\xe2\x80\x94enough to make you all rich in twenty-four hours!\r\nCome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should say he was as crazy as a loon!\xe2\x80\x9d said old Ballou, but wild with\r\nexcitement, nevertheless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything\xe2\x80\x94_I_ haven\xe2\x80\x99t been around, you\r\nknow, and of course don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything\xe2\x80\x94but all I ask of you is to cast\r\nyour eye on _that_, for instance, and tell me what you think of it!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nI tossed my treasure before them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n207.jpg (92K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was an eager scramble for it, and a closing of heads together over\r\nit under the candle-light. Then old Ballou said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink of it? I think it is nothing but a lot of granite rubbish and\r\nnasty glittering mica that isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth ten cents an acre!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo vanished my dream. So melted my wealth away. So toppled my airy\r\ncastle to the earth and left me stricken and forlorn.\r\n\r\nMoralizing, I observed, then, that \xe2\x80\x9call that glitters is not gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Ballou said I could go further than that, and lay it up among my\r\ntreasures of knowledge, that _nothing_ that glitters is gold. So I\r\nlearned then, once for all, that gold in its native state is but dull,\r\nunornamental stuff, and that only low-born metals excite the admiration\r\nof the ignorant with an ostentatious glitter. However, like the rest of\r\nthe world, I still go on underrating men of gold and glorifying men of\r\nmica. Commonplace human nature cannot rise above that.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nTrue knowledge of the nature of silver mining came fast enough. We went\r\nout \xe2\x80\x9cprospecting\xe2\x80\x9d with Mr. Ballou. We climbed the mountain sides, and\r\nclambered among sage-brush, rocks and snow till we were ready to drop\r\nwith exhaustion, but found no silver\xe2\x80\x94nor yet any gold. Day after day we\r\ndid this. Now and then we came upon holes burrowed a few feet into the\r\ndeclivities and apparently abandoned; and now and then we found one or\r\ntwo listless men still burrowing. But there was no appearance of silver.\r\nThese holes were the beginnings of tunnels, and the purpose was to drive\r\nthem hundreds of feet into the mountain, and some day tap the hidden\r\nledge where the silver was. Some day! It seemed far enough away, and\r\nvery hopeless and dreary. Day after day we toiled, and climbed and\r\nsearched, and we younger partners grew sicker and still sicker of the\r\npromiseless toil. At last we halted under a beetling rampart of rock\r\nwhich projected from the earth high upon the mountain. Mr. Ballou broke\r\noff some fragments with a hammer, and examined them long and attentively\r\nwith a small eye-glass; threw them away and broke off more; said this\r\nrock was quartz, and quartz was the sort of rock that contained silver.\r\n_Contained_ it! I had thought that at least it would be caked on the\r\noutside of it like a kind of veneering. He still broke off pieces and\r\ncritically examined them, now and then wetting the piece with his tongue\r\nand applying the glass. At last he exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n210.jpg (74K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe were full of anxiety in a moment. The rock was clean and white, where\r\nit was broken, and across it ran a ragged thread of blue. He said that\r\nthat little thread had silver in it, mixed with base metal, such as lead\r\nand antimony, and other rubbish, and that there was a speck or two of\r\ngold visible. After a great deal of effort we managed to discern some\r\nlittle fine yellow specks, and judged that a couple of tons of them\r\nmassed together might make a gold dollar, possibly. We were not\r\njubilant, but Mr. Ballou said there were worse ledges in the world than\r\nthat. He saved what he called the \xe2\x80\x9crichest\xe2\x80\x9d piece of the rock, in order\r\nto determine its value by the process called the \xe2\x80\x9cfire-assay.\xe2\x80\x9d Then we\r\nnamed the mine \xe2\x80\x9cMonarch of the Mountains\xe2\x80\x9d (modesty of nomenclature is\r\nnot a prominent feature in the mines), and Mr. Ballou wrote out and\r\nstuck up the following \xe2\x80\x9cnotice,\xe2\x80\x9d preserving a copy to be entered upon\r\nthe books in the mining recorder\xe2\x80\x99s office in the town.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNOTICE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe the undersigned claim three claims, of three hundred feet each (and\r\none for discovery), on this silver-bearing quartz lead or lode,\r\nextending north and south from this notice, with all its dips, spurs,\r\nand angles, variations and sinuosities, together with fifty feet of\r\nground on either side for working the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe put our names to it and tried to feel that our fortunes were made.\r\nBut when we talked the matter all over with Mr. Ballou, we felt\r\ndepressed and dubious. He said that this surface quartz was not all\r\nthere was of our mine; but that the wall or ledge of rock called the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonarch of the Mountains,\xe2\x80\x9d extended down hundreds and hundreds of feet\r\ninto the earth\xe2\x80\x94he illustrated by saying it was like a curb-stone, and\r\nmaintained a nearly uniform thickness\xe2\x80\x94say twenty feet\xe2\x80\x94away down into the\r\nbowels of the earth, and was perfectly distinct from the casing rock on\r\neach side of it; and that it kept to itself, and maintained its\r\ndistinctive character always, no matter how deep it extended into the\r\nearth or how far it stretched itself through and across the hills and\r\nvalleys. He said it might be a mile deep and ten miles long, for all we\r\nknew; and that wherever we bored into it above ground or below, we would\r\nfind gold and silver in it, but no gold or silver in the meaner rock it\r\nwas cased between. And he said that down in the great depths of the\r\nledge was its richness, and the deeper it went the richer it grew.\r\nTherefore, instead of working here on the surface, we must either bore\r\ndown into the rock with a shaft till we came to where it was rich\xe2\x80\x94say a\r\nhundred feet or so\xe2\x80\x94or else we must go down into the valley and bore a\r\nlong tunnel into the mountain side and tap the ledge far under the\r\nearth. To do either was plainly the labor of months; for we could blast\r\nand bore only a few feet a day\xe2\x80\x94some five or six. But this was not all.\r\nHe said that after we got the ore out it must be hauled in wagons to a\r\ndistant silver-mill, ground up, and the silver extracted by a tedious\r\nand costly process. Our fortune seemed a century away!\r\n\r\nBut we went to work. We decided to sink a shaft. So, for a week we\r\nclimbed the mountain, laden with picks, drills, gads, crowbars, shovels,\r\ncans of blasting powder and coils of fuse and strove with might and\r\nmain. At first the rock was broken and loose and we dug it up with picks\r\nand threw it out with shovels, and the hole progressed very well. But\r\nthe rock became more compact, presently, and gads and crowbars came into\r\nplay. But shortly nothing could make an impression but blasting powder.\r\n\r\nThat was the weariest work! One of us held the iron drill in its place\r\nand another would strike with an eight-pound sledge\xe2\x80\x94it was like driving\r\nnails on a large scale. In the course of an hour or two the drill would\r\nreach a depth of two or three feet, making a hole a couple of inches in\r\ndiameter. We would put in a charge of powder, insert half a yard of\r\nfuse, pour in sand and gravel and ram it down, then light the fuse and\r\nrun. When the explosion came and the rocks and smoke shot into the air,\r\nwe would go back and find about a bushel of that hard, rebellious quartz\r\njolted out. Nothing more. One week of this satisfied me. I resigned.\r\nClagget and Oliphant followed. Our shaft was only twelve feet deep. We\r\ndecided that a tunnel was the thing we wanted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n212.jpg (89K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSo we went down the mountain side and worked a week; at the end of which\r\ntime we had blasted a tunnel about deep enough to hide a hogshead in,\r\nand judged that about nine hundred feet more of it would reach the\r\nledge. I resigned again, and the other boys only held out one day\r\nlonger. We decided that a tunnel was not what we wanted. We wanted a\r\nledge that was already \xe2\x80\x9cdeveloped.\xe2\x80\x9d There were none in the camp.\r\n\r\nWe dropped the \xe2\x80\x9cMonarch\xe2\x80\x9d for the time being.\r\n\r\nMeantime the camp was filling up with people, and there was a constantly\r\ngrowing excitement about our Humboldt mines. We fell victims to the\r\nepidemic and strained every nerve to acquire more \xe2\x80\x9cfeet.\xe2\x80\x9d We prospected\r\nand took up new claims, put \xe2\x80\x9cnotices\xe2\x80\x9d on them and gave them\r\ngrandiloquent names. We traded some of our \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d for \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d in other\r\npeople\xe2\x80\x99s claims. In a little while we owned largely in the \xe2\x80\x9cGray Eagle,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cColumbiana,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cBranch Mint,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cMaria Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cUniverse,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cRoot-Hog-or-Die,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cSamson and Delilah,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cTreasure Trove,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cGolconda,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cSultana,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cBoomerang,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cGreat Republic,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cGrand Mogul,\xe2\x80\x9d and fifty other \xe2\x80\x9cmines\xe2\x80\x9d that had never been molested\r\nby a shovel or scratched with a pick. We had not less than thirty\r\nthousand \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d apiece in the \xe2\x80\x9crichest mines on earth\xe2\x80\x9d as the frenzied\r\ncant phrased it\xe2\x80\x94and were in debt to the butcher. We were stark mad with\r\nexcitement\xe2\x80\x94drunk with happiness\xe2\x80\x94smothered under mountains of prospective\r\nwealth\xe2\x80\x94arrogantly compassionate toward the plodding millions who knew\r\nnot our marvellous canyon\xe2\x80\x94but our credit was not good at the grocer\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nIt was the strangest phase of life one can imagine. It was a beggars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrevel. There was nothing doing in the district\xe2\x80\x94no mining\xe2\x80\x94no milling\xe2\x80\x94no\r\nproductive effort\xe2\x80\x94no income\xe2\x80\x94and not enough money in the entire camp to\r\nbuy a corner lot in an eastern village, hardly; and yet a stranger would\r\nhave supposed he was walking among bloated millionaires. Prospecting\r\nparties swarmed out of town with the first flush of dawn, and swarmed in\r\nagain at nightfall laden with spoil\xe2\x80\x94rocks. Nothing but rocks. Every\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s pockets were full of them; the floor of his cabin was littered\r\nwith them; they were disposed in labeled rows on his shelves.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n214.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXX.\r\n\r\n\r\nI met men at every turn who owned from one thousand to thirty thousand\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d in undeveloped silver mines, every single foot of which they\r\nbelieved would shortly be worth from fifty to a thousand dollars\xe2\x80\x94and as\r\noften as any other way they were men who had not twenty-five dollars in\r\nthe world. Every man you met had his new mine to boast of, and his\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cspecimens\xe2\x80\x9d ready; and if the opportunity offered, he would infallibly\r\nback you into a corner and offer as a favor to you, not to him, to part\r\nwith just a few feet in the \xe2\x80\x9cGolden Age,\xe2\x80\x9d or the \xe2\x80\x9cSarah Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d or some\r\nother unknown stack of croppings, for money enough to get a \xe2\x80\x9csquare\r\nmeal\xe2\x80\x9d with, as the phrase went. And you were never to reveal that he had\r\nmade you the offer at such a ruinous price, for it was only out of\r\nfriendship for you that he was willing to make the sacrifice. Then he\r\nwould fish a piece of rock out of his pocket, and after looking\r\nmysteriously around as if he feared he might be waylaid and robbed if\r\ncaught with such wealth in his possession, he would dab the rock against\r\nhis tongue, clap an eyeglass to it, and exclaim:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at that! Right there in that red dirt! See it? See the specks of\r\ngold? And the streak of silver? That\xe2\x80\x99s from the \xe2\x80\x98Uncle Abe.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nhundred thousand tons like that in sight! Right in sight, mind you! And\r\nwhen we get down on it and the ledge comes in solid, it will be the\r\nrichest thing in the world! Look at the assay! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to\r\nbelieve _me_\xe2\x80\x94look at the assay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n216.jpg (63K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen he would get out a greasy sheet of paper which showed that the\r\nportion of rock assayed had given evidence of containing silver and gold\r\nin the proportion of so many hundreds or thousands of dollars to the\r\nton.\r\n\r\nI little knew, then, that the custom was to hunt out the _richest_ piece\r\nof rock and get it assayed! Very often, that piece, the size of a\r\nfilbert, was the only fragment in a ton that had a particle of metal in\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94and yet the assay made it pretend to represent the average value of\r\nthe ton of rubbish it came from!\r\n\r\nOn such a system of assaying as that, the Humboldt world had gone crazy.\r\nOn the authority of such assays its newspaper correspondents were\r\nfrothing about rock worth four and seven thousand dollars a ton!\r\n\r\nAnd does the reader remember, a few pages back, the calculations, of a\r\nquoted correspondent, whereby the ore is to be mined and shipped all the\r\nway to England, the metals extracted, and the gold and silver contents\r\nreceived back by the miners as clear profit, the copper, antimony and\r\nother things in the ore being sufficient to pay all the expenses\r\nincurred? Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s head was full of such \xe2\x80\x9ccalculations\xe2\x80\x9d as those\xe2\x80\x94such\r\nraving insanity, rather. Few people took _work_ into their\r\ncalculations\xe2\x80\x94or outlay of money either; except the work and expenditures\r\nof other people.\r\n\r\nWe never touched our tunnel or our shaft again. Why? Because we judged\r\nthat we had learned the _real_ secret of success in silver mining\xe2\x80\x94which\r\nwas, _not_ to mine the silver ourselves by the sweat of our brows and\r\nthe labor of our hands, but to _sell_ the ledges to the dull slaves of\r\ntoil and let them do the mining!\r\n\r\nBefore leaving Carson, the Secretary and I had purchased \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d from\r\nvarious Esmeralda stragglers. We had expected immediate returns of\r\nbullion, but were only afflicted with regular and constant \xe2\x80\x9cassessments\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninstead\xe2\x80\x94demands for money wherewith to develop the said mines. These\r\nassessments had grown so oppressive that it seemed necessary to look\r\ninto the matter personally. Therefore I projected a pilgrimage to Carson\r\nand thence to Esmeralda. I bought a horse and started, in company with\r\nMr. Ballou and a gentleman named Ollendorff, a Prussian\xe2\x80\x94not the party\r\nwho has inflicted so much suffering on the world with his wretched\r\nforeign grammars, with their interminable repetitions of questions which\r\nnever have occurred and are never likely to occur in any conversation\r\namong human beings. We rode through a snow-storm for two or three days,\r\nand arrived at \xe2\x80\x9cHoney Lake Smith\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d a sort of isolated inn on the\r\nCarson river. It was a two-story log house situated on a small knoll in\r\nthe midst of the vast basin or desert through which the sickly Carson\r\nwinds its melancholy way. Close to the house were the Overland stage\r\nstables, built of sun-dried bricks. There was not another building\r\nwithin several leagues of the place. Towards sunset about twenty hay-\r\nwagons arrived and camped around the house and all the teamsters came in\r\nto supper\xe2\x80\x94a very, very rough set. There were one or two Overland stage\r\ndrivers there, also, and half a dozen vagabonds and stragglers;\r\nconsequently the house was well crowded.\r\n\r\nWe walked out, after supper, and visited a small Indian camp in the\r\nvicinity. The Indians were in a great hurry about something, and were\r\npacking up and getting away as fast as they could. In their broken\r\nEnglish they said, \xe2\x80\x9cBy\xe2\x80\x99m-by, heap water!\xe2\x80\x9d and by the help of signs made\r\nus understand that in their opinion a flood was coming. The weather was\r\nperfectly clear, and this was not the rainy season. There was about a\r\nfoot of water in the insignificant river\xe2\x80\x94or maybe two feet; the stream\r\nwas not wider than a back alley in a village, and its banks were\r\nscarcely higher than a man\xe2\x80\x99s head.\r\n\r\nSo, where was the flood to come from? We canvassed the subject awhile\r\nand then concluded it was a ruse, and that the Indians had some better\r\nreason for leaving in a hurry than fears of a flood in such an\r\nexceedingly dry time.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n218.jpg (37K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt seven in the evening we went to bed in the second story\xe2\x80\x94with our\r\nclothes on, as usual, and all three in the same bed, for every available\r\nspace on the floors, chairs, etc., was in request, and even then there\r\nwas barely room for the housing of the inn\xe2\x80\x99s guests. An hour later we\r\nwere awakened by a great turmoil, and springing out of bed we picked our\r\nway nimbly among the ranks of snoring teamsters on the floor and got to\r\nthe front windows of the long room. A glance revealed a strange\r\nspectacle, under the moonlight. The crooked Carson was full to the brim,\r\nand its waters were raging and foaming in the wildest way\xe2\x80\x94sweeping\r\naround the sharp bends at a furious speed, and bearing on their surface\r\na chaos of logs, brush and all sorts of rubbish. A depression, where its\r\nbed had once been, in other times, was already filling, and in one or\r\ntwo places the water was beginning to wash over the main bank. Men were\r\nflying hither and thither, bringing cattle and wagons close up to the\r\nhouse, for the spot of high ground on which it stood extended only some\r\nthirty feet in front and about a hundred in the rear. Close to the old\r\nriver bed just spoken of, stood a little log stable, and in this our\r\nhorses were lodged.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n219.jpg (173K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile we looked, the waters increased so fast in this place that in a\r\nfew minutes a torrent was roaring by the little stable and its margin\r\nencroaching steadily on the logs. We suddenly realized that this flood\r\nwas not a mere holiday spectacle, but meant damage\xe2\x80\x94and not only to the\r\nsmall log stable but to the Overland buildings close to the main river,\r\nfor the waves had now come ashore and were creeping about the\r\nfoundations and invading the great hay-corral adjoining. We ran down and\r\njoined the crowd of excited men and frightened animals. We waded knee-\r\ndeep into the log stable, unfastened the horses and waded out almost\r\n_waist_-deep, so fast the waters increased. Then the crowd rushed in a\r\nbody to the hay-corral and began to tumble down the huge stacks of baled\r\nhay and roll the bales up on the high ground by the house. Meantime it\r\nwas discovered that Owens, an overland driver, was missing, and a man\r\nran to the large stable, and wading in, boot-top deep, discovered him\r\nasleep in his bed, awoke him, and waded out again. But Owens was drowsy\r\nand resumed his nap; but only for a minute or two, for presently he\r\nturned in his bed, his hand dropped over the side and came in contact\r\nwith the cold water! It was up level with the mattress! He waded out,\r\nbreast-deep, almost, and the next moment the sun-burned bricks melted\r\ndown like sugar and the big building crumbled to a ruin and was washed\r\naway in a twinkling.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock only the roof of the little log stable was out of\r\nwater, and our inn was on an island in mid-ocean. As far as the eye\r\ncould reach, in the moonlight, there was no desert visible, but only a\r\nlevel waste of shining water. The Indians were true prophets, but how\r\ndid they get their information? I am not able to answer the question. We\r\nremained cooped up eight days and nights with that curious crew.\r\nSwearing, drinking and card playing were the order of the day, and\r\noccasionally a fight was thrown in for variety. Dirt and vermin\xe2\x80\x94but let\r\nus forget those features; their profusion is simply inconceivable\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nbetter that they remain so.\r\n\r\nThere were two men\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94however, this chapter is long enough.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were two men in the company who caused me particular discomfort.\r\nOne was a little Swede, about twenty-five years old, who knew only one\r\nsong, and he was forever singing it. By day we were all crowded into one\r\nsmall, stifling bar-room, and so there was no escaping this person\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmusic. Through all the profanity, whisky-guzzling, \xe2\x80\x9cold sledge\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nquarreling, his monotonous song meandered with never a variation in its\r\ntiresome sameness, and it seemed to me, at last, that I would be content\r\nto die, in order to be rid of the torture. The other man was a stalwart\r\nruffian called \xe2\x80\x9cArkansas,\xe2\x80\x9d who carried two revolvers in his belt and a\r\nbowie knife projecting from his boot, and who was always drunk and\r\nalways suffering for a fight. But he was so feared, that nobody would\r\naccommodate him. He would try all manner of little wary ruses to entrap\r\nsomebody into an offensive remark, and his face would light up now and\r\nthen when he fancied he was fairly on the scent of a fight, but\r\ninvariably his victim would elude his toils and then he would show a\r\ndisappointment that was almost pathetic. The landlord, Johnson, was a\r\nmeek, well-meaning fellow, and Arkansas fastened on him early, as a\r\npromising subject, and gave him no rest day or night, for awhile. On the\r\nfourth morning, Arkansas got drunk and sat himself down to wait for an\r\nopportunity. Presently Johnson came in, just comfortably sociable with\r\nwhisky, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reckon the Pennsylvania \xe2\x80\x99lection\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArkansas raised his finger impressively and Johnson stopped. Arkansas\r\nrose unsteadily and confronted him. Said he:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWh\xe2\x80\x94what do you know a\xe2\x80\x94about Pennsylvania? Answer me that. Wha\xe2\x80\x94what do\r\nyou know \xe2\x80\x99bout Pennsylvania?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was only goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou was only goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say. You was! You was only goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say\xe2\x80\x94what was\r\nyou goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say? That\xe2\x80\x99s it! That\xe2\x80\x99s what _I_ want to know. I want to\r\nknow wha-what you (\xe2\x80\x99_ic_) what you know about Pennsylvania, since you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nmakin\xe2\x80\x99 yourself so d\xe2\x80\x94-d free. Answer me that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Arkansas, if you\xe2\x80\x99d only let me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n222.jpg (55K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s a henderin\xe2\x80\x99 you? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you insinuate nothing agin me!\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\ndo it. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you come in here bullyin\xe2\x80\x99 around, and cussin\xe2\x80\x99 and goin\xe2\x80\x99 on\r\nlike a lunatic\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you do it. \xe2\x80\x99Coz _I_ won\xe2\x80\x99t stand it. If fight\xe2\x80\x99s what\r\nyou want, out with it! I\xe2\x80\x99m your man! Out with it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaid Johnson, backing into a corner, Arkansas following, menacingly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, _I_ never said nothing, Mr. Arkansas. You don\xe2\x80\x99t give a man no\r\nchance. I was only goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say that Pennsylvania was goin\xe2\x80\x99 to have an\r\nelection next week\xe2\x80\x94that was all\xe2\x80\x94that was everything I was goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwish I may never stir if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then why d\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t you say it? What did you come swellin\xe2\x80\x99 around that\r\nway for, and tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to raise trouble?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy I didn\xe2\x80\x99t come swellin\xe2\x80\x99 around, Mr. Arkansas\xe2\x80\x94I just\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a liar am I! Ger-reat Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s ghost\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, please, Mr. Arkansas, I never meant such a thing as that, I wish I\r\nmay die if I did. All the boys will tell you that I\xe2\x80\x99ve always spoke well\r\nof you, and respected you more\xe2\x80\x99n any man in the house. Ask Smith. Ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit so, Smith? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say, no longer ago than last night, that for a\r\nman that was a gentleman _all_ the time and every way you took him, give\r\nme Arkansas? I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave it to any gentleman here if them warn\xe2\x80\x99t the very\r\nwords I used. Come, now, Mr. Arkansas, le\xe2\x80\x99s take a drink\xe2\x80\x94le\xe2\x80\x99s shake\r\nhands and take a drink. Come up\xe2\x80\x94everybody! It\xe2\x80\x99s my treat. Come up, Bill,\r\nTom, Bob, Scotty\xe2\x80\x94come up. I want you all to take a drink with me and\r\nArkansas\xe2\x80\x94_old_ Arkansas, I call him\xe2\x80\x94bully old Arkansas. Gimme your hand\r\nagin. Look at him, boys\xe2\x80\x94just take a _look_ at him. Thar stands the\r\nwhitest man in America!\xe2\x80\x94and the man that denies it has got to fight\r\n_me_, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Gimme that old flipper agin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey embraced, with drunken affection on the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s part and\r\nunresponsive toleration on the part of Arkansas, who, bribed by a drink,\r\nwas disappointed of his prey once more. But the foolish landlord was so\r\nhappy to have escaped butchery, that he went on talking when he ought to\r\nhave marched himself out of danger. The consequence was that Arkansas\r\nshortly began to glower upon him dangerously, and presently said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLan\xe2\x80\x99lord, will you p-please make that remark over agin if you please?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was a-sayin\xe2\x80\x99 to Scotty that my father was up\xe2\x80\x99ards of eighty year old\r\nwhen he died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas that _all_ that you said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that was all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t say nothing but that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen an uncomfortable silence.\r\n\r\nArkansas played with his glass a moment, lolling on his elbows on the\r\ncounter. Then he meditatively scratched his left shin with his right\r\nboot, while the awkward silence continued. But presently he loafed away\r\ntoward the stove, looking dissatisfied; roughly shouldered two or three\r\nmen out of a comfortable position; occupied it himself, gave a sleeping\r\ndog a kick that sent him howling under a bench, then spread his long\r\nlegs and his blanket-coat tails apart and proceeded to warm his back. In\r\na little while he fell to grumbling to himself, and soon he slouched\r\nback to the bar and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLan\xe2\x80\x99lord, what\xe2\x80\x99s your idea for rakin\xe2\x80\x99 up old personalities and blowin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nabout your father? Ain\xe2\x80\x99t this company agreeable to you? Ain\xe2\x80\x99t it? If\r\nthis company ain\xe2\x80\x99t agreeable to you, p\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99aps we\xe2\x80\x99d better leave. Is that\r\nyour idea? Is that what you\xe2\x80\x99re coming at?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy bless your soul, Arkansas, I warn\xe2\x80\x99t thinking of such a thing. My\r\nfather and my mother\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLan\xe2\x80\x99lord, _don\xe2\x80\x99t_ crowd a man! Don\xe2\x80\x99t do it. If nothing\xe2\x80\x99ll do you but a\r\ndisturbance, out with it like a man (\xe2\x80\x99_ic_)\xe2\x80\x94but _don\xe2\x80\x99t_ rake up old\r\nbygones and fling\xe2\x80\x99em in the teeth of a passel of people that wants to be\r\npeaceable if they could git a chance. What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you this\r\nmornin\xe2\x80\x99, anyway? I never see a man carry on so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArkansas, I reely didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean no harm, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t go on with it if\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s onpleasant to you. I reckon my licker\xe2\x80\x99s got into my head, and what\r\nwith the flood, and havin\xe2\x80\x99 so many to feed and look out for\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo _that\xe2\x80\x99s_ what\xe2\x80\x99s a-ranklin\xe2\x80\x99 in your heart, is it? You want us to\r\nleave do you? There\xe2\x80\x99s too many on us. You want us to pack up and swim.\r\nIs that it? Come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease be reasonable, Arkansas. Now _you_ know that I ain\xe2\x80\x99t the man\r\nto\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you a threatenin\xe2\x80\x99 me? Are you? By George, the man don\xe2\x80\x99t live that\r\ncan skeer me! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you try to come that game, my chicken\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99cuz I can\r\nstand a good deal, but I won\xe2\x80\x99t stand that. Come out from behind that bar\r\ntill I clean you! You want to drive us out, do you, you sneakin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nunderhanded hound! Come out from behind that bar! _I\xe2\x80\x99ll_ learn you to\r\nbully and badger and browbeat a gentleman that\xe2\x80\x99s forever trying to\r\nbefriend you and keep you out of trouble!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Arkansas, please don\xe2\x80\x99t shoot! If there\xe2\x80\x99s got to be bloodshed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear that, gentlemen? Do you hear him talk about bloodshed? So\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s blood you want, is it, you ravin\xe2\x80\x99 desperado! You\xe2\x80\x99d made up your\r\nmind to murder somebody this mornin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94I knowed it perfectly well. I\xe2\x80\x99m the\r\nman, am I? It\xe2\x80\x99s me you\xe2\x80\x99re goin\xe2\x80\x99 to murder, is it? But you can\xe2\x80\x99t do it\r\n\xe2\x80\x99thout I get one chance first, you thievin\xe2\x80\x99 black-hearted, white-livered\r\nson of a nigger! Draw your weepon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that, Arkansas began to shoot, and the landlord to clamber over\r\nbenches, men and every sort of obstacle in a frantic desire to escape.\r\nIn the midst of the wild hubbub the landlord crashed through a glass\r\ndoor, and as Arkansas charged after him the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s wife suddenly\r\nappeared in the doorway and confronted the desperado with a pair of\r\nscissors! Her fury was magnificent. With head erect and flashing eye she\r\nstood a moment and then advanced, with her weapon raised. The astonished\r\nruffian hesitated, and then fell back a step. She followed. She backed\r\nhim step by step into the middle of the bar-room, and then, while the\r\nwondering crowd closed up and gazed, she gave him such another tongue-\r\nlashing as never a cowed and shamefaced braggart got before, perhaps! As\r\nshe finished and retired victorious, a roar of applause shook the house,\r\nand every man ordered \xe2\x80\x9cdrinks for the crowd\xe2\x80\x9d in one and the same breath.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n225.jpg (102K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe lesson was entirely sufficient. The reign of terror was over, and\r\nthe Arkansas domination broken for good. During the rest of the season\r\nof island captivity, there was one man who sat apart in a state of\r\npermanent humiliation, never mixing in any quarrel or uttering a boast,\r\nand never resenting the insults the once cringing crew now constantly\r\nleveled at him, and that man was \xe2\x80\x9cArkansas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy the fifth or sixth morning the waters had subsided from the land, but\r\nthe stream in the old river bed was still high and swift and there was\r\nno possibility of crossing it. On the eighth it was still too high for\r\nan entirely safe passage, but life in the inn had become next to\r\ninsupportable by reason of the dirt, drunkenness, fighting, etc., and so\r\nwe made an effort to get away. In the midst of a heavy snow-storm we\r\nembarked in a canoe, taking our saddles aboard and towing our horses\r\nafter us by their halters. The Prussian, Ollendorff, was in the bow,\r\nwith a paddle, Ballou paddled in the middle, and I sat in the stern\r\nholding the halters. When the horses lost their footing and began to\r\nswim, Ollendorff got frightened, for there was great danger that the\r\nhorses would make our aim uncertain, and it was plain that if we failed\r\nto land at a certain spot the current would throw us off and almost\r\nsurely cast us into the main Carson, which was a boiling torrent, now.\r\nSuch a catastrophe would be death, in all probability, for we would be\r\nswept to sea in the \xe2\x80\x9cSink\xe2\x80\x9d or overturned and drowned. We warned\r\nOllendorff to keep his wits about him and handle himself carefully, but\r\nit was useless; the moment the bow touched the bank, he made a spring\r\nand the canoe whirled upside down in ten-foot water.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n227.jpg (95K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOllendorff seized some brush and dragged himself ashore, but Ballou and\r\nI had to swim for it, encumbered with our overcoats. But we held on to\r\nthe canoe, and although we were washed down nearly to the Carson, we\r\nmanaged to push the boat ashore and make a safe landing. We were cold\r\nand water- soaked, but safe. The horses made a landing, too, but our\r\nsaddles were gone, of course. We tied the animals in the sage-brush and\r\nthere they had to stay for twenty-four hours. We baled out the canoe and\r\nferried over some food and blankets for them, but we slept one more\r\nnight in the inn before making another venture on our journey.\r\n\r\nThe next morning it was still snowing furiously when we got away with\r\nour new stock of saddles and accoutrements. We mounted and started. The\r\nsnow lay so deep on the ground that there was no sign of a road\r\nperceptible, and the snow-fall was so thick that we could not see more\r\nthan a hundred yards ahead, else we could have guided our course by the\r\nmountain ranges. The case looked dubious, but Ollendorff said his\r\ninstinct was as sensitive as any compass, and that he could \xe2\x80\x9cstrike a\r\nbee-line\xe2\x80\x9d for Carson city and never diverge from it. He said that if he\r\nwere to straggle a single point out of the true line his instinct would\r\nassail him like an outraged conscience. Consequently we dropped into his\r\nwake happy and content. For half an hour we poked along warily enough,\r\nbut at the end of that time we came upon a fresh trail, and Ollendorff\r\nshouted proudly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew I was as dead certain as a compass, boys! Here we are, right in\r\nsomebody\xe2\x80\x99s tracks that will hunt the way for us without any trouble.\r\nLet\xe2\x80\x99s hurry up and join company with the party.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo we put the horses into as much of a trot as the deep snow would\r\nallow, and before long it was evident that we were gaining on our\r\npredecessors, for the tracks grew more distinct. We hurried along, and\r\nat the end of an hour the tracks looked still newer and fresher\xe2\x80\x94but what\r\nsurprised us was, that the _number_ of travelers in advance of us seemed\r\nto steadily increase. We wondered how so large a party came to be\r\ntraveling at such a time and in such a solitude. Somebody suggested that\r\nit must be a company of soldiers from the fort, and so we accepted that\r\nsolution and jogged along a little faster still, for they could not be\r\nfar off now. But the tracks still multiplied, and we began to think the\r\nplatoon of soldiers was miraculously expanding into a regiment\xe2\x80\x94Ballou\r\nsaid they had already increased to five hundred! Presently he stopped\r\nhis horse and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoys, these are our own tracks, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve actually been circussing\r\nround and round in a circle for more than two hours, out here in this\r\nblind desert! By George this is perfectly hydraulic!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n229.jpg (83K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen the old man waxed wroth and abusive. He called Ollendorff all\r\nmanner of hard names\xe2\x80\x94said he never saw such a lurid fool as he was, and\r\nended with the peculiarly venomous opinion that he \xe2\x80\x9cdid not know as much\r\nas a logarythm!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe certainly had been following our own tracks. Ollendorff and his\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmental compass\xe2\x80\x9d were in disgrace from that moment.\r\n\r\nAfter all our hard travel, here we were on the bank of the stream again,\r\nwith the inn beyond dimly outlined through the driving snow-fall. While\r\nwe were considering what to do, the young Swede landed from the canoe\r\nand took his pedestrian way Carson-wards, singing his same tiresome song\r\nabout his \xe2\x80\x9csister and his brother\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe child in the grave with its\r\nmother,\xe2\x80\x9d and in a short minute faded and disappeared in the white\r\noblivion. He was never heard of again. He no doubt got bewildered and\r\nlost, and Fatigue delivered him over to Sleep and Sleep betrayed him to\r\nDeath. Possibly he followed our treacherous tracks till he became\r\nexhausted and dropped.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n230.jpg (20K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPresently the Overland stage forded the now fast receding stream and\r\nstarted toward Carson on its first trip since the flood came. We\r\nhesitated no longer, now, but took up our march in its wake, and trotted\r\nmerrily along, for we had good confidence in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s bump of\r\nlocality. But our horses were no match for the fresh stage team. We were\r\nsoon left out of sight; but it was no matter, for we had the deep ruts\r\nthe wheels made for a guide. By this time it was three in the afternoon,\r\nand consequently it was not very long before night came\xe2\x80\x94and not with a\r\nlingering twilight, but with a sudden shutting down like a cellar door,\r\nas is its habit in that country. The snowfall was still as thick as\r\never, and of course we could not see fifteen steps before us; but all\r\nabout us the white glare of the snow-bed enabled us to discern the\r\nsmooth sugar-loaf mounds made by the covered sage-bushes, and just in\r\nfront of us the two faint grooves which we knew were the steadily\r\nfilling and slowly disappearing wheel-tracks.\r\n\r\nNow those sage-bushes were all about the same height\xe2\x80\x94three or four feet;\r\nthey stood just about seven feet apart, all over the vast desert; each\r\nof them was a mere snow-mound, now; in _any_ direction that you\r\nproceeded (the same as in a well laid out orchard) you would find\r\nyourself moving down a distinctly defined avenue, with a row of these\r\nsnow-mounds an either side of it\xe2\x80\x94an avenue the customary width of a\r\nroad, nice and level in its breadth, and rising at the sides in the most\r\nnatural way, by reason of the mounds. But we had not thought of this.\r\nThen imagine the chilly thrill that shot through us when it finally\r\noccurred to us, far in the night, that since the last faint trace of the\r\nwheel-tracks had long ago been buried from sight, we might now be\r\nwandering down a mere sage-brush avenue, miles away from the road and\r\ndiverging further and further away from it all the time. Having a cake\r\nof ice slipped down one\xe2\x80\x99s back is placid comfort compared to it. There\r\nwas a sudden leap and stir of blood that had been asleep for an hour,\r\nand as sudden a rousing of all the drowsing activities in our minds and\r\nbodies. We were alive and awake at once\xe2\x80\x94and shaking and quaking with\r\nconsternation, too. There was an instant halting and dismounting, a\r\nbending low and an anxious scanning of the road-bed. Useless, of course;\r\nfor if a faint depression could not be discerned from an altitude of\r\nfour or five feet above it, it certainly could not with one\xe2\x80\x99s nose\r\nnearly against it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n231.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe seemed to be in a road, but that was no proof. We tested this by\r\nwalking off in various directions\xe2\x80\x94the regular snow-mounds and the\r\nregular avenues between them convinced each man that _he_ had found the\r\ntrue road, and that the others had found only false ones. Plainly the\r\nsituation was desperate. We were cold and stiff and the horses were\r\ntired. We decided to build a sage-brush fire and camp out till morning.\r\nThis was wise, because if we were wandering from the right road and the\r\nsnow-storm continued another day our case would be the next thing to\r\nhopeless if we kept on.\r\n\r\nAll agreed that a camp fire was what would come nearest to saving us,\r\nnow, and so we set about building it. We could find no matches, and so\r\nwe tried to make shift with the pistols. Not a man in the party had ever\r\ntried to do such a thing before, but not a man in the party doubted that\r\nit _could_ be done, and without any trouble\xe2\x80\x94because every man in the\r\nparty had read about it in books many a time and had naturally come to\r\nbelieve it, with trusting simplicity, just as he had long ago accepted\r\nand believed that _other_ common book-fraud about Indians and lost\r\nhunters making a fire by rubbing two dry sticks together.\r\n\r\nWe huddled together on our knees in the deep snow, and the horses put\r\ntheir noses together and bowed their patient heads over us; and while\r\nthe feathery flakes eddied down and turned us into a group of white\r\nstatuary, we proceeded with the momentous experiment. We broke twigs\r\nfrom a sage bush and piled them on a little cleared place in the shelter\r\nof our bodies. In the course of ten or fifteen minutes all was ready,\r\nand then, while conversation ceased and our pulses beat low with anxious\r\nsuspense, Ollendorff applied his revolver, pulled the trigger and blew\r\nthe pile clear out of the county! It was the flattest failure that ever\r\nwas.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n233.jpg (89K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThis was distressing, but it paled before a greater horror\xe2\x80\x94the horses\r\nwere gone! I had been appointed to hold the bridles, but in my absorbing\r\nanxiety over the pistol experiment I had unconsciously dropped them and\r\nthe released animals had walked off in the storm. It was useless to try\r\nto follow them, for their footfalls could make no sound, and one could\r\npass within two yards of the creatures and never see them. We gave them\r\nup without an effort at recovering them, and cursed the lying books that\r\nsaid horses would stay by their masters for protection and companionship\r\nin a distressful time like ours.\r\n\r\nWe were miserable enough, before; we felt still more forlorn, now.\r\nPatiently, but with blighted hope, we broke more sticks and piled them,\r\nand once more the Prussian shot them into annihilation. Plainly, to\r\nlight a fire with a pistol was an art requiring practice and experience,\r\nand the middle of a desert at midnight in a snow-storm was not a good\r\nplace or time for the acquiring of the accomplishment. We gave it up and\r\ntried the other. Each man took a couple of sticks and fell to chafing\r\nthem together. At the end of half an hour we were thoroughly chilled,\r\nand so were the sticks. We bitterly execrated the Indians, the hunters\r\nand the books that had betrayed us with the silly device, and wondered\r\ndismally what was next to be done. At this critical moment Mr. Ballou\r\nfished out four matches from the rubbish of an overlooked pocket. To\r\nhave found four gold bars would have seemed poor and cheap good luck\r\ncompared to this.\r\n\r\nOne cannot think how good a match looks under such circumstances\xe2\x80\x94or how\r\nlovable and precious, and sacredly beautiful to the eye. This time we\r\ngathered sticks with high hopes; and when Mr. Ballou prepared to light\r\nthe first match, there was an amount of interest centred upon him that\r\npages of writing could not describe. The match burned hopefully a\r\nmoment, and then went out. It could not have carried more regret with it\r\nif it had been a human life. The next match simply flashed and died. The\r\nwind puffed the third one out just as it was on the imminent verge of\r\nsuccess. We gathered together closer than ever, and developed a\r\nsolicitude that was rapt and painful, as Mr. Ballou scratched our last\r\nhope on his leg. It lit, burned blue and sickly, and then budded into a\r\nrobust flame. Shading it with his hands, the old gentleman bent\r\ngradually down and every heart went with him\xe2\x80\x94everybody, too, for that\r\nmatter\xe2\x80\x94and blood and breath stood still. The flame touched the sticks at\r\nlast, took gradual hold upon them\xe2\x80\x94hesitated\xe2\x80\x94took a stronger\r\nhold\xe2\x80\x94hesitated again\xe2\x80\x94held its breath five heart-breaking seconds, then\r\ngave a sort of human gasp and went out.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n234.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNobody said a word for several minutes. It was a solemn sort of silence;\r\neven the wind put on a stealthy, sinister quiet, and made no more noise\r\nthan the falling flakes of snow. Finally a sad-voiced conversation\r\nbegan, and it was soon apparent that in each of our hearts lay the\r\nconviction that this was our last night with the living. I had so hoped\r\nthat I was the only one who felt so. When the others calmly acknowledged\r\ntheir conviction, it sounded like the summons itself. Ollendorff said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrothers, let us die together. And let us go without one hard feeling\r\ntowards each other. Let us forget and forgive bygones. I know that you\r\nhave felt hard towards me for turning over the canoe, and for knowing\r\ntoo much and leading you round and round in the snow\xe2\x80\x94but I meant well;\r\nforgive me. I acknowledge freely that I have had hard feelings against\r\nMr. Ballou for abusing me and calling me a logarythm, which is a thing I\r\ndo not know what, but no doubt a thing considered disgraceful and\r\nunbecoming in America, and it has scarcely been out of my mind and has\r\nhurt me a great deal\xe2\x80\x94but let it go; I forgive Mr. Ballou with all my\r\nheart, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Ollendorff broke down and the tears came. He was not alone, for I\r\nwas crying too, and so was Mr. Ballou. Ollendorff got his voice again\r\nand forgave me for things I had done and said. Then he got out his\r\nbottle of whisky and said that whether he lived or died he would never\r\ntouch another drop. He said he had given up all hope of life, and\r\nalthough ill-prepared, was ready to submit humbly to his fate; that he\r\nwished he could be spared a little longer, not for any selfish reason,\r\nbut to make a thorough reform in his character, and by devoting himself\r\nto helping the poor, nursing the sick, and pleading with the people to\r\nguard themselves against the evils of intemperance, make his life a\r\nbeneficent example to the young, and lay it down at last with the\r\nprecious reflection that it had not been lived in vain. He ended by\r\nsaying that his reform should begin at this moment, even here in the\r\npresence of death, since no longer time was to be vouchsafed wherein to\r\nprosecute it to men\xe2\x80\x99s help and benefit\xe2\x80\x94and with that he threw away the\r\nbottle of whisky.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n236.jpg (21K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Ballou made remarks of similar purport, and began the reform he\r\ncould not live to continue, by throwing away the ancient pack of cards\r\nthat had solaced our captivity during the flood and made it bearable.\r\n\r\nHe said he never gambled, but still was satisfied that the meddling with\r\ncards in any way was immoral and injurious, and no man could be wholly\r\npure and blemishless without eschewing them. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd therefore,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x9cin doing this act I already feel more in sympathy with that\r\nspiritual saturnalia necessary to entire and obsolete reform.\xe2\x80\x9d These\r\nrolling syllables touched him as no intelligible eloquence could have\r\ndone, and the old man sobbed with a mournfulness not unmingled with\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\nMy own remarks were of the same tenor as those of my comrades, and I\r\nknow that the feelings that prompted them were heartfelt and sincere. We\r\nwere all sincere, and all deeply moved and earnest, for we were in the\r\npresence of death and without hope. I threw away my pipe, and in doing\r\nit felt that at last I was free of a hated vice and one that had ridden\r\nme like a tyrant all my days. While I yet talked, the thought of the\r\ngood I might have done in the world and the still greater good I might\r\n_now_ do, with these new incentives and higher and better aims to guide\r\nme if I could only be spared a few years longer, overcame me and the\r\ntears came again. We put our arms about each other\xe2\x80\x99s necks and awaited\r\nthe warning drowsiness that precedes death by freezing.\r\n\r\nIt came stealing over us presently, and then we bade each other a last\r\nfarewell. A delicious dreaminess wrought its web about my yielding\r\nsenses, while the snow-flakes wove a winding sheet about my conquered\r\nbody. Oblivion came. The battle of life was done.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n237.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nI do not know how long I was in a state of forgetfulness, but it seemed\r\nan age. A vague consciousness grew upon me by degrees, and then came a\r\ngathering anguish of pain in my limbs and through all my body. I\r\nshuddered. The thought flitted through my brain, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is death\xe2\x80\x94this is\r\nthe hereafter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen came a white upheaval at my side, and a voice said, with\r\nbitterness:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill some gentleman be so good as to kick me behind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was Ballou\xe2\x80\x94at least it was a towzled snow image in a sitting posture,\r\nwith Ballou\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\r\n\r\nI rose up, and there in the gray dawn, not fifteen steps from us, were\r\nthe frame buildings of a stage station, and under a shed stood our still\r\nsaddled and bridled horses!\r\n\r\nAn arched snow-drift broke up, now, and Ollendorff emerged from it, and\r\nthe three of us sat and stared at the houses without speaking a word. We\r\nreally had nothing to say. We were like the profane man who could not\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo the subject justice,\xe2\x80\x9d the whole situation was so painfully\r\nridiculous and humiliating that words were tame and we did not know\r\nwhere to commence anyhow.\r\n\r\nThe joy in our hearts at our deliverance was poisoned; well-nigh\r\ndissipated, indeed. We presently began to grow pettish by degrees, and\r\nsullen; and then, angry at each other, angry at ourselves, angry at\r\neverything in general, we moodily dusted the snow from our clothing and\r\nin unsociable single file plowed our way to the horses, unsaddled them,\r\nand sought shelter in the station.\r\n\r\nI have scarcely exaggerated a detail of this curious and absurd\r\nadventure. It occurred almost exactly as I have stated it. We actually\r\nwent into camp in a snow-drift in a desert, at midnight in a storm,\r\nforlorn and hopeless, within fifteen steps of a comfortable inn.\r\n\r\nFor two hours we sat apart in the station and ruminated in disgust. The\r\nmystery was gone, now, and it was plain enough why the horses had\r\ndeserted us. Without a doubt they were under that shed a quarter of a\r\nminute after they had left us, and they must have overheard and enjoyed\r\nall our confessions and lamentations.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast we felt better, and the zest of life soon came back. The\r\nworld looked bright again, and existence was as dear to us as ever.\r\nPresently an uneasiness came over me\xe2\x80\x94grew upon me\xe2\x80\x94assailed me without\r\nceasing. Alas, my regeneration was not complete\xe2\x80\x94I wanted to smoke! I\r\nresisted with all my strength, but the flesh was weak. I wandered away\r\nalone and wrestled with myself an hour. I recalled my promises of reform\r\nand preached to myself persuasively, upbraidingly, exhaustively. But it\r\nwas all vain, I shortly found myself sneaking among the snow-drifts\r\nhunting for my pipe. I discovered it after a considerable search, and\r\ncrept away to hide myself and enjoy it. I remained behind the barn a\r\ngood while, asking myself how I would feel if my braver, stronger, truer\r\ncomrades should catch me in my degradation. At last I lit the pipe, and\r\nno human being can feel meaner and baser than I did then. I was ashamed\r\nof being in my own pitiful company. Still dreading discovery, I felt\r\nthat perhaps the further side of the barn would be somewhat safer, and\r\nso I turned the corner. As I turned the one corner, smoking, Ollendorff\r\nturned the other with his bottle to his lips, and between us sat\r\nunconscious Ballou deep in a game of \xe2\x80\x9csolitaire\xe2\x80\x9d with the old greasy\r\ncards!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n240.jpg (102K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAbsurdity could go no farther. We shook hands and agreed to say no more\r\nabout \xe2\x80\x9creform\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cexamples to the rising generation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe station we were at was at the verge of the Twenty-six-Mile Desert.\r\nIf we had approached it half an hour earlier the night before, we must\r\nhave heard men shouting there and firing pistols; for they were\r\nexpecting some sheep drovers and their flocks and knew that they would\r\ninfallibly get lost and wander out of reach of help unless guided by\r\nsounds.\r\n\r\nWhile we remained at the station, three of the drovers arrived, nearly\r\nexhausted with their wanderings, but two others of their party were\r\nnever heard of afterward.\r\n\r\nWe reached Carson in due time, and took a rest. This rest, together with\r\npreparations for the journey to Esmeralda, kept us there a week, and the\r\ndelay gave us the opportunity to be present at the trial of the great\r\nland-slide case of Hyde _vs_. Morgan\xe2\x80\x94an episode which is famous in\r\nNevada to this day. After a word or two of necessary explanation, I will\r\nset down the history of this singular affair just as it transpired.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe mountains are very high and steep about Carson, Eagle and Washoe\r\nValleys\xe2\x80\x94very high and very steep, and so when the snow gets to melting\r\noff fast in the Spring and the warm surface-earth begins to moisten and\r\nsoften, the disastrous land-slides commence. The reader cannot know what\r\na land-slide is, unless he has lived in that country and seen the whole\r\nside of a mountain taken off some fine morning and deposited down in the\r\nvalley, leaving a vast, treeless, unsightly scar upon the mountain\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfront to keep the circumstance fresh in his memory all the years that he\r\nmay go on living within seventy miles of that place.\r\n\r\nGeneral Buncombe was shipped out to Nevada in the invoice of Territorial\r\nofficers, to be United States Attorney. He considered himself a lawyer\r\nof parts, and he very much wanted an opportunity to manifest it\xe2\x80\x94partly\r\nfor the pure gratification of it and partly because his salary was\r\nTerritorially meagre (which is a strong expression). Now the older\r\ncitizens of a new territory look down upon the rest of the world with a\r\ncalm, benevolent compassion, as long as it keeps out of the way\xe2\x80\x94when it\r\ngets in the way they snub it. Sometimes this latter takes the shape of a\r\npractical joke.\r\n\r\nOne morning Dick Hyde rode furiously up to General Buncombe\xe2\x80\x99s door in\r\nCarson city and rushed into his presence without stopping to tie his\r\nhorse. He seemed much excited. He told the General that he wanted him to\r\nconduct a suit for him and would pay him five hundred dollars if he\r\nachieved a victory. And then, with violent gestures and a world of\r\nprofanity, he poured out his grief. He said it was pretty well known\r\nthat for some years he had been farming (or ranching as the more\r\ncustomary term is) in Washoe District, and making a successful thing of\r\nit, and furthermore it was known that his ranch was situated just in the\r\nedge of the valley, and that Tom Morgan owned a ranch immediately above\r\nit on the mountain side.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n242.jpg (114K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd now the trouble was, that one of those hated and dreaded land-slides\r\nhad come and slid Morgan\xe2\x80\x99s ranch, fences, cabins, cattle, barns and\r\neverything down on top of _his_ ranch and exactly covered up every\r\nsingle vestige of his property, to a depth of about thirty-eight feet.\r\nMorgan was in possession and refused to vacate the premises\xe2\x80\x94said he was\r\noccupying his own cabin and not interfering with anybody else\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94and said\r\nthe cabin was standing on the same dirt and same ranch it had always\r\nstood on, and he would like to see anybody make him vacate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when I reminded him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hyde, weeping, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it was on top of my\r\nranch and that he was trespassing, he had the infernal meanness to ask\r\nme why didn\xe2\x80\x99t I _stay_ on my ranch and hold possession when I see him a-\r\ncoming! Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t I _stay_ on it, the blathering lunatic\xe2\x80\x94by George,\r\nwhen I heard that racket and looked up that hill it was just like the\r\nwhole world was a-ripping and a-tearing down that mountain\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94splinters, and cord-wood, thunder and lightning, hail and snow,\r\nodds and ends of hay stacks, and awful clouds of dust!\xe2\x80\x94trees going end\r\nover end in the air, rocks as big as a house jumping \xe2\x80\x99bout a thousand\r\nfeet high and busting into ten million pieces, cattle turned inside out\r\nand a-coming head on with their tails hanging out between their\r\nteeth!\xe2\x80\x94and in the midst of all that wrack and destruction sot that\r\ncussed Morgan on his gate-post, a-wondering why _I_ didn\xe2\x80\x99t _stay_ and\r\nhold possession! Laws bless me, I just took one glimpse, General, and\r\nlit out\xe2\x80\x99n the county in three jumps exactly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what grinds me is that that Morgan hangs on there and won\xe2\x80\x99t move\r\noff\xe2\x80\x99n that ranch\xe2\x80\x94says it\xe2\x80\x99s his\xe2\x80\x99n and he\xe2\x80\x99s going to keep it\xe2\x80\x94likes it\r\nbetter\xe2\x80\x99n he did when it was higher up the hill. Mad! Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been so\r\nmad for two days I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find my way to town\xe2\x80\x94been wandering around in\r\nthe brush in a starving condition\xe2\x80\x94got anything here to drink, General?\r\nBut I\xe2\x80\x99m here _now_, and I\xe2\x80\x99m a-going to law. You hear _me_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNever in all the world, perhaps, were a man\xe2\x80\x99s feelings so outraged as\r\nwere the General\xe2\x80\x99s. He said he had never heard of such high-handed\r\nconduct in all his life as this Morgan\xe2\x80\x99s. And he said there was no use\r\nin going to law\xe2\x80\x94Morgan had no shadow of right to remain where he\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94nobody in the wide world would uphold him in it, and no lawyer would\r\ntake his case and no judge listen to it. Hyde said that right there was\r\nwhere he was mistaken\xe2\x80\x94everybody in town sustained Morgan; Hal Brayton, a\r\nvery smart lawyer, had taken his case; the courts being in vacation, it\r\nwas to be tried before a referee, and ex-Governor Roop had already been\r\nappointed to that office and would open his court in a large public hall\r\nnear the hotel at two that afternoon.\r\n\r\nThe General was amazed. He said he had suspected before that the people\r\nof that Territory were fools, and now he knew it. But he said rest easy,\r\nrest easy and collect the witnesses, for the victory was just as certain\r\nas if the conflict were already over. Hyde wiped away his tears and\r\nleft.\r\n\r\nAt two in the afternoon referee Roop\xe2\x80\x99s Court opened and Roop appeared\r\nthroned among his sheriffs, the witnesses, and spectators, and wearing\r\nupon his face a solemnity so awe-inspiring that some of his fellow-\r\nconspirators had misgivings that maybe he had not comprehended, after\r\nall, that this was merely a joke. An unearthly stillness prevailed, for\r\nat the slightest noise the judge uttered sternly the command:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrder in the Court!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the sheriffs promptly echoed it. Presently the General elbowed his\r\nway through the crowd of spectators, with his arms full of law-books,\r\nand on his ears fell an order from the judge which was the first\r\nrespectful recognition of his high official dignity that had ever\r\nsaluted them, and it trickled pleasantly through his whole system:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWay for the United States Attorney!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe witnesses were called\xe2\x80\x94legislators, high government officers,\r\nranchmen, miners, Indians, Chinamen, negroes. Three fourths of them were\r\ncalled by the defendant Morgan, but no matter, their testimony\r\ninvariably went in favor of the plaintiff Hyde. Each new witness only\r\nadded new testimony to the absurdity of a man\xe2\x80\x99s claiming to own another\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s property because his farm had slid down on top of it. Then the\r\nMorgan lawyers made their speeches, and seemed to make singularly weak\r\nones\xe2\x80\x94they did really nothing to help the Morgan cause. And now the\r\nGeneral, with exultation in his face, got up and made an impassioned\r\neffort; he pounded the table, he banged the law-books, he shouted, and\r\nroared, and howled, he quoted from everything and everybody, poetry,\r\nsarcasm, statistics, history, pathos, bathos, blasphemy, and wound up\r\nwith a grand war-whoop for free speech, freedom of the press, free\r\nschools, the Glorious Bird of America and the principles of eternal\r\njustice! [Applause.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n244.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the General sat down, he did it with the conviction that if there\r\nwas anything in good strong testimony, a great speech and believing and\r\nadmiring countenances all around, Mr. Morgan\xe2\x80\x99s case was killed. Ex-\r\nGovernor Roop leant his head upon his hand for some minutes, thinking,\r\nand the still audience waited for his decision. Then he got up and stood\r\nerect, with bended head, and thought again. Then he walked the floor\r\nwith long, deliberate strides, his chin in his hand, and still the\r\naudience waited. At last he returned to his throne, seated himself, and\r\nbegan impressively:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I feel the great responsibility that rests upon me this day.\r\nThis is no ordinary case. On the contrary it is plain that it is the\r\nmost solemn and awful that ever man was called upon to decide.\r\nGentlemen, I have listened attentively to the evidence, and have\r\nperceived that the weight of it, the overwhelming weight of it, is in\r\nfavor of the plaintiff Hyde. I have listened also to the remarks of\r\ncounsel, with high interest\xe2\x80\x94and especially will I commend the masterly\r\nand irrefutable logic of the distinguished gentleman who represents the\r\nplaintiff. But gentlemen, let us beware how we allow mere human\r\ntestimony, human ingenuity in argument and human ideas of equity, to\r\ninfluence us at a moment so solemn as this. Gentlemen, it ill becomes\r\nus, worms as we are, to meddle with the decrees of Heaven. It is plain\r\nto me that Heaven, in its inscrutable wisdom, has seen fit to move this\r\ndefendant\xe2\x80\x99s ranch for a purpose. We are but creatures, and we must\r\nsubmit. If Heaven has chosen to favor the defendant Morgan in this\r\nmarked and wonderful manner; and if Heaven, dissatisfied with the\r\nposition of the Morgan ranch upon the mountain side, has chosen to\r\nremove it to a position more eligible and more advantageous for its\r\nowner, it ill becomes us, insects as we are, to question the legality of\r\nthe act or inquire into the reasons that prompted it. No\xe2\x80\x94Heaven created\r\nthe ranches and it is Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s prerogative to rearrange them, to\r\nexperiment with them around at its pleasure. It is for us to submit,\r\nwithout repining.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n246.jpg (92K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI warn you that this thing which has happened is a thing with which the\r\nsacrilegious hands and brains and tongues of men must not meddle.\r\nGentlemen, it is the verdict of this court that the plaintiff, Richard\r\nHyde, has been deprived of his ranch by the visitation of God! And from\r\nthis decision there is no appeal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBuncombe seized his cargo of law-books and plunged out of the court-room\r\nfrantic with indignation. He pronounced Roop to be a miraculous fool, an\r\ninspired idiot. In all good faith he returned at night and remonstrated\r\nwith Roop upon his extravagant decision, and implored him to walk the\r\nfloor and think for half an hour, and see if he could not figure out\r\nsome sort of modification of the verdict. Roop yielded at last and got\r\nup to walk. He walked two hours and a half, and at last his face lit up\r\nhappily and he told Buncombe it had occurred to him that the ranch\r\nunderneath the new Morgan ranch still belonged to Hyde, that his title\r\nto the ground was just as good as it had ever been, and therefore he was\r\nof opinion that Hyde had a right to dig it out from under there and\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nThe General never waited to hear the end of it. He was always an\r\nimpatient and irascible man, that way. At the end of two months the fact\r\nthat he had been played upon with a joke had managed to bore itself,\r\nlike another Hoosac Tunnel, through the solid adamant of his\r\nunderstanding.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXV.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen we finally left for Esmeralda, horseback, we had an addition to the\r\ncompany in the person of Capt.
