John Nye, the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s brother. He had\r\na good memory, and a tongue hung in the middle. This is a combination\r\nwhich gives immortality to conversation. Capt. John never suffered the\r\ntalk to flag or falter once during the hundred and twenty miles of the\r\njourney. In addition to his conversational powers, he had one or two\r\nother endowments of a marked character. One was a singular \xe2\x80\x9chandiness\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nabout doing anything and everything, from laying out a railroad or\r\norganizing a political party, down to sewing on buttons, shoeing a\r\nhorse, or setting a broken leg, or a hen. Another was a spirit of\r\naccommodation that prompted him to take the needs, difficulties and\r\nperplexities of anybody and everybody upon his own shoulders at any and\r\nall times, and dispose of them with admirable facility and\r\nalacrity\xe2\x80\x94hence he always managed to find vacant beds in crowded inns,\r\nand plenty to eat in the emptiest larders. And finally, wherever he met\r\na man, woman or child, in camp, inn or desert, he either knew such\r\nparties personally or had been acquainted with a relative of the same.\r\nSuch another traveling comrade was never seen before. I cannot forbear\r\ngiving a specimen of the way in which he overcame difficulties. On the\r\nsecond day out, we arrived, very tired and hungry, at a poor little inn\r\nin the desert, and were told that the house was full, no provisions on\r\nhand, and neither hay nor barley to spare for the horses\xe2\x80\x94must move on.\r\nThe rest of us wanted to hurry on while it was yet light, but Capt. John\r\ninsisted on stopping awhile. We dismounted and entered. There was no\r\nwelcome for us on any face. Capt. John began his blandishments, and\r\nwithin twenty minutes he had accomplished the following things, viz.:\r\nfound old acquaintances in three teamsters; discovered that he used to\r\ngo to school with the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s mother; recognized his wife as a lady\r\nwhose life he had saved once in California, by stopping her runaway\r\nhorse; mended a child\xe2\x80\x99s broken toy and won the favor of its mother, a\r\nguest of the inn; helped the hostler bleed a horse, and prescribed for\r\nanother horse that had the \xe2\x80\x9cheaves\xe2\x80\x9d; treated the entire party three\r\ntimes at the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s bar; produced a later paper than anybody had\r\nseen for a week and sat himself down to read the news to a deeply\r\ninterested audience. The result, summed up, was as follows: The hostler\r\nfound plenty of feed for our horses; we had a trout supper, an\r\nexceedingly sociable time after it, good beds to sleep in, and a\r\nsurprising breakfast in the morning\xe2\x80\x94and when we left, we left lamented\r\nby all! Capt. John had some bad traits, but he had some uncommonly\r\nvaluable ones to offset them with.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n249.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEsmeralda was in many respects another Humboldt, but in a little more\r\nforward state. The claims we had been paying assessments on were\r\nentirely worthless, and we threw them away. The principal one cropped\r\nout of the top of a knoll that was fourteen feet high, and the inspired\r\nBoard of Directors were running a tunnel under that knoll to strike the\r\nledge. The tunnel would have to be seventy feet long, and would then\r\nstrike the ledge at the same dept that a _shaft_ twelve feet deep would\r\nhave reached! The Board were living on the \xe2\x80\x9cassessments.\xe2\x80\x9d [N.B.\xe2\x80\x94This\r\nhint comes too late for the enlightenment of New York silver miners;\r\nthey have already learned all about this neat trick by experience.] The\r\nBoard had no desire to strike the ledge, knowing that it was as barren\r\nof silver as a curbstone. This reminiscence calls to mind Jim Townsend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntunnel. He had paid assessments on a mine called the \xe2\x80\x9cDaley\xe2\x80\x9d till he was\r\nwell-nigh penniless. Finally an assessment was levied to run a tunnel\r\ntwo hundred and fifty feet on the Daley, and Townsend went up on the\r\nhill to look into matters.\r\n\r\nHe found the Daley cropping out of the apex of an exceedingly sharp-\r\npointed peak, and a couple of men up there \xe2\x80\x9cfacing\xe2\x80\x9d the proposed tunnel.\r\nTownsend made a calculation. Then he said to the men:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you have taken a contract to run a tunnel into this hill two hundred\r\nand fifty feet to strike this ledge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you know that you have got one of the most expensive and\r\narduous undertakings before you that was ever conceived by man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy no\xe2\x80\x94how is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause this hill is only twenty-five feet through from side to side;\r\nand so you have got to build two hundred and twenty-five feet of your\r\ntunnel on trestle-work!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n250.jpg (61K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe ways of silver mining Boards are exceedingly dark and sinuous.\r\n\r\nWe took up various claims, and _commenced_ shafts and tunnels on them,\r\nbut never finished any of them. We had to do a certain amount of work on\r\neach to \xe2\x80\x9chold\xe2\x80\x9d it, else other parties could seize our property after the\r\nexpiration of ten days. We were always hunting up new claims and doing a\r\nlittle work on them and then waiting for a buyer\xe2\x80\x94who never came. We\r\nnever found any ore that would yield more than fifty dollars a ton; and\r\nas the mills charged fifty dollars a ton for _working_ ore and\r\nextracting the silver, our pocket-money melted steadily away and none\r\nreturned to take its place. We lived in a little cabin and cooked for\r\nourselves; and altogether it was a hard life, though a hopeful one\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nwe never ceased to expect fortune and a customer to burst upon us some\r\nday.\r\n\r\nAt last, when flour reached a dollar a pound, and money could not be\r\nborrowed on the best security at less than _eight per cent a month_ (I\r\nbeing without the security, too), I abandoned mining and went to\r\nmilling. That is to say, I went to work as a common laborer in a quartz\r\nmill, at ten dollars a week and board.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nI had already learned how hard and long and dismal a task it is to\r\nburrow down into the bowels of the earth and get out the coveted ore;\r\nand now I learned that the burrowing was only half the work; and that to\r\nget the silver out of the ore was the dreary and laborious other half of\r\nit. We had to turn out at six in the morning and keep at it till dark.\r\nThis mill was a six-stamp affair, driven by steam. Six tall, upright\r\nrods of iron, as large as a man\xe2\x80\x99s ankle, and heavily shod with a mass of\r\niron and steel at their lower ends, were framed together like a gate,\r\nand these rose and fell, one after the other, in a ponderous dance, in\r\nan iron box called a \xe2\x80\x9cbattery.\xe2\x80\x9d Each of these rods or stamps weighed six\r\nhundred pounds. One of us stood by the battery all day long, breaking up\r\nmasses of silver-bearing rock with a sledge and shoveling it into the\r\nbattery. The ceaseless dance of the stamps pulverized the rock to\r\npowder, and a stream of water that trickled into the battery turned it\r\nto a creamy paste. The minutest particles were driven through a fine\r\nwire screen which fitted close around the battery, and were washed into\r\ngreat tubs warmed by super-heated steam\xe2\x80\x94amalgamating pans, they are\r\ncalled. The mass of pulp in the pans was kept constantly stirred up by\r\nrevolving \xe2\x80\x9cmullers.\xe2\x80\x9d A quantity of quicksilver was kept always in the\r\nbattery, and this seized some of the liberated gold and silver particles\r\nand held on to them; quicksilver was shaken in a fine shower into the\r\npans, also, about every half hour, through a buckskin sack. Quantities\r\nof coarse salt and sulphate of copper were added, from time to time to\r\nassist the amalgamation by destroying base metals which coated the gold\r\nand silver and would not let it unite with the quicksilver.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n253.jpg (73K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAll these tiresome things we had to attend to constantly. Streams of\r\ndirty water flowed always from the pans and were carried off in broad\r\nwooden troughs to the ravine. One would not suppose that atoms of gold\r\nand silver would float on top of six inches of water, but they did; and\r\nin order to catch them, coarse blankets were laid in the troughs, and\r\nlittle obstructing \xe2\x80\x9criffles\xe2\x80\x9d charged with quicksilver were placed here\r\nand there across the troughs also. These riffles had to be cleaned and\r\nthe blankets washed out every evening, to get their precious\r\naccumulations\xe2\x80\x94and after all this eternity of trouble one third of the\r\nsilver and gold in a ton of rock would find its way to the end of the\r\ntroughs in the ravine at last and have to be worked over again some day.\r\nThere is nothing so aggravating as silver milling. There never was any\r\nidle time in that mill. There was always something to do. It is a pity\r\nthat Adam could not have gone straight out of Eden into a quartz mill,\r\nin order to understand the full force of his doom to \xe2\x80\x9cearn his bread by\r\nthe sweat of his brow.\xe2\x80\x9d Every now and then, during the day, we had to\r\nscoop some pulp out of the pans, and tediously \xe2\x80\x9cwash\xe2\x80\x9d it in a horn\r\nspoon\xe2\x80\x94wash it little by little over the edge till at last nothing was\r\nleft but some little dull globules of quicksilver in the bottom. If they\r\nwere soft and yielding, the pan needed some salt or some sulphate of\r\ncopper or some other chemical rubbish to assist digestion; if they were\r\ncrisp to the touch and would retain a dint, they were freighted with all\r\nthe silver and gold they could seize and hold, and consequently the pan\r\nneeded a fresh charge of quicksilver. When there was nothing else to do,\r\none could always \xe2\x80\x9cscreen tailings.\xe2\x80\x9d That is to say, he could shovel up\r\nthe dried sand that had washed down to the ravine through the troughs\r\nand dash it against an upright wire screen to free it from pebbles and\r\nprepare it for working over.\r\n\r\nThe process of amalgamation differed in the various mills, and this\r\nincluded changes in style of pans and other machinery, and a great\r\ndiversity of opinion existed as to the best in use, but none of the\r\nmethods employed, involved the principle of milling ore without\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cscreening the tailings.\xe2\x80\x9d Of all recreations in the world, screening\r\ntailings on a hot day, with a long-handled shovel, is the most\r\nundesirable.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n254.jpg (78K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the end of the week the machinery was stopped and we \xe2\x80\x9ccleaned up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThat is to say, we got the pulp out of the pans and batteries, and\r\nwashed the mud patiently away till nothing was left but the long\r\naccumulating mass of quicksilver, with its imprisoned treasures. This we\r\nmade into heavy, compact snow-balls, and piled them up in a bright,\r\nluxurious heap for inspection. Making these snow-balls cost me a fine\r\ngold ring\xe2\x80\x94that and ignorance together; for the quicksilver invaded the\r\nring with the same facility with which water saturates a\r\nsponge\xe2\x80\x94separated its particles and the ring crumbled to pieces.\r\n\r\nWe put our pile of quicksilver balls into an iron retort that had a pipe\r\nleading from it to a pail of water, and then applied a roasting heat.\r\nThe quicksilver turned to vapor, escaped through the pipe into the pail,\r\nand the water turned it into good wholesome quicksilver again.\r\nQuicksilver is very costly, and they never waste it. On opening the\r\nretort, there was our week\xe2\x80\x99s work\xe2\x80\x94a lump of pure white, frosty looking\r\nsilver, twice as large as a man\xe2\x80\x99s head. Perhaps a fifth of the mass was\r\ngold, but the color of it did not show\xe2\x80\x94would not have shown if two\r\nthirds of it had been gold. We melted it up and made a solid brick of it\r\nby pouring it into an iron brick-mould.\r\n\r\nBy such a tedious and laborious process were silver bricks obtained.\r\nThis mill was but one of many others in operation at the time. The first\r\none in Nevada was built at Egan Canyon and was a small insignificant\r\naffair and compared most unfavorably with some of the immense\r\nestablishments afterwards located at Virginia City and elsewhere.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n256.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFrom our bricks a little corner was chipped off for the \xe2\x80\x9cfire-assay\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nmethod used to determine the proportions of gold, silver and base metals\r\nin the mass. This is an interesting process. The chip is hammered out as\r\nthin as paper and weighed on scales so fine and sensitive that if you\r\nweigh a two-inch scrap of paper on them and then write your name on the\r\npaper with a course, soft pencil and weigh it again, the scales will\r\ntake marked notice of the addition.\r\n\r\nThen a little lead (also weighed) is rolled up with the flake of silver\r\nand the two are melted at a great heat in a small vessel called a cupel,\r\nmade by compressing bone ashes into a cup-shape in a steel mold. The\r\nbase metals oxydize and are absorbed with the lead into the pores of the\r\ncupel. A button or globule of perfectly pure gold and silver is left\r\nbehind, and by weighing it and noting the loss, the assayer knows the\r\nproportion of base metal the brick contains. He has to separate the gold\r\nfrom the silver now. The button is hammered out flat and thin, put in\r\nthe furnace and kept some time at a red heat; after cooling it off it is\r\nrolled up like a quill and heated in a glass vessel containing nitric\r\nacid; the acid dissolves the silver and leaves the gold pure and ready\r\nto be weighed on its own merits. Then salt water is poured into the\r\nvessel containing the dissolved silver and the silver returns to\r\npalpable form again and sinks to the bottom. Nothing now remains but to\r\nweigh it; then the proportions of the several metals contained in the\r\nbrick are known, and the assayer stamps the value of the brick upon its\r\nsurface.\r\n\r\nThe sagacious reader will know now, without being told, that the\r\nspeculative miner, in getting a \xe2\x80\x9cfire-assay\xe2\x80\x9d made of a piece of rock\r\nfrom his mine (to help him sell the same), was not in the habit of\r\npicking out the least valuable fragment of rock on his dump-pile, but\r\nquite the contrary. I have seen men hunt over a pile of nearly worthless\r\nquartz for an hour, and at last find a little piece as large as a\r\nfilbert, which was rich in gold and silver\xe2\x80\x94and this was reserved for a\r\nfire-assay! Of course the fire-assay would demonstrate that a ton of\r\nsuch rock would yield hundreds of dollars\xe2\x80\x94and on such assays many an\r\nutterly worthless mine was sold.\r\n\r\nAssaying was a good business, and so some men engaged in it,\r\noccasionally, who were not strictly scientific and capable. One assayer\r\ngot such rich results out of all specimens brought to him that in time\r\nhe acquired almost a monopoly of the business. But like all men who\r\nachieve success, he became an object of envy and suspicion. The other\r\nassayers entered into a conspiracy against him, and let some prominent\r\ncitizens into the secret in order to show that they meant fairly. Then\r\nthey broke a little fragment off a carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s grindstone and got a\r\nstranger to take it to the popular scientist and get it assayed. In the\r\ncourse of an hour the result came\xe2\x80\x94whereby it appeared that a ton of that\r\nrock would yield $1,184.40 in silver and $366.36 in gold!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n257.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDue publication of the whole matter was made in the paper, and the\r\npopular assayer left town \xe2\x80\x9cbetween two days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI will remark, in passing, that I only remained in the milling business\r\none week. I told my employer I could not stay longer without an advance\r\nin my wages; that I liked quartz milling, indeed was infatuated with it;\r\nthat I had never before grown so tenderly attached to an occupation in\r\nso short a time; that nothing, it seemed to me, gave such scope to\r\nintellectual activity as feeding a battery and screening tailings, and\r\nnothing so stimulated the moral attributes as retorting bullion and\r\nwashing blankets\xe2\x80\x94still, I felt constrained to ask an increase of salary.\r\nHe said he was paying me ten dollars a week, and thought it a good round\r\nsum. How much did I want?\r\n\r\nI said about _four hundred thousand_ dollars a month, and board, was\r\nabout all I could reasonably ask, considering the hard times.\r\n\r\nI was ordered off the premises! And yet, when I look back to those days\r\nand call to mind the exceeding hardness of the labor I performed in that\r\nmill, I only regret that I did not ask him seven hundred thousand.\r\n\r\nShortly after this I began to grow crazy, along with the rest of the\r\npopulation, about the mysterious and wonderful \xe2\x80\x9ccement mine,\xe2\x80\x9d and to\r\nmake preparations to take advantage of any opportunity that might offer\r\nto go and help hunt for it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was somewhere in the neighborhood of Mono Lake that the marvellous\r\nWhiteman cement mine was supposed to lie. Every now and then it would be\r\nreported that Mr. W. had passed stealthily through Esmeralda at dead of\r\nnight, in disguise, and then we would have a wild excitement\xe2\x80\x94because he\r\nmust be steering for his secret mine, and now was the time to follow\r\nhim. In less than three hours after daylight all the horses and mules\r\nand donkeys in the vicinity would be bought, hired or stolen, and half\r\nthe community would be off for the mountains, following in the wake of\r\nWhiteman. But W. would drift about through the mountain gorges for days\r\ntogether, in a purposeless sort of way, until the provisions of the\r\nminers ran out, and they would have to go back home. I have known it\r\nreported at eleven at night, in a large mining camp, that Whiteman had\r\njust passed through, and in two hours the streets, so quiet before,\r\nwould be swarming with men and animals. Every individual would be trying\r\nto be very secret, but yet venturing to whisper to just one neighbor\r\nthat W. had passed through. And long before daylight\xe2\x80\x94this in the dead of\r\nWinter\xe2\x80\x94the stampede would be complete, the camp deserted, and the whole\r\npopulation gone chasing after W.\r\n\r\nThe tradition was that in the early immigration, more than twenty years\r\nago, three young Germans, brothers, who had survived an Indian massacre\r\non the Plains, wandered on foot through the deserts, avoiding all trails\r\nand roads, and simply holding a westerly direction and hoping to find\r\nCalifornia before they starved, or died of fatigue. And in a gorge in\r\nthe mountains they sat down to rest one day, when one of them noticed a\r\ncurious vein of cement running along the ground, shot full of lumps of\r\ndull yellow metal. They saw that it was gold, and that here was a\r\nfortune to be acquired in a single day. The vein was about as wide as a\r\ncurbstone, and fully two thirds of it was pure gold. Every pound of the\r\nwonderful cement was worth well-nigh $200.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n260.jpg (59K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEach of the brothers loaded himself with about twenty-five pounds of it,\r\nand then they covered up all traces of the vein, made a rude drawing of\r\nthe locality and the principal landmarks in the vicinity, and started\r\nwestward again. But troubles thickened about them. In their wanderings\r\none brother fell and broke his leg, and the others were obliged to go on\r\nand leave him to die in the wilderness. Another, worn out and starving,\r\ngave up by and by, and laid down to die, but after two or three weeks of\r\nincredible hardships, the third reached the settlements of California\r\nexhausted, sick, and his mind deranged by his sufferings. He had thrown\r\naway all his cement but a few fragments, but these were sufficient to\r\nset everybody wild with excitement. However, he had had enough of the\r\ncement country, and nothing could induce him to lead a party thither. He\r\nwas entirely content to work on a farm for wages. But he gave Whiteman\r\nhis map, and described the cement region as well as he could and thus\r\ntransferred the curse to that gentleman\xe2\x80\x94for when I had my one accidental\r\nglimpse of Mr. W. in Esmeralda he had been hunting for the lost mine, in\r\nhunger and thirst, poverty and sickness, for twelve or thirteen years.\r\nSome people believed he had found it, but most people believed he had\r\nnot. I saw a piece of cement as large as my fist which was said to have\r\nbeen given to Whiteman by the young German, and it was of a seductive\r\nnature. Lumps of virgin gold were as thick in it as raisins in a slice\r\nof fruit cake. The privilege of working such a mine one week would be\r\nsufficient for a man of reasonable desires.\r\n\r\nA new partner of ours, a Mr. Higbie, knew Whiteman well by sight, and a\r\nfriend of ours, a Mr. Van Dorn, was well acquainted with him, and not\r\nonly that, but had Whiteman\xe2\x80\x99s promise that he should have a private hint\r\nin time to enable him to join the next cement expedition. Van Dorn had\r\npromised to extend the hint to us. One evening Higbie came in greatly\r\nexcited, and said he felt certain he had recognized Whiteman, up town,\r\ndisguised and in a pretended state of intoxication. In a little while\r\nVan Dorn arrived and confirmed the news; and so we gathered in our cabin\r\nand with heads close together arranged our plans in impressive whispers.\r\n\r\nWe were to leave town quietly, after midnight, in two or three small\r\nparties, so as not to attract attention, and meet at dawn on the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d overlooking Mono Lake, eight or nine miles distant. We were to\r\nmake no noise after starting, and not speak above a whisper under any\r\ncircumstances. It was believed that for once Whiteman\xe2\x80\x99s presence was\r\nunknown in the town and his expedition unsuspected. Our conclave broke\r\nup at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and we set about our preparation diligently and with\r\nprofound secrecy. At eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock we saddled our horses, hitched them\r\nwith their long _riatas_ (or lassos), and then brought out a side of\r\nbacon, a sack of beans, a small sack of coffee, some sugar, a hundred\r\npounds of flour in sacks, some tin cups and a coffee pot, frying pan and\r\nsome few other necessary articles. All these things were \xe2\x80\x9cpacked\xe2\x80\x9d on the\r\nback of a led horse\xe2\x80\x94and whoever has not been taught, by a Spanish adept,\r\nto pack an animal, let him never hope to do the thing by natural\r\nsmartness. That is impossible. Higbie had had some experience, but was\r\nnot perfect. He put on the pack saddle (a thing like a saw-buck), piled\r\nthe property on it and then wound a rope all over and about it and under\r\nit, \xe2\x80\x9cevery which way,\xe2\x80\x9d taking a hitch in it every now and then, and\r\noccasionally surging back on it till the horse\xe2\x80\x99s sides sunk in and he\r\ngasped for breath\xe2\x80\x94but every time the lashings grew tight in one place\r\nthey loosened in another. We never did get the load tight all over, but\r\nwe got it so that it would do, after a fashion, and then we started, in\r\nsingle file, close order, and without a word. It was a dark night. We\r\nkept the middle of the road, and proceeded in a slow walk past the rows\r\nof cabins, and whenever a miner came to his door I trembled for fear the\r\nlight would shine on us and excite curiosity. But nothing happened. We\r\nbegan the long winding ascent of the canyon, toward the \xe2\x80\x9cdivide,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\npresently the cabins began to grow infrequent, and the intervals between\r\nthem wider and wider, and then I began to breathe tolerably freely and\r\nfeel less like a thief and a murderer. I was in the rear, leading the\r\npack horse. As the ascent grew steeper he grew proportionately less\r\nsatisfied with his cargo, and began to pull back on his _riata_\r\noccasionally and delay progress. My comrades were passing out of sight\r\nin the gloom. I was getting anxious. I coaxed and bullied the pack horse\r\ntill I presently got him into a trot, and then the tin cups and pans\r\nstrung about his person frightened him and he ran. His _riata_ was wound\r\naround the pummel of my saddle, and so, as he went by he dragged me from\r\nmy horse and the two animals traveled briskly on without me. But I was\r\nnot alone\xe2\x80\x94the loosened cargo tumbled overboard from the pack horse and\r\nfell close to me. It was abreast of almost the last cabin.\r\n\r\nA miner came out and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was thirty steps from him, and knew he could not see me, it was so\r\nvery dark in the shadow of the mountain. So I lay still. Another head\r\nappeared in the light of the cabin door, and presently the two men\r\nwalked toward me. They stopped within ten steps of me, and one said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt! Listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n263.jpg (75K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI could not have been in a more distressed state if I had been escaping\r\njustice with a price on my head. Then the miners appeared to sit down on\r\na boulder, though I could not see them distinctly enough to be very sure\r\nwhat they did. One said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard a noise, as plain as I ever heard anything. It seemed to be\r\nabout there\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA stone whizzed by my head. I flattened myself out in the dust like a\r\npostage stamp, and thought to myself if he mended his aim ever so little\r\nhe would probably hear another noise. In my heart, now, I execrated\r\nsecret expeditions. I promised myself that this should be my last,\r\nthough the Sierras were ribbed with cement veins. Then one of the men\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what! Welch knew what he was talking about when he said\r\nhe saw Whiteman to-day. I heard horses\xe2\x80\x94that was the noise. I am going\r\ndown to Welch\xe2\x80\x99s, right away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey left and I was glad. I did not care whither they went, so they\r\nwent. I was willing they should visit Welch, and the sooner the better.\r\n\r\nAs soon as they closed their cabin door my comrades emerged from the\r\ngloom; they had caught the horses and were waiting for a clear coast\r\nagain. We remounted the cargo on the pack horse and got under way, and\r\nas day broke we reached the \xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d and joined Van Dorn. Then we\r\njourneyed down into the valley of the Lake, and feeling secure, we\r\nhalted to cook breakfast, for we were tired and sleepy and hungry. Three\r\nhours later the rest of the population filed over the \xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d in a long\r\nprocession, and drifted off out of sight around the borders of the Lake!\r\n\r\nWhether or not my accident had produced this result we never knew, but\r\nat least one thing was certain\xe2\x80\x94the secret was out and Whiteman would not\r\nenter upon a search for the cement mine this time. We were filled with\r\nchagrin.\r\n\r\nWe held a council and decided to make the best of our misfortune and\r\nenjoy a week\xe2\x80\x99s holiday on the borders of the curious Lake. Mono, it is\r\nsometimes called, and sometimes the \xe2\x80\x9cDead Sea of California.\xe2\x80\x9d It is one\r\nof the strangest freaks of Nature to be found in any land, but it is\r\nhardly ever mentioned in print and very seldom visited, because it lies\r\naway off the usual routes of travel and besides is so difficult to get\r\nat that only men content to endure the roughest life will consent to\r\ntake upon themselves the discomforts of such a trip. On the morning of\r\nour second day, we traveled around to a remote and particularly wild\r\nspot on the borders of the Lake, where a stream of fresh, ice-cold water\r\nentered it from the mountain side, and then we went regularly into camp.\r\nWe hired a large boat and two shot-guns from a lonely ranchman who lived\r\nsome ten miles further on, and made ready for comfort and recreation. We\r\nsoon got thoroughly acquainted with the Lake and all its peculiarities.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nMono Lake lies in a lifeless, treeless, hideous desert, eight thousand\r\nfeet above the level of the sea, and is guarded by mountains two\r\nthousand feet higher, whose summits are always clothed in clouds. This\r\nsolemn, silent, sailless sea\xe2\x80\x94this lonely tenant of the loneliest spot on\r\nearth\xe2\x80\x94is little graced with the picturesque. It is an unpretending\r\nexpanse of grayish water, about a hundred miles in circumference, with\r\ntwo islands in its centre, mere upheavals of rent and scorched and\r\nblistered lava, snowed over with gray banks and drifts of pumice-stone\r\nand ashes, the winding sheet of the dead volcano, whose vast crater the\r\nlake has seized upon and occupied.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n265.jpg (138K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe lake is two hundred feet deep, and its sluggish waters are so strong\r\nwith alkali that if you only dip the most hopelessly soiled garment into\r\nthem once or twice, and wring it out, it will be found as clean as if it\r\nhad been through the ablest of washerwomen\xe2\x80\x99s hands. While we camped\r\nthere our laundry work was easy. We tied the week\xe2\x80\x99s washing astern of\r\nour boat, and sailed a quarter of a mile, and the job was complete, all\r\nto the wringing out. If we threw the water on our heads and gave them a\r\nrub or so, the white lather would pile up three inches high. This water\r\nis not good for bruised places and abrasions of the skin. We had a\r\nvaluable dog. He had raw places on him. He had more raw places on him\r\nthan sound ones. He was the rawest dog I almost ever saw. He jumped\r\noverboard one day to get away from the flies. But it was bad judgment.\r\nIn his condition, it would have been just as comfortable to jump into\r\nthe fire.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n266a.jpg (44K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe alkali water nipped him in all the raw places simultaneously, and he\r\nstruck out for the shore with considerable interest. He yelped and\r\nbarked and howled as he went\xe2\x80\x94and by the time he got to the shore there\r\nwas no bark to him\xe2\x80\x94for he had barked the bark all out of his inside, and\r\nthe alkali water had cleaned the bark all off his outside, and he\r\nprobably wished he had never embarked in any such enterprise. He ran\r\nround and round in a circle, and pawed the earth and clawed the air, and\r\nthrew double somersaults, sometimes backward and sometimes forward, in\r\nthe most extraordinary manner. He was not a demonstrative dog, as a\r\ngeneral thing, but rather of a grave and serious turn of mind, and I\r\nnever saw him take so much interest in anything before. He finally\r\nstruck out over the mountains, at a gait which we estimated at about two\r\nhundred and fifty miles an hour, and he is going yet. This was about\r\nnine years ago. We look for what is left of him along here every day.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n266b.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA white man cannot drink the water of Mono Lake, for it is nearly pure\r\nlye. It is said that the Indians in the vicinity drink it sometimes,\r\nthough. It is not improbable, for they are among the purest liars I ever\r\nsaw. [There will be no additional charge for this joke, except to\r\nparties requiring an explanation of it. This joke has received high\r\ncommendation from some of the ablest minds of the age.]\r\n\r\nThere are no fish in Mono Lake\xe2\x80\x94no frogs, no snakes, no\r\npolliwigs\xe2\x80\x94nothing, in fact, that goes to make life desirable. Millions\r\nof wild ducks and sea-gulls swim about the surface, but no living thing\r\nexists _under_ the surface, except a white feathery sort of worm, one\r\nhalf an inch long, which looks like a bit of white thread frayed out at\r\nthe sides. If you dip up a gallon of water, you will get about fifteen\r\nthousand of these. They give to the water a sort of grayish-white\r\nappearance. Then there is a fly, which looks something like our house\r\nfly. These settle on the beach to eat the worms that wash ashore\xe2\x80\x94and any\r\ntime, you can see there a belt of flies an inch deep and six feet wide,\r\nand this belt extends clear around the lake\xe2\x80\x94a belt of flies one hundred\r\nmiles long. If you throw a stone among them, they swarm up so thick that\r\nthey look dense, like a cloud. You can hold them under water as long as\r\nyou please\xe2\x80\x94they do not mind it\xe2\x80\x94they are only proud of it. When you let\r\nthem go, they pop up to the surface as dry as a patent office report,\r\nand walk off as unconcernedly as if they had been educated especially\r\nwith a view to affording instructive entertainment to man in that\r\nparticular way. Providence leaves nothing to go by chance. All things\r\nhave their uses and their part and proper place in Nature\xe2\x80\x99s economy: the\r\nducks eat the flies\xe2\x80\x94the flies eat the worms\xe2\x80\x94the Indians eat all\r\nthree\xe2\x80\x94the wild cats eat the Indians\xe2\x80\x94the white folks eat the wild\r\ncats\xe2\x80\x94and thus all things are lovely.\r\n\r\nMono Lake is a hundred miles in a straight line from the ocean\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nbetween it and the ocean are one or two ranges of mountains\xe2\x80\x94yet\r\nthousands of sea-gulls go there every season to lay their eggs and rear\r\ntheir young. One would as soon expect to find sea-gulls in Kansas. And\r\nin this connection let us observe another instance of Nature\xe2\x80\x99s wisdom.\r\nThe islands in the lake being merely huge masses of lava, coated over\r\nwith ashes and pumice-stone, and utterly innocent of vegetation or\r\nanything that would burn; and sea-gull\xe2\x80\x99s eggs being entirely useless to\r\nanybody unless they be cooked, Nature has provided an unfailing spring\r\nof boiling water on the largest island, and you can put your eggs in\r\nthere, and in four minutes you can boil them as hard as any statement I\r\nhave made during the past fifteen years. Within ten feet of the boiling\r\nspring is a spring of pure cold water, sweet and wholesome.\r\n\r\nSo, in that island you get your board and washing free of charge\xe2\x80\x94and if\r\nnature had gone further and furnished a nice American hotel clerk who\r\nwas crusty and disobliging, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about the time\r\ntables, or the railroad routes\xe2\x80\x94or\xe2\x80\x94anything\xe2\x80\x94and was proud of it\xe2\x80\x94I would\r\nnot wish for a more desirable boarding-house.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n268.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHalf a dozen little mountain brooks flow into Mono Lake, but not a\r\nstream of any kind flows out of it. It neither rises nor falls,\r\napparently, and what it does with its surplus water is a dark and bloody\r\nmystery.\r\n\r\nThere are only two seasons in the region round about Mono Lake\xe2\x80\x94and these\r\nare, the breaking up of one Winter and the beginning of the next. More\r\nthan once (in Esmeralda) I have seen a perfectly blistering morning open\r\nup with the thermometer at ninety degrees at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and seen the\r\nsnow fall fourteen inches deep and that same identical thermometer go\r\ndown to forty-four degrees under shelter, before nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night.\r\nUnder favorable circumstances it snows at least once in every single\r\nmonth in the year, in the little town of Mono. So uncertain is the\r\nclimate in Summer that a lady who goes out visiting cannot hope to be\r\nprepared for all emergencies unless she takes her fan under one arm and\r\nher snow shoes under the other. When they have a Fourth of July\r\nprocession it generally snows on them, and they do say that as a general\r\nthing when a man calls for a brandy toddy there, the bar keeper chops it\r\noff with a hatchet and wraps it up in a paper, like maple sugar. And it\r\nis further reported that the old soakers haven\xe2\x80\x99t any teeth\xe2\x80\x94wore them out\r\neating gin cocktails and brandy punches. I do not endorse that\r\nstatement\xe2\x80\x94I simply give it for what it is worth\xe2\x80\x94and it is worth\xe2\x80\x94well, I\r\nshould say, millions, to any man who can believe it without straining\r\nhimself. But I do endorse the snow on the Fourth of July\xe2\x80\x94because I know\r\nthat to be true.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock one blistering hot morning\xe2\x80\x94for it was now dead\r\nsummer time\xe2\x80\x94Higbie and I took the boat and started on a voyage of\r\ndiscovery to the two islands. We had often longed to do this, but had\r\nbeen deterred by the fear of storms; for they were frequent, and severe\r\nenough to capsize an ordinary row-boat like ours without great\r\ndifficulty\xe2\x80\x94and once capsized, death would ensue in spite of the bravest\r\nswimming, for that venomous water would eat a man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes out like fire,\r\nand burn him out inside, too, if he shipped a sea. It was called twelve\r\nmiles, straight out to the islands\xe2\x80\x94a long pull and a warm one\xe2\x80\x94but the\r\nmorning was so quiet and sunny, and the lake so smooth and glassy and\r\ndead, that we could not resist the temptation. So we filled two large\r\ntin canteens with water (since we were not acquainted with the locality\r\nof the spring said to exist on the large island), and started. Higbie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrawny muscles gave the boat good speed, but by the time we reached our\r\ndestination we judged that we had pulled nearer fifteen miles than\r\ntwelve.\r\n\r\nWe landed on the big island and went ashore. We tried the water in the\r\ncanteens, now, and found that the sun had spoiled it; it was so brackish\r\nthat we could not drink it; so we poured it out and began a search for\r\nthe spring\xe2\x80\x94for thirst augments fast as soon as it is apparent that one\r\nhas no means at hand of quenching it. The island was a long, moderately\r\nhigh hill of ashes\xe2\x80\x94nothing but gray ashes and pumice-stone, in which we\r\nsunk to our knees at every step\xe2\x80\x94and all around the top was a forbidding\r\nwall of scorched and blasted rocks. When we reached the top and got\r\nwithin the wall, we found simply a shallow, far-reaching basin, carpeted\r\nwith ashes, and here and there a patch of fine sand. In places,\r\npicturesque jets of steam shot up out of crevices, giving evidence that\r\nalthough this ancient crater had gone out of active business, there was\r\nstill some fire left in its furnaces. Close to one of these jets of\r\nsteam stood the only tree on the island\xe2\x80\x94a small pine of most graceful\r\nshape and most faultless symmetry; its color was a brilliant green, for\r\nthe steam drifted unceasingly through its branches and kept them always\r\nmoist. It contrasted strangely enough, did this vigorous and beautiful\r\noutcast, with its dead and dismal surroundings. It was like a cheerful\r\nspirit in a mourning household.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n271.jpg (56K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe hunted for the spring everywhere, traversing the full length of the\r\nisland (two or three miles), and crossing it twice\xe2\x80\x94climbing ash-hills\r\npatiently, and then sliding down the other side in a sitting posture,\r\nplowing up smothering volumes of gray dust. But we found nothing but\r\nsolitude, ashes and a heart-breaking silence. Finally we noticed that\r\nthe wind had risen, and we forgot our thirst in a solicitude of greater\r\nimportance; for, the lake being quiet, we had not taken pains about\r\nsecuring the boat. We hurried back to a point overlooking our landing\r\nplace, and then\xe2\x80\x94but mere words cannot describe our dismay\xe2\x80\x94the boat was\r\ngone! The chances were that there was not another boat on the entire\r\nlake. The situation was not comfortable\xe2\x80\x94in truth, to speak plainly, it\r\nwas frightful. We were prisoners on a desolate island, in aggravating\r\nproximity to friends who were for the present helpless to aid us; and\r\nwhat was still more uncomfortable was the reflection that we had neither\r\nfood nor water. But presently we sighted the boat. It was drifting\r\nalong, leisurely, about fifty yards from shore, tossing in a foamy sea.\r\nIt drifted, and continued to drift, but at the same safe distance from\r\nland, and we walked along abreast it and waited for fortune to favor us.\r\nAt the end of an hour it approached a jutting cape, and Higbie ran ahead\r\nand posted himself on the utmost verge and prepared for the assault. If\r\nwe failed there, there was no hope for us. It was driving gradually\r\nshoreward all the time, now; but whether it was driving fast enough to\r\nmake the connection or not was the momentous question. When it got\r\nwithin thirty steps of Higbie I was so excited that I fancied I could\r\nhear my own heart beat. When, a little later, it dragged slowly along\r\nand seemed about to go by, only one little yard out of reach, it seemed\r\nas if my heart stood still; and when it was exactly abreast him and\r\nbegan to widen away, and he still standing like a watching statue, I\r\nknew my heart did stop. But when he gave a great spring, the next\r\ninstant, and lit fairly in the stern, I discharged a war-whoop that woke\r\nthe solitudes!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n273.jpg (62K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut it dulled my enthusiasm, presently, when he told me he had not been\r\ncaring whether the boat came within jumping distance or not, so that it\r\npassed within eight or ten yards of him, for he had made up his mind to\r\nshut his eyes and mouth and swim that trifling distance. Imbecile that I\r\nwas, I had not thought of that. It was only a long swim that could be\r\nfatal.\r\n\r\nThe sea was running high and the storm increasing. It was growing late,\r\ntoo\xe2\x80\x94three or four in the afternoon. Whether to venture toward the\r\nmainland or not, was a question of some moment. But we were so\r\ndistressed by thirst that we decide to try it, and so Higbie fell to\r\nwork and I took the steering-oar. When we had pulled a mile,\r\nlaboriously, we were evidently in serious peril, for the storm had\r\ngreatly augmented; the billows ran very high and were capped with\r\nfoaming crests, the heavens were hung with black, and the wind blew with\r\ngreat fury. We would have gone back, now, but we did not dare to turn\r\nthe boat around, because as soon as she got in the trough of the sea she\r\nwould upset, of course. Our only hope lay in keeping her head-on to the\r\nseas. It was hard work to do this, she plunged so, and so beat and\r\nbelabored the billows with her rising and falling bows. Now and then one\r\nof Higbie\xe2\x80\x99s oars would trip on the top of a wave, and the other one\r\nwould snatch the boat half around in spite of my cumbersome steering\r\napparatus. We were drenched by the sprays constantly, and the boat\r\noccasionally shipped water. By and by, powerful as my comrade was, his\r\ngreat exertions began to tell on him, and he was anxious that I should\r\nchange places with him till he could rest a little. But I told him this\r\nwas impossible; for if the steering oar were dropped a moment while we\r\nchanged, the boat would slue around into the trough of the sea, capsize,\r\nand in less than five minutes we would have a hundred gallons of soap-\r\nsuds in us and be eaten up so quickly that we could not even be present\r\nat our own inquest.\r\n\r\nBut things cannot last always. Just as the darkness shut down we came\r\nbooming into port, head on. Higbie dropped his oars to hurrah\xe2\x80\x94I dropped\r\nmine to help\xe2\x80\x94the sea gave the boat a twist, and over she went!\r\n\r\nThe agony that alkali water inflicts on bruises, chafes and blistered\r\nhands, is unspeakable, and nothing but greasing all over will modify\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94but we ate, drank and slept well, that night, notwithstanding.\r\n\r\nIn speaking of the peculiarities of Mono Lake, I ought to have mentioned\r\nthat at intervals all around its shores stand picturesque turret-looking\r\nmasses and clusters of a whitish, coarse-grained rock that resembles\r\ninferior mortar dried hard; and if one breaks off fragments of this rock\r\nhe will find perfectly shaped and thoroughly petrified gulls\xe2\x80\x99 eggs\r\ndeeply imbedded in the mass. How did they get there? I simply state the\r\nfact\xe2\x80\x94for it is a fact\xe2\x80\x94and leave the geological reader to crack the nut\r\nat his leisure and solve the problem after his own fashion.\r\n\r\nAt the end of a week we adjourned to the Sierras on a fishing excursion,\r\nand spent several days in camp under snowy Castle Peak, and fished\r\nsuccessfully for trout in a bright, miniature lake whose surface was\r\nbetween ten and eleven thousand feet above the level of the sea; cooling\r\nourselves during the hot August noons by sitting on snow banks ten feet\r\ndeep, under whose sheltering edges fine grass and dainty flowers\r\nflourished luxuriously; and at night entertaining ourselves by almost\r\nfreezing to death. Then we returned to Mono Lake, and finding that the\r\ncement excitement was over for the present, packed up and went back to\r\nEsmeralda. Mr. Ballou reconnoitred awhile, and not liking the prospect,\r\nset out alone for Humboldt.\r\n\r\nAbout this time occurred a little incident which has always had a sort\r\nof interest to me, from the fact that it came so near \xe2\x80\x9cinstigating\xe2\x80\x9d my\r\nfuneral. At a time when an Indian attack had been expected, the citizens\r\nhid their gunpowder where it would be safe and yet convenient to hand\r\nwhen wanted. A neighbor of ours hid six cans of rifle powder in the\r\nbake-oven of an old discarded cooking stove which stood on the open\r\nground near a frame out-house or shed, and from and after that day never\r\nthought of it again. We hired a half-tamed Indian to do some washing for\r\nus, and he took up quarters under the shed with his tub. The ancient\r\nstove reposed within six feet of him, and before his face. Finally it\r\noccurred to him that hot water would be better than cold, and he went\r\nout and fired up under that forgotten powder magazine and set on a\r\nkettle of water. Then he returned to his tub.\r\n\r\nI entered the shed presently and threw down some more clothes, and was\r\nabout to speak to him when the stove blew up with a prodigious crash,\r\nand disappeared, leaving not a splinter behind. Fragments of it fell in\r\nthe streets full two hundred yards away. Nearly a third of the shed roof\r\nover our heads was destroyed, and one of the stove lids, after cutting a\r\nsmall stanchion half in two in front of the Indian, whizzed between us\r\nand drove partly through the weather-boarding beyond. I was as white as\r\na sheet and as weak as a kitten and speechless. But the Indian betrayed\r\nno trepidation, no distress, not even discomfort. He simply stopped\r\nwashing, leaned forward and surveyed the clean, blank ground a moment,\r\nand then remarked:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n275.jpg (68K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMph! Dam stove heap gone!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and resumed his scrubbing as placidly as if\r\nit were an entirely customary thing for a stove to do. I will explain,\r\nthat \xe2\x80\x9cheap\xe2\x80\x9d is \xe2\x80\x9cInjun-English\xe2\x80\x9d for \xe2\x80\x9cvery much.\xe2\x80\x9d The reader will perceive\r\nthe exhaustive expressiveness of it in the present instance.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n276.jpg (30K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL.\r\n\r\n\r\nI now come to a curious episode\xe2\x80\x94the most curious, I think, that had yet\r\naccented my slothful, valueless, heedless career. Out of a hillside\r\ntoward the upper end of the town, projected a wall of reddish looking\r\nquartz-croppings, the exposed comb of a silver-bearing ledge that\r\nextended deep down into the earth, of course. It was owned by a company\r\nentitled the \xe2\x80\x9cWide West.\xe2\x80\x9d There was a shaft sixty or seventy feet deep\r\non the under side of the croppings, and everybody was acquainted with\r\nthe rock that came from it\xe2\x80\x94and tolerably rich rock it was, too, but\r\nnothing extraordinary. I will remark here, that although to the\r\ninexperienced stranger all the quartz of a particular \xe2\x80\x9cdistrict\xe2\x80\x9d looks\r\nabout alike, an old resident of the camp can take a glance at a mixed\r\npile of rock, separate the fragments and tell you which mine each came\r\nfrom, as easily as a confectioner can separate and classify the various\r\nkinds and qualities of candy in a mixed heap of the article.\r\n\r\nAll at once the town was thrown into a state of extraordinary\r\nexcitement. In mining parlance the Wide West had \xe2\x80\x9cstruck it rich!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nEverybody went to see the new developments, and for some days there was\r\nsuch a crowd of people about the Wide West shaft that a stranger would\r\nhave supposed there was a mass meeting in session there. No other topic\r\nwas discussed but the rich strike, and nobody thought or dreamed about\r\nanything else. Every man brought away a specimen, ground it up in a hand\r\nmortar, washed it out in his horn spoon, and glared speechless upon the\r\nmarvelous result. It was not hard rock, but black, decomposed stuff\r\nwhich could be crumbled in the hand like a baked potato, and when spread\r\nout on a paper exhibited a thick sprinkling of gold and particles of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnative\xe2\x80\x9d silver. Higbie brought a handful to the cabin, and when he had\r\nwashed it out his amazement was beyond description. Wide West stock\r\nsoared skywards. It was said that repeated offers had been made for it\r\nat a thousand dollars a foot, and promptly refused. We have all had the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cblues\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the mere sky-blues\xe2\x80\x94but mine were indigo, now\xe2\x80\x94because I did not\r\nown in the Wide West. The world seemed hollow to me, and existence a\r\ngrief. I lost my appetite, and ceased to take an interest in anything.\r\nStill I had to stay, and listen to other people\xe2\x80\x99s rejoicings, because I\r\nhad no money to get out of the camp with.\r\n\r\nThe Wide West company put a stop to the carrying away of \xe2\x80\x9cspecimens,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand well they might, for every handful of the ore was worth a sum of\r\nsome consequence. To show the exceeding value of the ore, I will remark\r\nthat a sixteen-hundred-pounds parcel of it was sold, just as it lay, at\r\nthe mouth of the shaft, at _one dollar a pound_; and the man who bought\r\nit \xe2\x80\x9cpacked\xe2\x80\x9d it on mules a hundred and fifty or two hundred miles, over\r\nthe mountains, to San Francisco, satisfied that it would yield at a rate\r\nthat would richly compensate him for his trouble. The Wide West people\r\nalso commanded their foreman to refuse any but their own operatives\r\npermission to enter the mine at any time or for any purpose. I kept up\r\nmy \xe2\x80\x9cblue\xe2\x80\x9d meditations and Higbie kept up a deal of thinking, too, but of\r\na different sort. He puzzled over the \xe2\x80\x9crock,\xe2\x80\x9d examined it with a glass,\r\ninspected it in different lights and from different points of view, and\r\nafter each experiment delivered himself, in soliloquy, of one and the\r\nsame unvarying opinion in the same unvarying formula:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is _not_ Wide West rock!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said once or twice that he meant to have a look into the Wide West\r\nshaft if he got shot for it. I was wretched, and did not care whether he\r\ngot a look into it or not. He failed that day, and tried again at night;\r\nfailed again; got up at dawn and tried, and failed again. Then he lay in\r\nambush in the sage brush hour after hour, waiting for the two or three\r\nhands to adjourn to the shade of a boulder for dinner; made a start\r\nonce, but was premature\xe2\x80\x94one of the men came back for something; tried it\r\nagain, but when almost at the mouth of the shaft, another of the men\r\nrose up from behind the boulder as if to reconnoitre, and he dropped on\r\nthe ground and lay quiet; presently he crawled on his hands and knees to\r\nthe mouth of the shaft, gave a quick glance around, then seized the rope\r\nand slid down the shaft.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n279.jpg (47K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe disappeared in the gloom of a \xe2\x80\x9cside drift\xe2\x80\x9d just as a head appeared in\r\nthe mouth of the shaft and somebody shouted \xe2\x80\x9cHello!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which he did not\r\nanswer. He was not disturbed any more. An hour later he entered the\r\ncabin, hot, red, and ready to burst with smothered excitement, and\r\nexclaimed in a stage whisper:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew it! We are rich! IT\xe2\x80\x99S A BLIND LEAD!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought the very earth reeled under me. Doubt\xe2\x80\x94conviction\xe2\x80\x94doubt\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94exultation\xe2\x80\x94hope, amazement, belief, unbelief\xe2\x80\x94every emotion\r\nimaginable swept in wild procession through my heart and brain, and I\r\ncould not speak a word. After a moment or two of this mental fury, I\r\nshook myself to rights, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay it again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s blind lead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCal. let\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94let\xe2\x80\x99s burn the house\xe2\x80\x94or kill somebody! Let\xe2\x80\x99s get out where\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s room to hurrah! But what is the use? It is a hundred times too\r\ngood to be true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a blind lead, for a million!\xe2\x80\x94hanging wall\xe2\x80\x94foot wall\xe2\x80\x94clay\r\ncasings\xe2\x80\x94everything complete!\xe2\x80\x9d He swung his hat and gave three cheers,\r\nand I cast doubt to the winds and chimed in with a will. For I was worth\r\na million dollars, and did not care \xe2\x80\x9cwhether school kept or not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n280.jpg (50K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut perhaps I ought to explain. A \xe2\x80\x9cblind lead\xe2\x80\x9d is a lead or ledge that\r\ndoes not \xe2\x80\x9ccrop out\xe2\x80\x9d above the surface. A miner does not know where to\r\nlook for such leads, but they are often stumbled upon by accident in the\r\ncourse of driving a tunnel or sinking a shaft. Higbie knew the Wide West\r\nrock perfectly well, and the more he had examined the new developments\r\nthe more he was satisfied that the ore could not have come from the Wide\r\nWest vein. And so had it occurred to him alone, of all the camp, that\r\nthere was a blind lead down in the shaft, and that even the Wide West\r\npeople themselves did not suspect it. He was right. When he went down\r\nthe shaft, he found that the blind lead held its independent way through\r\nthe Wide West vein, cutting it diagonally, and that it was enclosed in\r\nits own well-defined casing-rocks and clay. Hence it was public\r\nproperty. Both leads being perfectly well defined, it was easy for any\r\nminer to see which one belonged to the Wide West and which did not.\r\n\r\nWe thought it well to have a strong friend, and therefore we brought the\r\nforeman of the Wide West to our cabin that night and revealed the great\r\nsurprise to him. Higbie said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are going to take possession of this blind lead, record it and\r\nestablish ownership, and then forbid the Wide West company to take out\r\nany more of the rock. You cannot help your company in this matter\xe2\x80\x94nobody\r\ncan help them. I will go into the shaft with you and prove to your\r\nentire satisfaction that it _is_ a blind lead. Now we propose to take\r\nyou in with us, and claim the blind lead in our three names. What do you\r\nsay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat could a man say who had an opportunity to simply stretch forth his\r\nhand and take possession of a fortune without risk of any kind and\r\nwithout wronging any one or attaching the least taint of dishonor to his\r\nname? He could only say, \xe2\x80\x9cAgreed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe notice was put up that night, and duly spread upon the recorder\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbooks before ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock. We claimed two hundred feet each\xe2\x80\x94six hundred\r\nfeet in all\xe2\x80\x94the smallest and compactest organization in the district,\r\nand the easiest to manage.\r\n\r\nNo one can be so thoughtless as to suppose that we slept, that night.\r\nHigbie and I went to bed at midnight, but it was only to lie broad awake\r\nand think, dream, scheme. The floorless, tumble-down cabin was a palace,\r\nthe ragged gray blankets silk, the furniture rosewood and mahogany. Each\r\nnew splendor that burst out of my visions of the future whirled me\r\nbodily over in bed or jerked me to a sitting posture just as if an\r\nelectric battery had been applied to me. We shot fragments of\r\nconversation back and forth at each other. Once Higbie said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen are you going home\xe2\x80\x94to the States?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with an evolution or two, ending with a sitting position.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94but next month, at furthest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go in the same steamer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgreed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSteamer of the 10th?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. No, the 1st.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going to live?\xe2\x80\x9d said Higbie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSan Francisco.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo high\xe2\x80\x94too much climbing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94from Higbie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was thinking of Russian Hill\xe2\x80\x94building a house up there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo much climbing? Shan\xe2\x80\x99t you keep a carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course. I forgot that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPause.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n282.jpg (70K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCal., what kind of a house are you going to build?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was thinking about that. Brick, I suppose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrick\xe2\x80\x94bosh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? What is your idea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrown stone front\xe2\x80\x94French plate glass\xe2\x80\x94billiard-room off the dining-\r\nroom\xe2\x80\x94statuary and paintings\xe2\x80\x94shrubbery and two-acre grass\r\nplat\xe2\x80\x94greenhouse\xe2\x80\x94iron dog on the front stoop\xe2\x80\x94gray horses\xe2\x80\x94landau, and a\r\ncoachman with a bug on his hat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy George!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA long pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCal., when are you going to Europe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thought of that. When are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the Spring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing to be gone all summer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll summer! I shall remain there three years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94but are you in earnest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go along too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy of course you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat part of Europe shall you go to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll parts. France, England, Germany\xe2\x80\x94Spain, Italy, Switzerland, Syria,\r\nGreece, Palestine, Arabia, Persia, Egypt\xe2\x80\x94all over\xe2\x80\x94everywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m agreed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t it be a swell trip!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll spend forty or fifty thousand dollars trying to make it one,\r\nanyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother long pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigbie, we owe the butcher six dollars, and he has been threatening to\r\nstop our\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHang the butcher!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so it went on. By three o\xe2\x80\x99clock we found it was no use, and so we\r\ngot up and played cribbage and smoked pipes till sunrise. It was my week\r\nto cook. I always hated cooking\xe2\x80\x94now, I abhorred it.\r\n\r\nThe news was all over town. The former excitement was great\xe2\x80\x94this one was\r\ngreater still. I walked the streets serene and happy. Higbie said the\r\nforeman had been offered two hundred thousand dollars for his third of\r\nthe mine. I said I would like to see myself selling for any such price.\r\nMy ideas were lofty. My figure was a million. Still, I honestly believe\r\nthat if I had been offered it, it would have had no other effect than to\r\nmake me hold off for more.\r\n\r\nI found abundant enjoyment in being rich. A man offered me a three-\r\nhundred-dollar horse, and wanted to take my simple, unendorsed note for\r\nit. That brought the most realizing sense I had yet had that I was\r\nactually rich, beyond shadow of doubt. It was followed by numerous other\r\nevidences of a similar nature\xe2\x80\x94among which I may mention the fact of the\r\nbutcher leaving us a double supply of meat and saying nothing about\r\nmoney.\r\n\r\nBy the laws of the district, the \xe2\x80\x9clocators\xe2\x80\x9d or claimants of a ledge were\r\nobliged to do a fair and reasonable amount of work on their new property\r\nwithin ten days after the date of the location, or the property was\r\nforfeited, and anybody could go and seize it that chose. So we\r\ndetermined to go to work the next day. About the middle of the\r\nafternoon, as I was coming out of the post office, I met a Mr. Gardiner,\r\nwho told me that Capt. John Nye was lying dangerously ill at his place\r\n(the \xe2\x80\x9cNine-Mile Ranch\xe2\x80\x9d), and that he and his wife were not able to give\r\nhim nearly as much care and attention as his case demanded. I said if he\r\nwould wait for me a moment, I would go down and help in the sick room. I\r\nran to the cabin to tell Higbie. He was not there, but I left a note on\r\nthe table for him, and a few minutes later I left town in Gardiner\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwagon.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLI.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaptain Nye was very ill indeed, with spasmodic rheumatism. But the old\r\ngentleman was himself\xe2\x80\x94which is to say, he was kind-hearted and agreeable\r\nwhen comfortable, but a singularly violent wild-cat when things did not\r\ngo well. He would be smiling along pleasantly enough, when a sudden\r\nspasm of his disease would take him and he would go out of his smile\r\ninto a perfect fury. He would groan and wail and howl with the anguish,\r\nand fill up the odd chinks with the most elaborate profanity that strong\r\nconvictions and a fine fancy could contrive. With fair opportunity he\r\ncould swear very well and handle his adjectives with considerable\r\njudgment; but when the spasm was on him it was painful to listen to him,\r\nhe was so awkward. However, I had seen him nurse a sick man himself and\r\nput up patiently with the inconveniences of the situation, and\r\nconsequently I was willing that he should have full license now that his\r\nown turn had come. He could not disturb me, with all his raving and\r\nranting, for my mind had work on hand, and it labored on diligently,\r\nnight and day, whether my hands were idle or employed. I was altering\r\nand amending the plans for my house, and thinking over the propriety of\r\nhaving the billard-room in the attic, instead of on the same floor with\r\nthe dining-room; also, I was trying to decide between green and blue for\r\nthe upholstery of the drawing-room, for, although my preference was blue\r\nI feared it was a color that would be too easily damaged by dust and\r\nsunlight; likewise while I was content to put the coachman in a modest\r\nlivery, I was uncertain about a footman\xe2\x80\x94I needed one, and was even\r\nresolved to have one, but wished he could properly appear and perform\r\nhis functions out of livery, for I somewhat dreaded so much show; and\r\nyet, inasmuch as my late grandfather had had a coachman and such things,\r\nbut no liveries, I felt rather drawn to beat him;\xe2\x80\x94or beat his ghost, at\r\nany rate; I was also systematizing the European trip, and managed to get\r\nit all laid out, as to route and length of time to be devoted to\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94everything, with one exception\xe2\x80\x94namely, whether to cross the desert\r\nfrom Cairo to Jerusalem per camel, or go by sea to Beirut, and thence\r\ndown through the country per caravan. Meantime I was writing to the\r\nfriends at home every day, instructing them concerning all my plans and\r\nintentions, and directing them to look up a handsome homestead for my\r\nmother and agree upon a price for it against my coming, and also\r\ndirecting them to sell my share of the Tennessee land and tender the\r\nproceeds to the widows\xe2\x80\x99 and orphans\xe2\x80\x99 fund of the typographical union of\r\nwhich I had long been a member in good standing. [This Tennessee land\r\nhad been in the possession of the family many years, and promised to\r\nconfer high fortune upon us some day; it still promises it, but in a\r\nless violent way.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n287.jpg (69K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen I had been nursing the Captain nine days he was somewhat better,\r\nbut very feeble. During the afternoon we lifted him into a chair and\r\ngave him an alcoholic vapor bath, and then set about putting him on the\r\nbed again. We had to be exceedingly careful, for the least jar produced\r\npain. Gardiner had his shoulders and I his legs; in an unfortunate\r\nmoment I stumbled and the patient fell heavily on the bed in an agony of\r\ntorture. I never heard a man swear so in my life. He raved like a\r\nmaniac, and tried to snatch a revolver from the table\xe2\x80\x94but I got it. He\r\nordered me out of the house, and swore a world of oaths that he would\r\nkill me wherever he caught me when he got on his feet again. It was\r\nsimply a passing fury, and meant nothing. I knew he would forget it in\r\nan hour, and maybe be sorry for it, too; but it angered me a little, at\r\nthe moment. So much so, indeed, that I determined to go back to\r\nEsmeralda. I thought he was able to get along alone, now, since he was\r\non the war path. I took supper, and as soon as the moon rose, began my\r\nnine-mile journey, on foot.\r\n\r\nEven millionaires needed no horses, in those days, for a mere nine-mile\r\njaunt without baggage.\r\n\r\nAs I \xe2\x80\x9craised the hill\xe2\x80\x9d overlooking the town, it lacked fifteen minutes\r\nof twelve. I glanced at the hill over beyond the canyon, and in the\r\nbright moonlight saw what appeared to be about half the population of\r\nthe village massed on and around the Wide West croppings. My heart gave\r\nan exulting bound, and I said to myself, \xe2\x80\x9cThey have made a new strike\r\nto-night\xe2\x80\x94and struck it richer than ever, no doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d I started over\r\nthere, but gave it up. I said the \xe2\x80\x9cstrick\xe2\x80\x9d would keep, and I had climbed\r\nhill enough for one night. I went on down through the town, and as I was\r\npassing a little German bakery, a woman ran out and begged me to come in\r\nand help her. She said her husband had a fit. I went in, and judged she\r\nwas right\xe2\x80\x94he appeared to have a hundred of them, compressed into one.\r\nTwo Germans were there, trying to hold him, and not making much of a\r\nsuccess of it. I ran up the street half a block or so and routed out a\r\nsleeping doctor, brought him down half dressed, and we four wrestled\r\nwith the maniac, and doctored, drenched and bled him, for more than an\r\nhour, and the poor German woman did the crying. He grew quiet, now, and\r\nthe doctor and I withdrew and left him to his friends.\r\n\r\nIt was a little after one o\xe2\x80\x99clock. As I entered the cabin door, tired\r\nbut jolly, the dingy light of a tallow candle revealed Higbie, sitting\r\nby the pine table gazing stupidly at my note, which he held in his\r\nfingers, and looking pale, old, and haggard. I halted, and looked at\r\nhim. He looked at me, stolidly. I said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigbie, what\xe2\x80\x94what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re ruined\xe2\x80\x94we didn\xe2\x80\x99t do the work\xe2\x80\x94THE BLIND LEAD\xe2\x80\x99S RELOCATED!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n288.jpg (57K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was enough. I sat down sick, grieved\xe2\x80\x94broken-hearted, indeed. A minute\r\nbefore, I was rich and brimful of vanity; I was a pauper now, and very\r\nmeek. We sat still an hour, busy with thought, busy with vain and\r\nuseless self-upbraidings, busy with \xe2\x80\x9cWhy _didn\xe2\x80\x99t_ I do this, and why\r\n_didn\xe2\x80\x99t_ I do that,\xe2\x80\x9d but neither spoke a word. Then we dropped into\r\nmutual explanations, and the mystery was cleared away. It came out that\r\nHigbie had depended on me, as I had on him, and as both of us had on the\r\nforeman. The folly of it! It was the first time that ever staid and\r\nsteadfast Higbie had left an important matter to chance or failed to be\r\ntrue to his full share of a responsibility.\r\n\r\nBut he had never seen my note till this moment, and this moment was the\r\nfirst time he had been in the cabin since the day he had seen me last.\r\nHe, also, had left a note for me, on that same fatal afternoon\xe2\x80\x94had\r\nridden up on horseback, and looked through the window, and being in a\r\nhurry and not seeing me, had tossed the note into the cabin through a\r\nbroken pane. Here it was, on the floor, where it had remained\r\nundisturbed for nine days:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t fail to do the work before the ten days expire. W. has passed\r\nthrough and given me notice. I am to join him at Mono Lake, and we shall\r\ngo on from there to-night. He says he will find it this time, sure.\r\nCAL.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cW.\xe2\x80\x9d meant Whiteman, of course. That thrice accursed \xe2\x80\x9ccement!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat was the way of it. An old miner, like Higbie, could no more\r\nwithstand the fascination of a mysterious mining excitement like this\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccement\xe2\x80\x9d foolishness, than he could refrain from eating when he was\r\nfamishing. Higbie had been dreaming about the marvelous cement for\r\nmonths; and now, against his better judgment, he had gone off and \xe2\x80\x9ctaken\r\nthe chances\xe2\x80\x9d on my keeping secure a mine worth a million undiscovered\r\ncement veins. They had not been followed this time. His riding out of\r\ntown in broad daylight was such a common-place thing to do that it had\r\nnot attracted any attention. He said they prosecuted their search in the\r\nfastnesses of the mountains during nine days, without success; they\r\ncould not find the cement. Then a ghastly fear came over him that\r\nsomething might have happened to prevent the doing of the necessary work\r\nto hold the blind lead (though indeed he thought such a thing hardly\r\npossible), and forthwith he started home with all speed. He would have\r\nreached Esmeralda in time, but his horse broke down and he had to walk a\r\ngreat part of the distance. And so it happened that as he came into\r\nEsmeralda by one road, I entered it by another. His was the superior\r\nenergy, however, for he went straight to the Wide West, instead of\r\nturning aside as I had done\xe2\x80\x94and he arrived there about five or ten\r\nminutes too late! The \xe2\x80\x9cnotice\xe2\x80\x9d was already up, the \xe2\x80\x9crelocation\xe2\x80\x9d of our\r\nmine completed beyond recall, and the crowd rapidly dispersing. He\r\nlearned some facts before he left the ground. The foreman had not been\r\nseen about the streets since the night we had located the mine\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ntelegram had called him to California on a matter of life and death, it\r\nwas said. At any rate he had done no work and the watchful eyes of the\r\ncommunity were taking note of the fact. At midnight of this woful tenth\r\nday, the ledge would be \xe2\x80\x9crelocatable,\xe2\x80\x9d and by eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the hill\r\nwas black with men prepared to do the relocating. That was the crowd I\r\nhad seen when I fancied a new \xe2\x80\x9cstrike\xe2\x80\x9d had been made\xe2\x80\x94idiot that I was.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n290.jpg (141K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n[We three had the same right to relocate the lead that other people had,\r\nprovided we were quick enough.] As midnight was announced, fourteen men,\r\nduly armed and ready to back their proceedings, put up their \xe2\x80\x9cnotice\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand proclaimed their ownership of the blind lead, under the new name of\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cJohnson.\xe2\x80\x9d But A. D. Allen our partner (the foreman) put in a sudden\r\nappearance about that time, with a cocked revolver in his hand, and said\r\nhis name must be added to the list, or he would \xe2\x80\x9cthin out the Johnson\r\ncompany some.\xe2\x80\x9d He was a manly, splendid, determined fellow, and known to\r\nbe as good as his word, and therefore a compromise was effected. They\r\nput in his name for a hundred feet, reserving to themselves the\r\ncustomary two hundred feet each. Such was the history of the night\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nevents, as Higbie gathered from a friend on the way home.\r\n\r\nHigbie and I cleared out on a new mining excitement the next morning,\r\nglad to get away from the scene of our sufferings, and after a month or\r\ntwo of hardship and disappointment, returned to Esmeralda once more.\r\nThen we learned that the Wide West and the Johnson companies had\r\nconsolidated; that the stock, thus united, comprised five thousand feet,\r\nor shares; that the foreman, apprehending tiresome litigation, and\r\nconsidering such a huge concern unwieldy, had sold his hundred feet for\r\nninety thousand dollars in gold and gone home to the States to enjoy it.\r\nIf the stock was worth such a gallant figure, with five thousand shares\r\nin the corporation, it makes me dizzy to think what it would have been\r\nworth with only our original six hundred in it. It was the difference\r\nbetween six hundred men owning a house and five thousand owning it. We\r\nwould have been millionaires if we had only worked with pick and spade\r\none little day on our property and so secured our ownership!\r\n\r\nIt reads like a wild fancy sketch, but the evidence of many witnesses,\r\nand likewise that of the official records of Esmeralda District, is\r\neasily obtainable in proof that it is a true history. I can always have\r\nit to say that I was absolutely and unquestionably worth a million\r\ndollars, once, for ten days.\r\n\r\nA year ago my esteemed and in every way estimable old millionaire\r\npartner, Higbie, wrote me from an obscure little mining camp in\r\nCalifornia that after nine or ten years of buffetings and hard striving,\r\nhe was at last in a position where he could command twenty-five hundred\r\ndollars, and said he meant to go into the fruit business in a modest\r\nway. How such a thought would have insulted him the night we lay in our\r\ncabin planning European trips and brown stone houses on Russian Hill!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLII.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat to do next?\r\n\r\nIt was a momentous question. I had gone out into the world to shift for\r\nmyself, at the age of thirteen (for my father had endorsed for friends;\r\nand although he left us a sumptuous legacy of pride in his fine\r\nVirginian stock and its national distinction, I presently found that I\r\ncould not live on that alone without occasional bread to wash it down\r\nwith). I had gained a livelihood in various vocations, but had not\r\ndazzled anybody with my successes; still the list was before me, and the\r\namplest liberty in the matter of choosing, provided I wanted to\r\nwork\xe2\x80\x94which I did not, after being so wealthy. I had once been a grocery\r\nclerk, for one day, but had consumed so much sugar in that time that I\r\nwas relieved from further duty by the proprietor; said he wanted me\r\noutside, so that he could have my custom. I had studied law an entire\r\nweek, and then given it up because it was so prosy and tiresome. I had\r\nengaged briefly in the study of blacksmithing, but wasted so much time\r\ntrying to fix the bellows so that it would blow itself, that the master\r\nturned me adrift in disgrace, and told me I would come to no good. I had\r\nbeen a bookseller\xe2\x80\x99s clerk for awhile, but the customers bothered me so\r\nmuch I could not read with any comfort, and so the proprietor gave me a\r\nfurlough and forgot to put a limit to it. I had clerked in a drug store\r\npart of a summer, but my prescriptions were unlucky, and we appeared to\r\nsell more stomach pumps than soda water. So I had to go.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n293.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI had made of myself a tolerable printer, under the impression that I\r\nwould be another Franklin some day, but somehow had missed the\r\nconnection thus far. There was no berth open in the Esmeralda _Union_,\r\nand besides I had always been such a slow compositor that I looked with\r\nenvy upon the achievements of apprentices of two years\xe2\x80\x99 standing; and\r\nwhen I took a \xe2\x80\x9ctake,\xe2\x80\x9d foremen were in the habit of suggesting that it\r\nwould be wanted \xe2\x80\x9csome time during the year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was a good average St. Louis and New Orleans pilot and by no means\r\nashamed of my abilities in that line; wages were two hundred and fifty\r\ndollars a month and no board to pay, and I did long to stand behind a\r\nwheel again and never roam any more\xe2\x80\x94but I had been making such an ass of\r\nmyself lately in grandiloquent letters home about my blind lead and my\r\nEuropean excursion that I did what many and many a poor disappointed\r\nminer had done before; said \xe2\x80\x9cIt is all over with me now, and I will\r\nnever go back home to be pitied\xe2\x80\x94and snubbed.\xe2\x80\x9d I had been a private\r\nsecretary, a silver miner and a silver mill operative, and amounted to\r\nless than nothing in each, and now\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nWhat to do next?\r\n\r\nI yielded to Higbie\xe2\x80\x99s appeals and consented to try the mining once more.\r\nWe climbed far up on the mountain side and went to work on a little\r\nrubbishy claim of ours that had a shaft on it eight feet deep. Higbie\r\ndescended into it and worked bravely with his pick till he had loosened\r\nup a deal of rock and dirt and then I went down with a long-handled\r\nshovel (the most awkward invention yet contrived by man) to throw it\r\nout. You must brace the shovel forward with the side of your knee till\r\nit is full, and then, with a skilful toss, throw it backward over your\r\nleft shoulder. I made the toss, and landed the mess just on the edge of\r\nthe shaft and it all came back on my head and down the back of my neck.\r\nI never said a word, but climbed out and walked home. I inwardly\r\nresolved that I would starve before I would make a target of myself and\r\nshoot rubbish at it with a long-handled shovel.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n294.jpg (50K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI sat down, in the cabin, and gave myself up to solid misery\xe2\x80\x94so to\r\nspeak.
