Now in pleasanter days I had amused myself with writing letters\r\nto the chief paper of the Territory, the Virginia Daily Territorial\r\nEnterprise, and had always been surprised when they appeared in print.\r\nMy good opinion of the editors had steadily declined; for it seemed to\r\nme that they might have found something better to fill up with than my\r\nliterature. I had found a letter in the post office as I came home from\r\nthe hill side, and finally I opened it. Eureka! [I never did know what\r\nEureka meant, but it seems to be as proper a word to heave in as any\r\nwhen no other that sounds pretty offers.] It was a deliberate offer to\r\nme of Twenty-Five Dollars a week to come up to Virginia and be city\r\neditor of the Enterprise.\r\n\r\nI would have challenged the publisher in the \xe2\x80\x9cblind lead\xe2\x80\x9d days\xe2\x80\x94I wanted\r\nto fall down and worship him, now. Twenty-Five Dollars a week\xe2\x80\x94it looked\r\nlike bloated luxury\xe2\x80\x94a fortune a sinful and lavish waste of money. But my\r\ntransports cooled when I thought of my inexperience and consequent\r\nunfitness for the position\xe2\x80\x94and straightway, on top of this, my long\r\narray of failures rose up before me. Yet if I refused this place I must\r\npresently become dependent upon somebody for my bread, a thing\r\nnecessarily distasteful to a man who had never experienced such a\r\nhumiliation since he was thirteen years old. Not much to _be_ proud of,\r\nsince it is so common\xe2\x80\x94but then it was all I had to _be_ proud of. So I\r\nwas scared into being a city editor. I would have declined, otherwise.\r\nNecessity is the mother of \xe2\x80\x9ctaking chances.\xe2\x80\x9d I do not doubt that if, at\r\nthat time, I had been offered a salary to translate the Talmud from the\r\noriginal Hebrew, I would have accepted\xe2\x80\x94albeit with diffidence and some\r\nmisgivings\xe2\x80\x94and thrown as much variety into it as I could for the money.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n295.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI went up to Virginia and entered upon my new vocation. I was a rusty\r\nlooking city editor, I am free to confess\xe2\x80\x94coatless, slouch hat, blue\r\nwoolen shirt, pantaloons stuffed into boot-tops, whiskered half down to\r\nthe waist, and the universal navy revolver slung to my belt. But I\r\nsecured a more Christian costume and discarded the revolver.\r\n\r\nI had never had occasion to kill anybody, nor ever felt a desire to do\r\nso, but had worn the thing in deference to popular sentiment, and in\r\norder that I might not, by its absence, be offensively conspicuous, and\r\na subject of remark. But the other editors, and all the printers,\r\ncarried revolvers. I asked the chief editor and proprietor (Mr. Goodman,\r\nI will call him, since it describes him as well as any name could do)\r\nfor some instructions with regard to my duties, and he told me to go all\r\nover town and ask all sorts of people all sorts of questions, make notes\r\nof the information gained, and write them out for publication. And he\r\nadded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever say \xe2\x80\x98We learn\xe2\x80\x99 so-and-so, or \xe2\x80\x98It is reported,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98It is\r\nrumored,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98We understand\xe2\x80\x99 so-and-so, but go to headquarters and get\r\nthe absolute facts, and then speak out and say \xe2\x80\x98It _is_ so-and-so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nOtherwise, people will not put confidence in your news. Unassailable\r\ncertainly is the thing that gives a newspaper the firmest and most\r\nvaluable reputation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the whole thing in a nut-shell; and to this day when I find a\r\nreporter commencing his article with \xe2\x80\x9cWe understand,\xe2\x80\x9d I gather a\r\nsuspicion that he has not taken as much pains to inform himself as he\r\nought to have done. I moralize well, but I did not always practise well\r\nwhen I was a city editor; I let fancy get the upper hand of fact too\r\noften when there was a dearth of news. I can never forget my first day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexperience as a reporter. I wandered about town questioning everybody,\r\nboring everybody, and finding out that nobody knew anything. At the end\r\nof five hours my notebook was still barren. I spoke to Mr. Goodman. He\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDan used to make a good thing out of the hay wagons in a dry time when\r\nthere were no fires or inquests. Are there no hay wagons in from the\r\nTruckee? If there are, you might speak of the renewed activity and all\r\nthat sort of thing, in the hay business, you know.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n296.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t sensational or exciting, but it fills up and looks business\r\nlike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI canvassed the city again and found one wretched old hay truck dragging\r\nin from the country. But I made affluent use of it. I multiplied it by\r\nsixteen, brought it into town from sixteen different directions, made\r\nsixteen separate items out of it, and got up such another sweat about\r\nhay as Virginia City had never seen in the world before.\r\n\r\nThis was encouraging. Two nonpareil columns had to be filled, and I was\r\ngetting along. Presently, when things began to look dismal again, a\r\ndesperado killed a man in a saloon and joy returned once more. I never\r\nwas so glad over any mere trifle before in my life. I said to the\r\nmurderer:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, you are a stranger to me, but you have done me a kindness this day\r\nwhich I can never forget. If whole years of gratitude can be to you any\r\nslight compensation, they shall be yours. I was in trouble and you have\r\nrelieved me nobly and at a time when all seemed dark and drear. Count me\r\nyour friend from this time forth, for I am not a man to forget a favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n297.jpg (44K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIf I did not really say that to him I at least felt a sort of itching\r\ndesire to do it. I wrote up the murder with a hungry attention to\r\ndetails, and when it was finished experienced but one regret\xe2\x80\x94namely,\r\nthat they had not hanged my benefactor on the spot, so that I could work\r\nhim up too.\r\n\r\nNext I discovered some emigrant wagons going into camp on the plaza and\r\nfound that they had lately come through the hostile Indian country and\r\nhad fared rather roughly. I made the best of the item that the\r\ncircumstances permitted, and felt that if I were not confined within\r\nrigid limits by the presence of the reporters of the other papers I\r\ncould add particulars that would make the article much more interesting.\r\nHowever, I found one wagon that was going on to California, and made\r\nsome judicious inquiries of the proprietor. When I learned, through his\r\nshort and surly answers to my cross-questioning, that he was certainly\r\ngoing on and would not be in the city next day to make trouble, I got\r\nahead of the other papers, for I took down his list of names and added\r\nhis party to the killed and wounded. Having more scope here, I put this\r\nwagon through an Indian fight that to this day has no parallel in\r\nhistory.\r\n\r\nMy two columns were filled. When I read them over in the morning I felt\r\nthat I had found my legitimate occupation at last. I reasoned within\r\nmyself that news, and stirring news, too, was what a paper needed, and I\r\nfelt that I was peculiarly endowed with the ability to furnish it. Mr.\r\nGoodman said that I was as good a reporter as Dan. I desired no higher\r\ncommendation. With encouragement like that, I felt that I could take my\r\npen and murder all the immigrants on the plains if need be and the\r\ninterests of the paper demanded it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n298.jpg (22K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nHowever, as I grew better acquainted with the business and learned the\r\nrun of the sources of information I ceased to require the aid of fancy\r\nto any large extent, and became able to fill my columns without\r\ndiverging noticeably from the domain of fact.\r\n\r\nI struck up friendships with the reporters of the other journals, and we\r\nswapped \xe2\x80\x9cregulars\xe2\x80\x9d with each other and thus economized work. \xe2\x80\x9cRegulars\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nare permanent sources of news, like courts, bullion returns, \xe2\x80\x9cclean-ups\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nat the quartz mills, and inquests. Inasmuch as everybody went armed, we\r\nhad an inquest about every day, and so this department was naturally set\r\ndown among the \xe2\x80\x9cregulars.\xe2\x80\x9d We had lively papers in those days. My great\r\ncompetitor among the reporters was Boggs of the _Union_. He was an\r\nexcellent reporter. Once in three or four months he would get a little\r\nintoxicated, but as a general thing he was a wary and cautious drinker\r\nalthough always ready to tamper a little with the enemy. He had the\r\nadvantage of me in one thing; he could get the monthly public school\r\nreport and I could not, because the principal hated the _Enterprise_.\r\nOne snowy night when the report was due, I started out sadly wondering\r\nhow I was going to get it. Presently, a few steps up the almost deserted\r\nstreet I stumbled on Boggs and asked him where he was going.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter the school report.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go along with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, _sir_. I\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as you say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA saloon-keeper\xe2\x80\x99s boy passed by with a steaming pitcher of hot punch,\r\nand Boggs snuffed the fragrance gratefully. He gazed fondly after the\r\nboy and saw him start up the _Enterprise_ stairs. I said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you could help me get that school business, but since you can\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nI must run up to the _Union_ office and see if I can get them to let me\r\nhave a proof of it after they have set it up, though I don\xe2\x80\x99t begin to\r\nsuppose they will. Good night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold on a minute. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind getting the report and sitting around\r\nwith the boys a little, while you copy it, if you\xe2\x80\x99re willing to drop\r\ndown to the principal\xe2\x80\x99s with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you talk like a rational being. Come along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe plowed a couple of blocks through the snow, got the report and\r\nreturned to our office. It was a short document and soon copied.\r\nMeantime Boggs helped himself to the punch. I gave the manuscript back\r\nto him and we started out to get an inquest, for we heard pistol shots\r\nnear by. We got the particulars with little loss of time, for it was\r\nonly an inferior sort of bar-room murder, and of little interest to the\r\npublic, and then we separated. Away at three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning,\r\nwhen we had gone to press and were having a relaxing concert as\r\nusual\xe2\x80\x94for some of the printers were good singers and others good\r\nperformers on the guitar and on that atrocity the accordion\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nproprietor of the _Union_ strode in and desired to know if anybody had\r\nheard anything of Boggs or the school report. We stated the case, and\r\nall turned out to help hunt for the delinquent. We found him standing on\r\na table in a saloon, with an old tin lantern in one hand and the school\r\nreport in the other, haranguing a gang of intoxicated Cornish miners on\r\nthe iniquity of squandering the public moneys on education \xe2\x80\x9cwhen\r\nhundreds and hundreds of honest hard-working men are literally starving\r\nfor whiskey.\xe2\x80\x9d [Riotous applause.] He had been assisting in a regal spree\r\nwith those parties for hours. We dragged him away and put him to bed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n301.jpg (93K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOf course there was no school report in the _Union_, and Boggs held me\r\naccountable, though I was innocent of any intention or desire to compass\r\nits absence from that paper and was as sorry as any one that the\r\nmisfortune had occurred.\r\n\r\nBut we were perfectly friendly. The day that the school report was next\r\ndue, the proprietor of the \xe2\x80\x9cGenessee\xe2\x80\x9d mine furnished us a buggy and\r\nasked us to go down and write something about the property\xe2\x80\x94a very common\r\nrequest and one always gladly acceded to when people furnished buggies,\r\nfor we were as fond of pleasure excursions as other people. In due time\r\nwe arrived at the \xe2\x80\x9cmine\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94nothing but a hole in the ground ninety feet\r\ndeep, and no way of getting down into it but by holding on to a rope and\r\nbeing lowered with a windlass. The workmen had just gone off somewhere\r\nto dinner. I was not strong enough to lower Boggs\xe2\x80\x99s bulk; so I took an\r\nunlighted candle in my teeth, made a loop for my foot in the end of the\r\nrope, implored Boggs not to go to sleep or let the windlass get the\r\nstart of him, and then swung out over the shaft. I reached the bottom\r\nmuddy and bruised about the elbows, but safe. I lit the candle, made an\r\nexamination of the rock, selected some specimens and shouted to Boggs to\r\nhoist away. No answer. Presently a head appeared in the circle of\r\ndaylight away aloft, and a voice came down:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you all set?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll set\xe2\x80\x94hoist away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you comfortable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you wait a little?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh certainly\xe2\x80\x94no particular hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94good by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? Where are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter the school report!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n302.jpg (71K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd he did. I staid down there an hour, and surprised the workmen when\r\nthey hauled up and found a man on the rope instead of a bucket of rock.\r\nI walked home, too\xe2\x80\x94five miles\xe2\x80\x94up hill. We had no school report next\r\nmorning; but the _Union_ had.\r\n\r\nSix months after my entry into journalism the grand \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d of\r\nSilverland began, and they continued with unabated splendor for three\r\nyears. All difficulty about filling up the \xe2\x80\x9clocal department\xe2\x80\x9d ceased,\r\nand the only trouble now was how to make the lengthened columns hold the\r\nworld of incidents and happenings that came to our literary net every\r\nday. Virginia had grown to be the \xe2\x80\x9clivest\xe2\x80\x9d town, for its age and\r\npopulation, that America had ever produced. The sidewalks swarmed with\r\npeople\xe2\x80\x94to such an extent, indeed, that it was generally no easy matter\r\nto stem the human tide. The streets themselves were just as crowded with\r\nquartz wagons, freight teams and other vehicles. The procession was\r\nendless. So great was the pack, that buggies frequently had to wait half\r\nan hour for an opportunity to cross the principal street. Joy sat on\r\nevery countenance, and there was a glad, almost fierce, intensity in\r\nevery eye, that told of the money-getting schemes that were seething in\r\nevery brain and the high hope that held sway in every heart. Money was\r\nas plenty as dust; every individual considered himself wealthy, and a\r\nmelancholy countenance was nowhere to be seen. There were military\r\ncompanies, fire companies, brass bands, banks, hotels, theatres, \xe2\x80\x9churdy-\r\ngurdy houses,\xe2\x80\x9d wide-open gambling palaces, political pow-wows, civic\r\nprocessions, street fights, murders, inquests, riots, a whiskey mill\r\nevery fifteen steps, a Board of Aldermen, a Mayor, a City Surveyor, a\r\nCity Engineer, a Chief of the Fire Department, with First, Second and\r\nThird Assistants, a Chief of Police, City Marshal and a large police\r\nforce, two Boards of Mining Brokers, a dozen breweries and half a dozen\r\njails and station-houses in full operation, and some talk of building a\r\nchurch. The \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d were in magnificent flower! Large fire-proof\r\nbrick buildings were going up in the principal streets, and the wooden\r\nsuburbs were spreading out in all directions. Town lots soared up to\r\nprices that were amazing.\r\n\r\nThe great \xe2\x80\x9cComstock lode\xe2\x80\x9d stretched its opulent length straight through\r\nthe town from north to south, and every mine on it was in diligent\r\nprocess of development. One of these mines alone employed six hundred\r\nand seventy-five men, and in the matter of elections the adage was, \xe2\x80\x9cas\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x98Gould and Curry\xe2\x80\x99 goes, so goes the city.\xe2\x80\x9d Laboring men\xe2\x80\x99s wages were\r\nfour and six dollars a day, and they worked in three \xe2\x80\x9cshifts\xe2\x80\x9d or gangs,\r\nand the blasting and picking and shoveling went on without ceasing,\r\nnight and day.\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9ccity\xe2\x80\x9d of Virginia roosted royally midway up the steep side of Mount\r\nDavidson, seven thousand two hundred feet above the level of the sea,\r\nand in the clear Nevada atmosphere was visible from a distance of fifty\r\nmiles! It claimed a population of fifteen thousand to eighteen thousand,\r\nand all day long half of this little army swarmed the streets like bees\r\nand the other half swarmed among the drifts and tunnels of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cComstock,\xe2\x80\x9d hundreds of feet down in the earth directly under those same\r\nstreets. Often we felt our chairs jar, and heard the faint boom of a\r\nblast down in the bowels of the earth under the office.\r\n\r\nThe mountain side was so steep that the entire town had a slant to it\r\nlike a roof. Each street was a terrace, and from each to the next street\r\nbelow the descent was forty or fifty feet. The fronts of the houses were\r\nlevel with the street they faced, but their rear first floors were\r\npropped on lofty stilts; a man could stand at a rear first floor window\r\nof a C street house and look down the chimneys of the row of houses\r\nbelow him facing D street. It was a laborious climb, in that thin\r\natmosphere, to ascend from D to A street, and you were panting and out\r\nof breath when you got there; but you could turn around and go down\r\nagain like a house a-fire\xe2\x80\x94so to speak. The atmosphere was so rarified,\r\non account of the great altitude, that one\xe2\x80\x99s blood lay near the surface\r\nalways, and the scratch of a pin was a disaster worth worrying about,\r\nfor the chances were that a grievous erysipelas would ensue. But to\r\noffset this, the thin atmosphere seemed to carry healing to gunshot\r\nwounds, and therefore, to simply shoot your adversary through both lungs\r\nwas a thing not likely to afford you any permanent satisfaction, for he\r\nwould be nearly certain to be around looking for you within the month,\r\nand not with an opera glass, either.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n304.jpg (102K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFrom Virginia\xe2\x80\x99s airy situation one could look over a vast, far-reaching\r\npanorama of mountain ranges and deserts; and whether the day was bright\r\nor overcast, whether the sun was rising or setting, or flaming in the\r\nzenith, or whether night and the moon held sway, the spectacle was\r\nalways impressive and beautiful. Over your head Mount Davidson lifted\r\nits gray dome, and before and below you a rugged canyon clove the\r\nbattlemented hills, making a sombre gateway through which a soft-tinted\r\ndesert was glimpsed, with the silver thread of a river winding through\r\nit, bordered with trees which many miles of distance diminished to a\r\ndelicate fringe; and still further away the snowy mountains rose up and\r\nstretched their long barrier to the filmy horizon\xe2\x80\x94far enough beyond a\r\nlake that burned in the desert like a fallen sun, though that, itself,\r\nlay fifty miles removed. Look from your window where you would, there\r\nwas fascination in the picture. At rare intervals\xe2\x80\x94but very rare\xe2\x80\x94there\r\nwere clouds in our skies, and then the setting sun would gild and flush\r\nand glorify this mighty expanse of scenery with a bewildering pomp of\r\ncolor that held the eye like a spell and moved the spirit like music.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nMy salary was increased to forty dollars a week. But I seldom drew it. I\r\nhad plenty of other resources, and what were two broad twenty-dollar\r\ngold pieces to a man who had his pockets full of such and a cumbersome\r\nabundance of bright half dollars besides? [Paper money has never come\r\ninto use on the Pacific coast.] Reporting was lucrative, and every man\r\nin the town was lavish with his money and his \xe2\x80\x9cfeet.\xe2\x80\x9d The city and all\r\nthe great mountain side were riddled with mining shafts. There were more\r\nmines than miners. True, not ten of these mines were yielding rock worth\r\nhauling to a mill, but everybody said, \xe2\x80\x9cWait till the shaft gets down\r\nwhere the ledge comes in solid, and then you will see!\xe2\x80\x9d So nobody was\r\ndiscouraged. These were nearly all \xe2\x80\x9cwild cat\xe2\x80\x9d mines, and wholly\r\nworthless, but nobody believed it then. The \xe2\x80\x9cOphir,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cGould &\r\nCurry,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cMexican,\xe2\x80\x9d and other great mines on the Comstock lead in\r\nVirginia and Gold Hill were turning out huge piles of rich rock every\r\nday, and every man believed that his little wild cat claim was as good\r\nas any on the \xe2\x80\x9cmain lead\xe2\x80\x9d and would infallibly be worth a thousand\r\ndollars a foot when he \xe2\x80\x9cgot down where it came in solid.\xe2\x80\x9d Poor fellow,\r\nhe was blessedly blind to the fact that he never would see that day. So\r\nthe thousand wild cat shafts burrowed deeper and deeper into the earth\r\nday by day, and all men were beside themselves with hope and happiness.\r\nHow they labored, prophesied, exulted! Surely nothing like it was ever\r\nseen before since the world began. Every one of these wild cat mines\xe2\x80\x94not\r\nmines, but holes in the ground over imaginary mines\xe2\x80\x94was incorporated and\r\nhad handsomely engraved \xe2\x80\x9cstock\xe2\x80\x9d and the stock was salable, too. It was\r\nbought and sold with a feverish avidity in the boards every day. You\r\ncould go up on the mountain side, scratch around and find a ledge (there\r\nwas no lack of them), put up a \xe2\x80\x9cnotice\xe2\x80\x9d with a grandiloquent name in it,\r\nstart a shaft, get your stock printed, and with nothing whatever to\r\nprove that your mine was worth a straw, you could put your stock on the\r\nmarket and sell out for hundreds and even thousands of dollars. To make\r\nmoney, and make it fast, was as easy as it was to eat your dinner.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n307.jpg (54K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEvery man owned \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d in fifty different wild cat mines and considered\r\nhis fortune made. Think of a city with not one solitary poor man in it!\r\nOne would suppose that when month after month went by and still not a\r\nwild cat mine (by wild cat I mean, in general terms, _any_ claim not\r\nlocated on the mother vein, i.e., the \xe2\x80\x9cComstock\xe2\x80\x9d) yielded a ton of rock\r\nworth crushing, the people would begin to wonder if they were not\r\nputting too much faith in their prospective riches; but there was not a\r\nthought of such a thing. They burrowed away, bought and sold, and were\r\nhappy.\r\n\r\nNew claims were taken up daily, and it was the friendly custom to run\r\nstraight to the newspaper offices, give the reporter forty or fifty\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfeet,\xe2\x80\x9d and get them to go and examine the mine and publish a notice of\r\nit. They did not care a fig what you said about the property so you said\r\nsomething. Consequently we generally said a word or two to the effect\r\nthat the \xe2\x80\x9cindications\xe2\x80\x9d were good, or that the ledge was \xe2\x80\x9csix feet wide,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor that the rock \xe2\x80\x9cresembled the Comstock\xe2\x80\x9d (and so it did\xe2\x80\x94but as a\r\ngeneral thing the resemblance was not startling enough to knock you\r\ndown). If the rock was moderately promising, we followed the custom of\r\nthe country, used strong adjectives and frothed at the mouth as if a\r\nvery marvel in silver discoveries had transpired. If the mine was a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdeveloped\xe2\x80\x9d one, and had no pay ore to show (and of course it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t),\r\nwe praised the tunnel; said it was one of the most infatuating tunnels\r\nin the land; driveled and driveled about the tunnel till we ran entirely\r\nout of ecstasies\xe2\x80\x94but never said a word about the rock. We would squander\r\nhalf a column of adulation on a shaft, or a new wire rope, or a dressed\r\npine windlass, or a fascinating force pump, and close with a burst of\r\nadmiration of the \xe2\x80\x9cgentlemanly and efficient Superintendent\xe2\x80\x9d of the\r\nmine\xe2\x80\x94but never utter a whisper about the rock. And those people were\r\nalways pleased, always satisfied. Occasionally we patched up and\r\nvarnished our reputation for discrimination and stern, undeviating\r\naccuracy, by giving some old abandoned claim a blast that ought to have\r\nmade its dry bones rattle\xe2\x80\x94and then somebody would seize it and sell it\r\non the fleeting notoriety thus conferred upon it.\r\n\r\nThere was _nothing_ in the shape of a mining claim that was not salable.\r\nWe received presents of \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d every day. If we needed a hundred dollars\r\nor so, we sold some; if not, we hoarded it away, satisfied that it would\r\nultimately be worth a thousand dollars a foot. I had a trunk about half\r\nfull of \xe2\x80\x9cstock.\xe2\x80\x9d When a claim made a stir in the market and went up to a\r\nhigh figure, I searched through my pile to see if I had any of its\r\nstock\xe2\x80\x94and generally found it.\r\n\r\nThe prices rose and fell constantly; but still a fall disturbed us\r\nlittle, because a thousand dollars a foot was our figure, and so we were\r\ncontent to let it fluctuate as much as it pleased till it reached it. My\r\npile of stock was not all given to me by people who wished their claims\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnoticed.\xe2\x80\x9d At least half of it was given me by persons who had no\r\nthought of such a thing, and looked for nothing more than a simple\r\nverbal \xe2\x80\x9cthank you;\xe2\x80\x9d and you were not even obliged by law to furnish\r\nthat. If you are coming up the street with a couple of baskets of apples\r\nin your hands, and you meet a friend, you naturally invite him to take a\r\nfew. That describes the condition of things in Virginia in the \xe2\x80\x9cflush\r\ntimes.\xe2\x80\x9d Every man had his pockets full of stock, and it was the actual\r\n_custom_ of the country to part with small quantities of it to friends\r\nwithout the asking.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n309.jpg (41K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVery often it was a good idea to close the transaction instantly, when a\r\nman offered a stock present to a friend, for the offer was only good and\r\nbinding at that moment, and if the price went to a high figure shortly\r\nafterward the procrastination was a thing to be regretted. Mr. Stewart\r\n(Senator, now, from Nevada) one day told me he would give me twenty feet\r\nof \xe2\x80\x9cJustis\xe2\x80\x9d stock if I would walk over to his office. It was worth five\r\nor ten dollars a foot. I asked him to make the offer good for next day,\r\nas I was just going to dinner. He said he would not be in town; so I\r\nrisked it and took my dinner instead of the stock. Within the week the\r\nprice went up to seventy dollars and afterward to a hundred and fifty,\r\nbut nothing could make that man yield. I suppose he sold that stock of\r\nmine and placed the guilty proceeds in his own pocket. [My revenge will\r\nbe found in the accompanying portrait.] I met three friends one\r\nafternoon, who said they had been buying \xe2\x80\x9cOverman\xe2\x80\x9d stock at auction at\r\neight dollars a foot. One said if I would come up to his office he would\r\ngive me fifteen feet; another said he would add fifteen; the third said\r\nhe would do the same. But I was going after an inquest and could not\r\nstop. A few weeks afterward they sold all their \xe2\x80\x9cOverman\xe2\x80\x9d at six hundred\r\ndollars a foot and generously came around to tell me about it\xe2\x80\x94and also\r\nto urge me to accept of the next forty-five feet of it that people tried\r\nto force on me.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n310.jpg (27K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThese are actual facts, and I could make the list a long one and still\r\nconfine myself strictly to the truth. Many a time friends gave us as\r\nmuch as twenty-five feet of stock that was selling at twenty-five\r\ndollars a foot, and they thought no more of it than they would of\r\noffering a guest a cigar. These were \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d indeed! I thought\r\nthey were going to last always, but somehow I never was much of a\r\nprophet.\r\n\r\nTo show what a wild spirit possessed the mining brain of the community,\r\nI will remark that \xe2\x80\x9cclaims\xe2\x80\x9d were actually \xe2\x80\x9clocated\xe2\x80\x9d in excavations for\r\ncellars, where the pick had exposed what seemed to be quartz veins\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnot cellars in the suburbs, either, but in the very heart of the city;\r\nand forthwith stock would be issued and thrown on the market. It was\r\nsmall matter who the cellar belonged to\xe2\x80\x94the \xe2\x80\x9cledge\xe2\x80\x9d belonged to the\r\nfinder, and unless the United States government interfered (inasmuch as\r\nthe government holds the primary right to mines of the noble metals in\r\nNevada\xe2\x80\x94or at least did then), it was considered to be his privilege to\r\nwork it. Imagine a stranger staking out a mining claim among the costly\r\nshrubbery in your front yard and calmly proceeding to lay waste the\r\nground with pick and shovel and blasting powder! It has been often done\r\nin California. In the middle of one of the principal business streets of\r\nVirginia, a man \xe2\x80\x9clocated\xe2\x80\x9d a mining claim and began a shaft on it. He\r\ngave me a hundred feet of the stock and I sold it for a fine suit of\r\nclothes because I was afraid somebody would fall down the shaft and sue\r\nfor damages. I owned in another claim that was located in the middle of\r\nanother street; and to show how absurd people can be, that \xe2\x80\x9cEast India\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nstock (as it was called) sold briskly although there was an ancient\r\ntunnel running directly under the claim and any man could go into it and\r\nsee that it did not cut a quartz ledge or anything that remotely\r\nresembled one.\r\n\r\nOne plan of acquiring sudden wealth was to \xe2\x80\x9csalt\xe2\x80\x9d a wild cat claim and\r\nsell out while the excitement was up. The process was simple.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n311.jpg (69K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe schemer located a worthless ledge, sunk a shaft on it, bought a\r\nwagon load of rich \xe2\x80\x9cComstock\xe2\x80\x9d ore, dumped a portion of it into the shaft\r\nand piled the rest by its side, above ground. Then he showed the\r\nproperty to a simpleton and sold it to him at a high figure. Of course\r\nthe wagon load of rich ore was all that the victim ever got out of his\r\npurchase. A most remarkable case of \xe2\x80\x9csalting\xe2\x80\x9d was that of the \xe2\x80\x9cNorth\r\nOphir.\xe2\x80\x9d It was claimed that this vein was a \xe2\x80\x9cremote extension\xe2\x80\x9d of the\r\noriginal \xe2\x80\x9cOphir,\xe2\x80\x9d a valuable mine on the \xe2\x80\x9cComstock.\xe2\x80\x9d For a few days\r\neverybody was talking about the rich developments in the North Ophir. It\r\nwas said that it yielded perfectly pure silver in small, solid lumps. I\r\nwent to the place with the owners, and found a shaft six or eight feet\r\ndeep, in the bottom of which was a badly shattered vein of dull,\r\nyellowish, unpromising rock. One would as soon expect to find silver in\r\na grindstone. We got out a pan of the rubbish and washed it in a puddle,\r\nand sure enough, among the sediment we found half a dozen black, bullet-\r\nlooking pellets of unimpeachable \xe2\x80\x9cnative\xe2\x80\x9d silver. Nobody had ever heard\r\nof such a thing before; science could not account for such a queer\r\nnovelty. The stock rose to sixty-five dollars a foot, and at this figure\r\nthe world-renowned tragedian, McKean Buchanan, bought a commanding\r\ninterest and prepared to quit the stage once more\xe2\x80\x94he was always doing\r\nthat. And then it transpired that the mine had been \xe2\x80\x9csalted\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and not in\r\nany hackneyed way, either, but in a singularly bold, barefaced and\r\npeculiarly original and outrageous fashion. On one of the lumps of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnative\xe2\x80\x9d silver was discovered the minted legend, \xe2\x80\x9cTED STATES OF,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nthen it was plainly apparent that the mine had been \xe2\x80\x9csalted\xe2\x80\x9d with melted\r\nhalf-dollars! The lumps thus obtained had been blackened till they\r\nresembled native silver, and were then mixed with the shattered rock in\r\nthe bottom of the shaft. It is literally true. Of course the price of\r\nthe stock at once fell to nothing, and the tragedian was ruined. But for\r\nthis calamity we might have lost McKean Buchanan from the stage.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLV.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d held bravely on. Something over two years before, Mr.\r\nGoodman and another journeyman printer, had borrowed forty dollars and\r\nset out from San Francisco to try their fortunes in the new city of\r\nVirginia. They found the _Territorial Enterprise_, a poverty-stricken\r\nweekly journal, gasping for breath and likely to die. They bought it,\r\ntype, fixtures, good-will and all, for a thousand dollars, on long time.\r\nThe editorial sanctum, news-room, press-room, publication office, bed-\r\nchamber, parlor, and kitchen were all compressed into one apartment and\r\nit was a small one, too. The editors and printers slept on the floor, a\r\nChinaman did their cooking, and the \xe2\x80\x9cimposing-stone\xe2\x80\x9d was the general\r\ndinner table. But now things were changed. The paper was a great daily,\r\nprinted by steam; there were five editors and twenty-three compositors;\r\nthe subscription price was sixteen dollars a year; the advertising rates\r\nwere exorbitant, and the columns crowded. The paper was clearing from\r\nsix to ten thousand dollars a month, and the \xe2\x80\x9cEnterprise Building\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\nfinished and ready for occupation\xe2\x80\x94a stately fireproof brick. Every day\r\nfrom five all the way up to eleven columns of \xe2\x80\x9clive\xe2\x80\x9d advertisements were\r\nleft out or crowded into spasmodic and irregular \xe2\x80\x9csupplements.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cGould & Curry\xe2\x80\x9d company were erecting a monster hundred-stamp mill\r\nat a cost that ultimately fell little short of a million dollars. Gould\r\n& Curry stock paid heavy dividends\xe2\x80\x94a rare thing, and an experience\r\nconfined to the dozen or fifteen claims located on the \xe2\x80\x9cmain lead,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cComstock.\xe2\x80\x9d The Superintendent of the Gould & Curry lived, rent free, in\r\na fine house built and furnished by the company. He drove a fine pair of\r\nhorses which were a present from the company, and his salary was twelve\r\nthousand dollars a year. The superintendent of another of the great\r\nmines traveled in grand state, had a salary of twenty-eight thousand\r\ndollars a year, and in a law suit in after days claimed that he was to\r\nhave had one per cent. on the gross yield of the bullion likewise.\r\n\r\nMoney was wonderfully plenty. The trouble was, not how to get it,\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nhow to spend it, how to lavish it, get rid of it, squander it. And so it\r\nwas a happy thing that just at this juncture the news came over the\r\nwires that a great United States Sanitary Commission had been formed and\r\nmoney was wanted for the relief of the wounded sailors and soldiers of\r\nthe Union languishing in the Eastern hospitals. Right on the heels of it\r\ncame word that San Francisco had responded superbly before the telegram\r\nwas half a day old. Virginia rose as one man! A Sanitary Committee was\r\nhurriedly organized, and its chairman mounted a vacant cart in C street\r\nand tried to make the clamorous multitude understand that the rest of\r\nthe committee were flying hither and thither and working with all their\r\nmight and main, and that if the town would only wait an hour, an office\r\nwould be ready, books opened, and the Commission prepared to receive\r\ncontributions. His voice was drowned and his information lost in a\r\nceaseless roar of cheers, and demands that the money be received\r\n_now_\xe2\x80\x94they swore they would not wait. The chairman pleaded and argued,\r\nbut, deaf to all entreaty, men plowed their way through the throng and\r\nrained checks of gold coin into the cart and skurried away for more.\r\nHands clutching money, were thrust aloft out of the jam by men who hoped\r\nthis eloquent appeal would cleave a road their strugglings could not\r\nopen. The very Chinamen and Indians caught the excitement and dashed\r\ntheir half dollars into the cart without knowing or caring what it was\r\nall about. Women plunged into the crowd, trimly attired, fought their\r\nway to the cart with their coin, and emerged again, by and by, with\r\ntheir apparel in a state of hopeless dilapidation. It was the wildest\r\nmob Virginia had ever seen and the most determined and ungovernable; and\r\nwhen at last it abated its fury and dispersed, it had not a penny in its\r\npocket.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n315.jpg (125K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTo use its own phraseology, it came there \xe2\x80\x9cflush\xe2\x80\x9d and went away\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter that, the Commission got itself into systematic working order, and\r\nfor weeks the contributions flowed into its treasury in a generous\r\nstream. Individuals and all sorts of organizations levied upon\r\nthemselves a regular weekly tax for the sanitary fund, graduated\r\naccording to their means, and there was not another grand universal\r\noutburst till the famous \xe2\x80\x9cSanitary Flour Sack\xe2\x80\x9d came our way. Its history\r\nis peculiar and interesting. A former schoolmate of mine, by the name of\r\nReuel Gridley, was living at the little city of Austin, in the Reese\r\nriver country, at this time, and was the Democratic candidate for mayor.\r\nHe and the Republican candidate made an agreement that the defeated man\r\nshould be publicly presented with a fifty-pound sack of flour by the\r\nsuccessful one, and should carry it home on his shoulder. Gridley was\r\ndefeated. The new mayor gave him the sack of flour, and he shouldered it\r\nand carried it a mile or two, from Lower Austin to his home in Upper\r\nAustin, attended by a band of music and the whole population. Arrived\r\nthere, he said he did not need the flour, and asked what the people\r\nthought he had better do with it. A voice said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSell it to the highest bidder, for the benefit of the Sanitary fund.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe suggestion was greeted with a round of applause, and Gridley mounted\r\na dry-goods box and assumed the role of auctioneer. The bids went higher\r\nand higher, as the sympathies of the pioneers awoke and expanded, till\r\nat last the sack was knocked down to a mill man at two hundred and fifty\r\ndollars, and his check taken. He was asked where he would have the flour\r\ndelivered, and he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNowhere\xe2\x80\x94sell it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow the cheers went up royally, and the multitude were fairly in the\r\nspirit of the thing. So Gridley stood there and shouted and perspired\r\ntill the sun went down; and when the crowd dispersed he had sold the\r\nsack to three hundred different people, and had taken in eight thousand\r\ndollars in gold. And still the flour sack was in his possession.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n317.jpg (157K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe news came to Virginia, and a telegram went back:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch along your flour sack!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThirty-six hours afterward Gridley arrived, and an afternoon mass\r\nmeeting was held in the Opera House, and the auction began. But the sack\r\nhad come sooner than it was expected; the people were not thoroughly\r\naroused, and the sale dragged. At nightfall only five thousand dollars\r\nhad been secured, and there was a crestfallen feeling in the community.\r\nHowever, there was no disposition to let the matter rest here and\r\nacknowledge vanquishment at the hands of the village of Austin. Till\r\nlate in the night the principal citizens were at work arranging the\r\nmorrow\xe2\x80\x99s campaign, and when they went to bed they had no fears for the\r\nresult. At eleven the next morning a procession of open carriages,\r\nattended by clamorous bands of music and adorned with a moving display\r\nof flags, filed along C street and was soon in danger of blockade by a\r\nhuzzaing multitude of citizens. In the first carriage sat Gridley, with\r\nthe flour sack in prominent view, the latter splendid with bright paint\r\nand gilt lettering; also in the same carriage sat the mayor and the\r\nrecorder. The other carriages contained the Common Council, the editors\r\nand reporters, and other people of imposing consequence. The crowd\r\npressed to the corner of C and Taylor streets, expecting the sale to\r\nbegin there, but they were disappointed, and also unspeakably surprised;\r\nfor the cavalcade moved on as if Virginia had ceased to be of\r\nimportance, and took its way over the \xe2\x80\x9cdivide,\xe2\x80\x9d toward the small town of\r\nGold Hill. Telegrams had gone ahead to Gold Hill, Silver City and\r\nDayton, and those communities were at fever heat and rife for the\r\nconflict. It was a very hot day, and wonderfully dusty. At the end of a\r\nshort half hour we descended into Gold Hill with drums beating and\r\ncolors flying, and enveloped in imposing clouds of dust. The whole\r\npopulation\xe2\x80\x94men, women and children, Chinamen and Indians, were massed in\r\nthe main street, all the flags in town were at the mast head, and the\r\nblare of the bands was drowned in cheers. Gridley stood up and asked who\r\nwould make the first bid for the National Sanitary Flour Sack. Gen. W.\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Yellow Jacket silver mining company offers a thousand dollars,\r\ncoin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tempest of applause followed. A telegram carried the news to Virginia,\r\nand fifteen minutes afterward that city\xe2\x80\x99s population was massed in the\r\nstreets devouring the tidings\xe2\x80\x94for it was part of the programme that the\r\nbulletin boards should do a good work that day. Every few minutes a new\r\ndispatch was bulletined from Gold Hill, and still the excitement grew.\r\nTelegrams began to return to us from Virginia beseeching Gridley to\r\nbring back the flour sack; but such was not the plan of the campaign. At\r\nthe end of an hour Gold Hill\xe2\x80\x99s small population had paid a figure for\r\nthe flour sack that awoke all the enthusiasm of Virginia when the grand\r\ntotal was displayed upon the bulletin boards. Then the Gridley cavalcade\r\nmoved on, a giant refreshed with new lager beer and plenty of it\xe2\x80\x94for the\r\npeople brought it to the carriages without waiting to measure it\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nwithin three hours more the expedition had carried Silver City and\r\nDayton by storm and was on its way back covered with glory. Every move\r\nhad been telegraphed and bulletined, and as the procession entered\r\nVirginia and filed down C street at half past eight in the evening the\r\ntown was abroad in the thoroughfares, torches were glaring, flags\r\nflying, bands playing, cheer on cheer cleaving the air, and the city\r\nready to surrender at discretion. The auction began, every bid was\r\ngreeted with bursts of applause, and at the end of two hours and a half\r\na population of fifteen thousand souls had paid in coin for a fifty-\r\npound sack of flour a sum equal to forty thousand dollars in greenbacks!\r\nIt was at a rate in the neighborhood of three dollars for each man,\r\nwoman and child of the population. The grand total would have been twice\r\nas large, but the streets were very narrow, and hundreds who wanted to\r\nbid could not get within a block of the stand, and could not make\r\nthemselves heard. These grew tired of waiting and many of them went home\r\nlong before the auction was over. This was the greatest day Virginia\r\never saw, perhaps.\r\n\r\nGridley sold the sack in Carson city and several California towns; also\r\nin San Francisco. Then he took it east and sold it in one or two\r\nAtlantic cities, I think. I am not sure of that, but I know that he\r\nfinally carried it to St. Louis, where a monster Sanitary Fair was being\r\nheld, and after selling it there for a large sum and helping on the\r\nenthusiasm by displaying the portly silver bricks which Nevada\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndonation had produced, he had the flour baked up into small cakes and\r\nretailed them at high prices.\r\n\r\nIt was estimated that when the flour sack\xe2\x80\x99s mission was ended it had\r\nbeen sold for a grand total of a hundred and fifty thousand dollars in\r\ngreenbacks! This is probably the only instance on record where common\r\nfamily flour brought three thousand dollars a pound in the public\r\nmarket.\r\n\r\nIt is due to Mr. Gridley\xe2\x80\x99s memory to mention that the expenses of his\r\nsanitary flour sack expedition of fifteen thousand miles, going and\r\nreturning, were paid in large part if not entirely, out of his own\r\npocket. The time he gave to it was not less than three months. Mr.\r\nGridley was a soldier in the Mexican war and a pioneer Californian. He\r\ndied at Stockton, California, in December, 1870, greatly regretted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n319.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were nabobs in those days\xe2\x80\x94in the \xe2\x80\x9cflush times,\xe2\x80\x9d I mean. Every rich\r\nstrike in the mines created one or two. I call to mind several of these.\r\nThey were careless, easy-going fellows, as a general thing, and the\r\ncommunity at large was as much benefited by their riches as they were\r\nthemselves\xe2\x80\x94possibly more, in some cases.\r\n\r\nTwo cousins, teamsters, did some hauling for a man and had to take a\r\nsmall segregated portion of a silver mine in lieu of $300 cash. They\r\ngave an outsider a third to open the mine, and they went on teaming. But\r\nnot long. Ten months afterward the mine was out of debt and paying each\r\nowner $8,000 to $10,000 a month\xe2\x80\x94say $100,000 a year.\r\n\r\nOne of the earliest nabobs that Nevada was delivered of wore $6,000\r\nworth of diamonds in his bosom, and swore he was unhappy because he\r\ncould not spend his money as fast as he made it.\r\n\r\nAnother Nevada nabob boasted an income that often reached $16,000 a\r\nmonth; and he used to love to tell how he had worked in the very mine\r\nthat yielded it, for five dollars a day, when he first came to the\r\ncountry.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n321.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe silver and sage-brush State has knowledge of another of these pets\r\nof fortune\xe2\x80\x94lifted from actual poverty to affluence almost in a single\r\nnight\xe2\x80\x94who was able to offer $100,000 for a position of high official\r\ndistinction, shortly afterward, and did offer it\xe2\x80\x94but failed to get it,\r\nhis politics not being as sound as his bank account.\r\n\r\nThen there was John Smith. He was a good, honest, kind-hearted soul,\r\nborn and reared in the lower ranks of life, and miraculously ignorant.\r\nHe drove a team, and owned a small ranch\xe2\x80\x94a ranch that paid him a\r\ncomfortable living, for although it yielded but little hay, what little\r\nit did yield was worth from $250 to $300 in gold per ton in the market.\r\nPresently Smith traded a few acres of the ranch for a small undeveloped\r\nsilver mine in Gold Hill. He opened the mine and built a little\r\nunpretending ten-stamp mill. Eighteen months afterward he retired from\r\nthe hay business, for his mining income had reached a most comfortable\r\nfigure. Some people said it was $30,000 a month, and others said it was\r\n$60,000. Smith was very rich at any rate.\r\n\r\nAnd then he went to Europe and traveled. And when he came back he was\r\nnever tired of telling about the fine hogs he had seen in England, and\r\nthe gorgeous sheep he had seen in Spain, and the fine cattle he had\r\nnoticed in the vicinity of Rome. He was full of wonders of the old\r\nworld, and advised everybody to travel. He said a man never imagined\r\nwhat surprising things there were in the world till he had traveled.\r\n\r\nOne day, on board ship, the passengers made up a pool of $500, which was\r\nto be the property of the man who should come nearest to guessing the\r\nrun of the vessel for the next twenty-four hours. Next day, toward noon,\r\nthe figures were all in the purser\xe2\x80\x99s hands in sealed envelopes. Smith\r\nwas serene and happy, for he had been bribing the engineer. But another\r\nparty won the prize! Smith said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, that won\xe2\x80\x99t do! He guessed two miles wider of the mark than I\r\ndid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe purser said, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Smith, you missed it further than any man on\r\nboard. We traveled two hundred and eight miles yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Smith, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s just where I\xe2\x80\x99ve got you, for I guessed\r\ntwo hundred and nine. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll look at my figgers again you\xe2\x80\x99ll find a 2\r\nand two 0\xe2\x80\x99s, which stands for 200, don\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x94and after \xe2\x80\x99em you\xe2\x80\x99ll find a\r\n9 (2009), which stands for two hundred and nine. I reckon I\xe2\x80\x99ll take that\r\nmoney, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Gould & Curry claim comprised twelve hundred feet, and it all\r\nbelonged originally to the two men whose names it bears. Mr. Curry owned\r\ntwo thirds of it\xe2\x80\x94and he said that he sold it out for twenty-five hundred\r\ndollars in cash, and an old plug horse that ate up his market value in\r\nhay and barley in seventeen days by the watch. And he said that Gould\r\nsold out for a pair of second-hand government blankets and a bottle of\r\nwhisky that killed nine men in three hours, and that an unoffending\r\nstranger that smelt the cork was disabled for life. Four years afterward\r\nthe mine thus disposed of was worth in the San Francisco market seven\r\nmillions six hundred thousand dollars in gold coin.\r\n\r\nIn the early days a poverty-stricken Mexican who lived in a canyon\r\ndirectly back of Virginia City, had a stream of water as large as a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s wrist trickling from the hill-side on his premises. The Ophir\r\nCompany segregated a hundred feet of their mine and traded it to him for\r\nthe stream of water. The hundred feet proved to be the richest part of\r\nthe entire mine; four years after the swap, its market value (including\r\nits mill) was $1,500,000.\r\n\r\nAn individual who owned twenty feet in the Ophir mine before its great\r\nriches were revealed to men, traded it for a horse, and a very sorry\r\nlooking brute he was, too. A year or so afterward, when Ophir stock went\r\nup to $3,000 a foot, this man, who had not a cent, used to say he was\r\nthe most startling example of magnificence and misery the world had ever\r\nseen\xe2\x80\x94because he was able to ride a sixty-thousand-dollar horse\xe2\x80\x94yet could\r\nnot scrape up cash enough to buy a saddle, and was obliged to borrow one\r\nor ride bareback. He said if fortune were to give him another sixty-\r\nthousand-dollar horse it would ruin him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n323.jpg (46K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA youth of nineteen, who was a telegraph operator in Virginia on a\r\nsalary of a hundred dollars a month, and who, when he could not make out\r\nGerman names in the list of San Francisco steamer arrivals, used to\r\ningeniously select and supply substitutes for them out of an old Berlin\r\ncity directory, made himself rich by watching the mining telegrams that\r\npassed through his hands and buying and selling stocks accordingly,\r\nthrough a friend in San Francisco. Once when a private dispatch was sent\r\nfrom Virginia announcing a rich strike in a prominent mine and advising\r\nthat the matter be kept secret till a large amount of the stock could be\r\nsecured, he bought forty \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d of the stock at twenty dollars a foot,\r\nand afterward sold half of it at eight hundred dollars a foot and the\r\nrest at double that figure. Within three months he was worth $150,000,\r\nand had resigned his telegraphic position.\r\n\r\nAnother telegraph operator who had been discharged by the company for\r\ndivulging the secrets of the office, agreed with a moneyed man in San\r\nFrancisco to furnish him the result of a great Virginia mining lawsuit\r\nwithin an hour after its private reception by the parties to it in San\r\nFrancisco. For this he was to have a large percentage of the profits on\r\npurchases and sales made on it by his fellow-conspirator. So he went,\r\ndisguised as a teamster, to a little wayside telegraph office in the\r\nmountains, got acquainted with the operator, and sat in the office day\r\nafter day, smoking his pipe, complaining that his team was fagged out\r\nand unable to travel\xe2\x80\x94and meantime listening to the dispatches as they\r\npassed clicking through the machine from Virginia. Finally the private\r\ndispatch announcing the result of the lawsuit sped over the wires, and\r\nas soon as he heard it he telegraphed his friend in San Francisco:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm tired waiting. Shall sell the team and go home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the signal agreed upon. The word \xe2\x80\x9cwaiting\xe2\x80\x9d left out, would have\r\nsignified that the suit had gone the other way.\r\n\r\nThe mock teamster\xe2\x80\x99s friend picked up a deal of the mining stock, at low\r\nfigures, before the news became public, and a fortune was the result.\r\n\r\nFor a long time after one of the great Virginia mines had been\r\nincorporated, about fifty feet of the original location were still in\r\nthe hands of a man who had never signed the incorporation papers. The\r\nstock became very valuable, and every effort was made to find this man,\r\nbut he had disappeared. Once it was heard that he was in New York, and\r\none or two speculators went east but failed to find him. Once the news\r\ncame that he was in the Bermudas, and straightway a speculator or two\r\nhurried east and sailed for Bermuda\xe2\x80\x94but he was not there. Finally he was\r\nheard of in Mexico, and a friend of his, a bar-keeper on a salary,\r\nscraped together a little money and sought him out, bought his \xe2\x80\x9cfeet\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nfor a hundred dollars, returned and sold the property for $75,000.\r\n\r\nBut why go on? The traditions of Silverland are filled with instances\r\nlike these, and I would never get through enumerating them were I to\r\nattempt do it. I only desired to give, the reader an idea of a\r\npeculiarity of the \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d which I could not present so strikingly\r\nin any other way, and which some mention of was necessary to a realizing\r\ncomprehension of the time and the country.\r\n\r\nI was personally acquainted with the majority of the nabobs I have\r\nreferred to, and so, for old acquaintance sake, I have shifted their\r\noccupations and experiences around in such a way as to keep the Pacific\r\npublic from recognizing these once notorious men. No longer notorious,\r\nfor the majority of them have drifted back into poverty and obscurity\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nIn Nevada there used to be current the story of an adventure of two of\r\nher nabobs, which may or may not have occurred. I give it for what it is\r\nworth:\r\n\r\nCol. Jim had seen somewhat of the world, and knew more or less of its\r\nways; but Col. Jack was from the back settlements of the States, had led\r\na life of arduous toil, and had never seen a city. These two, blessed\r\nwith sudden wealth, projected a visit to New York,\xe2\x80\x94Col. Jack to see the\r\nsights, and Col. Jim to guard his unsophistication from misfortune. They\r\nreached San Francisco in the night, and sailed in the morning. Arrived\r\nin New York, Col. Jack said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard tell of carriages all my life, and now I mean to have a ride\r\nin one; I don\xe2\x80\x99t care what it costs. Come along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey stepped out on the sidewalk, and Col. Jim called a stylish\r\nbarouche. But Col. Jack said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_No_, sir! None of your cheap-John turn-outs for me. I\xe2\x80\x99m here to have a\r\ngood time, and money ain\xe2\x80\x99t any object. I mean to have the nobbiest rig\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s going. Now here comes the very trick. Stop that yaller one with\r\nthe pictures on it\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you fret\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand all the expenses myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo Col. Jim stopped an empty omnibus, and they got in. Said Col. Jack:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t it gay, though? Oh, no, I reckon not! Cushions, and windows, and\r\npictures, till you can\xe2\x80\x99t rest. What would the boys say if they _could_\r\nsee us cutting a swell like this in New York? By George, I wish they\r\ncould see us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he put his head out of the window, and shouted to the driver:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Johnny, this suits _me_!\xe2\x80\x94suits yours truly, you bet, you! I want\r\nthis shebang all day. I\xe2\x80\x99m _on_ it, old man! Let \xe2\x80\x99em out! Make \xe2\x80\x99em go!\r\nWe\xe2\x80\x99ll make it all right with _you_, sonny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe driver passed his hand through the strap-hole, and tapped for his\r\nfare\xe2\x80\x94it was before the gongs came into common use. Col. Jack took the\r\nhand, and shook it cordially. He said:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n326.jpg (51K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou twig me, old pard! All right between gents. Smell of _that_, and\r\nsee how you like it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he put a twenty-dollar gold piece in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s hand. After a\r\nmoment the driver said he could not make change.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBother the change! Ride it out. Put it in your pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen to Col. Jim, with a sounding slap on his thigh:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ain\xe2\x80\x99t_ it style, though? Hanged if I don\xe2\x80\x99t hire this thing every day\r\nfor a week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe omnibus stopped, and a young lady got in. Col. Jack stared a moment,\r\nthen nudged Col. Jim with his elbow:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say a word,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cLet her ride, if she wants to.\r\nGracious, there\xe2\x80\x99s room enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young lady got out her porte-monnaie, and handed her fare to Col.\r\nJack.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this for?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it to the driver, please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake back your money, madam. We can\xe2\x80\x99t allow it. You\xe2\x80\x99re welcome to ride\r\nhere as long as you please, but this shebang\xe2\x80\x99s chartered, and we can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlet you pay a cent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n327.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe girl shrunk into a corner, bewildered. An old lady with a basket\r\nclimbed in, and proffered her fare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Col. Jack. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re perfectly welcome here, madam, but\r\nwe can\xe2\x80\x99t allow you to pay. Set right down there, mum, and don\xe2\x80\x99t you be\r\nthe least uneasy. Make yourself just as free as if you was in your own\r\nturn-out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithin two minutes, three gentlemen, two fat women, and a couple of\r\nchildren, entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome right along, friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Col. Jack; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t mind _us_. This is a\r\nfree blow-out.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he whispered to Col. Jim,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNew York ain\xe2\x80\x99t no sociable place, I don\xe2\x80\x99t reckon\xe2\x80\x94it ain\xe2\x80\x99t no _name_ for\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe resisted every effort to pass fares to the driver, and made everybody\r\ncordially welcome. The situation dawned on the people, and they pocketed\r\ntheir money, and delivered themselves up to covert enjoyment of the\r\nepisode. Half a dozen more passengers entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there\xe2\x80\x99s _plenty_ of room,\xe2\x80\x9d said Col. Jack. \xe2\x80\x9cWalk right in, and make\r\nyourselves at home. A blow-out ain\xe2\x80\x99t worth anything _as_ a blow-out,\r\nunless a body has company.\xe2\x80\x9d Then in a whisper to Col. Jim: \xe2\x80\x9cBut _ain\xe2\x80\x99t_\r\nthese New Yorkers friendly? And ain\xe2\x80\x99t they cool about it, too? Icebergs\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t anywhere. I reckon they\xe2\x80\x99d tackle a hearse, if it was going their\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMore passengers got in; more yet, and still more. Both seats were\r\nfilled, and a file of men were standing up, holding on to the cleats\r\noverhead. Parties with baskets and bundles were climbing up on the roof.\r\nHalf-suppressed laughter rippled up from all sides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, for clean, cool, out-and-out cheek, if this don\xe2\x80\x99t bang anything\r\nthat ever I saw, I\xe2\x80\x99m an Injun!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Col. Jack.\r\n\r\nA Chinaman crowded his way in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI weaken!\xe2\x80\x9d said Col. Jack. \xe2\x80\x9cHold on, driver! Keep your seats, ladies,\r\nand gents. Just make yourselves free\xe2\x80\x94everything\xe2\x80\x99s paid for. Driver,\r\nrustle these folks around as long as they\xe2\x80\x99re a mind to go\xe2\x80\x94friends of\r\nours, you know. Take them everywheres\xe2\x80\x94and if you want more money, come\r\nto the St. Nicholas, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll make it all right. Pleasant journey to\r\nyou, ladies and gents\xe2\x80\x94go it just as long as you please\xe2\x80\x94it shan\xe2\x80\x99t cost\r\nyou a cent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n328.jpg (93K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe two comrades got out, and Col. Jack said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJimmy, it\xe2\x80\x99s the sociablest place _I_ ever saw. The Chinaman waltzed in\r\nas comfortable as anybody. If we\xe2\x80\x99d staid awhile, I reckon we\xe2\x80\x99d had some\r\nniggers. B\xe2\x80\x99 George, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to barricade our doors to-night, or some\r\nof these ducks will be trying to sleep with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nSomebody has said that in order to know a community, one must observe\r\nthe style of its funerals and know what manner of men they bury with\r\nmost ceremony. I cannot say which class we buried with most eclat in our\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cflush times,\xe2\x80\x9d the distinguished public benefactor or the distinguished\r\nrough\xe2\x80\x94possibly the two chief grades or grand divisions of society\r\nhonored their illustrious dead about equally; and hence, no doubt the\r\nphilosopher I have quoted from would have needed to see two\r\nrepresentative funerals in Virginia before forming his estimate of the\r\npeople.\r\n\r\nThere was a grand time over Buck Fanshaw when he died. He was a\r\nrepresentative citizen. He had \xe2\x80\x9ckilled his man\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94not in his own quarrel,\r\nit is true, but in defence of a stranger unfairly beset by numbers. He\r\nhad kept a sumptuous saloon. He had been the proprietor of a dashing\r\nhelpmeet whom he could have discarded without the formality of a\r\ndivorce. He had held a high position in the fire department and been a\r\nvery Warwick in politics. When he died there was great lamentation\r\nthroughout the town, but especially in the vast bottom-stratum of\r\nsociety.\r\n\r\nOn the inquest it was shown that Buck Fanshaw, in the delirium of a\r\nwasting typhoid fever, had taken arsenic, shot himself through the body,\r\ncut his throat, and jumped out of a four-story window and broken his\r\nneck\xe2\x80\x94and after due deliberation, the jury, sad and tearful, but with\r\nintelligence unblinded by its sorrow, brought in a verdict of death \xe2\x80\x9cby\r\nthe visitation of God.\xe2\x80\x9d What could the world do without juries?\r\n\r\nProdigious preparations were made for the funeral. All the vehicles in\r\ntown were hired, all the saloons put in mourning, all the municipal and\r\nfire-company flags hung at half-mast, and all the firemen ordered to\r\nmuster in uniform and bring their machines duly draped in black. Now\xe2\x80\x94let\r\nus remark in parenthesis\xe2\x80\x94as all the peoples of the earth had\r\nrepresentative adventurers in the Silverland, and as each adventurer had\r\nbrought the slang of his nation or his locality with him, the\r\ncombination made the slang of Nevada the richest and the most infinitely\r\nvaried and copious that had ever existed anywhere in the world, perhaps,\r\nexcept in the mines of California in the \xe2\x80\x9cearly days.\xe2\x80\x9d Slang was the\r\nlanguage of Nevada. It was hard to preach a sermon without it, and be\r\nunderstood. Such phrases as \xe2\x80\x9cYou bet!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, I reckon not!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNo Irish\r\nneed apply,\xe2\x80\x9d and a hundred others, became so common as to fall from the\r\nlips of a speaker unconsciously\xe2\x80\x94and very often when they did not touch\r\nthe subject under discussion and consequently failed to mean anything.\r\n\r\nAfter Buck Fanshaw\xe2\x80\x99s inquest, a meeting of the short-haired brotherhood\r\nwas held, for nothing can be done on the Pacific coast without a public\r\nmeeting and an expression of sentiment. Regretful resolutions were\r\npassed and various committees appointed; among others, a committee of\r\none was deputed to call on the minister, a fragile, gentle, spiritual\r\nnew fledgling from an Eastern theological seminary, and as yet\r\nunacquainted with the ways of the mines. The committeeman, \xe2\x80\x9cScotty\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nBriggs, made his visit; and in after days it was worth something to hear\r\nthe minister tell about it. Scotty was a stalwart rough, whose customary\r\nsuit, when on weighty official business, like committee work, was a fire\r\nhelmet, flaming red flannel shirt, patent leather belt with spanner and\r\nrevolver attached, coat hung over arm, and pants stuffed into boot tops.\r\nHe formed something of a contrast to the pale theological student. It is\r\nfair to say of Scotty, however, in passing, that he had a warm heart,\r\nand a strong love for his friends, and never entered into a quarrel when\r\nhe could reasonably keep out of it. Indeed, it was commonly said that\r\nwhenever one of Scotty\xe2\x80\x99s fights was investigated, it always turned out\r\nthat it had originally been no affair of his, but that out of native\r\ngoodheartedness he had dropped in of his own accord to help the man who\r\nwas getting the worst of it. He and Buck Fanshaw were bosom friends, for\r\nyears, and had often taken adventurous \xe2\x80\x9cpot-luck\xe2\x80\x9d together. On one\r\noccasion, they had thrown off their coats and taken the weaker side in a\r\nfight among strangers, and after gaining a hard-earned victory, turned\r\nand found that the men they were helping had deserted early, and not\r\nonly that, but had stolen their coats and made off with them! But to\r\nreturn to Scotty\xe2\x80\x99s visit to the minister. He was on a sorrowful mission,\r\nnow, and his face was the picture of woe. Being admitted to the presence\r\nhe sat down before the clergyman, placed his fire-hat on an unfinished\r\nmanuscript sermon under the minister\xe2\x80\x99s nose, took from it a red silk\r\nhandkerchief, wiped his brow and heaved a sigh of dismal impressiveness,\r\nexplanatory of his business.\r\n\r\nHe choked, and even shed tears; but with an effort he mastered his voice\r\nand said in lugubrious tones:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you the duck that runs the gospel-mill next door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I the\xe2\x80\x94pardon me, I believe I do not understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith another sigh and a half-sob, Scotty rejoined:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy you see we are in a bit of trouble, and the boys thought maybe you\r\nwould give us a lift, if we\xe2\x80\x99d tackle you\xe2\x80\x94that is, if I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the rights\r\nof it and you are the head clerk of the doxology-works next door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the shepherd in charge of the flock whose fold is next door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe which?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe spiritual adviser of the little company of believers whose\r\nsanctuary adjoins these premises.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n331.jpg (76K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nScotty scratched his head, reflected a moment, and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ruther hold over me, pard. I reckon I can\xe2\x80\x99t call that hand. Ante\r\nand pass the buck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? I beg pardon. What did I understand you to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ve ruther got the bulge on me. Or maybe we\xe2\x80\x99ve both got the\r\nbulge, somehow. You don\xe2\x80\x99t smoke me and I don\xe2\x80\x99t smoke you. You see, one\r\nof the boys has passed in his checks and we want to give him a good\r\nsend-off, and so the thing I\xe2\x80\x99m on now is to roust out somebody to jerk a\r\nlittle chin-music for us and waltz him through handsome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend, I seem to grow more and more bewildered. Your observations\r\nare wholly incomprehensible to me. Cannot you simplify them in some way?\r\nAt first I thought perhaps I understood you, but I grope now. Would it\r\nnot expedite matters if you restricted yourself to categorical\r\nstatements of fact unencumbered with obstructing accumulations of\r\nmetaphor and allegory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother pause, and more reflection. Then, said Scotty:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have to pass, I judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve raised me out, pard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI still fail to catch your meaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that last lead of yourn is too many for me\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the idea. He was down on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em. His word was, \xe2\x80\x98No Irish need apply!\xe2\x80\x99 But it didn\xe2\x80\x99t make no\r\ndifference about that when it came down to what a man\xe2\x80\x99s rights was\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nso, when some roughs jumped the Catholic bone-yard and started in to\r\nstake out town-lots in it he went for \xe2\x80\x99em! I\r\nwas there, pard, and I seen it myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n335.jpg (105K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was very well indeed\xe2\x80\x94at least the impulse was\xe2\x80\x94whether the act was\r\nstrictly defensible or not. Was he a good man, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x94I see that; don\xe2\x80\x99t put up another chip till I look at my hand. A\r\ngood man, says you? Pard, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t no name for it. He was the best man\r\nthat ever\xe2\x80\x94pard, you would have doted on that man. He could lam any\r\ngaloot of his inches in America. He waltzed in with a spanner in one hand and a\r\ntrumpet in the other, and sent fourteen men home on a shutter in less\r\nthan three minutes. He had that riot all broke up and prevented nice\r\nbefore anybody ever got a chance to strike a blow. He was always for\r\npeace, and he would have peace\xe2\x80\x94he could not stand disturbances. Here once when the Micks\r\ngot to throwing stones through the Methodis\xe2\x80\x99 Sunday school windows, Buck\r\nFanshaw, all of his own notion, shut up his saloon and took a couple of\r\nsix-shooters and mounted guard over the Sunday school. Says he, \xe2\x80\x98No\r\nIrish need apply!\xe2\x80\x99 And they didn\xe2\x80\x99t. He was the bulliest man in the\r\nmountains, pard! And you can say, pard, that he never shook his mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n337.jpg (60K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever shook his mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it\xe2\x80\x94any of the boys will tell you so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but why should he shake her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I say\xe2\x80\x94but some people does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot people of any repute?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, some that averages pretty so-so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my opinion the man that would offer personal violence to his own\r\nmother, ought to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCheese it, pard; you\xe2\x80\x99ve banked your ball clean outside the string. What\r\nI was a drivin\xe2\x80\x99 at, was, that he never throwed off on his mother\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou see? No indeedy. He give her a house to live in, and town lots, and\r\nplenty of money; and he looked after her and took care of her all the\r\ntime; and when she was down with the small-pox I\xe2\x80\x99m d\xe2\x80\x94-d if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t set\r\nup nights and nuss her himself! Beg your pardon for saying it, but it\r\nhopped out too quick for yours truly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve treated me like a gentleman, pard, and I ain\xe2\x80\x99t the man to hurt\r\nyour feelings intentional. I think you\xe2\x80\x99re white. I think you\xe2\x80\x99re a square\r\nman, pard. I like you, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll lick any man that don\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99ll lick him\r\ntill he can\xe2\x80\x99t tell himself from a last year\xe2\x80\x99s corpse! Put it there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n[Another fraternal hand-shake\xe2\x80\x94and exit.]\r\n\r\nThe obsequies were all that \xe2\x80\x9cthe boys\xe2\x80\x9d could desire. Such a marvel of\r\nfuneral pomp had never been seen in Virginia. The plumed hearse, the\r\ndirge-breathing brass bands, the closed marts of business, the flags\r\ndrooping at half mast, the long, plodding procession of uniformed secret\r\nsocieties, military battalions and fire companies, draped engines,\r\ncarriages of officials, and citizens in vehicles and on foot, attracted\r\nmultitudes of spectators to the sidewalks, roofs and windows; and for\r\nyears afterward, the degree of grandeur attained by any civic display in\r\nVirginia was determined by comparison with Buck Fanshaw\xe2\x80\x99s funeral.\r\n\r\nScotty Briggs, as a pall-bearer and a mourner, occupied a prominent\r\nplace at the funeral, and when the sermon was finished and the last\r\nsentence of the prayer for the dead man\xe2\x80\x99s soul ascended, he responded,\r\nin a low voice, but with feelings:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAMEN. No Irish need apply.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the bulk of the response was without apparent relevancy, it was\r\nprobably nothing more than a humble tribute to the memory of the friend\r\nthat was gone; for, as Scotty had once said, it was \xe2\x80\x9chis word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nScotty Briggs, in after days, achieved the distinction of becoming the\r\nonly convert to religion that was ever gathered from the Virginia\r\nroughs; and it transpired that the man who had it in him to espouse the\r\nquarrel of the weak out of inborn nobility of spirit was no mean timber\r\nwhereof to construct a Christian. The making him one did not warp his\r\ngenerosity or diminish his courage; on the contrary it gave intelligent\r\ndirection to the one and a broader field to the other.\r\n\r\nIf his Sunday-school class progressed faster than the other classes, was\r\nit matter for wonder? I think not. He talked to his pioneer small-fry in\r\na language they understood! It was my large privilege, a month before he\r\ndied, to hear him tell the beautiful story of Joseph and his brethren to\r\nhis class \xe2\x80\x9cwithout looking at the book.\xe2\x80\x9d I leave it to the reader to\r\nfancy what it was like, as it fell, riddled with slang, from the lips of\r\nthat grave, earnest teacher, and was listened to by his little learners\r\nwith a consuming interest that showed that they were as unconscious as\r\nhe was that any violence was being done to the sacred proprieties!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n338.jpg (52K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe first twenty-six graves in the Virginia cemetery were occupied by\r\nmurdered men. So everybody said, so everybody believed, and so they will\r\nalways say and believe. The reason why there was so much slaughtering\r\ndone, was, that in a new mining district the rough element predominates,\r\nand a person is not respected until he has \xe2\x80\x9ckilled his man.\xe2\x80\x9d That was\r\nthe very expression used.\r\n\r\nIf an unknown individual arrived, they did not inquire if he was\r\ncapable, honest, industrious, but\xe2\x80\x94had he killed his man? If he had not,\r\nhe gravitated to his natural and proper position, that of a man of small\r\nconsequence; if he had, the cordiality of his reception was graduated\r\naccording to the number of his dead. It was tedious work struggling up\r\nto a position of influence with bloodless hands; but when a man came\r\nwith the blood of half a dozen men on his soul, his worth was recognized\r\nat once and his acquaintance sought.\r\n\r\nIn Nevada, for a time, the lawyer, the editor, the banker, the chief\r\ndesperado, the chief gambler, and the saloon keeper, occupied the same\r\nlevel in society, and it was the highest. The cheapest and easiest way\r\nto become an influential man and be looked up to by the community at\r\nlarge, was to stand behind a bar, wear a cluster-diamond pin, and sell\r\nwhisky. I am not sure but that the saloon-keeper held a shade higher\r\nrank than any other member of society. His opinion had weight. It was\r\nhis privilege to say how the elections should go. No great movement\r\ncould succeed without the countenance and direction of the saloon-\r\nkeepers. It was a high favor when the chief saloon-keeper consented to\r\nserve in the legislature or the board of aldermen.\r\n\r\nYouthful ambition hardly aspired so much to the honors of the law, or\r\nthe army and navy as to the dignity of proprietorship in a saloon.\r\n\r\nTo be a saloon-keeper and kill a man was to be illustrious. Hence the\r\nreader will not be surprised to learn that more than one man was killed\r\nin Nevada under hardly the pretext of provocation, so impatient was the\r\nslayer to achieve reputation and throw off the galling sense of being\r\nheld in indifferent repute by his associates. I knew two youths who\r\ntried to \xe2\x80\x9ckill their men\xe2\x80\x9d for no other reason\xe2\x80\x94and got killed themselves\r\nfor their pains. \xe2\x80\x9cThere goes the man that killed Bill Adams\xe2\x80\x9d was higher\r\npraise and a sweeter sound in the ears of this sort of people than any\r\nother speech that admiring lips could utter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n340.jpg (115K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe men who murdered Virginia\xe2\x80\x99s original twenty-six cemetery-occupants\r\nwere never punished. Why? Because Alfred the Great, when he invented\r\ntrial by jury and knew that he had admirably framed it to secure justice\r\nin his age of the world, was not aware that in the nineteenth century\r\nthe condition of things would be so entirely changed that unless he rose\r\nfrom the grave and altered the jury plan to meet the emergency, it would\r\nprove the most ingenious and infallible agency for defeating justice\r\nthat human wisdom could contrive.
