For how could he imagine that we\r\nsimpletons would go on using his jury plan after circumstances had\r\nstripped it of its usefulness, any more than he could imagine that we\r\nwould go on using his candle-clock after we had invented chronometers?\r\nIn his day news could not travel fast, and hence he could easily find a\r\njury of honest, intelligent men who had not heard of the case they were\r\ncalled to try\xe2\x80\x94but in our day of telegraphs and newspapers his plan\r\ncompels us to swear in juries composed of fools and rascals, because the\r\nsystem rigidly excludes honest men and men of brains.\r\n\r\nI remember one of those sorrowful farces, in Virginia, which we call a\r\njury trial. A noted desperado killed Mr. B., a good citizen, in the most\r\nwanton and cold-blooded way. Of course the papers were full of it, and\r\nall men capable of reading, read about it. And of course all men not\r\ndeaf and dumb and idiotic, talked about it. A jury-list was made out,\r\nand Mr. B. L., a prominent banker and a valued citizen, was questioned\r\nprecisely as he would have been questioned in any court in America:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you heard of this homicide?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you held conversations upon the subject?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you formed or expressed opinions about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you read the newspaper accounts of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe do not want you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA minister, intelligent, esteemed, and greatly respected; a merchant of\r\nhigh character and known probity; a mining superintendent of\r\nintelligence and unblemished reputation; a quartz mill owner of\r\nexcellent standing, were all questioned in the same way, and all set\r\naside. Each said the public talk and the newspaper reports had not so\r\nbiased his mind but that sworn testimony would overthrow his previously\r\nformed opinions and enable him to render a verdict without prejudice and\r\nin accordance with the facts. But of course such men could not be\r\ntrusted with the case. Ignoramuses alone could mete out unsullied\r\njustice.\r\n\r\nWhen the peremptory challenges were all exhausted, a jury of twelve men\r\nwas impaneled\xe2\x80\x94a jury who swore they had neither heard, read, talked\r\nabout nor expressed an opinion concerning a murder which the very cattle\r\nin the corrals, the Indians in the sage-brush and the stones in the\r\nstreets were cognizant of! It was a jury composed of two desperadoes,\r\ntwo low beer-house politicians, three bar-keepers, two ranchmen who\r\ncould not read, and three dull, stupid, human donkeys! It actually came\r\nout afterward, that one of these latter thought that incest and arson\r\nwere the same thing.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n342.jpg (52K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe verdict rendered by this jury was, Not Guilty. What else could one\r\nexpect?\r\n\r\nThe jury system puts a ban upon intelligence and honesty, and a premium\r\nupon ignorance, stupidity and perjury. It is a shame that we must\r\ncontinue to use a worthless system because it _was_ good a thousand\r\nyears ago. In this age, when a gentleman of high social standing,\r\nintelligence and probity, swears that testimony given under solemn oath\r\nwill outweigh, with him, street talk and newspaper reports based upon\r\nmere hearsay, he is worth a hundred jurymen who will swear to their own\r\nignorance and stupidity, and justice would be far safer in his hands\r\nthan in theirs. Why could not the jury law be so altered as to give men\r\nof brains and honesty and _equal chance_ with fools and miscreants? Is\r\nit right to show the present favoritism to one class of men and inflict\r\na disability on another, in a land whose boast is that all its citizens\r\nare free and equal? I am a candidate for the legislature. I desire to\r\ntamper with the jury law. I wish to so alter it as to put a premium on\r\nintelligence and character, and close the jury box against idiots,\r\nblacklegs, and people who do not read newspapers. But no doubt I shall\r\nbe defeated\xe2\x80\x94every effort I make to save the country \xe2\x80\x9cmisses fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy idea, when I began this chapter, was to say something about\r\ndesperadoism in the \xe2\x80\x9cflush times\xe2\x80\x9d of Nevada. To attempt a portrayal of\r\nthat era and that land, and leave out the blood and carnage, would be\r\nlike portraying Mormondom and leaving out polygamy. The desperado\r\nstalked the streets with a swagger graded according to the number of his\r\nhomicides, and a nod of recognition from him was sufficient to make a\r\nhumble admirer happy for the rest of the day. The deference that was\r\npaid to a desperado of wide reputation, and who \xe2\x80\x9ckept his private\r\ngraveyard,\xe2\x80\x9d as the phrase went, was marked, and cheerfully accorded.\r\nWhen he moved along the sidewalk in his excessively long-tailed frock-\r\ncoat, shiny stump-toed boots, and with dainty little slouch hat tipped\r\nover left eye, the small-fry roughs made room for his majesty; when he\r\nentered the restaurant, the waiters deserted bankers and merchants to\r\noverwhelm him with obsequious service; when he shouldered his way to a\r\nbar, the shouldered parties wheeled indignantly, recognized him,\r\nand\xe2\x80\x94apologized.\r\n\r\nThey got a look in return that froze their marrow, and by that time a\r\ncurled and breast-pinned bar keeper was beaming over the counter, proud\r\nof the established acquaintanceship that permitted such a familiar form\r\nof speech as:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99re ye, Billy, old fel? Glad to see you. What\xe2\x80\x99ll you take\xe2\x80\x94the old\r\nthing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cold thing\xe2\x80\x9d meant his customary drink, of course.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n344.jpg (47K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe best known names in the Territory of Nevada were those belonging to\r\nthese long-tailed heroes of the revolver. Orators, Governors,\r\ncapitalists and leaders of the legislature enjoyed a degree of fame, but\r\nit seemed local and meagre when contrasted with the fame of such men as\r\nSam Brown, Jack Williams, Billy Mulligan, Farmer Pease, Sugarfoot Mike,\r\nPock Marked Jake, El Dorado Johnny, Jack McNabb, Joe McGee, Jack Harris,\r\nSix-fingered Pete, etc., etc. There was a long list of them. They were\r\nbrave, reckless men, and traveled with their lives in their hands. To\r\ngive them their due, they did their killing principally among\r\nthemselves, and seldom molested peaceable citizens, for they considered\r\nit small credit to add to their trophies so cheap a bauble as the death\r\nof a man who was \xe2\x80\x9cnot on the shoot,\xe2\x80\x9d as they phrased it. They killed\r\neach other on slight provocation, and hoped and expected to be killed\r\nthemselves\xe2\x80\x94for they held it almost shame to die otherwise than \xe2\x80\x9cwith\r\ntheir boots on,\xe2\x80\x9d as they expressed it.\r\n\r\nI remember an instance of a desperado\xe2\x80\x99s contempt for such small game as\r\na private citizen\xe2\x80\x99s life. I was taking a late supper in a restaurant one\r\nnight, with two reporters and a little printer named\xe2\x80\x94Brown, for\r\ninstance\xe2\x80\x94any name will do. Presently a stranger with a long-tailed coat\r\non came in, and not noticing Brown\xe2\x80\x99s hat, which was lying in a chair,\r\nsat down on it. Little Brown sprang up and became abusive in a moment.\r\nThe stranger smiled, smoothed out the hat, and offered it to Brown with\r\nprofuse apologies couched in caustic sarcasm, and begged Brown not to\r\ndestroy him. Brown threw off his coat and challenged the man to\r\nfight\xe2\x80\x94abused him, threatened him, impeached his courage, and urged and\r\neven implored him to fight; and in the meantime the smiling stranger\r\nplaced himself under our protection in mock distress. But presently he\r\nassumed a serious tone, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, gentlemen, if we must fight, we must, I suppose. But don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrush into danger and then say I gave you no warning. I am more than a\r\nmatch for all of you when I get started. I will give you proofs, and\r\nthen if my friend here still insists, I will try to accommodate him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe table we were sitting at was about five feet long, and unusually\r\ncumbersome and heavy. He asked us to put our hands on the dishes and\r\nhold them in their places a moment\xe2\x80\x94one of them was a large oval dish\r\nwith a portly roast on it. Then he sat down, tilted up one end of the\r\ntable, set two of the legs on his knees, took the end of the table\r\nbetween his teeth, took his hands away, and pulled down with his teeth\r\ntill the table came up to a level position, dishes and all! He said he\r\ncould lift a keg of nails with his teeth. He picked up a common glass\r\ntumbler and bit a semi-circle out of it. Then he opened his bosom and\r\nshowed us a net-work of knife and bullet scars; showed us more on his\r\narms and face, and said he believed he had bullets enough in his body to\r\nmake a pig of lead. He was armed to the teeth. He closed with the remark\r\nthat he was Mr.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94of Cariboo\xe2\x80\x94a celebrated name whereat we shook in our\r\nshoes. I would publish the name, but for the suspicion that he might\r\ncome and carve me. He finally inquired if Brown still thirsted for\r\nblood. Brown turned the thing over in his mind a moment, and then\xe2\x80\x94asked\r\nhim to supper.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n346.jpg (73K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWith the permission of the reader, I will group together, in the next\r\nchapter, some samples of life in our small mountain village in the old\r\ndays of desperadoism. I was there at the time. The reader will observe\r\npeculiarities in our official society; and he will observe also, an\r\ninstance of how, in new countries, murders breed murders.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nAn extract or two from the newspapers of the day will furnish a\r\nphotograph that can need no embellishment:\r\n\r\nFATAL SHOOTING AFFRAY.\xe2\x80\x94An affray occurred, last evening, in a billiard\r\nsaloon on C street, between Deputy Marshal Jack Williams and Wm. Brown,\r\nwhich resulted in the immediate death of the latter. There had been some\r\ndifficulty between the parties for several months.\r\n\r\nAn inquest was immediately held, and the following testimony adduced:\r\n\r\nOfficer GEO. BIRDSALL, sworn, says:\xe2\x80\x94I was told Wm. Brown was drunk and\r\nwas looking for Jack Williams; so soon as I heard that I started for the\r\nparties to prevent a collision; went into the billiard saloon; saw Billy\r\nBrown running around, saying if anybody had anything against him to show\r\ncause; he was talking in a boisterous manner, and officer Perry took him\r\nto the other end of the room to talk to him; Brown came back to me;\r\nremarked to me that he thought he was as good as anybody, and knew how\r\nto take care of himself; he passed by me and went to the bar; don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhether he drank or not; Williams was at the end of the billiard-table,\r\nnext to the stairway; Brown, after going to the bar, came back and said\r\nhe was as good as any man in the world; he had then walked out to the\r\nend of the first billiard-table from the bar; I moved closer to them,\r\nsupposing there would be a fight; as Brown drew his pistol I caught hold\r\nof it; he had fired one shot at Williams; don\xe2\x80\x99t know the effect of it;\r\ncaught hold of him with one hand, and took hold of the pistol and turned\r\nit up; think he fired once after I caught hold of the pistol; I wrenched\r\nthe pistol from him; walked to the end of the billiard-table and told a\r\nparty that I had Brown\xe2\x80\x99s pistol, and to stop shooting; I think four\r\nshots were fired in all; after walking out, Mr. Foster remarked that\r\nBrown was shot dead.\r\n\r\nOh, there was no excitement about it\xe2\x80\x94he merely \xe2\x80\x9cremarked\xe2\x80\x9d the small\r\ncircumstance!\r\n\r\nFour months later the following item appeared in the same paper (the\r\nEnterprise). In this item the name of one of the city officers above\r\nreferred to (Deputy Marshal Jack Williams) occurs again:\r\n\r\nROBBERY AND DESPERATE AFFRAY.\xe2\x80\x94On Tuesday night, a German named Charles\r\nHurtzal, engineer in a mill at Silver City, came to this place, and\r\nvisited the hurdy-gurdy house on B street. The music, dancing and\r\nTeutonic maidens awakened memories of Faderland until our German friend\r\nwas carried away with rapture. He evidently had money, and was spending\r\nif freely. Late in the evening Jack Williams and Andy Blessington\r\ninvited him down stairs to take a cup of coffee. Williams proposed a\r\ngame of cards and went up stairs to procure a deck, but not finding any\r\nreturned. On the stairway he met the German, and drawing his pistol\r\nknocked him down and rifled his pockets of some seventy dollars. Hurtzal\r\ndared give no alarm, as he was told, with a pistol at his head, if he\r\nmade any noise or exposed them, they would blow his brains out. So\r\neffectually was he frightened that he made no complaint, until his\r\nfriends forced him. Yesterday a warrant was issued, but the culprits had\r\ndisappeared.\r\n\r\nThis efficient city officer, Jack Williams, had the common reputation of\r\nbeing a burglar, a highwayman and a desperado. It was said that he had\r\nseveral times drawn his revolver and levied money contributions on\r\ncitizens at dead of night in the public streets of Virginia.\r\n\r\nFive months after the above item appeared, Williams was assassinated\r\nwhile sitting at a card table one night; a gun was thrust through the\r\ncrack of the door and Williams dropped from his chair riddled with\r\nballs. It was said, at the time, that Williams had been for some time\r\naware that a party of his own sort (desperadoes) had sworn away his\r\nlife; and it was generally believed among the people that Williams\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfriends and enemies would make the assassination memorable\xe2\x80\x94and useful,\r\ntoo\xe2\x80\x94by a wholesale destruction of each other.\r\n\r\nIt did not so happen, but still, times were not dull during the next\r\ntwenty-four hours, for within that time a woman was killed by a pistol\r\nshot, a man was brained with a slung shot, and a man named Reeder was\r\nalso disposed of permanently. Some matters in the Enterprise account of\r\nthe killing of Reeder are worth nothing\xe2\x80\x94especially the accommodating\r\ncomplaisance of a Virginia justice of the peace. The italics in the\r\nfollowing narrative are mine:\r\n\r\nMORE CUTTING AND SHOOTING.\xe2\x80\x94The devil seems to have again broken loose in\r\nour town. Pistols and guns explode and knives gleam in our streets as in\r\nearly times. When there has been a long season of quiet, people are slow\r\nto wet their hands in blood; but once blood is spilled, cutting and\r\nshooting come easy. Night before last Jack Williams was assassinated,\r\nand yesterday forenoon we had more bloody work, growing out of the\r\nkilling of Williams, and on the same street in which he met his death.\r\nIt appears that Tom Reeder, a friend of Williams, and George Gumbert\r\nwere talking, at the meat market of the latter, about the killing of\r\nWilliams the previous night, when Reeder said it was a most cowardly act\r\nto shoot a man in such a way, giving him \xe2\x80\x9cno show.\xe2\x80\x9d Gumbert said that\r\nWilliams had \xe2\x80\x9cas good a show as he gave Billy Brown,\xe2\x80\x9d meaning the man\r\nkilled by Williams last March. Reeder said it was a d\xe2\x80\x94-d lie, that\r\nWilliams had no show at all. At this, Gumbert drew a knife and stabbed\r\nReeder, cutting him in two places in the back. One stroke of the knife\r\ncut into the sleeve of Reeder\xe2\x80\x99s coat and passed downward in a slanting\r\ndirection through his clothing, and entered his body at the small of the\r\nback; another blow struck more squarely, and made a much more dangerous\r\nwound. Gumbert gave himself up to the officers of justice, and was\r\nshortly after discharged by Justice Atwill, on his own recognizance, to\r\nappear for trial at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening. In the meantime Reeder\r\nhad been taken into the office of Dr. Owens, where his wounds were\r\nproperly dressed. One of his wounds was considered quite dangerous, and\r\nit was thought by many that it would prove fatal. But being considerably\r\nunder the influence of liquor, Reeder did not feel his wounds as he\r\notherwise would, and he got up and went into the street. He went to the\r\nmeat market and renewed his quarrel with Gumbert, threatening his life.\r\nFriends tried to interfere to put a stop to the quarrel and get the\r\nparties away from each other. In the Fashion Saloon Reeder made threats\r\nagainst the life of Gumbert, saying he would kill him, and it is said\r\nthat he requested the officers not to arrest Gumbert, as he intended to\r\nkill him. After these threats Gumbert went off and procured a double-\r\nbarreled shot gun, loaded with buck-shot or revolver balls, and went\r\nafter Reeder. Two or three persons were assisting him along the street,\r\ntrying to get him home, and had him just in front of the store of\r\nKlopstock & Harris, when Gumbert came across toward him from the\r\nopposite side of the street with his gun. He came up within about ten or\r\nfifteen feet of Reeder, and called out to those with him to \xe2\x80\x9clook out!\r\nget out of the way!\xe2\x80\x9d and they had only time to heed the warning, when he\r\nfired. Reeder was at the time attempting to screen himself behind a\r\nlarge cask, which stood against the awning post of Klopstock & Harris\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstore, but some of the balls took effect in the lower part of his\r\nbreast, and he reeled around forward and fell in front of the cask.\r\nGumbert then raised his gun and fired the second barrel, which missed\r\nReeder and entered the ground. At the time that this occurred, there\r\nwere a great many persons on the street in the vicinity, and a number of\r\nthem called out to Gumbert, when they saw him raise his gun, to \xe2\x80\x9chold\r\non,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t shoot!\xe2\x80\x9d The cutting took place about ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock and the\r\nshooting about twelve. After the shooting the street was instantly\r\ncrowded with the inhabitants of that part of the town, some appearing\r\nmuch excited and laughing\xe2\x80\x94declaring that it looked like the \xe2\x80\x9cgood old\r\ntimes of \xe2\x80\x9860.\xe2\x80\x9d Marshal Perry and officer Birdsall were near when the\r\nshooting occurred, and Gumbert was immediately arrested and his gun\r\ntaken from him, when he was marched off to jail. Many persons who were\r\nattracted to the spot where this bloody work had just taken place,\r\nlooked bewildered and seemed to be asking themselves what was to happen\r\nnext, appearing in doubt as to whether the killing mania had reached its\r\nclimax, or whether we were to turn in and have a grand killing spell,\r\nshooting whoever might have given us offence. It was whispered around\r\nthat it was not all over yet\xe2\x80\x94five or six more were to be killed before\r\nnight. Reeder was taken to the Virginia City Hotel, and doctors called\r\nin to examine his wounds. They found that two or three balls had entered\r\nhis right side; one of them appeared to have passed through the\r\nsubstance of the lungs, while another passed into the liver. Two balls\r\nwere also found to have struck one of his legs. As some of the balls\r\nstruck the cask, the wounds in Reeder\xe2\x80\x99s leg were probably from these,\r\nglancing downwards, though they might have been caused by the second\r\nshot fired. After being shot, Reeder said when he got on his\r\nfeet\xe2\x80\x94smiling as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt will take better shooting than that to kill\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d The doctors consider it almost impossible for him to recover, but\r\nas he has an excellent constitution he may survive, notwithstanding the\r\nnumber and dangerous character of the wounds he has received. The town\r\nappears to be perfectly quiet at present, as though the late stormy\r\ntimes had cleared our moral atmosphere; but who can tell in what quarter\r\nclouds are lowering or plots ripening?\r\n\r\nReeder\xe2\x80\x94or at least what was left of him\xe2\x80\x94survived his wounds two days!\r\nNothing was ever done with Gumbert.\r\n\r\nTrial by jury is the palladium of our liberties. I do not know what a\r\npalladium is, having never seen a palladium, but it is a good thing no\r\ndoubt at any rate. Not less than a hundred men have been murdered in\r\nNevada\xe2\x80\x94perhaps I would be within bounds if I said three hundred\xe2\x80\x94and as\r\nfar as I can learn, only two persons have suffered the death penalty\r\nthere. However, four or five who had no money and no political influence\r\nhave been punished by imprisonment\xe2\x80\x94one languished in prison as much as\r\neight months, I think. However, I do not desire to be extravagant\xe2\x80\x94it may\r\nhave been less.\r\n\r\nHowever, one prophecy was verified, at any rate. It was asserted by the\r\ndesperadoes that one of their brethren (Joe McGee, a special policeman)\r\nwas known to be the conspirator chosen by lot to assassinate Williams;\r\nand they also asserted that doom had been pronounced against McGee, and\r\nthat he would be assassinated in exactly the same manner that had been\r\nadopted for the destruction of Williams\xe2\x80\x94a prophecy which came true a\r\nyear later. After twelve months of distress (for McGee saw a fancied\r\nassassin in every man that approached him), he made the last of many\r\nefforts to get out of the country unwatched. He went to Carson and sat\r\ndown in a saloon to wait for the stage\xe2\x80\x94it would leave at four in the\r\nmorning. But as the night waned and the crowd thinned, he grew uneasy,\r\nand told the bar-keeper that assassins were on his track. The bar-keeper\r\ntold him to stay in the middle of the room, then, and not go near the\r\ndoor, or the window by the stove. But a fatal fascination seduced him to\r\nthe neighborhood of the stove every now and then, and repeatedly the\r\nbar-keeper brought him back to the middle of the room and warned him to\r\nremain there. But he could not. At three in the morning he again\r\nreturned to the stove and sat down by a stranger. Before the bar-keeper\r\ncould get to him with another warning whisper, some one outside fired\r\nthrough the window and riddled McGee\xe2\x80\x99s breast with slugs, killing him\r\nalmost instantly. By the same discharge the stranger at McGee\xe2\x80\x99s side\r\nalso received attentions which proved fatal in the course of two or\r\nthree days.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n351.jpg (9K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER L.\r\n\r\n\r\nThese murder and jury statistics remind me of a certain very\r\nextraordinary trial and execution of twenty years ago; it is a scrap of\r\nhistory familiar to all old Californians, and worthy to be known by\r\nother peoples of the earth that love simple, straightforward justice\r\nunencumbered with nonsense. I would apologize for this digression but\r\nfor the fact that the information I am about to offer is apology enough\r\nin itself. And since I digress constantly anyhow, perhaps it is as well\r\nto eschew apologies altogether and thus prevent their growing irksome.\r\n\r\nCapt. Ned Blakely\xe2\x80\x94that name will answer as well as any other fictitious\r\none (for he was still with the living at last accounts, and may not\r\ndesire to be famous)\xe2\x80\x94sailed ships out of the harbor of San Francisco for\r\nmany years. He was a stalwart, warm-hearted, eagle-eyed veteran, who had\r\nbeen a sailor nearly fifty years\xe2\x80\x94a sailor from early boyhood. He was a\r\nrough, honest creature, full of pluck, and just as full of hard-headed\r\nsimplicity, too. He hated trifling conventionalities\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness\xe2\x80\x9d was the\r\nword, with him. He had all a sailor\xe2\x80\x99s vindictiveness against the quips\r\nand quirks of the law, and steadfastly believed that the first and last\r\naim and object of the law and lawyers was to defeat justice.\r\n\r\nHe sailed for the Chincha Islands in command of a guano ship. He had a\r\nfine crew, but his negro mate was his pet\xe2\x80\x94on him he had for years\r\nlavished his admiration and esteem. It was Capt. Ned\xe2\x80\x99s first voyage to\r\nthe Chinchas, but his fame had gone before him\xe2\x80\x94the fame of being a man\r\nwho would fight at the dropping of a handkerchief, when imposed upon,\r\nand would stand no nonsense. It was a fame well earned. Arrived in the\r\nislands, he found that the staple of conversation was the exploits of\r\none Bill Noakes, a bully, the mate of a trading ship. This man had\r\ncreated a small reign of terror there. At nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night, Capt.\r\nNed, all alone, was pacing his deck in the starlight. A form ascended\r\nthe side, and approached him. Capt. Ned said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n353.jpg (77K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Bill Noakes, the best man in the islands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want aboard this ship?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of Capt. Ned Blakely, and one of us is a better man than\r\n\xe2\x80\x99tother\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll know which, before I go ashore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve come to the right shop\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m your man. I\xe2\x80\x99ll learn you to come\r\naboard this ship without an _in_vite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe seized Noakes, backed him against the mainmast, pounded his face to a\r\npulp, and then threw him overboard.\r\n\r\nNoakes was not convinced. He returned the next night, got the pulp\r\nrenewed, and went overboard head first, as before.\r\n\r\nHe was satisfied.\r\n\r\nA week after this, while Noakes was carousing with a sailor crowd on\r\nshore, at noonday, Capt. Ned\xe2\x80\x99s colored mate came along, and Noakes tried\r\nto pick a quarrel with him. The negro evaded the trap, and tried to get\r\naway. Noakes followed him up; the negro began to run; Noakes fired on\r\nhim with a revolver and killed him. Half a dozen sea-captains witnessed\r\nthe whole affair. Noakes retreated to the small after-cabin of his ship,\r\nwith two other bullies, and gave out that death would be the portion of\r\nany man that intruded there. There was no attempt made to follow the\r\nvillains; there was no disposition to do it, and indeed very little\r\nthought of such an enterprise. There were no courts and no officers;\r\nthere was no government; the islands belonged to Peru, and Peru was far\r\naway; she had no official representative on the ground; and neither had\r\nany other nation.\r\n\r\nHowever, Capt. Ned was not perplexing his head about such things. They\r\nconcerned him not. He was boiling with rage and furious for justice. At\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night he loaded a double-barreled gun with slugs, fished\r\nout a pair of handcuffs, got a ship\xe2\x80\x99s lantern, summoned his\r\nquartermaster, and went ashore. He said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you see that ship there at the dock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy-ay, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the Venus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy-ay, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x94you know _me_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy-ay, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, then. Take the lantern. Carry it just under your chin. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nwalk behind you and rest this gun-barrel on your shoulder, p\xe2\x80\x99inting\r\nforward\xe2\x80\x94so. Keep your lantern well up so\xe2\x80\x99s I can see things ahead of you\r\ngood. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to march in on Noakes\xe2\x80\x94and take him\xe2\x80\x94and jug the other\r\nchaps. If you flinch\xe2\x80\x94well, you know _me_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy-ay, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn this order they filed aboard softly, arrived at Noakes\xe2\x80\x99s den, the\r\nquartermaster pushed the door open, and the lantern revealed the three\r\ndesperadoes sitting on the floor. Capt. Ned said:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n355.jpg (93K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Ned Blakely. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got you under fire. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you move without\r\norders\xe2\x80\x94any of you. You two kneel down in the corner; faces to the\r\nwall\xe2\x80\x94now. Bill Noakes, put these handcuffs on; now come up close.\r\nQuartermaster, fasten \xe2\x80\x99em. All right. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir, sir. Quartermaster,\r\nput the key in the outside of the door. Now, men, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to lock you\r\ntwo in; and if you try to burst through this door\xe2\x80\x94well, you\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of\r\n_me_. Bill Noakes, fall in ahead, and march. All set. Quartermaster,\r\nlock the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoakes spent the night on board Blakely\xe2\x80\x99s ship, a prisoner under strict\r\nguard. Early in the morning Capt. Ned called in all the sea-captains in\r\nthe harbor and invited them, with nautical ceremony, to be present on\r\nboard his ship at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock to witness the hanging of Noakes at the\r\nyard-arm!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! The man has not been tried.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t. But didn\xe2\x80\x99t he kill the nigger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly he did; but you are not thinking of hanging him without a\r\ntrial?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Trial_! What do I want to try him for, if he killed the nigger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Capt. Ned, this will _never_ do. Think how it will sound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSound be hanged! Didn\xe2\x80\x99t he kill the nigger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, certainly, Capt. Ned,\xe2\x80\x94nobody denies that,\xe2\x80\x94but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I\xe2\x80\x99m _going to hang him_, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Everybody I\xe2\x80\x99ve talked to\r\ntalks just the same way you do. Everybody says he killed the nigger,\r\neverybody knows he killed the nigger, and yet every lubber of you wants\r\nhim _tried_ for it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand such bloody foolishness as that.\r\n_Tried_! Mind you, I don\xe2\x80\x99t object to trying him, if it\xe2\x80\x99s got to be done\r\nto give satisfaction; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll be there, and chip in and help, too; but\r\nput it off till afternoon\xe2\x80\x94put it off till afternoon, for I\xe2\x80\x99ll have my\r\nhands middling full till after the burying\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what do you mean? Are you going to _hang_ him any how\xe2\x80\x94and try him\r\nafterward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I say I was going to _hang_ him? I never saw such people as you.\r\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the difference? You ask a favor, and then you ain\xe2\x80\x99t satisfied\r\nwhen you get it. Before or after\xe2\x80\x99s all one\xe2\x80\x94_you_ know how the trial will\r\ngo. He killed the nigger. Say\xe2\x80\x94I must be going. If your mate would like\r\nto come to the hanging, fetch him along. I like him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a stir in the camp. The captains came in a body and pleaded\r\nwith Capt. Ned not to do this rash thing. They promised that they would\r\ncreate a court composed of captains of the best character; they would\r\nempanel a jury; they would conduct everything in a way becoming the\r\nserious nature of the business in hand, and give the case an impartial\r\nhearing and the accused a fair trial. And they said it would be murder,\r\nand punishable by the American courts if he persisted and hung the\r\naccused on his ship. They pleaded hard. Capt. Ned said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I\xe2\x80\x99m not stubborn and I\xe2\x80\x99m not unreasonable. I\xe2\x80\x99m always\r\nwilling to do just as near right as I can. How long will it take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably only a little while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd can I take him up the shore and hang him as soon as you are done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_If_ he is proven guilty he shall be hanged without unnecessary delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he\xe2\x80\x99s proven guilty. Great Neptune, _ain\xe2\x80\x99t_ he guilty? This beats my\r\ntime. Why you all _know_ he\xe2\x80\x99s guilty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut at last they satisfied him that they were projecting nothing\r\nunderhanded. Then he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all right. You go on and try him and I\xe2\x80\x99ll go down and overhaul\r\nhis conscience and prepare him to go\xe2\x80\x94like enough he needs it, and I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want to send him off without a show for hereafter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was another obstacle. They finally convinced him that it was\r\nnecessary to have the accused in court. Then they said they would send a\r\nguard to bring him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, I prefer to fetch him myself\xe2\x80\x94he don\xe2\x80\x99t get out of _my_ hands.\r\nBesides, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to go to the ship to get a rope, anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe court assembled with due ceremony, empaneled a jury, and presently\r\nCapt. Ned entered, leading the prisoner with one hand and carrying a\r\nBible and a rope in the other. He seated himself by the side of his\r\ncaptive and told the court to \xe2\x80\x9cup anchor and make sail.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he turned\r\na searching eye on the jury, and detected Noakes\xe2\x80\x99s friends, the two\r\nbullies.\r\n\r\nHe strode over and said to them confidentially:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re here to interfere, you see. Now you vote right, do you hear?\xe2\x80\x94or\r\nelse there\xe2\x80\x99ll be a double-barreled inquest here when this trial\xe2\x80\x99s off,\r\nand your remainders will go home in a couple of baskets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe caution was not without fruit. The jury was a unit\xe2\x80\x94the verdict.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuilty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCapt. Ned sprung to his feet and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re my meat _now_, my lad, anyway. Gentlemen you\xe2\x80\x99ve done\r\nyourselves proud. I invite you all to come and see that I do it all\r\nstraight. Follow me to the canyon, a mile above here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe court informed him that a sheriff had been appointed to do the\r\nhanging, and\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nCapt. Ned\xe2\x80\x99s patience was at an end. His wrath was boundless. The subject\r\nof a sheriff was judiciously dropped.\r\n\r\nWhen the crowd arrived at the canyon, Capt. Ned climbed a tree and\r\narranged the halter, then came down and noosed his man. He opened his\r\nBible, and laid aside his hat. Selecting a chapter at random, he read it\r\nthrough, in a deep bass voice and with sincere solemnity. Then he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLad, you are about to go aloft and give an account of yourself; and the\r\nlighter a man\xe2\x80\x99s manifest is, as far as sin\xe2\x80\x99s concerned, the better for\r\nhim. Make a clean breast, man, and carry a log with you that\xe2\x80\x99ll bear\r\ninspection. You killed the nigger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n358.jpg (61K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNo reply. A long pause.\r\n\r\nThe captain read another chapter, pausing, from time to time, to impress\r\nthe effect. Then he talked an earnest, persuasive sermon to him, and\r\nended by repeating the question:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you kill the nigger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo reply\xe2\x80\x94other than a malignant scowl. The captain now read the first\r\nand second chapters of Genesis, with deep feeling\xe2\x80\x94paused a moment,\r\nclosed the book reverently, and said with a perceptible savor of\r\nsatisfaction:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere. Four chapters. There\xe2\x80\x99s few that would have took the pains with\r\nyou that I have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he swung up the condemned, and made the rope fast; stood by and\r\ntimed him half an hour with his watch, and then delivered the body to\r\nthe court. A little after, as he stood contemplating the motionless\r\nfigure, a doubt came into his face; evidently he felt a twinge of\r\nconscience\xe2\x80\x94a misgiving\xe2\x80\x94and he said with a sigh:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, p\xe2\x80\x99raps I ought to burnt him, maybe. But I was trying to do for\r\nthe best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the history of this affair reached California (it was in the \xe2\x80\x9cearly\r\ndays\xe2\x80\x9d) it made a deal of talk, but did not diminish the captain\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npopularity in any degree. It increased it, indeed. California had a\r\npopulation then that \xe2\x80\x9cinflicted\xe2\x80\x9d justice after a fashion that was\r\nsimplicity and primitiveness itself, and could therefore admire\r\nappreciatively when the same fashion was followed elsewhere.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n359.jpg (38K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LI.\r\n\r\n\r\nVice flourished luxuriantly during the hey-day of our \xe2\x80\x9cflush times.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nsaloons were overburdened with custom; so were the police courts, the\r\ngambling dens, the brothels and the jails\xe2\x80\x94unfailing signs of high\r\nprosperity in a mining region\xe2\x80\x94in any region for that matter. Is it not\r\nso? A crowded police court docket is the surest of all signs that trade\r\nis brisk and money plenty. Still, there is one other sign; it comes\r\nlast, but when it does come it establishes beyond cavil that the \xe2\x80\x9cflush\r\ntimes\xe2\x80\x9d are at the flood. This is the birth of the \xe2\x80\x9cliterary\xe2\x80\x9d paper. The\r\nWeekly Occidental, \xe2\x80\x9cdevoted to literature,\xe2\x80\x9d made its appearance in\r\nVirginia. All the literary people were engaged to write for it. Mr. F.\r\nwas to edit it. He was a felicitous skirmisher with a pen, and a man who\r\ncould say happy things in a crisp, neat way. Once, while editor of the\r\n_Union_, he had disposed of a labored, incoherent, two-column attack\r\nmade upon him by a contemporary, with a single line, which, at first\r\nglance, seemed to contain a solemn and tremendous compliment\xe2\x80\x94viz.: \xe2\x80\x9cTHE\r\nLOGIC OF OUR ADVERSARY RESEMBLES THE PEACE OF GOD,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and left it to the\r\nreader\xe2\x80\x99s memory and after-thought to invest the remark with another and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmore different\xe2\x80\x9d meaning by supplying for himself and at his own leisure\r\nthe rest of the Scripture\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_in that it passeth understanding._\xe2\x80\x9d He once\r\nsaid of a little, half-starved, wayside community that had no\r\nsubsistence except what they could get by preying upon chance passengers\r\nwho stopped over with them a day when traveling by the overland stage,\r\nthat in their Church service they had altered the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s Prayer to read:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive us this day our daily stranger!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe expected great things of the Occidental. Of course it could not get\r\nalong without an original novel, and so we made arrangements to hurl\r\ninto the work the full strength of the company. Mrs. F. was an able\r\nromancist of the ineffable school\xe2\x80\x94I know no other name to apply to a\r\nschool whose heroes are all dainty and all perfect. She wrote the\r\nopening chapter, and introduced a lovely blonde simpleton who talked\r\nnothing but pearls and poetry and who was virtuous to the verge of\r\neccentricity. She also introduced a young French Duke of aggravated\r\nrefinement, in love with the blonde. Mr. F. followed next week, with a\r\nbrilliant lawyer who set about getting the Duke\xe2\x80\x99s estates into trouble,\r\nand a sparkling young lady of high society who fell to fascinating the\r\nDuke and impairing the appetite of the blonde. Mr. D., a dark and bloody\r\neditor of one of the dailies, followed Mr. F., the third week,\r\nintroducing a mysterious Roscicrucian who transmuted metals, held\r\nconsultations with the devil in a cave at dead of night, and cast the\r\nhoroscope of the several heroes and heroines in such a way as to provide\r\nplenty of trouble for their future careers and breed a solemn and awful\r\npublic interest in the novel. He also introduced a cloaked and masked\r\nmelodramatic miscreant, put him on a salary and set him on the midnight\r\ntrack of the Duke with a poisoned dagger. He also created an Irish\r\ncoachman with a rich brogue and placed him in the service of the\r\nsociety-young-lady with an ulterior mission to carry billet-doux to the\r\nDuke.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n361.jpg (79K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout this time there arrived in Virginia a dissolute stranger with a\r\nliterary turn of mind\xe2\x80\x94rather seedy he was, but very quiet and\r\nunassuming; almost diffident, indeed. He was so gentle, and his manners\r\nwere so pleasing and kindly, whether he was sober or intoxicated, that\r\nhe made friends of all who came in contact with him. He applied for\r\nliterary work, offered conclusive evidence that he wielded an easy and\r\npracticed pen, and so Mr. F. engaged him at once to help write the\r\nnovel. His chapter was to follow Mr. D.\xe2\x80\x99s, and mine was to come next.\r\nNow what does this fellow do but go off and get drunk and then proceed\r\nto his quarters and set to work with his imagination in a state of\r\nchaos, and that chaos in a condition of extravagant activity. The result\r\nmay be guessed. He scanned the chapters of his predecessors, found\r\nplenty of heroes and heroines already created, and was satisfied with\r\nthem; he decided to introduce no more; with all the confidence that\r\nwhisky inspires and all the easy complacency it gives to its servant, he\r\nthen launched himself lovingly into his work: he married the coachman to\r\nthe society-young-lady for the sake of the scandal; married the Duke to\r\nthe blonde\xe2\x80\x99s stepmother, for the sake of the sensation; stopped the\r\ndesperado\xe2\x80\x99s salary; created a misunderstanding between the devil and the\r\nRoscicrucian; threw the Duke\xe2\x80\x99s property into the wicked lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s hands;\r\nmade the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s upbraiding conscience drive him to drink, thence to\r\ndelirium tremens, thence to suicide; broke the coachman\xe2\x80\x99s neck; let his\r\nwidow succumb to contumely, neglect, poverty and consumption; caused the\r\nblonde to drown herself, leaving her clothes on the bank with the\r\ncustomary note pinned to them forgiving the Duke and hoping he would be\r\nhappy; revealed to the Duke, by means of the usual strawberry mark on\r\nleft arm, that he had married his own long-lost mother and destroyed his\r\nlong-lost sister; instituted the proper and necessary suicide of the\r\nDuke and the Duchess in order to compass poetical justice; opened the\r\nearth and let the Roscicrucian through, accompanied with the accustomed\r\nsmoke and thunder and smell of brimstone, and finished with the promise\r\nthat in the next chapter, after holding a general inquest, he would take\r\nup the surviving character of the novel and tell what became of the\r\ndevil!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n362.jpg (39K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt read with singular smoothness, and with a \xe2\x80\x9cdead\xe2\x80\x9d earnestness that was\r\nfunny enough to suffocate a body. But there was war when it came in. The\r\nother novelists were furious. The mild stranger, not yet more than half\r\nsober, stood there, under a scathing fire of vituperation, meek and\r\nbewildered, looking from one to another of his assailants, and wondering\r\nwhat he could have done to invoke such a storm. When a lull came at\r\nlast, he said his say gently and appealingly\xe2\x80\x94said he did not rightly\r\nremember what he had written, but was sure he had tried to do the best\r\nhe could, and knew his object had been to make the novel not only\r\npleasant and plausible but instructive and\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nThe bombardment began again. The novelists assailed his ill-chosen\r\nadjectives and demolished them with a storm of denunciation and\r\nridicule. And so the siege went on. Every time the stranger tried to\r\nappease the enemy he only made matters worse. Finally he offered to\r\nrewrite the chapter. This arrested hostilities. The indignation\r\ngradually quieted down, peace reigned again and the sufferer retired in\r\nsafety and got him to his own citadel.\r\n\r\nBut on the way thither the evil angel tempted him and he got drunk\r\nagain. And again his imagination went mad. He led the heroes and\r\nheroines a wilder dance than ever; and yet all through it ran that same\r\nconvincing air of honesty and earnestness that had marked his first\r\nwork. He got the characters into the most extraordinary situations, put\r\nthem through the most surprising performances, and made them talk the\r\nstrangest talk! But the chapter cannot be described. It was\r\nsymmetrically crazy; it was artistically absurd; and it had explanatory\r\nfootnotes that were fully as curious as the text. I remember one of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csituations,\xe2\x80\x9d and will offer it as an example of the whole. He altered\r\nthe character of the brilliant lawyer, and made him a great-hearted,\r\nsplendid fellow; gave him fame and riches, and set his age at thirty-\r\nthree years. Then he made the blonde discover, through the help of the\r\nRoscicrucian and the melodramatic miscreant, that while the Duke loved\r\nher money ardently and wanted it, he secretly felt a sort of leaning\r\ntoward the society-young-lady. Stung to the quick, she tore her\r\naffections from him and bestowed them with tenfold power upon the\r\nlawyer, who responded with consuming zeal. But the parents would none of\r\nit. What they wanted in the family was a Duke; and a Duke they were\r\ndetermined to have; though they confessed that next to the Duke the\r\nlawyer had their preference. Necessarily the blonde now went into a\r\ndecline. The parents were alarmed. They pleaded with her to marry the\r\nDuke, but she steadfastly refused, and pined on. Then they laid a plan.\r\nThey told her to wait a year and a day, and if at the end of that time\r\nshe still felt that she could not marry the Duke, she might marry the\r\nlawyer with their full consent. The result was as they had foreseen:\r\ngladness came again, and the flush of returning health. Then the parents\r\ntook the next step in their scheme. They had the family physician\r\nrecommend a long sea voyage and much land travel for the thorough\r\nrestoration of the blonde\xe2\x80\x99s strength; and they invited the Duke to be of\r\nthe party. They judged that the Duke\xe2\x80\x99s constant presence and the\r\nlawyer\xe2\x80\x99s protracted absence would do the rest\xe2\x80\x94for they did not invite\r\nthe lawyer.\r\n\r\nSo they set sail in a steamer for America\xe2\x80\x94and the third day out, when\r\ntheir sea-sickness called truce and permitted them to take their first\r\nmeal at the public table, behold there sat the lawyer! The Duke and\r\nparty made the best of an awkward situation; the voyage progressed, and\r\nthe vessel neared America.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n365.jpg (74K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut, by and by, two hundred miles off New Bedford, the ship took fire;\r\nshe burned to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge; of all her crew and passengers, only\r\nthirty were saved. They floated about the sea half an afternoon and all\r\nnight long. Among them were our friends. The lawyer, by superhuman\r\nexertions, had saved the blonde and her parents, swimming back and forth\r\ntwo hundred yards and bringing one each time\xe2\x80\x94(the girl first). The Duke\r\nhad saved himself. In the morning two whale ships arrived on the scene\r\nand sent their boats. The weather was stormy and the embarkation was\r\nattended with much confusion and excitement. The lawyer did his duty\r\nlike a man; helped his exhausted and insensible blonde, her parents and\r\nsome others into a boat (the Duke helped himself in); then a child fell\r\noverboard at the other end of the raft and the lawyer rushed thither and\r\nhelped half a dozen people fish it out, under the stimulus of its\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s screams. Then he ran back\xe2\x80\x94a few seconds too late\xe2\x80\x94the blonde\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboat was under way. So he had to take the other boat, and go to the\r\nother ship. The storm increased and drove the vessels out of sight of\r\neach other\xe2\x80\x94drove them whither it would.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n366.jpg (83K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen it calmed, at the end of three days, the blonde\xe2\x80\x99s ship was seven\r\nhundred miles north of Boston and the other about seven hundred south of\r\nthat port. The blonde\xe2\x80\x99s captain was bound on a whaling cruise in the\r\nNorth Atlantic and could not go back such a distance or make a port\r\nwithout orders; such being nautical law. The lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s captain was to\r\ncruise in the North Pacific, and _he_ could not go back or make a port\r\nwithout orders. All the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s money and baggage were in the blonde\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboat and went to the blonde\xe2\x80\x99s ship\xe2\x80\x94so his captain made him work his\r\npassage as a common sailor. When both ships had been cruising nearly a\r\nyear, the one was off the coast of Greenland and the other in Behring\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nStrait. The blonde had long ago been well-nigh persuaded that her lawyer\r\nhad been washed overboard and lost just before the whale ships reached\r\nthe raft, and now, under the pleadings of her parents and the Duke she\r\nwas at last beginning to nerve herself for the doom of the covenant, and\r\nprepare for the hated marriage.\r\n\r\nBut she would not yield a day before the date set. The weeks dragged on,\r\nthe time narrowed, orders were given to deck the ship for the wedding\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nwedding at sea among icebergs and walruses. Five days more and all would\r\nbe over. So the blonde reflected, with a sigh and a tear. Oh where was\r\nher true love\xe2\x80\x94and why, why did he not come and save her? At that moment\r\nhe was lifting his harpoon to strike a whale in Behring\xe2\x80\x99s Strait, five\r\nthousand miles away, by the way of the Arctic Ocean, or twenty thousand\r\nby the way of the Horn\xe2\x80\x94that was the reason. He struck, but not with\r\nperfect aim\xe2\x80\x94his foot slipped and he fell in the whale\xe2\x80\x99s mouth and went\r\ndown his throat. He was insensible five days. Then he came to himself\r\nand heard voices; daylight was streaming through a hole cut in the\r\nwhale\xe2\x80\x99s roof. He climbed out and astonished the sailors who were\r\nhoisting blubber up a ship\xe2\x80\x99s side. He recognized the vessel, flew\r\naboard, surprised the wedding party at the altar and exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop the proceedings\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m here! Come to my arms, my own!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n367.jpg (88K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were foot-notes to this extravagant piece of literature wherein\r\nthe author endeavored to show that the whole thing was within the\r\npossibilities; he said he got the incident of the whale traveling from\r\nBehring\xe2\x80\x99s Strait to the coast of Greenland, five thousand miles in five\r\ndays, through the Arctic Ocean, from Charles Reade\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLove Me Little\r\nLove Me Long,\xe2\x80\x9d and considered that that established the fact that the\r\nthing could be done; and he instanced Jonah\xe2\x80\x99s adventure as proof that a\r\nman could live in a whale\xe2\x80\x99s belly, and added that if a preacher could\r\nstand it three days a lawyer could surely stand it five!\r\n\r\nThere was a fiercer storm than ever in the editorial sanctum now, and\r\nthe stranger was peremptorily discharged, and his manuscript flung at\r\nhis head. But he had already delayed things so much that there was not\r\ntime for some one else to rewrite the chapter, and so the paper came out\r\nwithout any novel in it. It was but a feeble, struggling, stupid\r\njournal, and the absence of the novel probably shook public confidence;\r\nat any rate, before the first side of the next issue went to press, the\r\nWeekly Occidental died as peacefully as an infant.\r\n\r\nAn effort was made to resurrect it, with the proposed advantage of a\r\ntelling new title, and Mr. F. said that The _Phenix_ would be just the\r\nname for it, because it would give the idea of a resurrection from its\r\ndead ashes in a new and undreamed of condition of splendor; but some\r\nlow- priced smarty on one of the dailies suggested that we call it the\r\n_Lazarus_; and inasmuch as the people were not profound in Scriptural\r\nmatters but thought the resurrected Lazarus and the dilapidated\r\nmendicant that begged in the rich man\xe2\x80\x99s gateway were one and the same\r\nperson, the name became the laughing stock of the town, and killed the\r\npaper for good and all.\r\n\r\nI was sorry enough, for I was very proud of being connected with a\r\nliterary paper\xe2\x80\x94prouder than I have ever been of anything since, perhaps.\r\nI had written some rhymes for it\xe2\x80\x94poetry I considered it\xe2\x80\x94and it was a\r\ngreat grief to me that the production was on the \xe2\x80\x9cfirst side\xe2\x80\x9d of the\r\nissue that was not completed, and hence did not see the light. But time\r\nbrings its revenges\xe2\x80\x94I can put it in here; it will answer in place of a\r\ntear dropped to the memory of the lost Occidental. The idea (not the\r\nchief idea, but the vehicle that bears it) was probably suggested by the\r\nold song called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Raging Canal,\xe2\x80\x9d but I cannot remember now. I do\r\nremember, though, that at that time I thought my doggerel was one of the\r\nablest poems of the age: THE AGED PILOT MAN.\r\n\r\nOn the Erie Canal, it was, All on a summer\xe2\x80\x99s day, I sailed forth with my\r\nparents Far away to Albany.\r\n\r\nFrom out the clouds at noon that day There came a dreadful storm, That\r\npiled the billows high about, And filled us with alarm.\r\n\r\nA man came rushing from a house, Saying, \xe2\x80\x98Snub up your boat I pray, [The\r\ncustomary canal technicality for \xe2\x80\x9dtie up.\xe2\x80\x9c] Snub up your boat, snub up,\r\nalas, Snub up while yet you may.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOur captain cast one glance astern, Then forward glanc\xc3\xa8d he, And said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife and little ones I never more shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaid Dollinger the pilot man, In noble words, but few,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFear not, but\r\nlean on Dollinger, And he will fetch you through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n370.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe boat drove on, the frightened mules Tore through the rain and wind,\r\nAnd bravely still, in danger\xe2\x80\x99s post, The whip-boy strode behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome \xe2\x80\x99board, come \xe2\x80\x99board,\xe2\x80\x9d the captain cried, \xe2\x80\x9cNor tempt so wild a\r\nstorm;\xe2\x80\x9d But still the raging mules advanced, And still the boy strode\r\non.\r\n\r\nThen said the captain to us all, \xe2\x80\x9cAlas, \xe2\x80\x99tis plain to me, The greater\r\ndanger is not there, But here upon the sea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo let us strive, while life remains, To save all souls on board, And\r\nthen if die at last we must, Let .  .  .  .  I cannot speak the word!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaid Dollinger the pilot man, Tow\xe2\x80\x99ring above the crew, \xe2\x80\x9cFear not, but\r\ntrust in Dollinger, And he will fetch you through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n371.jpg (102K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLow bridge!  low bridge!\xe2\x80\x9d all heads went down, The laboring bark sped\r\non; A mill we passed, we passed church, Hamlets, and fields of corn; And\r\nall the world came out to see, And chased along the shore Crying, \xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\r\nalas, the sheeted rain, The wind, the tempest\xe2\x80\x99s roar! Alas, the gallant\r\nship and crew, Can nothing help them more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd from our deck sad eyes looked out Across the stormy scene: The\r\ntossing wake of billows aft, The bending forests green, The chickens\r\nsheltered under carts In lee of barn the cows, The skurrying swine with\r\nstraw in mouth, The wild spray from our bows!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe balances! She wavers! Now let her go about! If she misses stays and\r\nbroaches to, We\xe2\x80\x99re all\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94then with a shout, \xe2\x80\x9cHuray!  huray! Avast!\r\nbelay! Take in more sail! Lord, what a gale! Ho, boy, haul taut on the\r\nhind mule\xe2\x80\x99s tail!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n372.jpg (105K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo!  lighten ship!  ho!  man the pump! Ho, hostler, heave the lead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA quarter-three!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis shoaling fast! Three feet large!\xe2\x80\x94t-h-r-e-e\r\nfeet!\xe2\x80\x94Three feet scant!\xe2\x80\x9d I cried in fright \xe2\x80\x9cOh, is there no retreat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaid Dollinger, the pilot man, As on the vessel flew, \xe2\x80\x9cFear not, but\r\ntrust in Dollinger, And he will fetch you through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA panic struck the bravest hearts, The boldest cheek turned pale; For\r\nplain to all, this shoaling said A leak had burst the ditch\xe2\x80\x99s bed! And,\r\nstraight as bolt from crossbow sped, Our ship swept on, with shoaling\r\nlead, Before the fearful gale!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSever the tow-line!  Cripple the mules!\xe2\x80\x9d Too late!  There comes a\r\nshock! Another length, and the fated craft Would have swum in the saving\r\nlock!\r\n\r\nThen gathered together the shipwrecked crew And took one last embrace,\r\nWhile sorrowful tears from despairing eyes Ran down each hopeless face;\r\nAnd some did think of their little ones Whom they never more might see,\r\nAnd others of waiting wives at home, And mothers that grieved would be.\r\n\r\nBut of all the children of misery there On that poor sinking frame, But\r\none spake words of hope and faith, And I worshipped as they came: Said\r\nDollinger the pilot man,\xe2\x80\x94(O brave heart, strong and true!)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFear not,\r\nbut trust in Dollinger, For he will fetch you through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLo!  scarce the words have passed his lips The dauntless prophet say\xe2\x80\x99th,\r\nWhen every soul about him seeth A wonder crown his faith!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd count ye all, both great and small, As numbered with the dead: For\r\nmariner for forty year, On Erie, boy and man, I never yet saw such a\r\nstorm, Or one\xe2\x80\x99t with it began!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo overboard a keg of nails And anvils three we threw, Likewise four\r\nbales of gunny-sacks, Two hundred pounds of glue, Two sacks of corn,\r\nfour ditto wheat, A box of books, a cow, A violin, Lord Byron\xe2\x80\x99s works, A\r\nrip-saw and a sow.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n374.jpg (67K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA curve!  a curve!  the dangers grow! \xe2\x80\x9cLabbord!\xe2\x80\x94stabbord!\xe2\x80\x94s-t-e-a-d-\r\ny!\xe2\x80\x94so!\xe2\x80\x94Hard-a-port, Dol!\xe2\x80\x94hellum-a-lee! Haw the head mule!\xe2\x80\x94the aft\r\none gee! Luff!\xe2\x80\x94bring her to the wind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor straight a farmer brought a plank,\xe2\x80\x94(Mysteriously inspired)\xe2\x80\x94And\r\nlaying it unto the ship, In silent awe retired.\r\n\r\nThen every sufferer stood amazed That pilot man before; A moment stood.\r\nThen wondering turned, And speechless walked ashore.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n375.jpg (82K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LII.\r\n\r\n\r\nSince I desire, in this chapter, to say an instructive word or two about\r\nthe silver mines, the reader may take this fair warning and skip, if he\r\nchooses. The year 1863 was perhaps the very top blossom and culmination\r\nof the \xe2\x80\x9cflush times.\xe2\x80\x9d Virginia swarmed with men and vehicles to that\r\ndegree that the place looked like a very hive\xe2\x80\x94that is when one\xe2\x80\x99s vision\r\ncould pierce through the thick fog of alkali dust that was generally\r\nblowing in summer. I will say, concerning this dust, that if you drove\r\nten miles through it, you and your horses would be coated with it a\r\nsixteenth of an inch thick and present an outside appearance that was a\r\nuniform pale yellow color, and your buggy would have three inches of\r\ndust in it, thrown there by the wheels. The delicate scales used by the\r\nassayers were inclosed in glass cases intended to be air-tight, and yet\r\nsome of this dust was so impalpable and so invisibly fine that it would\r\nget in, somehow, and impair the accuracy of those scales.\r\n\r\nSpeculation ran riot, and yet there was a world of substantial business\r\ngoing on, too. All freights were brought over the mountains from\r\nCalifornia (150 miles) by pack-train partly, and partly in huge wagons\r\ndrawn by such long mule teams that each team amounted to a procession,\r\nand it did seem, sometimes, that the grand combined procession of\r\nanimals stretched unbroken from Virginia to California. Its long route\r\nwas traceable clear across the deserts of the Territory by the writhing\r\nserpent of dust it lifted up. By these wagons, freights over that\r\nhundred and fifty miles were $200 a ton for small lots (same price for\r\nall express matter brought by stage), and $100 a ton for full loads. One\r\nVirginia firm received one hundred tons of freight a month, and paid\r\n$10,000 a month freightage. In the winter the freights were much higher.\r\nAll the bullion was shipped in bars by stage to San Francisco (a bar was\r\nusually about twice the size of a pig of lead and contained from $1,500\r\nto $3,000 according to the amount of gold mixed with the silver), and\r\nthe freight on it (when the shipment was large) was one and a quarter\r\nper cent. of its intrinsic value.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n377.jpg (16K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSo, the freight on these bars probably averaged something more than $25\r\neach. Small shippers paid two per cent. There were three stages a day,\r\neach way, and I have seen the out-going stages carry away a third of a\r\nton of bullion each, and more than once I saw them divide a two-ton lot\r\nand take it off. However, these were extraordinary events. [Mr.\r\nValentine, Wells Fargo\xe2\x80\x99s agent, has handled all the bullion shipped\r\nthrough the Virginia office for many a month. To his memory\xe2\x80\x94which is\r\nexcellent\xe2\x80\x94we are indebted for the following exhibit of the company\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbusiness in the Virginia office since the first of January, 1862: From\r\nJanuary 1st to April 1st, about $270,000 worth of bullion passed through\r\nthat office, during the next quarter, $570,000; next quarter, $800,000;\r\nnext quarter, $956,000; next quarter, $1,275,000; and for the quarter\r\nending on the 30th of last June, about $1,600,000. Thus in a year and a\r\nhalf, the Virginia office only shipped $5,330,000 in bullion. During the\r\nyear 1862 they shipped $2,615,000, so we perceive the average shipments\r\nhave more than doubled in the last six months. This gives us room to\r\npromise for the Virginia office $500,000 a month for the year 1863\r\n(though perhaps, judging by the steady increase in the business, we are\r\nunder estimating, somewhat). This gives us $6,000,000 for the year. Gold\r\nHill and Silver City together can beat us\xe2\x80\x94we will give them $10,000,000.\r\nTo Dayton, Empire City, Ophir and Carson City, we will allow an\r\naggregate of $8,000,000, which is not over the mark, perhaps, and may\r\npossibly be a little under it. To Esmeralda we give $4,000,000. To Reese\r\nRiver and Humboldt $2,000,000, which is liberal now, but may not be\r\nbefore the year is out. So we prognosticate that the yield of bullion\r\nthis year will be about $30,000,000. Placing the number of mills in the\r\nTerritory at one hundred, this gives to each the labor of producing\r\n$300,000 in bullion during the twelve months. Allowing them to run three\r\nhundred days in the year (which none of them more than do), this makes\r\ntheir work average $1,000 a day. Say the mills average twenty tons of\r\nrock a day and this rock worth $50 as a general thing, and you have the\r\nactual work of our one hundred mills figured down \xe2\x80\x9cto a spot\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94$1,000 a\r\nday each, and $30,000,000 a year in the aggregate.\xe2\x80\x94_Enterprise_. [A\r\nconsiderable over estimate\xe2\x80\x94M. T.]]\r\n\r\nTwo tons of silver bullion would be in the neighborhood of forty bars,\r\nand the freight on it over $1,000. Each coach always carried a deal of\r\nordinary express matter beside, and also from fifteen to twenty\r\npassengers at from $25 to $30 a head. With six stages going all the\r\ntime, Wells, Fargo and Co.\xe2\x80\x99s Virginia City business was important and\r\nlucrative.\r\n\r\nAll along under the centre of Virginia and Gold Hill, for a couple of\r\nmiles, ran the great Comstock silver lode\xe2\x80\x94a vein of ore from fifty to\r\n_eighty_ feet thick between its solid walls of rock\xe2\x80\x94a vein as wide as\r\nsome of New York\xe2\x80\x99s streets. I will remind the reader that in\r\nPennsylvania a coal vein only eight feet wide is considered ample.\r\n\r\nVirginia was a busy city of streets and houses above ground. Under it\r\nwas another busy city, down in the bowels of the earth, where a great\r\npopulation of men thronged in and out among an intricate maze of tunnels\r\nand drifts, flitting hither and thither under a winking sparkle of\r\nlights, and over their heads towered a vast web of interlocking timbers\r\nthat held the walls of the gutted Comstock apart. These timbers were as\r\nlarge as a man\xe2\x80\x99s body, and the framework stretched upward so far that no\r\neye could pierce to its top through the closing gloom. It was like\r\npeering up through the clean-picked ribs and bones of some colossal\r\nskeleton. Imagine such a framework two miles long, sixty feet wide, and\r\nhigher than any church spire in America. Imagine this stately lattice-\r\nwork stretching down Broadway, from the St. Nicholas to Wall street, and\r\na Fourth of July procession, reduced to pigmies, parading on top of it\r\nand flaunting their flags, high above the pinnacle of Trinity steeple.\r\nOne can imagine that, but he cannot well imagine what that forest of\r\ntimbers cost, from the time they were felled in the pineries beyond\r\nWashoe Lake, hauled up and around Mount Davidson at atrocious rates of\r\nfreightage, then squared, let down into the deep maw of the mine and\r\nbuilt up there. Twenty ample fortunes would not timber one of the\r\ngreatest of those silver mines. The Spanish proverb says it requires a\r\ngold mine to \xe2\x80\x9crun\xe2\x80\x9d a silver one, and it is true. A beggar with a silver\r\nmine is a pitiable pauper indeed if he cannot sell.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n379.jpg (47K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI spoke of the underground Virginia as a city. The Gould and Curry is\r\nonly one single mine under there, among a great many others; yet the\r\nGould and Curry\xe2\x80\x99s streets of dismal drifts and tunnels were five miles\r\nin extent, altogether, and its population five hundred miners. Taken as\r\na whole, the underground city had some thirty miles of streets and a\r\npopulation of five or six thousand. In this present day some of those\r\npopulations are at work from twelve to sixteen hundred feet under\r\nVirginia and Gold Hill, and the signal-bells that tell them what the\r\nsuperintendent above ground desires them to do are struck by telegraph\r\nas we strike a fire alarm. Sometimes men fall down a shaft, there, a\r\nthousand feet deep. In such cases, the usual plan is to hold an inquest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n380.jpg (161K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIf you wish to visit one of those mines, you may walk through a tunnel\r\nabout half a mile long if you prefer it, or you may take the quicker\r\nplan of shooting like a dart down a shaft, on a small platform. It is\r\nlike tumbling down through an empty steeple, feet first. When you reach\r\nthe bottom, you take a candle and tramp through drifts and tunnels where\r\nthrongs of men are digging and blasting; you watch them send up tubs\r\nfull of great lumps of stone\xe2\x80\x94silver ore; you select choice specimens\r\nfrom the mass, as souvenirs; you admire the world of skeleton timbering;\r\nyou reflect frequently that you are buried under a mountain, a thousand\r\nfeet below daylight; being in the bottom of the mine you climb from\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgallery\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cgallery,\xe2\x80\x9d up endless ladders that stand straight up and\r\ndown; when your legs fail you at last, you lie down in a small box-car\r\nin a cramped \xe2\x80\x9cincline\xe2\x80\x9d like a half-up-ended sewer and are dragged up to\r\ndaylight feeling as if you are crawling through a coffin that has no end\r\nto it. Arrived at the top, you find a busy crowd of men receiving the\r\nascending cars and tubs and dumping the ore from an elevation into long\r\nrows of bins capable of holding half a dozen tons each; under the bins\r\nare rows of wagons loading from chutes and trap-doors in the bins, and\r\ndown the long street is a procession of these wagons wending toward the\r\nsilver mills with their rich freight. It is all \xe2\x80\x9cdone,\xe2\x80\x9d now, and there\r\nyou are. You need never go down again, for you have seen it all. If you\r\nhave forgotten the process of reducing the ore in the mill and making\r\nthe silver bars, you can go back and find it again in my Esmeralda\r\nchapters if so disposed.\r\n\r\nOf course these mines cave in, in places, occasionally, and then it is\r\nworth one\xe2\x80\x99s while to take the risk of descending into them and observing\r\nthe crushing power exerted by the pressing weight of a settling\r\nmountain. I published such an experience in the Enterprise, once, and\r\nfrom it I will take an extract:\r\n\r\nAN HOUR IN THE CAVED MINES.\xe2\x80\x94We journeyed down into the Ophir mine,\r\nyesterday, to see the earthquake. We could not go down the deep incline,\r\nbecause it still has a propensity to cave in places. Therefore we\r\ntraveled through the long tunnel which enters the hill above the Ophir\r\noffice, and then by means of a series of long ladders, climbed away down\r\nfrom the first to the fourth gallery. Traversing a drift, we came to the\r\nSpanish line, passed five sets of timbers still uninjured, and found the\r\nearthquake. Here was as complete a chaos as ever was seen\xe2\x80\x94vast masses of\r\nearth and splintered and broken timbers piled confusedly together, with\r\nscarcely an aperture left large enough for a cat to creep through.\r\nRubbish was still falling at intervals from above, and one timber which\r\nhad braced others earlier in the day, was now crushed down out of its\r\nformer position, showing that the caving and settling of the tremendous\r\nmass was still going on. We were in that portion of the Ophir known as\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cnorth mines.\xe2\x80\x9d Returning to the surface, we entered a tunnel leading\r\ninto the Central, for the purpose of getting into the main Ophir.\r\nDescending a long incline in this tunnel, we traversed a drift or so,\r\nand then went down a deep shaft from whence we proceeded into the fifth\r\ngallery of the Ophir. From a side-drift we crawled through a small hole\r\nand got into the midst of the earthquake again\xe2\x80\x94earth and broken timbers\r\nmingled together without regard to grace or symmetry. A large portion of\r\nthe second, third and fourth galleries had caved in and gone to\r\ndestruction\xe2\x80\x94the two latter at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock on the previous evening.\r\n\r\nAt the turn-table, near the northern extremity of the fifth gallery, two\r\nbig piles of rubbish had forced their way through from the fifth\r\ngallery, and from the looks of the timbers, more was about to come.\r\nThese beams are solid\xe2\x80\x94eighteen inches square; first, a great beam is\r\nlaid on the floor, then upright ones, five feet high, stand on it,\r\nsupporting another horizontal beam, and so on, square above square, like\r\nthe framework of a window. The superincumbent weight was sufficient to\r\nmash the ends of those great upright beams fairly into the solid wood of\r\nthe horizontal ones three inches, compressing and bending the upright\r\nbeam till it curved like a bow. Before the Spanish caved in, some of\r\ntheir twelve-inch horizontal timbers were compressed in this way until\r\nthey were only five inches thick! Imagine the power it must take to\r\nsqueeze a solid log together in that way. Here, also, was a range of\r\ntimbers, for a distance of twenty feet, tilted six inches out of the\r\nperpendicular by the weight resting upon them from the caved galleries\r\nabove. You could hear things cracking and giving way, and it was not\r\npleasant to know that the world overhead was slowly and silently sinking\r\ndown upon you. The men down in the mine do not mind it, however.\r\n\r\nReturning along the fifth gallery, we struck the safe part of the Ophir\r\nincline, and went down it to the sixth; but we found ten inches of water\r\nthere, and had to come back. In repairing the damage done to the\r\nincline, the pump had to be stopped for two hours, and in the meantime\r\nthe water gained about a foot. However, the pump was at work again, and\r\nthe flood-water was decreasing. We climbed up to the fifth gallery again\r\nand sought a deep shaft, whereby we might descend to another part of the\r\nsixth, out of reach of the water, but suffered disappointment, as the\r\nmen had gone to dinner, and there was no one to man the windlass. So,\r\nhaving seen the earthquake, we climbed out at the _Union_ incline and\r\ntunnel, and adjourned, all dripping with candle grease and perspiration,\r\nto lunch at the Ophir office.\r\n\r\nDuring the great flush year of 1863, Nevada [claims to have] produced\r\n$25,000,000 in bullion\xe2\x80\x94almost, if not quite, a round million to each\r\nthousand inhabitants, which is very well, considering that she was\r\nwithout agriculture and manufactures. Silver mining was her sole\r\nproductive industry.\r\n\r\n[Since the above was in type, I learn from an official source that the\r\nabove figure is too high, and that the yield for 1863 did not exceed\r\n$20,000,000.] However, the day for large figures is approaching; the\r\nSutro Tunnel is to plow through the Comstock lode from end to end, at a\r\ndepth of two thousand feet, and then mining will be easy and\r\ncomparatively inexpensive; and the momentous matters of drainage, and\r\nhoisting and hauling of ore will cease to be burdensome. This vast work\r\nwill absorb many years, and millions of dollars, in its completion; but\r\nit will early yield money, for that desirable epoch will begin as soon\r\nas it strikes the first end of the vein. The tunnel will be some eight\r\nmiles long, and will develop astonishing riches. Cars will carry the ore\r\nthrough the tunnel and dump it in the mills and thus do away with the\r\npresent costly system of double handling and transportation by mule\r\nteams. The water from the tunnel will furnish the motive power for the\r\nmills. Mr. Sutro, the originator of this prodigious enterprise, is one\r\nof the few men in the world who is gifted with the pluck and\r\nperseverance necessary to follow up and hound such an undertaking to its\r\ncompletion. He has converted several obstinate Congresses to a deserved\r\nfriendliness toward his important work, and has gone up and down and to\r\nand fro in Europe until he has enlisted a great moneyed interest in it\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nEvery now and then, in these days, the boys used to tell me I ought to\r\nget one Jim Blaine to tell me the stirring story of his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nold ram\xe2\x80\x94but they always added that I must not mention the matter unless\r\nJim was drunk at the time\xe2\x80\x94just comfortably and sociably drunk. They kept\r\nthis up until my curiosity was on the rack to hear the story. I got to\r\nhaunting Blaine; but it was of no use, the boys always found fault with\r\nhis condition; he was often moderately but never satisfactorily drunk. I\r\nnever watched a man\xe2\x80\x99s condition with such absorbing interest, such\r\nanxious solicitude; I never so pined to see a man uncompromisingly drunk\r\nbefore. At last, one evening I hurried to his cabin, for I learned that\r\nthis time his situation was such that even the most fastidious could\r\nfind no fault with it\xe2\x80\x94he was tranquilly, serenely, symmetrically\r\ndrunk\xe2\x80\x94not a hiccup to mar his voice, not a cloud upon his brain thick\r\nenough to obscure his memory. As I entered, he was sitting upon an empty\r\npowder-keg, with a clay pipe in one hand and the other raised to command\r\nsilence. His face was round, red, and very serious; his throat was bare\r\nand his hair tumbled; in general appearance and costume he was a\r\nstalwart miner of the period. On the pine table stood a candle, and its\r\ndim light revealed \xe2\x80\x9cthe boys\xe2\x80\x9d sitting here and there on bunks, candle-\r\nboxes, powder-kegs, etc. They said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSh\xe2\x80\x94! Don\xe2\x80\x99t speak\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s going to commence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n384.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE STORY OF THE OLD RAM.\r\n\r\nI found a seat at once, and Blaine said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t reckon them times will ever come again. There never was a more\r\nbullier old ram than what he was. Grandfather fetched him from\r\nIllinois\xe2\x80\x94got him of a man by the name of Yates\xe2\x80\x94Bill Yates\xe2\x80\x94maybe you\r\nmight have heard of him; his father was a deacon\xe2\x80\x94Baptist\xe2\x80\x94and he was a\r\nrustler, too; a man had to get up ruther early to get the start of old\r\nThankful Yates; it was him that put the Greens up to jining teams with\r\nmy grandfather when he moved west.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Seth Green was prob\xe2\x80\x99ly the pick of the flock; he married a\r\nWilkerson\xe2\x80\x94Sarah Wilkerson\xe2\x80\x94good cretur, she was\xe2\x80\x94one of the likeliest\r\nheifers that was ever raised in old Stoddard, everybody said that knowed\r\nher. She could heft a bar\xe2\x80\x99l of flour as easy as I can flirt a flapjack.\r\nAnd spin? Don\xe2\x80\x99t mention it! Independent? Humph! When Sile Hawkins come a\r\nbrowsing around her, she let him know that for all his tin he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntrot in harness alongside of _her_. You see, Sile Hawkins was\xe2\x80\x94no, it\r\nwarn\xe2\x80\x99t Sile Hawkins, after all\xe2\x80\x94it was a galoot by the name of Filkins\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ndisremember his first name; but he _was_ a stump\xe2\x80\x94come into pra\xe2\x80\x99r meeting\r\ndrunk, one night, hooraying for Nixon, becuz he thought it was a\r\nprimary; and old deacon Ferguson up and scooted him through the window\r\nand he lit on old Miss Jefferson\xe2\x80\x99s head, poor old filly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n385.jpg (52K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nShe was a good soul\xe2\x80\x94had a glass eye and used to lend it to old Miss\r\nWagner, that hadn\xe2\x80\x99t any, to receive company in; it warn\xe2\x80\x99t big enough,\r\nand when Miss Wagner warn\xe2\x80\x99t noticing, it would get twisted around in the\r\nsocket, and look up, maybe, or out to one side, and every which way,\r\nwhile t\xe2\x80\x99 other one was looking as straight ahead as a spy-glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrown people didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind it, but it most always made the children cry,\r\nit was so sort of scary.
