She tried packing it in raw cotton, but it\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t work, somehow\xe2\x80\x94the cotton would get loose and stick out and look\r\nso kind of awful that the children couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stand it no way.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n386.jpg (26K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nShe was always dropping it out, and turning up her old dead-light on the\r\ncompany empty, and making them oncomfortable, becuz _she_ never could\r\ntell when it hopped out, being blind on that side, you see. So somebody\r\nwould have to hunch her and say, \xe2\x80\x9cYour game eye has fetched loose. Miss\r\nWagner dear\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and then all of them would have to sit and wait till she\r\njammed it in again\xe2\x80\x94wrong side before, as a general thing, and green as a\r\nbird\xe2\x80\x99s egg, being a bashful cretur and easy sot back before company. But\r\nbeing wrong side before warn\xe2\x80\x99t much difference, anyway; becuz her own\r\neye was sky-blue and the glass one was yaller on the front side, so\r\nwhichever way she turned it it didn\xe2\x80\x99t match nohow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old Miss Wagner was considerable on the borrow, she was. When she had a\r\nquilting, or Dorcas S\xe2\x80\x99iety at her house she gen\xe2\x80\x99ally borrowed Miss\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99s wooden leg to stump around on; it was considerable shorter\r\nthan her other pin, but much _she_ minded that. She said she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nabide crutches when she had company, becuz they were so slow; said when\r\nshe had company and things had to be done, she wanted to get up and hump\r\nherself. She was as bald as a jug, and so she used to borrow Miss\r\nJacops\xe2\x80\x99s wig\xe2\x80\x94Miss Jacops was the coffin-peddler\xe2\x80\x99s wife\xe2\x80\x94a ratty old\r\nbuzzard, he was, that used to go roosting around where people was sick,\r\nwaiting for \xe2\x80\x99em; and there that old rip would sit all day, in the shade,\r\non a coffin that he judged would fit the can\xe2\x80\x99idate; and if it was a slow\r\ncustomer and kind of uncertain, he\xe2\x80\x99d fetch his rations and a blanket\r\nalong and sleep in the coffin nights. He was anchored out that way, in\r\nfrosty weather, for about three weeks, once, before old Robbins\xe2\x80\x99s place,\r\nwaiting for him; and after that, for as much as two years, Jacops was\r\nnot on speaking terms with the old man, on account of his disapp\xe2\x80\x99inting\r\nhim. He got one of his feet froze, and lost money, too, becuz old\r\nRobbins took a favorable turn and got well.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n387.jpg (61K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next time Robbins got sick, Jacops tried to make up with him, and\r\nvarnished up the same old coffin and fetched it along; but old Robbins\r\nwas too many for him; he had him in, and \xe2\x80\x99peared to be powerful weak; he\r\nbought the coffin for ten dollars and Jacops was to pay it back and\r\ntwenty-five more besides if Robbins didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the coffin after he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ntried it. And then Robbins died, and at the funeral he bursted off the\r\nlid and riz up in his shroud and told the parson to let up on the\r\nperformances, becuz he could _not_ stand such a coffin as that. You see\r\nhe had been in a trance once before, when he was young, and he took the\r\nchances on another, cal\xe2\x80\x99lating that if he made the trip it was money in\r\nhis pocket, and if he missed fire he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t lose a cent. And by George\r\nhe sued Jacops for the rhino and got jedgment; and he set up the coffin\r\nin his back parlor and said he \xe2\x80\x99lowed to take his time, now. It was\r\nalways an aggravation to Jacops, the way that miserable old thing acted.\r\nHe moved back to Indiany pretty soon\xe2\x80\x94went to Wellsville\xe2\x80\x94Wellsville was\r\nthe place the Hogadorns was from. Mighty fine family. Old Maryland\r\nstock. Old Squire Hogadorn could carry around more mixed licker, and\r\ncuss better than most any man I ever see. His second wife was the widder\r\nBillings\xe2\x80\x94she that was Becky Martin; her dam was deacon Dunlap\xe2\x80\x99s first\r\nwife. Her oldest child, Maria, married a missionary and died in grace\xe2\x80\x94et\r\nup by the savages. They et _him_, too, poor feller\xe2\x80\x94biled him. It warn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthe custom, so they say, but they explained to friends of his\xe2\x80\x99n that\r\nwent down there to bring away his things, that they\xe2\x80\x99d tried missionaries\r\nevery other way and never could get any good out of \xe2\x80\x99em\xe2\x80\x94and so it\r\nannoyed all his relations to find out that that man\xe2\x80\x99s life was fooled\r\naway just out of a dern\xe2\x80\x99d experiment, so to speak. But mind you, there\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t anything ever reely lost; everything that people can\xe2\x80\x99t understand\r\nand don\xe2\x80\x99t see the reason of does good if you only hold on and give it a\r\nfair shake; Prov\xe2\x80\x99dence don\xe2\x80\x99t fire no blank ca\xe2\x80\x99tridges, boys. That there\r\nmissionary\xe2\x80\x99s substance, unbeknowns to himself, actu\xe2\x80\x99ly converted every\r\nlast one of them heathens that took a chance at the barbacue. Nothing\r\never fetched them but that. Don\xe2\x80\x99t tell _me_ it was an accident that he\r\nwas biled. There ain\xe2\x80\x99t no such a thing as an accident.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n388.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When my uncle Lem was leaning up agin a scaffolding once, sick, or\r\ndrunk, or suthin, an Irishman with a hod full of bricks fell on him out\r\nof the third story and broke the old man\xe2\x80\x99s back in two places. People\r\nsaid it was an accident. Much accident there was about that. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow what he was there for, but he was there for a good object. If he\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t been there the Irishman would have been killed. Nobody can ever\r\nmake me believe anything different from that. Uncle Lem\xe2\x80\x99s dog was there.\r\nWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t the Irishman fall on the dog? Becuz the dog would a seen him\r\na coming and stood from under. That\xe2\x80\x99s the reason the dog warn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nappinted. A dog can\xe2\x80\x99t be depended on to carry out a special providence.\r\nMark my words it was a put-up thing. Accidents don\xe2\x80\x99t happen, boys. Uncle\r\nLem\xe2\x80\x99s dog\xe2\x80\x94I wish you could a seen that dog. He was a reglar shepherd\xe2\x80\x94or\r\nruther he was part bull and part shepherd\xe2\x80\x94splendid animal; belonged to\r\nparson Hagar before Uncle Lem got him. Parson Hagar belonged to the\r\nWestern Reserve Hagars; prime family; his mother was a Watson; one of\r\nhis sisters married a Wheeler; they settled in Morgan county, and he got\r\nnipped by the machinery in a carpet factory and went through in less\r\nthan a quarter of a minute; his widder bought the piece of carpet that\r\nhad his remains wove in, and people come a hundred mile to \xe2\x80\x99tend the\r\nfuneral. There was fourteen yards in the piece.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let them roll him up, but planted him just so\xe2\x80\x94full length.\r\nThe church was middling small where they preached the funeral, and they\r\nhad to let one end of the coffin stick out of the window. They didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbury him\xe2\x80\x94they planted one end, and let him stand up, same as a monument.\r\nAnd they nailed a sign on it and put\xe2\x80\x94put on\xe2\x80\x94put on it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csacred to\xe2\x80\x94the m-\r\ne-m-o-r-y\xe2\x80\x94of fourteen y-a-r-d-s\xe2\x80\x94of three-ply\xe2\x80\x94car\xe2\x80\x94-pet\xe2\x80\x94containing all\r\nthat was\xe2\x80\x94m-o-r-t-a-l\xe2\x80\x94of\xe2\x80\x94of\xe2\x80\x94W-i-l-l-i-a-m\xe2\x80\x94W-h-e\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n389.jpg (111K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nJim Blaine had been growing gradually drowsy and drowsier\xe2\x80\x94his head\r\nnodded, once, twice, three times\xe2\x80\x94dropped peacefully upon his breast, and\r\nhe fell tranquilly asleep. The tears were running down the boys\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncheeks\xe2\x80\x94they were suffocating with suppressed laughter\xe2\x80\x94and had been from\r\nthe start, though I had never noticed it. I perceived that I was \xe2\x80\x9csold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nI learned then that Jim Blaine\xe2\x80\x99s peculiarity was that whenever he\r\nreached a certain stage of intoxication, no human power could keep him\r\nfrom setting out, with impressive unction, to tell about a wonderful\r\nadventure which he had once had with his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s old ram\xe2\x80\x94and the\r\nmention of the ram in the first sentence was as far as any man had ever\r\nheard him get, concerning it. He always maundered off, interminably,\r\nfrom one thing to another, till his whisky got the best of him and he\r\nfell asleep. What the thing was that happened to him and his\r\ngrandfather\xe2\x80\x99s old ram is a dark mystery to this day, for nobody has ever\r\nyet found out.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n390.jpg (64K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nOf course there was a large Chinese population in Virginia\xe2\x80\x94it is the\r\ncase with every town and city on the Pacific coast. They are a harmless\r\nrace when white men either let them alone or treat them no worse than\r\ndogs; in fact they are almost entirely harmless anyhow, for they seldom\r\nthink of resenting the vilest insults or the cruelest injuries. They are\r\nquiet, peaceable, tractable, free from drunkenness, and they are as\r\nindustrious as the day is long. A disorderly Chinaman is rare, and a\r\nlazy one does not exist. So long as a Chinaman has strength to use his\r\nhands he needs no support from anybody; white men often complain of want\r\nof work, but a Chinaman offers no such complaint; he always manages to\r\nfind something to do. He is a great convenience to everybody\xe2\x80\x94even to the\r\nworst class of white men, for he bears the most of their sins, suffering\r\nfines for their petty thefts, imprisonment for their robberies, and\r\ndeath for their murders. Any white man can swear a Chinaman\xe2\x80\x99s life away\r\nin the courts, but no Chinaman can testify against a white man. Ours is\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cland of the free\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94nobody denies that\xe2\x80\x94nobody challenges it. [Maybe\r\nit is because we won\xe2\x80\x99t let other people testify.] As I write, news comes\r\nthat in broad daylight in San Francisco, some boys have stoned an\r\ninoffensive Chinaman to death, and that although a large crowd witnessed\r\nthe shameful deed, no one interfered.\r\n\r\nThere are seventy thousand (and possibly one hundred thousand) Chinamen\r\non the Pacific coast. There were about a thousand in Virginia. They were\r\npenned into a \xe2\x80\x9cChinese quarter\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a thing which they do not particularly\r\nobject to, as they are fond of herding together. Their buildings were of\r\nwood; usually only one story high, and set thickly together along\r\nstreets scarcely wide enough for a wagon to pass through. Their quarter\r\nwas a little removed from the rest of the town. The chief employment of\r\nChinamen in towns is to wash clothing. They always send a bill, like\r\nthis below, pinned to the clothes. It is mere ceremony, for it does not\r\nenlighten the customer much.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n392.jpg (12K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTheir price for washing was $2.50 per dozen\xe2\x80\x94rather cheaper than white\r\npeople could afford to wash for at that time. A very common sign on the\r\nChinese houses was: \xe2\x80\x9cSee Yup, Washer and Ironer\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cHong Wo, Washer\xe2\x80\x9d;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSam Sing & Ah Hop, Washing.\xe2\x80\x9d The house servants, cooks, etc., in\r\nCalifornia and Nevada, were chiefly Chinamen. There were few white\r\nservants and no Chinawomen so employed. Chinamen make good house\r\nservants, being quick, obedient, patient, quick to learn and tirelessly\r\nindustrious. They do not need to be taught a thing twice, as a general\r\nthing. They are imitative. If a Chinaman were to see his master break up\r\na centre table, in a passion, and kindle a fire with it, that Chinaman\r\nwould be likely to resort to the furniture for fuel forever afterward.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n393.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAll Chinamen can read, write and cipher with easy facility\xe2\x80\x94pity but all\r\nour petted _voters_ could. In California they rent little patches of\r\nground and do a deal of gardening. They will raise surprising crops of\r\nvegetables on a sand pile. They waste nothing. What is rubbish to a\r\nChristian, a Chinaman carefully preserves and makes useful in one way or\r\nanother. He gathers up all the old oyster and sardine cans that white\r\npeople throw away, and procures marketable tin and solder from them by\r\nmelting. He gathers up old bones and turns them into manure. In\r\nCalifornia he gets a living out of old mining claims that white men have\r\nabandoned as exhausted and worthless\xe2\x80\x94and then the officers come down on\r\nhim once a month with an exorbitant swindle to which the legislature has\r\ngiven the broad, general name of \xe2\x80\x9cforeign\xe2\x80\x9d mining tax, but it is usually\r\ninflicted on no foreigners but Chinamen. This swindle has in some cases\r\nbeen repeated once or twice on the same victim in the course of the same\r\nmonth\xe2\x80\x94but the public treasury was not additionally enriched by it,\r\nprobably.\r\n\r\nChinamen hold their dead in great reverence\xe2\x80\x94they worship their departed\r\nancestors, in fact. Hence, in China, a man\xe2\x80\x99s front yard, back yard, or\r\nany other part of his premises, is made his family burying ground, in\r\norder that he may visit the graves at any and all times. Therefore that\r\nhuge empire is one mighty cemetery; it is ridged and wringled from its\r\ncentre to its circumference with graves\xe2\x80\x94and inasmuch as every foot of\r\nground must be made to do its utmost, in China, lest the swarming\r\npopulation suffer for food, the very graves are cultivated and yield a\r\nharvest, custom holding this to be no dishonor to the dead. Since the\r\ndeparted are held in such worshipful reverence, a Chinaman cannot bear\r\nthat any indignity be offered the places where they sleep. Mr.\r\nBurlingame said that herein lay China\xe2\x80\x99s bitter opposition to railroads;\r\na road could not be built anywhere in the empire without disturbing the\r\ngraves of their ancestors or friends.\r\n\r\nA Chinaman hardly believes he could enjoy the hereafter except his body\r\nlay in his beloved China; also, he desires to receive, himself, after\r\ndeath, that worship with which he has honored his dead that preceded\r\nhim. Therefore, if he visits a foreign country, he makes arrangements to\r\nhave his bones returned to China in case he dies; if he hires to go to a\r\nforeign country on a labor contract, there is always a stipulation that\r\nhis body shall be taken back to China if he dies; if the government\r\nsells a gang of Coolies to a foreigner for the usual five-year term, it\r\nis specified in the contract that their bodies shall be restored to\r\nChina in case of death. On the Pacific coast the Chinamen all belong to\r\none or another of several great companies or organizations, and these\r\ncompanies keep track of their members, register their names, and ship\r\ntheir bodies home when they die. The See Yup Company is held to be the\r\nlargest of these. The Ning Yeong Company is next, and numbers eighteen\r\nthousand members on the coast. Its headquarters are at San Francisco,\r\nwhere it has a costly temple, several great officers (one of whom keeps\r\nregal state in seclusion and cannot be approached by common humanity),\r\nand a numerous priesthood. In it I was shown a register of its members,\r\nwith the dead and the date of their shipment to China duly marked. Every\r\nship that sails from San Francisco carries away a heavy freight of\r\nChinese corpses\xe2\x80\x94or did, at least, until the legislature, with an\r\ningenious refinement of Christian cruelty, forbade the shipments, as a\r\nneat underhanded way of deterring Chinese immigration. The bill was\r\noffered, whether it passed or not. It is my impression that it passed.\r\nThere was another bill\xe2\x80\x94it became a law\xe2\x80\x94compelling every incoming\r\nChinaman to be vaccinated on the wharf and pay a duly appointed quack\r\n(no decent doctor would defile himself with such legalized robbery) ten\r\ndollars for it. As few importers of Chinese would want to go to an\r\nexpense like that, the law-makers thought this would be another heavy\r\nblow to Chinese immigration.\r\n\r\nWhat the Chinese quarter of Virginia was like\xe2\x80\x94or, indeed, what the\r\nChinese quarter of any Pacific coast town was and is like\xe2\x80\x94may be\r\ngathered from this item which I printed in the Enterprise while\r\nreporting for that paper:\r\n\r\nCHINATOWN.\xe2\x80\x94Accompanied by a fellow reporter, we made a trip through our\r\nChinese quarter the other night. The Chinese have built their portion of\r\nthe city to suit themselves; and as they keep neither carriages nor\r\nwagons, their streets are not wide enough, as a general thing, to admit\r\nof the passage of vehicles. At ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night the Chinaman may be\r\nseen in all his glory. In every little cooped-up, dingy cavern of a hut,\r\nfaint with the odor of burning Josh-lights and with nothing to see the\r\ngloom by save the sickly, guttering tallow candle, were two or three\r\nyellow, long-tailed vagabonds, coiled up on a sort of short truckle-bed,\r\nsmoking opium, motionless and with their lustreless eyes turned inward\r\nfrom excess of satisfaction\xe2\x80\x94or rather the recent smoker looks thus,\r\nimmediately after having passed the pipe to his neighbor\xe2\x80\x94for opium-\r\nsmoking is a comfortless operation, and requires constant attention. A\r\nlamp sits on the bed, the length of the long pipe-stem from the smoker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmouth; he puts a pellet of opium on the end of a wire, sets it on fire,\r\nand plasters it into the pipe much as a Christian would fill a hole with\r\nputty; then he applies the bowl to the lamp and proceeds to smoke\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthe stewing and frying of the drug and the gurgling of the juices in the\r\nstem would well-nigh turn the stomach of a statue. John likes it,\r\nthough; it soothes him, he takes about two dozen whiffs, and then rolls\r\nover to dream, Heaven only knows what, for we could not imagine by\r\nlooking at the soggy creature. Possibly in his visions he travels far\r\naway from the gross world and his regular washing, and feast on\r\nsucculent rats and birds\xe2\x80\x99-nests in Paradise.\r\n\r\nMr. Ah Sing keeps a general grocery and provision store at No. 13 Wang\r\nstreet. He lavished his hospitality upon our party in the friendliest\r\nway. He had various kinds of colored and colorless wines and brandies,\r\nwith unpronouncable names, imported from China in little crockery jugs,\r\nand which he offered to us in dainty little miniature wash-basins of\r\nporcelain. He offered us a mess of birds\xe2\x80\x99-nests; also, small, neat\r\nsausages, of which we could have swallowed several yards if we had\r\nchosen to try, but we suspected that each link contained the corpse of a\r\nmouse, and therefore refrained. Mr. Sing had in his store a thousand\r\narticles of merchandise, curious to behold, impossible to imagine the\r\nuses of, and beyond our ability to describe.\r\n\r\nHis ducks, however, and his eggs, we could understand; the former were\r\nsplit open and flattened out like codfish, and came from China in that\r\nshape, and the latter were plastered over with some kind of paste which\r\nkept them fresh and palatable through the long voyage.\r\n\r\nWe found Mr. Hong Wo, No. 37 Chow-chow street, making up a lottery\r\nscheme\xe2\x80\x94in fact we found a dozen others occupied in the same way in\r\nvarious parts of the quarter, for about every third Chinaman runs a\r\nlottery, and the balance of the tribe \xe2\x80\x9cbuck\xe2\x80\x9d at it. \xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d who speaks\r\nfaultless English, and used to be chief and only cook to the\r\n_Territorial Enterprise_, when the establishment kept bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s hall\r\ntwo years ago, said that \xe2\x80\x9cSometime Chinaman buy ticket one dollar hap,\r\nketch um two tree hundred, sometime no ketch um anything; lottery like\r\none man fight um seventy\xe2\x80\x94may-be he whip, may-be he get whip heself,\r\nwelly good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n396.jpg (69K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHowever, the percentage being sixty-nine against him, the chances are,\r\nas a general thing, that \xe2\x80\x9che get whip heself.\xe2\x80\x9d We could not see that\r\nthese lotteries differed in any respect from our own, save that the\r\nfigures being Chinese, no ignorant white man might ever hope to succeed\r\nin telling \xe2\x80\x9ct\xe2\x80\x99other from which;\xe2\x80\x9d the manner of drawing is similar to\r\nours.\r\n\r\nMr. See Yup keeps a fancy store on Live Fox street. He sold us fans of\r\nwhite feathers, gorgeously ornamented; perfumery that smelled like\r\nLimburger cheese, Chinese pens, and watch-charms made of a stone\r\nunscratchable with steel instruments, yet polished and tinted like the\r\ninner coat of a sea-shell. As tokens of his esteem, See Yup presented\r\nthe party with gaudy plumes made of gold tinsel and trimmed with\r\npeacocks\xe2\x80\x99 feathers.\r\n\r\nWe ate chow-chow with chop-sticks in the celestial restaurants; our\r\ncomrade chided the moon-eyed damsels in front of the houses for their\r\nwant of feminine reserve; we received protecting Josh-lights from our\r\nhosts and \xe2\x80\x9cdickered\xe2\x80\x9d for a pagan God or two. Finally, we were impressed\r\nwith the genius of a Chinese book-keeper; he figured up his accounts on\r\na machine like a gridiron with buttons strung on its bars; the different\r\nrows represented units, tens, hundreds and thousands. He fingered them\r\nwith incredible rapidity\xe2\x80\x94in fact, he pushed them from place to place as\r\nfast as a musical professor\xe2\x80\x99s fingers travel over the keys of a piano.\r\n\r\nThey are a kindly disposed, well-meaning race, and are respected and\r\nwell treated by the upper classes, all over the Pacific coast. No\r\nCalifornian _gentleman or lady_ ever abuses or oppresses a Chinaman,\r\nunder any circumstances, an explanation that seems to be much needed in\r\nthe East. Only the scum of the population do it\xe2\x80\x94they and their children;\r\nthey, and, naturally and consistently, the policemen and politicians,\r\nlikewise, for these are the dust-licking pimps and slaves of the scum,\r\nthere as well as elsewhere in America.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n397.jpg (76K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LV.\r\n\r\n\r\nI began to get tired of staying in one place so long.\r\n\r\nThere was no longer satisfying variety in going down to Carson to report\r\nthe proceedings of the legislature once a year, and horse-races and\r\npumpkin-shows once in three months; (they had got to raising pumpkins\r\nand potatoes in Washoe Valley, and of course one of the first\r\nachievements of the legislature was to institute a ten-thousand-dollar\r\nAgricultural Fair to show off forty dollars\xe2\x80\x99 worth of those pumpkins\r\nin\xe2\x80\x94however, the territorial legislature was usually spoken of as the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9casylum\xe2\x80\x9d). I wanted to see San Francisco. I wanted to go somewhere. I\r\nwanted\xe2\x80\x94I did not know _what_ I wanted. I had the \xe2\x80\x9cspring fever\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nwanted a change, principally, no doubt. Besides, a convention had framed\r\na State Constitution; nine men out of every ten wanted an office; I\r\nbelieved that these gentlemen would \xe2\x80\x9ctreat\xe2\x80\x9d the moneyless and the\r\nirresponsible among the population into adopting the constitution and\r\nthus well-nigh killing the country (it could not well carry such a load\r\nas a State government, since it had nothing to tax that could stand a\r\ntax, for undeveloped mines could not, and there were not fifty developed\r\nones in the land, there was but little realty to tax, and it did seem as\r\nif nobody was ever going to think of the simple salvation of inflicting\r\na money penalty on murder). I believed that a State government would\r\ndestroy the \xe2\x80\x9cflush times,\xe2\x80\x9d and I wanted to get away. I believed that the\r\nmining stocks I had on hand would soon be worth $100,000, and thought if\r\nthey reached that before the Constitution was adopted, I would sell out\r\nand make myself secure from the crash the change of government was going\r\nto bring. I considered $100,000 sufficient to go home with decently,\r\nthough it was but a small amount compared to what I had been expecting\r\nto return with. I felt rather down-hearted about it, but I tried to\r\ncomfort myself with the reflection that with such a sum I could not fall\r\ninto want. About this time a schoolmate of mine whom I had not seen\r\nsince boyhood, came tramping in on foot from Reese River, a very\r\nallegory of Poverty. The son of wealthy parents, here he was, in a\r\nstrange land, hungry, bootless, mantled in an ancient horse-blanket,\r\nroofed with a brimless hat, and so generally and so extravagantly\r\ndilapidated that he could have \xe2\x80\x9ctaken the shine out of the Prodigal Son\r\nhimself,\xe2\x80\x9d as he pleasantly remarked.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n399.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe wanted to borrow forty-six dollars\xe2\x80\x94twenty-six to take him to San\r\nFrancisco, and twenty for something else; to buy some soap with, maybe,\r\nfor he needed it. I found I had but little more than the amount wanted,\r\nin my pocket; so I stepped in and borrowed forty-six dollars of a banker\r\n(on twenty days\xe2\x80\x99 time, without the formality of a note), and gave it\r\nhim, rather than walk half a block to the office, where I had some\r\nspecie laid up. If anybody had told me that it would take me two years\r\nto pay back that forty-six dollars to the banker (for I did not expect\r\nit of the Prodigal, and was not disappointed), I would have felt\r\ninjured. And so would the banker.\r\n\r\nI wanted a change. I wanted variety of some kind. It came. Mr. Goodman\r\nwent away for a week and left me the post of chief editor. It destroyed\r\nme. The first day, I wrote my \xe2\x80\x9cleader\xe2\x80\x9d in the forenoon. The second day,\r\nI had no subject and put it off till the afternoon. The third day I put\r\nit off till evening, and then copied an elaborate editorial out of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Cyclopedia,\xe2\x80\x9d that steadfast friend of the editor, all over\r\nthis land. The fourth day I \xe2\x80\x9cfooled around\xe2\x80\x9d till midnight, and then fell\r\nback on the Cyclopedia again. The fifth day I cudgeled my brain till\r\nmidnight, and then kept the press waiting while I penned some bitter\r\npersonalities on six different people. The sixth day I labored in\r\nanguish till far into the night and brought forth\xe2\x80\x94nothing. The paper\r\nwent to press without an editorial. The seventh day I resigned. On the\r\neighth, Mr. Goodman returned and found six duels on his hands\xe2\x80\x94my\r\npersonalities had borne fruit.\r\n\r\nNobody, except he has tried it, knows what it is to be an editor. It is\r\neasy to scribble local rubbish, with the facts all before you; it is\r\neasy to clip selections from other papers; it is easy to string out a\r\ncorrespondence from any locality; but it is unspeakable hardship to\r\nwrite editorials. _Subjects_ are the trouble\xe2\x80\x94the dreary lack of them, I\r\nmean. Every day, it is drag, drag, drag\xe2\x80\x94think, and worry and suffer\xe2\x80\x94all\r\nthe world is a dull blank, and yet the editorial columns _must_ be\r\nfilled. Only give the editor a _subject_, and his work is done\xe2\x80\x94it is no\r\ntrouble to write it up; but fancy how you would feel if you had to pump\r\nyour brains dry every day in the week, fifty-two weeks in the year. It\r\nmakes one low spirited simply to think of it. The matter that each\r\neditor of a daily paper in America writes in the course of a year would\r\nfill from four to eight bulky volumes like this book! Fancy what a\r\nlibrary an editor\xe2\x80\x99s work would make, after twenty or thirty years\xe2\x80\x99\r\nservice. Yet people often marvel that Dickens, Scott, Bulwer, Dumas,\r\netc., have been able to produce so many books. If these authors had\r\nwrought as voluminously as newspaper editors do, the result would be\r\nsomething to marvel at, indeed. How editors can continue this tremendous\r\nlabor, this exhausting consumption of brain fibre (for their work is\r\ncreative, and not a mere mechanical laying-up of facts, like reporting),\r\nday after day and year after year, is incomprehensible. Preachers take\r\ntwo months\xe2\x80\x99 holiday in midsummer, for they find that to produce two\r\nsermons a week is wearing, in the long run. In truth it must be so, and\r\nis so; and therefore, how an editor can take from ten to twenty texts\r\nand build upon them from ten to twenty painstaking editorials a week and\r\nkeep it up all the year round, is farther beyond comprehension than\r\never. Ever since I survived my week as editor, I have found at least one\r\npleasure in any newspaper that comes to my hand; it is in admiring the\r\nlong columns of editorial, and wondering to myself how in the mischief\r\nhe did it!\r\n\r\nMr. Goodman\xe2\x80\x99s return relieved me of employment, unless I chose to become\r\na reporter again. I could not do that; I could not serve in the ranks\r\nafter being General of the army. So I thought I would depart and go\r\nabroad into the world somewhere. Just at this juncture, Dan, my\r\nassociate in the reportorial department, told me, casually, that two\r\ncitizens had been trying to persuade him to go with them to New York and\r\naid in selling a rich silver mine which they had discovered and secured\r\nin a new mining district in our neighborhood. He said they offered to\r\npay his expenses and give him one third of the proceeds of the sale. He\r\nhad refused to go. It was the very opportunity I wanted. I abused him\r\nfor keeping so quiet about it, and not mentioning it sooner. He said it\r\nhad not occurred to him that I would like to go, and so he had\r\nrecommended them to apply to Marshall, the reporter of the other paper.\r\nI asked Dan if it was a good, honest mine, and no swindle. He said the\r\nmen had shown him nine tons of the rock, which they had got out to take\r\nto New York, and he could cheerfully say that he had seen but little\r\nrock in Nevada that was richer; and moreover, he said that they had\r\nsecured a tract of valuable timber and a mill-site, near the mine. My\r\nfirst idea was to kill Dan. But I changed my mind, notwithstanding I was\r\nso angry, for I thought maybe the chance was not yet lost. Dan said it\r\nwas by no means lost; that the men were absent at the mine again, and\r\nwould not be in Virginia to leave for the East for some ten days; that\r\nthey had requested him to do the talking to Marshall, and he had\r\npromised that he would either secure Marshall or somebody else for them\r\nby the time they got back; he would now say nothing to anybody till they\r\nreturned, and then fulfil his promise by furnishing me to them.\r\n\r\nIt was splendid. I went to bed all on fire with excitement; for nobody\r\nhad yet gone East to sell a Nevada silver mine, and the field was white\r\nfor the sickle. I felt that such a mine as the one described by Dan\r\nwould bring a princely sum in New York, and sell without delay or\r\ndifficulty. I could not sleep, my fancy so rioted through its castles in\r\nthe air. It was the \xe2\x80\x9cblind lead\xe2\x80\x9d come again.\r\n\r\nNext day I got away, on the coach, with the usual eclat attending\r\ndepartures of old citizens,\xe2\x80\x94for if you have only half a dozen friends\r\nout there they will make noise for a hundred rather than let you seem to\r\ngo away neglected and unregretted\xe2\x80\x94and Dan promised to keep strict watch\r\nfor the men that had the mine to sell.\r\n\r\nThe trip was signalized but by one little incident, and that occurred\r\njust as we were about to start. A very seedy looking vagabond passenger\r\ngot out of the stage a moment to wait till the usual ballast of silver\r\nbricks was thrown in. He was standing on the pavement, when an awkward\r\nexpress employee, carrying a brick weighing a hundred pounds, stumbled\r\nand let it fall on the bummer\xe2\x80\x99s foot. He instantly dropped on the ground\r\nand began to howl in the most heart-breaking way. A sympathizing crowd\r\ngathered around and were going to pull his boot off; but he screamed\r\nlouder than ever and they desisted; then he fell to gasping, and between\r\nthe gasps ejaculated \xe2\x80\x9cBrandy! for Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, brandy!\xe2\x80\x9d They poured\r\nhalf a pint down him, and it wonderfully restored and comforted him.\r\nThen he begged the people to assist him to the stage, which was done.\r\nThe express people urged him to have a doctor at their expense, but he\r\ndeclined, and said that if he only had a little brandy to take along\r\nwith him, to soothe his paroxyms of pain when they came on, he would be\r\ngrateful and content. He was quickly supplied with two bottles, and we\r\ndrove off. He was so smiling and happy after that, that I could not\r\nrefrain from asking him how he could possibly be so comfortable with a\r\ncrushed foot.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n403.jpg (72K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had a drink for twelve hours, and hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\ncent to my name. I was most perishing\xe2\x80\x94and so, when that duffer dropped\r\nthat hundred-pounder on my foot, I see my chance. Got a cork leg, you\r\nknow!\xe2\x80\x9d and he pulled up his pantaloons and proved it.\r\n\r\nHe was as drunk as a lord all day long, and full of chucklings over his\r\ntimely ingenuity.\r\n\r\nOne drunken man necessarily reminds one of another. I once heard a\r\ngentleman tell about an incident which he witnessed in a Californian\r\nbar- room. He entitled it \xe2\x80\x9cYe Modest Man Taketh a Drink.\xe2\x80\x9d It was nothing\r\nbut a bit of acting, but it seemed to me a perfect rendering, and worthy\r\nof Toodles himself. The modest man, tolerably far gone with beer and\r\nother matters, enters a saloon (twenty-five cents is the price for\r\nanything and everything, and specie the only money used) and lays down a\r\nhalf dollar; calls for whiskey and drinks it; the bar-keeper makes\r\nchange and lays the quarter in a wet place on the counter; the modest\r\nman fumbles at it with nerveless fingers, but it slips and the water\r\nholds it; he contemplates it, and tries again; same result; observes\r\nthat people are interested in what he is at, blushes; fumbles at the\r\nquarter again\xe2\x80\x94blushes\xe2\x80\x94puts his forefinger carefully, slowly down, to\r\nmake sure of his aim\xe2\x80\x94pushes the coin toward the bar-keeper, and says\r\nwith a sigh:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n404.jpg (120K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c(\xe2\x80\x99_ic_)Gimme a cigar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNaturally, another gentleman present told about another drunken man. He\r\nsaid he reeled toward home late at night; made a mistake and entered the\r\nwrong gate; thought he saw a dog on the stoop; and it was\xe2\x80\x94an iron one.\r\n\r\nHe stopped and considered; wondered if it was a dangerous dog; ventured\r\nto say \xe2\x80\x9cBe (hic) begone!\xe2\x80\x9d No effect. Then he approached warily, and\r\nadopted conciliation; pursed up his lips and tried to whistle, but\r\nfailed; still approached, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor dog!\xe2\x80\x94doggy, doggy, doggy!\xe2\x80\x94poor\r\ndoggy-dog!\xe2\x80\x9d Got up on the stoop, still petting with fond names; till\r\nmaster of the advantages; then exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cLeave, you thief!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94planted a\r\nvindictive kick in his ribs, and went head-over-heels overboard, of\r\ncourse. A pause; a sigh or two of pain, and then a remark in a\r\nreflective voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAwful solid dog. What could he ben eating? (\xe2\x80\x99ic!) Rocks, p\xe2\x80\x99raps. Such\r\nanimals is dangerous.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99 At\xe2\x80\x99s what I say\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re dangerous. If a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94(\xe2\x80\x99ic!)\xe2\x80\x94if a man wants to feed a dog on rocks, let him _feed_ him on\r\nrocks; \xe2\x80\x99at\xe2\x80\x99s all right; but let him keep him at _home_\xe2\x80\x94not have him\r\nlayin\xe2\x80\x99 round promiscuous, where (\xe2\x80\x99ic!) where people\xe2\x80\x99s liable to stumble\r\nover him when they ain\xe2\x80\x99t noticin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was not without regret that I took a last look at the tiny flag (it\r\nwas thirty-five feet long and ten feet wide) fluttering like a lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhandkerchief from the topmost peak of Mount Davidson, two thousand feet\r\nabove Virginia\xe2\x80\x99s roofs, and felt that doubtless I was bidding a\r\npermanent farewell to a city which had afforded me the most vigorous\r\nenjoyment of life I had ever experienced. And this reminds me of an\r\nincident which the dullest memory Virginia could boast at the time it\r\nhappened must vividly recall, at times, till its possessor dies. Late\r\none summer afternoon we had a rain shower.\r\n\r\nThat was astonishing enough, in itself, to set the whole town buzzing,\r\nfor it only rains (during a week or two weeks) in the winter in Nevada,\r\nand even then not enough at a time to make it worth while for any\r\nmerchant to keep umbrellas for sale. But the rain was not the chief\r\nwonder. It only lasted five or ten minutes; while the people were still\r\ntalking about it all the heavens gathered to themselves a dense\r\nblackness as of midnight. All the vast eastern front of Mount Davidson,\r\nover-looking the city, put on such a funereal gloom that only the\r\nnearness and solidity of the mountain made its outlines even faintly\r\ndistinguishable from the dead blackness of the heavens they rested\r\nagainst. This unaccustomed sight turned all eyes toward the mountain;\r\nand as they looked, a little tongue of rich golden flame was seen waving\r\nand quivering in the heart of the midnight, away up on the extreme\r\nsummit! In a few minutes the streets were packed with people, gazing\r\nwith hardly an uttered word, at the one brilliant mote in the brooding\r\nworld of darkness. It flicked like a candle-flame, and looked no larger;\r\nbut with such a background it was wonderfully bright, small as it was.\r\nIt was the flag!\xe2\x80\x94though no one suspected it at first, it seemed so like\r\na supernatural visitor of some kind\xe2\x80\x94a mysterious messenger of good\r\ntidings, some were fain to believe. It was the nation\xe2\x80\x99s emblem\r\ntransfigured by the departing rays of a sun that was entirely palled\r\nfrom view; and on no other object did the glory fall, in all the broad\r\npanorama of mountain ranges and deserts. Not even upon the staff of the\r\nflag\xe2\x80\x94for that, a needle in the distance at any time, was now untouched\r\nby the light and undistinguishable in the gloom. For a whole hour the\r\nweird visitor winked and burned in its lofty solitude, and still the\r\nthousands of uplifted eyes watched it with fascinated interest. How the\r\npeople were wrought up! The superstition grew apace that this was a\r\nmystic courier come with great news from the war\xe2\x80\x94the poetry of the idea\r\nexcusing and commending it\xe2\x80\x94and on it spread, from heart to heart, from\r\nlip to lip and from street to street, till there was a general impulse\r\nto have out the military and welcome the bright waif with a salvo of\r\nartillery!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n406.jpg (72K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd all that time one sorely tried man, the telegraph operator sworn to\r\nofficial secrecy, had to lock his lips and chain his tongue with a\r\nsilence that was like to rend them; for he, and he only, of all the\r\nspeculating multitude, knew the great things this sinking sun had seen\r\nthat day in the east\xe2\x80\x94Vicksburg fallen, and the Union arms victorious at\r\nGettysburg!\r\n\r\nBut for the journalistic monopoly that forbade the slightest revealment\r\nof eastern news till a day after its publication in the California\r\npapers, the glorified flag on Mount Davidson would have been saluted and\r\nre-saluted, that memorable evening, as long as there was a charge of\r\npowder to thunder with; the city would have been illuminated, and every\r\nman that had any respect for himself would have got drunk,\xe2\x80\x94as was the\r\ncustom of the country on all occasions of public moment. Even at this\r\ndistant day I cannot think of this needlessly marred supreme opportunity\r\nwithout regret. What a time we might have had!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n407.jpg (12K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe rumbled over the plains and valleys, climbed the Sierras to the\r\nclouds, and looked down upon summer-clad California. And I will remark\r\nhere, in passing, that all scenery in California requires _distance_ to\r\ngive it its highest charm. The mountains are imposing in their sublimity\r\nand their majesty of form and altitude, from any point of view\xe2\x80\x94but one\r\nmust have distance to soften their ruggedness and enrich their tintings;\r\na Californian forest is best at a little distance, for there is a sad\r\npoverty of variety in species, the trees being chiefly of one monotonous\r\nfamily\xe2\x80\x94redwood, pine, spruce, fir\xe2\x80\x94and so, at a near view there is a\r\nwearisome sameness of attitude in their rigid arms, stretched downward\r\nand outward in one continued and reiterated appeal to all men to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSh!\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t say a word!\xe2\x80\x94you might disturb somebody!\xe2\x80\x9d Close at hand, too,\r\nthere is a reliefless and relentless smell of pitch and turpentine;\r\nthere is a ceaseless melancholy in their sighing and complaining\r\nfoliage; one walks over a soundless carpet of beaten yellow bark and\r\ndead spines of the foliage till he feels like a wandering spirit bereft\r\nof a footfall; he tires of the endless tufts of needles and yearns for\r\nsubstantial, shapely leaves; he looks for moss and grass to loll upon,\r\nand finds none, for where there is no bark there is naked clay and dirt,\r\nenemies to pensive musing and clean apparel. Often a grassy plain in\r\nCalifornia, is what it should be, but often, too, it is best\r\ncontemplated at a distance, because although its grass blades are tall,\r\nthey stand up vindictively straight and self-sufficient, and are\r\nunsociably wide apart, with uncomely spots of barren sand between.\r\n\r\nOne of the queerest things I know of, is to hear tourists from \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nStates\xe2\x80\x9d go into ecstasies over the loveliness of \xe2\x80\x9cever-blooming\r\nCalifornia.\xe2\x80\x9d And they always do go into that sort of ecstasies. But\r\nperhaps they would modify them if they knew how old Californians, with\r\nthe memory full upon them of the dust-covered and questionable summer\r\ngreens of Californian \xe2\x80\x9cverdure,\xe2\x80\x9d stand astonished, and filled with\r\nworshipping admiration, in the presence of the lavish richness, the\r\nbrilliant green, the infinite freshness, the spend-thrift variety of\r\nform and species and foliage that make an Eastern landscape a vision of\r\nParadise itself. The idea of a man falling into raptures over grave and\r\nsombre California, when that man has seen New England\xe2\x80\x99s meadow-expanses\r\nand her maples, oaks and cathedral-windowed elms decked in summer\r\nattire, or the opaline splendors of autumn descending upon her forests,\r\ncomes very near being funny\xe2\x80\x94would be, in fact, but that it is so\r\npathetic. No land with an unvarying climate can be very beautiful. The\r\ntropics are not, for all the sentiment that is wasted on them. They seem\r\nbeautiful at first, but sameness impairs the charm by and by. _Change_\r\nis the handmaiden Nature requires to do her miracles with. The land that\r\nhas four well-defined seasons, cannot lack beauty, or pall with\r\nmonotony. Each season brings a world of enjoyment and interest in the\r\nwatching of its unfolding, its gradual, harmonious development, its\r\nculminating graces\xe2\x80\x94and just as one begins to tire of it, it passes away\r\nand a radical change comes, with new witcheries and new glories in its\r\ntrain. And I think that to one in sympathy with nature, each season, in\r\nits turn, seems the loveliest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n409.jpg (49K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSan Francisco, a truly fascinating city to live in, is stately and\r\nhandsome at a fair distance, but close at hand one notes that the\r\narchitecture is mostly old-fashioned, many streets are made up of\r\ndecaying, smoke-grimed, wooden houses, and the barren sand-hills toward\r\nthe outskirts obtrude themselves too prominently. Even the kindly\r\nclimate is sometimes pleasanter when read about than personally\r\nexperienced, for a lovely, cloudless sky wears out its welcome by and\r\nby, and then when the longed for rain does come it _stays_. Even the\r\nplayful earthquake is better contemplated at a dis\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nHowever there are varying opinions about that.\r\n\r\nThe climate of San Francisco is mild and singularly equable. The\r\nthermometer stands at about seventy degrees the year round. It hardly\r\nchanges at all. You sleep under one or two light blankets Summer and\r\nWinter, and never use a mosquito bar. Nobody ever wears Summer clothing.\r\nYou wear black broadcloth\xe2\x80\x94if you have it\xe2\x80\x94in August and January, just the\r\nsame. It is no colder, and no warmer, in the one month than the other.\r\nYou do not use overcoats and you do not use fans. It is as pleasant a\r\nclimate as could well be contrived, take it all around, and is doubtless\r\nthe most unvarying in the whole world. The wind blows there a good deal\r\nin the summer months, but then you can go over to Oakland, if you\r\nchoose\xe2\x80\x94three or four miles away\xe2\x80\x94it does not blow there. It has only\r\nsnowed twice in San Francisco in nineteen years, and then it only\r\nremained on the ground long enough to astonish the children, and set\r\nthem to wondering what the feathery stuff was.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n410.jpg (53K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring eight months of the year, straight along, the skies are bright\r\nand cloudless, and never a drop of rain falls. But when the other four\r\nmonths come along, you will need to go and steal an umbrella. Because\r\nyou will require it. Not just one day, but one hundred and twenty days\r\nin hardly varying succession. When you want to go visiting, or attend\r\nchurch, or the theatre, you never look up at the clouds to see whether\r\nit is likely to rain or not\xe2\x80\x94you look at the almanac. If it is Winter, it\r\n_will_ rain\xe2\x80\x94and if it is Summer, it _won\xe2\x80\x99t_ rain, and you cannot help\r\nit. You never need a lightning-rod, because it never thunders and it\r\nnever lightens. And after you have listened for six or eight weeks,\r\nevery night, to the dismal monotony of those quiet rains, you will wish\r\nin your heart the thunder _would_ leap and crash and roar along those\r\ndrowsy skies once, and make everything alive\xe2\x80\x94you will wish the prisoned\r\nlightnings _would_ cleave the dull firmament asunder and light it with a\r\nblinding glare for _one_ little instant. You would give _anything_ to\r\nhear the old familiar thunder again and see the lightning strike\r\nsomebody. And along in the Summer, when you have suffered about four\r\nmonths of lustrous, pitiless sunshine, you are ready to go down on your\r\nknees and plead for rain\xe2\x80\x94hail\xe2\x80\x94snow\xe2\x80\x94thunder and lightning\xe2\x80\x94anything to\r\nbreak the monotony\xe2\x80\x94you will take an earthquake, if you cannot do any\r\nbetter. And the chances are that you\xe2\x80\x99ll get it, too.\r\n\r\nSan Francisco is built on sand hills, but they are prolific sand hills.\r\nThey yield a generous vegetation. All the rare flowers which people in\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe States\xe2\x80\x9d rear with such patient care in parlor flower-pots and\r\ngreen-houses, flourish luxuriantly in the open air there all the year\r\nround. Calla lilies, all sorts of geraniums, passion flowers, moss\r\nroses\xe2\x80\x94I do not know the names of a tenth part of them. I only know that\r\nwhile New Yorkers are burdened with banks and drifts of snow,\r\nCalifornians are burdened with banks and drifts of flowers, if they only\r\nkeep their hands off and let them grow. And I have heard that they have\r\nalso that rarest and most curious of all the flowers, the beautiful\r\nEspiritu Santo, as the Spaniards call it\xe2\x80\x94or flower of the Holy\r\nSpirit\xe2\x80\x94though I thought it grew only in Central America\xe2\x80\x94down on the\r\nIsthmus. In its cup is the daintiest little facsimile of a dove, as pure\r\nas snow. The Spaniards have a superstitious reverence for it. The\r\nblossom has been conveyed to the States, submerged in ether; and the\r\nbulb has been taken thither also, but every attempt to make it bloom\r\nafter it arrived, has failed.\r\n\r\nI have elsewhere spoken of the endless Winter of Mono, California, and\r\nbut this moment of the eternal Spring of San Francisco. Now if we travel\r\na hundred miles in a straight line, we come to the eternal Summer of\r\nSacramento. One never sees Summer-clothing or mosquitoes in San\r\nFrancisco\xe2\x80\x94but they can be found in Sacramento. Not always and\r\nunvaryingly, but about one hundred and forty-three months out of twelve\r\nyears, perhaps. Flowers bloom there, always, the reader can easily\r\nbelieve\xe2\x80\x94people suffer and sweat, and swear, morning, noon and night, and\r\nwear out their stanchest energies fanning themselves. It gets hot there,\r\nbut if you go down to Fort Yuma you will find it hotter. Fort Yuma is\r\nprobably the hottest place on earth. The thermometer stays at one\r\nhundred and twenty in the shade there all the time\xe2\x80\x94except when it varies\r\nand goes higher. It is a U.S. military post, and its occupants get so\r\nused to the terrific heat that they suffer without it. There is a\r\ntradition (attributed to John Phenix [It has been purloined by fifty\r\ndifferent scribblers who were too poor to invent a fancy but not ashamed\r\nto steal one.\xe2\x80\x94M. T.]) that a very, very wicked soldier died there, once,\r\nand of course, went straight to the hottest corner of perdition,\xe2\x80\x94and the\r\nnext day he _telegraphed back for his blankets._ There is no doubt about\r\nthe truth of this statement\xe2\x80\x94there can be no doubt about it. I have seen\r\nthe place where that soldier used to board. In Sacramento it is fiery\r\nSummer always, and you can gather roses, and eat strawberries and ice-\r\ncream, and wear white linen clothes, and pant and perspire, at eight or\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, and then take the cars, and at noon put on\r\nyour furs and your skates, and go skimming over frozen Donner Lake,\r\nseven thousand feet above the valley, among snow banks fifteen feet\r\ndeep, and in the shadow of grand mountain peaks that lift their frosty\r\ncrags ten thousand feet above the level of the sea.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n413.jpg (94K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThere is a transition for you! Where will you find another like it in\r\nthe Western hemisphere? And some of us have swept around snow-walled\r\ncurves of the Pacific Railroad in that vicinity, six thousand feet above\r\nthe sea, and looked down as the birds do, upon the deathless Summer of\r\nthe Sacramento Valley, with its fruitful fields, its feathery foliage,\r\nits silver streams, all slumbering in the mellow haze of its enchanted\r\natmosphere, and all infinitely softened and spiritualized by distance\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndreamy, exquisite glimpse of fairyland, made all the more charming and\r\nstriking that it was caught through a forbidden gateway of ice and snow,\r\nand savage crags and precipices.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was in this Sacramento Valley, just referred to, that a deal of the\r\nmost lucrative of the early gold mining was done, and you may still see,\r\nin places, its grassy slopes and levels torn and guttered and disfigured\r\nby the avaricious spoilers of fifteen and twenty years ago. You may see\r\nsuch disfigurements far and wide over California\xe2\x80\x94and in some such\r\nplaces, where only meadows and forests are visible\xe2\x80\x94not a living\r\ncreature, not a house, no stick or stone or remnant of a ruin, and not a\r\nsound, not even a whisper to disturb the Sabbath stillness\xe2\x80\x94you will find\r\nit hard to believe that there stood at one time a fiercely-flourishing\r\nlittle city, of two thousand or three thousand souls, with its\r\nnewspaper, fire company, brass band, volunteer militia, bank, hotels,\r\nnoisy Fourth of July processions and speeches, gambling hells crammed\r\nwith tobacco smoke, profanity, and rough-bearded men of all nations and\r\ncolors, with tables heaped with gold dust sufficient for the revenues of\r\na German principality\xe2\x80\x94streets crowded and rife with business\xe2\x80\x94town lots\r\nworth four hundred dollars a front foot\xe2\x80\x94labor, laughter, music, dancing,\r\nswearing, fighting, shooting, stabbing\xe2\x80\x94a bloody inquest and a man for\r\nbreakfast every morning\xe2\x80\x94_everything_ that delights and adorns\r\nexistence\xe2\x80\x94all the appointments and appurtenances of a thriving and\r\nprosperous and promising young city,\xe2\x80\x94and _now_ nothing is left of it all\r\nbut a lifeless, homeless solitude. The men are gone, the houses have\r\nvanished, even the _name_ of the place is forgotten. In no other land,\r\nin modern times, have towns so absolutely died and disappeared, as in\r\nthe old mining regions of California.\r\n\r\nIt was a driving, vigorous, restless population in those days. It was a\r\n_curious_ population. It was the _only_ population of the kind that the\r\nworld has ever seen gathered together, and it is not likely that the\r\nworld will ever see its like again. For observe, it was an assemblage of\r\ntwo hundred thousand _young_ men\xe2\x80\x94not simpering, dainty, kid-gloved\r\nweaklings, but stalwart, muscular, dauntless young braves, brimful of\r\npush and energy, and royally endowed with every attribute that goes to\r\nmake up a peerless and magnificent manhood\xe2\x80\x94the very pick and choice of\r\nthe world\xe2\x80\x99s glorious ones. No women, no children, no gray and stooping\r\nveterans,\xe2\x80\x94none but erect, bright-eyed, quick-moving, strong-handed young\r\ngiants\xe2\x80\x94the strangest population, the finest population, the most gallant\r\nhost that ever trooped down the startled solitudes of an unpeopled land.\r\nAnd where are they now? Scattered to the ends of the earth\xe2\x80\x94or\r\nprematurely aged and decrepit\xe2\x80\x94or shot or stabbed in street affrays\xe2\x80\x94or\r\ndead of disappointed hopes and broken hearts\xe2\x80\x94all gone, or nearly\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94victims devoted upon the altar of the golden calf\xe2\x80\x94the noblest\r\nholocaust that ever wafted its sacrificial incense heavenward. It is\r\npitiful to think upon.\r\n\r\nIt was a splendid population\xe2\x80\x94for all the slow, sleepy, sluggish-brained\r\nsloths staid at home\xe2\x80\x94you never find that sort of people among\r\npioneers\xe2\x80\x94you cannot build pioneers out of that sort of material. It was\r\nthat population that gave to California a name for getting up astounding\r\nenterprises and rushing them through with a magnificent dash and daring\r\nand a recklessness of cost or consequences, which she bears unto this\r\nday\xe2\x80\x94and when she projects a new surprise, the grave world smiles as\r\nusual, and says \xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is California all over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut they were rough in those times! They fairly reveled in gold, whisky,\r\nfights, and fandangoes, and were unspeakably happy. The honest miner\r\nraked from a hundred to a thousand dollars out of his claim a day, and\r\nwhat with the gambling dens and the other entertainments, he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\ncent the next morning, if he had any sort of luck. They cooked their own\r\nbacon and beans, sewed on their own buttons, washed their own\r\nshirts\xe2\x80\x94blue woollen ones; and if a man wanted a fight on his hands\r\nwithout any annoying delay, all he had to do was to appear in public in\r\na white shirt or a stove-pipe hat, and he would be accommodated. For\r\nthose people hated aristocrats. They had a particular and malignant\r\nanimosity toward what they called a \xe2\x80\x9cbiled shirt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a wild, free, disorderly, grotesque society! _Men_\xe2\x80\x94only swarming\r\nhosts of stalwart _men_\xe2\x80\x94nothing juvenile, nothing feminine, visible\r\nanywhere!\r\n\r\nIn those days miners would flock in crowds to catch a glimpse of that\r\nrare and blessed spectacle, a woman! Old inhabitants tell how, in a\r\ncertain camp, the news went abroad early in the morning that a woman was\r\ncome! They had seen a calico dress hanging out of a wagon down at the\r\ncamping-ground\xe2\x80\x94sign of emigrants from over the great plains. Everybody\r\nwent down there, and a shout went up when an actual, bona fide dress was\r\ndiscovered fluttering in the wind! The male emigrant was visible. The\r\nminers said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch her out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is my wife, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94she is sick\xe2\x80\x94we have been robbed of\r\nmoney, provisions, everything, by the Indians\xe2\x80\x94we want to rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch her out! We\xe2\x80\x99ve got to see her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, gentlemen, the poor thing, she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFETCH HER OUT!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n416.jpg (87K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe \xe2\x80\x9cfetched her out,\xe2\x80\x9d and they swung their hats and sent up three\r\nrousing cheers and a tiger; and they crowded around and gazed at her,\r\nand touched her dress, and listened to her voice with the look of men\r\nwho listened to a _memory_ rather than a present reality\xe2\x80\x94and then they\r\ncollected twenty-five hundred dollars in gold and gave it to the man,\r\nand swung their hats again and gave three more cheers, and went home\r\nsatisfied.\r\n\r\nOnce I dined in San Francisco with the family of a pioneer, and talked\r\nwith his daughter, a young lady whose first experience in San Francisco\r\nwas an adventure, though she herself did not remember it, as she was\r\nonly two or three years old at the time. Her father said that, after\r\nlanding from the ship, they were walking up the street, a servant\r\nleading the party with the little girl in her arms. And presently a huge\r\nminer, bearded, belted, spurred, and bristling with deadly weapons\xe2\x80\x94just\r\ndown from a long campaign in the mountains, evidently&mdashbarred the\r\nway, stopped the servant, and stood gazing, with a face all alive with\r\ngratification and astonishment. Then he said, reverently:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n417.jpg (58K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if it ain\xe2\x80\x99t a child!\xe2\x80\x9d And then he snatched a little leather sack\r\nout of his pocket and said to the servant:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a hundred and fifty dollars in dust, there, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll give it to\r\nyou to let me kiss the child!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat anecdote is _true_.\r\n\r\nBut see how things change. Sitting at that dinner-table, listening to\r\nthat anecdote, if I had offered double the money for the privilege of\r\nkissing the same child, I would have been refused. Seventeen added years\r\nhave far more than doubled the price.\r\n\r\nAnd while upon this subject I will remark that once in Star City, in the\r\nHumboldt Mountains, I took my place in a sort of long, post-office\r\nsingle file of miners, to patiently await my chance to peep through a\r\ncrack in the cabin and get a sight of the splendid new sensation\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngenuine, live Woman! And at the end of half of an hour my turn came, and\r\nI put my eye to the crack, and there she was, with one arm akimbo, and\r\ntossing flap-jacks in a frying-pan with the other.\r\n\r\nAnd she was one hundred and sixty-five [Being in calmer mood, now, I\r\nvoluntarily knock off a hundred from that.\xe2\x80\x94M.T.] years old, and hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\ntooth in her head.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n418.jpg (28K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nFor a few months I enjoyed what to me was an entirely new phase of\r\nexistence\xe2\x80\x94a butterfly idleness; nothing to do, nobody to be responsible\r\nto, and untroubled with financial uneasiness. I fell in love with the\r\nmost cordial and sociable city in the Union. After the sage-brush and\r\nalkali deserts of Washoe, San Francisco was Paradise to me. I lived at\r\nthe best hotel, exhibited my clothes in the most conspicuous places,\r\ninfested the opera, and learned to seem enraptured with music which\r\noftener afflicted my ignorant ear than enchanted it, if I had had the\r\nvulgar honesty to confess it. However, I suppose I was not greatly worse\r\nthan the most of my countrymen in that. I had longed to be a butterfly,\r\nand I was one at last. I attended private parties in sumptuous evening\r\ndress, simpered and aired my graces like a born beau, and polked and\r\nschottisched with a step peculiar to myself\xe2\x80\x94and the kangaroo. In a word,\r\nI kept the due state of a man worth a hundred thousand dollars\r\n(prospectively,) and likely to reach absolute affluence when that\r\nsilver- mine sale should be ultimately achieved in the East. I spent\r\nmoney with a free hand, and meantime watched the stock sales with an\r\ninterested eye and looked to see what might happen in Nevada.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n420.jpg (49K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSomething very important happened. The property holders of Nevada voted\r\nagainst the State Constitution; but the folks who had nothing to lose\r\nwere in the majority, and carried the measure over their heads. But\r\nafter all it did not immediately look like a disaster, though\r\nunquestionably it was one I hesitated, calculated the chances, and then\r\nconcluded not to sell. Stocks went on rising; speculation went mad;\r\nbankers, merchants, lawyers, doctors, mechanics, laborers, even the very\r\nwasherwomen and servant girls, were putting up their earnings on silver\r\nstocks, and every sun that rose in the morning went down on paupers\r\nenriched and rich men beggared. What a gambling carnival it was! Gould\r\nand Curry soared to six thousand three hundred dollars a foot! And\r\nthen\xe2\x80\x94all of a sudden, out went the bottom and everything and everybody\r\nwent to ruin and destruction! The wreck was complete.\r\n\r\nThe bubble scarcely left a microscopic moisture behind it. I was an\r\nearly beggar and a thorough one. My hoarded stocks were not worth the\r\npaper they were printed on. I threw them all away. I, the cheerful idiot\r\nthat had been squandering money like water, and thought myself beyond\r\nthe reach of misfortune, had not now as much as fifty dollars when I\r\ngathered together my various debts and paid them. I removed from the\r\nhotel to a very private boarding house. I took a reporter\xe2\x80\x99s berth and\r\nwent to work. I was not entirely broken in spirit, for I was building\r\nconfidently on the sale of the silver mine in the east. But I could not\r\nhear from Dan. My letters miscarried or were not answered.\r\n\r\nOne day I did not feel vigorous and remained away from the office. The\r\nnext day I went down toward noon as usual, and found a note on my desk\r\nwhich had been there twenty-four hours. It was signed \xe2\x80\x9cMarshall\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nVirginia reporter\xe2\x80\x94and contained a request that I should call at the\r\nhotel and see him and a friend or two that night, as they would sail for\r\nthe east in the morning. A postscript added that their errand was a big\r\nmining speculation! I was hardly ever so sick in my life. I abused\r\nmyself for leaving Virginia and entrusting to another man a matter I\r\nought to have attended to myself; I abused myself for remaining away\r\nfrom the office on the one day of all the year that I should have been\r\nthere. And thus berating myself I trotted a mile to the steamer wharf\r\nand arrived just in time to be too late. The ship was in the stream and\r\nunder way.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n421.jpg (20K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI comforted myself with the thought that may be the speculation would\r\namount to nothing\xe2\x80\x94poor comfort at best\xe2\x80\x94and then went back to my slavery,\r\nresolved to put up with my thirty-five dollars a week and forget all\r\nabout it.\r\n\r\nA month afterward I enjoyed my first earthquake. It was one which was\r\nlong called the \xe2\x80\x9cgreat\xe2\x80\x9d earthquake, and is doubtless so distinguished\r\ntill this day. It was just after noon, on a bright October day. I was\r\ncoming down Third street. The only objects in motion anywhere in sight\r\nin that thickly built and populous quarter, were a man in a buggy behind\r\nme, and a street car wending slowly up the cross street. Otherwise, all\r\nwas solitude and a Sabbath stillness. As I turned the corner, around a\r\nframe house, there was a great rattle and jar, and it occurred to me\r\nthat here was an item!\xe2\x80\x94no doubt a fight in that house. Before I could\r\nturn and seek the door, there came a really terrific shock; the ground\r\nseemed to roll under me in waves, interrupted by a violent joggling up\r\nand down, and there was a heavy grinding noise as of brick houses\r\nrubbing together. I fell up against the frame house and hurt my elbow. I\r\nknew what it was, now, and from mere reportorial instinct, nothing else,\r\ntook out my watch and noted the time of day; at that moment a third and\r\nstill severer shock came, and as I reeled about on the pavement trying\r\nto keep my footing, I saw a sight! The entire front of a tall four-story\r\nbrick building in Third street sprung outward like a door and fell\r\nsprawling across the street, raising a dust like a great volume of\r\nsmoke! And here came the buggy\xe2\x80\x94overboard went the man, and in less time\r\nthan I can tell it the vehicle was distributed in small fragments along\r\nthree hundred yards of street.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n422.jpg (87K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOne could have fancied that somebody had fired a charge of chair-rounds\r\nand rags down the thoroughfare. The street car had stopped, the horses\r\nwere rearing and plunging, the passengers were pouring out at both ends,\r\nand one fat man had crashed half way through a glass window on one side\r\nof the car, got wedged fast and was squirming and screaming like an\r\nimpaled madman. Every door, of every house, as far as the eye could\r\nreach, was vomiting a stream of human beings; and almost before one\r\ncould execute a wink and begin another, there was a massed multitude of\r\npeople stretching in endless procession down every street my position\r\ncommanded. Never was solemn solitude turned into teeming life quicker.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n423a.jpg (38K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOf the wonders wrought by \xe2\x80\x9cthe great earthquake,\xe2\x80\x9d these were all that\r\ncame under my eye; but the tricks it did, elsewhere, and far and wide\r\nover the town, made toothsome gossip for nine days.\r\n\r\nThe destruction of property was trifling\xe2\x80\x94the injury to it was wide-\r\nspread and somewhat serious.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n423b.jpg (37K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9ccuriosities\xe2\x80\x9d of the earthquake were simply endless. Gentlemen and\r\nladies who were sick, or were taking a siesta, or had dissipated till a\r\nlate hour and were making up lost sleep, thronged into the public\r\nstreets in all sorts of queer apparel, and some without any at all. One\r\nwoman who had been washing a naked child, ran down the street holding it\r\nby the ankles as if it were a dressed turkey. Prominent citizens who\r\nwere supposed to keep the Sabbath strictly, rushed out of saloons in\r\ntheir shirt-sleeves, with billiard cues in their hands. Dozens of men\r\nwith necks swathed in napkins, rushed from barber-shops, lathered to the\r\neyes or with one cheek clean shaved and the other still bearing a hairy\r\nstubble. Horses broke from stables, and a frightened dog rushed up a\r\nshort attic ladder and out on to a roof, and when his scare was over had\r\nnot the nerve to go down again the same way he had gone up.\r\n\r\nA prominent editor flew down stairs, in the principal hotel, with\r\nnothing on but one brief undergarment\xe2\x80\x94met a chambermaid, and exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what _shall_ I do! Where shall I go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe responded with naive serenity:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you have no choice, you might try a clothing-store!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n424.jpg (63K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA certain foreign consul\xe2\x80\x99s lady was the acknowledged leader of fashion,\r\nand every time she appeared in anything new or extraordinary, the ladies\r\nin the vicinity made a raid on their husbands\xe2\x80\x99 purses and arrayed\r\nthemselves similarly. One man who had suffered considerably and growled\r\naccordingly, was standing at the window when the shocks came, and the\r\nnext instant the consul\xe2\x80\x99s wife, just out of the bath, fled by with no\r\nother apology for clothing than\xe2\x80\x94a bath-towel! The sufferer rose superior\r\nto the terrors of the earthquake, and said to his wife:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow that is something _like_! Get out your towel my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n425 (40K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe plastering that fell from ceilings in San Francisco that day, would\r\nhave covered several acres of ground. For some days afterward, groups of\r\neyeing and pointing men stood about many a building, looking at long\r\nzig- zag cracks that extended from the eaves to the ground. Four feet of\r\nthe tops of three chimneys on one house were broken square off and\r\nturned around in such a way as to completely stop the draft.\r\n\r\nA crack a hundred feet long gaped open six inches wide in the middle of\r\none street and then shut together again with such force, as to ridge up\r\nthe meeting earth like a slender grave. A lady sitting in her rocking\r\nand quaking parlor, saw the wall part at the ceiling, open and shut\r\ntwice, like a mouth, and then drop the end of a brick on the floor like\r\na tooth. She was a woman easily disgusted with foolishness, and she\r\narose and went out of there. One lady who was coming down stairs was\r\nastonished to see a bronze Hercules lean forward on its pedestal as if\r\nto strike her with its club. They both reached the bottom of the flight\r\nat the same time,\xe2\x80\x94the woman insensible from the fright. Her child, born\r\nsome little time afterward, was club-footed. However\xe2\x80\x94on second\r\nthought,\xe2\x80\x94if the reader sees any coincidence in this, he must do it at\r\nhis own risk.\r\n\r\nThe first shock brought down two or three huge organ-pipes in one of the\r\nchurches. The minister, with uplifted hands, was just closing the\r\nservices. He glanced up, hesitated, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever, we will omit the benediction!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and the next instant there was\r\na vacancy in the atmosphere where he had stood.\r\n\r\nAfter the first shock, an Oakland minister said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep your seats! There is no better place to die than this\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nAnd added, after the third:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut outside is good enough!\xe2\x80\x9d He then skipped out at the back door.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n426.jpg (40K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch another destruction of mantel ornaments and toilet bottles as the\r\nearthquake created, San Francisco never saw before. There was hardly a\r\ngirl or a matron in the city but suffered losses of this kind. Suspended\r\npictures were thrown down, but oftener still, by a curious freak of the\r\nearthquake\xe2\x80\x99s humor, they were whirled completely around with their faces\r\nto the wall! There was great difference of opinion, at first, as to the\r\ncourse or direction the earthquake traveled, but water that splashed out\r\nof various tanks and buckets settled that. Thousands of people were made\r\nso sea-sick by the rolling and pitching of floors and streets that they\r\nwere weak and bed-ridden for hours, and some few for even days\r\nafterward.\xe2\x80\x94Hardly an individual escaped nausea entirely.\r\n\r\nThe queer earthquake\xe2\x80\x94episodes that formed the staple of San Francisco\r\ngossip for the next week would fill a much larger book than this, and so\r\nI will diverge from the subject.\r\n\r\nBy and by, in the due course of things, I picked up a copy of the\r\nEnterprise one day, and fell under this cruel blow:\r\n\r\nNEVADA MINES IN NEW YORK.\xe2\x80\x94G. M. Marshall, Sheba Hurs and Amos H. Rose,\r\nwho left San Francisco last July for New York City, with ores from mines\r\nin Pine Wood District, Humboldt County, and on the Reese River range,\r\nhave disposed of a mine containing six thousand feet and called the Pine\r\nMountains Consolidated, for the sum of $3,000,000. The stamps on the\r\ndeed, which is now on its way to Humboldt County, from New York, for\r\nrecord, amounted to $3,000, which is said to be the largest amount of\r\nstamps ever placed on one document. A working capital of $1,000,000 has\r\nbeen paid into the treasury, and machinery has already been purchased\r\nfor a large quartz mill, which will be put up as soon as possible. The\r\nstock in this company is all full paid and entirely unassessable. The\r\nores of the mines in this district somewhat resemble those of the Sheba\r\nmine in Humboldt. Sheba Hurst, the discoverer of the mines, with his\r\nfriends corralled all the best leads and all the land and timber they\r\ndesired before making public their whereabouts. Ores from there, assayed\r\nin this city, showed them to be exceedingly rich in silver and\r\ngold\xe2\x80\x94silver predominating. There is an abundance of wood and water in\r\nthe District. We are glad to know that New York capital has been\r\nenlisted in the development of the mines of this region. Having seen the\r\nores and assays, we are satisfied that the mines of the District are\r\nvery valuable\xe2\x80\x94anything but wild-cat.\r\n\r\nOnce more native imbecility had carried the day, and I had lost a\r\nmillion! It was the \xe2\x80\x9cblind lead\xe2\x80\x9d over again.\r\n\r\nLet us not dwell on this miserable matter. If I were inventing these\r\nthings, I could be wonderfully humorous over them; but they are too true\r\nto be talked of with hearty levity, even at this distant day. [True, and\r\nyet not exactly as given in the above figures, possibly. I saw Marshall,\r\nmonths afterward, and although he had plenty of money he did not claim\r\nto have captured an entire million. In fact I gathered that he had not\r\nthen received $50,000. Beyond that figure his fortune appeared to\r\nconsist of uncertain vast expectations rather than prodigious\r\ncertainties. However, when the above item appeared in print I put full\r\nfaith in it, and incontinently wilted and went to seed under it.]\r\nSuffice it that I so lost heart, and so yielded myself up to repinings\r\nand sighings and foolish regrets, that I neglected my duties and became\r\nabout worthless, as a reporter for a brisk newspaper. And at last one of\r\nthe proprietors took me aside, with a charity I still remember with\r\nconsiderable respect, and gave me an opportunity to resign my berth and\r\nso save myself the disgrace of a dismissal.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nFor a time I wrote literary screeds for the Golden Era. C. H. Webb had\r\nestablished a very excellent literary weekly called the Californian, but\r\nhigh merit was no guaranty of success; it languished, and he sold out to\r\nthree printers, and Bret Harte became editor at $20 a week, and I was\r\nemployed to contribute an article a week at $12. But the journal still\r\nlanguished, and the printers sold out to Captain Ogden, a rich man and a\r\npleasant gentleman who chose to amuse himself with such an expensive\r\nluxury without much caring about the cost of it. When he grew tired of\r\nthe novelty, he re-sold to the printers, the paper presently died a\r\npeaceful death, and I was out of work again. I would not mention these\r\nthings but for the fact that they so aptly illustrate the ups and downs\r\nthat characterize life on the Pacific coast. A man could hardly stumble\r\ninto such a variety of queer vicissitudes in any other country.\r\n\r\nFor two months my sole occupation was avoiding acquaintances; for during\r\nthat time I did not earn a penny, or buy an article of any kind, or pay\r\nmy board. I became a very adept at \xe2\x80\x9cslinking.\xe2\x80\x9d I slunk from back street\r\nto back street, I slunk away from approaching faces that looked\r\nfamiliar, I slunk to my meals, ate them humbly and with a mute apology\r\nfor every mouthful I robbed my generous landlady of, and at midnight,\r\nafter wanderings that were but slinkings away from cheerfulness and\r\nlight, I slunk to my bed. I felt meaner, and lowlier and more despicable\r\nthan the worms. During all this time I had but one piece of money\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nsilver ten cent piece\xe2\x80\x94and I held to it and would not spend it on any\r\naccount, lest the consciousness coming strong upon me that I was\r\nentirely penniless, might suggest suicide. I had pawned every thing but\r\nthe clothes I had on; so I clung to my dime desperately, till it was\r\nsmooth with handling.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n429.jpg (36K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHowever, I am forgetting. I did have one other occupation beside that of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cslinking.\xe2\x80\x9d It was the entertaining of a collector (and being\r\nentertained by him,) who had in his hands the Virginia banker\xe2\x80\x99s bill for\r\nforty-six dollars which I had loaned my schoolmate, the \xe2\x80\x9cProdigal.\xe2\x80\x9d This\r\nman used to call regularly once a week and dun me, and sometimes\r\noftener. He did it from sheer force of habit, for he knew he could get\r\nnothing. He would get out his bill, calculate the interest for me, at\r\nfive per cent a month, and show me clearly that there was no attempt at\r\nfraud in it and no mistakes; and then plead, and argue and dun with all\r\nhis might for any sum\xe2\x80\x94any little trifle\xe2\x80\x94even a dollar\xe2\x80\x94even half a\r\ndollar, on account. Then his duty was accomplished and his conscience\r\nfree. He immediately dropped the subject there always; got out a couple\r\nof cigars and divided, put his feet in the window, and then we would\r\nhave a long, luxurious talk about everything and everybody, and he would\r\nfurnish me a world of curious dunning adventures out of the ample store\r\nin his memory. By and by he would clap his hat on his head, shake hands\r\nand say briskly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, business is business\xe2\x80\x94can\xe2\x80\x99t stay with you always!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and was off in\r\na second.\r\n\r\nThe idea of pining for a dun! And yet I used to long for him to come,\r\nand would get as uneasy as any mother if the day went by without his\r\nvisit, when I was expecting him. But he never collected that bill, at\r\nlast nor any part of it. I lived to pay it to the banker myself.\r\n\r\nMisery loves company.
