Now and then at night, in out-of-the way, dimly\r\nlighted places, I found myself happening on another child of misfortune.\r\nHe looked so seedy and forlorn, so homeless and friendless and forsaken,\r\nthat I yearned toward him as a brother. I wanted to claim kinship with\r\nhim and go about and enjoy our wretchedness together. The drawing toward\r\neach other must have been mutual; at any rate we got to falling together\r\noftener, though still seemingly by accident; and although we did not\r\nspeak or evince any recognition, I think the dull anxiety passed out of\r\nboth of us when we saw each other, and then for several hours we would\r\nidle along contentedly, wide apart, and glancing furtively in at home\r\nlights and fireside gatherings, out of the night shadows, and very much\r\nenjoying our dumb companionship.\r\n\r\nFinally we spoke, and were inseparable after that. For our woes were\r\nidentical, almost. He had been a reporter too, and lost his berth, and\r\nthis was his experience, as nearly as I can recollect it. After losing\r\nhis berth he had gone down, down, down, with never a halt: from a\r\nboarding house on Russian Hill to a boarding house in Kearney street;\r\nfrom thence to Dupont; from thence to a low sailor den; and from thence\r\nto lodgings in goods boxes and empty hogsheads near the wharves. Then;\r\nfor a while, he had gained a meagre living by sewing up bursted sacks of\r\ngrain on the piers; when that failed he had found food here and there as\r\nchance threw it in his way. He had ceased to show his face in daylight,\r\nnow, for a reporter knows everybody, rich and poor, high and low, and\r\ncannot well avoid familiar faces in the broad light of day.\r\n\r\nThis mendicant Blucher\xe2\x80\x94I call him that for convenience\xe2\x80\x94was a splendid\r\ncreature. He was full of hope, pluck and philosophy; he was well read\r\nand a man of cultivated taste; he had a bright wit and was a master of\r\nsatire; his kindliness and his generous spirit made him royal in my eyes\r\nand changed his curb-stone seat to a throne and his damaged hat to a\r\ncrown.\r\n\r\nHe had an adventure, once, which sticks fast in my memory as the most\r\npleasantly grotesque that ever touched my sympathies. He had been\r\nwithout a penny for two months. He had shirked about obscure streets,\r\namong friendly dim lights, till the thing had become second nature to\r\nhim. But at last he was driven abroad in daylight. The cause was\r\nsufficient; _he had not tasted food for forty-eight hours_, and he could\r\nnot endure the misery of his hunger in idle hiding. He came along a back\r\nstreet, glowering at the loaves in bake-shop windows, and feeling that\r\nhe could trade his life away for a morsel to eat. The sight of the bread\r\ndoubled his hunger; but it was good to look at it, any how, and imagine\r\nwhat one might do if one only had it.\r\n\r\nPresently, in the middle of the street he saw a shining spot\xe2\x80\x94looked\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94did not, and could not, believe his eyes\xe2\x80\x94turned away, to try them,\r\nthen looked again. It was a verity\xe2\x80\x94no vain, hunger-inspired delusion\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nwas a silver dime!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n431.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe snatched it\xe2\x80\x94gloated over it; doubted it\xe2\x80\x94bit it\xe2\x80\x94found it\r\ngenuine\xe2\x80\x94choked his heart down, and smothered a halleluiah. Then he\r\nlooked around\xe2\x80\x94saw that nobody was looking at him\xe2\x80\x94threw the dime down\r\nwhere it was before\xe2\x80\x94walked away a few steps, and approached again,\r\npretending he did not know it was there, so that he could re-enjoy the\r\nluxury of finding it. He walked around it, viewing it from different\r\npoints; then sauntered about with his hands in his pockets, looking up\r\nat the signs and now and then glancing at it and feeling the old thrill\r\nagain. Finally he took it up, and went away, fondling it in his pocket.\r\nHe idled through unfrequented streets, stopping in doorways and corners\r\nto take it out and look at it. By and by he went home to his lodgings\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nempty queens-ware hogshead,\xe2\x80\x94and employed himself till night trying to\r\nmake up his mind what to buy with it. But it was hard to do. To get the\r\nmost for it was the idea. He knew that at the Miner\xe2\x80\x99s Restaurant he\r\ncould get a plate of beans and a piece of bread for ten cents; or a\r\nfish-ball and some few trifles, but they gave \xe2\x80\x9cno bread with one fish-\r\nball\xe2\x80\x9d there. At French Pete\xe2\x80\x99s he could get a veal cutlet, plain, and\r\nsome radishes and bread, for ten cents; or a cup of coffee\xe2\x80\x94a pint at\r\nleast\xe2\x80\x94and a slice of bread; but the slice was not thick enough by the\r\neighth of an inch, and sometimes they were still more criminal than that\r\nin the cutting of it. At seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock his hunger was wolfish; and still\r\nhis mind was not made up. He turned out and went up Merchant street,\r\nstill ciphering; and chewing a bit of stick, as is the way of starving\r\nmen.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n432.jpg (38K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe passed before the lights of Martin\xe2\x80\x99s restaurant, the most\r\naristocratic in the city, and stopped. It was a place where he had often\r\ndined, in better days, and Martin knew him well. Standing aside, just\r\nout of the range of the light, he worshiped the quails and steaks in the\r\nshow window, and imagined that may be the fairy times were not gone yet\r\nand some prince in disguise would come along presently and tell him to\r\ngo in there and take whatever he wanted. He chewed his stick with a\r\nhungry interest as he warmed to his subject. Just at this juncture he\r\nwas conscious of some one at his side, sure enough; and then a finger\r\ntouched his arm. He looked up, over his shoulder, and saw an\r\napparition\xe2\x80\x94a very allegory of Hunger! It was a man six feet high, gaunt,\r\nunshaven, hung with rags; with a haggard face and sunken cheeks, and\r\neyes that pleaded piteously. This phantom said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me\xe2\x80\x94please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe locked his arm in Blucher\xe2\x80\x99s and walked up the street to where the\r\npassengers were few and the light not strong, and then facing about, put\r\nout his hands in a beseeching way, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend\xe2\x80\x94stranger\xe2\x80\x94look at me! Life is easy to you\xe2\x80\x94you go about, placid\r\nand content, as I did once, in my day\xe2\x80\x94you have been in there, and eaten\r\nyour sumptuous supper, and picked your teeth, and hummed your tune, and\r\nthought your pleasant thoughts, and said to yourself it is a good\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x94but you\xe2\x80\x99ve never _suffered_! You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what trouble is\xe2\x80\x94you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what misery is\xe2\x80\x94nor hunger! Look at me! Stranger have pity on\r\na poor friendless, homeless dog! As God is my judge, I have not tasted\r\nfood for eight and forty hours!\xe2\x80\x94look in my eyes and see if I lie! Give\r\nme the least trifle in the world to keep me from\r\nstarving\xe2\x80\x94anything\xe2\x80\x94twenty-five cents! Do it, stranger\xe2\x80\x94do it, _please_. It\r\nwill be nothing to you, but life to me. Do it, and I will go down on my\r\nknees and lick the dust before you! I will kiss your footprints\xe2\x80\x94I will\r\nworship the very ground you walk on! Only twenty-five cents! I am\r\nfamishing\xe2\x80\x94perishing\xe2\x80\x94starving by inches! For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake don\xe2\x80\x99t desert me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n433.jpg (71K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBlucher was bewildered\xe2\x80\x94and touched, too\xe2\x80\x94stirred to the depths. He\r\nreflected. Thought again. Then an idea struck him, and he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the outcast\xe2\x80\x99s arm, walked him down to Martin\xe2\x80\x99s restaurant,\r\nseated him at a marble table, placed the bill of fare before him, and\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrder what you want, friend. Charge it to me, Mr. Martin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, Mr. Blucher,\xe2\x80\x9d said Martin.\r\n\r\nThen Blucher stepped back and leaned against the counter and watched the\r\nman stow away cargo after cargo of buckwheat cakes at seventy-five cents\r\na plate; cup after cup of coffee, and porter house steaks worth two\r\ndollars apiece; and when six dollars and a half\xe2\x80\x99s worth of destruction\r\nhad been accomplished, and the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s hunger appeased, Blucher went\r\ndown to French Pete\xe2\x80\x99s, bought a veal cutlet plain, a slice of bread, and\r\nthree radishes, with his dime, and set to and feasted like a king!\r\n\r\nTake the episode all around, it was as odd as any that can be culled\r\nfrom the myriad curiosities of Californian life, perhaps.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LX.\r\n\r\n\r\nBy and by, an old friend of mine, a miner, came down from one of the\r\ndecayed mining camps of Tuolumne, California, and I went back with him.\r\nWe lived in a small cabin on a verdant hillside, and there were not five\r\nother cabins in view over the wide expanse of hill and forest. Yet a\r\nflourishing city of two or three thousand population had occupied this\r\ngrassy dead solitude during the flush times of twelve or fifteen years\r\nbefore, and where our cabin stood had once been the heart of the teeming\r\nhive, the centre of the city. When the mines gave out the town fell into\r\ndecay, and in a few years wholly disappeared\xe2\x80\x94streets, dwellings, shops,\r\neverything\xe2\x80\x94and left no sign. The grassy slopes were as green and smooth\r\nand desolate of life as if they had never been disturbed. The mere\r\nhandful of miners still remaining, had seen the town spring up spread,\r\ngrow and flourish in its pride; and they had seen it sicken and die, and\r\npass away like a dream. With it their hopes had died, and their zest of\r\nlife. They had long ago resigned themselves to their exile, and ceased\r\nto correspond with their distant friends or turn longing eyes toward\r\ntheir early homes. They had accepted banishment, forgotten the world and\r\nbeen forgotten of the world. They were far from telegraphs and\r\nrailroads, and they stood, as it were, in a living grave, dead to the\r\nevents that stirred the globe\xe2\x80\x99s great populations, dead to the common\r\ninterests of men, isolated and outcast from brotherhood with their kind.\r\nIt was the most singular, and almost the most touching and melancholy\r\nexile that fancy can imagine.\xe2\x80\x94One of my associates in this locality, for\r\ntwo or three months, was a man who had had a university education; but\r\nnow for eighteen years he had decayed there by inches, a bearded, rough-\r\nclad, clay-stained miner, and at times, among his sighings and\r\nsoliloquizings, he unconsciously interjected vaguely remembered Latin\r\nand Greek sentences\xe2\x80\x94dead and musty tongues, meet vehicles for the\r\nthoughts of one whose dreams were all of the past, whose life was a\r\nfailure; a tired man, burdened with the present, and indifferent to the\r\nfuture; a man without ties, hopes, interests, waiting for rest and the\r\nend.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n436.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn that one little corner of California is found a species of mining\r\nwhich is seldom or never mentioned in print. It is called \xe2\x80\x9cpocket\r\nmining\xe2\x80\x9d and I am not aware that any of it is done outside of that little\r\ncorner. The gold is not evenly distributed through the surface dirt, as\r\nin ordinary placer mines, but is collected in little spots, and they are\r\nvery wide apart and exceedingly hard to find, but when you do find one\r\nyou reap a rich and sudden harvest. There are not now more than twenty\r\npocket miners in that entire little region. I think I know every one of\r\nthem personally. I have known one of them to hunt patiently about the\r\nhill-sides every day for eight months without finding gold enough to\r\nmake a snuff-box\xe2\x80\x94his grocery bill running up relentlessly all the\r\ntime\xe2\x80\x94and then find a pocket and take out of it two thousand dollars in\r\ntwo dips of his shovel. I have known him to take out three thousand\r\ndollars in two hours, and go and pay up every cent of his indebtedness,\r\nthen enter on a dazzling spree that finished the last of his treasure\r\nbefore the night was gone. And the next day he bought his groceries on\r\ncredit as usual, and shouldered his pan and shovel and went off to the\r\nhills hunting pockets again happy and content. This is the most\r\nfascinating of all the different kinds of mining, and furnishes a very\r\nhandsome percentage of victims to the lunatic asylum.\r\n\r\nPocket hunting is an ingenious process. You take a spadeful of earth\r\nfrom the hill-side and put it in a large tin pan and dissolve and wash\r\nit gradually away till nothing is left but a teaspoonful of fine\r\nsediment. Whatever gold was in that earth has remained, because, being\r\nthe heaviest, it has sought the bottom. Among the sediment you will find\r\nhalf a dozen yellow particles no larger than pin-heads. You are\r\ndelighted. You move off to one side and wash another pan. If you find\r\ngold again, you move to one side further, and wash a third pan. If you\r\nfind _no_ gold this time, you are delighted again, because you know you\r\nare on the right scent.\r\n\r\nYou lay an imaginary plan, shaped like a fan, with its handle up the\r\nhill\xe2\x80\x94for just where the end of the handle is, you argue that the rich\r\ndeposit lies hidden, whose vagrant grains of gold have escaped and been\r\nwashed down the hill, spreading farther and farther apart as they\r\nwandered. And so you proceed up the hill, washing the earth and\r\nnarrowing your lines every time the absence of gold in the pan shows\r\nthat you are outside the spread of the fan; and at last, twenty yards up\r\nthe hill your lines have converged to a point\xe2\x80\x94a single foot from that\r\npoint you cannot find any gold. Your breath comes short and quick, you\r\nare feverish with excitement; the dinner-bell may ring its clapper off,\r\nyou pay no attention; friends may die, weddings transpire, houses burn\r\ndown, they are nothing to you; you sweat and dig and delve with a\r\nfrantic interest\xe2\x80\x94and all at once you strike it! Up comes a spadeful of\r\nearth and quartz that is all lovely with soiled lumps and leaves and\r\nsprays of gold. Sometimes that one spadeful is all\xe2\x80\x94$500. Sometimes the\r\nnest contains $10,000, and it takes you three or four days to get it all\r\nout. The pocket-miners tell of one nest that yielded $60,000 and two men\r\nexhausted it in two weeks, and then sold the ground for $10,000 to a\r\nparty who never got $300 out of it afterward.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n437.jpg (37K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe hogs are good pocket hunters. All the summer they root around the\r\nbushes, and turn up a thousand little piles of dirt, and then the miners\r\nlong for the rains; for the rains beat upon these little piles and wash\r\nthem down and expose the gold, possibly right over a pocket. Two pockets\r\nwere found in this way by the same man in one day. One had $5,000 in it\r\nand the other $8,000. That man could appreciate it, for he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had a\r\ncent for about a year.\r\n\r\nIn Tuolumne lived two miners who used to go to the neighboring village\r\nin the afternoon and return every night with household supplies. Part of\r\nthe distance they traversed a trail, and nearly always sat down to rest\r\non a great boulder that lay beside the path. In the course of thirteen\r\nyears they had worn that boulder tolerably smooth, sitting on it. By and\r\nby two vagrant Mexicans came along and occupied the seat. They began to\r\namuse themselves by chipping off flakes from the boulder with a sledge-\r\nhammer. They examined one of these flakes and found it rich with gold.\r\nThat boulder paid them $800 afterward. But the aggravating circumstance\r\nwas that these \xe2\x80\x9cGreasers\xe2\x80\x9d knew that there must be more gold where that\r\nboulder came from, and so they went panning up the hill and found what\r\nwas probably the richest pocket that region has yet produced. It took\r\nthree months to exhaust it, and it yielded $120,000. The two American\r\nminers who used to sit on the boulder are poor yet, and they take turn\r\nabout in getting up early in the morning to curse those Mexicans\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nwhen it comes down to pure ornamental cursing, the native American is\r\ngifted above the sons of men.\r\n\r\nI have dwelt at some length upon this matter of pocket mining because it\r\nis a subject that is seldom referred to in print, and therefore I judged\r\nthat it would have for the reader that interest which naturally attaches\r\nto novelty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nOne of my comrades there\xe2\x80\x94another of those victims of eighteen years of\r\nunrequited toil and blighted hopes\xe2\x80\x94was one of the gentlest spirits that\r\never bore its patient cross in a weary exile: grave and simple Dick\r\nBaker, pocket-miner of Dead-House Gulch.\xe2\x80\x94He was forty-six, gray as a\r\nrat, earnest, thoughtful, slenderly educated, slouchily dressed and\r\nclay-soiled, but his heart was finer metal than any gold his shovel ever\r\nbrought to light\xe2\x80\x94than any, indeed, that ever was mined or minted.\r\n\r\nWhenever he was out of luck and a little down-hearted, he would fall to\r\nmourning over the loss of a wonderful cat he used to own (for where\r\nwomen and children are not, men of kindly impulses take up with pets,\r\nfor they must love something). And he always spoke of the strange\r\nsagacity of that cat with the air of a man who believed in his secret\r\nheart that there was something human about it\xe2\x80\x94may be even supernatural.\r\n\r\nI heard him talking about this animal once. He said:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n440.jpg (18K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I used to have a cat here, by the name of Tom Quartz, which\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d a took an interest in I reckon\xe2\x80\x94most any body would. I had him here\r\neight year\xe2\x80\x94and he was the remarkablest cat _I_ ever see. He was a large\r\ngray one of the Tom specie, an\xe2\x80\x99 he had more hard, natchral sense than\r\nany man in this camp\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 a _power_ of dignity\xe2\x80\x94he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let the\r\nGov\xe2\x80\x99ner of Californy be familiar with him. He never ketched a rat in his\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99peared to be above it. He never cared for nothing but mining. He\r\nknowed more about mining, that cat did, than any man _I_ ever, ever see.\r\nYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell _him_ noth\xe2\x80\x99n \xe2\x80\x99bout placer diggin\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 as for pocket\r\nmining, why he was just born for it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would dig out after me an\xe2\x80\x99 Jim when we went over the hills\r\nprospect\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99, and he would trot along behind us for as much as five mile,\r\nif we went so fur. An\xe2\x80\x99 he had the best judgment about mining ground\xe2\x80\x94why\r\nyou never see anything like it. When we went to work, he\xe2\x80\x99d scatter a\r\nglance around, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t think much of the indications, he would\r\ngive a look as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x98Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to get you to excuse\r\n_me_,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 without another word he\xe2\x80\x99d hyste his nose into the air \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99\r\nshove for home. But if the ground suited him, he would lay low \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 keep\r\ndark till the first pan was washed, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 then he would sidle up \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 take\r\na look, an\xe2\x80\x99 if there was about six or seven grains of gold _he_ was\r\nsatisfied\xe2\x80\x94he didn\xe2\x80\x99t want no better prospect \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 then he would\r\nlay down on our coats and snore like a steamboat till we\xe2\x80\x99d struck the\r\npocket, an\xe2\x80\x99 then get up \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 superintend. He was nearly lightnin\xe2\x80\x99 on\r\nsuperintending.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, bye an\xe2\x80\x99 bye, up comes this yer quartz excitement. Every body was\r\ninto it\xe2\x80\x94every body was pick\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 blast\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 instead of shovelin\xe2\x80\x99 dirt on\r\nthe hill side\xe2\x80\x94every body was put\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 down a shaft instead of scrapin\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nsurface. We commenced put\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 down a shaft, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 Tom Quartz he begin to\r\nwonder what in the Dickens it was all about. He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t ever seen any\r\nmining like that before, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 he was all upset, as you may say\xe2\x80\x94he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come to a right understanding of it no way\xe2\x80\x94it was too many for\r\n_him_. An\xe2\x80\x99 then we lit the\r\nfuse \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 clumb out \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 got off \xe2\x80\x99bout fifty yards\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 forgot \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 left Tom\r\nQuartz sound asleep on the gunny sack.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n441.jpg (89K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn \xe2\x80\x99bout a minute we seen a puff of smoke bust up out of the hole, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthen everything let go with an awful crash, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 about four million ton\r\nof rocks \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 dirt \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 smoke \xe2\x80\x99n; splinters shot up \xe2\x80\x99bout a mile an\xe2\x80\x99 a\r\nhalf into the air, an\xe2\x80\x99 by George, right in the dead centre of it was old\r\nTom Quartz a goin\xe2\x80\x99 end over end, an\xe2\x80\x99 a snortin\xe2\x80\x99 an\xe2\x80\x99 a sneez\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99, an\xe2\x80\x99 a\r\nclawin\xe2\x80\x99 an\xe2\x80\x99 a reachin\xe2\x80\x99 for things like all possessed. But it warn\xe2\x80\x99t no\r\nuse, you know, it warn\xe2\x80\x99t no use. An\xe2\x80\x99 that was the last we see of _him_\r\nfor about two minutes \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 a half, an\xe2\x80\x99 then all of a sudden it begin to\r\nrain rocks and rubbage, an\xe2\x80\x99 directly he come down ker-whop about ten\r\nfoot off f\xe2\x80\x99m where we stood Well, I reckon he was p\xe2\x80\x99raps the orneriest\r\nlookin\xe2\x80\x99 beast you ever see. One ear was sot back on his neck, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 his\r\ntail was stove up, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 his eye-winkers was swinged off, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 he was all\r\nblacked up with powder an\xe2\x80\x99 smoke, an\xe2\x80\x99 all sloppy with mud \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 slush f\xe2\x80\x99m\r\none end to the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell sir, it warn\xe2\x80\x99t no use to try to apologize\xe2\x80\x94we couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say a word.\r\nHe took a sort of a disgusted look at hisself, \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 then he looked at\r\nus\xe2\x80\x94an\xe2\x80\x99 it was just exactly the same as if he had said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99Gents, may be\r\n_you_ think it\xe2\x80\x99s smart to take advantage of a cat that \xe2\x80\x99ain\xe2\x80\x99t had no\r\nexperience of quartz minin\xe2\x80\x99, but _I_ think _different_\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94an\xe2\x80\x99 then he\r\nturned on his heel \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 marched off home without ever saying another\r\nword.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n442.jpg (16K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was jest his style. An\xe2\x80\x99 may be you won\xe2\x80\x99t believe it, but after\r\nthat you never see a cat so prejudiced agin quartz mining as what he\r\nwas. An\xe2\x80\x99 by an\xe2\x80\x99 bye when he _did_ get to goin\xe2\x80\x99 down in the shaft agin,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d \xe2\x80\x99a been astonished at his sagacity. The minute we\xe2\x80\x99d tetch off a\r\nblast \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 the fuse\xe2\x80\x99d begin to sizzle, he\xe2\x80\x99d give a look as much as to\r\nsay: \xe2\x80\x99Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to git you to excuse _me_,\xe2\x80\x99 an\xe2\x80\x99 it was surpris\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe way he\xe2\x80\x99d shin out of that hole \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 go f\xe2\x80\x99r a tree. Sagacity? It ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nno name for it. \xe2\x80\x99Twas _inspiration_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mr. Baker, his prejudice against quartz-mining _was_\r\nremarkable, considering how he came by it. Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t you ever cure him of\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Cure him!_ No! When Tom Quartz was sot once, he was _always_ sot\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nyou might a blowed him up as much as three million times \xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 you\xe2\x80\x99d never\r\na broken him of his cussed prejudice agin quartz mining.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe affection and the pride that lit up Baker\xe2\x80\x99s face when he delivered\r\nthis tribute to the firmness of his humble friend of other days, will\r\nalways be a vivid memory with me.\r\n\r\nAt the end of two months we had never \xe2\x80\x9cstruck\xe2\x80\x9d a pocket. We had panned\r\nup and down the hillsides till they looked plowed like a field; we could\r\nhave put in a crop of grain, then, but there would have been no way to\r\nget it to market. We got many good \xe2\x80\x9cprospects,\xe2\x80\x9d but when the gold gave\r\nout in the pan and we dug down, hoping and longing, we found only\r\nemptiness\xe2\x80\x94the pocket that should have been there was as barren as our\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x94At last we shouldered our pans and shovels and struck out over the\r\nhills to try new localities. We prospected around Angel\xe2\x80\x99s Camp, in\r\nCalaveras county, during three weeks, but had no success. Then we\r\nwandered on foot among the mountains, sleeping under the trees at night,\r\nfor the weather was mild, but still we remained as centless as the last\r\nrose of summer. That is a poor joke, but it is in pathetic harmony with\r\nthe circumstances, since we were so poor ourselves. In accordance with\r\nthe custom of the country, our door had always stood open and our board\r\nwelcome to tramping miners\xe2\x80\x94they drifted along nearly every day, dumped\r\ntheir paust shovels by the threshold and took \xe2\x80\x9cpot luck\xe2\x80\x9d with us\xe2\x80\x94and now\r\non our own tramp we never found cold hospitality.\r\n\r\nOur wanderings were wide and in many directions; and now I could give\r\nthe reader a vivid description of the Big Trees and the marvels of the\r\nYo Semite\xe2\x80\x94but what has this reader done to me that I should persecute\r\nhim? I will deliver him into the hands of less conscientious tourists\r\nand take his blessing. Let me be charitable, though I fail in all\r\nvirtues else.\r\n\r\nNote: Some of the phrases in the above are mining technicalities,\r\npurely, and may be a little obscure to the general reader. In \xe2\x80\x9cplacer\r\ndiggings\xe2\x80\x9d the gold is scattered all through the surface dirt; in\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpocket\xe2\x80\x9d diggings it is concentrated in one little spot; in \xe2\x80\x9cquartz\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\ngold is in a solid, continuous vein of rock, enclosed between distinct\r\nwalls of some other kind of stone\xe2\x80\x94and this is the most laborious and\r\nexpensive of all the different kinds of mining. \xe2\x80\x9cProspecting\xe2\x80\x9d is hunting\r\nfor a \xe2\x80\x9cplacer\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cindications\xe2\x80\x9d are signs of its presence; \xe2\x80\x9cpanning out\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nrefers to the washing process by which the grains of gold are separated\r\nfrom the dirt; a \xe2\x80\x9cprospect\xe2\x80\x9d is what one finds in the first panful of\r\ndirt\xe2\x80\x94and its value determines whether it is a good or a bad prospect,\r\nand whether it is worth while to tarry there or seek further.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter a three months\xe2\x80\x99 absence, I found myself in San Francisco again,\r\nwithout a cent. When my credit was about exhausted, (for I had become\r\ntoo mean and lazy, now, to work on a morning paper, and there were no\r\nvacancies on the evening journals,) I was created San Francisco\r\ncorrespondent of the _Enterprise_, and at the end of five months I was\r\nout of debt, but my interest in my work was gone; for my correspondence\r\nbeing a daily one, without rest or respite, I got unspeakably tired of\r\nit. I wanted another change. The vagabond instinct was strong upon me.\r\nFortune favored and I got a new berth and a delightful one. It was to go\r\ndown to the Sandwich Islands and write some letters for the Sacramento\r\n_Union_, an excellent journal and liberal with employees.\r\n\r\nWe sailed in the propeller _Ajax_, in the middle of winter. The almanac\r\ncalled it winter, distinctly enough, but the weather was a compromise\r\nbetween spring and summer. Six days out of port, it became summer\r\naltogether. We had some thirty passengers; among them a cheerful soul by\r\nthe name of Williams, and three sea-worn old whaleship captains going\r\ndown to join their vessels. These latter played euchre in the smoking\r\nroom day and night, drank astonishing quantities of raw whisky without\r\nbeing in the least affected by it, and were the happiest people I think\r\nI ever saw. And then there was \xe2\x80\x9cthe old Admiral\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d a retired whaleman. He\r\nwas a roaring, terrific combination of wind and lightning and thunder,\r\nand earnest, whole-souled profanity. But nevertheless he was tender-\r\nhearted as a girl. He was a raving, deafening, devastating typhoon,\r\nlaying waste the cowering seas but with an unvexed refuge in the centre\r\nwhere all comers were safe and at rest. Nobody could know the \xe2\x80\x9cAdmiral\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwithout liking him; and in a sudden and dire emergency I think no friend\r\nof his would know which to choose\xe2\x80\x94to be cursed by him or prayed for by a\r\nless efficient person.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n445.jpg (65K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHis Title of \xe2\x80\x9cAdmiral\xe2\x80\x9d was more strictly \xe2\x80\x9cofficial\xe2\x80\x9d than any ever worn\r\nby a naval officer before or since, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94for it was the voluntary\r\noffering of a whole nation, and came direct from the _people_ themselves\r\nwithout any intermediate red tape\xe2\x80\x94the people of the Sandwich Islands. It\r\nwas a title that came to him freighted with affection, and honor, and\r\nappreciation of his unpretending merit. And in testimony of the\r\ngenuineness of the title it was publicly ordained that an exclusive flag\r\nshould be devised for him and used solely to welcome his coming and wave\r\nhim God-speed in his going. From that time forth, whenever his ship was\r\nsignaled in the offing, or he catted his anchor and stood out to sea,\r\nthat ensign streamed from the royal halliards on the parliament house\r\nand the nation lifted their hats to it with spontaneous accord.\r\n\r\nYet he had never fired a gun or fought a battle in his life. When I knew\r\nhim on board the _Ajax_, he was seventy-two years old and had plowed the\r\nsalt water sixty-one of them. For sixteen years he had gone in and out\r\nof the harbor of Honolulu in command of a whaleship, and for sixteen\r\nmore had been captain of a San Francisco and Sandwich Island passenger\r\npacket and had never had an accident or lost a vessel. The simple\r\nnatives knew him for a friend who never failed them, and regarded him as\r\nchildren regard a father. It was a dangerous thing to oppress them when\r\nthe roaring Admiral was around.\r\n\r\nTwo years before I knew the Admiral, he had retired from the sea on a\r\ncompetence, and had sworn a colossal nine-jointed oath that he would\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnever go within _smelling_ distance of the salt water again as long as\r\nhe lived.\xe2\x80\x9d And he had conscientiously kept it. That is to say, _he_\r\nconsidered he had kept it, and it would have been more than dangerous to\r\nsuggest to him, even in the gentlest way, that making eleven long sea\r\nvoyages, as a passenger, during the two years that had transpired since\r\nhe \xe2\x80\x9cretired,\xe2\x80\x9d was only keeping the general spirit of it and not the\r\nstrict letter.\r\n\r\nThe Admiral knew only one narrow line of conduct to pursue in any and\r\nall cases where there was a fight, and that was to shoulder his way\r\nstraight in without an inquiry as to the rights or the merits of it, and\r\ntake the part of the weaker side.\xe2\x80\x94And this was the reason why he was\r\nalways sure to be present at the trial of any universally execrated\r\ncriminal to oppress and intimidate the jury with a vindictive pantomime\r\nof what he would do to them if he ever caught them out of the box. And\r\nthis was why harried cats and outlawed dogs that knew him confidently\r\ntook sanctuary under his chair in time of trouble. In the beginning he\r\nwas the most frantic and bloodthirsty Union man that drew breath in the\r\nshadow of the Flag; but the instant the Southerners began to go down\r\nbefore the sweep of the Northern armies, he ran up the Confederate\r\ncolors and from that time till the end was a rampant and inexorable\r\nsecessionist.\r\n\r\nHe hated intemperance with a more uncompromising animosity than any\r\nindividual I have ever met, of either sex; and he was never tired of\r\nstorming against it and beseeching friends and strangers alike to be\r\nwary and drink with moderation. And yet if any creature had been\r\nguileless enough to intimate that his absorbing nine gallons of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cstraight\xe2\x80\x9d whiskey during our voyage was any fraction short of rigid or\r\ninflexible abstemiousness, in that self-same moment the old man would\r\nhave spun him to the uttermost parts of the earth in the whirlwind of\r\nhis wrath. Mind, I am not saying his whisky ever affected his head or\r\nhis legs, for it did not, in even the slightest degree. He was a\r\ncapacious container, but he did not hold enough for that. He took a\r\nlevel tumblerful of whisky every morning before he put his clothes\r\non\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cto sweeten his bilgewater,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\xe2\x80\x94He took another after he got\r\nthe most of his clothes on, \xe2\x80\x9cto settle his mind and give him his\r\nbearings.\xe2\x80\x9d He then shaved, and put on a clean shirt; after which he\r\nrecited the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s Prayer in a fervent, thundering bass that shook the\r\nship to her kelson and suspended all conversation in the main cabin.\r\nThen, at this stage, being invariably \xe2\x80\x9cby the head,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cby the stern,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor \xe2\x80\x9clisted to port or starboard,\xe2\x80\x9d he took one more to \xe2\x80\x9cput him on an\r\neven keel so that he would mind his hellum and not miss stays and go\r\nabout, every time he came up in the wind.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And now, his state-room door\r\nswung open and the sun of his benignant face beamed redly out upon men\r\nand women and children, and he roared his \xe2\x80\x9cShipmets a\xe2\x80\x99hoy!\xe2\x80\x9d in a way\r\nthat was calculated to wake the dead and precipitate the final\r\nresurrection; and forth he strode, a picture to look at and a presence\r\nto enforce attention. Stalwart and portly; not a gray hair; broadbrimmed\r\nslouch hat; semi-sailor toggery of blue navy flannel\xe2\x80\x94roomy and ample; a\r\nstately expanse of shirt-front and a liberal amount of black silk neck-\r\ncloth tied with a sailor knot; large chain and imposing seals impending\r\nfrom his fob; awe-inspiring feet, and \xe2\x80\x9ca hand like the hand of\r\nProvidence,\xe2\x80\x9d as his whaling brethren expressed it; wrist-bands and\r\nsleeves pushed back half way to the elbow, out of respect for the warm\r\nweather, and exposing hairy arms, gaudy with red and blue anchors,\r\nships, and goddesses of liberty tattooed in India ink. But these details\r\nwere only secondary matters\xe2\x80\x94his face was the lodestone that chained the\r\neye. It was a sultry disk, glowing determinedly out through a weather\r\nbeaten mask of mahogany, and studded with warts, seamed with scars,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cblazed\xe2\x80\x9d all over with unfailing fresh slips of the razor; and with\r\ncheery eyes, under shaggy brows, contemplating the world from over the\r\nback of a gnarled crag of a nose that loomed vast and lonely out of the\r\nundulating immensity that spread away from its foundations. At his heels\r\nfrisked the darling of his bachelor estate, his terrier \xe2\x80\x9cFan,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\ncreature no larger than a squirrel. The main part of his daily life was\r\noccupied in looking after \xe2\x80\x9cFan,\xe2\x80\x9d in a motherly way, and doctoring her\r\nfor a hundred ailments which existed only in his imagination.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n448.jpg (48K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Admiral seldom read newspapers; and when he did he never believed\r\nanything they said. He read nothing, and believed in nothing, but \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nOld Guard,\xe2\x80\x9d a secession periodical published in New York. He carried a\r\ndozen copies of it with him, always, and referred to them for all\r\nrequired information. If it was not there, he supplied it himself, out\r\nof a bountiful fancy, inventing history, names, dates, and every thing\r\nelse necessary to make his point good in an argument. Consequently he\r\nwas a formidable antagonist in a dispute. Whenever he swung clear of the\r\nrecord and began to create history, the enemy was helpless and had to\r\nsurrender. Indeed, the enemy could not keep from betraying some little\r\nspark of indignation at his manufactured history\xe2\x80\x94and when it came to\r\nindignation, that was the Admiral\xe2\x80\x99s very \xe2\x80\x9cbest hold.\xe2\x80\x9d He was always\r\nready for a political argument, and if nobody started one he would do it\r\nhimself. With his third retort his temper would begin to rise, and\r\nwithin five minutes he would be blowing a gale, and within fifteen his\r\nsmoking-room audience would be utterly stormed away and the old man left\r\nsolitary and alone, banging the table with his fist, kicking the chairs,\r\nand roaring a hurricane of profanity. It got so, after a while, that\r\nwhenever the Admiral approached, with politics in his eye, the\r\npassengers would drop out with quiet accord, afraid to meet him; and he\r\nwould camp on a deserted field.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n449.jpg (34K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut he found his match at last, and before a full company. At one time\r\nor another, everybody had entered the lists against him and been routed,\r\nexcept the quiet passenger Williams. He had never been able to get an\r\nexpression of opinion out of him on politics. But now, just as the\r\nAdmiral drew near the door and the company were about to slip out,\r\nWilliams said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmiral, are you _certain_ about that circumstance concerning the\r\nclergymen you mentioned the other day?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94referring to a piece of the\r\nAdmiral\xe2\x80\x99s manufactured history.\r\n\r\nEvery one was amazed at the man\xe2\x80\x99s rashness. The idea of deliberately\r\ninviting annihilation was a thing incomprehensible. The retreat came to\r\na halt; then everybody sat down again wondering, to await the upshot of\r\nit. The Admiral himself was as surprised as any one. He paused in the\r\ndoor, with his red handkerchief half raised to his sweating face, and\r\ncontemplated the daring reptile in the corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Certain_ of it? Am I _certain_ of it? Do you think I\xe2\x80\x99ve been lying\r\nabout it? What do you take me for? Anybody that don\xe2\x80\x99t know that\r\ncircumstance, don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything; a child ought to know it. Read up\r\nyour history! Read it up\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94, and don\xe2\x80\x99t come asking a man if he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n_certain_ about a bit of ABC stuff that the very southern niggers know\r\nall about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the Admiral\xe2\x80\x99s fires began to wax hot, the atmosphere thickened, the\r\ncoming earthquake rumbled, he began to thunder and lighten. Within three\r\nminutes his volcano was in full irruption and he was discharging flames\r\nand ashes of indignation, belching black volumes of foul history aloft,\r\nand vomiting red-hot torrents of profanity from his crater. Meantime\r\nWilliams sat silent, and apparently deeply and earnestly interested in\r\nwhat the old man was saying. By and by, when the lull came, he said in\r\nthe most deferential way, and with the gratified air of a man who has\r\nhad a mystery cleared up which had been puzzling him uncomfortably:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Now_ I understand it. I always thought I knew that piece of history\r\nwell enough, but was still afraid to trust it, because there was not\r\nthat convincing particularity about it that one likes to have in\r\nhistory; but when you mentioned every name, the other day, and every\r\ndate, and every little circumstance, in their just order and sequence, I\r\nsaid to myself, _this_ sounds something like\xe2\x80\x94_this_ is history\xe2\x80\x94_this_ is\r\nputting it in a shape that gives a man confidence; and I said to myself\r\nafterward, I will just ask the Admiral if he is perfectly certain about\r\nthe details, and if he is I will come out and thank him for clearing\r\nthis matter up for me. And that is what I want to do now\xe2\x80\x94for until you\r\nset that matter right it was nothing but just a confusion in my mind,\r\nwithout head or tail to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNobody ever saw the Admiral look so mollified before, and so pleased.\r\nNobody had ever received his bogus history as gospel before; its\r\ngenuineness had always been called in question either by words or looks;\r\nbut here was a man that not only swallowed it all down, but was grateful\r\nfor the dose. He was taken a back; he hardly knew what to say; even his\r\nprofanity failed him. Now, Williams continued, modestly and earnestly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Admiral, in saying that this was the first stone thrown, and that\r\nthis precipitated the war, you have overlooked a circumstance which you\r\nare perfectly familiar with, but which has escaped your memory. Now I\r\ngrant you that what you have stated is correct in every detail\xe2\x80\x94to wit:\r\nthat on the 16th of October, 1860, two Massachusetts clergymen, named\r\nWaite and Granger, went in disguise to the house of John Moody, in\r\nRockport, at dead of night, and dragged forth two southern women and\r\ntheir two little children, and after tarring and feathering them\r\nconveyed them to Boston and burned them alive in the State House square;\r\nand I also grant your proposition that this deed is what led to the\r\nsecession of South Carolina on the 20th of December following. Very\r\nwell.\xe2\x80\x9d [Here the company were pleasantly surprised to hear Williams\r\nproceed to come back at the Admiral with his own invincible\r\nweapon\xe2\x80\x94clean, pure, _manufactured history_, without a word of truth in\r\nit.] \xe2\x80\x9cVery well, I say. But Admiral, why overlook the Willis and Morgan\r\ncase in South Carolina? You are too well informed a man not to know all\r\nabout that circumstance. Your arguments and your conversations have\r\nshown you to be intimately conversant with every detail of this national\r\nquarrel. You develop matters of history every day that show plainly that\r\nyou are no smatterer in it, content to nibble about the surface, but a\r\nman who has searched the depths and possessed yourself of everything\r\nthat has a bearing upon the great question. Therefore, let me just\r\nrecall to your mind that Willis and Morgan case\xe2\x80\x94though I see by your\r\nface that the whole thing is already passing through your memory at this\r\nmoment. On the 12th of August, 1860, _two months_ before the Waite and\r\nGranger affair, two South Carolina clergymen, named John H. Morgan and\r\nWinthrop L. Willis, one a Methodist and the other an Old School Baptist,\r\ndisguised themselves, and went at midnight to the house of a planter\r\nnamed Thompson\xe2\x80\x94Archibald F. Thompson, Vice President under Thomas\r\nJefferson,\xe2\x80\x94and took thence, at midnight, his widowed aunt, (a Northern\r\nwoman,) and her adopted child, an orphan named Mortimer Highie,\r\nafflicted with epilepsy and suffering at the time from white swelling on\r\none of his legs, and compelled to walk on crutches in consequence; and\r\nthe two ministers, in spite of the pleadings of the victims, dragged\r\nthem to the bush, tarred and feathered them, and afterward burned them\r\nat the stake in the city of Charleston. You remember perfectly well what\r\na stir it made; you remember perfectly well that even the Charleston\r\n_Courier_ stigmatized the act as being unpleasant, of questionable\r\npropriety, and scarcely justifiable, and likewise that it would not be\r\nmatter of surprise if retaliation ensued. And you remember also, that\r\nthis thing was the _cause_ of the Massachusetts outrage. Who, indeed,\r\nwere the two Massachusetts ministers? and who were the two Southern\r\nwomen they burned? I do not need to remind _you_, Admiral, with your\r\nintimate knowledge of history, that Waite was the nephew of the woman\r\nburned in Charleston; that Granger was her cousin in the second degree,\r\nand that the woman they burned in Boston was the wife of John H. Morgan,\r\nand the still loved but divorced wife of Winthrop L. Willis. Now,\r\nAdmiral, it is only fair that you should acknowledge that the first\r\nprovocation came from the Southern preachers and that the Northern ones\r\nwere justified in retaliating. In your arguments you never yet have\r\nshown the least disposition to withhold a just verdict or be in anywise\r\nunfair, when authoritative history condemned your position, and\r\ntherefore I have no hesitation in asking you to take the original blame\r\nfrom the Massachusetts ministers, in this matter, and transfer it to the\r\nSouth Carolina clergymen where it justly belongs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n453.jpg (44K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Admiral was conquered. This sweet spoken creature who swallowed his\r\nfraudulent history as if it were the bread of life; basked in his\r\nfurious blasphemy as if it were generous sunshine; found only calm,\r\neven-handed justice in his rampart partisanship; and flooded him with\r\ninvented history so sugarcoated with flattery and deference that there\r\nwas no rejecting it, was \xe2\x80\x9ctoo many\xe2\x80\x9d for him. He stammered some awkward,\r\nprofane sentences about the\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94Willis and Morgan business having\r\nescaped his memory, but that he \xe2\x80\x9cremembered it now,\xe2\x80\x9d and then, under\r\npretence of giving Fan some medicine for an imaginary cough, drew out of\r\nthe battle and went away, a vanquished man. Then cheers and laughter\r\nwent up, and Williams, the ship\xe2\x80\x99s benefactor was a hero. The news went\r\nabout the vessel, champagne was ordered, and enthusiastic reception\r\ninstituted in the smoking room, and everybody flocked thither to shake\r\nhands with the conqueror. The wheelman said afterward, that the Admiral\r\nstood up behind the pilot house and \xe2\x80\x9cripped and cursed all to himself\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ntill he loosened the smokestack guys and becalmed the mainsail.\r\n\r\nThe Admiral\xe2\x80\x99s power was broken. After that, if he began argument,\r\nsomebody would bring Williams, and the old man would grow weak and begin\r\nto quiet down at once. And as soon as he was done, Williams in his\r\ndulcet, insinuating way, would invent some history (referring for proof,\r\nto the old man\xe2\x80\x99s own excellent memory and to copies of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Old Guard\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nknown not to be in his possession) that would turn the tables completely\r\nand leave the Admiral all abroad and helpless. By and by he came to so\r\ndread Williams and his gilded tongue that he would stop talking when he\r\nsaw him approach, and finally ceased to mention politics altogether, and\r\nfrom that time forward there was entire peace and serenity in the ship.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn a certain bright morning the Islands hove in sight, lying low on the\r\nlonely sea, and everybody climbed to the upper deck to look. After two\r\nthousand miles of watery solitude the vision was a welcome one. As we\r\napproached, the imposing promontory of Diamond Head rose up out of the\r\nocean its rugged front softened by the hazy distance, and presently the\r\ndetails of the land began to make themselves manifest: first the line of\r\nbeach; then the plumed coacoanut trees of the tropics; then cabins of\r\nthe natives; then the white town of Honolulu, said to contain between\r\ntwelve and fifteen thousand inhabitants spread over a dead level; with\r\nstreets from twenty to thirty feet wide, solid and level as a floor,\r\nmost of them straight as a line and few as crooked as a corkscrew.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n455.jpg (98K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe further I traveled through the town the better I liked it. Every\r\nstep revealed a new contrast\xe2\x80\x94disclosed something I was unaccustomed to.\r\nIn place of the grand mud-colored brown fronts of San Francisco, I saw\r\ndwellings built of straw, adobies, and cream-colored pebble-and-shell-\r\nconglomerated coral, cut into oblong blocks and laid in cement; also a\r\ngreat number of neat white cottages, with green window-shutters; in\r\nplace of front yards like billiard-tables with iron fences around them,\r\nI saw these homes surrounded by ample yards, thickly clad with green\r\ngrass, and shaded by tall trees, through whose dense foliage the sun\r\ncould scarcely penetrate; in place of the customary geranium, calla\r\nlily, etc., languishing in dust and general debility, I saw luxurious\r\nbanks and thickets of flowers, fresh as a meadow after a rain, and\r\nglowing with the richest dyes; in place of the dingy horrors of San\r\nFrancisco\xe2\x80\x99s pleasure grove, the \xe2\x80\x9cWillows,\xe2\x80\x9d I saw huge-bodied, wide-\r\nspreading forest trees, with strange names and stranger appearance\xe2\x80\x94trees\r\nthat cast a shadow like a thunder-cloud, and were able to stand alone\r\nwithout being tied to green poles; in place of gold fish, wiggling\r\naround in glass globes, assuming countless shades and degrees of\r\ndistortion through the magnifying and diminishing qualities of their\r\ntransparent prison houses, I saw cats\xe2\x80\x94Tom-cats, Mary Ann cats, long-\r\ntailed cats, bob-tailed cats, blind cats, one-eyed cats, wall-eyed cats,\r\ncross-eyed cats, gray cats, black cats, white cats, yellow cats, striped\r\ncats, spotted cats, tame cats, wild cats, singed cats, individual cats,\r\ngroups of cats, platoons of cats, companies of cats, regiments of cats,\r\narmies of cats, multitudes of cats, millions of cats, and all of them\r\nsleek, fat, lazy and sound asleep. I looked on a multitude of people,\r\nsome white, in white coats, vests, pantaloons, even white cloth shoes,\r\nmade snowy with chalk duly laid on every morning; but the majority of\r\nthe people were almost as dark as negroes\xe2\x80\x94women with comely features,\r\nfine black eyes, rounded forms, inclining to the voluptuous, clad in a\r\nsingle bright red or white garment that fell free and unconfined from\r\nshoulder to heel, long black hair falling loose, gypsy hats, encircled\r\nwith wreaths of natural flowers of a brilliant carmine tint; plenty of\r\ndark men in various costumes, and some with nothing on but a battered\r\nstove-pipe hat tilted on the nose, and a very scant breech-\r\nclout;\xe2\x80\x94certain smoke-dried children were clothed in nothing but\r\nsunshine\xe2\x80\x94a very neat fitting and picturesque apparel indeed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n456.jpg (25K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn place of roughs and rowdies staring and blackguarding on the corners,\r\nI saw long-haired, saddle-colored Sandwich Island maidens sitting on the\r\nground in the shade of corner houses, gazing indolently at whatever or\r\nwhoever happened along; instead of wretched cobble-stone pavements, I\r\nwalked on a firm foundation of coral, built up from the bottom of the\r\nsea by the absurd but persevering insect of that name, with a light\r\nlayer of lava and cinders overlying the coral, belched up out of\r\nfathomless perdition long ago through the seared and blackened crater\r\nthat stands dead and harmless in the distance now; instead of cramped\r\nand crowded street-cars, I met dusky native women sweeping by, free as\r\nthe wind, on fleet horses and astride, with gaudy riding-sashes,\r\nstreaming like banners behind them; instead of the combined stenches of\r\nChinadom and Brannan street slaughter-houses, I breathed the balmy\r\nfragrance of jessamine, oleander, and the Pride of India; in place of\r\nthe hurry and bustle and noisy confusion of San Francisco, I moved in\r\nthe midst of a Summer calm as tranquil as dawn in the Garden of Eden; in\r\nplace of the Golden City\xe2\x80\x99s skirting sand hills and the placid bay, I saw\r\non the one side a frame-work of tall, precipitous mountains close at\r\nhand, clad in refreshing green, and cleft by deep, cool, chasm-like\r\nvalleys\xe2\x80\x94and in front the grand sweep of the ocean: a brilliant,\r\ntransparent green near the shore, bound and bordered by a long white\r\nline of foamy spray dashing against the reef, and further out the dead\r\nblue water of the deep sea, flecked with \xe2\x80\x9cwhite caps,\xe2\x80\x9d and in the far\r\nhorizon a single, lonely sail\xe2\x80\x94a mere accent-mark to emphasize a\r\nslumberous calm and a solitude that were without sound or limit. When\r\nthe sun sunk down\xe2\x80\x94the one intruder from other realms and persistent in\r\nsuggestions of them\xe2\x80\x94it was tranced luxury to sit in the perfumed air and\r\nforget that there was any world but these enchanted islands.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n457.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was such ecstacy to dream, and dream\xe2\x80\x94till you got a bite. A scorpion\r\nbite. Then the first duty was to get up out of the grass and kill the\r\nscorpion; and the next to bathe the bitten place with alcohol or brandy;\r\nand the next to resolve to keep out of the grass in future. Then came an\r\nadjournment to the bed-chamber and the pastime of writing up the day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njournal with one hand and the destruction of mosquitoes with the other\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nwhole community of them at a slap. Then, observing an enemy\r\napproaching,\xe2\x80\x94a hairy tarantula on stilts\xe2\x80\x94why not set the spittoon on\r\nhim? It is done, and the projecting ends of his paws give a luminous\r\nidea of the magnitude of his reach. Then to bed and become a promenade\r\nfor a centipede with forty-two legs on a side and every foot hot enough\r\nto burn a hole through a raw-hide. More soaking with alcohol, and a\r\nresolution to examine the bed before entering it, in future. Then wait,\r\nand suffer, till all the mosquitoes in the neighborhood have crawled in\r\nunder the bar, then slip out quickly, shut them in and sleep peacefully\r\non the floor till morning. Meantime it is comforting to curse the\r\ntropics in occasional wakeful intervals.\r\n\r\nWe had an abundance of fruit in Honolulu, of course. Oranges, pine-\r\napples, bananas, strawberries, lemons, limes, mangoes, guavas, melons,\r\nand a rare and curious luxury called the chirimoya, which is\r\ndeliciousness itself. Then there is the tamarind. I thought tamarinds\r\nwere made to eat, but that was probably not the idea. I ate several, and\r\nit seemed to me that they were rather sour that year. They pursed up my\r\nlips, till they resembled the stem-end of a tomato, and I had to take my\r\nsustenance through a quill for twenty-four hours.\r\n\r\nThey sharpened my teeth till I could have shaved with them, and gave\r\nthem a \xe2\x80\x9cwire edge\xe2\x80\x9d that I was afraid would stay; but a citizen said \xe2\x80\x9cno,\r\nit will come off when the enamel does\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which was comforting, at any\r\nrate. I found, afterward, that only strangers eat tamarinds\xe2\x80\x94but they\r\nonly eat them once.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n458.jpg (145K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn my diary of our third day in Honolulu, I find this:\r\n\r\nI am probably the most sensitive man in Hawaii to-night\xe2\x80\x94especially about\r\nsitting down in the presence of my betters. I have ridden fifteen or\r\ntwenty miles on horse-back since 5 P.M. and to tell the honest truth, I\r\nhave a delicacy about sitting down at all.\r\n\r\nAn excursion to Diamond Head and the King\xe2\x80\x99s Coacoanut Grove was planned\r\nto-day\xe2\x80\x94time, 4:30 P.M.\xe2\x80\x94the party to consist of half a dozen gentlemen\r\nand three ladies. They all started at the appointed hour except myself.\r\nI was at the Government prison, (with Captain Fish and another\r\nwhaleship-skipper, Captain Phillips,) and got so interested in its\r\nexamination that I did not notice how quickly the time was passing.\r\nSomebody remarked that it was twenty minutes past five o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and that\r\nwoke me up. It was a fortunate circumstance that Captain Phillips was\r\nalong with his \xe2\x80\x9cturn out,\xe2\x80\x9d as he calls a top-buggy that Captain Cook\r\nbrought here in 1778, and a horse that was here when Captain Cook came.\r\nCaptain Phillips takes a just pride in his driving and in the speed of\r\nhis horse, and to his passion for displaying them I owe it that we were\r\nonly sixteen minutes coming from the prison to the American Hotel\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndistance which has been estimated to be over half a mile. But it took\r\nsome fearful driving. The Captain\xe2\x80\x99s whip came down fast, and the blows\r\nstarted so much dust out of the horse\xe2\x80\x99s hide that during the last half\r\nof the journey we rode through an impenetrable fog, and ran by a pocket\r\ncompass in the hands of Captain Fish, a whaler of twenty-six years\r\nexperience, who sat there through the perilous voyage as self-possessed\r\nas if he had been on the euchre-deck of his own ship, and calmly said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPort your helm\xe2\x80\x94port,\xe2\x80\x9d from time to time, and \xe2\x80\x9cHold her a little\r\nfree\xe2\x80\x94steady\xe2\x80\x94so\xe2\x80\x94so,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLuff\xe2\x80\x94hard down to starboard!\xe2\x80\x9d and never once\r\nlost his presence of mind or betrayed the least anxiety by voice or\r\nmanner. When we came to anchor at last, and Captain Phillips looked at\r\nhis watch and said, \xe2\x80\x9cSixteen minutes\xe2\x80\x94I told you it was in her! that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nover three miles an hour!\xe2\x80\x9d I could see he felt entitled to a compliment,\r\nand so I said I had never seen lightning go like that horse. And I never\r\nhad.\r\n\r\nThe landlord of the American said the party had been gone nearly an\r\nhour, but that he could give me my choice of several horses that could\r\novertake them. I said, never mind\xe2\x80\x94I preferred a safe horse to a fast\r\none\xe2\x80\x94I would like to have an excessively gentle horse\xe2\x80\x94a horse with no\r\nspirit whatever\xe2\x80\x94a lame one, if he had such a thing. Inside of five\r\nminutes I was mounted, and perfectly satisfied with my outfit. I had no\r\ntime to label him \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a horse,\xe2\x80\x9d and so if the public took him for a\r\nsheep I cannot help it. I was satisfied, and that was the main thing. I\r\ncould see that he had as many fine points as any man\xe2\x80\x99s horse, and so I\r\nhung my hat on one of them, behind the saddle, and swabbed the\r\nperspiration from my face and started. I named him after this island,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOahu\xe2\x80\x9d (pronounced O-waw-hee). The first gate he came to he started in;\r\nI had neither whip nor spur, and so I simply argued the case with him.\r\nHe resisted argument, but ultimately yielded to insult and abuse. He\r\nbacked out of that gate and steered for another one on the other side of\r\nthe street. I triumphed by my former process. Within the next six\r\nhundred yards he crossed the street fourteen times and attempted\r\nthirteen gates, and in the meantime the tropical sun was beating down\r\nand threatening to cave the top of my head in, and I was literally\r\ndripping with perspiration. He abandoned the gate business after that\r\nand went along peaceably enough, but absorbed in meditation. I noticed\r\nthis latter circumstance, and it soon began to fill me with\r\napprehension. I said to my self, this creature is planning some new\r\noutrage, some fresh deviltry or other\xe2\x80\x94no horse ever thought over a\r\nsubject so profoundly as this one is doing just for nothing. The more\r\nthis thing preyed upon my mind the more uneasy I became, until the\r\nsuspense became almost unbearable and I dismounted to see if there was\r\nanything wild in his eye\xe2\x80\x94for I had heard that the eye of this noblest of\r\nour domestic animals is very expressive.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n461.jpg (86K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI cannot describe what a load of anxiety was lifted from my mind when I\r\nfound that he was only asleep. I woke him up and started him into a\r\nfaster walk, and then the villainy of his nature came out again. He\r\ntried to climb over a stone wall, five or six feet high. I saw that I\r\nmust apply force to this horse, and that I might as well begin first as\r\nlast. I plucked a stout switch from a tamarind tree, and the moment he\r\nsaw it, he surrendered. He broke into a convulsive sort of a canter,\r\nwhich had three short steps in it and one long one, and reminded me\r\nalternately of the clattering shake of the great earthquake, and the\r\nsweeping plunging of the _Ajax_ in a storm.\r\n\r\nAnd now there can be no fitter occasion than the present to pronounce a\r\nleft-handed blessing upon the man who invented the American saddle.\r\nThere is no seat to speak of about it\xe2\x80\x94one might as well sit in a\r\nshovel\xe2\x80\x94and the stirrups are nothing but an ornamental nuisance. If I\r\nwere to write down here all the abuse I expended on those stirrups, it\r\nwould make a large book, even without pictures. Sometimes I got one\r\nfoot so far through, that the stirrup partook of the nature of an\r\nanklet; sometimes both feet were through, and I was handcuffed by the\r\nlegs; and sometimes my feet got clear out and left the stirrups wildly\r\ndangling about my shins. Even when I was in proper position and\r\ncarefully balanced upon the balls of my feet, there was no comfort in\r\nit, on account of my nervous dread that they were going to slip one way\r\nor the other in a moment. But the subject is too exasperating to write\r\nabout.\r\n\r\nA mile and a half from town, I came to a grove of tall cocoanut trees,\r\nwith clean, branchless stems reaching straight up sixty or seventy feet\r\nand topped with a spray of green foliage sheltering clusters of cocoa-\r\nnuts\xe2\x80\x94not more picturesque than a forest of collossal ragged parasols,\r\nwith bunches of magnified grapes under them, would be.\r\n\r\nI once heard a gouty northern invalid say that a cocoanut tree might be\r\npoetical, possibly it was; but it looked like a feather-duster struck by\r\nlightning. I think that describes it better than a picture\xe2\x80\x94and yet,\r\nwithout any question, there is something fascinating about a cocoa-nut\r\ntree\xe2\x80\x94and graceful, too.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n462.jpg (29K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout a dozen cottages, some frame and the others of native grass,\r\nnestled sleepily in the shade here and there. The grass cabins are of a\r\ngrayish color, are shaped much like our own cottages, only with higher\r\nand steeper roofs usually, and are made of some kind of weed strongly\r\nbound together in bundles. The roofs are very thick, and so are the\r\nwalls; the latter have square holes in them for windows. At a little\r\ndistance these cabins have a furry appearance, as if they might be made\r\nof bear skins. They are very cool and pleasant inside. The King\xe2\x80\x99s flag\r\nwas flying from the roof of one of the cottages, and His Majesty was\r\nprobably within. He owns the whole concern thereabouts, and passes his\r\ntime there frequently, on sultry days \xe2\x80\x9claying off.\xe2\x80\x9d The spot is called\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe King\xe2\x80\x99s Grove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNear by is an interesting ruin\xe2\x80\x94the meagre remains of an ancient heathen\r\ntemple\xe2\x80\x94a place where human sacrifices were offered up in those old\r\nbygone days when the simple child of nature, yielding momentarily to sin\r\nwhen sorely tempted, acknowledged his error when calm reflection had\r\nshown it him, and came forward with noble frankness and offered up his\r\ngrandmother as an atoning sacrifice\xe2\x80\x94in those old days when the luckless\r\nsinner could keep on cleansing his conscience and achieving periodical\r\nhappiness as long as his relations held out; long, long before the\r\nmissionaries braved a thousand privations to come and make them\r\npermanently miserable by telling them how beautiful and how blissful a\r\nplace heaven is, and how nearly impossible it is to get there; and\r\nshowed the poor native how dreary a place perdition is and what\r\nunnecessarily liberal facilities there are for going to it; showed him\r\nhow, in his ignorance he had gone and fooled away all his kinfolks to no\r\npurpose; showed him what rapture it is to work all day long for fifty\r\ncents to buy food for next day with, as compared with fishing for\r\npastime and lolling in the shade through eternal Summer, and eating of\r\nthe bounty that nobody labored to provide but Nature. How sad it is to\r\nthink of the multitudes who have gone to their graves in this beautiful\r\nisland and never knew there was a hell!\r\n\r\nThis ancient temple was built of rough blocks of lava, and was simply a\r\nroofless inclosure a hundred and thirty feet long and seventy\r\nwide\xe2\x80\x94nothing but naked walls, very thick, but not much higher than a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s head. They will last for ages no doubt, if left unmolested. Its\r\nthree altars and other sacred appurtenances have crumbled and passed\r\naway years ago. It is said that in the old times thousands of human\r\nbeings were slaughtered here, in the presence of naked and howling\r\nsavages. If these mute stones could speak, what tales they could tell,\r\nwhat pictures they could describe, of fettered victims writhing under\r\nthe knife; of massed forms straining forward out of the gloom, with\r\nferocious faces lit up by the sacrificial fires; of the background of\r\nghostly trees; of the dark pyramid of Diamond Head standing sentinel\r\nover the uncanny scene, and the peaceful moon looking down upon it\r\nthrough rifts in the cloud-rack!\r\n\r\nWhen Kamehameha (pronounced Ka-may-ha-may-ah) the Great\xe2\x80\x94who was a sort\r\nof a Napoleon in military genius and uniform success\xe2\x80\x94invaded this island\r\nof Oahu three quarters of a century ago, and exterminated the army sent\r\nto oppose him, and took full and final possession of the country, he\r\nsearched out the dead body of the King of Oahu, and those of the\r\nprincipal chiefs, and impaled their heads on the walls of this temple.\r\n\r\nThose were savage times when this old slaughter-house was in its prime.\r\nThe King and the chiefs ruled the common herd with a rod of iron; made\r\nthem gather all the provisions the masters needed; build all the houses\r\nand temples; stand all the expenses, of whatever kind; take kicks and\r\ncuffs for thanks; drag out lives well flavored with misery, and then\r\nsuffer death for trifling offences or yield up their lives on the\r\nsacrificial altars to purchase favors from the gods for their hard\r\nrulers. The missionaries have clothed them, educated them, broken up the\r\ntyrannous authority of their chiefs, and given them freedom and the\r\nright to enjoy whatever their hands and brains produce with equal laws\r\nfor all, and punishment for all alike who transgress them. The contrast\r\nis so strong\xe2\x80\x94the benefit conferred upon this people by the missionaries\r\nis so prominent, so palpable and so unquestionable, that the frankest\r\ncompliment I can pay them, and the best, is simply to point to the\r\ncondition of the Sandwich Islanders of Captain Cook\xe2\x80\x99s time, and their\r\ncondition to-day.\r\n\r\nTheir work speaks for itself.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXV.\r\n\r\n\r\nBy and by, after a rugged climb, we halted on the summit of a hill which\r\ncommanded a far-reaching view. The moon rose and flooded mountain and\r\nvalley and ocean with a mellow radiance, and out of the shadows of the\r\nfoliage the distant lights of Honolulu glinted like an encampment of\r\nfireflies. The air was heavy with the fragrance of flowers. The halt was\r\nbrief.\xe2\x80\x94Gayly laughing and talking, the party galloped on, and I clung to\r\nthe pommel and cantered after. Presently we came to a place where no\r\ngrass grew\xe2\x80\x94a wide expanse of deep sand. They said it was an old battle\r\nground. All around everywhere, not three feet apart, the bleached bones\r\nof men gleamed white in the moonlight. We picked up a lot of them for\r\nmementoes. I got quite a number of arm bones and leg bones\xe2\x80\x94of great\r\nchiefs, may be, who had fought savagely in that fearful battle in the\r\nold days, when blood flowed like wine where we now stood\xe2\x80\x94and wore the\r\nchoicest of them out on Oahu afterward, trying to make him go. All sorts\r\nof bones could be found except skulls; but a citizen said, irreverently,\r\nthat there had been an unusual number of \xe2\x80\x9cskull-hunters\xe2\x80\x9d there lately\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nspecies of sportsmen I had never heard of before.\r\n\r\nNothing whatever is known about this place\xe2\x80\x94its story is a secret that\r\nwill never be revealed. The oldest natives make no pretense of being\r\npossessed of its history. They say these bones were here when they were\r\nchildren. They were here when their grandfathers were children\xe2\x80\x94but how\r\nthey came here, they can only conjecture. Many people believe this spot\r\nto be an ancient battle-ground, and it is usual to call it so; and they\r\nbelieve that these skeletons have lain for ages just where their\r\nproprietors fell in the great fight. Other people believe that\r\nKamehameha I. fought his first battle here. On this point, I have heard\r\na story, which may have been taken from one of the numerous books which\r\nhave been written concerning these islands\xe2\x80\x94I do not know where the\r\nnarrator got it. He said that when Kamehameha (who was at first merely a\r\nsubordinate chief on the island of Hawaii), landed here, he brought a\r\nlarge army with him, and encamped at Waikiki. The Oahuans marched\r\nagainst him, and so confident were they of success that they readily\r\nacceded to a demand of their priests that they should draw a line where\r\nthese bones now lie, and take an oath that, if forced to retreat at all,\r\nthey would never retreat beyond this boundary. The priests told them\r\nthat death and everlasting punishment would overtake any who violated\r\nthe oath, and the march was resumed. Kamehameha drove them back step by\r\nstep; the priests fought in the front rank and exhorted them both by\r\nvoice and inspiriting example to remember their oath\xe2\x80\x94to die, if need be,\r\nbut never cross the fatal line. The struggle was manfully maintained,\r\nbut at last the chief priest fell, pierced to the heart with a spear,\r\nand the unlucky omen fell like a blight upon the brave souls at his\r\nback; with a triumphant shout the invaders pressed forward\xe2\x80\x94the line was\r\ncrossed\xe2\x80\x94the offended gods deserted the despairing army, and, accepting\r\nthe doom their perjury had brought upon them, they broke and fled over\r\nthe plain where Honolulu stands now\xe2\x80\x94up the beautiful Nuuanu\r\nValley\xe2\x80\x94paused a moment, hemmed in by precipitous mountains on either\r\nhand and the frightful precipice of the Pari in front, and then were\r\ndriven over\xe2\x80\x94a sheer plunge of six hundred feet!\r\n\r\nThe story is pretty enough, but Mr. Jarves\xe2\x80\x99 excellent history says the\r\nOahuans were intrenched in Nuuanu Valley; that Kamehameha ousted them,\r\nrouted them, pursued them up the valley and drove them over the\r\nprecipice. He makes no mention of our bone-yard at all in his book.\r\n\r\nImpressed by the profound silence and repose that rested over the\r\nbeautiful landscape, and being, as usual, in the rear, I gave voice to\r\nmy thoughts. I said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a picture is here slumbering in the solemn glory of the moon! How\r\nstrong the rugged outlines of the dead volcano stand out against the\r\nclear sky! What a snowy fringe marks the bursting of the surf over the\r\nlong, curved reef! How calmly the dim city sleeps yonder in the plain!\r\nHow soft the shadows lie upon the stately mountains that border the\r\ndream-haunted Mauoa Valley! What a grand pyramid of billowy clouds\r\ntowers above the storied Pari! How the grim warriors of the past seem\r\nflocking in ghostly squadrons to their ancient battlefield again\xe2\x80\x94how the\r\nwails of the dying well up from the\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point the horse called Oahu sat down in the sand. Sat down to\r\nlisten, I suppose. Never mind what he heard, I stopped apostrophising\r\nand convinced him that I was not a man to allow contempt of Court on the\r\npart of a horse. I broke the back-bone of a Chief over his rump and set\r\nout to join the cavalcade again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n467.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVery considerably fagged out we arrived in town at 9 o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night,\r\nmyself in the lead\xe2\x80\x94for when my horse finally came to understand that he\r\nwas homeward bound and hadn\xe2\x80\x99t far to go, he turned his attention\r\nstrictly to business.\r\n\r\nThis is a good time to drop in a paragraph of information. There is no\r\nregular livery stable in Honolulu, or, indeed, in any part of the\r\nKingdom of Hawaii; therefore unless you are acquainted with wealthy\r\nresidents (who all have good horses), you must hire animals of the\r\nwretchedest description from the Kanakas. (i.e. natives.) Any horse you\r\nhire, even though it be from a white man, is not often of much account,\r\nbecause it will be brought in for you from some ranch, and has\r\nnecessarily been leading a hard life. If the Kanakas who have been\r\ncaring for him (inveterate riders they are) have not ridden him half to\r\ndeath every day themselves, you can depend upon it they have been doing\r\nthe same thing by proxy, by clandestinely hiring him out. At least, so I\r\nam informed. The result is, that no horse has a chance to eat, drink,\r\nrest, recuperate, or look well or feel well, and so strangers go about\r\nthe Islands mounted as I was to-day.\r\n\r\nIn hiring a horse from a Kanaka, you must have all your eyes about you,\r\nbecause you can rest satisfied that you are dealing with a shrewd\r\nunprincipled rascal. You may leave your door open and your trunk\r\nunlocked as long as you please, and he will not meddle with your\r\nproperty; he has no important vices and no inclination to commit robbery\r\non a large scale; but if he can get ahead of you in the horse business,\r\nhe will take a genuine delight in doing it. This traits is\r\ncharacteristic of horse jockeys, the world over, is it not? He will\r\novercharge you if he can; he will hire you a fine-looking horse at night\r\n(anybody\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94may be the King\xe2\x80\x99s, if the royal steed be in convenient view),\r\nand bring you the mate to my Oahu in the morning, and contend that it is\r\nthe same animal. If you make trouble, he will get out by saying it was\r\nnot himself who made the bargain with you, but his brother, \xe2\x80\x9cwho went\r\nout in the country this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d They have always got a \xe2\x80\x9cbrother\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\nshift the responsibility upon. A victim said to one of these fellows one\r\nday:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I know I hired the horse of you, because I noticed that scar on\r\nyour cheek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe reply was not bad: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes\xe2\x80\x94yes\xe2\x80\x94my brother all same\xe2\x80\x94we twins!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n469.jpg (81K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA friend of mine, J. Smith, hired a horse yesterday, the Kanaka\r\nwarranting him to be in excellent condition.\r\n\r\nSmith had a saddle and blanket of his own, and he ordered the Kanaka to\r\nput these on the horse. The Kanaka protested that he was perfectly\r\nwilling to trust the gentleman with the saddle that was already on the\r\nanimal, but Smith refused to use it. The change was made; then Smith\r\nnoticed that the Kanaka had only changed the saddles, and had left the\r\noriginal blanket on the horse; he said he forgot to change the blankets,\r\nand so, to cut the bother short, Smith mounted and rode away. The horse\r\nwent lame a mile from town, and afterward got to cutting up some\r\nextraordinary capers. Smith got down and took off the saddle, but the\r\nblanket stuck fast to the horse\xe2\x80\x94glued to a procession of raw places. The\r\nKanaka\xe2\x80\x99s mysterious conduct stood explained.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n470.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnother friend of mine bought a pretty good horse from a native, a day\r\nor two ago, after a tolerably thorough examination of the animal. He\r\ndiscovered today that the horse was as blind as a bat, in one eye. He\r\nmeant to have examined that eye, and came home with a general notion\r\nthat he had done it; but he remembers now that every time he made the\r\nattempt his attention was called to something else by his victimizer.\r\n\r\nOne more instance, and then I will pass to something else. I am informed\r\nthat when a certain Mr. L., a visiting stranger, was here, he bought a\r\npair of very respectable-looking match horses from a native. They were\r\nin a little stable with a partition through the middle of it\xe2\x80\x94one horse\r\nin each apartment. Mr. L. examined one of them critically through a\r\nwindow (the Kanaka\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cbrother\xe2\x80\x9d having gone to the country with the key),\r\nand then went around the house and examined the other through a window\r\non the other side. He said it was the neatest match he had ever seen,\r\nand paid for the horses on the spot. Whereupon the Kanaka departed to\r\njoin his brother in the country. The fellow had shamefully swindled L.\r\nThere was only one \xe2\x80\x9cmatch\xe2\x80\x9d horse, and he had examined his starboard side\r\nthrough one window and his port side through another! I decline to\r\nbelieve this story, but I give it because it is worth something as a\r\nfanciful illustration of a fixed fact\xe2\x80\x94namely, that the Kanaka horse-\r\njockey is fertile in invention and elastic in conscience.\r\n\r\nYou can buy a pretty good horse for forty or fifty dollars, and a good\r\nenough horse for all practical purposes for two dollars and a half. I\r\nestimate \xe2\x80\x9cOahu\xe2\x80\x9d to be worth somewhere in the neighborhood of thirty-five\r\ncents.
