A good deal better animal than he is was sold here day before\r\nyesterday for a dollar and seventy-five cents, and sold again to-day for\r\ntwo dollars and twenty-five cents; Williams bought a handsome and lively\r\nlittle pony yesterday for ten dollars; and about the best common horse\r\non the island (and he is a really good one) sold yesterday, with Mexican\r\nsaddle and bridle, for seventy dollars\xe2\x80\x94a horse which is well and widely\r\nknown, and greatly respected for his speed, good disposition and\r\neverlasting bottom.\r\n\r\nYou give your horse a little grain once a day; it comes from San\r\nFrancisco, and is worth about two cents a pound; and you give him as\r\nmuch hay as he wants; it is cut and brought to the market by natives,\r\nand is not very good it is baled into long, round bundles, about the\r\nsize of a large man; one of them is stuck by the middle on each end of a\r\nsix foot pole, and the Kanaka shoulders the pole and walks about the\r\nstreets between the upright bales in search of customers. These hay\r\nbales, thus carried, have a general resemblance to a colossal capital\r\n\xe2\x80\x98H.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n471.jpg (59K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe hay-bundles cost twenty-five cents apiece, and one will last a horse\r\nabout a day. You can get a horse for a song, a week\xe2\x80\x99s hay for another\r\nsong, and you can turn your animal loose among the luxuriant grass in\r\nyour neighbor\xe2\x80\x99s broad front yard without a song at all\xe2\x80\x94you do it at\r\nmidnight, and stable the beast again before morning. You have been at no\r\nexpense thus far, but when you come to buy a saddle and bridle they will\r\ncost you from twenty to thirty-five dollars. You can hire a horse,\r\nsaddle and bridle at from seven to ten dollars a week, and the owner\r\nwill take care of them at his own expense.\r\n\r\nIt is time to close this day\xe2\x80\x99s record\xe2\x80\x94bed time. As I prepare for sleep,\r\na rich voice rises out of the still night, and, far as this ocean rock\r\nis toward the ends of the earth, I recognize a familiar home air. But\r\nthe words seem somewhat out of joint:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWaikiki lantoni oe Kaa hooly hooly wawhoo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTranslated, that means \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we were marching through Georgia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n472.jpg (28K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nPassing through the market place we saw that feature of Honolulu under\r\nits most favorable auspices\xe2\x80\x94that is, in the full glory of Saturday\r\nafternoon, which is a festive day with the natives. The native girls by\r\ntwos and threes and parties of a dozen, and sometimes in whole platoons\r\nand companies, went cantering up and down the neighboring streets\r\nastride of fleet but homely horses, and with their gaudy riding habits\r\nstreaming like banners behind them. Such a troop of free and easy\r\nriders, in their natural home, the saddle, makes a gay and graceful\r\nspectacle. The riding habit I speak of is simply a long, broad scarf,\r\nlike a tavern table cloth brilliantly colored, wrapped around the loins\r\nonce, then apparently passed between the limbs and each end thrown\r\nbackward over the same, and floating and flapping behind on both sides\r\nbeyond the horse\xe2\x80\x99s tail like a couple of fancy flags; then, slipping the\r\nstirrup-irons between her toes, the girl throws her chest forward, sits\r\nup like a Major General and goes sweeping by like the wind.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n474.jpg (88K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe girls put on all the finery they can on Saturday afternoon\xe2\x80\x94fine\r\nblack silk robes; flowing red ones that nearly put your eyes out; others\r\nas white as snow; still others that discount the rainbow; and they wear\r\ntheir hair in nets, and trim their jaunty hats with fresh flowers, and\r\nencircle their dusky throats with home-made necklaces of the brilliant\r\nvermillion-tinted blossom of the _ohia_; and they fill the markets and\r\nthe adjacent street with their bright presences, and smell like a rag\r\nfactory on fire with their offensive cocoanut oil.\r\n\r\nOccasionally you see a heathen from the sunny isles away down in the\r\nSouth Seas, with his face and neck tatooed till he looks like the\r\ncustomary mendicant from Washoe who has been blown up in a mine. Some\r\nare tattooed a dead blue color down to the upper lip\xe2\x80\x94masked, as it\r\nwere\xe2\x80\x94leaving the natural light yellow skin of Micronesia unstained from\r\nthence down; some with broad marks drawn down from hair to neck, on both\r\nsides of the face, and a strip of the original yellow skin, two inches\r\nwide, down the center\xe2\x80\x94a gridiron with a spoke broken out; and some with\r\nthe entire face discolored with the popular mortification tint, relieved\r\nonly by one or two thin, wavy threads of natural yellow running across\r\nthe face from ear to ear, and eyes twinkling out of this darkness, from\r\nunder shadowing hat-brims, like stars in the dark of the moon.\r\n\r\nMoving among the stirring crowds, you come to the poi merchants,\r\nsquatting in the shade on their hams, in true native fashion, and\r\nsurrounded by purchasers. (The Sandwich Islanders always squat on their\r\nhams, and who knows but they may be the old original \xe2\x80\x9cham sandwiches?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe thought is pregnant with interest.) The poi looks like common flour\r\npaste, and is kept in large bowls formed of a species of gourd, and\r\ncapable of holding from one to three or four gallons. Poi is the chief\r\narticle of food among the natives, and is prepared from the _taro_\r\nplant.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n475.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe _taro_ root looks like a thick, or, if you please, a corpulent sweet\r\npotato, in shape, but is of a light purple color when boiled. When\r\nboiled it answers as a passable substitute for bread. The buck Kanakas\r\nbake it under ground, then mash it up well with a heavy lava pestle, mix\r\nwater with it until it becomes a paste, set it aside and let if ferment,\r\nand then it is poi\xe2\x80\x94and an unseductive mixture it is, almost tasteless\r\nbefore it ferments and too sour for a luxury afterward. But nothing is\r\nmore nutritious. When solely used, however, it produces acrid humors, a\r\nfact which sufficiently accounts for the humorous character of the\r\nKanakas. I think there must be as much of a knack in handling poi as\r\nthere is in eating with chopsticks. The forefinger is thrust into the\r\nmess and stirred quickly round several times and drawn as quickly out,\r\nthickly coated, just as it it were poulticed; the head is thrown back,\r\nthe finger inserted in the mouth and the delicacy stripped off and\r\nswallowed\xe2\x80\x94the eye closing gently, meanwhile, in a languid sort of\r\necstasy. Many a different finger goes into the same bowl and many a\r\ndifferent kind of dirt and shade and quality of flavor is added to the\r\nvirtues of its contents.\r\n\r\nAround a small shanty was collected a crowd of natives buying the _awa_\r\nroot. It is said that but for the use of this root the destruction of\r\nthe people in former times by certain imported diseases would have been\r\nfar greater than it was, and by others it is said that this is merely a\r\nfancy. All agree that poi will rejuvenate a man who is used up and his\r\nvitality almost annihilated by hard drinking, and that in some kinds of\r\ndiseases it will restore health after all medicines have failed; but all\r\nare not willing to allow to the _awa_ the virtues claimed for it. The\r\nnatives manufacture an intoxicating drink from it which is fearful in\r\nits effects when persistently indulged in. It covers the body with dry,\r\nwhite scales, inflames the eyes, and causes premature decripitude.\r\nAlthough the man before whose establishment we stopped has to pay a\r\nGovernment license of eight hundred dollars a year for the exclusive\r\nright to sell _awa_ root, it is said that he makes a small fortune every\r\ntwelve-month; while saloon keepers, who pay a thousand dollars a year\r\nfor the privilege of retailing whiskey, etc., only make a bare living.\r\n\r\nWe found the fish market crowded; for the native is very fond of fish,\r\nand _eats the article raw and alive_! Let us change the subject.\r\n\r\nIn old times here Saturday was a grand gala day indeed. All the native\r\npopulation of the town forsook their labors, and those of the\r\nsurrounding country journeyed to the city. Then the white folks had to\r\nstay indoors, for every street was so packed with charging cavaliers and\r\ncavalieresses that it was next to impossible to thread one\xe2\x80\x99s way through\r\nthe cavalcades without getting crippled.\r\n\r\nAt night they feasted and the girls danced the lascivious _hula hula_\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndance that is said to exhibit the very perfection of educated notion of\r\nlimb and arm, hand, head and body, and the exactest uniformity of\r\nmovement and accuracy of \xe2\x80\x9ctime.\xe2\x80\x9d It was performed by a circle of girls\r\nwith no raiment on them to speak of, who went through an infinite\r\nvariety of motions and figures without prompting, and yet so true was\r\ntheir \xe2\x80\x9ctime,\xe2\x80\x9d and in such perfect concert did they move that when they\r\nwere placed in a straight line, hands, arms, bodies, limbs and heads\r\nwaved, swayed, gesticulated, bowed, stooped, whirled, squirmed, twisted\r\nand undulated as if they were part and parcel of a single individual;\r\nand it was difficult to believe they were not moved in a body by some\r\nexquisite piece of mechanism.\r\n\r\nOf late years, however, Saturday has lost most of its quondam gala\r\nfeatures. This weekly stampede of the natives interfered too much with\r\nlabor and the interests of the white folks, and by sticking in a law\r\nhere, and preaching a sermon there, and by various other means, they\r\ngradually broke it up. The demoralizing _hula hula_ was forbidden to be\r\nperformed, save at night, with closed doors, in presence of few\r\nspectators, and only by permission duly procured from the authorities\r\nand the payment of ten dollars for the same. There are few girls now-a-\r\ndays able to dance this ancient national dance in the highest perfection\r\nof the art.\r\n\r\nThe missionaries have christianized and educated all the natives. They\r\nall belong to the Church, and there is not one of them, above the age of\r\neight years, but can read and write with facility in the native tongue.\r\nIt is the most universally educated race of people outside of China.\r\nThey have any quantity of books, printed in the Kanaka language, and all\r\nthe natives are fond of reading. They are inveterate church-\r\ngoers\xe2\x80\x94nothing can keep them away. All this ameliorating cultivation has\r\nat last built up in the native women a profound respect for chastity\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nother people. Perhaps that is enough to say on that head. The national\r\nsin will die out when the race does, but perhaps not earlier.\xe2\x80\x94But\r\ndoubtless this purifying is not far off, when we reflect that contact\r\nwith civilization and the whites has reduced the native population from\r\nfour hundred thousand (Captain Cook\xe2\x80\x99s estimate,) to _fifty-five\r\nthousand_ in something over eighty years!\r\n\r\nSociety is a queer medley in this notable missionary, whaling and\r\ngovernmental centre. If you get into conversation with a stranger and\r\nexperience that natural desire to know what sort of ground you are\r\ntreading on by finding out what manner of man your stranger is, strike\r\nout boldly and address him as \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain.\xe2\x80\x9d Watch him narrowly, and if you\r\nsee by his countenance that you are on the wrong tack, ask him where he\r\npreaches. It is a safe bet that he is either a missionary or captain of\r\na whaler. I am now personally acquainted with seventy-two captains and\r\nninety-six missionaries. The captains and ministers form one-half of the\r\npopulation; the third fourth is composed of common Kanakas and\r\nmercantile foreigners and their families, and the final fourth is made\r\nup of high officers of the Hawaiian Government. And there are just about\r\ncats enough for three apiece all around.\r\n\r\nA solemn stranger met me in the suburbs the other day, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood morning, your reverence. Preach in the stone church yonder, no\r\ndoubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99m not a preacher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, I beg your pardon, Captain. I trust you had a good season. How\r\nmuch oil\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOil? What do you take me for? I\xe2\x80\x99m not a whaler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I beg a thousand pardons, your Excellency.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMajor General in the household troops, no doubt? Minister of the\r\nInterior, likely? Secretary of war? First Gentleman of the Bed-chamber?\r\nCommissioner of the Royal\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStuff! I\xe2\x80\x99m no official. I\xe2\x80\x99m not connected in any way with the\r\nGovernment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless my life! Then, who the mischief are you? what the mischief are\r\nyou? and how the mischief did you get here, and where in thunder did you\r\ncome from?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m only a private personage\xe2\x80\x94an unassuming stranger\xe2\x80\x94lately arrived from\r\nAmerica.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo? Not a missionary! Not a whaler! not a member of his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGovernment! not even Secretary of the Navy! Ah, Heaven! it is too\r\nblissful to be true; alas, I do but dream. And yet that noble, honest\r\ncountenance\xe2\x80\x94those oblique, ingenuous eyes\xe2\x80\x94that massive head, incapable\r\nof\xe2\x80\x94of\xe2\x80\x94anything; your hand; give me your hand, bright waif. Excuse these\r\ntears. For sixteen weary years I have yearned for a moment like this,\r\nand\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n478.jpg (67K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHere his feelings were too much for him, and he swooned away. I pitied\r\nthis poor creature from the bottom of my heart. I was deeply moved. I\r\nshed a few tears on him and kissed him for his mother. I then took what\r\nsmall change he had and \xe2\x80\x9cshoved\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n479.jpg (31K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nI still quote from my journal:\r\n\r\nI found the national Legislature to consist of half a dozen white men\r\nand some thirty or forty natives. It was a dark assemblage. The nobles\r\nand Ministers (about a dozen of them altogether) occupied the extreme\r\nleft of the hall, with David Kalakaua (the King\xe2\x80\x99s Chamberlain) and\r\nPrince William at the head. The President of the Assembly, His Royal\r\nHighness M. Kekuanaoa, [Kekuanaoa is not of the blood royal. He derives\r\nhis princely rank from his wife, who was a daughter of Kamehameha the\r\nGreat. Under other monarchies the male line takes precedence of the\r\nfemale in tracing genealogies, but here the opposite is the case\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nfemale line takes precedence. Their reason for this is exceedingly\r\nsensible, and I recommend it to the aristocracy of Europe: They say it\r\nis easy to know who a man\xe2\x80\x99s mother was, but, etc., etc.] and the Vice\r\nPresident (the latter a white man,) sat in the pulpit, if I may so term\r\nit. The President is the King\xe2\x80\x99s father. He is an erect, strongly built,\r\nmassive featured, white-haired, tawny old gentleman of eighty years of\r\nage or thereabouts. He was simply but well dressed, in a blue cloth coat\r\nand white vest, and white pantaloons, without spot, dust or blemish upon\r\nthem. He bears himself with a calm, stately dignity, and is a man of\r\nnoble presence. He was a young man and a distinguished warrior under\r\nthat terrific fighter, Kamehameha I., more than half a century ago. A\r\nknowledge of his career suggested some such thought as this: \xe2\x80\x9cThis man,\r\nnaked as the day he was born, and war-club and spear in hand, has\r\ncharged at the head of a horde of savages against other hordes of\r\nsavages more than a generation and a half ago, and reveled in slaughter\r\nand carnage; has worshipped wooden images on his devout knees; has seen\r\nhundreds of his race offered up in heathen temples as sacrifices to\r\nwooden idols, at a time when no missionary\xe2\x80\x99s foot had ever pressed this\r\nsoil, and he had never heard of the white man\xe2\x80\x99s God; has believed his\r\nenemy could secretly pray him to death; has seen the day, in his\r\nchildhood, when it was a crime punishable by death for a man to eat with\r\nhis wife, or for a plebeian to let his shadow fall upon the King\xe2\x80\x94and now\r\nlook at him; an educated Christian; neatly and handsomely dressed; a\r\nhigh-minded, elegant gentleman; a traveler, in some degree, and one who\r\nhas been the honored guest of royalty in Europe; a man practiced in\r\nholding the reins of an enlightened government, and well versed in the\r\npolitics of his country and in general, practical information. Look at\r\nhim, sitting there presiding over the deliberations of a legislative\r\nbody, among whom are white men\xe2\x80\x94a grave, dignified, statesmanlike\r\npersonage, and as seemingly natural and fitted to the place as if he had\r\nbeen born in it and had never been out of it in his life time. How the\r\nexperiences of this old man\xe2\x80\x99s eventful life shame the cheap inventions\r\nof romance!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe christianizing of the natives has hardly even weakened some of their\r\nbarbarian superstitions, much less destroyed them. I have just referred\r\nto one of these. It is still a popular belief that if your enemy can get\r\nhold of any article belonging to you he can get down on his knees over\r\nit and _pray you to death_. Therefore many a native gives up and dies\r\nmerely because he _imagines_ that some enemy is putting him through a\r\ncourse of damaging prayer. This praying an individual to death seems\r\nabsurd enough at a first glance, but then when we call to mind some of\r\nthe pulpit efforts of certain of our own ministers the thing looks\r\nplausible.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n482.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn former times, among the Islanders, not only a plurality of wives was\r\ncustomary, but a _plurality of husbands_ likewise. Some native women of\r\nnoble rank had as many as six husbands. A woman thus supplied did not\r\nreside with all her husbands at once, but lived several months with each\r\nin turn. An understood sign hung at her door during these months. When\r\nthe sign was taken down, it meant \xe2\x80\x9cNEXT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn those days woman was rigidly taught to \xe2\x80\x9cknow her place.\xe2\x80\x9d Her place\r\nwas to do all the work, take all the cuffs, provide all the food, and\r\ncontent herself with what was left after her lord had finished his\r\ndinner. She was not only forbidden, by ancient law, and under penalty of\r\ndeath, to eat with her husband or enter a canoe, but was debarred, under\r\nthe same penalty, from eating bananas, pine-apples, oranges and other\r\nchoice fruits at any time or in any place. She had to confine herself\r\npretty strictly to \xe2\x80\x9cpoi\xe2\x80\x9d and hard work. These poor ignorant heathen seem\r\nto have had a sort of groping idea of what came of woman eating fruit in\r\nthe garden of Eden, and they did not choose to take any more chances.\r\nBut the missionaries broke up this satisfactory arrangement of things.\r\nThey liberated woman and made her the equal of man.\r\n\r\nThe natives had a romantic fashion of burying some of their children\r\nalive when the family became larger than necessary. The missionaries\r\ninterfered in this matter too, and stopped it.\r\n\r\nTo this day the natives are able to _lie down and die whenever they want\r\nto_, whether there is anything the matter with them or not. If a Kanaka\r\ntakes a notion to die, that is the end of him; nobody can persuade him\r\nto hold on; all the doctors in the world could not save him.\r\n\r\nA luxury which they enjoy more than anything else, is a large funeral.\r\nIf a person wants to get rid of a troublesome native, it is only\r\nnecessary to promise him a fine funeral and name the hour and he will be\r\non hand to the minute\xe2\x80\x94at least his remains will.\r\n\r\nAll the natives are Christians, now, but many of them still desert to\r\nthe Great Shark God for temporary succor in time of trouble. An\r\nirruption of the great volcano of Kilauea, or an earthquake, always\r\nbrings a deal of latent loyalty to the Great Shark God to the surface.\r\nIt is common report that the King, educated, cultivated and refined\r\nChristian gentleman as he undoubtedly is, still turns to the idols of\r\nhis fathers for help when disaster threatens. A planter caught a shark,\r\nand one of his christianized natives testified his emancipation from the\r\nthrall of ancient superstition by assisting to dissect the shark after a\r\nfashion forbidden by his abandoned creed. But remorse shortly began to\r\ntorture him. He grew moody and sought solitude; brooded over his sin,\r\nrefused food, and finally said he must die and ought to die, for he had\r\nsinned against the Great Shark God and could never know peace any more.\r\nHe was proof against persuasion and ridicule, and in the course of a day\r\nor two took to his bed and died, although he showed no symptom of\r\ndisease. His young daughter followed his lead and suffered a like fate\r\nwithin the week. Superstition is ingrained in the native blood and bone\r\nand it is only natural that it should crop out in time of distress.\r\nWherever one goes in the Islands, he will find small piles of stones by\r\nthe wayside, covered with leafy offerings, placed there by the natives\r\nto appease evil spirits or honor local deities belonging to the\r\nmythology of former days.\r\n\r\nIn the rural districts of any of the Islands, the traveler hourly comes\r\nupon parties of dusky maidens bathing in the streams or in the sea\r\nwithout any clothing on and exhibiting no very intemperate zeal in the\r\nmatter of hiding their nakedness. When the missionaries first took up\r\ntheir residence in Honolulu, the native women would pay their families\r\nfrequent friendly visits, day by day, not even clothed with a blush. It\r\nwas found a hard matter to convince them that this was rather\r\nindelicate. Finally the missionaries provided them with long, loose\r\ncalico robes, and that ended the difficulty\xe2\x80\x94for the women would troop\r\nthrough the town, stark naked, with their robes folded under their arms,\r\nmarch to the missionary houses and then proceed to dress!\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n484.jpg (63K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe natives soon manifested a strong proclivity for clothing, but it was\r\nshortly apparent that they only wanted it for grandeur. The missionaries\r\nimported a quantity of hats, bonnets, and other male and female wearing\r\napparel, instituted a general distribution, and begged the people not to\r\ncome to church naked, next Sunday, as usual. And they did not; but the\r\nnational spirit of unselfishness led them to divide up with neighbors\r\nwho were not at the distribution, and next Sabbath the poor preachers\r\ncould hardly keep countenance before their vast congregations. In the\r\nmidst of the reading of a hymn a brown, stately dame would sweep up the\r\naisle with a world of airs, with nothing in the world on but a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cstovepipe\xe2\x80\x9d hat and a pair of cheap gloves; another dame would follow,\r\ntricked out in a man\xe2\x80\x99s shirt, and nothing else; another one would enter\r\nwith a flourish, with simply the sleeves of a bright calico dress tied\r\naround her waist and the rest of the garment dragging behind like a\r\npeacock\xe2\x80\x99s tail off duty; a stately \xe2\x80\x9cbuck\xe2\x80\x9d Kanaka would stalk in with a\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet on, wrong side before\xe2\x80\x94only this, and nothing more; after\r\nhim would stride his fellow, with the legs of a pair of pantaloons tied\r\naround his neck, the rest of his person untrammeled; in his rear would\r\ncome another gentleman simply gotten up in a fiery neck-tie and a\r\nstriped vest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n485.jpg (90K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe poor creatures were beaming with complacency and wholly unconscious\r\nof any absurdity in their appearance. They gazed at each other with\r\nhappy admiration, and it was plain to see that the young girls were\r\ntaking note of what each other had on, as naturally as if they had\r\nalways lived in a land of Bibles and knew what churches were made for;\r\nhere was the evidence of a dawning civilization. The spectacle which the\r\ncongregation presented was so extraordinary and withal so moving, that\r\nthe missionaries found it difficult to keep to the text and go on with\r\nthe services; and by and by when the simple children of the sun began a\r\ngeneral swapping of garments in open meeting and produced some\r\nirresistibly grotesque effects in the course of re-dressing, there was\r\nnothing for it but to cut the thing short with the benediction and\r\ndismiss the fantastic assemblage.\r\n\r\nIn our country, children play \xe2\x80\x9ckeep house;\xe2\x80\x9d and in the same high-\r\nsounding but miniature way the grown folk here, with the poor little\r\nmaterial of slender territory and meagre population, play \xe2\x80\x9cempire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThere is his royal Majesty the King, with a New York detective\xe2\x80\x99s income\r\nof thirty or thirty-five thousand dollars a year from the \xe2\x80\x9croyal civil\r\nlist\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9croyal domain.\xe2\x80\x9d He lives in a two-story frame \xe2\x80\x9cpalace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n486.jpg (35K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd there is the \xe2\x80\x9croyal family\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the customary hive of royal brothers,\r\nsisters, cousins and other noble drones and vagrants usual to\r\nmonarchy,\xe2\x80\x94all with a spoon in the national pap-dish, and all bearing\r\nsuch titles as his or her Royal Highness the Prince or Princess So-and-\r\nso. Few of them can carry their royal splendors far enough to ride in\r\ncarriages, however; they sport the economical Kanaka horse or \xe2\x80\x9choof it\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwith the plebeians.\r\n\r\nThen there is his Excellency the \xe2\x80\x9croyal Chamberlain\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a sinecure, for his\r\nmajesty dresses himself with his own hands, except when he is ruralizing\r\nat Waikiki and then he requires no dressing.\r\n\r\nNext we have his Excellency the Commander-in-chief of the Household\r\nTroops, whose forces consist of about the number of soldiers usually\r\nplaced under a corporal in other lands.\r\n\r\nNext comes the royal Steward and the Grand Equerry in Waiting\xe2\x80\x94high\r\ndignitaries with modest salaries and little to do.\r\n\r\nThen we have his Excellency the First Gentleman of the Bed-chamber\xe2\x80\x94an\r\noffice as easy as it is magnificent.\r\n\r\nNext we come to his Excellency the Prime Minister, a renegade American\r\nfrom New Hampshire, all jaw, vanity, bombast and ignorance, a lawyer of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cshyster\xe2\x80\x9d calibre, a fraud by nature, a humble worshipper of the sceptre\r\nabove him, a reptile never tired of sneering at the land of his birth or\r\nglorifying the ten-acre kingdom that has adopted him\xe2\x80\x94salary, $4,000 a\r\nyear, vast consequence, and no perquisites.\r\n\r\nThen we have his Excellency the Imperial Minister of Finance, who\r\nhandles a million dollars of public money a year, sends in his annual\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbudget\xe2\x80\x9d with great ceremony, talks prodigiously of \xe2\x80\x9cfinance,\xe2\x80\x9d suggests\r\nimposing schemes for paying off the \xe2\x80\x9cnational debt\xe2\x80\x9d (of $150,000,) and\r\ndoes it all for $4,000 a year and unimaginable glory.\r\n\r\nNext we have his Excellency the Minister of War, who holds sway over the\r\nroyal armies\xe2\x80\x94they consist of two hundred and thirty uniformed Kanakas,\r\nmostly Brigadier Generals, and if the country ever gets into trouble\r\nwith a foreign power we shall probably hear from them. I knew an\r\nAmerican whose copper-plate visiting card bore this impressive legend:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLieutenant-Colonel in the Royal Infantry.\xe2\x80\x9d To say that he was proud of\r\nthis distinction is stating it but tamely. The Minister of War has also\r\nin his charge some venerable swivels on Punch-Bowl Hill wherewith royal\r\nsalutes are fired when foreign vessels of war enter the port.\r\n\r\nNext comes his Excellency the Minister of the Navy\xe2\x80\x94a nabob who rules the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9croyal fleet,\xe2\x80\x9d (a steam-tug and a sixty-ton schooner.)\r\n\r\nAnd next comes his Grace the Lord Bishop of Honolulu, the chief\r\ndignitary of the \xe2\x80\x9cEstablished Church\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94for when the American Presbyterian\r\nmissionaries had completed the reduction of the nation to a compact\r\ncondition of Christianity, native royalty stepped in and erected the\r\ngrand dignity of an \xe2\x80\x9cEstablished (Episcopal) Church\xe2\x80\x9d over it, and\r\nimported a cheap ready-made Bishop from England to take charge. The\r\nchagrin of the missionaries has never been comprehensively expressed, to\r\nthis day, profanity not being admissible.\r\n\r\nNext comes his Excellency the Minister of Public Instruction.\r\n\r\nNext, their Excellencies the Governors of Oahu, Hawaii, etc., and after\r\nthem a string of High Sheriffs and other small fry too numerous for\r\ncomputation.\r\n\r\nThen there are their Excellencies the Envoy Extraordinary and Minister\r\nPlenipotentiary of his Imperial Majesty the Emperor of the French; her\r\nBritish Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s Minister; the Minister Resident, of the United States;\r\nand some six or eight representatives of other foreign nations, all with\r\nsounding titles, imposing dignity and prodigious but economical state.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n488.jpg (94K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nImagine all this grandeur in a play-house \xe2\x80\x9ckingdom\xe2\x80\x9d whose population\r\nfalls absolutely short of sixty thousand souls!\r\n\r\nThe people are so accustomed to nine-jointed titles and colossal\r\nmagnates that a foreign prince makes very little more stir in Honolulu\r\nthan a Western Congressman does in New York.\r\n\r\nAnd let it be borne in mind that there is a strictly defined \xe2\x80\x9ccourt\r\ncostume\xe2\x80\x9d of so \xe2\x80\x9cstunning\xe2\x80\x9d a nature that it would make the clown in a\r\ncircus look tame and commonplace by comparison; and each Hawaiian\r\nofficial dignitary has a gorgeous vari-colored, gold-laced uniform\r\npeculiar to his office\xe2\x80\x94no two of them are alike, and it is hard to tell\r\nwhich one is the \xe2\x80\x9cloudest.\xe2\x80\x9d The King had a \xe2\x80\x9cdrawing-room\xe2\x80\x9d at stated\r\nintervals, like other monarchs, and when these varied uniforms\r\ncongregate there\xe2\x80\x94weak-eyed people have to contemplate the spectacle\r\nthrough smoked glass. Is there not a gratifying contrast between this\r\nlatter-day exhibition and the one the ancestors of some of these\r\nmagnates afforded the missionaries the Sunday after the old-time\r\ndistribution of clothing? Behold what religion and civilization have\r\nwrought!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n489.jpg (40K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXVIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile I was in Honolulu I witnessed the ceremonious funeral of the\r\nKing\xe2\x80\x99s sister, her Royal Highness the Princess Victoria. According to\r\nthe royal custom, the remains had lain in state at the palace _thirty\r\ndays_, watched day and night by a guard of honor. And during all that\r\ntime a great multitude of natives from the several islands had kept the\r\npalace grounds well crowded and had made the place a pandemonium every\r\nnight with their howlings and wailings, beating of tom-toms and dancing\r\nof the (at other times) forbidden \xe2\x80\x9chula-hula\xe2\x80\x9d by half-clad maidens to\r\nthe music of songs of questionable decency chanted in honor of the\r\ndeceased. The printed programme of the funeral procession interested me\r\nat the time; and after what I have just said of Hawaiian grandiloquence\r\nin the matter of \xe2\x80\x9cplaying empire,\xe2\x80\x9d I am persuaded that a perusal of it\r\nmay interest the reader:\r\n\r\nAfter reading the long list of dignitaries, etc., and remembering the\r\nsparseness of the population, one is almost inclined to wonder where the\r\nmaterial for that portion of the procession devoted to \xe2\x80\x9cHawaiian\r\nPopulation Generally\xe2\x80\x9d is going to be procured:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n490.jpg (34K) 491.jpg (105K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nUndertaker. Royal School. Kawaiahao School. Roman Catholic School.\r\nMaemae School. Honolulu Fire Department. Mechanics\xe2\x80\x99 Benefit Union.\r\nAttending Physicians. Knonohikis (Superintendents) of the Crown Lands,\r\nKonohikis of the Private Lands of His Majesty Konohikis of the Private\r\nLands of Her late Royal Highness. Governor of Oahu and Staff. Hulumanu\r\n(Military Company). Household Troops. The Prince of Hawaii\xe2\x80\x99s Own\r\n(Military Company). The King\xe2\x80\x99s household servants. Servants of Her late\r\nRoyal Highness. Protestant Clergy. The Clergy of the Roman Catholic\r\nChurch. His Lordship Louis Maigret, The Right Rev. Bishop of Arathea,\r\nVicar-Apostolic of the Hawaiian Islands. The Clergy of the Hawaiian\r\nReformed Catholic Church. His Lordship the Right Rev. Bishop of\r\nHonolulu. Her Majesty Queen Emma\xe2\x80\x99s Carriage. His Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s Staff.\r\nCarriage of Her late Royal Highness. Carriage of Her Majesty the Queen\r\nDowager. The King\xe2\x80\x99s Chancellor. Cabinet Ministers. His Excellency the\r\nMinister Resident of the United States. H. B. M\xe2\x80\x99s Commissioner. H. B.\r\nM\xe2\x80\x99s Acting Commissioner. Judges of Supreme Court. Privy Councillors.\r\nMembers of Legislative Assembly. Consular Corps. Circuit Judges. Clerks\r\nof Government Departments. Members of the Bar. Collector General,\r\nCustom-house Officers and Officers of the Customs. Marshal and Sheriffs\r\nof the different Islands. King\xe2\x80\x99s Yeomanry. Foreign Residents. Ahahui\r\nKaahumanu. Hawaiian Population Generally. Hawaiian Cavalry. Police\r\nForce.\r\n\r\nI resume my journal at the point where the procession arrived at the\r\nroyal mausoleum:\r\n\r\nAs the procession filed through the gate, the military deployed\r\nhandsomely to the right and left and formed an avenue through which the\r\nlong column of mourners passed to the tomb. The coffin was borne through\r\nthe door of the mausoleum, followed by the King and his chiefs, the\r\ngreat officers of the kingdom, foreign Consuls, Embassadors and\r\ndistinguished guests (Burlingame and General Van Valkenburgh). Several\r\nof the kahilis were then fastened to a frame-work in front of the tomb,\r\nthere to remain until they decay and fall to pieces, or, forestalling\r\nthis, until another scion of royalty dies. At this point of the\r\nproceedings the multitude set up such a heart-broken wailing as I hope\r\nnever to hear again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n492.jpg (90K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe soldiers fired three volleys of musketry\xe2\x80\x94the wailing being\r\npreviously silenced to permit of the guns being heard. His Highness\r\nPrince William, in a showy military uniform (the \xe2\x80\x9ctrue prince,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94scion of the house over-thrown by the present dynasty\xe2\x80\x94he was\r\nformerly betrothed to the Princess but was not allowed to marry her),\r\nstood guard and paced back and forth within the door. The privileged few\r\nwho followed the coffin into the mausoleum remained sometime, but the\r\nKing soon came out and stood in the door and near one side of it. A\r\nstranger could have guessed his rank (although he was so simply and\r\nunpretentiously dressed) by the profound deference paid him by all\r\npersons in his vicinity; by seeing his high officers receive his quiet\r\norders and suggestions with bowed and uncovered heads; and by observing\r\nhow careful those persons who came out of the mausoleum were to avoid\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccrowding\xe2\x80\x9d him (although there was room enough in the doorway for a\r\nwagon to pass, for that matter); how respectfully they edged out\r\nsideways, scraping their backs against the wall and always presenting a\r\nfront view of their persons to his Majesty, and never putting their hats\r\non until they were well out of the royal presence.\r\n\r\nHe was dressed entirely in black\xe2\x80\x94dress-coat and silk hat\xe2\x80\x94and looked\r\nrather democratic in the midst of the showy uniforms about him. On his\r\nbreast he wore a large gold star, which was half hidden by the lapel of\r\nhis coat. He remained at the door a half hour, and occasionally gave an\r\norder to the men who were erecting the kahilis [Ranks of long-handled\r\nmops made of gaudy feathers\xe2\x80\x94sacred to royalty. They are stuck in the\r\nground around the tomb and left there.] before the tomb. He had the good\r\ntaste to make one of them substitute black crape for the ordinary hempen\r\nrope he was about to tie one of them to the frame-work with. Finally he\r\nentered his carriage and drove away, and the populace shortly began to\r\ndrop into his wake. While he was in view there was but one man who\r\nattracted more attention than himself, and that was Harris (the Yankee\r\nPrime Minister). This feeble personage had crape enough around his hat\r\nto express the grief of an entire nation, and as usual he neglected no\r\nopportunity of making himself conspicuous and exciting the admiration of\r\nthe simple Kanakas. Oh! noble ambition of this modern Richelieu!\r\n\r\nIt is interesting to contrast the funeral ceremonies of the Princess\r\nVictoria with those of her noted ancestor Kamehameha the Conqueror, who\r\ndied fifty years ago\xe2\x80\x94in 1819, the year before the first missionaries\r\ncame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the 8th of May, 1819, at the age of sixty-six, he died, as he had\r\nlived, in the faith of his country. It was his misfortune not to have\r\ncome in contact with men who could have rightly influenced his religious\r\naspirations. Judged by his advantages and compared with the most eminent\r\nof his countrymen he may be justly styled not only great, but good. To\r\nthis day his memory warms the heart and elevates the national feelings\r\nof Hawaiians. They are proud of their old warrior King; they love his\r\nname; his deeds form their historical age; and an enthusiasm everywhere\r\nprevails, shared even by foreigners who knew his worth, that constitutes\r\nthe firmest pillar of the throne of his dynasty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn lieu of human victims (the custom of that age), a sacrifice of three\r\nhundred dogs attended his obsequies\xe2\x80\x94no mean holocaust when their\r\nnational value and the estimation in which they were held are\r\nconsidered. The bones of Kamehameha, after being kept for a while, were\r\nso carefully concealed that all knowledge of their final resting place\r\nis now lost. There was a proverb current among the common people that\r\nthe bones of a cruel King could not be hid; they made fish-hooks and\r\narrows of them, upon which, in using them, they vented their abhorrence\r\nof his memory in bitter execrations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe account of the circumstances of his death, as written by the native\r\nhistorians, is full of minute detail, but there is scarcely a line of it\r\nwhich does not mention or illustrate some by-gone custom of the country.\r\nIn this respect it is the most comprehensive document I have yet met\r\nwith. I will quote it entire:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen Kamehameha was dangerously sick, and the priests were unable to\r\ncure him, they said: \xe2\x80\x98Be of good courage and build a house for the god\xe2\x80\x99\r\n(his own private god or idol), that thou mayest recover.\xe2\x80\x99 The chiefs\r\ncorroborated this advice of the priests, and a place of worship was\r\nprepared for Kukailimoku, and consecrated in the evening. They proposed\r\nalso to the King, with a view to prolong his life, that human victims\r\nshould be sacrificed to his deity; upon which the greater part of the\r\npeople absconded through fear of death, and concealed themselves in\r\nhiding places till the _tabu_ [Tabu (pronounced tah-boo,) means\r\nprohibition (we have borrowed it,) or sacred. The _tabu_ was sometimes\r\npermanent, sometimes temporary; and the person or thing placed under\r\n_tabu_ was for the time being sacred to the purpose for which it was set\r\napart. In the above case the victims selected under the _tabu_ would be\r\nsacred to the sacrifice] in which destruction impended, was past. It is\r\ndoubtful whether Kamehameha approved of the plan of the chiefs and\r\npriests to sacrifice men, as he was known to say, \xe2\x80\x98The men are sacred\r\nfor the King;\xe2\x80\x99 meaning that they were for the service of his successor.\r\nThis information was derived from Liholiho, his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter this, his sickness increased to such a degree that he had not\r\nstrength to turn himself in his bed. When another season, consecrated\r\nfor worship at the new temple (heiau) arrived, he said to his son,\r\nLiholiho, \xe2\x80\x98Go thou and make supplication to thy god; I am not able to\r\ngo, and will offer my prayers at home.\xe2\x80\x99 When his devotions to his\r\nfeathered god, Kukailimoku, were concluded, a certain religiously\r\ndisposed individual, who had a bird god, suggested to the King that\r\nthrough its influence his sickness might be removed. The name of this\r\ngod was Pua; its body was made of a bird, now eaten by the Hawaiians,\r\nand called in their language alae. Kamehameha was willing that a trial\r\nshould be made, and two houses were constructed to facilitate the\r\nexperiment; but while dwelling in them he became so very weak as not to\r\nreceive food. After lying there three days, his wives, children and\r\nchiefs, perceiving that he was very low, returned him to his own house.\r\nIn the evening he was carried to the eating house, where he took a\r\nlittle food in his mouth which he did not swallow; also a cup of water.\r\nThe chiefs requested him to give them his counsel; but he made no reply,\r\nand was carried back to the dwelling house; but when near midnight\xe2\x80\x94ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94he was carried again to the place to eat; but, as\r\nbefore, he merely tasted of what was presented to him. Then Kaikioewa\r\naddressed him thus: \xe2\x80\x98Here we all are, your younger brethren, your son\r\nLiholiho and your foreigner; impart to us your dying charge, that\r\nLiholiho and Kaahumanu may hear.\xe2\x80\x99 Then Kamehameha inquired, \xe2\x80\x98What do you\r\nsay?\xe2\x80\x99 Kaikioewa repeated, \xe2\x80\x98Your counsels for us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe then said, \xe2\x80\x98Move on in my good way and\xe2\x80\x94.\xe2\x80\x99 He could proceed no\r\nfurther. The foreigner, Mr. Young, embraced and kissed him. Hoapili also\r\nembraced him, whispering something in his ear, after which he was taken\r\nback to the house. About twelve he was carried once more to the house\r\nfor eating, into which his head entered, while his body was in the\r\ndwelling house immediately adjoining. It should be remarked that this\r\nfrequent carrying of a sick chief from one house to another resulted\r\nfrom the _tabu_ system, then in force. There were at that time six\r\nhouses (huts) connected with an establishment\xe2\x80\x94one was for worship, one\r\nfor the men to eat in, an eating house for the women, a house to sleep\r\nin, a house in which to manufacture kapa (native cloth) and one where,\r\nat certain intervals, the women might dwell in seclusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sick was once more taken to his house, when he expired; this was at\r\ntwo o\xe2\x80\x99clock, a circumstance from which Leleiohoku derived his name. As\r\nhe breathed his last, Kalaimoku came to the eating house to order those\r\nin it to go out. There were two aged persons thus directed to depart;\r\none went, the other remained on account of love to the King, by whom he\r\nhad formerly been kindly sustained. The children also were sent away.\r\nThen Kalaimoku came to the house, and the chiefs had a consultation. One\r\nof them spoke thus: \xe2\x80\x98This is my thought\xe2\x80\x94we will eat him raw. [This\r\nsounds suspicious, in view of the fact that all Sandwich Island\r\nhistorians, white and black, protest that cannibalism never existed in\r\nthe islands. However, since they only proposed to \xe2\x80\x9ceat him raw\xe2\x80\x9d we\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwon\xe2\x80\x99t count that\xe2\x80\x9d. But it would certainly have been cannibalism if they\r\nhad cooked him.\xe2\x80\x94M. T.] Kaahumanu (one of the dead King\xe2\x80\x99s widows)\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps his body is not at our disposal; that is more properly\r\nwith his successor. Our part in him\xe2\x80\x94his breath\xe2\x80\x94has departed; his remains\r\nwill be disposed of by Liholiho.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter this conversation the body was taken into the consecrated house\r\nfor the performance of the proper rites by the priest and the new King.\r\nThe name of this ceremony is uko; and when the sacred hog was baked the\r\npriest offered it to the dead body, and it became a god, the King at the\r\nsame time repeating the customary prayers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the priest, addressing himself to the King and chiefs, said: \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nwill now make known to you the rules to be observed respecting persons\r\nto be sacrificed on the burial of this body. If you obtain one man\r\nbefore the corpse is removed, one will be sufficient; but after it\r\nleaves this house four will be required. If delayed until we carry the\r\ncorpse to the grave there must be ten; but after it is deposited in the\r\ngrave there must be fifteen. To-morrow morning there will be a _tabu_,\r\nand, if the sacrifice be delayed until that time, forty men must die.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the high priest, Hewahewa, inquired of the chiefs, \xe2\x80\x98Where shall be\r\nthe residence of King Liholiho?\xe2\x80\x99 They replied, \xe2\x80\x98Where, indeed? You, of\r\nall men, ought to know.\xe2\x80\x99 Then the priest observed, \xe2\x80\x98There are two\r\nsuitable places; one is Kau, the other is Kohala.\xe2\x80\x99 The chiefs preferred\r\nthe latter, as it was more thickly inhabited. The priest added, \xe2\x80\x98These\r\nare proper places for the King\xe2\x80\x99s residence; but he must not remain in\r\nKona, for it is polluted.\xe2\x80\x99 This was agreed to. It was now break of day.\r\nAs he was being carried to the place of burial the people perceived that\r\ntheir King was dead, and they wailed. When the corpse was removed from\r\nthe house to the tomb, a distance of one chain, the procession was met\r\nby a certain man who was ardently attached to the deceased. He leaped\r\nupon the chiefs who were carrying the King\xe2\x80\x99s body; he desired to die\r\nwith him on account of his love. The chiefs drove him away. He persisted\r\nin making numerous attempts, which were unavailing. Kalaimoka also had\r\nit in his heart to die with him, but was prevented by Hookio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe morning following Kamehameha\xe2\x80\x99s death, Liholiho and his train\r\ndeparted for Kohala, according to the suggestions of the priest, to\r\navoid the defilement occasioned by the dead. At this time if a chief\r\ndied the land was polluted, and the heirs sought a residence in another\r\npart of the country until the corpse was dissected and the bones tied in\r\na bundle, which being done, the season of defilement terminated. If the\r\ndeceased were not a chief, the house only was defiled which became pure\r\nagain on the burial of the body. Such were the laws on this subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the morning on which Liholiho sailed in his canoe for Kohala, the\r\nchiefs and people mourned after their manner on occasion of a chief\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath, conducting themselves like madmen and like beasts. Their conduct\r\nwas such as to forbid description; The priests, also, put into action\r\nthe sorcery apparatus, that the person who had prayed the King to death\r\nmight die; for it was not believed that Kamehameha\xe2\x80\x99s departure was the\r\neffect either of sickness or old age. When the sorcerers set up by their\r\nfire-places stick with a strip of kapa flying at the top, the chief\r\nKeeaumoku, Kaahumaun\xe2\x80\x99s brother, came in a state of intoxication and\r\nbroke the flag-staff of the sorcerers, from which it was inferred that\r\nKaahumanu and her friends had been instrumental in the King\xe2\x80\x99s death. On\r\nthis account they were subjected to abuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYou have the contrast, now, and a strange one it is. This great Queen,\r\nKaahumanu, who was \xe2\x80\x9csubjected to abuse\xe2\x80\x9d during the frightful orgies that\r\nfollowed the King\xe2\x80\x99s death, in accordance with ancient custom, afterward\r\nbecame a devout Christian and a steadfast and powerful friend of the\r\nmissionaries.\r\n\r\nDogs were, and still are, reared and fattened for food, by the\r\nnatives\xe2\x80\x94hence the reference to their value in one of the above\r\nparagraphs.\r\n\r\nForty years ago it was the custom in the Islands to suspend all law for\r\na certain number of days after the death of a royal personage; and then\r\na saturnalia ensued which one may picture to himself after a fashion,\r\nbut not in the full horror of the reality. The people shaved their\r\nheads, knocked out a tooth or two, plucked out an eye sometimes, cut,\r\nbruised, mutilated or burned their flesh, got drunk, burned each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhuts, maimed or murdered one another according to the caprice of the\r\nmoment, and both sexes gave themselves up to brutal and unbridled\r\nlicentiousness.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n497.jpg (96K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd after it all, came a torpor from which the nation slowly emerged\r\nbewildered and dazed, as if from a hideous half-remembered nightmare.\r\nThey were not the salt of the earth, those \xe2\x80\x9cgentle children of the sun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe natives still keep up an old custom of theirs which cannot be\r\ncomforting to an invalid. When they think a sick friend is going to die,\r\na couple of dozen neighbors surround his hut and keep up a deafening\r\nwailing night and day till he either dies or gets well. No doubt this\r\narrangement has helped many a subject to a shroud before his appointed\r\ntime.\r\n\r\nThey surround a hut and wail in the same heart-broken way when its\r\noccupant returns from a journey. This is their dismal idea of a welcome.\r\nA very little of it would go a great way with most of us.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nBound for Hawaii (a hundred and fifty miles distant,) to visit the great\r\nvolcano and behold the other notable things which distinguish that\r\nisland above the remainder of the group, we sailed from Honolulu on a\r\ncertain Saturday afternoon, in the good schooner Boomerang.\r\n\r\nThe Boomerang was about as long as two street cars, and about as wide as\r\none. She was so small (though she was larger than the majority of the\r\ninter-island coasters) that when I stood on her deck I felt but little\r\nsmaller than the Colossus of Rhodes must have felt when he had a man-of-\r\nwar under him. I could reach the water when she lay over under a strong\r\nbreeze. When the Captain and my comrade (a Mr. Billings), myself and\r\nfour other persons were all assembled on the little after portion of the\r\ndeck which is sacred to the cabin passengers, it was full\xe2\x80\x94there was not\r\nroom for any more quality folks. Another section of the deck, twice as\r\nlarge as ours, was full of natives of both sexes, with their customary\r\ndogs, mats, blankets, pipes, calabashes of poi, fleas, and other\r\nluxuries and baggage of minor importance. As soon as we set sail the\r\nnatives all lay down on the deck as thick as negroes in a slave-pen, and\r\nsmoked, conversed, and spit on each other, and were truly sociable.\r\n\r\nThe little low-ceiled cabin below was rather larger than a hearse, and\r\nas dark as a vault. It had two coffins on each side\xe2\x80\x94I mean two bunks. A\r\nsmall table, capable of accommodating three persons at dinner, stood\r\nagainst the forward bulkhead, and over it hung the dingiest whale oil\r\nlantern that ever peopled the obscurity of a dungeon with ghostly\r\nshapes. The floor room unoccupied was not extensive. One might swing a\r\ncat in it, perhaps, but not a long cat. The hold forward of the bulkhead\r\nhad but little freight in it, and from morning till night a portly old\r\nrooster, with a voice like Baalam\xe2\x80\x99s ass, and the same disposition to use\r\nit, strutted up and down in that part of the vessel and crowed. He\r\nusually took dinner at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and then, after an hour devoted to\r\nmeditation, he mounted a barrel and crowed a good part of the night. He\r\ngot hoarser and hoarser all the time, but he scorned to allow any\r\npersonal consideration to interfere with his duty, and kept up his\r\nlabors in defiance of threatened diphtheria.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n499.jpg (19K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSleeping was out of the question when he was on watch. He was a source\r\nof genuine aggravation and annoyance. It was worse than useless to shout\r\nat him or apply offensive epithets to him\xe2\x80\x94he only took these things for\r\napplause, and strained himself to make more noise. Occasionally, during\r\nthe day, I threw potatoes at him through an aperture in the bulkhead,\r\nbut he only dodged and went on crowing.\r\n\r\nThe first night, as I lay in my coffin, idly watching the dim lamp\r\nswinging to the rolling of the ship, and snuffing the nauseous odors of\r\nbilge water, I felt something gallop over me. I turned out promptly.\r\nHowever, I turned in again when I found it was only a rat. Presently\r\nsomething galloped over me once more. I knew it was not a rat this time,\r\nand I thought it might be a centipede, because the Captain had killed\r\none on deck in the afternoon. I turned out. The first glance at the\r\npillow showed me repulsive sentinel perched upon each end of\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94cockroaches as large as peach leaves\xe2\x80\x94fellows with long, quivering\r\nantennae and fiery, malignant eyes. They were grating their teeth like\r\ntobacco worms, and appeared to be dissatisfied about something. I had\r\noften heard that these reptiles were in the habit of eating off sleeping\r\nsailors\xe2\x80\x99 toe nails down to the quick, and I would not get in the bunk\r\nany more. I lay down on the floor. But a rat came and bothered me, and\r\nshortly afterward a procession of cockroaches arrived and camped in my\r\nhair. In a few moments the rooster was crowing with uncommon spirit and\r\na party of fleas were throwing double somersaults about my person in the\r\nwildest disorder, and taking a bite every time they struck. I was\r\nbeginning to feel really annoyed. I got up and put my clothes on and\r\nwent on deck.\r\n\r\nThe above is not overdrawn; it is a truthful sketch of inter-island\r\nschooner life. There is no such thing as keeping a vessel in elegant\r\ncondition, when she carries molasses and Kanakas.\r\n\r\nIt was compensation for my sufferings to come unexpectedly upon so\r\nbeautiful a scene as met my eye\xe2\x80\x94to step suddenly out of the sepulchral\r\ngloom of the cabin and stand under the strong light of the moon\xe2\x80\x94in the\r\ncentre, as it were, of a glittering sea of liquid silver\xe2\x80\x94to see the\r\nbroad sails straining in the gale, the ship heeled over on her side, the\r\nangry foam hissing past her lee bulwarks, and sparkling sheets of spray\r\ndashing high over her bows and raining upon her decks; to brace myself\r\nand hang fast to the first object that presented itself, with hat jammed\r\ndown and coat tails whipping in the breeze, and feel that exhilaration\r\nthat thrills in one\xe2\x80\x99s hair and quivers down his back bone when he knows\r\nthat every inch of canvas is drawing and the vessel cleaving through the\r\nwaves at her utmost speed. There was no darkness, no dimness, no\r\nobscurity there. All was brightness, every object was vividly defined.\r\nEvery prostrate Kanaka; every coil of rope; every calabash of poi; every\r\npuppy; every seam in the flooring; every bolthead; every object; however\r\nminute, showed sharp and distinct in its every outline; and the shadow\r\nof the broad mainsail lay black as a pall upon the deck, leaving\r\nBillings\xe2\x80\x99s white upturned face glorified and his body in a total\r\neclipse.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n501.jpg (93K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMonday morning we were close to the island of Hawaii. Two of its high\r\nmountains were in view\xe2\x80\x94Mauna Loa and Hualaiai. The latter is an imposing\r\npeak, but being only ten thousand feet high is seldom mentioned or heard\r\nof. Mauna Loa is said to be sixteen thousand feet high. The rays of\r\nglittering snow and ice, that clasped its summit like a claw, looked\r\nrefreshing when viewed from the blistering climate we were in. One could\r\nstand on that mountain (wrapped up in blankets and furs to keep warm),\r\nand while he nibbled a snowball or an icicle to quench his thirst he\r\ncould look down the long sweep of its sides and see spots where plants\r\nare growing that grow only where the bitter cold of Winter prevails;\r\nlower down he could see sections devoted to production that thrive in\r\nthe temperate zone alone; and at the bottom of the mountain he could see\r\nthe home of the tufted cocoa-palms and other species of vegetation that\r\ngrow only in the sultry atmosphere of eternal Summer. He could see all\r\nthe climes of the world at a single glance of the eye, and that glance\r\nwould only pass over a distance of four or five miles as the bird flies!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n502.jpg (162K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBy and by we took boat and went ashore at Kailua, designing to ride\r\nhorseback through the pleasant orange and coffee region of Kona, and\r\nrejoin the vessel at a point some leagues distant. This journey is well\r\nworth taking. The trail passes along on high ground\xe2\x80\x94say a thousand feet\r\nabove sea level\xe2\x80\x94and usually about a mile distant from the ocean, which\r\nis always in sight, save that occasionally you find yourself buried in\r\nthe forest in the midst of a rank tropical vegetation and a dense growth\r\nof trees, whose great bows overarch the road and shut out sun and sea\r\nand everything, and leave you in a dim, shady tunnel, haunted with\r\ninvisible singing birds and fragrant with the odor of flowers. It was\r\npleasant to ride occasionally in the warm sun, and feast the eye upon\r\nthe ever-changing panorama of the forest (beyond and below us), with its\r\nmany tints, its softened lights and shadows, its billowy undulations\r\nsweeping gently down from the mountain to the sea. It was pleasant also,\r\nat intervals, to leave the sultry sun and pass into the cool, green\r\ndepths of this forest and indulge in sentimental reflections under the\r\ninspiration of its brooding twilight and its whispering foliage. We rode\r\nthrough one orange grove that had ten thousand trees in it! They were\r\nall laden with fruit.\r\n\r\nAt one farmhouse we got some large peaches of excellent flavor. This\r\nfruit, as a general thing, does not do well in the Sandwich Islands. It\r\ntakes a sort of almond shape, and is small and bitter. It needs frost,\r\nthey say, and perhaps it does; if this be so, it will have a good\r\nopportunity to go on needing it, as it will not be likely to get it. The\r\ntrees from which the fine fruit I have spoken of, came, had been planted\r\nand replanted _sixteen times_, and to this treatment the proprietor of\r\nthe orchard attributed his success.\r\n\r\nWe passed several sugar plantations\xe2\x80\x94new ones and not very extensive. The\r\ncrops were, in most cases, third rattoons. [NOTE.\xe2\x80\x94The first crop is\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cplant cane;\xe2\x80\x9d subsequent crops which spring from the original\r\nroots, without replanting, are called \xe2\x80\x9crattoons.\xe2\x80\x9d] Almost everywhere on\r\nthe island of Hawaii sugar-cane matures in twelve months, both rattoons\r\nand plant, and although it ought to be taken off as soon as it tassels,\r\nno doubt, it is not absolutely necessary to do it until about four\r\nmonths afterward. In Kona, the average yield of an acre of ground is\r\n_two tons_ of sugar, they say. This is only a moderate yield for these\r\nislands, but would be astounding for Louisiana and most other sugar\r\ngrowing countries. The plantations in Kona being on pretty high\r\nground\xe2\x80\x94up among the light and frequent rains\xe2\x80\x94no irrigation whatever is\r\nrequired.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n503.jpg (55K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXX.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe stopped some time at one of the plantations, to rest ourselves and\r\nrefresh the horses. We had a chatty conversation with several gentlemen\r\npresent; but there was one person, a middle aged man, with an absent\r\nlook in his face, who simply glanced up, gave us good-day and lapsed\r\nagain into the meditations which our coming had interrupted. The\r\nplanters whispered us not to mind him\xe2\x80\x94crazy. They said he was in the\r\nIslands for his health; was a preacher; his home, Michigan. They said\r\nthat if he woke up presently and fell to talking about a correspondence\r\nwhich he had some time held with Mr. Greeley about a trifle of some\r\nkind, we must humor him and listen with interest; and we must humor his\r\nfancy that this correspondence was the talk of the world.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n505.jpg (46K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was easy to see that he was a gentle creature and that his madness\r\nhad nothing vicious in it. He looked pale, and a little worn, as if with\r\nperplexing thought and anxiety of mind. He sat a long time, looking at\r\nthe floor, and at intervals muttering to himself and nodding his head\r\nacquiescingly or shaking it in mild protest. He was lost in his thought,\r\nor in his memories. We continued our talk with the planters, branching\r\nfrom subject to subject. But at last the word \xe2\x80\x9ccircumstance,\xe2\x80\x9d casually\r\ndropped, in the course of conversation, attracted his attention and\r\nbrought an eager look into his countenance. He faced about in his chair\r\nand said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCircumstance? What circumstance? Ah, I know\xe2\x80\x94I know too well. So you\r\nhave heard of it too.\xe2\x80\x9d [With a sigh.] \xe2\x80\x9cWell, no matter\xe2\x80\x94all the world has\r\nheard of it. All the world. The whole world. It is a large world, too,\r\nfor a thing to travel so far in\xe2\x80\x94now isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Yes, yes\xe2\x80\x94the Greeley\r\ncorrespondence with Erickson has created the saddest and bitterest\r\ncontroversy on both sides of the ocean\xe2\x80\x94and still they keep it up! It\r\nmakes us famous, but at what a sorrowful sacrifice! I was so sorry when\r\nI heard that it had caused that bloody and distressful war over there in\r\nItaly. It was little comfort to me, after so much bloodshed, to know\r\nthat the victors sided with me, and the vanquished with Greeley.\xe2\x80\x94It is\r\nlittle comfort to know that Horace Greeley is responsible for the battle\r\nof Sadowa, and not me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQueen Victoria wrote me that she felt just as I did about it\xe2\x80\x94she said\r\nthat as much as she was opposed to Greeley and the spirit he showed in\r\nthe correspondence with me, she would not have had Sadowa happen for\r\nhundreds of dollars. I can show you her letter, if you would like to see\r\nit. But gentlemen, much as you may think you know about that unhappy\r\ncorrespondence, you cannot know the _straight_ of it till you hear it\r\nfrom my lips. It has always been garbled in the journals, and even in\r\nhistory. Yes, even in history\xe2\x80\x94think of it! Let me\xe2\x80\x94_please_ let me, give\r\nyou the matter, exactly as it occurred. I truly will not abuse your\r\nconfidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he leaned forward, all interest, all earnestness, and told his\r\nstory\xe2\x80\x94and told it appealingly, too, and yet in the simplest and most\r\nunpretentious way; indeed, in such a way as to suggest to one, all the\r\ntime, that this was a faithful, honorable witness, giving evidence in\r\nthe sacred interest of justice, and under oath. He said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Beazeley\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Jackson Beazeley, widow, of the village of\r\nCampbellton, Kansas,\xe2\x80\x94wrote me about a matter which was near her heart\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nmatter which many might think trivial, but to her it was a thing of deep\r\nconcern. I was living in Michigan, then\xe2\x80\x94serving in the ministry. She\r\nwas, and is, an estimable woman\xe2\x80\x94a woman to whom poverty and hardship\r\nhave proven incentives to industry, in place of discouragements. Her\r\nonly treasure was her son William, a youth just verging upon manhood;\r\nreligious, amiable, and sincerely attached to agriculture. He was the\r\nwidow\xe2\x80\x99s comfort and her pride. And so, moved by her love for him, she\r\nwrote me about a matter, as I have said before, which lay near her\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x94because it lay near her boy\xe2\x80\x99s. She desired me to confer with Mr.\r\nGreeley about turnips. Turnips were the dream of her child\xe2\x80\x99s young\r\nambition. While other youths were frittering away in frivolous\r\namusements the precious years of budding vigor which God had given them\r\nfor useful preparation, this boy was patiently enriching his mind with\r\ninformation concerning turnips. The sentiment which he felt toward the\r\nturnip was akin to adoration. He could not think of the turnip without\r\nemotion; he could not speak of it calmly; he could not contemplate it\r\nwithout exaltation. He could not eat it without shedding tears. All the\r\npoetry in his sensitive nature was in sympathy with the gracious\r\nvegetable. With the earliest pipe of dawn he sought his patch, and when\r\nthe curtaining night drove him from it he shut himself up with his books\r\nand garnered statistics till sleep overcame him. On rainy days he sat\r\nand talked hours together with his mother about turnips. When company\r\ncame, he made it his loving duty to put aside everything else and\r\nconverse with them all the day long of his great joy in the turnip.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n507.jpg (67K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, was this joy rounded and complete? Was there no secret alloy\r\nof unhappiness in it? Alas, there was. There was a canker gnawing at his\r\nheart; the noblest inspiration of his soul eluded his endeavor\xe2\x80\x94viz: he\r\ncould not make of the turnip a climbing vine. Months went by; the bloom\r\nforsook his cheek, the fire faded out of his eye; sighings and\r\nabstraction usurped the place of smiles and cheerful converse. But a\r\nwatchful eye noted these things and in time a motherly sympathy unsealed\r\nthe secret. Hence the letter to me. She pleaded for attention\xe2\x80\x94she said\r\nher boy was dying by inches.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was a stranger to Mr. Greeley, but what of that? The matter was\r\nurgent. I wrote and begged him to solve the difficult problem if\r\npossible and save the student\xe2\x80\x99s life. My interest grew, until it partook\r\nof the anxiety of the mother. I waited in much suspense.\xe2\x80\x94At last the\r\nanswer came.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n509.jpg (127K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI found that I could not read it readily, the handwriting being\r\nunfamiliar and my emotions somewhat wrought up. It seemed to refer in\r\npart to the boy\xe2\x80\x99s case, but chiefly to other and irrelevant matters\xe2\x80\x94such\r\nas paving-stones, electricity, oysters, and something which I took to be\r\n\xe2\x80\x98absolution\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98agrarianism,\xe2\x80\x99 I could not be certain which; still,\r\nthese appeared to be simply casual mentions, nothing more; friendly in\r\nspirit, without doubt, but lacking the connection or coherence necessary\r\nto make them useful.\xe2\x80\x94I judged that my understanding was affected by my\r\nfeelings, and so laid the letter away till morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the morning I read it again, but with difficulty and uncertainty\r\nstill, for I had lost some little rest and my mental vision seemed\r\nclouded. The note was more connected, now, but did not meet the\r\nemergency it was expected to meet. It was too discursive. It appeared to\r\nread as follows, though I was not certain of some of the words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPolygamy dissembles majesty; extracts redeem polarity; causes hitherto\r\nexist. Ovations pursue wisdom, or warts inherit and condemn. Boston,\r\nbotany, cakes, folony undertakes, but who shall allay? We fear not.\r\nYrxwly, HEVACE EVEELOJ.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut there did not seem to be a word about turnips. There seemed to be\r\nno suggestion as to how they might be made to grow like vines. There was\r\nnot even a reference to the Beazeleys. I slept upon the matter; I ate no\r\nsupper, neither any breakfast next morning. So I resumed my work with a\r\nbrain refreshed, and was very hopeful. _Now_ the letter took a different\r\naspect\xe2\x80\x94all save the signature, which latter I judged to be only a\r\nharmless affectation of Hebrew. The epistle was necessarily from Mr.\r\nGreeley, for it bore the printed heading of The _Tribune_, and I had\r\nwritten to no one else there. The letter, I say, had taken a different\r\naspect, but still its language was eccentric and avoided the issue. It\r\nnow appeared to say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBolivia extemporizes mackerel; borax esteems polygamy; sausages wither\r\nin the east. Creation perdu, is done; for woes inherent one can damn.\r\nButtons, buttons, corks, geology underrates but we shall allay. My\r\nbeer\xe2\x80\x99s out. Yrxwly, HEVACE EVEELOJ.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was evidently overworked. My comprehension was impaired. Therefore I\r\ngave two days to recreation, and then returned to my task greatly\r\nrefreshed. The letter now took this form:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoultices do sometimes choke swine; tulips reduce posterity; causes\r\nleather to resist. Our notions empower wisdom, her let\xe2\x80\x99s afford while we\r\ncan. Butter but any cakes, fill any undertaker, we\xe2\x80\x99ll wean him from his\r\nfilly. We feel hot. Yrxwly, HEVACE EVEELOJ.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was still not satisfied. These generalities did not meet the\r\nquestion. They were crisp, and vigorous, and delivered with a confidence\r\nthat almost compelled conviction; but at such a time as this, with a\r\nhuman life at stake, they seemed inappropriate, worldly, and in bad\r\ntaste. At any other time I would have been not only glad, but proud, to\r\nreceive from a man like Mr. Greeley a letter of this kind, and would\r\nhave studied it earnestly and tried to improve myself all I could; but\r\nnow, with that poor boy in his far home languishing for relief, I had no\r\nheart for learning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree days passed by, and I read the note again. Again its tenor had\r\nchanged. It now appeared to say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPotations do sometimes wake wines; turnips restrain passion; causes\r\nnecessary to state. Infest the poor widow; her lord\xe2\x80\x99s effects will be\r\nvoid. But dirt, bathing, etc., etc., followed unfairly, will worm him\r\nfrom his folly\xe2\x80\x94so swear not. Yrxwly, HEVACE EVEELOJ.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was more like it. But I was unable to proceed. I was too much\r\nworn. The word \xe2\x80\x98turnips\xe2\x80\x99 brought temporary joy and encouragement, but my\r\nstrength was so much impaired, and the delay might be so perilous for\r\nthe boy, that I relinquished the idea of pursuing the translation\r\nfurther, and resolved to do what I ought to have done at first. I sat\r\ndown and wrote Mr. Greeley as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDEAR SIR: I fear I do not entirely comprehend your kind note. It cannot\r\nbe possible, Sir, that \xe2\x80\x98turnips restrain passion\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94at least the study or\r\ncontemplation of turnips cannot\xe2\x80\x94for it is this very employment that has\r\nscorched our poor friend\xe2\x80\x99s mind and sapped his bodily strength.\xe2\x80\x94But if\r\nthey do restrain it, will you bear with us a little further and explain\r\nhow they should be prepared? I observe that you say \xe2\x80\x98causes necessary to\r\nstate,\xe2\x80\x99 but you have omitted to state them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder a misapprehension, you seem to attribute to me interested motives\r\nin this matter\xe2\x80\x94to call it by no harsher term. But I assure you, dear\r\nsir, that if I seem to be \xe2\x80\x98infesting the widow,\xe2\x80\x99 it is all seeming, and\r\nvoid of reality. It is from no seeking of mine that I am in this\r\nposition. She asked me, herself, to write you. I never have infested\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94indeed I scarcely know her. I do not infest anybody. I try to go\r\nalong, in my humble way, doing as near right as I can, never harming\r\nanybody, and never throwing out insinuations. As for \xe2\x80\x98her lord and his\r\neffects,\xe2\x80\x99 they are of no interest to me. I trust I have effects enough\r\nof my own\xe2\x80\x94shall endeavor to get along with them, at any rate, and not go\r\nmousing around to get hold of somebody\xe2\x80\x99s that are \xe2\x80\x98void.\xe2\x80\x99 But do you not\r\nsee?\xe2\x80\x94this woman is a widow\xe2\x80\x94she has no \xe2\x80\x98lord.\xe2\x80\x99 He is dead\xe2\x80\x94or pretended to\r\nbe, when they buried him. Therefore, no amount of \xe2\x80\x98dirt, bathing,\xe2\x80\x99 etc.,\r\netc., howsoever \xe2\x80\x98unfairly followed\xe2\x80\x99 will be likely to \xe2\x80\x98worm him from his\r\nfolly\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94if being dead and a ghost is \xe2\x80\x98folly.\xe2\x80\x99 Your closing remark is as\r\nunkind as it was uncalled for; and if report says true you might have\r\napplied it to yourself, sir, with more point and less impropriety. Very\r\nTruly Yours, SIMON ERICKSON.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the course of a few days, Mr. Greely did what would have saved a\r\nworld of trouble, and much mental and bodily suffering and\r\nmisunderstanding, if he had done it sooner. To wit, he sent an\r\nintelligible rescript or translation of his original note, made in a\r\nplain hand by his clerk. Then the mystery cleared, and I saw that his\r\nheart had been right, all the time. I will recite the note in its\r\nclarified form:\r\n\r\n[Translation.] \xe2\x80\x98Potatoes do sometimes make vines; turnips remain\r\npassive: cause unnecessary to state. Inform the poor widow her lad\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nefforts will be vain. But diet, bathing, etc. etc., followed uniformly,\r\nwill wean him from his folly\xe2\x80\x94so fear not. Yours, HORACE GREELEY.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut alas, it was too late, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94too late. The criminal delay had\r\ndone its work\xe2\x80\x94young Beazely was no more. His spirit had taken its flight\r\nto a land where all anxieties shall be charmed away, all desires\r\ngratified, all ambitions realized. Poor lad, they laid him to his rest\r\nwith a turnip in each hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo ended Erickson, and lapsed again into nodding, mumbling, and\r\nabstraction. The company broke up, and left him so.... But they did not\r\nsay what drove him crazy. In the momentary confusion, I forgot to ask.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon we were winding down a mountain of\r\ndreary and desolate lava to the sea, and closing our pleasant land\r\njourney. This lava is the accumulation of ages; one torrent of fire\r\nafter another has rolled down here in old times, and built up the island\r\nstructure higher and higher. Underneath, it is honey-combed with caves;\r\nit would be of no use to dig wells in such a place; they would not hold\r\nwater\xe2\x80\x94you would not find any for them to hold, for that matter.\r\nConsequently, the planters depend upon cisterns.\r\n\r\nThe last lava flow occurred here so long ago that there are none now\r\nliving who witnessed it. In one place it enclosed and burned down a\r\ngrove of cocoa-nut trees, and the holes in the lava where the trunks\r\nstood are still visible; their sides retain the impression of the bark;\r\nthe trees fell upon the burning river, and becoming partly submerged,\r\nleft in it the perfect counterpart of every knot and branch and leaf,\r\nand even nut, for curiosity seekers of a long distant day to gaze upon\r\nand wonder at.\r\n\r\nThere were doubtless plenty of Kanaka sentinels on guard hereabouts at\r\nthat time, but they did not leave casts of their figures in the lava as\r\nthe Roman sentinels at Herculaneum and Pompeii did. It is a pity it is\r\nso, because such things are so interesting; but so it is. They probably\r\nwent away. They went away early, perhaps. However, they had their\r\nmerits; the Romans exhibited the higher pluck, but the Kanakas showed\r\nthe sounder judgment.\r\n\r\nShortly we came in sight of that spot whose history is so familiar to\r\nevery school-boy in the wide world\xe2\x80\x94_Kealakekua_ Bay\xe2\x80\x94the place where\r\nCaptain Cook, the great circumnavigator, was killed by the natives,\r\nnearly a hundred years ago. The setting sun was flaming upon it, a\r\nSummer shower was falling, and it was spanned by two magnificent\r\nrainbows. Two men who were in advance of us rode through one of these\r\nand for a moment their garments shone with a more than regal splendor.\r\nWhy did not Captain Cook have taste enough to call his great discovery\r\nthe Rainbow Islands? These charming spectacles are present to you at\r\nevery turn; they are common in all the islands; they are visible every\r\nday, and frequently at night also\xe2\x80\x94not the silvery bow we see once in an\r\nage in the States, by moonlight, but barred with all bright and\r\nbeautiful colors, like the children of the sun and rain. I saw one of\r\nthem a few nights ago. What the sailors call \xe2\x80\x9craindogs\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94little patches\r\nof rainbow\xe2\x80\x94are often seen drifting about the heavens in these latitudes,\r\nlike stained cathedral windows.\r\n\r\n_Kealakekua_ Bay is a little curve like the last kink of a snail-shell,\r\nwinding deep into the land, seemingly not more than a mile wide from\r\nshore to shore. It is bounded on one side\xe2\x80\x94where the murder was done\xe2\x80\x94by a\r\nlittle flat plain, on which stands a cocoanut grove and some ruined\r\nhouses; a steep wall of lava, a thousand feet high at the upper end and\r\nthree or four hundred at the lower, comes down from the mountain and\r\nbounds the inner extremity of it.
