From this wall the place takes its\r\nname, _Kealakekua_, which in the native tongue signifies \xe2\x80\x9cThe Pathway of\r\nthe Gods.\xe2\x80\x9d They say, (and still believe, in spite of their liberal\r\neducation in Christianity), that the great god _Lono_, who used to live\r\nupon the hillside, always traveled that causeway when urgent business\r\nconnected with heavenly affairs called him down to the seashore in a\r\nhurry.\r\n\r\nAs the red sun looked across the placid ocean through the tall, clean\r\nstems of the cocoanut trees, like a blooming whiskey bloat through the\r\nbars of a city prison, I went and stood in the edge of the water on the\r\nflat rock pressed by Captain Cook\xe2\x80\x99s feet when the blow was dealt which\r\ntook away his life, and tried to picture in my mind the doomed man\r\nstruggling in the midst of the multitude of exasperated savages\xe2\x80\x94the men\r\nin the ship crowding to the vessel\xe2\x80\x99s side and gazing in anxious dismay\r\ntoward the shore\xe2\x80\x94the\xe2\x80\x94but I discovered that I could not do it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n514.jpg (93K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was growing dark, the rain began to fall, we could see that the\r\ndistant Boomerang was helplessly becalmed at sea, and so I adjourned to\r\nthe cheerless little box of a warehouse and sat down to smoke and think,\r\nand wish the ship would make the land\xe2\x80\x94for we had not eaten much for ten\r\nhours and were viciously hungry.\r\n\r\nPlain unvarnished history takes the romance out of Captain Cook\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nassassination, and renders a deliberate verdict of justifiable homicide.\r\nWherever he went among the islands, he was cordially received and\r\nwelcomed by the inhabitants, and his ships lavishly supplied with all\r\nmanner of food. He returned these kindnesses with insult and ill-\r\ntreatment. Perceiving that the people took him for the long vanished and\r\nlamented god _Lono_, he encouraged them in the delusion for the sake of\r\nthe limitless power it gave him; but during the famous disturbance at\r\nthis spot, and while he and his comrades were surrounded by fifteen\r\nthousand maddened savages, he received a hurt and betrayed his earthly\r\norigin with a groan. It was his death-warrant. Instantly a shout went\r\nup: \xe2\x80\x9cHe groans!\xe2\x80\x94he is not a god!\xe2\x80\x9d So they closed in upon him and\r\ndispatched him.\r\n\r\nHis flesh was stripped from the bones and burned (except nine pounds of\r\nit which were sent on board the ships). The heart was hung up in a\r\nnative hut, where it was found and eaten by three children, who mistook\r\nit for the heart of a dog. One of these children grew to be a very old\r\nman, and died in Honolulu a few years ago. Some of Cook\xe2\x80\x99s bones were\r\nrecovered and consigned to the deep by the officers of the ships.\r\n\r\nSmall blame should attach to the natives for the killing of Cook. They\r\ntreated him well. In return, he abused them. He and his men inflicted\r\nbodily injury upon many of them at different times, and killed at least\r\nthree of them before they offered any proportionate retaliation.\r\n\r\nNear the shore we found \xe2\x80\x9cCook\xe2\x80\x99s Monument\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94only a cocoanut stump, four\r\nfeet high and about a foot in diameter at the butt. It had lava boulders\r\npiled around its base to hold it up and keep it in its place, and it was\r\nentirely sheathed over, from top to bottom, with rough, discolored\r\nsheets of copper, such as ships\xe2\x80\x99 bottoms are coppered with. Each sheet\r\nhad a rude inscription scratched upon it\xe2\x80\x94with a nail, apparently\xe2\x80\x94and in\r\nevery case the execution was wretched. Most of these merely recorded the\r\nvisits of British naval commanders to the spot, but one of them bore\r\nthis legend:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear this spot fell CAPTAIN JAMES COOK, The Distinguished\r\nCircumnavigator, who Discovered these Islands A. D. 1778.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter Cook\xe2\x80\x99s murder, his second in command, on board the ship, opened\r\nfire upon the swarms of natives on the beach, and one of his cannon\r\nballs cut this cocoanut tree short off and left this monumental stump\r\nstanding. It looked sad and lonely enough to us, out there in the rainy\r\ntwilight. But there is no other monument to Captain Cook. True, up on\r\nthe mountain side we had passed by a large inclosure like an ample hog-\r\npen, built of lava blocks, which marks the spot where Cook\xe2\x80\x99s flesh was\r\nstripped from his bones and burned; but this is not properly a monument\r\nsince it was erected by the natives themselves, and less to do honor to\r\nthe circumnavigator than for the sake of convenience in roasting him. A\r\nthing like a guide-board was elevated above this pen on a tall pole, and\r\nformerly there was an inscription upon it describing the memorable\r\noccurrence that had there taken place; but the sun and the wind have\r\nlong ago so defaced it as to render it illegible.\r\n\r\nToward midnight a fine breeze sprang up and the schooner soon worked\r\nherself into the bay and cast anchor. The boat came ashore for us, and\r\nin a little while the clouds and the rain were all gone. The moon was\r\nbeaming tranquilly down on land and sea, and we two were stretched upon\r\nthe deck sleeping the refreshing sleep and dreaming the happy dreams\r\nthat are only vouchsafed to the weary and the innocent.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the breezy morning we went ashore and visited the ruined temple of\r\nthe last god _Lono_. The high chief cook of this temple\xe2\x80\x94the priest who\r\npresided over it and roasted the human sacrifices\xe2\x80\x94was uncle to Obookia,\r\nand at one time that youth was an apprentice-priest under him. Obookia\r\nwas a young native of fine mind, who, together with three other native\r\nboys, was taken to New England by the captain of a whaleship during the\r\nreign of Kamehameha I, and they were the means of attracting the\r\nattention of the religious world to their country. This resulted in the\r\nsending of missionaries there. And this Obookia was the very same\r\nsensitive savage who sat down on the church steps and wept because his\r\npeople did not have the Bible. That incident has been very elaborately\r\npainted in many a charming Sunday School book\xe2\x80\x94aye, and told so\r\nplaintively and so tenderly that I have cried over it in Sunday School\r\nmyself, on general principles, although at a time when I did not know\r\nmuch and could not understand why the people of the Sandwich Islands\r\nneeded to worry so much about it as long as they did not know there was\r\na Bible at all.\r\n\r\nObookia was converted and educated, and was to have returned to his\r\nnative land with the first missionaries, had he lived. The other native\r\nyouths made the voyage, and two of them did good service, but the third,\r\nWilliam Kanui, fell from grace afterward, for a time, and when the gold\r\nexcitement broke out in California he journeyed thither and went to\r\nmining, although he was fifty years old. He succeeded pretty well, but\r\nthe failure of Page, Bacon & Co. relieved him of six thousand dollars,\r\nand then, to all intents and purposes, he was a bankrupt in his old age\r\nand he resumed service in the pulpit again. He died in Honolulu in 1864.\r\n\r\nQuite a broad tract of land near the temple, extending from the sea to\r\nthe mountain top, was sacred to the god _Lono_ in olden times\xe2\x80\x94so sacred\r\nthat if a common native set his sacrilegious foot upon it it was\r\njudicious for him to make his will, because his time had come. He might\r\ngo around it by water, but he could not cross it. It was well sprinkled\r\nwith pagan temples and stocked with awkward, homely idols carved out of\r\nlogs of wood. There was a temple devoted to prayers for rain\xe2\x80\x94and with\r\nfine sagacity it was placed at a point so well up on the mountain side\r\nthat if you prayed there twenty-four times a day for rain you would be\r\nlikely to get it every time. You would seldom get to your Amen before\r\nyou would have to hoist your umbrella.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n518.jpg (54K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd there was a large temple near at hand which was built in a single\r\nnight, in the midst of storm and thunder and rain, by the ghastly hands\r\nof dead men! Tradition says that by the weird glare of the lightning a\r\nnoiseless multitude of phantoms were seen at their strange labor far up\r\nthe mountain side at dead of night\xe2\x80\x94flitting hither and thither and\r\nbearing great lava-blocks clasped in their nerveless fingers\xe2\x80\x94appearing\r\nand disappearing as the pallid lustre fell upon their forms and faded\r\naway again. Even to this day, it is said, the natives hold this dread\r\nstructure in awe and reverence, and will not pass by it in the night.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n519.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt noon I observed a bevy of nude native young ladies bathing in the\r\nsea, and went and sat down on their clothes to keep them from being\r\nstolen. I begged them to come out, for the sea was rising and I was\r\nsatisfied that they were running some risk. But they were not afraid,\r\nand presently went on with their sport. They were finished swimmers and\r\ndivers, and enjoyed themselves to the last degree.\r\n\r\nThey swam races, splashed and ducked and tumbled each other about, and\r\nfilled the air with their laughter. It is said that the first thing an\r\nIslander learns is how to swim; learning to walk being a matter of\r\nsmaller consequence, comes afterward. One hears tales of native men and\r\nwomen swimming ashore from vessels many miles at sea\xe2\x80\x94more miles, indeed,\r\nthan I dare vouch for or even mention. And they tell of a native diver\r\nwho went down in thirty or forty-foot waters and brought up an anvil! I\r\nthink he swallowed the anvil afterward, if my memory serves me. However\r\nI will not urge this point.\r\n\r\nI have spoken, several times, of the god _Lono_\xe2\x80\x94I may as well furnish\r\ntwo or three sentences concerning him.\r\n\r\nThe idol the natives worshipped for him was a slender, unornamented\r\nstaff twelve feet long. Tradition says he was a favorite god on the\r\nIsland of Hawaii\xe2\x80\x94a great king who had been deified for meritorious\r\nservices\xe2\x80\x94just our own fashion of rewarding heroes, with the difference\r\nthat we would have made him a Postmaster instead of a god, no doubt. In\r\nan angry moment he slew his wife, a goddess named Kaikilani Aiii.\r\nRemorse of conscience drove him mad, and tradition presents us the\r\nsingular spectacle of a god traveling \xe2\x80\x9con the shoulder;\xe2\x80\x9d for in his\r\ngnawing grief he wandered about from place to place boxing and wrestling\r\nwith all whom he met. Of course this pastime soon lost its novelty,\r\ninasmuch as it must necessarily have been the case that when so powerful\r\na deity sent a frail human opponent \xe2\x80\x9cto grass\xe2\x80\x9d he never came back any\r\nmore. Therefore, he instituted games called makahiki, and ordered that\r\nthey should be held in his honor, and then sailed for foreign lands on a\r\nthree-cornered raft, stating that he would return some day\xe2\x80\x94and that was\r\nthe last of _Lono_. He was never seen any more; his raft got swamped,\r\nperhaps. But the people always expected his return, and thus they were\r\neasily led to accept Captain Cook as the restored god.\r\n\r\nSome of the old natives believed Cook was _Lono_ to the day of their\r\ndeath; but many did not, for they could not understand how he could die\r\nif he was a god.\r\n\r\nOnly a mile or so from _Kealakekua_ Bay is a spot of historic\r\ninterest\xe2\x80\x94the place where the last battle was fought for idolatry. Of\r\ncourse we visited it, and came away as wise as most people do who go and\r\ngaze upon such mementoes of the past when in an unreflective mood.\r\n\r\nWhile the first missionaries were on their way around the Horn, the\r\nidolatrous customs which had obtained in the island, as far back as\r\ntradition reached were suddenly broken up. Old Kamehameha I., was dead,\r\nand his son, Liholiho, the new King was a free liver, a roystering,\r\ndissolute fellow, and hated the restraints of the ancient _tabu_. His\r\nassistant in the Government, Kaahumanu, the Queen dowager, was proud and\r\nhigh-spirited, and hated the _tabu_ because it restricted the privileges\r\nof her sex and degraded all women very nearly to the level of brutes. So\r\nthe case stood. Liholiho had half a mind to put his foot down, Kaahumahu\r\nhad a whole mind to badger him into doing it, and whiskey did the rest.\r\nIt was probably the rest. It was probably the first time whiskey ever\r\nprominently figured as an aid to civilization. Liholiho came up to\r\nKailua as drunk as a piper, and attended a great feast; the determined\r\nQueen spurred his drunken courage up to a reckless pitch, and then,\r\nwhile all the multitude stared in blank dismay, he moved deliberately\r\nforward and sat down with the women!\r\n\r\nThey saw him eat from the same vessel with them, and were appalled!\r\nTerrible moments drifted slowly by, and still the King ate, still he\r\nlived, still the lightnings of the insulted gods were withheld! Then\r\nconviction came like a revelation\xe2\x80\x94the superstitions of a hundred\r\ngenerations passed from before the people like a cloud, and a shout went\r\nup, \xe2\x80\x9cthe _tabu_ is broken! the _tabu_ is broken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n521.jpg (100K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThus did King Liholiho and his dreadful whiskey preach the first sermon\r\nand prepare the way for the new gospel that was speeding southward over\r\nthe waves of the Atlantic.\r\n\r\nThe _tabu_ broken and destruction failing to follow the awful sacrilege,\r\nthe people, with that childlike precipitancy which has always\r\ncharacterized them, jumped to the conclusion that their gods were a weak\r\nand wretched swindle, just as they formerly jumped to the conclusion\r\nthat Captain Cook was no god, merely because he groaned, and promptly\r\nkilled him without stopping to inquire whether a god might not groan as\r\nwell as a man if it suited his convenience to do it; and satisfied that\r\nthe idols were powerless to protect themselves they went to work at once\r\nand pulled them down\xe2\x80\x94hacked them to pieces\xe2\x80\x94applied the torch\xe2\x80\x94annihilated\r\nthem!\r\n\r\nThe pagan priests were furious. And well they might be; they had held\r\nthe fattest offices in the land, and now they were beggared; they had\r\nbeen great\xe2\x80\x94they had stood above the chiefs\xe2\x80\x94and now they were vagabonds.\r\nThey raised a revolt; they scared a number of people into joining their\r\nstandard, and Bekuokalani, an ambitious offshoot of royalty, was easily\r\npersuaded to become their leader.\r\n\r\nIn the first skirmish the idolaters triumphed over the royal army sent\r\nagainst them, and full of confidence they resolved to march upon Kailua.\r\nThe King sent an envoy to try and conciliate them, and came very near\r\nbeing an envoy short by the operation; the savages not only refused to\r\nlisten to him, but wanted to kill him. So the King sent his men forth\r\nunder Major General Kalaimoku and the two host met a Kuamoo. The battle\r\nwas long and fierce\xe2\x80\x94men and women fighting side by side, as was the\r\ncustom\xe2\x80\x94and when the day was done the rebels were flying in every\r\ndirection in hopeless panic, and idolatry and the _tabu_ were dead in\r\nthe land!\r\n\r\nThe royalists marched gayly home to Kailua glorifying the new\r\ndispensation. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no power in the gods,\xe2\x80\x9d said they; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are a\r\nvanity and a lie. The army with idols was weak; the army without idols\r\nwas strong and victorious!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe nation was without a religion.\r\n\r\nThe missionary ship arrived in safety shortly afterward, timed by\r\nprovidential exactness to meet the emergency, and the Gospel was planted\r\nas in a virgin soil.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n523.jpg (57K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt noon, we hired a Kanaka to take us down to the ancient ruins at\r\nHonaunau in his canoe\xe2\x80\x94price two dollars\xe2\x80\x94reasonable enough, for a sea\r\nvoyage of eight miles, counting both ways.\r\n\r\nThe native canoe is an irresponsible looking contrivance. I cannot think\r\nof anything to liken it to but a boy\xe2\x80\x99s sled runner hollowed out, and\r\nthat does not quite convey the correct idea. It is about fifteen feet\r\nlong, high and pointed at both ends, is a foot and a half or two feet\r\ndeep, and so narrow that if you wedged a fat man into it you might not\r\nget him out again. It sits on top of the water like a duck, but it has\r\nan outrigger and does not upset easily, if you keep still. This\r\noutrigger is formed of two long bent sticks like plow handles, which\r\nproject from one side, and to their outer ends is bound a curved beam\r\ncomposed of an extremely light wood, which skims along the surface of\r\nthe water and thus saves you from an upset on that side, while the\r\noutrigger\xe2\x80\x99s weight is not so easily lifted as to make an upset on the\r\nother side a thing to be greatly feared. Still, until one gets used to\r\nsitting perched upon this knifeblade, he is apt to reason within himself\r\nthat it would be more comfortable if there were just an outrigger or so\r\non the other side also. I had the bow seat, and Billings sat amidships\r\nand faced the Kanaka, who occupied the stern of the craft and did the\r\npaddling. With the first stroke the trim shell of a thing shot out from\r\nthe shore like an arrow. There was not much to see. While we were on the\r\nshallow water of the reef, it was pastime to look down into the limpid\r\ndepths at the large bunches of branching coral\xe2\x80\x94the unique shrubbery of\r\nthe sea. We lost that, though, when we got out into the dead blue water\r\nof the deep. But we had the picture of the surf, then, dashing angrily\r\nagainst the crag-bound shore and sending a foaming spray high into the\r\nair.\r\n\r\nThere was interest in this beetling border, too, for it was honey-combed\r\nwith quaint caves and arches and tunnels, and had a rude semblance of\r\nthe dilapidated architecture of ruined keeps and castles rising out of\r\nthe restless sea. When this novelty ceased to be a novelty, we turned\r\nour eyes shoreward and gazed at the long mountain with its rich green\r\nforests stretching up into the curtaining clouds, and at the specks of\r\nhouses in the rearward distance and the diminished schooner riding\r\nsleepily at anchor. And when these grew tiresome we dashed boldly into\r\nthe midst of a school of huge, beastly porpoises engaged at their\r\neternal game of arching over a wave and disappearing, and then doing it\r\nover again and keeping it up\xe2\x80\x94always circling over, in that way, like so\r\nmany well-submerged wheels. But the porpoises wheeled themselves away,\r\nand then we were thrown upon our own resources. It did not take many\r\nminutes to discover that the sun was blazing like a bonfire, and that\r\nthe weather was of a melting temperature. It had a drowsing effect, too.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n525.jpg (87K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn one place we came upon a large company of naked natives, of both\r\nsexes and all ages, amusing themselves with the national pastime of\r\nsurf-bathing. Each heathen would paddle three or four hundred yards out\r\nto sea, (taking a short board with him), then face the shore and wait\r\nfor a particularly prodigious billow to come along; at the right moment\r\nhe would fling his board upon its foamy crest and himself upon the\r\nboard, and here he would come whizzing by like a bombshell! It did not\r\nseem that a lightning express train could shoot along at a more hair-\r\nlifting speed. I tried surf-bathing once, subsequently, but made a\r\nfailure of it. I got the board placed right, and at the right moment,\r\ntoo; but missed the connection myself.\xe2\x80\x94The board struck the shore in\r\nthree quarters of a second, without any cargo, and I struck the bottom\r\nabout the same time, with a couple of barrels of water in me. None but\r\nnatives ever master the art of surf-bathing thoroughly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n526.jpg (33K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the end of an hour, we had made the four miles, and landed on a level\r\npoint of land, upon which was a wide extent of old ruins, with many a\r\ntall cocoanut tree growing among them. Here was the ancient City of\r\nRefuge\xe2\x80\x94a vast inclosure, whose stone walls were twenty feet thick at the\r\nbase, and fifteen feet high; an oblong square, a thousand and forty feet\r\none way and a fraction under seven hundred the other. Within this\r\ninclosure, in early times, has been three rude temples; each two hundred\r\nand ten feet long by one hundred wide, and thirteen high.\r\n\r\nIn those days, if a man killed another anywhere on the island the\r\nrelatives were privileged to take the murderer\xe2\x80\x99s life; and then a chase\r\nfor life and liberty began\xe2\x80\x94the outlawed criminal flying through pathless\r\nforests and over mountain and plain, with his hopes fixed upon the\r\nprotecting walls of the City of Refuge, and the avenger of blood\r\nfollowing hotly after him!\r\n\r\nSometimes the race was kept up to the very gates of the temple, and the\r\npanting pair sped through long files of excited natives, who watched the\r\ncontest with flashing eye and dilated nostril, encouraging the hunted\r\nrefugee with sharp, inspiriting ejaculations, and sending up a ringing\r\nshout of exultation when the saving gates closed upon him and the\r\ncheated pursuer sank exhausted at the threshold. But sometimes the\r\nflying criminal fell under the hand of the avenger at the very door,\r\nwhen one more brave stride, one more brief second of time would have\r\nbrought his feet upon the sacred ground and barred him against all harm.\r\nWhere did these isolated pagans get this idea of a City of Refuge\xe2\x80\x94this\r\nancient Oriental custom?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n527.jpg (73K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThis old sanctuary was sacred to all\xe2\x80\x94even to rebels in arms and invading\r\narmies. Once within its walls, and confession made to the priest and\r\nabsolution obtained, the wretch with a price upon his head could go\r\nforth without fear and without danger\xe2\x80\x94he was _tabu_, and to harm him was\r\ndeath. The routed rebels in the lost battle for idolatry fled to this\r\nplace to claim sanctuary, and many were thus saved.\r\n\r\nClose to the corner of the great inclosure is a round structure of\r\nstone, some six or eight feet high, with a level top about ten or twelve\r\nin diameter. This was the place of execution. A high palisade of\r\ncocoanut piles shut out the cruel scenes from the vulgar multitude. Here\r\ncriminals were killed, the flesh stripped from the bones and burned, and\r\nthe bones secreted in holes in the body of the structure. If the man had\r\nbeen guilty of a high crime, the entire corpse was burned.\r\n\r\nThe walls of the temple are a study. The same food for speculation that\r\nis offered the visitor to the Pyramids of Egypt he will find here\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nmystery of how they were constructed by a people unacquainted with\r\nscience and mechanics. The natives have no invention of their own for\r\nhoisting heavy weights, they had no beasts of burden, and they have\r\nnever even shown any knowledge of the properties of the lever. Yet some\r\nof the lava blocks quarried out, brought over rough, broken ground, and\r\nbuilt into this wall, six or seven feet from the ground, are of\r\nprodigious size and would weigh tons. How did they transport and how\r\nraise them?\r\n\r\nBoth the inner and outer surfaces of the walls present a smooth front\r\nand are very creditable specimens of masonry. The blocks are of all\r\nmanner of shapes and sizes, but yet are fitted together with the neatest\r\nexactness. The gradual narrowing of the wall from the base upward is\r\naccurately preserved.\r\n\r\nNo cement was used, but the edifice is firm and compact and is capable\r\nof resisting storm and decay for centuries. Who built this temple, and\r\nhow was it built, and when, are mysteries that may never be unraveled.\r\nOutside of these ancient walls lies a sort of coffin-shaped stone eleven\r\nfeet four inches long and three feet square at the small end (it would\r\nweigh a few thousand pounds), which the high chief who held sway over\r\nthis district many centuries ago brought thither on his shoulder one day\r\nto use as a lounge! This circumstance is established by the most\r\nreliable traditions. He used to lie down on it, in his indolent way, and\r\nkeep an eye on his subjects at work for him and see that there was no\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csoldiering\xe2\x80\x9d done. And no doubt there was not any done to speak of,\r\nbecause he was a man of that sort of build that incites to attention to\r\nbusiness on the part of an employee.\r\n\r\nHe was fourteen or fifteen feet high. When he stretched himself at full\r\nlength on his lounge, his legs hung down over the end, and when he\r\nsnored he woke the dead. These facts are all attested by irrefragable\r\ntradition.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n529.jpg (86K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the other side of the temple is a monstrous seven-ton rock, eleven\r\nfeet long, seven feet wide and three feet thick. It is raised a foot or\r\na foot and a half above the ground, and rests upon half a dozen little\r\nstony pedestals. The same old fourteen-footer brought it down from the\r\nmountain, merely for fun (he had his own notions about fun), and propped\r\nit up as we find it now and as others may find it a century hence, for\r\nit would take a score of horses to budge it from its position. They say\r\nthat fifty or sixty years ago the proud Queen Kaahumanu used to fly to\r\nthis rock for safety, whenever she had been making trouble with her\r\nfierce husband, and hide under it until his wrath was appeased. But\r\nthese Kanakas will lie, and this statement is one of their ablest\r\nefforts\xe2\x80\x94for Kaahumanu was six feet high\xe2\x80\x94she was bulky\xe2\x80\x94she was built like\r\nan ox\xe2\x80\x94and she could no more have squeezed herself under that rock than\r\nshe could have passed between the cylinders of a sugar mill. What could\r\nshe gain by it, even if she succeeded? To be chased and abused by a\r\nsavage husband could not be otherwise than humiliating to her high\r\nspirit, yet it could never make her feel so flat as an hour\xe2\x80\x99s repose\r\nunder that rock would.\r\n\r\nWe walked a mile over a raised macadamized road of uniform width; a road\r\npaved with flat stones and exhibiting in its every detail a considerable\r\ndegree of engineering skill. Some say that that wise old pagan,\r\nKamehameha I planned and built it, but others say it was built so long\r\nbefore his time that the knowledge of who constructed it has passed out\r\nof the traditions. In either case, however, as the handiwork of an\r\nuntaught and degraded race it is a thing of pleasing interest. The\r\nstones are worn and smooth, and pushed apart in places, so that the road\r\nhas the exact appearance of those ancient paved highways leading out of\r\nRome which one sees in pictures.\r\n\r\nThe object of our tramp was to visit a great natural curiosity at the\r\nbase of the foothills\xe2\x80\x94a congealed cascade of lava. Some old forgotten\r\nvolcanic eruption sent its broad river of fire down the mountain side\r\nhere, and it poured down in a great torrent from an overhanging bluff\r\nsome fifty feet high to the ground below. The flaming torrent cooled in\r\nthe winds from the sea, and remains there to-day, all seamed, and\r\nfrothed and rippled a petrified Niagara. It is very picturesque, and\r\nwithal so natural that one might almost imagine it still flowed. A\r\nsmaller stream trickled over the cliff and built up an isolated pyramid\r\nabout thirty feet high, which has the semblance of a mass of large\r\ngnarled and knotted vines and roots and stems intricately twisted and\r\nwoven together.\r\n\r\nWe passed in behind the cascade and the pyramid, and found the bluff\r\npierced by several cavernous tunnels, whose crooked courses we followed\r\na long distance.\r\n\r\nTwo of these winding tunnels stand as proof of Nature\xe2\x80\x99s mining\r\nabilities. Their floors are level, they are seven feet wide, and their\r\nroofs are gently arched. Their height is not uniform, however. We passed\r\nthrough one a hundred feet long, which leads through a spur of the hill\r\nand opens out well up in the sheer wall of a precipice whose foot rests\r\nin the waves of the sea. It is a commodious tunnel, except that there\r\nare occasional places in it where one must stoop to pass under. The roof\r\nis lava, of course, and is thickly studded with little lava-pointed\r\nicicles an inch long, which hardened as they dripped. They project as\r\nclosely together as the iron teeth of a corn-sheller, and if one will\r\nstand up straight and walk any distance there, he can get his hair\r\ncombed free of charge.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n531.jpg (55K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXIV.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe got back to the schooner in good time, and then sailed down to Kau,\r\nwhere we disembarked and took final leave of the vessel. Next day we\r\nbought horses and bent our way over the summer-clad mountain-terraces,\r\ntoward the great volcano of Kilauea (Ke-low-way-ah). We made nearly a\r\ntwo days\xe2\x80\x99 journey of it, but that was on account of laziness. Toward\r\nsunset on the second day, we reached an elevation of some four thousand\r\nfeet above sea level, and as we picked our careful way through billowy\r\nwastes of lava long generations ago stricken dead and cold in the climax\r\nof its tossing fury, we began to come upon signs of the near presence of\r\nthe volcano\xe2\x80\x94signs in the nature of ragged fissures that discharged jets\r\nof sulphurous vapor into the air, hot from the molten ocean down in the\r\nbowels of the mountain.\r\n\r\nShortly the crater came into view. I have seen Vesuvius since, but it\r\nwas a mere toy, a child\xe2\x80\x99s volcano, a soup-kettle, compared to this.\r\nMount Vesuvius is a shapely cone thirty-six hundred feet high; its\r\ncrater an inverted cone only three hundred feet deep, and not more than\r\na thousand feet in diameter, if as much as that; its fires meagre,\r\nmodest, and docile.\xe2\x80\x94But here was a vast, perpendicular, walled cellar,\r\nnine hundred feet deep in some places, thirteen hundred in others,\r\nlevel- floored, and _ten miles in circumference_! Here was a yawning pit\r\nupon whose floor the armies of Russia could camp, and have room to\r\nspare.\r\n\r\nPerched upon the edge of the crater, at the opposite end from where we\r\nstood, was a small look-out house\xe2\x80\x94say three miles away. It assisted us,\r\nby comparison, to comprehend and appreciate the great depth of the\r\nbasin\xe2\x80\x94it looked like a tiny martin-box clinging at the eaves of a\r\ncathedral. After some little time spent in resting and looking and\r\nciphering, we hurried on to the hotel.\r\n\r\nBy the path it is half a mile from the Volcano House to the lookout-\r\nhouse. After a hearty supper we waited until it was thoroughly dark and\r\nthen started to the crater. The first glance in that direction revealed\r\na scene of wild beauty. There was a heavy fog over the crater and it was\r\nsplendidly illuminated by the glare from the fires below. The\r\nillumination was two miles wide and a mile high, perhaps; and if you\r\never, on a dark night and at a distance beheld the light from thirty or\r\nforty blocks of distant buildings all on fire at once, reflected\r\nstrongly against over-hanging clouds, you can form a fair idea of what\r\nthis looked like.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n533.jpg (37K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA colossal column of cloud towered to a great height in the air\r\nimmediately above the crater, and the outer swell of every one of its\r\nvast folds was dyed with a rich crimson luster, which was subdued to a\r\npale rose tint in the depressions between. It glowed like a muffled\r\ntorch and stretched upward to a dizzy height toward the zenith. I\r\nthought it just possible that its like had not been seen since the\r\nchildren of Israel wandered on their long march through the desert so\r\nmany centuries ago over a path illuminated by the mysterious \xe2\x80\x9cpillar of\r\nfire.\xe2\x80\x9d And I was sure that I now had a vivid conception of what the\r\nmajestic \xe2\x80\x9cpillar of fire\xe2\x80\x9d was like, which almost amounted to a\r\nrevelation.\r\n\r\nArrived at the little thatched lookout house, we rested our elbows on\r\nthe railing in front and looked abroad over the wide crater and down\r\nover the sheer precipice at the seething fires beneath us. The view was\r\na startling improvement on my daylight experience. I turned to see the\r\neffect on the balance of the company and found the reddest-faced set of\r\nmen I almost ever saw. In the strong light every countenance glowed like\r\nred-hot iron, every shoulder was suffused with crimson and shaded\r\nrearward into dingy, shapeless obscurity! The place below looked like\r\nthe infernal regions and these men like half-cooled devils just come up\r\non a furlough.\r\n\r\nI turned my eyes upon the volcano again. The \xe2\x80\x9ccellar\xe2\x80\x9d was tolerably well\r\nlighted up. For a mile and a half in front of us and half a mile on\r\neither side, the floor of the abyss was magnificently illuminated;\r\nbeyond these limits the mists hung down their gauzy curtains and cast a\r\ndeceptive gloom over all that made the twinkling fires in the remote\r\ncorners of the crater seem countless leagues removed\xe2\x80\x94made them seem like\r\nthe camp-fires of a great army far away. Here was room for the\r\nimagination to work! You could imagine those lights the width of a\r\ncontinent away\xe2\x80\x94and that hidden under the intervening darkness were\r\nhills, and winding rivers, and weary wastes of plain and desert\xe2\x80\x94and even\r\nthen the tremendous vista stretched on, and on, and on!\xe2\x80\x94to the fires and\r\nfar beyond! You could not compass it\xe2\x80\x94it was the idea of eternity made\r\ntangible\xe2\x80\x94and the longest end of it made visible to the naked eye!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n535.jpg (125K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe greater part of the vast floor of the desert under us was as black\r\nas ink, and apparently smooth and level; but over a mile square of it\r\nwas ringed and streaked and striped with a thousand branching streams of\r\nliquid and gorgeously brilliant fire! It looked like a colossal railroad\r\nmap of the State of Massachusetts done in chain lightning on a midnight\r\nsky. Imagine it\xe2\x80\x94imagine a coal-black sky shivered into a tangled net-\r\nwork of angry fire!\r\n\r\nHere and there were gleaming holes a hundred feet in diameter, broken in\r\nthe dark crust, and in them the melted lava\xe2\x80\x94the color a dazzling white\r\njust tinged with yellow\xe2\x80\x94was boiling and surging furiously; and from\r\nthese holes branched numberless bright torrents in many directions, like\r\nthe spokes of a wheel, and kept a tolerably straight course for a while\r\nand then swept round in huge rainbow curves, or made a long succession\r\nof sharp worm-fence angles, which looked precisely like the fiercest\r\njagged lightning. These streams met other streams, and they mingled with\r\nand crossed and recrossed each other in every conceivable direction,\r\nlike skate tracks on a popular skating ground. Sometimes streams twenty\r\nor thirty feet wide flowed from the holes to some distance without\r\ndividing\xe2\x80\x94and through the opera-glasses we could see that they ran down\r\nsmall, steep hills and were genuine cataracts of fire, white at their\r\nsource, but soon cooling and turning to the richest red, grained with\r\nalternate lines of black and gold. Every now and then masses of the dark\r\ncrust broke away and floated slowly down these streams like rafts down a\r\nriver. Occasionally the molten lava flowing under the superincumbent\r\ncrust broke through\xe2\x80\x94split a dazzling streak, from five hundred to a\r\nthousand feet long, like a sudden flash of lightning, and then acre\r\nafter acre of the cold lava parted into fragments, turned up edgewise\r\nlike cakes of ice when a great river breaks up, plunged downward and\r\nwere swallowed in the crimson cauldron. Then the wide expanse of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthaw\xe2\x80\x9d maintained a ruddy glow for a while, but shortly cooled and\r\nbecame black and level again. During a \xe2\x80\x9cthaw,\xe2\x80\x9d every dismembered cake\r\nwas marked by a glittering white border which was superbly shaded inward\r\nby aurora borealis rays, which were a flaming yellow where they joined\r\nthe white border, and from thence toward their points tapered into\r\nglowing crimson, then into a rich, pale carmine, and finally into a\r\nfaint blush that held its own a moment and then dimmed and turned black.\r\nSome of the streams preferred to mingle together in a tangle of\r\nfantastic circles, and then they looked something like the confusion of\r\nropes one sees on a ship\xe2\x80\x99s deck when she has just taken in sail and\r\ndropped anchor\xe2\x80\x94provided one can imagine those ropes on fire.\r\n\r\nThrough the glasses, the little fountains scattered about looked very\r\nbeautiful. They boiled, and coughed, and spluttered, and discharged\r\nsprays of stringy red fire\xe2\x80\x94of about the consistency of mush, for\r\ninstance\xe2\x80\x94from ten to fifteen feet into the air, along with a shower of\r\nbrilliant white sparks\xe2\x80\x94a quaint and unnatural mingling of gouts of blood\r\nand snow-flakes!\r\n\r\nWe had circles and serpents and streaks of lightning all twined and\r\nwreathed and tied together, without a break throughout an area more than\r\na mile square (that amount of ground was covered, though it was not\r\nstrictly \xe2\x80\x9csquare\xe2\x80\x9d), and it was with a feeling of placid exultation that\r\nwe reflected that many years had elapsed since any visitor had seen such\r\na splendid display\xe2\x80\x94since any visitor had seen anything more than the now\r\nsnubbed and insignificant \xe2\x80\x9cNorth\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSouth\xe2\x80\x9d lakes in action. We had\r\nbeen reading old files of Hawaiian newspapers and the \xe2\x80\x9cRecord Book\xe2\x80\x9d at\r\nthe Volcano House, and were posted.\r\n\r\nI could see the North Lake lying out on the black floor away off in the\r\nouter edge of our panorama, and knitted to it by a web-work of lava\r\nstreams. In its individual capacity it looked very little more\r\nrespectable than a schoolhouse on fire. True, it was about nine hundred\r\nfeet long and two or three hundred wide, but then, under the present\r\ncircumstances, it necessarily appeared rather insignificant, and besides\r\nit was so distant from us.\r\n\r\nI forgot to say that the noise made by the bubbling lava is not great,\r\nheard as we heard it from our lofty perch. It makes three distinct\r\nsounds\xe2\x80\x94a rushing, a hissing, and a coughing or puffing sound; and if you\r\nstand on the brink and close your eyes it is no trick at all to imagine\r\nthat you are sweeping down a river on a large low-pressure steamer, and\r\nthat you hear the hissing of the steam about her boilers, the puffing\r\nfrom her escape-pipes and the churning rush of the water abaft her\r\nwheels. The smell of sulphur is strong, but not unpleasant to a sinner.\r\n\r\nWe left the lookout house at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in a half cooked condition,\r\nbecause of the heat from Pele\xe2\x80\x99s furnaces, and wrapping up in blankets,\r\nfor the night was cold, we returned to our Hotel.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXV.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next night was appointed for a visit to the bottom of the crater,\r\nfor we desired to traverse its floor and see the \xe2\x80\x9cNorth Lake\xe2\x80\x9d (of fire)\r\nwhich lay two miles away, toward the further wall. After dark half a\r\ndozen of us set out, with lanterns and native guides, and climbed down a\r\ncrazy, thousand-foot pathway in a crevice fractured in the crater wall,\r\nand reached the bottom in safety.\r\n\r\nThe irruption of the previous evening had spent its force and the floor\r\nlooked black and cold; but when we ran out upon it we found it hot yet,\r\nto the feet, and it was likewise riven with crevices which revealed the\r\nunderlying fires gleaming vindictively. A neighboring cauldron was\r\nthreatening to overflow, and this added to the dubiousness of the\r\nsituation. So the native guides refused to continue the venture, and\r\nthen every body deserted except a stranger named Marlette. He said he\r\nhad been in the crater a dozen times in daylight and believed he could\r\nfind his way through it at night. He thought that a run of three hundred\r\nyards would carry us over the hottest part of the floor and leave us our\r\nshoe-soles. His pluck gave me back-bone. We took one lantern and\r\ninstructed the guides to hang the other to the roof of the look-out\r\nhouse to serve as a beacon for us in case we got lost, and then the\r\nparty started back up the precipice and Marlette and I made our run. We\r\nskipped over the hot floor and over the red crevices with brisk dispatch\r\nand reached the cold lava safe but with pretty warm feet. Then we took\r\nthings leisurely and comfortably, jumping tolerably wide and probably\r\nbottomless chasms, and threading our way through picturesque lava\r\nupheavals with considerable confidence. When we got fairly away from the\r\ncauldrons of boiling fire, we seemed to be in a gloomy desert, and a\r\nsuffocatingly dark one, surrounded by dim walls that seemed to tower to\r\nthe sky. The only cheerful objects were the glinting stars high\r\noverhead.\r\n\r\nBy and by Marlette shouted \xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d I never stopped quicker in my life. I\r\nasked what the matter was. He said we were out of the path. He said we\r\nmust not try to go on till we found it again, for we were surrounded\r\nwith beds of rotten lava through which we could easily break and plunge\r\ndown a thousand feet. I thought eight hundred would answer for me, and\r\nwas about to say so when Marlette partly proved his statement by\r\naccidentally crushing through and disappearing to his arm-pits.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n539.jpg (43K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe got out and we hunted for the path with the lantern. He said there\r\nwas only one path and that it was but vaguely defined. We could not find\r\nit. The lava surface was all alike in the lantern light. But he was an\r\ningenious man. He said it was not the lantern that had informed him that\r\nwe were out of the path, but his _feet_. He had noticed a crisp grinding\r\nof fine lava-needles under his feet, and some instinct reminded him that\r\nin the path these were all worn away. So he put the lantern behind him,\r\nand began to search with his boots instead of his eyes. It was good\r\nsagacity. The first time his foot touched a surface that did not grind\r\nunder it he announced that the trail was found again; and after that we\r\nkept up a sharp listening for the rasping sound and it always warned us\r\nin time.\r\n\r\nIt was a long tramp, but an exciting one. We reached the North Lake\r\nbetween ten and eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and sat down on a huge overhanging lava-\r\nshelf, tired but satisfied. The spectacle presented was worth coming\r\ndouble the distance to see. Under us, and stretching away before us, was\r\na heaving sea of molten fire of seemingly limitless extent. The glare\r\nfrom it was so blinding that it was some time before we could bear to\r\nlook upon it steadily.\r\n\r\nIt was like gazing at the sun at noon-day, except that the glare was not\r\nquite so white. At unequal distances all around the shores of the lake\r\nwere nearly white-hot chimneys or hollow drums of lava, four or five\r\nfeet high, and up through them were bursting gorgeous sprays of lava-\r\ngouts and gem spangles, some white, some red and some golden\xe2\x80\x94a ceaseless\r\nbombardment, and one that fascinated the eye with its unapproachable\r\nsplendor. The mere distant jets, sparkling up through an intervening\r\ngossamer veil of vapor, seemed miles away; and the further the curving\r\nranks of fiery fountains receded, the more fairy-like and beautiful they\r\nappeared.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n540.jpg (78K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNow and then the surging bosom of the lake under our noses would calm\r\ndown ominously and seem to be gathering strength for an enterprise; and\r\nthen all of a sudden a red dome of lava of the bulk of an ordinary\r\ndwelling would heave itself aloft like an escaping balloon, then burst\r\nasunder, and out of its heart would flit a pale-green film of vapor, and\r\nfloat upward and vanish in the darkness\xe2\x80\x94a released soul soaring homeward\r\nfrom captivity with the damned, no doubt. The crashing plunge of the\r\nruined dome into the lake again would send a world of seething billows\r\nlashing against the shores and shaking the foundations of our perch. By\r\nand by, a loosened mass of the hanging shelf we sat on tumbled into the\r\nlake, jarring the surroundings like an earthquake and delivering a\r\nsuggestion that may have been intended for a hint, and may not. We did\r\nnot wait to see.\r\n\r\nWe got lost again on our way back, and were more than an hour hunting\r\nfor the path. We were where we could see the beacon lantern at the look-\r\nout house at the time, but thought it was a star and paid no attention\r\nto it. We reached the hotel at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning pretty well\r\nfagged out.\r\n\r\nKilauea never overflows its vast crater, but bursts a passage for its\r\nlava through the mountain side when relief is necessary, and then the\r\ndestruction is fearful. About 1840 it rent its overburdened stomach and\r\nsent a broad river of fire careering down to the sea, which swept away\r\nforests, huts, plantations and every thing else that lay in its path.\r\nThe stream was _five miles broad_, in places, and _two hundred feet\r\ndeep_, and the distance it traveled was forty miles. It tore up and bore\r\naway acre-patches of land on its bosom like rafts\xe2\x80\x94rocks, trees and all\r\nintact. At night the red glare was visible a hundred miles at sea; and\r\nat a distance of forty miles fine print could be read at midnight. The\r\natmosphere was poisoned with sulphurous vapors and choked with falling\r\nashes, pumice stones and cinders; countless columns of smoke rose up and\r\nblended together in a tumbled canopy that hid the heavens and glowed\r\nwith a ruddy flush reflected from the fires below; here and there jets\r\nof lava sprung hundreds of feet into the air and burst into rocket-\r\nsprays that returned to earth in a crimson rain; and all the while the\r\nlaboring mountain shook with Nature\xe2\x80\x99s great palsy and voiced its\r\ndistress in moanings and the muffled booming of subterranean thunders.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n542.jpg (103K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFishes were killed for twenty miles along the shore, where the lava\r\nentered the sea. The earthquakes caused some loss of human life, and a\r\nprodigious tidal wave swept inland, carrying every thing before it and\r\ndrowning a number of natives. The devastation consummated along the\r\nroute traversed by the river of lava was complete and incalculable. Only\r\na Pompeii and a Herculaneum were needed at the foot of Kilauea to make\r\nthe story of the irruption immortal.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n543.jpg (113K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXVI.\r\n\r\n\r\nWe rode horseback all around the island of Hawaii (the crooked road\r\nmaking the distance two hundred miles), and enjoyed the journey very\r\nmuch. We were more than a week making the trip, because our Kanaka\r\nhorses would not go by a house or a hut without stopping\xe2\x80\x94whip and spur\r\ncould not alter their minds about it, and so we finally found that it\r\neconomized time to let them have their way. Upon inquiry the mystery was\r\nexplained: the natives are such thorough-going gossips that they never\r\npass a house without stopping to swap news, and consequently their\r\nhorses learn to regard that sort of thing as an essential part of the\r\nwhole duty of man, and his salvation not to be compassed without it.\r\nHowever, at a former crisis of my life I had once taken an aristocratic\r\nyoung lady out driving, behind a horse that had just retired from a long\r\nand honorable career as the moving impulse of a milk wagon, and so this\r\npresent experience awoke a reminiscent sadness in me in place of the\r\nexasperation more natural to the occasion. I remembered how helpless I\r\nwas that day, and how humiliated; how ashamed I was of having intimated\r\nto the girl that I had always owned the horse and was accustomed to\r\ngrandeur; how hard I tried to appear easy, and even vivacious, under\r\nsuffering that was consuming my vitals; how placidly and maliciously the\r\ngirl smiled, and kept on smiling, while my hot blushes baked themselves\r\ninto a permanent blood-pudding in my face; how the horse ambled from one\r\nside of the street to the other and waited complacently before every\r\nthird house two minutes and a quarter while I belabored his back and\r\nreviled him in my heart; how I tried to keep him from turning corners\r\nand failed; how I moved heaven and earth to get him out of town, and did\r\nnot succeed; how he traversed the entire settlement and delivered\r\nimaginary milk at a hundred and sixty-two different domiciles, and how\r\nhe finally brought up at a dairy depot and refused to budge further,\r\nthus rounding and completing the revealment of what the plebeian service\r\nof his life had been; how, in eloquent silence, I walked the girl home,\r\nand how, when I took leave of her, her parting remark scorched my soul\r\nand appeared to blister me all over: she said that my horse was a fine,\r\ncapable animal, and I must have taken great comfort in him in my\r\ntime\xe2\x80\x94but that if I would take along some milk-tickets next time, and\r\nappear to deliver them at the various halting places, it might expedite\r\nhis movements a little. There was a coolness between us after that.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n545.jpg (90K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn one place in the island of Hawaii, we saw a laced and ruffled\r\ncataract of limpid water leaping from a sheer precipice fifteen hundred\r\nfeet high; but that sort of scenery finds its stanchest ally in the\r\narithmetic rather than in spectacular effect. If one desires to be so\r\nstirred by a poem of Nature wrought in the happily commingled graces of\r\npicturesque rocks, glimpsed distances, foliage, color, shifting lights\r\nand shadows, and failing water, that the tears almost come into his eyes\r\nso potent is the charm exerted, he need not go away from America to\r\nenjoy such an experience. The Rainbow Fall, in Watkins Glen (N.Y.), on\r\nthe Erie railway, is an example. It would recede into pitiable\r\ninsignificance if the callous tourist drew on arithmetic on it; but left\r\nto compete for the honors simply on scenic grace and beauty\xe2\x80\x94the grand,\r\nthe august and the sublime being barred the contest\xe2\x80\x94it could challenge\r\nthe old world and the new to produce its peer.\r\n\r\nIn one locality, on our journey, we saw some horses that had been born\r\nand reared on top of the mountains, above the range of running water,\r\nand consequently they had never drank that fluid in their lives, but had\r\nbeen always accustomed to quenching their thirst by eating dew-laden or\r\nshower-wetted leaves. And now it was destructively funny to see them\r\nsniff suspiciously at a pail of water, and then put in their noses and\r\ntry to take a _bite_ out of the fluid, as if it were a solid. Finding it\r\nliquid, they would snatch away their heads and fall to trembling,\r\nsnorting and showing other evidences of fright. When they became\r\nconvinced at last that the water was friendly and harmless, they thrust\r\nin their noses up to their eyes, brought out a mouthful of water, and\r\nproceeded to _chew_ it complacently. We saw a man coax, kick and spur\r\none of them five or ten minutes before he could make it cross a running\r\nstream. It spread its nostrils, distended its eyes and trembled all\r\nover, just as horses customarily do in the presence of a serpent\xe2\x80\x94and for\r\naught I know it thought the crawling stream _was_ a serpent.\r\n\r\nIn due course of time our journey came to an end at Kawaehae (usually\r\npronounced To-a-_hi_\xe2\x80\x94and before we find fault with this elaborate\r\northographical method of arriving at such an unostentatious result, let\r\nus lop off the _ugh_ from our word \xe2\x80\x9cthough\xe2\x80\x9d). I made this horseback trip\r\non a mule. I paid ten dollars for him at Kau (Kah-oo), added four to get\r\nhim shod, rode him two hundred miles, and then sold him for fifteen\r\ndollars. I mark the circumstance with a white stone (in the absence of\r\nchalk\xe2\x80\x94for I never saw a white stone that a body could mark anything\r\nwith, though out of respect for the ancients I have tried it often\r\nenough); for up to that day and date it was the first strictly\r\ncommercial transaction I had ever entered into, and come out winner. We\r\nreturned to Honolulu, and from thence sailed to the island of Maui, and\r\nspent several weeks there very pleasantly. I still remember, with a\r\nsense of indolent luxury, a picnicing excursion up a romantic gorge\r\nthere, called the Iao Valley. The trail lay along the edge of a brawling\r\nstream in the bottom of the gorge\xe2\x80\x94a shady route, for it was well roofed\r\nwith the verdant domes of forest trees. Through openings in the foliage\r\nwe glimpsed picturesque scenery that revealed ceaseless changes and new\r\ncharms with every step of our progress. Perpendicular walls from one to\r\nthree thousand feet high guarded the way, and were sumptuously plumed\r\nwith varied foliage, in places, and in places swathed in waving ferns.\r\nPassing shreds of cloud trailed their shadows across these shining\r\nfronts, mottling them with blots; billowy masses of white vapor hid the\r\nturreted summits, and far above the vapor swelled a background of\r\ngleaming green crags and cones that came and went, through the veiling\r\nmists, like islands drifting in a fog; sometimes the cloudy curtain\r\ndescended till half the ca\xc3\xb1on wall was hidden, then shredded gradually\r\naway till only airy glimpses of the ferny front appeared through it\xe2\x80\x94then\r\nswept aloft and left it glorified in the sun again. Now and then, as our\r\nposition changed, rocky bastions swung out from the wall, a mimic ruin\r\nof castellated ramparts and crumbling towers clothed with mosses and\r\nhung with garlands of swaying vines, and as we moved on they swung back\r\nagain and hid themselves once more in the foliage. Presently a verdure-\r\nclad needle of stone, a thousand feet high, stepped out from behind a\r\ncorner, and mounted guard over the mysteries of the valley. It seemed to\r\nme that if Captain Cook needed a monument, here was one ready\r\nmade\xe2\x80\x94therefore, why not put up his sign here, and sell out the venerable\r\ncocoanut stump?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n547.jpg (192K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBut the chief pride of Maui is her dead volcano of Haleakala\xe2\x80\x94which\r\nmeans, translated, \xe2\x80\x9cthe house of the sun.\xe2\x80\x9d We climbed a thousand feet up\r\nthe side of this isolated colossus one afternoon; then camped, and next\r\nday climbed the remaining nine thousand feet, and anchored on the\r\nsummit, where we built a fire and froze and roasted by turns, all night.\r\nWith the first pallor of dawn we got up and saw things that were new to\r\nus. Mounted on a commanding pinnacle, we watched Nature work her silent\r\nwonders. The sea was spread abroad on every hand, its tumbled surface\r\nseeming only wrinkled and dimpled in the distance. A broad valley below\r\nappeared like an ample checker-board, its velvety green sugar\r\nplantations alternating with dun squares of barrenness and groves of\r\ntrees diminished to mossy tufts. Beyond the valley were mountains\r\npicturesquely grouped together; but bear in mind, we fancied that we\r\nwere looking _up_ at these things\xe2\x80\x94not down. We seemed to sit in the\r\nbottom of a symmetrical bowl ten thousand feet deep, with the valley and\r\nthe skirting sea lifted away into the sky above us! It was curious; and\r\nnot only curious, but aggravating; for it was having our trouble all for\r\nnothing, to climb ten thousand feet toward heaven and then have to look\r\n_up_ at our scenery. However, we had to be content with it and make the\r\nbest of it; for, all we could do we could not coax our landscape down\r\nout of the clouds. Formerly, when I had read an article in which Poe\r\ntreated of this singular fraud perpetrated upon the eye by isolated\r\ngreat altitudes, I had looked upon the matter as an invention of his own\r\nfancy.\r\n\r\nI have spoken of the outside view\xe2\x80\x94but we had an inside one, too. That\r\nwas the yawning dead crater, into which we now and then tumbled rocks,\r\nhalf as large as a barrel, from our perch, and saw them go careering\r\ndown the almost perpendicular sides, bounding three hundred feet at a\r\njump; kicking up cast-clouds wherever they struck; diminishing to our\r\nview as they sped farther into distance; growing invisible, finally, and\r\nonly betraying their course by faint little puffs of dust; and coming to\r\na halt at last in the bottom of the abyss, two thousand five hundred\r\nfeet down from where they started! It was magnificent sport. We wore\r\nourselves out at it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n549.jpg (138K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe crater of Vesuvius, as I have before remarked, is a modest pit about\r\na thousand feet deep and three thousand in circumference; that of\r\nKilauea is somewhat deeper, and _ten miles_ in circumference. But what\r\nare either of them compared to the vacant stomach of Haleakala? I will\r\nnot offer any figures of my own, but give official ones\xe2\x80\x94those of\r\nCommander Wilkes, U.S.N., who surveyed it and testifies that it is\r\n_twenty-seven miles in circumference_! If it had a level bottom it would\r\nmake a fine site for a city like London. It must have afforded a\r\nspectacle worth contemplating in the old days when its furnaces gave\r\nfull rein to their anger.\r\n\r\nPresently vagrant white clouds came drifting along, high over the sea\r\nand the valley; then they came in couples and groups; then in imposing\r\nsquadrons; gradually joining their forces, they banked themselves\r\nsolidly together, a thousand feet under us, and _totally shut out land\r\nand ocean_\xe2\x80\x94not a vestige of _anything_ was left in view but just a\r\nlittle of the rim of the crater, circling away from the pinnacle whereon\r\nwe sat (for a ghostly procession of wanderers from the filmy hosts\r\nwithout had drifted through a chasm in the crater wall and filed round\r\nand round, and gathered and sunk and blended together till the abyss was\r\nstored to the brim with a fleecy fog). Thus banked, motion ceased, and\r\nsilence reigned. Clear to the horizon, league on league, the snowy floor\r\nstretched without a break\xe2\x80\x94not level, but in rounded folds, with shallow\r\ncreases between, and with here and there stately piles of vapory\r\narchitecture lifting themselves aloft out of the common plain\xe2\x80\x94some near\r\nat hand, some in the middle distances, and others relieving the monotony\r\nof the remote solitudes. There was little conversation, for the\r\nimpressive scene overawed speech. I felt like the Last Man, neglected of\r\nthe judgment, and left pinnacled in mid-heaven, a forgotten relic of a\r\nvanished world.\r\n\r\nWhile the hush yet brooded, the messengers of the coming resurrection\r\nappeared in the East. A growing warmth suffused the horizon, and soon\r\nthe sun emerged and looked out over the cloud-waste, flinging bars of\r\nruddy light across it, staining its folds and billow-caps with blushes,\r\npurpling the shaded troughs between, and glorifying the massy vapor-\r\npalaces and cathedrals with a wasteful splendor of all blendings and\r\ncombinations of rich coloring.\r\n\r\nIt was the sublimest spectacle I ever witnessed, and I think the memory\r\nof it will remain with me always.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nI stumbled upon one curious character in the Island of Maui. He became a\r\nsore annoyance to me in the course of time. My first glimpse of him was\r\nin a sort of public room in the town of Lahaina. He occupied a chair at\r\nthe opposite side of the apartment, and sat eyeing our party with\r\ninterest for some minutes, and listening as critically to what we were\r\nsaying as if he fancied we were talking to him and expecting him to\r\nreply. I thought it very sociable in a stranger. Presently, in the\r\ncourse of conversation, I made a statement bearing upon the subject\r\nunder discussion\xe2\x80\x94and I made it with due modesty, for there was nothing\r\nextraordinary about it, and it was only put forth in illustration of a\r\npoint at issue. I had barely finished when this person spoke out with\r\nrapid utterance and feverish anxiety:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that was certainly remarkable, after a fashion, but you ought to\r\nhave seen _my_ chimney\xe2\x80\x94you ought to have seen _my_ chimney, sir! Smoke!\r\nI wish I may hang if\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Jones, _you_ remember that chimney\xe2\x80\x94_you_ must\r\nremember that chimney! No, no\xe2\x80\x94I recollect, now, you warn\xe2\x80\x99t living on\r\nthis side of the island then. But I am telling you nothing but the\r\ntruth, and I wish I may never draw another breath if that chimney didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsmoke so that the smoke actually got _caked_ in it and I had to dig it\r\nout with a pickaxe! You may smile, gentlemen, but the High Sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s got\r\na hunk of it which I dug out before his eyes, and so it\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly easy\r\nfor you to go and examine for yourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe interruption broke up the conversation, which had already begun to\r\nlag, and we presently hired some natives and an out-rigger canoe or two,\r\nand went out to overlook a grand surf-bathing contest.\r\n\r\nTwo weeks after this, while talking in a company, I looked up and\r\ndetected this same man boring through and through me with his intense\r\neye, and noted again his twitching muscles and his feverish anxiety to\r\nspeak. The moment I paused, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Beg_ your pardon, sir, beg your pardon, but it can only be considered\r\nremarkable when brought into strong outline by isolation. Sir,\r\ncontrasted with a circumstance which occurred in my own experience, it\r\ninstantly becomes commonplace. No, not that\xe2\x80\x94for I will not speak so\r\ndiscourteously of any experience in the career of a stranger and a\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x94but I am _obliged_ to say that you could not, and you _would_\r\nnot ever again refer to this tree as a _large_ one, if you could behold,\r\nas I have, the great Yakmatack tree, in the island of Ounaska, sea of\r\nKamtchatka\xe2\x80\x94a tree, sir, not one inch less than four hundred and fifteen\r\nfeet in solid diameter!\xe2\x80\x94and I wish I may die in a minute if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t so!\r\nOh, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t look so questioning, gentlemen; here\xe2\x80\x99s old Cap Saltmarsh\r\ncan say whether I know what I\xe2\x80\x99m talking about or not. I showed him the\r\ntree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_Captain Saltmarsh_.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, cat your anchor, lad\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re heaving too\r\ntaut. You _promised_ to show me that stunner, and I walked more than\r\neleven mile with you through the cussedest jungle _I_ ever see, a\r\nhunting for it; but the tree you showed me finally warn\xe2\x80\x99t as big around\r\nas a beer cask, and _you_ know that your own self, Markiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n553.jpg (48K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear the man talk! Of _course_ the tree was reduced that way, but\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t I _explain_ it? Answer me, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say I wished you\r\ncould have seen it when _I_ first saw it? When you got up on your ear\r\nand called me names, and said I had brought you eleven miles to look at\r\na sapling, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I _explain_ to you that all the whale-ships in the\r\nNorth Seas had been wooding off of it for more than twenty-seven years?\r\nAnd did you s\xe2\x80\x99pose the tree could last for-_ever_, con-_found_ it? I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t see why you want to keep back things that way, and try to injure a\r\nperson that\xe2\x80\x99s never done _you_ any harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomehow this man\xe2\x80\x99s presence made me uncomfortable, and I was glad when a\r\nnative arrived at that moment to say that Muckawow, the most\r\ncompanionable and luxurious among the rude war-chiefs of the Islands,\r\ndesired us to come over and help him enjoy a missionary whom he had\r\nfound trespassing on his grounds.\r\n\r\nI think it was about ten days afterward that, as I finished a statement\r\nI was making for the instruction of a group of friends and\r\nacquaintances, and which made no pretence of being extraordinary, a\r\nfamiliar voice chimed instantly in on the heels of my last word, and\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear sir, there was _nothing_ remarkable about that horse, or\r\nthe circumstance either\xe2\x80\x94nothing in the world! I mean no sort of offence\r\nwhen I say it, sir, but you really do not know anything whatever about\r\nspeed. Bless your heart, if you could only have seen my mare Margaretta;\r\n_there_ was a beast!\xe2\x80\x94_there_ was lightning for you! Trot! Trot is no\r\nname for it\xe2\x80\x94she flew! How she could whirl a buggy along! I started her\r\nout once, sir\xe2\x80\x94Colonel Bilgewater, _you_ recollect that animal perfectly\r\nwell\xe2\x80\x94I started her out about thirty or thirty-five yards ahead of the\r\nawfullest storm I ever saw in my life, and it chased us upwards of\r\neighteen miles! It did, by the everlasting hills! And I\xe2\x80\x99m telling you\r\nnothing but the unvarnished truth when I say that not one single _drop_\r\nof rain fell on me\xe2\x80\x94not a single drop, sir! And I swear to it! But my dog\r\nwas a-swimming behind the wagon all the way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n554.jpg (76K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFor a week or two I stayed mostly within doors, for I seemed to meet\r\nthis person everywhere, and he had become utterly hateful to me. But one\r\nevening I dropped in on Captain Perkins and his friends, and we had a\r\nsociable time. About ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock I chanced to be talking about a\r\nmerchant friend of mine, and without really intending it, the remark\r\nslipped out that he was a little mean and parsimonious about paying his\r\nworkmen. Instantly, through the steam of a hot whiskey punch on the\r\nopposite side of the room, a remembered voice shot\xe2\x80\x94and for a moment I\r\ntrembled on the imminent verge of profanity:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my dear sir, really you expose yourself when you parade _that_ as a\r\nsurprising circumstance. Bless your heart and hide, you are ignorant of\r\nthe very A B C of meanness! ignorant as the unborn babe! ignorant as\r\nunborn _twins_! You don\xe2\x80\x99t know _anything_ about it! It is pitiable to\r\nsee you, sir, a well-spoken and prepossessing stranger, making such an\r\nenormous pow-wow here about a subject concerning which your ignorance is\r\nperfectly humiliating! Look me in the eye, if you please; look me in the\r\neye. John James Godfrey was the son of poor but honest parents in the\r\nState of Mississippi\xe2\x80\x94boyhood friend of mine\xe2\x80\x94bosom comrade in later\r\nyears. Heaven rest his noble spirit, he is gone from us now. John James\r\nGodfrey was hired by the Hayblossom Mining Company in California to do\r\nsome blasting for them\xe2\x80\x94the \xe2\x80\x9cIncorporated Company of Mean Men,\xe2\x80\x9d the boys\r\nused to call it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, one day he drilled a hole about four feet deep and put in an\r\nawful blast of powder, and was standing over it ramming it down with an\r\niron crowbar about nine foot long, when the cussed thing struck a spark\r\nand fired the powder, and scat! away John Godfrey whizzed like a\r\nskyrocket, him and his crowbar! Well, sir, he kept on going up in the\r\nair higher and higher, till he didn\xe2\x80\x99t look any bigger than a boy\xe2\x80\x94and he\r\nkept going on up higher and higher, till he didn\xe2\x80\x99t look any bigger than\r\na doll\xe2\x80\x94and he kept on going up higher and higher, till he didn\xe2\x80\x99t look\r\nany bigger than a little small bee\xe2\x80\x94and then he went out of sight!\r\nPresently he came in sight again, looking like a little small bee\xe2\x80\x94and he\r\ncame along down further and further, till he looked as big as a doll\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94and down further and further, till he was as big as a boy\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94and further and further, till he was a full-sized man once more;\r\nand then him and his crowbar came a wh-izzing down and lit right exactly\r\nin the same old tracks and went to r-ramming down, and r-ramming down,\r\nand r-ramming down again, just the same as if nothing had happened! Now\r\ndo you know, that poor cuss warn\xe2\x80\x99t gone only sixteen minutes, and yet\r\nthat Incorporated Company of Mean Men DOCKED HIM FOR THE LOST TIME!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n555.jpg (42K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nI said I had the headache, and so excused myself and went home. And on\r\nmy diary I entered \xe2\x80\x9canother night spoiled\xe2\x80\x9d by this offensive loafer. And\r\na fervent curse was set down with it to keep the item company. And the\r\nvery next day I packed up, out of all patience, and left the Island.\r\n\r\nAlmost from the very beginning, I regarded that man as a liar\r\n.................................\r\n\r\nThe line of points represents an interval of years. At the end of which\r\ntime the opinion hazarded in that last sentence came to be gratifyingly\r\nand remarkably endorsed, and by wholly disinterested persons. The man\r\nMarkiss was found one morning hanging to a beam of his own bedroom (the\r\ndoors and windows securely fastened on the inside), dead; and on his\r\nbreast was pinned a paper in his own handwriting begging his friends to\r\nsuspect no innocent person of having any thing to do with his death, for\r\nthat it was the work of his own hands entirely. Yet the jury brought in\r\nthe astounding verdict that deceased came to his death \xe2\x80\x9cby the hands of\r\nsome person or persons unknown!\xe2\x80\x9d They explained that the perfectly\r\nundeviating consistency of Markiss\xe2\x80\x99s character for thirty years towered\r\naloft as colossal and indestructible testimony, that whatever statement\r\nhe chose to make was entitled to instant and unquestioning acceptance as\r\na _lie_. And they furthermore stated their belief that he was not dead,\r\nand instanced the strong circumstantial evidence of his own word that he\r\n_was_ dead\xe2\x80\x94and beseeched the coroner to delay the funeral as long as\r\npossible, which was done. And so in the tropical climate of Lahaina the\r\ncoffin stood open for seven days, and then even the loyal jury gave him\r\nup. But they sat on him again, and changed their verdict to \xe2\x80\x9csuicide\r\ninduced by mental aberration\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94because, said they, with penetration, \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nsaid he was dead, and he _was_ dead; and would he have told the truth if\r\nhe had been in his right mind? No, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n557.jpg (26K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter half a year\xe2\x80\x99s luxurious vagrancy in the islands, I took shipping\r\nin a sailing vessel, and regretfully returned to San Francisco\xe2\x80\x94a voyage\r\nin every way delightful, but without an incident: unless lying two long\r\nweeks in a dead calm, eighteen hundred miles from the nearest land, may\r\nrank as an incident. Schools of whales grew so tame that day after day\r\nthey played about the ship among the porpoises and the sharks without\r\nthe least apparent fear of us, and we pelted them with empty bottles for\r\nlack of better sport. Twenty-four hours afterward these bottles would be\r\nstill lying on the glassy water under our noses, showing that the ship\r\nhad not moved out of her place in all that time. The calm was absolutely\r\nbreathless, and the surface of the sea absolutely without a wrinkle. For\r\na whole day and part of a night we lay so close to another ship that had\r\ndrifted to our vicinity, that we carried on conversations with her\r\npassengers, introduced each other by name, and became pretty intimately\r\nacquainted with people we had never heard of before, and have never\r\nheard of since. This was the only vessel we saw during the whole lonely\r\nvoyage.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n559.jpg (91K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWe had fifteen passengers, and to show how hard pressed they were at\r\nlast for occupation and amusement, I will mention that the gentlemen\r\ngave a good part of their time every day, during the calm, to trying to\r\nsit on an empty champagne bottle (lying on its side), and thread a\r\nneedle without touching their heels to the deck, or falling over; and\r\nthe ladies sat in the shade of the mainsail, and watched the enterprise\r\nwith absorbing interest. We were at sea five Sundays; and yet, but for\r\nthe almanac, we never would have known but that all the other days were\r\nSundays too.\r\n\r\nI was home again, in San Francisco, without means and without\r\nemployment. I tortured my brain for a saving scheme of some kind, and at\r\nlast a public lecture occurred to me! I sat down and wrote one, in a\r\nfever of hopeful anticipation. I showed it to several friends, but they\r\nall shook their heads. They said nobody would come to hear me, and I\r\nwould make a humiliating failure of it.\r\n\r\nThey said that as I had never spoken in public, I would break down in\r\nthe delivery, anyhow. I was disconsolate now. But at last an editor\r\nslapped me on the back and told me to \xe2\x80\x9cgo ahead.\xe2\x80\x9d He said, \xe2\x80\x9cTake the\r\nlargest house in town, and charge a dollar a ticket.\xe2\x80\x9d The audacity of\r\nthe proposition was charming; it seemed fraught with practical worldly\r\nwisdom, however. The proprietor of the several theatres endorsed the\r\nadvice, and said I might have his handsome new opera-house at half\r\nprice\xe2\x80\x94fifty dollars. In sheer desperation I took it\xe2\x80\x94on credit, for\r\nsufficient reasons. In three days I did a hundred and fifty dollars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nworth of printing and advertising, and was the most distressed and\r\nfrightened creature on the Pacific coast. I could not sleep\xe2\x80\x94who could,\r\nunder such circumstances? For other people there was facetiousness in\r\nthe last line of my posters, but to me it was plaintive with a pang when\r\nI wrote it:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoors open at 7 1/2. The trouble will begin at 8.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat line has done good service since. Showmen have borrowed it\r\nfrequently. I have even seen it appended to a newspaper advertisement\r\nreminding school pupils in vacation what time next term would begin. As\r\nthose three days of suspense dragged by, I grew more and more unhappy. I\r\nhad sold two hundred tickets among my personal friends, but I feared\r\nthey might not come. My lecture, which had seemed \xe2\x80\x9chumorous\xe2\x80\x9d to me, at\r\nfirst, grew steadily more and more dreary, till not a vestige of fun\r\nseemed left, and I grieved that I could not bring a coffin on the stage\r\nand turn the thing into a funeral. I was so panic-stricken, at last,\r\nthat I went to three old friends, giants in stature, cordial by nature,\r\nand stormy-voiced, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis thing is going to be a failure; the jokes in it are so dim that\r\nnobody will ever see them; I would like to have you sit in the\r\nparquette, and help me through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey said they would. Then I went to the wife of a popular citizen, and\r\nsaid that if she was willing to do me a very great kindness, I would be\r\nglad if she and her husband would sit prominently in the left-hand\r\nstage- box, where the whole house could see them. I explained that I\r\nshould need help, and would turn toward her and smile, as a signal, when\r\nI had been delivered of an obscure joke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand then,\xe2\x80\x9d I added, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t wait\r\nto investigate, but _respond_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe promised. Down the street I met a man I never had seen before. He\r\nhad been drinking, and was beaming with smiles and good nature. He said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name\xe2\x80\x99s Sawyer. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know me, but that don\xe2\x80\x99t matter. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot a cent, but if you knew how bad I wanted to laugh, you\xe2\x80\x99d give me a\r\nticket. Come, now, what do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your laugh hung on a hair-trigger?\xe2\x80\x94that is, is it critical, or can\r\nyou get it off _easy_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy drawling infirmity of speech so affected him that he laughed a\r\nspecimen or two that struck me as being about the article I wanted, and\r\nI gave him a ticket, and appointed him to sit in the second circle, in\r\nthe centre, and be responsible for that division of the house. I gave\r\nhim minute instructions about how to detect indistinct jokes, and then\r\nwent away, and left him chuckling placidly over the novelty of the idea.\r\n\r\nI ate nothing on the last of the three eventful days\xe2\x80\x94I only suffered. I\r\nhad advertised that on this third day the box-office would be opened for\r\nthe sale of reserved seats. I crept down to the theater at four in the\r\nafternoon to see if any sales had been made. The ticket seller was gone,\r\nthe box-office was locked up. I had to swallow suddenly, or my heart\r\nwould have got out. \xe2\x80\x9cNo sales,\xe2\x80\x9d I said to myself; \xe2\x80\x9cI might have known\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d I thought of suicide, pretended illness, flight. I thought of these\r\nthings in earnest, for I was very miserable and scared. But of course I\r\nhad to drive them away, and prepare to meet my fate. I could not wait\r\nfor half-past seven\xe2\x80\x94I wanted to face the horror, and end it\xe2\x80\x94the feeling\r\nof many a man doomed to hang, no doubt. I went down back streets at six\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, and entered the theatre by the back door. I stumbled my way in\r\nthe dark among the ranks of canvas scenery, and stood on the stage. The\r\nhouse was gloomy and silent, and its emptiness depressing. I went into\r\nthe dark among the scenes again, and for an hour and a half gave myself\r\nup to the horrors, wholly unconscious of everything else. Then I heard a\r\nmurmur; it rose higher and higher, and ended in a crash, mingled with\r\ncheers. It made my hair raise, it was so close to me, and so loud.\r\n\r\nThere was a pause, and then another; presently came a third, and before\r\nI well knew what I was about, I was in the middle of the stage, staring\r\nat a sea of faces, bewildered by the fierce glare of the lights, and\r\nquaking in every limb with a terror that seemed like to take my life\r\naway.
