The house was full, aisles and all!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n561.jpg (45K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe tumult in my heart and brain and legs continued a full minute before\r\nI could gain any command over myself. Then I recognized the charity and\r\nthe friendliness in the faces before me, and little by little my fright\r\nmelted away, and I began to talk. Within three or four minutes I was\r\ncomfortable, and even content. My three chief allies, with three\r\nauxiliaries, were on hand, in the parquette, all sitting together, all\r\narmed with bludgeons, and all ready to make an onslaught upon the\r\nfeeblest joke that might show its head. And whenever a joke did fall,\r\ntheir bludgeons came down and their faces seemed to split from ear to\r\near;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n562.jpg (153K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSawyer, whose hearty countenance was seen looming redly in the centre of\r\nthe second circle, took it up, and the house was carried handsomely.\r\nInferior jokes never fared so royally before. Presently I delivered a\r\nbit of serious matter with impressive unction (it was my pet), and the\r\naudience listened with an absorbed hush that gratified me more than any\r\napplause; and as I dropped the last word of the clause, I happened to\r\nturn and catch Mrs.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99s intent and waiting eye; my conversation with her\r\nflashed upon me, and in spite of all I could do I smiled. She took it\r\nfor the signal, and promptly delivered a mellow laugh that touched off\r\nthe whole audience; and the explosion that followed was the triumph of\r\nthe evening. I thought that that honest man Sawyer would choke himself;\r\nand as for the bludgeons, they performed like pile-drivers. But my poor\r\nlittle morsel of pathos was ruined. It was taken in good faith as an\r\nintentional joke, and the prize one of the entertainment, and I wisely\r\nlet it go at that.\r\n\r\nAll the papers were kind in the morning; my appetite returned; I had a\r\nabundance of money. All\xe2\x80\x99s well that ends well.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LXXIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nI launched out as a lecturer, now, with great boldness. I had the field\r\nall to myself, for public lectures were almost an unknown commodity in\r\nthe Pacific market. They are not so rare, now, I suppose. I took an old\r\npersonal friend along to play agent for me, and for two or three weeks\r\nwe roamed through Nevada and California and had a very cheerful time of\r\nit. Two days before I lectured in Virginia City, two stagecoaches were\r\nrobbed within two miles of the town. The daring act was committed just\r\nat dawn, by six masked men, who sprang up alongside the coaches,\r\npresented revolvers at the heads of the drivers and passengers, and\r\ncommanded a general dismount. Everybody climbed down, and the robbers\r\ntook their watches and every cent they had. Then they took gunpowder and\r\nblew up the express specie boxes and got their contents. The leader of\r\nthe robbers was a small, quick-spoken man, and the fame of his vigorous\r\nmanner and his intrepidity was in everybody\xe2\x80\x99s mouth when we arrived.\r\n\r\nThe night after instructing Virginia, I walked over the desolate\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d and down to Gold Hill, and lectured there. The lecture done, I\r\nstopped to talk with a friend, and did not start back till eleven. The\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d was high, unoccupied ground, between the towns, the scene of\r\ntwenty midnight murders and a hundred robberies. As we climbed up and\r\nstepped out on this eminence, the Gold Hill lights dropped out of sight\r\nat our backs, and the night closed down gloomy and dismal. A sharp wind\r\nswept the place, too, and chilled our perspiring bodies through.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you I don\xe2\x80\x99t like this place at night,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mike the agent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak so loud,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t remind anybody that we\r\nare here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then a dim figure approached me from the direction of Virginia\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nman, evidently. He came straight at me, and I stepped aside to let him\r\npass; he stepped in the way and confronted me again. Then I saw that he\r\nhad a mask on and was holding something in my face\xe2\x80\x94I heard a click-click\r\nand recognized a revolver in dim outline. I pushed the barrel aside with\r\nmy hand and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe ejaculated sharply:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour watch! Your money!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can have them with pleasure\xe2\x80\x94but take the pistol away from my face,\r\nplease. It makes me shiver.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo remarks! Hand out your money!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut up your _hands_! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you go for a weapon! Put \xe2\x80\x99em up! Higher!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI held them above my head.\r\n\r\nA pause. Then:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Are_ you going to hand out your money or _not_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI dropped my hands to my pockets and said:\r\n\r\nCertainly! I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut up your hands! Do you want your head blown off? Higher!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI put them above my head again.\r\n\r\nAnother pause.\r\n\r\nAre you going to hand out your money or not? Ah-ah\xe2\x80\x94again? Put up your\r\nhands! By George, you want the head shot off you awful bad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, friend, I\xe2\x80\x99m trying my best to please you. You tell me to give up\r\nmy money, and when I reach for it you tell me to put up my hands. If you\r\nwould only\xe2\x80\x94. Oh, now\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t! All six of you at me! That other man will\r\nget away while.\xe2\x80\x94Now please take some of those revolvers out of my\r\nface\xe2\x80\x94_do_, if you _please_! Every time one of them clicks, my liver\r\ncomes up into my throat! If you have a mother\xe2\x80\x94any of you\xe2\x80\x94or if any of\r\nyou have ever _had_ a mother\xe2\x80\x94or a\xe2\x80\x94grandmother\xe2\x80\x94or a\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCheese it! _Will_ you give up your money, or have we got to\xe2\x80\x94.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x94none of that! Put up your _hands_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen\xe2\x80\x94I know you are gentlemen by your\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence! If you want to be facetious, young man, there are times and\r\nplaces more fitting. _This_ is a serious business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou prick the marrow of my opinion. The funerals I have attended in my\r\ntime were comedies compared to it. Now _I_ think\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCurse your palaver! Your money!\xe2\x80\x94your money!\xe2\x80\x94your money! Hold!\xe2\x80\x94put up\r\nyour hands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, listen to reason. You _see_ how I am situated\xe2\x80\x94now _don\xe2\x80\x99t_\r\nput those pistols so close\xe2\x80\x94I smell the powder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see how I am situated. If I had four hands\xe2\x80\x94so that I could hold up\r\ntwo and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrottle him! Gag him! Kill him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, _don\xe2\x80\x99t_! Nobody\xe2\x80\x99s watching the other fellow. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t some\r\nof you\xe2\x80\x94. Ouch! Take it away, please!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, you see that I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to hold up my hands; and so I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntake out my money\xe2\x80\x94but if you\xe2\x80\x99ll be so kind as to take it out for me, I\r\nwill do as much for you some\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSearch him Beauregard\xe2\x80\x94and stop his jaw with a bullet, quick, if he wags\r\nit again. Help Beauregard, Stonewall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen three of them, with the small, spry leader, adjourned to Mike and\r\nfell to searching him. I was so excited that my lawless fancy tortured\r\nme to ask my two men all manner of facetious questions about their rebel\r\nbrother-generals of the South, but, considering the order they had\r\nreceived, it was but common prudence to keep still. When everything had\r\nbeen taken from me,\xe2\x80\x94watch, money, and a multitude of trifles of small\r\nvalue,\xe2\x80\x94I supposed I was free, and forthwith put my cold hands into my\r\nempty pockets and began an inoffensive jig to warm my feet and stir up\r\nsome latent courage\xe2\x80\x94but instantly all pistols were at my head, and the\r\norder came again:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe still! Put up your hands! And keep them up!\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n567.jpg (72K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThey stood Mike up alongside of me, with strict orders to keep his hands\r\nabove his head, too, and then the chief highwayman said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeauregard, hide behind that boulder; Phil Sheridan, you hide behind\r\nthat other one; Stonewall Jackson, put yourself behind that sage-bush\r\nthere. Keep your pistols bearing on these fellows, and if they take down\r\ntheir hands within ten minutes, or move a single peg, let them have it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen three disappeared in the gloom toward the several ambushes, and the\r\nother three disappeared down the road toward Virginia.\r\n\r\nIt was depressingly still, and miserably cold. Now this whole thing was\r\na practical joke, and the robbers were personal friends of ours in\r\ndisguise, and twenty more lay hidden within ten feet of us during the\r\nwhole operation, listening. Mike knew all this, and was in the joke, but\r\nI suspected nothing of it. To me it was most uncomfortably genuine. When\r\nwe had stood there in the middle of the road five minutes, like a couple\r\nof idiots, with our hands aloft, freezing to death by inches, Mike\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninterest in the joke began to wane. He said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe time\xe2\x80\x99s up, now, aint it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you keep still. Do you want to take any chances with these bloody\r\nsavages?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPresently Mike said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Now_ the time\xe2\x80\x99s up, anyway. I\xe2\x80\x99m freezing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell freeze. Better freeze than carry your brains home in a basket.\r\nMaybe the time _is_ up, but how do _we_ know?\xe2\x80\x94got no watch to tell by. I\r\nmean to give them good measure. I calculate to stand here fifteen\r\nminutes or die. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you move.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo, without knowing it, I was making one joker very sick of his\r\ncontract. When we took our arms down at last, they were aching with cold\r\nand fatigue, and when we went sneaking off, the dread I was in that the\r\ntime might not yet be up and that we would feel bullets in a moment, was\r\nnot sufficient to draw all my attention from the misery that racked my\r\nstiffened body.\r\n\r\nThe joke of these highwayman friends of ours was mainly a joke upon\r\nthemselves; for they had waited for me on the cold hill-top two full\r\nhours before I came, and there was very little fun in that; they were so\r\nchilled that it took them a couple of weeks to get warm again. Moreover,\r\nI never had a thought that they would kill me to get money which it was\r\nso perfectly easy to get without any such folly, and so they did not\r\nreally frighten me bad enough to make their enjoyment worth the trouble\r\nthey had taken. I was only afraid that their weapons would go off\r\naccidentally. Their very numbers inspired me with confidence that no\r\nblood would be intentionally spilled. They were not smart; they ought to\r\nhave sent only _one_ highwayman, with a double-barrelled shot gun, if\r\nthey desired to see the author of this volume climb a tree.\r\n\r\nHowever, I suppose that in the long run I got the largest share of the\r\njoke at last; and in a shape not foreseen by the highwaymen; for the\r\nchilly exposure on the \xe2\x80\x9cdivide\xe2\x80\x9d while I was in a perspiration gave me a\r\ncold which developed itself into a troublesome disease and kept my hands\r\nidle some three months, besides costing me quite a sum in doctor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbills. Since then I play no practical jokes on people and generally lose\r\nmy temper when one is played upon me.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n569.jpg (39K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen I returned to San Francisco I projected a pleasure journey to Japan\r\nand thence westward around the world; but a desire to see home again\r\nchanged my mind, and I took a berth in the steamship, bade good-bye to\r\nthe friendliest land and livest, heartiest community on our continent,\r\nand came by the way of the Isthmus to New York\xe2\x80\x94a trip that was not much\r\nof a pic-nic excursion, for the cholera broke out among us on the\r\npassage and we buried two or three bodies at sea every day. I found home\r\na dreary place after my long absence; for half the children I had known\r\nwere now wearing whiskers or waterfalls, and few of the grown people I\r\nhad been acquainted with remained at their hearthstones prosperous and\r\nhappy\xe2\x80\x94some of them had wandered to other scenes, some were in jail, and\r\nthe rest had been hanged. These changes touched me deeply, and I went\r\naway and joined the famous Quaker City European Excursion and carried my\r\ntears to foreign lands.\r\n\r\nThus, after seven years of vicissitudes, ended a \xe2\x80\x9cpleasure trip\xe2\x80\x9d to the\r\nsilver mines of Nevada which had originally been intended to occupy only\r\nthree months. However, I usually miss my calculations further than that.\r\n\r\nMORAL.\r\n\r\nIf the reader thinks he is done, now, and that this book has no moral to\r\nit, he is in error. The moral of it is this: If you are of any account,\r\nstay at home and make your way by faithful diligence; but if you are \xe2\x80\x9cno\r\naccount,\xe2\x80\x9d go away from home, and then you will _have_ to work, whether\r\nyou want to or not. Thus you become a blessing to your friends by\r\nceasing to be a nuisance to them\xe2\x80\x94if the people you go among suffer by\r\nthe operation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n570.jpg (75K)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAPPENDIX.\r\n\r\n\r\nAPPENDIX. A.\r\n\r\nBRIEF SKETCH OF MORMON HISTORY.\r\n\r\nMormonism is only about forty years old, but its career has been full of\r\nstir and adventure from the beginning, and is likely to remain so to the\r\nend. Its adherents have been hunted and hounded from one end of the\r\ncountry to the other, and the result is that for years they have hated\r\nall \xe2\x80\x9cGentiles\xe2\x80\x9d indiscriminately and with all their might. Joseph Smith,\r\nthe finder of the Book of Mormon and founder of the religion, was driven\r\nfrom State to State with his mysterious copperplates and the miraculous\r\nstones he read their inscriptions with. Finally he instituted his\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cchurch\xe2\x80\x9d in Ohio and Brigham Young joined it. The neighbors began to\r\npersecute, and apostasy commenced. Brigham held to the faith and worked\r\nhard. He arrested desertion. He did more\xe2\x80\x94he added converts in the midst\r\nof the trouble. He rose in favor and importance with the brethren. He\r\nwas made one of the Twelve Apostles of the Church. He shortly fought his\r\nway to a higher post and a more powerful\xe2\x80\x94President of the Twelve. The\r\nneighbors rose up and drove the Mormons out of Ohio, and they settled in\r\nMissouri. Brigham went with them. The Missourians drove them out and\r\nthey retreated to Nauvoo, Illinois. They prospered there, and built a\r\ntemple which made some pretensions to architectural grace and achieved\r\nsome celebrity in a section of country where a brick court-house with a\r\ntin dome and a cupola on it was contemplated with reverential awe. But\r\nthe Mormons were badgered and harried again by their neighbors. All the\r\nproclamations Joseph Smith could issue denouncing polygamy and\r\nrepudiating it as utterly anti-Mormon were of no avail; the people of\r\nthe neighborhood, on both sides of the Mississippi, claimed that\r\npolygamy was practised by the Mormons, and not only polygamy but a\r\nlittle of everything that was bad. Brigham returned from a mission to\r\nEngland, where he had established a Mormon newspaper, and he brought\r\nback with him several hundred converts to his preaching. His influence\r\namong the brethren augmented with every move he made. Finally Nauvoo was\r\ninvaded by the Missouri and Illinois Gentiles, and Joseph Smith killed.\r\nA Mormon named Rigdon assumed the Presidency of the Mormon church and\r\ngovernment, in Smith\xe2\x80\x99s place, and even tried his hand at a prophecy or\r\ntwo. But a greater than he was at hand. Brigham seized the advantage of\r\nthe hour and without other authority than superior brain and nerve and\r\nwill, hurled Rigdon from his high place and occupied it himself. He did\r\nmore. He launched an elaborate curse at Rigdon and his disciples; and he\r\npronounced Rigdon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cprophecies\xe2\x80\x9d emanations from the devil, and ended by\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chanding the false prophet over to the buffetings of Satan for a\r\nthousand years\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94probably the longest term ever inflicted in Illinois.\r\nThe people recognized their master. They straightway elected Brigham\r\nYoung President, by a prodigious majority, and have never faltered in\r\ntheir devotion to him from that day to this. Brigham had forecast\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nquality which no other prominent Mormon has probably ever possessed. He\r\nrecognized that it was better to move to the wilderness than _be_ moved.\r\nBy his command the people gathered together their meagre effects, turned\r\ntheir backs upon their homes, and their faces toward the wilderness, and\r\non a bitter night in February filed in sorrowful procession across the\r\nfrozen Mississippi, lighted on their way by the glare from their burning\r\ntemple, whose sacred furniture their own hands had fired! They camped,\r\nseveral days afterward, on the western verge of Iowa, and poverty, want,\r\nhunger, cold, sickness, grief and persecution did their work, and many\r\nsuccumbed and died\xe2\x80\x94martyrs, fair and true, whatever else they might have\r\nbeen. Two years the remnant remained there, while Brigham and a small\r\nparty crossed the country and founded Great Salt Lake City, purposely\r\nchoosing a land _which was outside the ownership and jurisdiction of the\r\nhated American nation_. Note that. This was in 1847. Brigham moved his\r\npeople there and got them settled just in time to see disaster fall\r\nagain. For the war closed and Mexico ceded Brigham\xe2\x80\x99s refuge to the\r\nenemy\xe2\x80\x94the United States! In 1849 the Mormons organized a \xe2\x80\x9cfree and\r\nindependent\xe2\x80\x9d government and erected the \xe2\x80\x9cState of Deseret,\xe2\x80\x9d with Brigham\r\nYoung as its head. But the very next year Congress deliberately snubbed\r\nit and created the \xe2\x80\x9cTerritory of Utah\xe2\x80\x9d out of the same accumulation of\r\nmountains, sage-brush, alkali and general desolation,\xe2\x80\x94but made Brigham\r\nGovernor of it. Then for years the enormous migration across the plains\r\nto California poured through the land of the Mormons and yet the church\r\nremained staunch and true to its lord and master. Neither hunger,\r\nthirst, poverty, grief, hatred, contempt, nor persecution could drive\r\nthe Mormons from their faith or their allegiance; and even the thirst\r\nfor gold, which gleaned the flower of the youth and strength of many\r\nnations was not able to entice them! That was the final test. An\r\nexperiment that could survive that was an experiment with some substance\r\nto it somewhere.\r\n\r\nGreat Salt Lake City throve finely, and so did Utah. One of the last\r\nthings which Brigham Young had done before leaving Iowa, was to appear\r\nin the pulpit dressed to personate the worshipped and lamented prophet\r\nSmith, and confer the prophetic succession, with all its dignities,\r\nemoluments and authorities, upon \xe2\x80\x9cPresident Brigham Young!\xe2\x80\x9d The people\r\naccepted the pious fraud with the maddest enthusiasm, and Brigham\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npower was sealed and secured for all time. Within five years afterward\r\nhe openly added polygamy to the tenets of the church by authority of a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9crevelation\xe2\x80\x9d which he pretended had been received nine years before by\r\nJoseph Smith, albeit Joseph is amply on record as denouncing polygamy to\r\nthe day of his death.\r\n\r\nNow was Brigham become a second Andrew Johnson in the small beginning\r\nand steady progress of his official grandeur. He had served successively\r\nas a disciple in the ranks; home missionary; foreign missionary; editor\r\nand publisher; Apostle; President of the Board of Apostles; President of\r\nall Mormondom, civil and ecclesiastical; successor to the great Joseph\r\nby the will of heaven; \xe2\x80\x9cprophet,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cseer,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9crevelator.\xe2\x80\x9d There was but one\r\ndignity higher which he _could_ aspire to, and he reached out modestly\r\nand took that\xe2\x80\x94he proclaimed himself a God!\r\n\r\nHe claims that he is to have a heaven of his own hereafter, and that he\r\nwill be its God, and his wives and children its goddesses, princes and\r\nprincesses. Into it all faithful Mormons will be admitted, with their\r\nfamilies, and will take rank and consequence according to the number of\r\ntheir wives and children. If a disciple dies before he has had time to\r\naccumulate enough wives and children to enable him to be respectable in\r\nthe next world any friend can marry a few wives and raise a few children\r\nfor him _after he is dead_, and they are duly credited to his account\r\nand his heavenly status advanced accordingly.\r\n\r\nLet it be borne in mind that the majority of the Mormons have always\r\nbeen ignorant, simple, of an inferior order of intellect, unacquainted\r\nwith the world and its ways; and let it be borne in mind that the wives\r\nof these Mormons are necessarily after the same pattern and their\r\nchildren likely to be fit representatives of such a conjunction; and\r\nthen let it be remembered that _for forty years_ these creatures have\r\nbeen driven, driven, driven, relentlessly! and mobbed, beaten, and shot\r\ndown; cursed, despised, expatriated; banished to a remote desert,\r\nwhither they journeyed gaunt with famine and disease, disturbing the\r\nancient solitudes with their lamentations and marking the long way with\r\ngraves of their dead\xe2\x80\x94and all because they were simply trying to live and\r\nworship God in the way which _they_ believed with all their hearts and\r\nsouls to be the true one. Let all these things be borne in mind, and\r\nthen it will not be hard to account for the deathless hatred which the\r\nMormons bear our people and our government.\r\n\r\nThat hatred has \xe2\x80\x9cfed fat its ancient grudge\xe2\x80\x9d ever since Mormon Utah\r\ndeveloped into a self-supporting realm and the church waxed rich and\r\nstrong. Brigham as Territorial Governor made it plain that Mormondom was\r\nfor the Mormons. The United States tried to rectify all that by\r\nappointing territorial officers from New England and other anti-Mormon\r\nlocalities, but Brigham prepared to make their entrance into his\r\ndominions difficult. Three thousand United States troops had to go\r\nacross the plains and put these gentlemen in office. And after they were\r\nin office they were as helpless as so many stone images. They made laws\r\nwhich nobody minded and which could not be executed. The federal judges\r\nopened court in a land filled with crime and violence and sat as holiday\r\nspectacles for insolent crowds to gape at\xe2\x80\x94for there was nothing to try,\r\nnothing to do nothing on the dockets! And if a Gentile brought a suit,\r\nthe Mormon jury would do just as it pleased about bringing in a verdict,\r\nand when the judgment of the court was rendered no Mormon cared for it\r\nand no officer could execute it. Our Presidents shipped one cargo of\r\nofficials after another to Utah, but the result was always the same\xe2\x80\x94they\r\nsat in a blight for awhile they fairly feasted on scowls and insults day\r\nby day, they saw every attempt to do their official duties find its\r\nreward in darker and darker looks, and in secret threats and warnings of\r\na more and more dismal nature\xe2\x80\x94and at last they either succumbed and\r\nbecame despised tools and toys of the Mormons, or got scared and\r\ndiscomforted beyond all endurance and left the Territory. If a brave\r\nofficer kept on courageously till his pluck was proven, some pliant\r\nBuchanan or Pierce would remove him and appoint a stick in his place. In\r\n1857 General Harney came very near being appointed Governor of Utah. And\r\nso it came very near being Harney governor and Cradlebaugh judge!\xe2\x80\x94two\r\nmen who never had any idea of fear further than the sort of murky\r\ncomprehension of it which they were enabled to gather from the\r\ndictionary. Simply (if for nothing else) for the variety they would have\r\nmade in a rather monotonous history of Federal servility and\r\nhelplessness, it is a pity they were not fated to hold office together\r\nin Utah.\r\n\r\nUp to the date of our visit to Utah, such had been the Territorial\r\nrecord. The Territorial government established there had been a hopeless\r\nfailure, and Brigham Young was the only real power in the land. He was\r\nan absolute monarch\xe2\x80\x94a monarch who defied our President\xe2\x80\x94a monarch who\r\nlaughed at our armies when they camped about his capital\xe2\x80\x94a monarch who\r\nreceived without emotion the news that the august Congress of the United\r\nStates had enacted a solemn law against polygamy, and then went forth\r\ncalmly and married twenty-five or thirty more wives.\r\n\r\nB. THE MOUNTAIN MEADOWS MASSACRE.\r\n\r\nThe persecutions which the Mormons suffered so long\xe2\x80\x94and which they\r\nconsider they still suffer in not being allowed to govern\r\nthemselves\xe2\x80\x94they have endeavored and are still endeavoring to repay. The\r\nnow almost forgotten \xe2\x80\x9cMountain Meadows massacre\xe2\x80\x9d was their work. It was\r\nvery famous in its day. The whole United States rang with its horrors. A\r\nfew items will refresh the reader\xe2\x80\x99s memory. A great emigrant train from\r\nMissouri and Arkansas passed through Salt Lake City and a few\r\ndisaffected Mormons joined it for the sake of the strong protection it\r\nafforded for their escape. In that matter lay sufficient cause for hot\r\nretaliation by the Mormon chiefs. Besides, these one hundred and forty-\r\nfive or one hundred and fifty unsuspecting emigrants being in part from\r\nArkansas, where a noted Mormon missionary had lately been killed, and in\r\npart from Missouri, a State remembered with execrations as a bitter\r\npersecutor of the saints when they were few and poor and friendless,\r\nhere were substantial additional grounds for lack of love for these\r\nwayfarers. And finally, this train was rich, very rich in cattle,\r\nhorses, mules and other property\xe2\x80\x94and how could the Mormons consistently\r\nkeep up their coveted resemblance to the Israelitish tribes and not\r\nseize the \xe2\x80\x9cspoil\xe2\x80\x9d of an enemy when the Lord had so manifestly \xe2\x80\x9cdelivered\r\nit into their hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWherefore, according to Mrs. C. V. Waite\xe2\x80\x99s entertaining book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nMormon Prophet,\xe2\x80\x9d it transpired that\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA \xe2\x80\x98revelation\xe2\x80\x99 from Brigham Young, as Great Grand Archee or God, was\r\ndispatched to President J. C. Haight, Bishop Higbee and J. D. Lee\r\n(adopted son of Brigham), commanding them to raise all the forces they\r\ncould muster and trust, follow those cursed Gentiles (so read the\r\nrevelation), attack them disguised as Indians, and with the arrows of\r\nthe Almighty make a clean sweep of them, and leave none to tell the\r\ntale; and if they needed any assistance they were commanded to hire the\r\nIndians as their allies, promising them a share of the booty. They were\r\nto be neither slothful nor negligent in their duty, and to be punctual\r\nin sending the teams back to him before winter set in, for this was the\r\nmandate of Almighty God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe command of the \xe2\x80\x9crevelation\xe2\x80\x9d was faithfully obeyed. A large party of\r\nMormons, painted and tricked out as Indians, overtook the train of\r\nemigrant wagons some three hundred miles south of Salt Lake City, and\r\nmade an attack. But the emigrants threw up earthworks, made fortresses\r\nof their wagons and defended themselves gallantly and successfully for\r\nfive days! Your Missouri or Arkansas gentleman is not much afraid of the\r\nsort of scurvy apologies for \xe2\x80\x9cIndians\xe2\x80\x9d which the southern part of Utah\r\naffords. He would stand up and fight five hundred of them.\r\n\r\nAt the end of the five days the Mormons tried military strategy. They\r\nretired to the upper end of the \xe2\x80\x9cMeadows,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed civilized apparel,\r\nwashed off their paint, and then, heavily armed, drove down in wagons to\r\nthe beleaguered emigrants, bearing a flag of truce! When the emigrants\r\nsaw white men coming they threw down their guns and welcomed them with\r\ncheer after cheer! And, all unconscious of the poetry of it, no doubt,\r\nthey lifted a little child aloft, dressed in white, in answer to the\r\nflag of truce!\r\n\r\nThe leaders of the timely white \xe2\x80\x9cdeliverers\xe2\x80\x9d were President Haight and\r\nBishop John D. Lee, of the Mormon Church. Mr. Cradlebaugh, who served a\r\nterm as a Federal Judge in Utah and afterward was sent to Congress from\r\nNevada, tells in a speech delivered in Congress how these leaders next\r\nproceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey professed to be on good terms with the Indians, and represented\r\nthem as being very mad. They also proposed to intercede and settle the\r\nmatter with the Indians. After several hours parley they, having\r\n(apparently) visited the Indians, gave the _ultimatum_ of the savages;\r\nwhich was, that the emigrants should march out of their camp, leaving\r\neverything behind them, even their guns. It was promised by the Mormon\r\nbishops that they would bring a force and guard the emigrants back to\r\nthe settlements. The terms were agreed to, the emigrants being desirous\r\nof saving the lives of their families. The Mormons retired, and\r\nsubsequently appeared with thirty or forty armed men. The emigrants were\r\nmarched out, the women and children in front and the men behind, the\r\nMormon guard being in the rear. When they had marched in this way about\r\na mile, at a given signal the slaughter commenced. The men were almost\r\nall shot down at the first fire from the guard. Two only escaped, who\r\nfled to the desert, and were followed one hundred and fifty miles before\r\nthey were overtaken and slaughtered. The women and children ran on, two\r\nor three hundred yards further, when they were overtaken and with the\r\naid of the Indians they were slaughtered. Seventeen individuals only, of\r\nall the emigrant party, were spared, and they were little children, the\r\neldest of them being only seven years old. Thus, on the 10th day of\r\nSeptember, 1857, was consummated one of the most cruel, cowardly and\r\nbloody murders known in our history.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe number of persons butchered by the Mormons on this occasion was _one\r\nhundred and twenty_.\r\n\r\nWith unheard-of temerity Judge Cradlebaugh opened his court and\r\nproceeded to make Mormondom answer for the massacre. And what a\r\nspectacle it must have been to see this grim veteran, solitary and alone\r\nin his pride and his pluck, glowering down on his Mormon jury and Mormon\r\nauditory, deriding them by turns, and by turns \xe2\x80\x9cbreathing threatenings\r\nand slaughter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn editorial in the _Territorial Enterprise_ of that day says of him and\r\nof the occasion:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe spoke and acted with the fearlessness and resolution of a Jackson;\r\nbut the jury failed to indict, or even report on the charges, while\r\nthreats of violence were heard in every quarter, and an attack on the\r\nU.S. troops intimated, if he persisted in his course.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFinding that nothing could be done with the juries, they were\r\ndischarged with a scathing rebuke from the judge. And then, sitting as a\r\ncommitting magistrate, _he commenced his task alone_. He examined\r\nwitnesses, made arrests in every quarter, and created a consternation in\r\nthe camps of the saints greater than any they had ever witnessed before,\r\nsince Mormondom was born. At last accounts terrified elders and bishops\r\nwere decamping to save their necks; and developments of the most\r\nstarling character were being made, implicating the highest Church\r\ndignitaries in the many murders and robberies committed upon the\r\nGentiles during the past eight years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHad Harney been Governor, Cradlebaugh would have been supported in his\r\nwork, and the absolute proofs adduced by him of Mormon guilt in this\r\nmassacre and in a number of previous murders, would have conferred\r\ngratuitous coffins upon certain citizens, together with occasion to use\r\nthem. But Cumming was the Federal Governor, and he, under a curious\r\npretense of impartiality, sought to screen the Mormons from the demands\r\nof justice. On one occasion he even went so far as to publish his\r\nprotest against the use of the U.S. troops in aid of Cradlebaugh\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproceedings.\r\n\r\nMrs. C. V. Waite closes her interesting detail of the great massacre\r\nwith the following remark and accompanying summary of the testimony\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthe summary is concise, accurate and reliable:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the benefit of those who may still be disposed to doubt the guilt\r\nof Young and his Mormons in this transaction, the testimony is here\r\ncollated and circumstances given which go not merely to implicate but to\r\nfasten conviction upon them by \xe2\x80\x98confirmations strong as proofs of Holy\r\nWrit:\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c1. The evidence of Mormons themselves, engaged in the affair, as shown\r\nby the statements of Judge Cradlebaugh and Deputy U.S. Marshall Rodgers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c2. The failure of Brigham Young to embody any account of it in his\r\nReport as Superintendent of Indian Affairs. Also his failure to make any\r\nallusion to it whatever from the pulpit, until several years after the\r\noccurrence\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c3. The flight to the mountains of men high in authority in the Mormon\r\nChurch and State, when this affair was brought to the ordeal of a\r\njudicial investigation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c4. The failure of the _Deseret News_, the Church organ, and the only\r\npaper then published in the Territory, to notice the massacre until\r\nseveral months afterward, and then only to deny that Mormons were\r\nengaged in it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c5. The testimony of the children saved from the massacre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c6. The children and the property of the emigrants found in possession\r\nof the Mormons, and that possession traced back to the very day after\r\nthe massacre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c7. The statements of Indians in the neighborhood of the scene of the\r\nmassacre: these statements are shown, not only by Cradlebaugh and\r\nRodgers, but by a number of military officers, and by J. Forney, who\r\nwas, in 1859, Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Territory. To all\r\nthese were such statements freely and frequently made by the Indians.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c8. The testimony of R. P. Campbell, Capt. 2d Dragoons, who was sent in\r\nthe Spring of 1859 to Santa Clara, to protect travelers on the road to\r\nCalifornia and to inquire into Indian depredations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nC. CONCERNING A FRIGHTFUL ASSASSINATION THAT WAS NEVER CONSUMMATED\r\n\r\n[If ever there was a harmless man, it is Conrad Wiegand, of Gold Hill,\r\nNevada. If ever there was a gentle spirit that thought itself unfired\r\ngunpowder and latent ruin, it is Conrad Wiegand. If ever there was an\r\noyster that fancied itself a whale; or a jack-o\xe2\x80\x99lantern, confined to a\r\nswamp, that fancied itself a planet with a billion-mile orbit; or a\r\nsummer zephyr that deemed itself a hurricane, it is Conrad Wiegand.\r\nTherefore, what wonder is it that when he says a thing, he thinks the\r\nworld listens; that when he does a thing the world stands still to look;\r\nand that when he suffers, there is a convulsion of nature? When I met\r\nConrad, he was \xe2\x80\x9cSuperintendent of the Gold Hill Assay Office\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he was\r\nnot only its Superintendent, but its entire force. And he was a street\r\npreacher, too, with a mongrel religion of his own invention, whereby he\r\nexpected to regenerate the universe. This was years ago. Here latterly\r\nhe has entered journalism; and his journalism is what it might be\r\nexpected to be: colossal to ear, but pigmy to the eye. It is extravagant\r\ngrandiloquence confined to a newspaper about the size of a double letter\r\nsheet. He doubtless edits, sets the type, and prints his paper, all\r\nalone; but he delights to speak of the concern as if it occupies a block\r\nand employs a thousand men.\r\n\r\n[Something less than two years ago, Conrad assailed several people\r\nmercilessly in his little \xe2\x80\x9cPeople\xe2\x80\x99s _Tribune_,\xe2\x80\x9d and got himself into\r\ntrouble. Straightway he airs the affair in the \xe2\x80\x9cTerritorial Enterprise,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nin a communication over his own signature, and I propose to reproduce it\r\nhere, in all its native simplicity and more than human candor. Long as\r\nit is, it is well worth reading, for it is the richest specimen of\r\njournalistic literature the history of America can furnish, perhaps:]\r\n\r\nFrom the _Territorial Enterprise_, Jan. 20, 1870.\r\n\r\nSEEMING PLOT FOR ASSASSINATION MISCARRIED.\r\n\r\nTO THE EDITOR OF THE ENTERPRISE: Months ago, when Mr. Sutro incidentally\r\nexposed mining management on the Comstock, and among others roused me to\r\nprotest against its continuance, in great kindness you warned me that\r\nany attempt by publications, by public meetings and by legislative\r\naction, aimed at the correction of chronic mining evils in Storey\r\nCounty, must entail upon me (a) business ruin, (b) the burden of all its\r\ncosts, (c) personal violence, and if my purpose were persisted in, then\r\n(d) assassination, and after all nothing would be effected.\r\n\r\nYOUR PROPHECY FULFILLING. In large part at least your prophecies have\r\nbeen fulfilled, for (a) assaying, which was well attended to in the Gold\r\nHill Assay Office (of which I am superintendent), in consequence of my\r\npublications, has been taken elsewhere, so the President of one of the\r\ncompanies assures me. With no reason assigned, other work has been taken\r\naway. With but one or two important exceptions, our assay business now\r\nconsists simply of the gleanings of the vicinity. (b) Though my own\r\npersonal donations to the People\xe2\x80\x99s Tribune Association have already\r\nexceeded $1,500, outside of our own numbers we have received (in money)\r\nless than $300 as contributions and subscriptions for the journal. (c)\r\nOn Thursday last, on the main street in Gold Hill, near noon, with\r\nneither warning nor cause assigned, by a powerful blow I was felled to\r\nthe ground, and while down I was kicked by a man who it would seem had\r\nbeen led to believe that I had spoken derogatorily of him. By whom he\r\nwas so induced to believe I am as yet unable to say. On Saturday last I\r\nwas again assailed and beaten by a man who first informed me why he did\r\nso, and who persisted in making his assault even after the erroneous\r\nimpression under which he also was at first laboring had been clearly\r\nand repeatedly pointed out. This same man, after failing through\r\nintimidation to elicit from me the names of our editorial contributors,\r\nagainst giving which he knew me to be pledged, beat himself weary upon\r\nme with a raw hide, I not resisting, and then pantingly threatened me\r\nwith permanent disfiguring mayhem, if ever again I should introduce his\r\nname into print, and who but a few minutes before his attack upon me\r\nassured me that the only reason I was \xe2\x80\x9cpermitted\xe2\x80\x9d to reach home alive on\r\nWednesday evening last (at which time the PEOPLE\xe2\x80\x99S TRIBUNE was issued)\r\nwas, that he deems me only half-witted, and be it remembered the very\r\nnext morning I was knocked down and kicked by a man who seemed to be\r\nprepared for flight. [He sees doom impending:]\r\n\r\nWHEN WILL THE CIRCLE JOIN? How long before the whole of your prophecy\r\nwill be fulfilled I cannot say, but under the shadow of so much\r\nfulfillment in so short a time, and with such threats from a man who is\r\none of the most prominent exponents of the San Francisco mining-ring\r\nstaring me and this whole community defiantly in the face and pointing\r\nto a completion of your augury, do you blame me for feeling that this\r\ncommunication is the last I shall ever write for the Press, especially\r\nwhen a sense alike of personal self-respect, of duty to this money-\r\noppressed and fear-ridden community, and of American fealty to the\r\nspirit of true Liberty all command me, and each more loudly than love of\r\nlife itself, to declare the name of that prominent man to be JOHN B.\r\nWINTERS, President of the Yellow Jacket Company, a political aspirant\r\nand a military General? The name of his partially duped accomplice and\r\nabettor in this last marvelous assault, is no other than PHILIP LYNCH,\r\nEditor and Proprietor of the Gold Hill News.\r\n\r\nDespite the insult and wrong heaped upon me by John B. Winters, on\r\nSaturday afternoon, only a glimpse of which I shall be able to afford\r\nyour readers, so much do I deplore clinching (by publicity) a serious\r\nmistake of any one, man or woman, committed under natural and not self-\r\nwrought passion, in view of his great apparent excitement at the time\r\nand in view of the almost perfect privacy of the assault, I am far from\r\nsure that I should not have given him space for repentance before\r\nexposing him, were it not that he himself has so far exposed the matter\r\nas to make it the common talk of the town that he has horsewhipped me.\r\nThat fact having been made public, all the facts in connection need to\r\nbe also, or silence on my part would seem more than singular, and with\r\nmany would be proof either that I was conscious of some unworthy aim in\r\npublishing the article, or else that my \xe2\x80\x9cnon-combatant\xe2\x80\x9d principles are\r\nbut a convenient cloak alike of physical and moral cowardice. I\r\ntherefore shall try to present a graphic but truthful picture of this\r\nwhole affair, but shall forbear all comments, presuming that the editors\r\nof our own journal, if others do not, will speak freely and fittingly\r\nupon this subject in our next number, whether I shall then be dead or\r\nliving, for my death will not stop, though it may suspend, the\r\npublication of the PEOPLE\xe2\x80\x99S TRIBUNE. [The \xe2\x80\x9cnon-combatant\xe2\x80\x9d sticks to\r\nprinciple, but takes along a friend or two of a conveniently different\r\nstripe:]\r\n\r\nTHE TRAP SET. On Saturday morning John B. Winters sent verbal word to\r\nthe Gold Hill Assay Office that he desired to see me at the Yellow\r\nJacket office. Though such a request struck me as decidedly cool in view\r\nof his own recent discourtesies to me there alike as a publisher and as\r\na stockholder in the Yellow Jacket mine, and though it seemed to me more\r\nlike a summons than the courteous request by one gentleman to another\r\nfor a favor, hoping that some conference with Sharon looking to the\r\nbetterment of mining matters in Nevada might arise from it, I felt\r\nstrongly inclined to overlook what possibly was simply an oversight in\r\ncourtesy. But as then it had only been two days since I had been bruised\r\nand beaten under a hasty and false apprehension of facts, my caution was\r\nsomewhat aroused. Moreover I remembered sensitively his contemptuousness\r\nof manner to me at my last interview in his office. I therefore felt it\r\nneedful, if I went at all, to go accompanied by a friend whom he would\r\nnot dare to treat with incivility, and whose presence with me might\r\nsecure exemption from insult. Accordingly I asked a neighbor to\r\naccompany me.\r\n\r\nTHE TRAP ALMOST DETECTED. Although I was not then aware of this fact, it\r\nwould seem that previous to my request this same neighbor had heard Dr.\r\nZabriskie state publicly in a saloon, that Mr. Winters had told him he\r\nhad decided either to kill or to horsewhip me, but had not finally\r\ndecided on which. My neighbor, therefore, felt unwilling to go down with\r\nme until he had first called on Mr. Winters alone. He therefore paid him\r\na visit. From that interview he assured me that he gathered the\r\nimpression that he did not believe I would have any difficulty with Mr.\r\nWinters, and that he (Winters) would call on me at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in my\r\nown office.\r\n\r\nMY OWN PRECAUTIONS. As Sheriff Cummings was in Gold Hill that afternoon,\r\nand as I desired to converse with him about the previous assault, I\r\ninvited him to my office, and he came. Although a half hour had passed\r\nbeyond four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Mr. Winters had not called, and we both of us began\r\npreparing to go home. Just then, Philip Lynch, Publisher of the Gold\r\nHill News, came in and said, blandly and cheerily, as if bringing good\r\nnews:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello, John B. Winters wants to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI replied, \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! Why he sent me word that he would call on me here\r\nthis afternoon at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well, it don\xe2\x80\x99t do to be too ceremonious just now, he\xe2\x80\x99s in my office,\r\nand that will do as well\xe2\x80\x94come on in, Winters wants to consult with you\r\nalone. He\xe2\x80\x99s got something to say to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough slightly uneasy at this change of programme, yet believing that\r\nin an editor\xe2\x80\x99s house I ought to be safe, and anyhow that I would be\r\nwithin hail of the street, I hurriedly, and but partially whispered my\r\ndim apprehensions to Mr. Cummings, and asked him if he would not keep\r\nnear enough to hear my voice in case I should call. He consented to do\r\nso while waiting for some other parties, and to come in if he heard my\r\nvoice or thought I had need of protection.\r\n\r\nOn reaching the editorial part of the News office, which viewed from the\r\nstreet is dark, I did not see Mr. Winters, and again my misgivings\r\narose. Had I paused long enough to consider the case, I should have\r\ninvited Sheriff Cummings in, but as Lynch went down stairs, he said:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis way, Wiegand\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s best to be private,\xe2\x80\x9d or some such remark.\r\n\r\n[I do not desire to strain the reader\xe2\x80\x99s fancy, hurtfully, and yet it\r\nwould be a favor to me if he would try to fancy this lamb in battle, or\r\nthe duelling ground or at the head of a vigilance committee\xe2\x80\x94M. T.:]\r\n\r\nI followed, and without Mr. Cummings, and without arms, which I never do\r\nor will carry, unless as a soldier in war, or unless I should yet come\r\nto feel I must fight a duel, or to join and aid in the ranks of a\r\nnecessary Vigilance Committee. But by following I made a fatal mistake.\r\nFollowing was entering a trap, and whatever animal suffers itself to be\r\ncaught should expect the common fate of a caged rat, as I fear events to\r\ncome will prove.\r\n\r\nTraps commonly are not set for benevolence. [His body-guard is shut\r\nout:]\r\n\r\nTHE TRAP INSIDE. I followed Lynch down stairs. At their foot a door to\r\nthe left opened into a small room. From that room another door opened\r\ninto yet another room, and once entered I found myself inveigled into\r\nwhat many will ever henceforth regard as a private subterranean Gold\r\nHill den, admirably adapted in proper hands to the purposes of murder,\r\nraw or disguised, for from it, with both or even one door closed, when\r\ntoo late, I saw that I could not be heard by Sheriff Cummings, and from\r\nit, BY VIOLENCE AND BY FORCE, I was prevented from making a peaceable\r\nexit, when I thought I saw the studious object of this \xe2\x80\x9cconsultation\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwas no other than to compass my killing, in the presence of Philip Lynch\r\nas a witness, as soon as by insult a proverbially excitable man should\r\nbe exasperated to the point of assailing Mr. Winters, so that Mr. Lynch,\r\nby his conscience and by his well known tenderness of heart toward the\r\nrich and potent would be compelled to testify that he saw Gen. John B.\r\nWinters kill Conrad Wiegand in \xe2\x80\x9cself-defence.\xe2\x80\x9d But I am going too fast.\r\n\r\nOUR HOST. Mr. Lynch was present during the most of the time (say a\r\nlittle short of an hour), but three times he left the room. His\r\ntestimony, therefore, would be available only as to the bulk of what\r\ntranspired. On entering this carpeted den I was invited to a seat near\r\none corner of the room. Mr. Lynch took a seat near the window. J. B.\r\nWinters sat (at first) near the door, and began his remarks essentially\r\nas follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come here to exact of you a retraction, in black and white, of\r\nthose damnably false charges which you have preferred against me in\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94infamous lying sheet of yours, and you must declare yourself\r\ntheir author, that you published them knowing them to be false, and that\r\nyour motives were malicious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, Mr. Winters. Your language is insulting and your demand an\r\nenormity. I trust I was not invited here either to be insulted or\r\ncoerced. I supposed myself here by invitation of Mr. Lynch, at your\r\nrequest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor did I come here to insult you. I have already told you that I am\r\nhere for a very different purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet your language has been offensive, and even now shows strong\r\nexcitement. If insult is repeated I shall either leave the room or call\r\nin Sheriff Cummings, whom I just left standing and waiting for me\r\noutside the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you won\xe2\x80\x99t, sir. You may just as well understand it at once as not.\r\nHere you are my man, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you why! Months ago you put your\r\nproperty out of your hands, boasting that you did so to escape losing it\r\non prosecution for libel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true that I did convert all my immovable property into personal\r\nproperty, such as I could trust safely to others, and chiefly to escape\r\nruin through possible libel suits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, sir. Having placed yourself beyond the pale of the law, may\r\nGod help your soul if you DON\xe2\x80\x99T make precisely such a retraction as I\r\nhave demanded. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got you now, and by\xe2\x80\x94before you can get out of this\r\nroom you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to both write and sign precisely the retraction I have\r\ndemanded, and before you go, anyhow\xe2\x80\x94you \xe2\x80\x94 low-lived \xe2\x80\x94 lying \xe2\x80\x94, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nteach you what personal responsibility is outside of the law; and, by\xe2\x80\x94,\r\nSheriff Cummings and all the friends you\xe2\x80\x99ve got in the world besides,\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t save you, you\xe2\x80\x94-, etc.! _No_, sir. I\xe2\x80\x99m alone now, and I\xe2\x80\x99m prepared\r\nto be shot down just here and now rather than be villified by you as I\r\nhave been, and suffer you to escape me after publishing those charges,\r\nnot only here where I am known and universally respected, but where I am\r\nnot personally known and may be injured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI confess this speech, with its terrible and but too plainly implied\r\nthreat of killing me if I did not sign the paper he demanded, terrified\r\nme, especially as I saw he was working himself up to the highest\r\npossible pitch of passion, and instinct told me that any reply other\r\nthan one of seeming concession to his demands would only be fuel to a\r\nraging fire, so I replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to sign\xe2\x80\x94,\xe2\x80\x9d and then I paused some time. Resuming, I\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cBut, Mr. Winters, you are greatly excited. Besides, I see you are\r\nlaboring under a total misapprehension. It is your duty not to inflame\r\nbut to calm yourself. I am prepared to show you, if you will only point\r\nout the article that you allude to, that you regard as \xe2\x80\x98charges\xe2\x80\x99 what no\r\ncalm and logical mind has any right to regard as such. Show me the\r\ncharges, and I will try, at all events; and if it becomes plain that no\r\ncharges have been preferred, then plainly there can be nothing to\r\nretract, and no one could rightly urge you to demand a retraction. You\r\nshould beware of making so serious a mistake, for however honest a man\r\nmay be, every one is liable to misapprehend. Besides you assume that I\r\nam the author of some certain article which you have not pointed out. It\r\nis hasty to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then pointed to some numbered paragraphs in a TRIBUNE article, headed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the Matter with Yellow Jacket?\xe2\x80\x9d saying \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I refer to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo gain time for general reflection and resolution, I took up the paper\r\nand looked it over for awhile, he remaining silent, and as I hoped,\r\ncooling. I then resumed saying, \xe2\x80\x9cAs I supposed. I do not admit having\r\nwritten that article, nor have you any right to assume so important a\r\npoint, and then base important action upon your assumption. You might\r\ndeeply regret it afterwards. In my published Address to the People, I\r\nnotified the world that no information as to the authorship of any\r\narticle would be given without the consent of the writer. I therefore\r\ncannot honorably tell you who wrote that article, nor can you exact it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are not the author, then I do demand to know who is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must decline to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, by\xe2\x80\x94, I brand you as its author, and shall treat you accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPassing that point, the most important misapprehension which I notice\r\nis, that you regard them as \xe2\x80\x98charges\xe2\x80\x99 at all, when their context, both\r\nat their beginning and end, show they are not. These words introduce\r\nthem: \xe2\x80\x98Such an investigation [just before indicated], we think MIGHT\r\nresult in showing some of the following points.\xe2\x80\x99 Then follow eleven\r\nspecifications, and the succeeding paragraph shows that the suggested\r\ninvestigation \xe2\x80\x98might EXONERATE those who are generally believed guilty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nYou see, therefore, the context proves they are not preferred as\r\ncharges, and this you seem to have overlooked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile making those comments, Mr. Winters frequently interrupted me in\r\nsuch a way as to convince me that he was resolved not to consider\r\ncandidly the thoughts contained in my words. He insisted upon it that\r\nthey were charges, and \xe2\x80\x9cBy\xe2\x80\x94,\xe2\x80\x9d he would make me take them back as\r\ncharges, and he referred the question to Philip Lynch, to whom I then\r\nappealed as a literary man, as a logician, and as an editor, calling his\r\nattention especially to the introductory paragraph just before quoted.\r\nHe replied, \xe2\x80\x9cif they are not charges, they certainly are insinuations,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwhereupon Mr. Winters renewed his demands for retraction precisely such\r\nas he had before named, except that he would allow me to state who did\r\nwrite the article if I did not myself, and this time shaking his fist in\r\nmy face with more cursings and epithets.\r\n\r\nWhen he threatened me with his clenched fist, instinctively I tried to\r\nrise from my chair, but Winters then forcibly thrust me down, as he did\r\nevery other time (at least seven or eight), when under similar imminent\r\ndanger of bruising by his fist (or for aught I could know worse than\r\nthat after the first stunning blow), which he could easily and safely to\r\nhimself have dealt me so long as he kept me down and stood over me.\r\n\r\nThis fact it was, which more than anything else, convinced me that by\r\nplan and plot I was purposely made powerless in Mr. Winters\xe2\x80\x99 hands, and\r\nthat he did not mean to allow me that advantage of being afoot, which he\r\npossessed. Moreover, I then became convinced, that Philip Lynch (and for\r\nwhat reason I wondered) would do absolutely nothing to protect me in his\r\nown house. I realized then the situation thoroughly. I had found it\r\nequally vain to protest or argue, and I would make no unmanly appeal for\r\npity, still less apologize. Yet my life had been by the plainest\r\npossible implication threatened. I was a weak man. I was unarmed. I was\r\nhelplessly down, and Winters was afoot and probably armed. Lynch was the\r\nonly \xe2\x80\x9cwitness.\xe2\x80\x9d The statements demanded, if given and not explained,\r\nwould utterly sink me in my own self-respect, in my family\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, and\r\nin the eyes of the community. On the other hand, should I give the\r\nauthor\xe2\x80\x99s name how could I ever expect that confidence of the People\r\nwhich I should no longer deserve, and how much dearer to me and to my\r\nfamily was my life than the life of the real author to his friends. Yet\r\nlife seemed dear and each minute that remained seemed precious if not\r\nsolemn. I sincerely trust that neither you nor any of your readers, and\r\nespecially none with families, may ever be placed in such seeming direct\r\nproximity to death while obliged to decide the one question I was\r\ncompelled to, viz.: What should I do\xe2\x80\x94I, a man of family, and not as Mr.\r\nWinters is, \xe2\x80\x9calone.\xe2\x80\x9d [The reader is requested not to skip the\r\nfollowing.\xe2\x80\x94M. T.:]\r\n\r\nSTRATEGY AND MESMERISM. To gain time for further reflection, and hoping\r\nthat by a seeming acquiescence I might regain my personal liberty, at\r\nleast till I could give an alarm, or take advantage of some momentary\r\ninadvertence of Winters, and then without a cowardly flight escape, I\r\nresolved to write a certain kind of retraction, but previously had\r\ninwardly decided:\r\n\r\nFirst.\xe2\x80\x94That I would studiously avoid every action which might be\r\nconstrued into the drawing of a weapon, even by a self-infuriated man,\r\nno matter what amount of insult might be heaped upon me, for it seemed\r\nto me that this great excess of compound profanity, foulness and epithet\r\nmust be more than a mere indulgence, and therefore must have some\r\nobject. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nTherefore, as before without thought, I thereafter by intent kept my\r\nhands away from my pockets, and generally in sight and spread upon my\r\nknees.\r\n\r\nSecond.\xe2\x80\x94I resolved to make no motion with my arms or hands which could\r\npossibly be construed into aggression.\r\n\r\nThird.\xe2\x80\x94I resolved completely to govern my outward manner and suppress\r\nindignation. To do this, I must govern my spirit. To do that, by force\r\nof imagination I was obliged like actors on the boards to resolve myself\r\ninto an unnatural mental state and see all things through the eyes of an\r\nassumed character.\r\n\r\nFourth.\xe2\x80\x94I resolved to try on Winters, silently, and unconsciously to\r\nhimself a mesmeric power which I possess over certain kinds of people,\r\nand which at times I have found to work even in the dark over the lower\r\nanimals.\r\n\r\nDoes any one smile at these last counts? God save you from ever being\r\nobliged to beat in a game of chess, whose stake is your life, you having\r\nbut four poor pawns and pieces and your adversary with his full force\r\nunshorn. But if you are, provided you have any strength with breadth of\r\nwill, do not despair. Though mesmeric power may not save you, it may\r\nhelp you; try it at all events. In this instance I was conscious of\r\npower coming into me, and by a law of nature, I know Winters was\r\ncorrespondingly weakened. If I could have gained more time I am sure he\r\nwould not even have struck me.\r\n\r\nIt takes time both to form such resolutions and to recite them. That\r\ntime, however, I gained while thinking of my retraction, which I first\r\nwrote in pencil, altering it from time to time till I got it to suit me,\r\nmy aim being to make it look like a concession to demands, while in fact\r\nit should tersely speak the truth into Mr. Winters\xe2\x80\x99 mind. When it was\r\nfinished, I copied it in ink, and if correctly copied from my first\r\ndraft it should read as follows. In copying I do not think I made any\r\nmaterial change.\r\n\r\nCOPY. To Philip Lynch, Editor of the Gold Hill News: I learn that Gen.\r\nJohn B. Winters believes the following (pasted on) clipping from the\r\nPEOPLE\xe2\x80\x99S TRIBUNE of January to contain distinct charges of mine against\r\nhim personally, and that as such he desires me to retract them\r\nunqualifiedly.\r\n\r\nIn compliance with his request, permit me to say that, although Mr.\r\nWinters and I see this matter differently, in view of his strong\r\nfeelings in the premises, I hereby declare that I do not know those\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccharges\xe2\x80\x9d (if such they are) to be true, and I hope that a critical\r\nexamination would altogether disprove them. CONRAD WIEGAND. Gold Hill,\r\nJanuary 15, 1870.\r\n\r\nI then read what I had written and handed it to Mr. Lynch, whereupon Mr.\r\nWinters said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not satisfactory, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t do;\xe2\x80\x9d and then addressing himself\r\nto Mr. Lynch, he further said: \xe2\x80\x9cHow does it strike you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I confess I don\xe2\x80\x99t see that it retracts anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor do I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Winters; \xe2\x80\x9cin fact, I regard it as adding insult to\r\ninjury. Mr. Wiegand you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do better than that. You are not the\r\nman who can pull wool over my eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, sir, is the only retraction I can write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo it isn\xe2\x80\x99t, sir, and if you so much as say so again you do it at your\r\nperil, for I\xe2\x80\x99ll thrash you to within an inch of your life, and, by\xe2\x80\x94,\r\nsir, I don\xe2\x80\x99t pledge myself to spare you even that inch either. I want\r\nyou to understand I have asked you for a very different paper, and that\r\npaper you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to sign.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Winters, I assure you that I do not wish to irritate you, but, at\r\nthe same time, it is utterly impossible for me to write any other paper\r\nthan that which I have written. If you are resolved to compel me to sign\r\nsomething, Philip Lynch\xe2\x80\x99s hand must write at your dictation, and if,\r\nwhen written, I can sign it I will do so, but such a document as you say\r\nyou must have from me, I never can sign. I mean what I say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, what\xe2\x80\x99s to be done must be done quickly, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve been here\r\nlong enough already. I\xe2\x80\x99ll put the thing in another shape (and then\r\npointing to the paper); don\xe2\x80\x99t you know those charges to be false?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know them to be true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf my own personal knowledge I do not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy then did you print them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause rightly considered in their connection they are not charges,\r\nbut pertinent and useful suggestions in answer to the queries of a\r\ncorrespondent who stated facts which are inexplicable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know that I know they are false?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you do, the proper course is simply to deny them and court an\r\ninvestigation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do YOU claim the right to make ME come out and deny anything you\r\nmay choose to write and print?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo that question I think I made no reply, and he then further said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, we\xe2\x80\x99ve talked about the matter long enough. I want your final\r\nanswer\xe2\x80\x94did you write that article or not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot in honor tell you who wrote it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you not see it before it was printed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost certainly, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you deem it a fit thing to publish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost assuredly, sir, or I would never have consented to its appearance.\r\nOf its authorship I can say nothing whatever, but for its publication I\r\nassume full, sole and personal responsibility.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you then retract it or not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Winters, if my refusal to sign such a paper as you have demanded\r\nmust entail upon me all that your language in this room fairly implies,\r\nthen I ask a few minutes for prayer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrayer!\xe2\x80\x94-you, this is not your hour for prayer\xe2\x80\x94your time to pray was\r\nwhen you were writing those\xe2\x80\x94lying charges. Will you sign or not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou already have my answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! do you still refuse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake that, then,\xe2\x80\x9d and to my amazement and inexpressible relief he drew\r\nonly a rawhide instead of what I expected\xe2\x80\x94a bludgeon or pistol. With it,\r\nas he spoke, he struck at my left ear downwards, as if to tear it off,\r\nand afterwards on the side of the head. As he moved away to get a better\r\nchance for a more effective shot, for the first time I gained a chance\r\nunder peril to rise, and I did so pitying him from the very bottom of my\r\nsoul, to think that one so naturally capable of true dignity, power and\r\nnobility could, by the temptations of this State, and by unfortunate\r\nassociations and aspirations, be so deeply debased as to find in such\r\nbrutality anything which he could call satisfaction\xe2\x80\x94but the great hope\r\nfor us all is in progress and growth, and John B. Winters, I trust, will\r\nyet be able to comprehend my feelings.\r\n\r\nHe continued to beat me with all his great force, until absolutely\r\nweary, exhausted and panting for breath. I still adhered to my purpose\r\nof non-aggressive defence, and made no other use of my arms than to\r\ndefend my head and face from further disfigurement. The mere pain\r\narising from the blows he inflicted upon my person was of course\r\ntransient, and my clothing to some extent deadened its severity, as it\r\nnow hides all remaining traces.\r\n\r\nWhen I supposed he was through, taking the butt end of his weapon and\r\nshaking it in my face, he warned me, if I correctly understood him, of\r\nmore yet to come, and furthermore said, if ever I again dared introduce\r\nhis name to print, in either my own or any other public journal, he\r\nwould cut off my left ear (and I do not think he was jesting) and send\r\nme home to my family a visibly mutilated man, to be a standing warning\r\nto all low-lived puppies who seek to blackmail gentlemen and to injure\r\ntheir good names. And when he did so operate, he informed me that his\r\nimplement would not be a whip but a knife.\r\n\r\nWhen he had said this, unaccompanied by Mr. Lynch, as I remember it, he\r\nleft the room, for I sat down by Mr. Lynch, exclaiming: \xe2\x80\x9cThe man is\r\nmad\xe2\x80\x94he is utterly mad\xe2\x80\x94this step is his ruin\xe2\x80\x94it is a mistake\xe2\x80\x94it would be\r\nungenerous in me, despite of all the ill usage I have here received, to\r\nexpose him, at least until he has had an opportunity to reflect upon the\r\nmatter. I shall be in no haste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWinters is very mad just now,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Lynch, \xe2\x80\x9cbut when he is\r\nhimself he is one of the finest men I ever met. In fact, he told me the\r\nreason he did not meet you upstairs was to spare you the humiliation of\r\na beating in the sight of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI submit that that unguarded remark of Philip Lynch convicts him of\r\nhaving been privy in advance to Mr. Winters\xe2\x80\x99 intentions whatever they\r\nmay have been, or at least to his meaning to make an assault upon me,\r\nbut I leave to others to determine how much censure an editor deserves\r\nfor inveigling a weak, non-combatant man, also a publisher, to a pen of\r\nhis own to be horsewhipped, if no worse, for the simple printing of what\r\nis verbally in the mouth of nine out of ten men, and women too, upon the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\nWhile writing this account two theories have occurred to me as possibly\r\ntrue respecting this most remarkable assault: First\xe2\x80\x94The aim may have\r\nbeen simply to extort from me such admissions as in the hands of money\r\nand influence would have sent me to the Penitentiary for libel. This,\r\nhowever, seems unlikely, because any statements elicited by fear or\r\nforce could not be evidence in law or could be so explained as to have\r\nno force. The statements wanted so badly must have been desired for some\r\nother purpose. Second\xe2\x80\x94The other theory has so dark and wilfully\r\nmurderous a look that I shrink from writing it, yet as in all\r\nprobability my death at the earliest practicable moment has already been\r\ndecreed, I feel I should do all I can before my hour arrives, at least\r\nto show others how to break up that aristocratic rule and combination\r\nwhich has robbed all Nevada of true freedom, if not of manhood itself.\r\nAlthough I do not prefer this hypothesis as a \xe2\x80\x9ccharge,\xe2\x80\x9d I feel that as\r\nan American citizen I still have a right both to think and to speak my\r\nthoughts even in the land of Sharon and Winters, and as much so\r\nrespecting the theory of a brutal assault (especially when I have been\r\nits subject) as respecting any other apparent enormity. I give the\r\nmatter simply as a suggestion which may explain to the proper\r\nauthorities and to the people whom they should represent, a well\r\nascertained but notwithstanding a darkly mysterious fact. The scheme of\r\nthe assault may have been:\r\n\r\nFirst\xe2\x80\x94To terrify me by making me conscious of my own helplessness after\r\nmaking actual though not legal threats against my life.\r\n\r\nSecond\xe2\x80\x94To imply that I could save my life only by writing or signing\r\ncertain specific statements which if not subsequently explained would\r\neternally have branded me as infamous and would have consigned my family\r\nto shame and want, and to the dreadful compassion and patronage of the\r\nrich.\r\n\r\nThird\xe2\x80\x94To blow my brains out the moment I had signed, thereby preventing\r\nme from making any subsequent explanation such as could remove the\r\ninfamy.\r\n\r\nFourth\xe2\x80\x94Philip Lynch to be compelled to testify that I was killed by John\r\nB. Winters in self-defence, for the conviction of Winters would bring\r\nhim in as an accomplice. If that was the programme in John B. Winters\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmind nothing saved my life but my persistent refusal to sign, when that\r\nrefusal seemed clearly to me to be the choice of death.\r\n\r\nThe remarkable assertion made to me by Mr. Winters, that pity only\r\nspared my life on Wednesday evening last, almost compels me to believe\r\nthat at first he could not have intended me to leave that room alive;\r\nand why I was allowed to, unless through mesmeric or some other\r\ninvisible influence, I cannot divine. The more I reflect upon this\r\nmatter, the more probable as true does this horrible interpretation\r\nbecome.\r\n\r\nThe narration of these things I might have spared both to Mr. Winters\r\nand to the public had he himself observed silence, but as he has both\r\nverbally spoken and suffered a thoroughly garbled statement of facts to\r\nappear in the Gold Hill News I feel it due to myself no less than to\r\nthis community, and to the entire independent press of America and Great\r\nBritain, to give a true account of what even the Gold Hill News has\r\npronounced a disgraceful affair, and which it deeply regrets because of\r\nsome alleged telegraphic mistake in the account of it. [Who received the\r\nerroneous telegrams?]\r\n\r\nThough he may not deem it prudent to take my life just now, the\r\npublication of this article I feel sure must compel Gen. Winters (with\r\nhis peculiar views about his right to exemption from criticism by me) to\r\nresolve on my violent death, though it may take years to compass it.\r\nNotwithstanding I bear him no ill will; and if W. C. Ralston and William\r\nSharon, and other members of the San Francisco mining and milling Ring\r\nfeel that he above all other men in this State and California is the\r\nmost fitting man to supervise and control Yellow Jacket matters, until I\r\nam able to vote more than half their stock I presume he will be retained\r\nto grace his present post.\r\n\r\nMeantime, I cordially invite all who know of any sort of important\r\nvillainy which only can be cured by exposure (and who would expose it if\r\nthey felt sure they would not be betrayed under bullying threats), to\r\ncommunicate with the PEOPLE\xe2\x80\x99S TRIBUNE; for until I am murdered, so long\r\nas I can raise the means to publish, I propose to continue my efforts at\r\nleast to revive the liberties of the State, to curb oppression, and to\r\nbenefit man\xe2\x80\x99s world and God\xe2\x80\x99s earth.\r\n\r\nCONRAD WIEGAND.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n[It does seem a pity that the Sheriff was shut out, since the good sense\r\nof a general of militia and of a prominent editor failed to teach them\r\nthat the merited castigation of this weak, half-witted child was a thing\r\nthat ought to have been done in the street, where the poor thing could\r\nhave a chance to run. When a journalist maligns a citizen, or attacks\r\nhis good name on hearsay evidence, he deserves to be thrashed for it,\r\neven if he is a \xe2\x80\x9cnon-combatant\xe2\x80\x9d weakling; but a generous adversary would\r\nat least allow such a lamb the use of his legs at such a time.\xe2\x80\x94M. T.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK ROUGHING IT ***\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the\r\nUnited States without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
